htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting for Business Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the operating activities of businesses and the roles that accounting information plays in planning, evaluating, and recording those activities. An introduction to financial statements is included.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100 and GENBA 110 or sophomore standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting for Investing and Financing
htmlparse.Course.description: Extends the concepts of planning and evaluation to the business activities of acquiring, disposing, and financing productive assets. Financial statement analysis will be covered.

htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting Processes and Controls
htmlparse.Course.description: The accounting information system will be shown as a means of insuring the accuracy of information and safeguarding assets. Students will interpret documents and record many transactions that typically occur in business, governmental units, and not-for-profit entities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture and voluntary one hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Taxation I
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental concepts of income determination in federal and state income tax regulations; examination of the impact of tax regulation on business and personal financial planning and decision making.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ACCTG 331, or ACCTG 241 and senior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Accounting
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for the problems undertaken in accounting and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Managerial Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: Identifying relevant accounting data and organizing, summarizing, and analyzing that data into information useful for planning and budgeting, decision making, controlling, and evaluating functions of management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the U.S. and international rules and regulations that govern current reporting to external entities by profit entities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting for Not-For-Profit Entities
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the source of authoritative guidance, rules and regulations that govern current reporting to external entities by not-for-profit entities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Auditing I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the environment of auditing and the objectives and techniques of both financial and operational auditing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ACCTG 433, For accounting majors only.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Statement Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will develop a student’s skills and knowledge in the analysis and interpretation of corporate financial statements and their related footnotes.  The class will encourage the student to think logically and creatively about the strengths and weaknesses of accounting information available to investors and shareholders.  The main course objective is for the student to be capable of doing an in-depth analysis of a company’s financial and operating performance from several financial statements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ACCTG 231 and ACCTG 241, and FINAN 450.

htmlparse.Course.title: Law for Accountants
htmlparse.Course.description: An intensive study of an accountant’s professional responsibilities to the public and the profession and the knowledge of the legal implications of business transactions, particularly as they relate to accounting and auditing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides a full semester of practical accounting experience prior to entering graduate accounting program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting Theory and History
htmlparse.Course.description: The theories which underlie the practice of accounting and financial reporting including a historical perspective on the evolution of the theories.

htmlparse.Course.title: Accounting Research and Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of the sources of authoritative guidance in resolving complex, professionally oriented problems that include auditing, financial reporting, and tax reporting. Students analyze numerous unstructured cases and present their conclusion with written reports and oral presentations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students may be enrolled concurrent in ACCTG 442. For accounting majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Financial Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the reporting requirements of large (often multinational) corporations, e.g., foreign currency translation, interim and segment reporting, and business combinations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerospace Studies Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: The leadership laboratory for aerospace studies. Students will receive leadership training and experience as well as training in Air Force customs and courtesies. This course runs concurrently with AERO 100, 200, 300, and 400 level classes; is required for all cadets; and includes mandatory physical fitness training.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerospace Studies 1A
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the mission and organization of the United States Air Force; United States general purpose and aerospace support forces.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerospace Studies 1B
htmlparse.Course.description: United States strategic offensive and defensive forces; their mission, function, and employment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerospace Studies 2A
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of air power from its beginnings to the end of World War II. It traces the development of various concepts of employment of air power.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerospace Studies 2B
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of air power from the close of World War II to the present. It focuses upon factors which have prompted research and technological change and stresses significant examples of the impact of air power on strategic thought.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: AFROTC Summer Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides AFROTC cadets up to 13 options for practical leadership and specialized training through exposure to USAF functions, deployments, and employment operations.  Foreign language and cultural immersions also available/possible but overall emphasis remains on leadership development and practicum.  All programs conducted off-site at selected Air Forces bases and other locations in the USA and abroad.

htmlparse.Course.title: Officer Leadership Studies 3A
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of USAF professionalism, leadership, and management includes the meaning of professionalism, professional responsibilities, leadership theory, functions and practices, management principles and functions, problem solving, and management tools, practices, and controls.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Officer Leadership Studies 3B
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of AERO 310.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Regional Studies and Defense Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will examine the role of the professional officer in a democratic society; socialization processes within the armed services; the requisites for maintaining adequate national security forces; political, economic, and social constraints upon the overall defense policy-making process.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerospace Studies/Civil Military Relationships
htmlparse.Course.description: Focusing on the armed forces as an integral element of society, this course provides an examination of the broad range of American civil-military relations and the environmental context in which defense policy is formulated. Communicative skills are stressed. The role of contemporary aerospace power, and current and future employment of aerospace forces will also be examined. The last portion of this course concentrates on preparation for active duty military service.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of class a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problem Solving in Aerospace Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Work offered in any of the AFROTC general or professional courses for students out of phase for graduation; material covered in a basic or advanced course.

htmlparse.Course.title: African Study Abroad
htmlparse.Course.description: The study abroad educational trip will provide students the opportunity to apply their knowledge of an African language and to learn first hand about various African societies and cultures, farming systems, environment, health and other issues related to their host country.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar I
htmlparse.Course.description: Economics of Poverty and Wealth Creation in Africa (social science component). Explores opportunities for breaking the cycle of poverty across the continent using strategic wealth creation techniques that overcome poverty. Focusing on the agriculture and food system, the environment and natural resources, and the health of the African people.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar II
htmlparse.Course.description: African Development. Introduction to current political and economic conditions facing Africa from historical, social, economic, political, and human context. Solutions to the current problems confronting the African continent are analyzed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Agricultural Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to agricultural communications programs, activities, careers, and trends.  Orientation to department, college, and university policies and services to enhance student success.  Required of all students beginning a major in agricultural communications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Layout and Design Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: This course uses leading industry-adopted software to develop printed communications pieces to the point of being “printer ready”, addressing design concepts and layout aspects critical to successfully printing a project.  Assignments will integrate software functionality and design concepts with print production technology requirements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lecture

htmlparse.Course.title: Communicating in the Agricultural Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to help students identify the influence of communication styles and theories on agricultural issues. Agricultural sales will provide the experiential component for application of communication theory and interpersonal interactions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Business Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Written communications as used in agricultural industries. A writing course emphasizing the tools and techniques of writing memos, letters, short and long reports, proposals, and presentations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 100 and sophomore standing or above.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone Seminar in Agricultural Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone experience and project for agricultural communications and journalism students. Includes analysis of trends and issues in the field and discussion of communications planning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Student Magazine
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, interviewing, and preparing stories, headlines, layouts, advertising, and editing, for the Kansas State Agriculturist published by students in the College of Agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Agricultural Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions of topics, studies, and activities important to agricultural communications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course may be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Research in Agricultural Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: This course uses qualitative, quantitative or mixed methods to conduct an agricultural and environmental communications research project. A faculty coordinator will assist students through the stages of conducting a research project and reporting its outcomes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Documentary Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of visual storytelling is combined with basic and intermediate video camera and non-linear editing instruction to produce TV documentaries, magazine-type stories, and personal videos for web and broadcast distribution.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 or MC 221 or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Agricultural Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: The intern works in a professional capacity in areas such as print journalism, electronic media, advertising, photography, and public relations. Student is supervised by a professional and a faculty member. One hour of credit for each four weeks of supervised work. Internship report and presentation required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: New Media Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the study and application of emerging “new media” technologies to effectively communicate information and market products and programs to general and targeted audiences.  Students will study underlying communication theories such as Roger’s Theory of Innovation Diffusion to provide a context of how society adopts and incorporates new technology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crisis Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is placed on the application of effective crisis communication practices and techniques.  Students will learn relevant interpersonal and organizational communication theory, assess/evaluate organizational risks, and develop a crisis communication plan.  Students will partner with a community business to create and deliver a comprehensive crisis plan.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 60 hours of college credit, or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Combines theoretical discussions with practical experience regarding communication about environmental issues and provides introduction to natural and applied science topics related to the communications plan.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to agricultural economics and agribusiness programs, activities, resources, and careers. Required of all freshmen in agricultural economics or agribusiness at K-State.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Meets first half of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Decision Tools for Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of foundational computer-based empirical skills that address economic and business issues in food and agriculture. Students will learn how to model information on an issue or problem using mathematical spreadsheets to find relevant answers for decision makers and stakeholders.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness
htmlparse.Course.description: A course suggested for all students interested in the agricultural economy. A study of economic principles, with emphasis on their application to the solution of farm, agribusiness, and agricultural industry problems in relationship to other sectors of the United States economy and foreign countries.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness
htmlparse.Course.description: A course suggested for all honors students interested in the agricultural economy. A study of economic principles, with emphasis on their application to the solution of farm, agribusiness, natural resource and agricultural industry problems in relationship to other sectors of the United States economy and foreign countries. The course will include extensive discussion, writing, and computer assignments on application of economic principles to real-world problems and issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admitted to university honors or college scholars program or instructor permission and eligible for honors program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Business Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Opportunities in business ownership, principles governing the starting of a small enterprise; importance, status, problems, and management of a small business.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain and Livestock Marketing Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the institutions and mechanisms that facilitate and regulate the sale and marketing of grain and livestock commodities. Topics include the physical and informational flows in the commodity supply chains, cash pricing, commodity grades to improve market efficiency and the governmental regulations and agencies influencing commodity trading.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Farm and Ranch Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Decision-making process, cost concepts, farm records and financial management, budgeting, time value of money, and introduction to whole farm/ranch planning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Global Food and Agricultural Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of contemporary economic issues affecting world agricultural systems including population growth, trade, globalization, natural resource and environmental policy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120, AGEC 121, ECON 110, or ECON 120.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food and Agribusiness Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of marketing, production, risk, human resource management, and financial management in agribusiness firms. Particular attention is given to the application of economic principles to the management of marketing and farm supply firms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120; and MATH 100.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: Institutional and analytical treatment of historical and current economic problems, public policies and government programs affecting agriculture and rural America.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120 or ECON 110.

htmlparse.Course.title: Commodity Futures
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the purpose, operation, and use of commodity futures and options markets. The objectives are to: (1) understand why futures exchanges and commodity futures contracts exist; (2) understand and be able to forecast basis; (3) understand hedging and be able to design hedging strategies for various commodity producers and users; (4) understand both put and call options and their potential use in a commodity risk management program; and (5) understand the usefulness and shortcomings of fundamental and technical analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminars of special interest will be offered upon sufficient demand in selected areas relating to agricultural economics and agribusiness or competitive teams qualifying for academic credit.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agribusiness Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Approved and supervised work-study programs in various areas of agribusiness.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Project reports required. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Problems
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Food and Agribusiness Study Tour
htmlparse.Course.description: An experiential learning course to prepare students for and to immerse them in an international study tour of selected food and agribusiness industries.  The topics vary by the tour and the industries studied.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Production Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of economic principles to problems of agricultural production. Analysis of consumer demand for agricultural products and input and output decisions of the agricultural firm. AGEC 505 is a continuation of this course and they are intended to be taken in consecutive semesters.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120 and MATH 205. Recommended prerequisite: AGEC 115.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Data Analysis and Optimization
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of agricultural business and economic data and optimization for decision making.  Study applications of regression, time series analysis and forecasting to agricultural and economic data. Introduction to mathematical programming to model optimization of problems commonly encountered in agricultural economics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 115 or AGEC 490, AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120, MATH 205, STAT 350.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Market Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of economic principles to marketing problems in agriculture. Pricing of agricultural output and productive services under various forms of economic organization and competition; regional specialization, location, and trade; determinants of economic change; evaluation of economic and consumer welfare.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120 and MATH 205 and AGEC 500. Recommended prerequisite: AGEC 115.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of capital investments, interpretation of financial statements, capital structure considerations for agricultural firms, and farm real estate pricing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 308 or AGEC 318 and ACCTG 231. Recommended prerequisite: AGEC 115.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food and Agribusiness Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: A broad view of marketing; food markets and consumption; marketing functions and institutions; prices, competition, and marketing costs; functional and organizational issues; food marketing regulations; commodity marketing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Law and Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: The legal framework for decision making by farm firms, families, and individuals; liabilities, real and personal property, contracts, uniform commercial code, organization of farm firms, intergeneration property transfers, water law, fence law, federal and state regulatory power, insurance, income tax, and social security.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120 and junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Market Fundamentals and Futures/Options Trading
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an experiential course in the trading of commodity futures and options. Attention is focused on the study of market price determination, the implications of market efficiency notions, and on actual trading of futures and options. Students invest in a commodity educational trading fund. Class approves recommendations by vote, orders are placed with a broker, and the class monitors open trades. The pool balance at the end of the semester is redistributed to students.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resource and Environmental Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on the application of demand, supply, and price concepts in the study of natural resource use, policies, and management. Interdependence between environmental quality and economic actions are examined through discussion of property rights, economic incentives, externalities, and economic components of environmental policies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120 or ECON 110 and junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminars of special interest will be offered upon sufficient demand in selected areas relating to agricultural economics and agribusiness.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Manufacturing, Distribution and Retailing
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the economic and business aspects of the food industry from processing to distribution to retailing. Emerging trends in nutrition, food consumption, food safety and supply chain arrangements along with management and marketing issues in the food industry will be studied.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Farm Management Strategies
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of management concepts, tools, and decision strategies applied to farm firms. Alternative measures of farm business performances, as well as planning and evaluation techniques for an uncertain environment, are examined.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 308 or AGEC 318, AGEC 500, and AGEC 513 or FINAN 450.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Food and Agribusiness Management Strategies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course integrates the risk, production, marketing, and financial management strategies of agribusiness firms. Special attention is given to the application of economic theory and quantitative analysis to business decision-making processes. In addition to case studies, a variety of analytical techniques will focus on both markets and firms involved in the production and marketing of food commodities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 318, AGEC 500, and either AGEC 513 or FINAN 450. Recommended prerequisite: AGEC 515.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Price Analysis and Forecasting
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis of selected agricultural prices; application of regression analysis to price analysis, the role of futures markets and market efficiency, optimal hedging strategies, commodity option pricing, and price forecasting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A course in statistics; AGEC 501; AGEC 505 or ECON 520.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Agriculture and Natural Resource Policy Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Current issues in agricultural and natural resource policy from divergent perspectives. Classroom discussion, debate, writing assignments, and student presentations. Current events are analyzed and synthesized from both economic and noneconomic perspectives. Topics may include environmental issues, international agricultural development, the politics of farm programs, and the relationship between technology, agriculture, and society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 505 and either AGEC 525 or AGEC 410.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Agricultural Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Current issues in global agricultural systems and international agricultural development from an economic perspective. Students will engage in microeconomic study of important contemporary issues affecting the global agricultural economy including technological change, policy, environmental stressors and global treatises.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Agricultural Trade
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied economics of agricultural trade. Emphasis on why trade occurs, current agricultural trade patterns, the effects of agricultural policy on trade, and the institutions of trade.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Agribusiness Logistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning for efficient use of transportation, storage and processing facilities in the handling of raw materials and products for agribusiness firms, controlling shipments and inventory in coordination with warehouse and handling operations, and scientific selection of routes, schedules, and equipment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120, and junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminars of special interest will be offered upon sufficient demand in selected areas relating to agricultural economics and agribusinesses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Risk Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytical concepts and quantitative tools to make better decisions in risky situations. Identifying various types of risk an operation faces, measuring the degree of risk, and exploring ways to manage risk. Includes portfolio analysis, futures and options, contracting, and insurance. Emphasis on computer applications. Topics are focused on agriculture but are applicable to other industries and household decisions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 420, AGEC 513 or FINAN 450, and a course in statistics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Food and Agriculture Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a comparative analysis of the business and economic situation of the food and agriculture sector around the world. The course will cover the European Union, the Former Soviet Union, MERCORSUR, and Southeast Asia, Oceania and possibly other regions. The course will focus briefly on the historical development, the current situation, and the future outlook of the food and agriculture sector. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to evaluate the comparative advantage of the United States in the production of food and fiber.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 120 or AGEC 121 or ECON 120.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Optimization Techniques for Agricultural Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of optimization techniques including linear programming and nonlinear programming for research and decision analysis in agricultural economics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGEC 500 and AGEC 501, or graduate standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Agricultural Economics Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on methods of economic analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness Problems
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Provide students with the theory, knowledge and skills necessary for the construction/fabrication of metal projects. Emphasis will be placed on: laboratory safety, general laboratory measurements, metal identification/ characteristics, oxyacetylene welding and cutting, shielded metal arc welding (SMAW), gas metal arc welding (GMAW), gas tungsten arc welding (GTAW), plasma cutting, and project construction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Provide students with the theory, knowledge and skills necessary for the construction/fabrication agricultural structure type projects. Emphasis will be placed on: laboratory safety, general laboratory measurements, material selection, basic construction techniques, electrical theory and operation, plumbing theory and operation, concrete theory and construction, and basic surveying.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Power
htmlparse.Course.description: Provide students with the theory, knowledge and skills necessary for the repair and maintenance of small gas engines and basic hydraulic systems. Emphasis will be placed on: laboratory safety, general laboratory measurements, engine operation, compression, fuel, governor, electrical, cooling, lubrication systems, engine troubleshooting and basic hydraulics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the program responsibilities, methodology, organization, current trends and issues, and future direction of programs in agricultural education. Students will be actively involved in the discussion and application of course material both in the classroom and in early field experiences conducted as a part of this course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership and Professional Development in Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an introduction to the leadership skills needed in the role of FFA advisor and professional agricultural educator including career, professional, and student leadership development and FFA chapter management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Teaching Agriculture in the Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to content area instruction in the secondary and middle schools; motivation; organization of subject matter; lesson planning; evaluation and reporting; challenging the levels of ability; organization and management of the classroom; methodology and materials of the secondary schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, 477, AGED 520, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Adult Classes in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Organization and preparation of materials and methods used in teaching adult classes in vocational education in agriculture for young farmers and adults. Departments are visited for evaluation of programs and results.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Experience in Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A course for prospective teachers to help bridge the gap between classroom theory and student teaching. Emphasis will be on observation of and participation in school and community organizations and programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Block II Lab: Content Area Methods and Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of specific content area with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, 477, AGED 500 and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory and Safety Techniques in Teaching Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to design, organize, and conduct programs in agricultural laboratory instruction in secondary agricultural education programs. Students will gain experiences in the development of laboratory lesson plans, safety and technical demonstrations, student management in a laboratory setting, laboratory design, and laboratory curriculum development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Planning in Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: The program development and planning process; development of guides for teaching and evaluating reimbursable secondary programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Extension Organization and Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and objectives of Cooperative Extension and other university adult education programs; with emphasis on programs and procedures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organization Problems in Teaching Agricultural Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the agricultural mechanics course of study; needs and interests of students; learning difficulties; skills and technical knowledge required; correlation with agriculture; application of laws of learning to the teaching process; determination of objectives.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Teaching Adults in Extension
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods and principles of adult teaching with emphasis on Cooperative Extension Service; application to various adult education programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Agriculture-Related Occupations
htmlparse.Course.description: Related occupational or professional experiences in approved industry, school, Cooperative Extension Service, or similar agency setting under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Extension Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Related occupational or professional experiences in approved industry, school, Cooperative Extension Service, or similar agency setting under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current topics in agricultural education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Varied specialized topics will be offered so course may be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crop Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles underlying practices used in the culture of grain and forage crops. Crop classification, structure, growth, and improvement. Crop response to environmental factors, soils, and pests and associated management practices. Laboratories will cover crop botany, crop development, and problem solving. A basic course for majors in agronomy and others interested in crop production.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Not open to students with credit in HORT 201.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soils
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental chemical, physical, and biological properties of soils; their formation, fertility, and management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seed Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course to prepare students for the anticipated expansion of the seed industry resulting from the impact of biotechnology and identity preservation. Basic concepts of seed quality, purity, vigor testing, and quality assurance will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Weed Science
htmlparse.Course.description: For those interested in crop production, crop protection, and agricultural education. Considers the origin of weeds, their relations to crops, and control systems emphasizing cultural, mechanical, biological, and chemical practices. Includes weed identification.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Quality
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination and survey of topics in environmental quality. Includes classification of soil, air, and water pollutants and their interaction with the environment, including the human food chain. Discussion of remediation techniques, risk assessment, and environmental legislation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three lectures a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain Grading
htmlparse.Course.description: Procedures for grading grains, emphasizing soybeans, corn, wheat, and sorghum. Identification and evaluation of kernel damage and other conditions determining grades of these grains.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant and Seed Identification
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification of crops and weeds by seed and vegetative characteristics. Analysis of seed samples for impurities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crop Growth and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative growth and development of warm- and cool-season monocot and dicot crops. Environmental influences on growth and development processes and management techniques to minimize stresses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 110 or 210. Recommended prerequisite: AGRON 220 and 305.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Fertility
htmlparse.Course.description: Detailed information on the plant nutrition, soil fertility, and fertilizer management of the essential macro- and micronutrients. The influence of numerous soil biological, physical, and chemical properties on plant nutrient availability to crops will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Fertility Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Detailed information on (1) the chemical methods utilized in routine soil testing and plant analysis, (2) field soil sampling techniques, (3) fertilizer recommendations, and (4) fertilizer response functions. Soil chemistry and computer laboratory exercises are designed to reinforce the theoretical principles presented in lectures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Topics in Agronomy
htmlparse.Course.description: Special topics in agronomy not completely treated in other courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Agronomy
htmlparse.Course.description: Intern programs in various areas of agronomy. One hour credit for each four weeks of supervised and evaluated work experience with cooperating employers. A maximum of 3 hours may be applied to the major in agronomy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once if second internship is different from the first.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soils Judging
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques employed in writing descriptions of soil morphology and in classifying soils for intercollegiate soils judging.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week for the first half of the semester. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Course in Weed Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory and field course pertaining to weed identification, sprayer calibration, herbicide action, and herbicide performance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crops Team
htmlparse.Course.description: Grain grading, seed and plant identification, and seed analysis. Studies lead to participation in intercollegiate crops contest.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Range Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental ecological principles of production, conservation, and use of grasslands. Application of these fundamental principles to management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Emerging Topics in Agronomy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide a platform for in-depth discussion of emerging topics in the agronomic field. Topics that have immediate relevance in crop production, plant breeding, range science, soil fertility, soil management, and soil and water quality are discussed. Experts in fields outside of agronomy will often be guest facilitators in this course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: Junior or senior status.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Genesis and Classification
htmlparse.Course.description: Factors and processes of soil formation, classification of soils according to soil taxonomy, and use of soil survey information. Practical field experience describing soil properties. Required field trips.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forage Management and Utilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Production and utilization of forage crops. Development of forage programs for livestock production, including pasture and stored forages.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: AGRON 220 and junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forage Management and Utilization Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification of forage species, techniques for estimating forage quality, forage physiology, and field trips.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of or concurrent enrollment in AGRON 550.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One two-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Identification of Range and Pasture Plants
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification of range pasture plants through exposure to them in their natural environment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Research in Agronomy
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent research experience guided by faculty in crop science, weed science, range science, or soil science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agronomy-The Profession
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of opportunities, responsibilities, and challenges for the professional agronomist. Discussion of current topics and important issues in crops and soils, range management, and soil and water resources.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crop Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies may be chosen in: genetics, crop improvement, forages, ecology, weed control, plant physiology, or crop production.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agronomy Capstone Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: A culminating learning experience to apply the knowledge gained by the student in the undergraduate curriculum, to apply the skills of problem-solving and critical thinking, and to develop the ability to work in teams and participate in civil discourses. Current issues in Agronomy will be discussed and a team project will be completed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of seminar a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil and Environmental Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of inorganic and organic chemistry of soils with a detailed examination of the solid, liquid, and gaseous phases. Includes discussions of mineral solubility, electrochemical and adsorption phenomena, acidity, salinity, and fertility. Emphasis is placed on the biogeochemical cycling of plant nutrients and important soil contaminants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: AGRON 375 or 305 and CHM 230.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Remote Sensing of the Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Remote sensing and its application to earth study, especially environmental problems and land use. Course employs both readings and the use of imagery.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in physical science and one in biological science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, two hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: The use of biotechnology and molecular genetic approaches in plant and animal sciences. Emphasis is on the use of molecular techniques for plant and animal improvement.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies may be chosen in: chemistry, physics, conservation, fertility, genesis, morphology, or classification.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applications of Nutrient Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles for developing plant nutrient management programs in the Great Plains. Topics include assessing crop nutrient needs, making fertilizer recommendations, applying application technology and products to enhance nutrient use efficiency, using sensing technology to assess in-season nutrient needs, quality control functions, and the use of waste products as nutrient sources.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crop Improvement and Biotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques in basic plant breeding and biotechnology used to genetically improve crops and procedures to increase, distribute, and maintain breeding stocks and varieties.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one two-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Conservation and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, mechanics, and prediction of water and wind erosion. Influence of soil erosion on soil productivity and environmental quality. Conservation management technologies for erosion control and sustaining soil productivity. Legislation and land-use planning for soil conservation. Course requires microcomputer skills.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and 1 three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cropping Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles for developing and managing cropping systems in the Great Plains for the efficient use of natural resources, primarily water. Emphasis on dryland cropping systems, management of crop rotations, and the plant/soil/environment interaction. Includes the efficient use of natural resources via an understanding of yield limiting factors, impact of crop rotations and cultural practices, climate, plant growth, and development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioenergy Feedstock Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of production and characteristics of cultivated crops, perennial grasses, and woody species as feedstocks for bioenergy. Fundamentals of plant growth factors, culture, harvest and storage, quality and improvement, and introduction to environmental impact, modeling, and resource utilization. Knowledge of Microsoft-compatible word processing and spreadsheet programs including graphing is required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature and function of soil microorganisms in the soil ecosystem. The role of soil microbial activity to soil organic matter, mineral transformations, plant nutrition, and environmental quality.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Microbiology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Discuss and perform laboratory procedures for enumerating soil microorganisms, quantifying soil biological activities, and nutrient cycling.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integrated Weed Management
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of weed management systems based on diagnosis of weed and crop problems, understanding crop-weed associations and interactions with the environment, and integrating weed control tactics such as chemical, biological, cultural, and mechanical practices into recommendations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Specific Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to spatial analysis and management of agricultural and environmental resources using Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology. Emphasis on collecting, displaying, and analyzing spatial or georeferenced soil, crop, or other land surface data.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: AGRON 220 and 305 and GEOG 508.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, two hours lab, and one hour by appointment per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grassland Monitoring and Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Vegetation sampling techniques used in rangeland research and for grassland monitoring and assessment. Use of statistics for sampling, analysis, and presentation of data.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grassland Monitoring and Assessment Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: A field laboratory course designed as a companion to AGRON 660. Labs will consist of methods used for determination of biomass, basal cover, frequency, and density. Additional time will be spent on basic statistics, experimental design, and use of the microcomputer in analyzing data sets.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Meets during the first half of the semester.
One hour recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rangeland Watershed Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the management of physical/biological settings and processes along with human activities on water and watersheds considering preventative and restorative strategies in a natural resource rangeland setting. Web-based distance AG*IDEA course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Range Management Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Range Management Problems
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Range Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of ecological principles to range ecosystem management. Study of plant-soil-animal interactions with rangelands, and discussion of plant succession, environmental influences, and ecological concepts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week and one lab credit consisting of field trips to representative range areas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grassland Fire Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to describe the ecological effects of fire on grassland ecosystems. It also provides insight into the history of fires, the people who use them and why, the parts of a afire, how fires behave in relation to fuel and weather, and the conducting and safety of prescribed burns. Web-based distance AG*IDEA course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tropical Soil Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Characteristics of agriculture in tropical conditions with a focus on the environment and soils. Includes discussion of soil management systems in tropical agriculture that use conventional methods as well as methods that emphasize sustainability including no-till, crop rotation, and cover crops.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Climate Change and Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Impact of climate and climate change on agricultural systems and soil and water resources at global and regional scales. Discussion on adaptation and mitigation strategies including economics and policies that affect agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Plant Resistance to Pests
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of the biology, ecology, genetics and breeding for pest resistance in plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENTOM 300 or PLPTH 500 or ENTOM 312 and ENTOM 313, and one course in plant or animal genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture and discussion a week. To meet the first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Properties of Soils
htmlparse.Course.description: The properties of soils as affected by their physical environment, including water content, water potential, temperature, aeration, flocculation-dispersion, and soil compaction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Range Grasses
htmlparse.Course.description: Field and laboratory study of range and pasture plants, with special emphasis on grasses and their distinguishing characteristics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts and application of basic genetic principles in higher plants. Probability, linkage, chromosome aberrations, aneuploidy analysis, gene transfer in wide crosses, tissue culture and crop improvement, and genetics of disease resistance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ASI 500. Recommended prerequisite: AGRON 610 and 630
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecology of Invasive Species
htmlparse.Course.description: Ecological principles and their application to invasive species. Discussion of population, community and ecosystem level characteristics affecting a wide variety of invasive plant and animal species. Discussions will include current global consequences and governmental policies/programs designed to limit the spread of invasives. Web-based distance AG*IDEA course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Range Management Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Inventory and analysis of rangeland resources and development of detailed management plan. Emphasizes range management principles and practices useful in maximizing production from rangelands.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week and one lab credit including field trips to ranch operations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces students to the major concepts related to ethnicity and to some of the major American ethnic groups.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to American Ethnic Studies-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces students to the major concepts related to ethnicity and to some of the major American ethnic groups.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Ethnic Studies I
htmlparse.Course.description: A comparative introduction to the social, historical, political and economic issues impacting race and ethnic relations.  An analysis of how race and ethnicity intersect with gender, sexuality, social class, and how systems of power and inequality are constructed, reinforced, and challenged.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Ethnic Studies II
htmlparse.Course.description: A comparative introduction to cultural forms including literature, music, theater, folklore, media arts, and oral history from a variety of U.S. ethnic groups.  An analysis of how race and ethnicity intersect with gender, sexuality, and social class, and how systems of power and inequality are constructed reinforced, and challenged.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: African American Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of African American experience in the context of U.S. society and institutions.  The analysis will consider the interrelationships between and among various African American groups and “mainstream” America, and their corresponding nationalities and regions of origin.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Indian Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of American Indian experience in the context of U.S. society and institutions.  The analysis will consider the interrelationships between and among various American Indians and “mainstream” America, American Indian nations and/or tribes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Latino/a Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of U.S. Latino/a experience in the context of American society and institutions.  The analysis will consider the interrelationships between and among various Latino/a groups, “mainstream” America, and their corresponding nationalities and regions of origins.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Asian American Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of Asian American experience in the context of U.S. society and institutions.  The analysis will consider the interrelationships between and among various Asian American groups, “mainstream” America, and their corresponding nationalities and regions of origin.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Reading and Research in American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Guided reading and research on a specific topic of student interest, leading to preparation of a research paper or creative work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AMETH 160, at least one other American ethnic studies course and permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Topic and credit to be arranged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Research Project in American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Guided research in American ethnic studies. Students prepare a research paper on a relevant subject of their choice. Each student is responsible for arranging to work with a member of the American ethnic studies faculty.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Recitation Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrative review of concepts in American ethnic studies under faculty supervision. Preparation for leading discussions, workshops and reviews in American ethnic studies. Students attend two lecture sessions per week concurrent with AMETH 160, one additional seminar session focused on planning and preparation for recitations, and are responsible for leading discussions in one or more recitation sections in AMETH 160 per week.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a broad overview of social research methods pertinent to the study of ethnicity and culture. Students will be introduced to qualitative and quantitative methods of research, including oral history interviews, ethnographic observation/field research, surveys, and experimentation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: To introduce and familiarize students with the concept of multicultural.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics of special interest in American Ethnic Studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable with change of topic. Topic and credit to be arranged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone course for seniors enrolled in the American ethnic studies major.  Integrating the learning from all previous courses through the writing of a major research paper and completion of a multicultural portfolio will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Reading and Research in American Ethnic Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced guided reading and research on a specific topic of student interest, leading to preparation of a research paper or creative work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing and permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Topic and credit to be arranged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to ethnology and ethnography; analysis and comparison of technological, social, and religious characteristics of cultural systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students who have credit in ANTH 204.

htmlparse.Course.title: A General Education Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to ethnology and ethnography; analysis and comparison of technological, social, and religious characteristics of cultural systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students who have credit in ANTH 200.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology, Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic ethnology and ethnography; technological, social, and religious characteristics of cultural systems; discussion and independent study.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Linguistic Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Language as a part of human behavior: its origins, uses and abuses, and ways of defining reality. Basic descriptive and ethnosemantic skills used by anthropologists to learn languages in the field.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Archeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Brief introduction to the field of anthropological archeology.  General survey of world prehistory revealing major cultural changes from the development of early foraging societies through the rise of agricultural and complex communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Physical Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: History of research; principles of evolution and human genetics; primate relations of hominids; fossil evidence of the evolution of hominids; the study of modern race; culture and evolution.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Physical Anthropology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory investigation of human skeletal anatomy, human genetics, primate comparative anatomy, fossil hominid morphology, and comparative evolution of hominid types.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cultures of South Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an interdisciplinary exploration of the disparate cultures and communities of the South Asian region.  We will examine thematic issues of colonization, religion, nationalism, modernity, sexuality, gender, globalization and social stratification in their various South Asian contexts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics for Educators
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of selected topics in archaeology, cultural, or linguistic anthropology designed to address education standards in the social sciences.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Does not apply towards requirements for anthropology major or minor.
May be repeated with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings and discussion of selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proficiency Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrative review of anthropological concepts and skills under faculty supervision. For single students or groups of students. Not applicable to major field requirements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and superior performance in relevant course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not repeatable. For undergraduate credit only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Archaeological Fact or Fiction
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of popular beliefs about the human past through the application of critical thinking skills. Topics include ancient North American inscriptions, Vikings in the Americas, the moundbuilder myth, lost civilizations, and advanced prehistoric technology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary survey of the development of civilizations in India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, and Afghanistan, including geography, philosophy, social, economic, political institution, and historical movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 3 hours of social science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethnological approaches to politics in societies around the world. Structural-functional, evolutionary, and conflict theories. A comparison of the political systems of small-scale and complex societies: political modernization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Language and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of language and dialect as aspects of social and ethnic group identities. Emphasis on analysis of conversational style in diverse cultural settings. Research project to be determined according to student interests.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 220 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Creativity and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: How ethnologists view the expressive and creative aspects of culture. A cross-cultural survey of the verbal, visual, and performing arts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethnomusicology
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethnic, popular, and traditional musics from around the world. The course samples a wide range of stylistic traditions from Africa, Asia, Oceania, Europe, and the Americas. Emphasis is on understanding musical style in cultural context.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practical Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of anthropological principles and insights to programs of planned change, cultural innovation, and contemporary problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive exploration of anthropological problems for both majors and non-majors of sufficient background. High levels of individual participation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Archaeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive exploration of archaeological problems for both major and non-majors with adequate background.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Cultural Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive exploration of problems in cultural anthropology for both majors and non-majors with adequate background.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Linguistic Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive exploration of problems in linguistic anthropology for both major and non-majors with adequate background.

htmlparse.Course.title: Immigrant America
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of post-1965 immigration to the United States with a focus on Asian and Latino newcomers. Immigrant adaptation, economic strategies and the reinterpretation of cultural identity. Implications for American society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Physical Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive exploration of problems in physical anthropology for both major and non-majors with adequate background.

htmlparse.Course.title: Central America: Its Peoples and Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: An anthropological perspective of the interactions of indigenous and foreign populations with an examination of the geographic, social, economic, political, and ideological bases of the problems facing Central America today. A look at the seven countries composing Central America in terms of their particular problems and unique solutions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Kansas Archaeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the native cultures of Kansas and the Central Plains region based on archaeological and ethnohistoric research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cultures of Africa
htmlparse.Course.description: Family life, subsistence patterns, exchange systems, languages, religions, and development of the peoples of Africa.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: North American Archaeology
htmlparse.Course.description: The prehistoric of native cultures of North America explored through the archaeological record from the peopling of the continent, to the spread of agriculture and village life, up to contact period.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cultural Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Cultural processes and their conditions and consequences, mechanisms by which customs originate and become culturally significant; development, modification, and decline of customs and cultures; processes and consequences of intercultural contacts; applied anthropology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 200 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anthropological Theory
