htmlparse.Course.description: Review and integration of the major theoretical approaches in the principal branches of anthropology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Religion in Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature of religion in different cultural systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 200 or ANTH 210 or SOCIO 211.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Reading and Research in Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Guided reading and research on a specific anthropological topic of student interest, leading to preparation of a research paper. Topic and credit to be arranged.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three hours of anthropology and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Museology
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical professional museum experience of at least three weeks full time or 150 hours part time in the processing of collections, conservation, cataloging, archive and library maintenance, and/or planning and preparation of exhibits.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to anthropology majors only. May be repeated once for credit if at a different museum.

htmlparse.Course.title: North American Indians
htmlparse.Course.description: Description and comparison of native cultures of Canada and the United States; culture contact and change among surviving groups.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender, Power, and International Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of various models of development and their impact on various roles of woman and men in various cultures. Emphasis upon Africa, Asia, and Latin America. Comparisons of public, service, and economics sectors, including agriculture, marketing, and industry. Examination of policy issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 or ANTH 200 or ANTH 210 and 3 additional hours in sociology or cultural anthropology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: South American Indians
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the nature and variability of the original cultures of Latin America. Analysis of sample cultures, stressing economic, social, political, and religious structures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Applied Anthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience of at least three weeks full time or 150 hours part time with an organization or institution in the application of anthropological approaches to problem solving and working in a professional setting. Emphasis is on anthropological skills in relation to the objectives and operations of an institution.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 519 and junior and consent of program coordinator.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to anthropology major only. May be repeated once for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mesoamerican Archaeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Early foraging societies, the beginnings of agriculture; the rise of civilization; the classic empires of the Maya, Aztec, Tarascans, and their neighbors; relationships with the United States.

htmlparse.Course.title: European Archaeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of human prehistory in Europe from the earliest Paleolithic hominins to evolve in Europe, expansion of Homo sapiens and associated cultural  developments, the spread of agriculture, diversity of Bronze Age adaptations, to the development of Celtic societies. Studies of archaeological and related evidence are investigated to interpret the dynamics of past ways of living.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Digital Ethnography
htmlparse.Course.description: A hands-on exploration of the uses of digital technology for ethnographic research and representation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Archaeological Laboratory Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Hands-on instruction in and application of professional principles of processing, analyzing, and curating artifacts and related archeological materials.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 260 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Archaeological Field Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Archaeological site survey, site excavation, and laboratory analysis of sites and artifacts from the Manhattan, Kansas region.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Field work on Saturday, 8 a.m.-5 p.m., while weather permits, laboratory work thereafter.

htmlparse.Course.title: Survey of Forensic Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: Anthropological survey of the predominantly biological areas of forensic science, their methods and techniques, as they pertain to the application of that science to the purpose of the law. Particular emphasis will be given to perspectives about the science itself, its application to anthropology, and the unique ways in which that science may be used by law.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A life science with laboratory requirement in the College of Arts and Sciences or the consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Race and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The biological meaning of race; the interrelationships of biological and cultural traits in human evolution; processes of racial formation of man; methods of classifying human races; cultural inheritance; the distinction of race, culture, personality, and intelligence; a review of modern racism; race as an evolutionary episode.

htmlparse.Course.title: Paleoanthropology
htmlparse.Course.description: Human origins and evolution as indicated by fossil evidence; interpretation of man-apes, Pithecanthropus, Neanderthal, Cro-Magnon, and other major fossil groups within the context of evolutionary theory, primate comparisons, and cultural evolution.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 200 or 280 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Primatology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the primate order including considerations of evolution, morphology, and behavior. Particular emphasis will be given to developing perspectives about the origin and evolution of hominids in the context of the primate order.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 280 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Osteology
htmlparse.Course.description: Detailed study of human skeleton, with special attention to health and demographic conditions in prehistoric cultures and the evaluation of physical characteristics and genetic relationships of prehistoric populations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 280 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory in Osteology
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory demonstration and exercise in working with skeletal material for analysis of sex, age, stature, and race. Complete metric and nonmetric analysis with consideration given to paleodemography, paleopathology in situ analysis and excavation, and preservation. Written reports on bone material remains will be necessary.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Osteology
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of human and nonhuman skeletal remains including age, sex, stature, race, anomalities, pathologies, trauma, metric and nonmetric traits, cause of death, and time since death. This course allows greater breadth and depth of osteological analysis than either ANTH 694 or 695, and allows for more concentration on individual methods and techniques and case studies.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: In odd years and on sufficient demand

htmlparse.Course.title: Field and Laboratory Techniques in Archaeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Participation in archaeological excavations; techniques, methods, and procedures in a field research situation. The laboratory work of cleaning, cataloging, analyzing, and preliminary report preparation of materials recovered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ANTH 200 or 260 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once if the areas or problems involved are different.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Methods in Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques of collecting and analyzing linguistic data in the field. Work with language consultants in class, on languages such as Swahili.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cardiorespiratory Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study of a selected topic in kinesiology involving either great in-depth study, or application of theory presented in a related course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 6 hrs in Kinesiology 500 and above. Only 6 hours may be counted toward degree.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated as topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cardiovascular Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the structure and function of the respiratory system and the manner in which oxygen passes from the atmosphere to its site of utilization in the mitochondria. Exercise and environmental stresses will form the basis for examining the capacity, plasticity and limitations to respiratory function.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gross Anatomy I
htmlparse.Course.description: Gross dissection of the dog with comparative aspects of the cat.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine or consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gross Anatomy II
htmlparse.Course.description: Gross dissection of the horse and ruminant with comparative aspects of the pig, laboratory animals, and the chicken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microscopic Anatomy I
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin, development, and microscopic structure and appearance of the cells and tissues of the animal body.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and six hours lab a week. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stem Cells and Comparative Biomedicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Characteristics of major categories of stem cells. Applicable or potential clinical uses, including their utilization in tissue engineering or targeted delivery of therapeutics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cross-Course Integration I
htmlparse.Course.description: Vertical and horizontal integration among semester courses to improve student cognitive retention and understanding of core content. Structure-function relationships will be emphasized to facilitate student assimilation and provide clinical relevance to basic science content.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Physiology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Function of the animal body at the cellular level, including nerve and muscle function. Basic pathophysiological mechanisms and intermediary metabolism will be emphasized and correlated with clinical topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cross-Course Integration II
htmlparse.Course.description: Vertical and horizontal integration within and between semester courses to improve student cognitive retention and understanding of core content. Structure-function relationships will be emphasized to facilitate student assimilation and provide clinical relevance to basic science content.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AP 730 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Physiology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Function of the cardiovascular, endocrine, respiratory, renal, digestive, and reproductive systems of domestic animals with emphasis on physiologic control mechanisms, interrelationships of body systems, and criteria for evaluating animal health.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pharmacology I
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic principles of pharmacology, the interactions of drugs and living systems including fundamental principles of pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, receptor-coupling, and mechanisms of action. A systems-based approach to drug classes will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pharmacology II
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic principles of pharmacology, the relationship of drug actions and interactions on physiological principles and pathophysiological conditions. Pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and a systems-based approach to drug classes will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AP 770 or consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioinstrumentation Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience with and evaluation of laboratory and clinical techniques related to electrodes, transducers, computer-based data acquisition and analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AP 747 or equivalent and concurrent enrollment in ECE 772.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electives in Anatomy and Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description:
Fall–Elective course work. Topics: Veterinary Medical Language Cognates and Etymology; Special Interest Anatomy for Veterinary Students; History of Veterinary Medicine; Practical Use and Interpretation of Veterinary Scientific Literature.

Spring–Elective course work. Topics: Three Dimensional Imaging Anatomy of the Dog; Special Interest Anatomy for Veterinary Students; Veterinary Neuroscience; Behavior of Domestic Animals; Comparative Embryology.

Summer–Elective course work. Topics: Special Interest Anatomy for Veterinary Students; Veterinary Medical Language Cognates and Etymology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Professional veterinary student standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Anatomy and Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction of undergraduate and graduate students to research involving various anatomical and physiological systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study of a selected topic in Exercise Physiology involving either great in-depth study, or application of theory presented in a related course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 335, KIN 336. Only 6 hours may be counted toward degree.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring, Summer, on sufficient demand
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated as topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Arabic I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of modern Arabic. Essentials of grammar, speaking, reading, and writing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Arabic II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Arabic I.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Arabic III
htmlparse.Course.description: Further development of language skills.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Arabic IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Arabic III.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Arabic V
htmlparse.Course.description: Further development of language and culture skills.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Arabic VI
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of Arabic V, with further development of language and culture skills.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Arabic
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Arabic
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of the department head and instructor involved.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Science, Technology, and Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of the interrelationships between architecture and various sciences including the technological applications of selected scientific theories.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Non-majors may take this course for UGE credit, but it will not fulfill UGE requirements for majors. However, it may be taken as a professional support elective (PSE) by architecture students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Architectural Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in the fundamentals of architectural technology with emphasis on the concepts and principles necessary for developing an integrated approach to building design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 115 or 113 and admission to a professional program in the college.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Problems in Architectural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of specific architectural design problems under the direction of a member of the architecture faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Architecture I
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will introduce students to digital management concepts, basic architectural digital representation, 3-dimensional computer modeling, raster, and vector graphics with an emphasis on conceptual development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisites: Second year standing or higher, or permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architecture Through the Ages
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory survey of the history of architecture worldwide from its prehistoric beginnings up to the present day.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May not be taken for credit by students enrolled in the College of Architecture, Planning and Design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Appreciation of Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of the evolution of architectural styles to determine the relation of architectural expression to the needs of society.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week. May not be taken for credit by students enrolled in the architecture, landscape architecture, or interior architecture curricula.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio I
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in architectural design focusing on the application of elements and principles of form and space in design. Instruction in the use of techniques for visually representing design ideas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the architecture program and ENVD 202.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio II
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in architectural design focusing on the synthesis of basic social, functional, technical, and aesthetic factors in design. Continued instruction in techniques for visually representing design ideas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Design and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in behavioral, cultural, and ecological factors that contribute to successful environmental design; considers how the design process is affected by a conceptual point of view. Case studies from architecture, landscape architecture, interior architecture, and interior design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second-year standing or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Systems in Architecture I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to structure as a building system.  Overview of contemporary structural systems and their components, including wood, timber, steel, concrete, masonry, and hybrid structures.  Discussion of building code requirements for structure, general guidelines for building structures, including appropriate application, and methods for schematic estimation of structural member sizing.  Basic understanding of how gravity and lateral forces are propagated through a structural frame from load to building foundation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisites: PHYS 113 or 115, MATH 100 or higher, ARCH 248, and admission to a professional program in the college.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture, two hours laboratory per week.
This course replaces ARCH 348 and ARCH 449.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Systems in Architecture I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to statics; force analysis and the study of forces in equilibrium; principles of statics as applied to the study of simple elemental structures; the origin, the nature, and the action of loads on structural systems. Instruction in the use of statics in the preliminary stages of building design. For ARCH and IAPD students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 113 or 115, MATH 100 or higher.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Designed Environment III
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of the designed environment from the mid-18th century through present.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENVD 251 or permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Architecture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will be introduced to Building Information Modeling (BIM) during the course, with emphasis on BIM methods for conceptual development, the design and representation of building assemblies and systems, and architectural documentation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second year standing or higher, or permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Architecture III
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods for digital 3-dimensional visualization, including rendering, animation, compositing and analysis will be introduced during this course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 274, ARCH 373, or permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio III
htmlparse.Course.description: Relation of structures to their environment; client and community restraint; development of building programs; synthesis of functional, technical, and aesthetic considerations in the design of structures for human use.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 304 and not more than one D in an architectural design course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Relation of structures to their environment; client and community restraint; development of building programs; synthesis of functional, technical, and aesthetic considerations in the design of structures for human use.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 403 and not more than one D in an architectural design course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Systems in Architecture I
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in bioclimatic and ecological design principles as a basis for architectural and landscape design. Emphasis on passive solar heating and cooling and daylighting.   For ARCH and IAPD students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 113 or 115, MATH 100 or higher, and enrollment in a professional program in the college.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Construction Systems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture course that develops an understanding of how materials and systems assembly reinforce and extend the intentions of the designer as well as an understanding of the strategies and techniques for integration and coordination of the building components.  For ARCH and IAPD students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 248, 348, and admission to a professional program in the college.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Systems in Architecture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in the quantitative analysis of structural systems and the forces they resist, proceeding from the design loads associated with building through the reactions of particular structural elements.  Overview of material strengths, and other properties of specific structural systems.  Instruction in structural system sizing, by hand calculation and computer analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 347 and admission to a professional program in the college.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture, two hours laboratory per week. This course replaces ARCH 452 and ARCH 453.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Systems in Architecture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in strength of materials focusing on the behavior of building materials under loading; their ability to resist deformation and failure. Instruction in sizing simple structural elements.  For ARCH and IAPD students.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Systems in Architecture III
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in the design of building structures as whole systems. Instruction in the principles of structural subsystem design; emphasis on the overall structural behavior and subsystems integrity required to achieve a variety of building forms.  Instruction in strategies for the use of approximation in the manipulation of key quantitative properties of whole systems and major subsystems in building design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, two hours workshop/test each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Systems in Architecture IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in the design of building structures as whole systems; overall-to-specific systems behavior and manipulative design of major subsystems. Emphasis on the design of subsystems and subsystem components as they are affected by structural material. Instruction in specialized issues associated with the analysis and design of high rise and long-span building structure, including foundation, constructive, and economic factors which affect building design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, two hours workshop/test each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Applications in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to technical, representational, and theoretical issues of digital design tools in architecture. Acquisition of skills to independently employ three-dimensional design, modeling, rendering, image processing, two-dimensional drawing, and other applications.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Students are required to provide their own computer and software.
Two hours of lecture and two hours of lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Architectural Presentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of various methods of graphically representing architectural problems to develop professional office techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second-year standing and approval of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship Planning Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration and preparation for an architecture internship in the field of architecture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No Credit

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Internship, Part A
htmlparse.Course.description: Off-campus work study program with an approved professional, building industry, government, or non-profit agency sponsor.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 605 and approval of the internship coordinator.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Must be enrolled concurrent with ARCH 506, and each course must be successfully completed before credit is awarded in either.
This course is graded Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Internship, Part B
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation of internship journals and employer profiles, during the approved off-campus work-study program in ARCH 505.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 605 and approval of the internship coordinator.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Must be enrolled concurrent with ARCH 505, and each course must be successfully completed before credit is awarded in either.
This course is letter-graded only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Internship, Part C
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of the approved off-campus internship of ARCH 505 and ARCH 506. Preparation of internship journals, employer profiles, and a final internship analysis paper based on the entire 30-week internship experience.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course must be completed in order for internship to count as an equivalent of ARCH 606.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Systems in Architecture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Criteria for selection and application of natural and mechanical environmental control systems in architecture. Focus on the integration of thermal, illumination, sanitary, movement, and acoustical systems with the building fabric and the natural environment. Contemporary and developing approaches are explored.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Systems in Architecture III
htmlparse.Course.description: Criteria for selection and application of natural and mechanical environmental control systems in architecture. Focus on the integration of thermal, illumination, sanitary, movement, and acoustical systems with the building fabric and the natural environment. Contemporary and developing approaches are explored.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Architectural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of specific design problems under the direct supervision of a member of the architecture faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio V
htmlparse.Course.description: A design studio that integrates a design project with design development, (including structural, mechanical, lighting and movement systems) and construction documentation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 404 and not more than one grade of D in an architectural design course, LAR 500, ARCH 433, ARCH 453, ARCH 514 and concurrent enrollment in ARCH 515.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio VI
htmlparse.Course.description: On or off-campus advanced studio. Department and College approval required for off-campus studios, whether in a domestic or international studies program or university.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 605 and not more than one grade of D in an architectural design course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course surveying the basic philosophies and methodologies for architectural programming; emphasis on the comparative evaluation of different strategies and their integration within the process of design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing or permission of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Study Abroad Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation for participation in study abroad with a focus on specific information pertaining to the design professions and the analysis of the built and natural environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in History of the Designed Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on topics involving specific periods or subjects in the history of the built environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 350 or M. ARCH standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with credit for different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Aesthetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems involving aesthetics in areas related to student’s major field.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Environment and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on topics in human behavior as it relates to physical environments.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 304 or IAPD 320 or LAR 320 or M. ARCH standing or junior standing if outside CAPD.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Project Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of a program for ARCH 707, Architectural Design VIII, under direction of a faculty member.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 606, or ARCH 505/506, ARCH 650, and approval of the faculty committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio VII
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of the physiological, psychological, and sociological parameters in the design of environments. Analysis, programming, and planning problems, increased complexity of function and space definition systems. Relating environmental technology to total design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Either ARCH 505 and ARCH 506 or ARCH 606; not more than one D in an architectural design course; ARCH 434, ARCH 453 and ARCH 515.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio VIII
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of the student’s project programmed in ARCH 705, under the direction of a faculty committee. Project must demonstrate a high level of achievement in systematic and comprehensive thinking, application of resources, and communication of total process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 705, ARCH 706, not more than one D in an architectural design course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Architectural Design Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive review of selected design methodologies, including systematic and computer-based approaches to problem definition and project design; emphasis upon the comparative evaluation of problem-solving strategies within the architectural design process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 304 or IAPD 320 or LAR 320 or M. ARCH standing or junior standing if outside CAPD.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Architecture Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on topics in architecture with readings, class discussion, student presentations, research papers or projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 304 or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Environmental Systems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: A concentrated study of a particular subject related to the environmental systems of the built environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 413 or M. ARCH standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environment and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigates the relationship between human behavior and design of the physical environment. Includes identification of psychological, social, cultural concepts which influence and are influenced by the built environment. Emphasizes applying this knowledge in design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 325 or equivalent or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour seminar per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architecture Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course surveying the basic philosophies and methodologies of science and research as they apply to the field of architecture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Special emphasis will be placed on those methods appropriate for investigating human response to the built environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Building Construction Systems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the relationship of conceptual and/or technological factors of building construction to architecture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 433 or M. ARCH standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Structural Systems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the relationship of conceptual and/or technological factors of structure to architectural design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 453 or M. ARCH standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of conventional and newly developing methods of professional design practice. Instruction in the relationships of architects, landscape architects, interior architects and other professions to users, clients, construction industry, society, government, and one another.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of specific architectural problems under the direct supervision of a member of the architecture faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical application of studies related to a student’s area focus.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
For Master of Architecture and Master of Science in Architecture students.
May be taken with departmental permission only.
Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in History of the Designed Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on topics involving specific periods or subjects in the history of the built environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Aesthetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems involving aesthetics in areas related to student’s major field.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Environment and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on topics in human perceptions, reactions, and behavior as they relate to physical environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Project Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of an architectural program for ARCH 807. Identify evaluation criteria and prepare statement of objectives; perform appropriate research and analysis; and create programming document.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 650; either ARCH 606 or ARCH 507.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For M. ARCH students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architecture Design Studio VII
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of the physiological, psychological, and sociological parameters in the design of environments. Analysis, programming, and planning problems, increased complexity of function and space definition systems. Relating environmental technology to total design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: either ARCH 507 or ARCH 606; not more than one D in an architectural design course; ARCH 434, ARCH 453 and ARCH 515.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week. For M. ARCH students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Studio VIII
htmlparse.Course.description: Final design studio course in the professional curriculum in architecture. Using the program established in ARCH 805, demonstrate mastery in systematic and comprehensive thinking, project research, application of resources, architectural design, and communication of total process.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours studio a week. For M. ARCH students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Design Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in design communication with emphasis on concepts, principles, strategies and skills for effectively combining writing with images and other products of design; focuses on ideas, processes and proposals developed during the final year of architectural design studio.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 200-Expository Writing II and concurrent enrollment with ARCH 807-Architectural Design Studio VIII.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Architectural Design Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive review of selected design methodologies, including systematic and computer-based approaches to problem definition and project design; emphasis upon the comparative evaluation of problem-solving strategies within the architectural design process.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on topics in architecture with readings, class discussion, student presentations, research papers or projects.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Environmental Systems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: A concentrated study of a particular subject related to the environmental systems of the built environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environment and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigates the relationship between human behavior and design of the physical environment. Includes identification of psychological, social, cultural factors which influence and are influenced by the built environment. Emphasizes applying this knowledge in design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Three hour seminar per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Architectural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies related to the area of focus of a M.ARCH student in the non-thesis option. Preparation of a non-thesis proposal and a non-thesis project which may include a design project, synthesis paper, portfolio of written work, series of case studies, or other project.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be taken by M.Arch student with departmental permission only.
May be repeated.
Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Building Construction Systems in Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the relationship of conceptual and/or technological factors of building construction to architecture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Structural Systems in Architecture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the relationship of conceptual and/or technological factors of structure to architectural design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of conventional and newly developing methods of professional design practice. Instruction in the relationships of architects, landscape architects, interior architects, and other professions to users, clients, construction industry, society, government, and one another.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
For M.ARCH students.
May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems in Architectural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of specific architectural design problems under the direct supervision of a member of the architecture faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Study in architecture and related fields leading to thesis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Engineering Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation of professional problems and practices by students, faculty, and professionals associated with the career of architectural engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
One hour lecture a month.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Engineering Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to architectural engineering; emphasis on relationship of architectural engineering to the building design and construction industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to AutoCAD
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the basics of AutoCAD.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: CAD in Engineering and Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Basics of CAD and the applications to the engineering and construction industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and six hours lab a week (7 week course).

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Revit®
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of building information modeling as a design method related to the engineering and construction industry.  With basic instruction of an industry accepted software platform:  Autodesk Revit® Architecture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course will be taught by distance education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Engineering Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and elements of design; synthesis of structural, mechanical, electrical, lighting, sanitary, and construction systems, considering interrelationship in performance and economics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Architectural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. Open to students in the college of engineering honors program. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Loading and Load Paths in Buildings
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of International Building Code structural loading requirements, applications, determination of design loads, and establishing correct and continuous load paths for all loads acting on a structure for buildings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 533, CE 534 and CNS 200. Prerequisite or concurrent: CE 537.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Steel Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and design of steel structures following the AISC/LRFD specifications for buildings. Includes background on the probability-based LRFD method.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reinforced Concrete Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of reinforced concrete building frames; floorings, columns and floor systems, attention being given to costs and economical design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lighting Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of human needs in lighting, lighting sources, lighting systems design and application.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Electrical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of basic design of building electrical systems including circuit design, power distribution and service equipment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermal Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of man’s physiological needs, principles of heat transfer, principles of building thermal balance, comfort systems, and space-use relationships involving heating, ventilating, and cooling as integral parts of architectural engineering design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plumbing/Fire Protection Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of the design and layout of sewage disposal systems, building plumbing and fire protection systems, space relationships, equipment requirements as related to architectural design, structural systems, construction materials, and techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Acoustic Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Hearing and the ear, sound generation, acoustical correction, noise reduction, and sound transmission all as integral parts of architectural design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Architectural Engineering Management
htmlparse.Course.description: General business, management, and contractual procedures in professional practice. Personal and professional development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IMSE 530. Must be taken concurrent with ARE 690.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Mechanical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of heat loss and heat gain using computers, various types of HVAC air systems selection and application, HVAC hydronic systems, and an introduction to mechanical systems controls.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integrated Building System Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods for integration and coordination of structural, mechanical, electrical, and lighting systems in the building architectural design process.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation, four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Architectural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of specific design problems under the direct supervision of a member of the architectural engineering faculty.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Approval of the department head.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to LEED
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to green building design and construction principles and practices based on the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Green Building Rating System of the United States Green Building Council (USGBC).
htmlparse.Course.notes: One or two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Student working individually with laboratory support will prepare and present a design project of appropriate scope and complexity with emphasis on structural or mechanical and electrical building systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARE 590 and CE 522. Must be taken concurrent with ARE 539.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Energy Codes and Standards
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the background, importance, impact, and application of the energy codes to the mechanical and electrical systems design process.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Energy Modeling Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of current building energy sources and trends, basic engineering economics applied to building energy use, energy calculations for building systems, and software-based whole building energy simulation using eQUEST.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Architectural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Participation in student design competition teams under the direct supervision of a member of the architectural engineering faculty.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Approval of the department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Architectural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of specific design problems in architectural engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Timber Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and design of timber structures including dimension lumber, glu-lam members, and engineered wood products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cold-Formed Steel Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of behavior, design, fabrication, and construction of cold-formed steel structures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARE 524 or CNS 524 or CE 542.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two or three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Masonry Structural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to masonry materials, specifications, testing and construction methods. The design of unreinforced and reinforced masonry structures according to applicable building codes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARE 528 or equivalent first course in reinforced concrete design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Seismic Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of ARE 524 and ARE 528 with special emphasis on seismic design as applied to a complete structure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Lighting Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and application of lighting systems for commercial buildings, using current industry practices and computer-assisted analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Mechanical Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and application of selected mechanical systems for commercial buildings, expanding on the material and topics presented in ARE 534 and ARE 540.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electrical Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and application of various electrical distribution system for commercial buildings. The course uses the National Electrical Code in conjunction with current industry practices.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Plumbing Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and application of domestic water and waste systems, storm water systems, fuel gas systems, medical gas systems and fire protections systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Control Systems in Buildings
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to pneumatic, electric, electronic, and direct digital control systems to optimize energy usage and environmental comfort in buildings, including preparation of control diagrams and control sequences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Communication Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Detailed design and analysis of special electrical systems for buildings including, fire alarm, and communication systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: 2- Dimensional Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to and laboratory practice in the principles and elements of design. Emphasis is placed on organizational command of the two-dimensional picture plane and issues of illusion.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Art Careers Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to art concentrations and professions.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Required of all art majors and must be completed prior to the concentrations admission review procedure.
May not be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drawing I
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of drawing as applied to the realistic and expressive representation of objects through the use of a variety of media and approaches.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Survey of Art History I
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical development of art from pre-history through the Middle Ages.

htmlparse.Course.title: Survey of Art History II
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical development of art from the Renaissance to the nineteenth century.

htmlparse.Course.title: 3- Dimensional Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to laboratory practice in the principles and elements of design. Emphasis is placed on the perceptions and use of spatial properties as related to components of 3-D art and design. Students will develop design vocabulary, methodology and judgment skills that will implement further study in the visual arts.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drawing II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Drawing I, with strong emphasis on creative expression.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Media I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to painting with water-based media through a variety of techniques. Emphasis is placed on learning transparent watercolor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Figure Drawing I
htmlparse.Course.description: Sustained drawings of the human figure using a variety of media; introduction to human anatomy used by artists.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sculpture I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the problems of sculptural form; fundamental techniques and theory in woodcarving, clay modeling, mold making, casting, oxy/acetylene welding, and metal casting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Printmaking I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the intaglio, lithographic, relief, and serigraphic printmaking techniques and tools.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for four semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Oil Painting
htmlparse.Course.description: Technical aspects of oil painting materials, including preparation of grounds and use of limited color palettes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ceramics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic hand building techniques and basic throwing techniques; decoration of ceramic forms using slips, stains, glazes. Student participation in Raku firing procedures; stacking and firing of electric kilns.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Metalsmithing I
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and execution of small-scale, three-dimensional objects, involving the basic processes of raising, forging, and fabrication in semi-precious metals. The techniques of centrifugal and vacuum casting of precious metals will also be introduced as well as soldering and piercing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Illustration I
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of various applied drawing/painting/collage techniques and how they relate to illustration and layout. Various traditional and digital media will be utilized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Type and Design Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of design and type principles to the development of letterforms and to principles of symbology. Selected topics in design, i.e., perception, figure/ground; shape, visual dynamics, Gestalt principle; fundamentals of the design process: research, thumbnails/roughs, comprehensive, presentation, paste-up, and digital fines.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Photography in Art I
htmlparse.Course.description: Understanding and using photography as an art form. The basic elements and principles of art are explored. Camera usage and photographic processing are covered. A 35MM SLR is required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ART 100, 190 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concentration Admission Procedure
htmlparse.Course.description: The preparation and display of a student’s own creative work, upon completion of the Department of Art 24-credit-hour core. The concentration admission procedure occurs after student selection of an area of concentration within the BFA art major format.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fine Arts will do admission reviews both fall and spring, Graphic Design and Digital Media only in the Spring
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Specialized workshops or seminars conducted in studio, art therapy, art education, or art history.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Form and Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: Building stylization and expressive image making of the human form with experimental methods: use of color, mono-print, mixed media. A connected and sustained studio time available during intersession only, providing students a working rhythm without interruption from other course work.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Museum Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of museum work including specific museum functions, role of professional personnel, and proper care and handling of art works.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graphic Design Studio I
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and preparation of design concepts for application to the printing process. (Black and white and color.)
htmlparse.Course.notes: Studio class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Techniques in Visual Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the most frequently used programs in the Studio Arts and equipment necessary for successful navigation on the digital arena.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drawing III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Drawing II, emphasizing exploration in mixed media.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for two semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Studio Art Exploration
htmlparse.Course.description: Studio experiences in a variety of media including printmaking, fibers, drawing, and sculpture. Art materials, techniques, and process are explored.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in art.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: For students in the honors program only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Imaging in Graphic Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of computer imaging through the use of image processing, page layout, and design concept.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ART 298 in Graphic Design or Digital Media, 290 and 310.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Studio class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Illustration II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studio that explores various techniques in illustration in traditional and digital media.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: BFA Exhibition or Portfolio Presentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Course builds an awareness of professional practices and emphasizes the production and exhibition of a final portfolio of the student’s art work. Development of evaluative skills involved in the resolution and presentation of a body of individual work.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students must take their final 3 credits in their concentration during the same semester as ART 410.

htmlparse.Course.title: Art for Elementary Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Art methods, materials, and philosophy of children’s art at different grade levels.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab, three hours online lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Ceramics
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in ceramics after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Crafts
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in crafts after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Drawing
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in drawing after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Graphic Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in graphic design after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Metalsmithing
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in metalsmithing and jewelry after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Painting
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in painting after competency has been achieved.  Personal development is emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Permission of instructor and painting area head required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Printmaking
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in printmaking after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Sculpture
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in sculpture after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Water Color
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in water color after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study/Research Computer Art and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is intended to provide students an opportunity to focus on a specific visual project/problem that will be solved using computers to focus on as the primary tool/medium.

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth Century Art History I
htmlparse.Course.description: Origins and development of twentieth century art from 1980 to 1914.

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth Century Art History II
htmlparse.Course.description: Origins and development of twentieth century art from 1914 to 1950.

htmlparse.Course.title: Art for the Exceptional Individual
htmlparse.Course.description: Using art concepts and activities to meet the needs of the mentally retarded, physically impaired, emotionally disturbed, or gifted.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Oil Painting II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Introduction to Oil Painting, with emphasis on direct observation from still life and the human form.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hour lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Photography in Art II
htmlparse.Course.description: Creative exploration of broad-based approaches to photographic images. Both camera and dark-room manipulations will be used in the process of image making.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ceramics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced work on potter’s wheel combined with hand-built forms. Consideration of simple kiln design, firing techniques, and procedures using various fuel burning kilns.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for four semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Techniques: Digital Photography
htmlparse.Course.description: Digital photography.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mixed Media Painting Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Experimental approaches to painting within varied media. Focus on media, idea and composition, using traditional painting materials, including assemblage.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to Interactive and User Experience Design principles. Topics include the planning, prototyping and construction of web and interaction design projects.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for four semesters. Final semester will include a portfolio project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Typography
htmlparse.Course.description: Typographic theory and use exploring formal and informal structures with an analysis of historic styles. Multipage layouts emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Studio class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Matrix Studio and Business Practices
htmlparse.Course.description: Students are selected by portfolio review, design projects are completed to client specifications. Professional design management, ethics, setting up a business, client/designer relationships, and contractual options, billing practices, and operating procedures will be covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ART 400 and must be a major.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graphic Design Senior Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed senior thesis project, portfolio and resume preparation. Selected topics in design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Studio class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internships in Visual Art & Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on problem solving and related skills in visual art, art history, and graphic design in a professional setting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated up to total of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Drawing
htmlparse.Course.description: Upper-level drawing, development, and personal motivation. Lectures and problems directed toward an understanding of the historical development of drawing as well as investigations of contemporary studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for 4 semesters. Credits over 3 hours must be approved by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graphic Desigh History/Theory/Criticism
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of significant works from late nineteenth century to the present to provide understanding of the development and character of graphic design, artists, and designers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth Century Art History III
htmlparse.Course.description: Art movements beginning with abstract expressions and continuing through pop, op, minimal, and conceptual art movements up to 1980.

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth Century Art History IV
htmlparse.Course.description: The art movements of the 1980s beginning with photo-realism and continuing through pattern and decoration, new image art, neo-expressionisms, and neo-abstraction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Greek Art History
htmlparse.Course.description: The art of classical Greece, from its Aegean origins through the Hellenistic period.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Specialized workshops or seminars conducted in studio, art therapy, art education, or art history.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three credit hours in the relevant area.

htmlparse.Course.title: Figure Drawing II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Figure Drawing I, with emphasis on individual expression.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for four semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Renaissance Art History
htmlparse.Course.description: Renaissance art of northern and southern Europe in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, with a brief discussion of its fourteenth century origins.

htmlparse.Course.title: 3D Animation in Graphic Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Specialized training in the 3D realm, modeling, lighting, motion graphic design. Studio.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three credit hours in the relevant area (Graphic Design, Digital Arts, Photography).

htmlparse.Course.title: Baroque Art History
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of the baroque period in northern and southern Europe, from its beginnings in the early seventeenth century to the rococo style of the eighteenth century.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Concepts in Computer Art and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Studio exploration of computers as a tool/medium for art disciplines.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture, four hours lab.
May be repeated for up to 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Art Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Work offered in art education after competency has been achieved. Personal development is emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Full sequence of courses related to art education subject matter.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study-Photography
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced work in photography, an emphasis on personal development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Competency in camera and photo-related processes required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foreign Studies in Art History
htmlparse.Course.description: Participation in art history study abroad.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three credit hours of art history and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foreign Studies in Studio Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Participation in studio art study abroad.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three credit hours of studio art and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Media Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: A review of trends in contemporary media and visual communication.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Studio/lecture.
May be repeated for up to 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Development of American Art
htmlparse.Course.description: American art from the Colonial period to the beginnings of abstract expressionism in the early 1940s, with major emphasis on the late nineteenth and early twentieth century developments.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Modern Sculpture
htmlparse.Course.description: Directions in sculpture since the time of Rodin.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Printmaking
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced work in relief, serigraphy, lithography, and intaglio.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for six semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Color Printmaking Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of color printmaking.  Color theory and practical techniques provide experience in multicolor and intermedia graphic production.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for 12 credit hours maximum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nineteenth Century Art History
htmlparse.Course.description: Painting, sculpture, and architecture of the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, with emphasis on the art of France.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sculpture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on artistic development through exploratory experiences in the various media. Advanced wood working processes, mold making, foundry techniques and welding processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hour lab. May be taken for four semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced/Senior Painting Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Individualized studio work in varied painting media. Focus on strengths and exploration of media for personal expression. Emphasis for graduating seniors will be on producing a cohesive body of work in preparation of BFA exhibition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for 12 credits total. Six hours studio.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in Art
htmlparse.Course.description: The work of women artists from early Middle Ages to the twentieth century, with emphasis on the contemporary period.

htmlparse.Course.title: Metalsmithing Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Surface embellishment, container construction of various techniques, linkage, and mechanical problems will be explored in addition to stone setting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab. May be taken for three semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sculpture III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Sculpture II. Further exploration of media and technique, emphasizing the development of individual direction and expression. Primarily for undergraduate sculpture majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for a maximum of 9 credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Southwestern Indian Arts and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of southwestern Indian silversmithing, weaving, pottery, basketry, and painting from the prehistoric period through the twentieth century.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ceramics III
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual exploration and further development of ceramic design and glaze technology; continuation of kiln design and construction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab. May be taken for three semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Ceramics
htmlparse.Course.description: History and development of ceramics; study of the use of pottery and other aspects of ceramics from earliest known records to present day. Use of slides and other visual materials.

htmlparse.Course.title: Color Experiments, Theory and Application
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the interaction of color through a variety of exercises, both practical and experimental. Emphasis on visual perception and the relative use of color. Color’s potential in illusionist structures and visual communication, color systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Metals Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: A number of metalsmithing techniques will be explored by the upper division student with emphasis on experimental problems and possibilities. The development of an individual point of view will predominate throughout the course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated twice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Independent Study Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced work in design-related subjects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Full sequence of courses related to problem subject matter.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Techniques in Teaching Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and class discussion of methods, consideration of suitable laboratory equipment, use of illustrative material, and preparation of courses of study.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Twelve hours in art or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Art History
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent exploration in selected problems in art history.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Sciences & Industry Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the animal sciences & industry programs, activities, resources, faculty and career opportunities.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Required of all freshmen in animal sciences & industry.
One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic principles which apply to animal agriculture; survey of the industry; types, purposes, and products of livestock; principles of breeding, selection, nutrition, lactation, reproduction, management, and marketing.
