htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week. ASI 105, 106, and 107 are companion courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the breeding and market types and classes of livestock including a comparison of the live animal and carcass evaluation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 102 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dairy and Poultry Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the dairy and poultry industries.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Companion Animal and Horse Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the companion animal and equine industries. Career opportunities in the companion animal and equine industries. The use of companion animals in society, their value, and production systems. Basic biology, breed identification, health, handling, training, and selection.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 102 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Research in Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to research with agricultural animals.  The breadth of research activities in animal science will be covered. Research careers in academic, government, and private sector settings will be emphasized. Types of research, ethical considerations in research, animal care, and regulatory issues will be addressed. Student team projects are integral.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microcomputer Applications in Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of microcomputer techniques to the solutions of problems in animal science and related food industries. Includes use of existing software packages for breakeven analysis, animal identification and health records, feed ration analysis, farm/ranch accounting, and electronic communication.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Attitudes of Animal Use
htmlparse.Course.description: A short history of animal use and the livestock industry; attitudes towards animals; the symbiotic bond between humans and animals; the contributions from animals of food, fiber, work, and recreation; animal well-being; the interaction of livestock production and the environment; and ethical issues about using animals for research, food, and recreation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture/recitation a week. Interactive discussion will be emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Poultry and Poultry Product Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied knowledge of physical and anatomical characteristics for evaluating poultry for egg and meat production. Evaluation of ready-to-cook poultry products as well as eggs on their exterior, interior, and broken-out appearance according to the latest USDA standards.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two two-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Livestock and Meat Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of slaughter livestock and their carcasses as related to economically efficient production of red meat. Evaluation of breeding livestock on visual appraisal and performance records. A study of growth and the effects of nutrition, environment, and hormones on growth patterns. Breeds of livestock and performance programs will be studied.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ASI 105. Recommended prerequisite: ASI 102 or instructor consent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary principles of comparative nutrition of farm animals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Feeding
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of basic nutrition principles to the feeding of beef cattle, sheep, and swine; feedstuff evaluation; nutrient requirements; ration formulation and practical feeding problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beginning Horse Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of conformation and athletic performance of horses. The use of records in selection and the influence of heredity, environment, and training on conformation and performance is addressed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students will learn to give an oral justification of their evaluations. Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Horse Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth study of horse conformation and performance horse evaluation. Theories from various equine disciplines are covered with emphasis placed on interpreting horse industry standards, and abilities to communicate those ideals effectively.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Horse as A Window to the World
htmlparse.Course.description: A general education course using the horse as an organizing theme for exploration of many of the aspects of evolution, comparative physiology, economics, ethics, multiculturalism and esthetics.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring, not offered in all years
htmlparse.Course.notes: Designed for students in any major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Enterprise Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis will be placed on management issues affecting the successful development and operation of an equine facility.  Topics covered include health care, diet formulation, equipment needs, facility design and management, and equine business considerations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Recommended prerequisite: ASI 107.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Meat Science
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the meat industry for off-campus students using a videotaped format.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: A course in biology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Food science and animal science majors cannot substitute this course for ASI 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beginning Horse Training and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Inherited and learned behavior of the horse. Development of methods to communicate with the horse. Emphasis on handling and safety techniques. Opportunities to observe and practice advanced training techniques used in saddling and riding.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Meat Science
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the red meat industry relating the fundamental properties of muscle structure, chemistry, and physiology to meat quality, composition, processing, nutritional value, and marketing. The laboratory will demonstrate the conversion of animals to meat and by-products, and meat processing technology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOL 198, or a course in chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Meat Animal Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: A student participation course in processing live animals into meat and by-products. Interrelates all phases of modern slaughter and processing techniques, inspection and processing, and related operations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Meat Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: The use of subjective and objective standards to evaluate beef, lamb, and pork carcasses and wholesale cuts for both quality and yield of edible portion as they relate to value and consumer acceptance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wool Grading and Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of factors determining the commercial grades of wool and the desired fleece qualities of sheep, practice in judging and grading wool.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dairy Cattle Judging
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the principles of evaluating dairy cattle on the basis of their physical characteristics. Interpretation of the official dairy cow unified score card. Training includes preparation and presentation of oral defense on one’s placing of four cow classes.

htmlparse.Course.title: ASI Quadrathalon
htmlparse.Course.description: Active participation in the ASI Quadrathalon involving oral presentations, written exams, practical application of animal knowledge, and a quiz bowl.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Fifteen hours for presentations will be designated each spring. No more than 2 credits earned in this course may apply towards graduation.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Farm Animal Reproduction
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic reproductive anatomy and physiology of cattle, horses, pigs, poultry, and sheep during the first half of the semester provides a solid basis for reproduction management topics which occupy the second half of the course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Farm Animal Reproduction Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory exercises with reproductive specimens of farm species. Will include adult male and female reproductive tracts, anatomical changes associated with estrous cycles and anestrus, pregnancy, fetal and placental development, semen characteristics, and ultrasonography.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Calving
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis will be placed on various aspects of managing parturition in cattle. Focus on stages of parturition, dystocia, and calf care.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 102 and junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foaling
htmlparse.Course.description: Events associated with late gestation, parturition, and the early postpartum period in the horse. Emphasis will be placed on the important aspects of caring for and monitoring a pregnant/lactating mare and her newborn foal.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 102 and 107 and junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lambing
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical and practical experience in lambing. Management of the ewe and lambs at parturition, physiology of parturition, and common problems encountered by ewes and lambs during parturition.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 102 and junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Milk Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of fundamentals of processing, quality assurance, inspection, and marketing of fluid milk and related products in a modern market milk enterprise.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Dairy Cattle Judging
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced Dairy Cattle Judging
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Livestock Sales Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Hands-on experience in the planning, promotion, and production of a purebred livestock sale.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of equine health care and practical experience with the procedures routinely performed by horse owners in the overall management of their horse’s well-being. Topics covered include basic anatomy and physiology, recognizing and managing disease conditions and emergency situations, and preventative management strategies and treatment options for a variety of health-related issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Recommended prerequisite: ASI 107.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Horse Training and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will further develop skills acquired in ASI 345. Students will learn how to utilize advanced training practices and applications to enhance the training and performance of horses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Livestock Selection
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin, development, characteristics, and adaptation of different breeds of livestock, with special emphasis on the selection of market and breeding animals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Form and Function in Livestock
htmlparse.Course.description: A detailed study of animal form and type; influence of type related to function; special training in presenting orally the relative merits of beef cattle, sheep, swine, and horses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Meat Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study in the evaluation of carcasses, wholesale cuts, and retail cuts of beef, lamb, and pork. Application of grade standards and specifications to beef, lamb, and pork carcasses and subprimal cuts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to Mendelian, molecular, quantitative, and population genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Equine Reproductive Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the physiological mechanisms involved in equine reproduction and the scientific reasoning for breeding management decisions. Recent advances in equine reproductive technology will be highlighted and relevant research will be incorporated into the presentations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a web-based lecture course intended for off-campus distance education students. Lecture material is supplemented with web-based demonstrations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Reproduction Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the physiological mechanisms involved in equine reproduction and the scientific reasoning behind breeding management decisions.  Recent advances in equine reproductive technology will be highlighted.  Lab exercises focus on learning breeding techniques including semen collection and processing, and artificial insemination.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended prerequisite: ASI 400.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Breeding Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: The genetic principles of evaluation, selection and mating systems used in beef, dairy, sheep, swine, poultry, horse and companion animal breeding. Intended for ASI majors and minors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bovine Reproductive Technologies
htmlparse.Course.description: Reproductive technologies used in management of cattle including the physiology of the estrous cycle, embryo viability, and fetal development. Practical training in reproductive management technique.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ASI 400, senior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and five hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beef Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive course covering all phases of the beef cattle industry. Practical application of nutrition, breeding, physiology of reproduction, merchandising, risk management and related areas. Special emphasis on management systems of raising, growing and finishing beef cattle.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Companion Animal Management
htmlparse.Course.description: General biology and management of pets in zoos, kennels and at home. Working safely with companion animals. Management of animals in kennels, shelters, research facilities and zoos. Regulatory issues of small animals used as companion pets and in laboratory research. Interactive discussion and written skills will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended prerequisite: ASI 107.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture/recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horse Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the horse industry in the United States, breed profiles, anatomy and evaluation, nutrition, reproduction, growth and development, health, exercise physiology, facilities and equipment, business considerations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sheep and Meat Goat Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of scientific management principles to the sheep and meat goat industries. Breeding, reproduction, nutrition, health, management and economic aspects as related to sheep and meat goat production.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anatomy and Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: General anatomy and physiology of the domestic animals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Swine Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of basic scientific principles to the economical production of pork. Recommendations are made in breeding, reproduction, nutrition, health, housing, marketing, and management of swine production units of varying sizes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Animal Disease Control
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the factors that influence animal health and disease control for students majoring in agriculture and other fields.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Sciences and Industry Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Career exploration and life skill development. Assist students with internship development, interviewing skills, and professional communication formats. Open only to junior students majoring in animal sciences and industry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ASI major and Junior Standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
One hour recitation a week.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Animal Science and Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: The development and management of current issues affecting animal agriculture and science in three primary areas: 1) how do issues develop; 2) the political aspects of issues; and 3) the development of expertise based on objective assessment. Current issues such as animal welfare/rights, environment, genetic engineering, etc., will be used to provide students with practical learning experiences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioscience Internship in Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised professional experience in bioscience realm of animal sciences. One credit hour per one month full-time supervised and evaluated work hours. Internship proposal, evaluation by supervisor, self-assessment, and presentation of internship required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 total credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Science Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised professional experience in animal science related field. One credit hour per month full-time supervised and evaluated work hours. Internship proposal, evaluation by supervisor, self-assessment and presentation of internship required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of supervising faculty member.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable for maximum 6 total credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Animal Biotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: The objective of this course is to provide insight into the use of animals in areas of biotechnology.  The course will emphasize the use of livestock in food production as well as human medicine applications.  Lectures will include topics such as marker assisted selection of livestock, invitro fertilization, transgenesis, cloning and stem cell technology.  Laboratories will complement material from lectures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: Senior standing, BIOCH 521 and ASI 500.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiology of Lactation
htmlparse.Course.description: Anatomy and embryonic development of the mammary gland, physiology of lactation, milk constituents, and management practices that alter quality and quantity of milk. Contemporary milking practices and mastitis control.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Breeding and Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of genetic and animal breeding principles to the horse.  Emphasis on inheritance of color and diseases, as well as selection and mating programs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: Junior standing.
Recommended prerequisite: ASI 500 and ASI 510.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dairy Foods Processing & Techonology
htmlparse.Course.description: The fundamental technologies used to process high quality dairy foods using freezing, heat membrane and pressure technologies. Changes in milk chemistry, microbiology and structure will be emphasized during the processing of butter, soft and hard cheeses, concentrated milks, ice cream and yogurt.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture and one three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Processed Meat Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: An intensive course in processed meats, relating the science, technology and quality control of curing, smoking and sausage manufacture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beef Systems Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of beef enterprise business plans and analysis of breeding, nutrition, health and management programs for beef operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and five hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dairy Cattle Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of biologic and economic aspects of dairy production with dairy farm organization, planning, operation and analysis. Field trips, dairy farm analysis and case studies will be used to supplement lecture material.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation, two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gamebird Production and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of upland game bird production including incubation and hatching, flight pen construction, nutritional management, predation control, disease management and meat processing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and 2 hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Poultry Products Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on the technical problems that exist between production and consumption during the processing and marketing of poultry meat and egg products. A study of the microbiology of shell eggs, meat and manufactured products and the basic principles of quality assurance. Food manufacturing and product development are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Poultry Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A detailed study of the production and management practices involved in commercial poultry and game bird enterprises.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Identification and Data Management of Food Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: Procedures and the conventions required to accomplish individual identification for farm animals. Principles of sound data collection and management. Principles of automatic information and data capture technologies for transforming data into information. Guest lectures from allied industry and livestock producers will illustrate various products, services and applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Behavior of Domestic Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: Behavior associated with domestication. Effects of selective breeding, physical and social environments, and developmental stage on social organization, aggressive behavior, sexual behavior, productivity and training of domestic animals. Physiology of behavior and abnormal behavior considered briefly.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Growth and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of domestic animal growth and development of muscle, bone, and adipose tissue will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: A course in biochemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Study Experience in Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar and travel course designed to prepare students before the experience and for students to analyze, critique, and report their experiences of an international experience associated with study tours or short courses. Course will focus on appropriate oral and written documentation of the student learning objectives for course experience. The academic topics will vary with each international activity.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Sciences and Industry Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent guided studies in any of the many fields associated with animals and animal products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminars of special interest. Will be offered upon sufficient demand in selected areas relating to animal science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Meat Selection and Utilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on meat cut identification, muscle and bone anatomy, grades, fabricated meat, institutional cuts, specification writing, processing, meat preparation and shrinkage costs.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture-recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Monogastric Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the nutritional principles involved with feeding nonruminants. Topics will include digestive anatomy and the metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, vitamins, and minerals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Avian Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional requirements of game birds, caged birds, exotics, and commercial poultry. Interactive discussion will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Equine digestive anatomy and physiology. Nutrient requirements of the equine as they relate to growth, work, reproduction and lactation, as well as the relationship of nutrition to disease and environment. Practical management considerations and current equine nutrition research will be reviewed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Swine Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the nutrient requirements of swine for various stages of production. Discussion of the interrelationships among nutrition and other factors (environment, management, and health) that affect performance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ruminant Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of nutritional management of different species of ruminant livestock. Topics covered include ruminal function, post-ruminal digestion and absorption, utilization of key nutrients, and discussion of select metabolic disorders.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dairy Cattle Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional management of dairy calves, replacement heifers, dry and lactating dairy cows. Diet formulation, feeding systems and current concepts in dairy cattle nutrition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Formulation of Livestock and Poultry Diets
htmlparse.Course.description: Diet formulation for the major species of livestock and poultry. Major topics include hand formulation of diets: ingredient/nutrient cost comparisons; dry matter manipulation; computerized diet formulation; developing specifications for diets, supplements, basemixes and premixes; projecting animal performance; and feed labeling.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grazing Livestock Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional management of grazing beef cattle. Nutrition of beef cows and stocker cattle maintained under grazing conditions. Major topics to be covered include nutrient requirements, forage intake, forage quality, and supplementation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition of Feedlot Cattle
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional management of growing and finishing beef cattle maintained under confined feeding conditions. Utilization of cereal grains and byproducts in the production of beef. Major topics include nutrient requirements, feed processing, growing-finishing systems, feed additives, metabolic disturbances, and nutrient management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stored Forage Systems for Ruminant Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of nutrient conservation in various stored forage systems including storage facilities and equipment, nutrient loss, aerobic deterioration, chemical and physical analysis. Discussions will also include the impact of stored forage systems on forage quality and the subsequent effects on digestion and utilization in ruminant animals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Equine Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Physiological systems reactions and adaption to exercise and training in the equine athlete.  Additional topics addressed will include biomechanics, injury prevention and rehabilitation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 533, BIOL 198, BIOCH 265 or BIOCH 521.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiology of Reproduction in Farm Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: The physiological aspects of reproduction in farm animals including endocrine inter-relationships controlling reproductive cycles and gamete production. Periodic demonstrations deal with specialized reproductive anatomy of farm animals, experimental techniques used in animal reproduction, and contemporary animal production practices.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anaerobic Bacteriology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of anaerobic bacteria, anaerobiosis, description of anaerobic techniques, and physiology and biochemistry of anaerobes of natural environment including gastrointestinal tract, and of veterinary, medical, and industrial importance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Animal Breeding
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of genetic principles to livestock improvement, selection methods, mating systems, heritability estimates and methods of analyzing genetic data.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 500 and three hours in statistics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Meat Industry Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Apply concepts and information about meat composition, product safety and spoilage, quality; formulation, processing and evaluation of cured, pre-cooked, and sausage packaging, troubleshooting, and plant organization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a web-based lecture class intended for distance education students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Meat Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical, chemical, and microbiological affects of processing technologies on meat products.  Non-meat ingredient functionality, processing techniques, and quality parameters associated with processed meat manufacturing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ASI 350; senior or graduate standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Internship in Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth work-study experiences on beef cattle, sheep, dairy cattle, swine, horse or poultry production operations or in animal food products plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of supervising faculty member.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textiles Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Orientation for incoming first year and transfer students designed to acquaint them with matters related to the apparel and textiles major, to promote active involvement, and to enhance the university experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textile Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the organization and operation of the U.S. apparel and textile industry; examination of the principles and processes required to meet the needs of the apparel/textile consumer.

htmlparse.Course.title: Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of textiles as related to the production, sale, and use of apparel and other products. Laboratory experiences related to the identification of fibers, yarns, and fabrics and to the care and performance of textile products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel Production I
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of apparel production; introduction to garment sizing and fit.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textiles Retailing
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the elements, processes, and controls involved in operating a soft goods retailing business.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AT 245, MATH 100 or 220 with grade of C or higher.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel Consumers and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Cultural, social, psychological, and economic aspects related to apparel needs and consumer behavior of individuals and groups; focus on market segmentation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 or PSYCH 110 and sophomore standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aesthetics of Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Understanding and application of aesthetics as it relates to the roles of the apparel industry professional and the development, selection, and promotion of apparel and textile products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fashion Illustration
htmlparse.Course.description: Fashion illustration, technical apparel drawings, and line development by hand and computer methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Instructor’s permission. Recommended prerequisite: ART 100. Recommended corequisite: ART 190.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel Production II
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate level apparel production focused on increasing knowledge of garment construction and fit; use of challenging fabrics.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Apparel Fashion: Renaissance to Present
htmlparse.Course.description: Interrelationship of costume and social, cultural, political, and economic environments from the Renaissance to present day.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation for internship and professional development in apparel and textile industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours recitation per week.
A graded course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textile Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification and evaluation of apparel product quality and serviceability from the standpoint of fiber, fabric, and construction performance, material and product standards and specifications, and cost.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and 2 hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: New content, technology or theory related to apparel and textiles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for maximum of 8 credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Apparel and Textile Production and Distribution
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of global fiber, textile, and apparel production and distribution; structure of industry and distribution channels; impact of culture, economics, and government regulations on production and distribution.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textile Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Pre-planned and supervised off-campus work experience in the apparel industry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AT 445; AT 655 or 575; junior standing; and instructor’s permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Forecasting
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction of the processes and methods used by the textile and apparel industry to conduct short-term and long-term forecasts. Application of fashion theory and principles, sources of information, knowledge, techniques and skills for planning and implementing fashion projection.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Buying
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the processes and methods used by apparel buyers to purchase merchandise assortments. Application of fashion theory and principles, sources of information, knowledge, techniques and skills for assortment planning, buying, vendor negotiations, and profit planning. Emphasis on merchandising mathematics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer-Aided Design of Apparel
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of computer-aided design as it relates to the apparel industry; development and presentation of apparel and textile design using visual graphic software.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textile Business Strategy
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of the external and internal factors impacting apparel and textile business performance; development and analysis of creative and responsible strategic response.

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Label Apparel Product Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Capstone course using a team approach to synthesize and perform activities used by apparel retailers to create a line of private label merchandise for a targeted consumer market.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AT 460. Corequisite: AT 575 or AT 610.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textiles Study Tour
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised off-campus tour of facilities or equivalent experience where textile products are designed, manufactured, tested, marketed, exhibited, and/or conserved.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for maximum of 6 credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel Pattern Development I
htmlparse.Course.description: Apparel design through flat pattern methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel Pre-Production Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Computer application of pattern drafting, pattern grading, and marker layout for apparel pre-production processes. Computer applications for design development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Technologies for Merchandising
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies in computer-based advertising and promotional strategies for the apparel and textile industry. Students will apply skills to graphic presentation, web design, and current industry technologies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel Pattern Development II
htmlparse.Course.description: Apparel design by draping; line development for a variety of markets; senior project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Advancement in Merchandising
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of leadership in a merchandising form and how it affects organizational culture and change. Various leadership styles will be examined and a personal leadership philosophy will be developed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory and Practice of Apparel/Textile Marketing and Distribution
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical and applied analysis of apparel/textile marketing and distribution strategies, with an emphasis on the effectiveness of a market-oriented approach for decision-making; assessment of environmental forces affecting strategic decisions by firms in the apparel/textile distribution channel; synthesis of past and present trends in order to forecast probable future patterns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Promotional Strategies in Merchandising
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of promotional strategies and techniques used by merchandising firms, emphasizing cultural and global awareness, social responsibility, and ethical decision making.

htmlparse.Course.title: Varsity Baseball
htmlparse.Course.description: Varsity Baseball

htmlparse.Course.title: Varsity Basketball
htmlparse.Course.description: Varsity Basketball

htmlparse.Course.title: Varsity Track Instructor
htmlparse.Course.description: Varsity Track Instructor

htmlparse.Course.title: Varsity Football
htmlparse.Course.description: Varsity Football

htmlparse.Course.title: Varsity Golf
htmlparse.Course.description: Varsity Golf

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Basketball
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate Basketball

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Track
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate Track

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Tennis
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate Tennis

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Volleyball
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate Volleyball

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Rowing
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate Rowing

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Golf
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate Golf

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Biological and Agricultural Engineering and Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to discipline, department, university, and profession.  Exploration of career options.  Gain skills through application-oriented problem solving.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineered Systems and Technology in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course designed for non-engineering majors. This course introduces engineering principles and problem solving associated with energy resources and power systems for agriculture, machinery systems, natural resources and environmental management, and food and fiber processing and storage.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Application Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Systems, components, operation practices, and safety procedures used in the chemical application industry.  Liquid and granular application systems and respective components will be studied along with procedures for equipment sizing and maintenance, minimizing drift, systems calibration, and safe handling, transporting, storage, disposal and spill clean-up of agrichemicals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Application Systems Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory and hands-on activities on pumps, valves, nozzles, drift measurement, and application technology used in the home and garden, turf, private and commercial agricultural, aerial, and research industries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Must be taken concurrent with ATM 250.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sensors and Controls for Agricultural and Biological Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of instrumentation. Sensors used in agricultural machines and processes for measurement of voltage, force, torque, pressure, displacement, velocity, acceleration, flow, temperature, humidity, etc. Analog and digital signal conditioning and processing. Feedback controls concept. Computer interface.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 113 or PHYS 115, ATM 160 or MATH 100.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engines and Power Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, operation, and analysis of engine thermodynamics, fuel and combustion, engine components, engine cycles, engine power transfer and efficiencies, and exhaust gas emissions. Mechanism and selection of bearings, belt drives, chain drives, gear drives, and shaft drives. Operation and performance analysis of hydraulic power transfer components and systems, fluid mechanics, and hydraulic motors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Agricultural Technology Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Intern programs in agricultural technology management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour of credit for each four weeks of supervised and evaluated off-campus work experience with cooperating employers. A maximum of 3 hours may be applied to a BS in agricultural technology management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Building Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Environmental control systems for agricultural buildings; structural members and systems for agricultural buildings; farmstead planning concepts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Agricultural Technology Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in the application of technical principles to agricultural technology management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Processing and Storage of Grains
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of grain and forage conditioning and storage.  Structures and equipment for quality preservation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ATM 160 or PHYS 113 or 115, and senior standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Precision Agriculture Technologies
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of precision technologies for gathering information to assist decision making for production systems. Topics will include global positioning systems, vehicle guidance systems, crop yield monitors, variable rate control systems for applicators, and the communication among these devices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 150 or equivalent, PHYS 113 or PHYS 115, and STAT 325 or 340 or 350.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Erosion and Sediment Pollution Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning and analysis of production systems with respect to regulatory, environmental, and resource management. Water and wind erosion; estimating soil loss; estimating runoff rate and volume; laying out and checking terraces, waterways and farm ponds; agricultural surveying; and conservation planning.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Management and Irrigation Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Management of water in crop production systems, crop water use, and irrigation scheduling. Fundamentals of water flow in pipe networks, pumping plants, and irrigation systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ATM 160 or PHYS 113, AGRON 305, and junior standing or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Management and Irrigation Systems Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory and hands-on activities on soil water balance characteristics, crop water use, water flow in pipe networks, pump hydraulics, sprinkler nozzles, drip irrigation systems, water filtration systems, and chemigation systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Must be taken concurrent with ATM 653, and junior standing or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour lab each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Watershed Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of watershed sources, fate, and transport of pollutants, with focus on issues of the prairie agroecosystem. Impacts of watershed protection and restoration strategies on water and environmental quality. Application of computer models.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Aircraft Electricity
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic concept of DC/AC circuits, with basic laws relating to the following: measuring voltage, current, resistance, continuity and leakage; relationship of voltage, current and resistance in electrical circuits; reading and interpretation of electrical circuit diagrams; electrical devices and inspection and servicing of batteries. Introduction to digital numbering systems and digital logic functions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Welding
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and skill development in aircraft welding processes. Exercises in gas welding processes as applied to ferrous and nonferrous materials. Oxygen/acetylene, inert gas, and resistance welding processes are to be studied.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Drawings
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to teach the student how to recognize and identify each kind of line as it appears in aircraft drawings and to interpret the meaning of the lines as they relate to surfaces and details in drawings.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Standards
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the organization of the Federal Aviation Administration. Emphasis will be placed on regulations, standards, specifications, procedures and the practice of using charts, graphs and drawings. Also included are the introduction to air transport maintenance procedures, weight and balance procedures, aircraft ground operations and the introduction to flight training to include several flights.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Flight lab fees required.
Two hours lecture and six hours of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Fluid Power
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of basic fluid mechanics as it applies to practical applications in aircraft systems. Compressible and incompressible fluid systems will be studied.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Science
htmlparse.Course.description: This is a study of applied mathematics and basic physics. Section one: mathematics will provide the learner with the tools needed to perform the calculations normally confronted by the aviation maintenance technician. Section two: the study of basic science will enable the student to better understand the operation of aircraft and the many complex systems needed to sustain safe flight.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airframe Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the airframe systems and components to include: pressurization, heating and cooling, and structural device.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Maintenance Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to permit the student to learn and practice those skills and techniques essential to the career development of the aviation maintenance technician. The subjects included are: shop safety, aircraft general familiarization, fluid lines and fittings, hand tools and measuring devices, aircraft hardware, cleaning and corrosion control, aircraft metals, inspection fundamentals, ground operation and servicing, and support equipment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airframe Structures and Repair
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of materials commonly used in airframe structures and the associated study of making structural repairs according to recommended procedures. Skills in sheet metal are stressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airframe Electrical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced study of DC/AC circuits law relating to circuit analysis and a detailed study of measuring instruments. Advanced study of relays, switches, alternators, and other devices encountered in circuit analysis, troubleshooting, and repair. Theory of operation and fault isolation on solid-state devices in aircraft circuitry. Inspection of aircraft electrical systems, including wire inspections and the types of repairs allowed, using appropriate technical manuals.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Finish and Fabrication
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to acquaint the student with the wood and fabric coverings and procedures used on aircraft, and methods used in preparation for and application of paint finishes to aircraft surfaces.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Navigational Aids and Communication Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey study of the aids to navigation and communications used in light and intermediate class aircraft. Operation and installation of the various types of equipment will be stressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Navigational Aids and Communication Systems for Avionics
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey study of the aids to navigation and communications used in light and intermediate class aircraft. Operation and installation of the various types of equipment is stressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Inspection and Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of assembly and manufacturing procedures and inspection of aircraft components. This course also covers in detail annual and 100-hour inspections.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study in a specific area chosen by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Propellers
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the use, maintenance, and inspection of propellers and their related control systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Powerplant Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the principles of operation, design features, and operating characteristics of reciprocating aircraft engines. Includes overhaul inspection procedures on current horizontal opposed and radial engines.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Powerplant Operation and Troubleshooting
htmlparse.Course.description: Experience in installation, operation, and removal of aircraft engines. Engine analysis and diagnosis of malfunctions, including methods of remedy, are performed on airworthy engines.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gas Turbine Powerplant
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the fundamentals of gas turbine powerplants including operation, studies of supporting systems and inspection methods are fundamental to this course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Powerplant Induction and Fuel Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of aircraft induction and fuel metering systems including fuels, carburetors, fuel injection systems, superchargers, and other induction system components used to ensure a dependable and accurate fuel supply at any flight configuration and attitude.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Powerplant Ignition and Electrical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of battery, magneto high and low tension ignition systems, including turbine igniters for today’s aircraft. Also a study of powerplant starting and charging systems and related components. Emphasis will be placed on troubleshooting, repair, and timing of aircraft ignition systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Powerplant Overhaul
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience in overhauling reciprocating engines. Engines are assembled and operationally checked in lab.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the student the opportunity for advanced study in a specific topic area or to apply aviation education to the improvement of skills previously learned.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Topics are selected jointly by the student and the instructor.
May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines the history of aviation and a look at the future. Students discuss the attributes of an aviation professional, careers, career planning, and pilot certification. Students consider historical events and their relationship to current aviation aspects. The interdependency and synergy in the development of military aircraft, the space program, as well as the growth of commercial and general aviation is discussed. Students use the Internet for various research projects concerning the past, present, and future of aviation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Air Traffic Control
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory air traffic control (ATC) course that focuses on Terminal, Enroute, and FSS ATC procedures. The course examines the role of an air traffic controller at the various operational positions throughout the ATC system. The course gives an overview of the current U.S. National Airspace System as it relates to ATC procedures. In addition, the course looks at the use of future technologies and how they enhance the ATC system. Off-campus trips contribute to experiential learning.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Meteorology
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic aviation-related meteorology concepts through the study of atmospheric elements and how they generally affect the weather: introduction to the subject, water in the atmosphere, variables which cause local weather changes, specific aviation-associated hazards, understanding meteorological reports and forecasts, meteorological techniques used in predicting weather patterns.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft Electrical, Navigational, and Communication Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides students the basic knowledge of aircraft electrical systems, including navigation, communications, instruments, and power systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Safety and Security of Airport Ground Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: This course discusses general aviation airport ground operations, particularly from the mechanic, pilot, and ramp worker perspective. Focus will be on increasing awareness of airport operations. Attention will be given to improving airport safety by creating an enhanced awareness of rules, policies, procedures, and potential hazards that affect all individuals working in and around the airport ground operations environment. Some topics included are: aircraft marshalling procedures, airfield security issues, ground vehicle operations, and security and accident/incident response reporting.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Unmanned Aerial Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the history of Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) and survey of current UAS platforms, terminology, challenges to airspace integration and operational theory.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Avionics
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers the latest developments and trends in navigation and communication systems. Topics include Future Aviation Navigation Systems (FANS), fiber optics, enhanced vision, ADS-B, the FAA’s NextGen, as well as other advancements in avionics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: AET and FCC Training
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is a self-paced lab that allows students to study for their Aviation Electronics Technician certificate and their Federal Communication Commission license in Elements 1, 3 and 8.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lab a week.
This is a credit/no-credit course and will not affect the student’s GPA.

htmlparse.Course.title: Composites I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to composite materials used in aircraft production; detailed description of different composite materials, and the procedures for installing an antenna to bonded aircraft structures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Avionics Repair
htmlparse.Course.description: An in depth overview of aircraft wiring. Procedures in terminating, repairing, testing and troubleshooting of aircraft wiring, as well as aging wiring inspections.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Avionics Troubleshooting
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth troubleshooting project, requiring critical thinking to analyze the problem and provide the correct repairs.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Factors in Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the physical environment and physiology limitations imposed on the aviation professional. Health, fatigue, human behavior and errors, communication, team building, leadership, situation awareness, crew resource management, judgment, and aeronautical decision making are studied to achieve safe and efficient operation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PPIL 111 or AVT 100, or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Law
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of how the U.S. regulatory and legal systems work in relation to airport management. This course emphasizes contract law related to the Federal Aviation Administration Airport covenants and restrictions, Federal Aviation Regulation compliance and airport operator liability.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Environmental Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to responsibilities, liabilities and public relations when dealing with environmental issues in day-to-day airport operations.  Includes strategies for addressing airport and aircraft noise, wildlife hazard mitigation, compatible land use, wetlands, historical properties and impacts of construction.  Federal regulations and enforcement are studied with emphasis on the Clean Water Act, Clean Air Act, Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Pollution Prevention ACT, and National Historic Preservation Act as they apply to airports.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Unmanned Aerial Systems I
htmlparse.Course.description: UAS mission planning and operations, to include communication, mission planning, navigation, launch/recovery procedures and ground control station operations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerodynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers incompressible flow theory and wing theory as well as calculations of stall speed, drag, and basic performance criteria. This course also examines configuration changes, high and low speed conditions, and special flight operations. Stability and control, weight and balance, and operational data are also examined. Aerodynamic performance of aircraft powered by reciprocating, turboprop, and jet turbine engines are considered. The student will be introduced to aircraft design and high-speed aerodynamics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100; and PPIL 111 or AVM 141.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the student an opportunity to apply their aviation education to the improvement of skills previously learned as designated by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Composites II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of AVT 317 Composites I with an emphasis on repair procedures for composites. This course involves hands-on repair projects that develop repair techniques, such as vacuum bagging and hot bonding.

htmlparse.Course.title: Non-Destructive Testing
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to non-destructive testing and inspection methods in use in the aviation industry. The course will cover the following types of inspection methods: visual, x-ray (radiographic) magnetic particle, ultrasonic, dye penetrant.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AVM 112 and AVM 261; or MET 231 and MET 245.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Maintenance Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides students with an understanding of general aviation and commercial aviation maintenance programs. Includes regulations, maintenance levels, technical publications, quality assurance, inspections, human factors, and unions. It also provides an understanding of the difficulties in managing a line operation. Case studies of maintenance scenarios are used.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Composites III
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on advanced composite inspection techniques, special hardware, and the repair of composite structural components. Involves hands-on repair techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Accident Investigation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide a general understanding of the methods and procedures used in aviation accident investigation. Students in this course will learn methods used to gather and analyze facts of accidents as well as determine probable cause and contributing factors. Procedures and techniques used to determine accident causes will also be analyzed. Historical accident reports from National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and other organizations will be examined.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Avionics Installation
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides practical knowledge of avionics suite installation, to include Garmin.  Students gain experience in installing, wiring, continuity checks, operational checks, and troubleshooting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Avionics Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the basic knowledge to repair and install avionics. Practical experience in troubleshooting and using maintenance test equipment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Avionics Installation
htmlparse.Course.description: Students gain practical knowledge of the Garmin G1000/900X, including installation, wiring, continuity checks, operational checks, software loading, and troubleshooting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Air Transportation
htmlparse.Course.description: This interactive course examines the development of the United States air transportation system, current issues, and the competitive strategies of past and present airline executives; examines the many attributes of starting and operating a successful airline in a competitive market; and explores the role of airport operations and the commercial and corporate aircraft that challenge the air transportation system.

htmlparse.Course.title: Air Carrier Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of Federal Aviation Regulations that influence air carrier and commercial operators. Students will gain an appreciation of the variety of regulatory issues involved in air carrier operations such as certification, training, and operational safety and security requirements. Students will also gather the background information necessary to correlate and apply relevant regulations to daily aviation operations. The course focuses on FAR Part 61, 91, 119, 121, and 135.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PPIL 111 or AVT 100, and junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Air Traffic Control
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of tower, TRACON, and enroute procedures. Also examines the FAA’s future air navigation system concept.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Law
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of how the U.S. regulatory and legal systems work in relation to aviation activities. It is designed to help those in the aviation industry understand their rights, liabilities, and responsibilities and avoid common legal pitfalls. Emphasis will also be placed on aircraft ownership, registration, and insurance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Corporate and Business Aviation Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the history of corporate and business aviation, the regulation of the industry, and the operation and management of corporate and business flight departments. Students will receive an overview of the social, economic, and political effects of business aviation. Aircraft selection and utilization, maintenance responsibilities, fiscal considerations, fractional ownership, and passenger and crew safety and security measures will also be studied.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Legislation
htmlparse.Course.description: Students are required to take part in the University Aviation Association’s Annual Seminar on Establishing Aviation Policy during the first full week of January in Washington, D.C.  Students prepare for the seminar with required reading assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Safety Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A course designed to assist the student to develop an attitude and philosophy for accident prevention. The course includes ideal and practical, personal and organizational safety procedures and goals; safety philosophies; aircraft accident reports; human factors; principles of accident investigation; accident prevention program and accident statistics; current events; NTSB special studies. The safety program is analyzed from the theoretical and philosophic points of view. A safety program is developed with an examination of safety concepts, the human elements of accidents, managing a safety office in an organization, and current events.

htmlparse.Course.title: System Safety
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the system safety discipline. Students will learn how the system safety process is used in accident prevention and examine its role in management. Students will also examine various aircraft systems for overall safety of operation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Trends and Issues in Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course explores current trends and issues in the aviation industry. Emphasis is placed on discussing current issues that are impacting the world aviation marketplace. Students will address these issues and trends from the standpoint of application to their career, relevance to the economic viability of the industry, and the impact such trends place on aircraft operators and manufacturers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Unmanned Aerial Systems II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced UAS planning and operations. Topics include normal/abnormal and emergency procedures, safety/air vehicle pilot checklist procedures, and software-in-the-loop/hardware-in-the loop simulated missions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Planning and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An in depth overview of the Federal Aviation Regulation Part 139 airport design standard as well as a study of both landside and airside airport business management.  Includes a study of the role of the airport in community development. Major course project required.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Certified Manager
htmlparse.Course.description: Guided Study for the American Association of Airport Executives (AAAE) Certified manager (CM) test.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AVT 250, AVT 446, AVT 440, AVT 445, AVT 461, and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Unmanned Aerial Systems Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Allows the UAS major to become familiar with the latest UAS technologies and their associated systems integration architectures as well as deployment procedures.  Topics include: Current Federal Aviation Administration policies and regulations affecting UAS, current and emerging technologies, as well as emerging and future technologies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course is primarily laboratory based.

htmlparse.Course.title: Helicopter Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced study of the major components of rotary-winged aircraft to include airframe, rotor, transmission and engine components of turbine and reciprocating engine helicopters. Also includes a detailed study and validation of all Federal Aviation Administration required documentation related to maintenance, historical records, and inspection of components.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AVM 111, 121, 131, 141, 151 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and 4 hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Project
htmlparse.Course.description: This culminating experience is a sustained occasion when students will put into independent practice the intellectual, creative, and expressive skills/knowledge they have cultivated in their undergraduate curriculum. In this course students integrate discipline-specific knowledge in addition to communication and inquiry methods to solve problems and communicate mastery of their respective area of interest.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and instructor consent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Research, scholarly and creative activities in the aviation field. Working with faculty on a current research project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The specific course content varies in accordance with current projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Master Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the requirements and resources used to plan, fund and construct airport projects or modifications to show the airport manager’s role in project development. Components and organization of the Airport Master Plan (AMP) and Airport Layout Plan (ALP) are studied in outlines and existing plans to show applicability to local conditions and with emphasis on FAR Part 77 and AC 150/5300-13.
