Typical projects are reviewed for Airport Capital Improvement Funding and utilization of Computer Assisted Design (CAD). Student case study research will be integrated to assess a project’s feasibility.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation of professional problems and practices by students, faculty, and professionals associated with the career of biological and agricultural engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. One hour lecture a month.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Biological and Agricultural Engineering and Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to discipline, department, university, and profession. Exploration of career option. Gain skills through application-oriented problem solving.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Design for Biological and Agricultural Engineers
htmlparse.Course.description: Gain skills in biological and agricultural engineering topics through experiential design labs, application-oriented problem solving, computer use, teamwork, and written and oral communication.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Systems Engineering Project I
htmlparse.Course.description: Completion of a team-oriented design project, with emphasis on applying computer tools to problem solving in biological systems engineering.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour lab a week

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Systems Engineering Project II
htmlparse.Course.description: Completion of a team-oriented design project, with emphasis on systems design, data collection, and quantitative analysis related to biological systems engineering.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Properties of Biological Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Characterization of biological material properties that affect the design and analysis of material handling equipment and processes. Physical, electrical, thermal, mechanical, aerodynamic, hygroscopic, and rheological properties of grain and other agricultural products will be examined.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Machinery Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic power and energy concepts. Machinery systems for tillage, planting, and harvesting crops. Impact of these systems on the environment and natural resources.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Machinery Systems Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic power and energy concepts. Machinery systems for tillage, planting, and harvesting crops. Impact of these systems on the environment and natural resources.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Must be taken concurrent with BAE 350.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Biological and Agricultural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. Open to students in the college of engineering honors program. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structures and Environment Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Environmental control for agricultural buildings and structures; analysis and design of structural systems and members for agricultural structures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ME 513 and CE 333 or CE 530.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Systems Engineering Senior Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Team-oriented design laboratory, with projects selected to address design of equipment or systems to produce or process food, fiber, and energy, or to preserve environmental quality, remediate damage, and conserve natural resources.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BAE 331 and one of the following courses: ME 533, BAE 545, BAE 560.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three 3-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Process Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and design of biological and agricultural processes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CHE 320 or ME 571.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resource Engineering I
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and measures for controlling storm water runoff and soil erosion including hydrology and surface water flow; design of water handling structures for land drainage, flood protection, and irrigation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: STAT 490. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ME 571.
Not available for students with credit for CE 550.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Agricultural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in the design, construction, or application of machinery or power in agriculture, structures, modern conveniences, and rural electrification.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Systems Engineering Design Project
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of BAE 536. Completion of a team-oriented design project, with emphasis on construction, evaluation, documentation, and presentation of the design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BAE 536 or other approved capstone design course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumentation and Control for Biological Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of instrumentation and control engineering applied in biological and agricultural systems and processes. Time-domain analysis and frequency response methods. Sensors and actuators in feedback control systems. Control system design. Case studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECE 510 or ECE 519, and MATH 240.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Conversion of Biorenewable Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the conversion of biorenewable resources into biobased products and biofuels.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Life Cycle Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the process and methodologies associated with life cycle analysis. Application of the methods developed in the course to a project to gain experience in defining and quantifying uncertainty associated with human perturbation, management and utilization of biofuels and other complex processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Energy and Biofuel Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Energy use and production in agriculture and related industries. Energetics of primary production, including crop energy conversion. Energy and material balances of biomass energy production and processing systems, including energy embodied in fertilizers and pesticides. Review of the role of fossil fuels in agricultural and forestry operations, including opportunities for energy conservation. Impact of alternative fuels on internal combustion engine emissions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Air Pollution Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Air pollution legislation, standards, measurement, and terminology. Design and economics of particulate pollution control systems including cyclones, fabric filters, wet scrubbers, and electrostatic precipitators. Abatement of gas and vapor pollution using VOC incineration, gas adsorption and gas absorption. Meteorology and atmospheric dispersion modeling.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resource Engineering II
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and operative problems on the fundamentals of irrigation/water application system design and management. Field water balances; sources of water and water quality; pipeline, pump, and system hydraulic design; design of irrigation/water application systems; filtration systems and water treatment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BAE 560 or CE 550. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ME 571.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental and Ecological Risk Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of processes and methodologies associated with human environmental and ecological risk assessments. Application of the methods learned to a project to gain experience in defining and quantifying uncertainty associated with human perturbation, management and restoration of environmental and ecological processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecological Engineering Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Definition, classification, and practice of ecological engineering. Course describes ecological systems, ecosystem restoration, and the utilization of natural processes to provide societal services and benefits to nature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 221 and one of the following courses: BAE 560, CE 563, BIOL 529, BIOL 612, ATM 661.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Watershed Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and evaluation of process equations used in watershed-scale, water-quality models. Use and application of watershed models.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOG 508 and one of the following courses: BAE 560, CE 550, ATM 661.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biomaterials Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Technologies of bio-based material processing including starch extraction (wet milling), plant oil extraction and refining, plant protein extraction and processing, cellulose processing, biofuel production, chemicals bioconversion, and drying technologies or biomaterials.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BAE 500 or BAE 575 or GRSC 602.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis and Design of Off-Highway Vehicles
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytical study of design, testing, construction, and operating characteristics of off-highway vehicles and machinery. Includes human factors, mobility, and precision agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Engineering Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current advances in research and practice of environmental engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. One hour seminar biweekly.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Engineering Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current advances in research and practice of environmental engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour seminar biweekly.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geoenvironmental Engineering Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone design project in geoenvironmental engineering focused on resolving issues related to containment of pollutants and remediation of soil and groundwater.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite one of the following: AGRON 605, AGRON 746, BAE 690, CE 625, CE 654, CHE 531, or GEOL 611.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of biochemistry as a discipline in the life sciences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Biochemically oriented topics related to aspects of daily living. Development of knowledge and skills for understanding bioscience information in news media and the Internet. Selected biochemical concepts with applications to humans, such as: chemical principles and biomolecules, nutrition/diets, growth and aging, disease, fermentation, drug action, medical diagnostics and forensics, and bioethics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Intended for non-science majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry and Society Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Experiments to promote understanding of chemicals and reactions in living systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lab a week.
Intended for non-science majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Organic and Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: For students in human ecology, nursing, and other areas desiring an integrated organic and biochemistry course to provide an understanding of carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, and digestive and metabolic systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and discussions on basic topics in biochemistry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Lecture, guided reading, and discussion of topics of general interest in biochemistry. Topics will vary depending on the interests and backgrounds of students enrolled.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
May be used by honors students to satisfy BS requirement for BIOCH 799.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic study of the chemistry and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: General Biochemistry Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A one semester laboratory course with experiments relating to carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, and enzymes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 351 and BIOCH 521 or concurrent enrollment, or BIOCH 765 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medical Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers medically related concepts, structures, pathways and mechanisms in biochemistry. Addresses the fundamental biochemistry behind veterinary, medical or dental topics and issues. Instructs in the fundamental principles of protein structure and function, enzymology, carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, hormones, biochemical energetics, membranes, nucleic acid and protein metabolism, information transfer and the genetic code, genomic and proteomic analyses, the interdependence of biochemical pathways, pathogenesis and additional new topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Serves as preparatory for the MCAT/DAT/GRE examinations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Training in Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides laboratory experience for majors and nonmajors in research techniques contributing to ongoing biochemical research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background adequate for relevant techniques.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated up to 8 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to physical methods, kinetics, and thermodynamics of biochemical reactions and bioenergetics, chemistry of proteins and amino acids, carbohydrate chemistry, and metabolism. BIOCH 755 and 765 are for students interested in a two-semester comprehensive coverage of biochemistry. For a one-semester course, enroll in BIOCH 521.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Chemical analysis, one year of organic chemistry, differential and integral calculus.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Non-majors lacking these prerequisites should obtain consent of instructor before enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry I Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: An intensive laboratory course to accompany BIOCH 755. BIOCH 756 and 766 are sequential courses for students interested in a two-semester comprehensive coverage of experiments in biochemistry. For a one-semester laboratory course, enroll in BIOCH 522.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: *BIOCH 755 or concurrent enrollment.
*Non-majors lacking these prerequisites should obtain consent of instructor before enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: NMR Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic methods and strategies of nuclear magnetic resonance used in the study of biological molecules. Principles and applications of simple one-dimensional and two-dimensional NMR experiments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two three-hour laboratories per week. Meets second half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Protein Structure Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and uses of computational and experimental approaches for studying peptide and protein structure and dynamics: computer modeling and simulation techniques, fluorescence and circular dichroism spectroscopies, microcalorimetry, and analytical ultracentrifugation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two three-hour laboratories per week. Meets first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of BIOCH 755; lipid chemistry and metabolism, amino acid metabolism, nutrition, nucleic acid chemistry and metabolism, integration of biochemical pathways and metabolic control mechanisms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Non-majors lacking these prerequisites should obtain consent of instructor before enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Recombinant DNA Laboratory I
htmlparse.Course.description: Biochemical manipulation of nucleic acids. Isolation and restriction enzyme characterization of plasmid DNA, ligation of DNA fragments to vector DNA, polymerase chain reaction, Southern blot analysis, DNA sequencing and analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two three-hour labs per week. Meets first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Recombinant DNA Laboratory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Approaches to study RNA and proteins using recombinant DNA techniques. RNA extraction and affinity isolation of mRNA, Northern blot analysis, cDNA library construction and screening, bacterial or eukaryotic expression systems, purification and characterization of recombinant proteins, site-directed mutagenesis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two three-hour labs per week. Meets second half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Biophysics
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey if the biophysical methods most frequently encountered in biochemistry and related disciplines. It summarized concepts and techniques of physical science used in studying the structure and function of biomacromolecules such as proteins and DNA. Applications include classical equilibrium thermodynamics and analytical methods like mass spectrometry and circular dichroism (CD), fluorescence, EPR and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The class emphasizes the underlying principles and techniques used in determining the molecular weight and shape of biopolymers, biochemical mechanisms of action, and observation of conformational changes in macromolecules.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of biophysical methods most frequently encountered in biochemistry and related disciplines. Emphasizes principles underlying methods used in determining the molecular weight and shape of biopolymers and techniques used in detecting conformational changes in nucleic acids, proteins, and polysaccharides.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Problem may include laboratory and/or library work in various phases of biochemistry, agricultural chemistry, or nutrition.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: *Background adequate for problem undertaken.
*Non-majors lacking these prerequisites should obtain consent of instructor before enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course for majors and non-majors focusing on plants, animals and microbes. Specific areas covered include biological molecules, cells, genetics, energy flow, physiology, ecology, and evolution.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two two-hour studio sessions incorporating lecture and lab elements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Biology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course for majors and non-majors focusing on plants, animals and microbes. Specific areas covered include biological molecules, cells, genetics, energy flow, physiology, ecology, and evolution.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two two-hour studio sessions incorporating lecture and lab elements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organismic Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the structure and function of organisms with special attention paid to the phylogenetic origins of taxonomic groups and the integration of their structural systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and four hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Ornithology
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification of bird species in the field and the illustration of attributes of avian behavior and ecology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecology of Environmental Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of ecology and their application to such problems as pollution, human population growth, and land-use planning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in natural science.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour discussion a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions of the developments and use of biomedical technology and its social, moral, and ethical impact on the human spectrum from conception to death.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic Botany
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin and uses of cultivated plants useful to humans, especially grains, legumes, spices, beverage plants, fibers, and dyes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental concepts of human infectious and organic diseases with emphasis on disease etiology and mechanisms, collection of epidemiological data, and the influences upon, and consequences of, governmental public health policy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structure and Function of the Human Body
htmlparse.Course.description: Anatomy and physiology of the organ systems of the human body. Laboratory includes physiology experiments, study of anatomy from human cadavers, dissection experience, x-rays, and slide work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Cumulative GPA of 2.75 or better; BIOL 198 taken at K-State (with a B grade or better) or transferred introductory biology credit plus at least one of the following introductory natural science courses, taken at K-State, with a B grade or better: CHM 110 (with CHM 111), CHM 210, PHYS 113, or any K-State biology course that has BIOL 198 as a prerequisite.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours lecture and two three-hour lab sessions a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience as a teaching assistant in biology courses. Approximately 3 hours of commitment per week is expected for each credit hour earned.  One hour recitation a week plus three to nine hours lab a week.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor and credit with superior performance in the course in which the student will be involved.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Special course offering in an area of faculty expertise and/or supervised independent study project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Biology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Special course offering in an area of faculty expertise and/or supervised independent study project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biology of Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to theories, both physiological and evolutionary, proposed to explain the aging phenomena. Major emphasis on a systems approach, e.g., circulatory, nervous, etc. A coverage of each system includes a review of normal structure and function, age related changes and age related dysfunctions and diseases.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198; and GERON 315 or a second course in biology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Biology of the Cancer Cell
htmlparse.Course.description: Current concepts of cancer biology including roles of cell surfaces, cell division, viruses, self-recognition, and chemical carcinogens.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Wildlife and Fisheries Conservation
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the ecological and management principles associated with the fields of fisheries, wildlife, and conservation biology. Topics include population ecology and assessment, resource management, and environmental legislation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the principles and mechanisms of inheritance at both the organismic and molecular levels. Provides an integrated approach to transmission genetics and the fundamentals of molecular biology. Topics covered include Mendelian inheritance, DNA and chromosome structure, gene expression, mutation, recombinant DNA, quantitative inheritance, population, and evolutionary genetics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one hour recitation/studio.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Microorganisms; their handling, morphology, growth, and importance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198 and one course in chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised independent study project and/or special course offering in an area of faculty expertise.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual directed research and study of a topic in biology, normally as a prerequisite to writing a senior honor thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, membership in the honors program of the College of Arts and Sciences, and permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Detailed consideration of physiological processes of higher plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198 and BIOCH 265 or another course in organic chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developmental Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the stages and mechanisms of embryonic animal development. Integrated approach that includes classic experimental embryology and the genetic and molecular regulation of invertebrate and vertebrate animal development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developmental Biology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Developmental Biology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.notes: One three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiological Adaptations of Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of physiological mechanisms as the basis for adaptive responses of animals to different environments.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 201; and a course in organic chemistry or biochemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiological Adaptations of Animals Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Physiological Adaptations of Animals Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.notes: One three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Behavioral Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the social, environmental, genetic, and evolutionary processes that affect animal behavior. Topics include: evolution of social organization, spacing and group behavior, mating systems and parental care, sexual selection, communication, aggression, habitat selection, and foraging. Research project required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Evolution
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the theory of evolution including its historical and social implications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 450 or a course in genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary examination of organisms and their interaction with the environment, ecosystem structure and function, population ecology and demography, community structure and dynamics, and basic ecological principles and their relevance to contemporary environmental issues.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathogenic Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Etiology and descriptions of major infectious diseases of humans within the perspective of host defenses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour laboratory-demonstration a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cell Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure and function of cells and subcellular components. A molecular understanding of membranes and cellular physiology will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ichthyology
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematics, morphology, physiology, distribution, and natural history of fishes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ornithology
htmlparse.Course.description: Classification, morphology, physiology, distribution, and natural history of birds.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mammalogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Characteristics, evolution, life histories, and ecology of mammals, especially North American game species.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Parasitology
htmlparse.Course.description: Protozoan and helminth parasites of humans with lesser emphasis on ectoparasitic arthropods. Emphasis on life cycles, control, and laboratory diagnosis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Parasitology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of prepared materials and identification of internal parasites of man.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lower Plants
htmlparse.Course.description: Morphology, adaptive mechanisms, and evolutionary relationships of the cellular and vascular cryptograms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Taxonomy of Flowering Plants
htmlparse.Course.description: Morphology, taxonomy, and biogeography of the vascular plants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two three-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Oncology
htmlparse.Course.description: Etiology and pathogenesis of human cancer with emphasis on the biological, biochemical, and molecular mechanisms involved in the multistage process of tumorigenesis and the role of biological, chemical, and physical carcinogens in neoplasia.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in biology and a course in organic chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biology of the Fungi
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to fungal structure, function, physiology, ecology, and genetics. Importance of fungi as disease organisms, as saprotrophs, and in industry. Techniques of isolation, cultivation, and as experimental organisms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cellular and Molecular Biology of Human Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental basis of the major common non-infectious diseases and disorders affecting our society, with emphasis on the biochemical and molecular biological mechanisms by which the structures and functions of specific human tissues, organs and systems are altered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Freshwater Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic ecological principles of aquatic environments and environmental applications. Plants and animals of local streams, rivers, ponds, and reservoirs are used to demonstrate the interaction of biological processes with the chemical and physical features of natural aquatic environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, three hours lab a week; two optional weekend field trips.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cellular and Developmental Biology of the Nervous System
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the cellular and molecular biology and embryology of developing brains and nervous systems of vertebrates and some model invertebrates.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Parasitology
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology and pathology of the principal protozoan, helminth, and arthropod parasites of domestic animals and wildlife.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory and field experiences with ecological problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Population Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the theories of quantitative population biology including dynamics, demography and genetics. Emphasis on spatio-temporal variation within and among populations and species.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Conservation Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Biological diversity and the factors contributing to loss of biodiversity. Scientific principles of biological conservation emphasizing the application of ecological theory and population genetics to the conservation of threatened populations, species and ecosystems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Immunology
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemical, genetic, and biological properties of the immune response, acquired immunity, and antibody production.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in biology; and a course in biochemistry or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Immunology Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory exercises in immunology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three-hour lab a week plus one hour recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Genetics of Microorganisms
htmlparse.Course.description: The genetics of bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms. Both the use of genetics in microbiological studies and the use of microbial systems to investigate basic genetic problems will be covered.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Genetics Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course in the techniques of molecular genetics and recombinant DNA technology, including molecular cloning, library screening, polymerase chain reaction, and RFLP and DNA sequence analysis. A number of projects will be completed during the semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One-hour lecture and two three-hour labs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fish Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: The interaction between fish and their environment. Exploring fundamental ecological processes in aquatic systems at individual, population, community and ecosystem scales.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wildlife Management and Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts and techniques of wildlife ecology and management with emphasis on North American game species. Applied population dynamics as they relate to historical and recent developments in wildlife management, habitat improvement, and related material.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, one hour recitation, and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microbial Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: The ecology of aquatic and terrestrial microorganisms in their natural environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microbial Physiology and Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of structure, function, regulation, and intermediary metabolism of bacteria.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fisheries Management and Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical and contemporary issues in the management and conservation of exploited fishes. Methods for managing fisheries resources in streams, lakes, and ponds including estimating abundances, quantifying age and growth, manipulating populations, modeling population dynamics, culturing fishes, and improving aquatic habitat.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Special course offering in an area of faculty expertise and/or supervised independent study project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Undergraduate research project pursued under the direction of a faculty mentor. A minimum of 45 hours of research effort is expected over the semester for each credit hour the student is enrolled.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Attendance at seminars or journal clubs with topics of a biological nature. A summary and personal reflection on each meeting is submitted for course credit.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiation Safety in the Research Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of radioactive safety and isotope handling, licensing procedures, and laboratory techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198 or 455; and CHM 210 or PHYS 113.

htmlparse.Course.title: Eukaryotic Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: An integrated exploration of transmission genetics and molecular genetics of eukaryotic organisms. The focus will be on genetic model organisms and their contributions to our understanding of mechanisms of genetic transmission and exchange, mutagenesis, gene expression, and regulation of cell division and development. Modern approaches to genomic analysis will be discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Cell Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected current topics in cell biology which reflect recent advances in the field. Major topics include membranes and transport, protein sorting, signal transduction, cell adhesion and motility, cell cycle, apoptosis, and specialized cell functions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Endocrinology
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the glands of internal secretion in vertebrates with emphasis on mechanisms of control of hormone secretion and mechanisms of hormone action.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198; and a course in organic chemistry or biochemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anaerobic Bacteriology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of anaerobic bacteria, anaerobiosis, description of anaerobic techniques, and physiology and biochemistry of anaerobes of the natural environment, including the gastrointestinal tract, and of veterinary, medical and industrial importance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Virology
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical and experimental basis of virology, with emphasis on how viruses manipulate cells to insure their own survival, mechanisms of virus replication, principles of virus host interactions including how viruses cause disease, and selected medically relevant viruses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Twelve hours of biological sciences, including BIOL 450 and 455; and BIOCH 521 or equivalent; consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Virology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the techniques used in virus propagation, detection, and quantification. Emphasis will be placed on the methodology used to study virus replication and virus-host cell interactions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One-hour lecture and three-hour lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Genomics and Bioinformatics
htmlparse.Course.description: A problem solving approach to understanding genomics and bioinformatics. Practical use of databases and web-based tools used to study biological problems. Introduction to the algorithms behind these tools.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cancer Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Current methods of cancer management with emphasis on the kinetic principles of chemotherapy and radiation therapy; diagnosis; surgical oncology; oncologic emergencies; adverse effects of cancer therapy; and the new therapies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Business
htmlparse.Course.description: This course surveys the objectives, decisions, and activities within a business organization. Topics include a study of management responsibilities and controls, organizational structures, and marketing activities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of business topics such as alternative forms of business organizations; typical business practices; legal instruments such as notes, bonds, and stocks; and financial statements and analysis. The main objective is to develop the ability to provide information to stockholders, creditors, and others who are outside an organization.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Managerial Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: This course outlines the use of internal accounting data by managers in directing the affairs of business and non-business organizations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervisory Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of the responsibilities and work environment of a supervisor, with an examination of skills, practices, and concepts helpful in developing effective relations with people in today’s changing environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 100; and COMM 105 or COMM 106.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: The course includes an international emphasis using South Asia as a case study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Total Quality Management for Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses the commitment of management and the organization as a whole to the cultural changes necessary to implement quality improvements throughout the organization. Topics include quality organization and philosophy, quality audit and ISO 9000 series, integration of functional areas, team building, management principles, quality costs, and other associated interactive facets of Total Quality Management. The main concern is to provide the student with a working knowledge of conventional TQM tools.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation to Community Development
htmlparse.Course.description: An Introduction to the Community Development program. Focus is on on-line delivery methods, graduate level research and writing, and technology skills necessary for student success in the program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Native Community Development
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is a base knowledge course for students currently working with native communities. Students taking this course will develop a basic understanding within the context of community development of the diversity of tribal structures and cultures and the unique history and jurisdictional considerations of these nations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Native Communities and Economic Capacity
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will focus on non-western approaches to helping native communities build their capacity. Students will learn to take a participatory, culture-centered, and strength-based approach to development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Indian Country Agriculture and Natural Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the historical and contemporary issues related to natural resource management on Native American lands. Study will include a variety of ecological settings across Native American lands, along with an analysis of tribal sovereignty as it relates to land tenure and water rights. Arguments concerning natural resource conservation, preservation and extraction will be explored.

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth Development in Native Communities
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on contemporary issues impacting native youth including: Demographics (Criminal justice, early parenting, poverty, education, suicide and morbidity), identity formation (risky behavior and achievement opportunities), health care (diabetes, obesity, fetal alcohol), prevention activities (4H, BGC, horse clubs, running strong), and influx of youth leadership (youth-elder connections).

htmlparse.Course.title: Wellness in Native Communities: Challenges and Opportunities
htmlparse.Course.description: Healthcare issues challenging Native communities, and strategies and practices to address those challenges. Focus on the impact of the Indian Health System, other bureaucratic systems, and current consumer practices that impact healthcare for Native peoples and the ways tribes are working to create healthier communities and improve the lifestyle of Indian people.

htmlparse.Course.title: Role of Tribal Colleges in Economic Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus: the role of tribally-chartered colleges/universities in economic development within Native communities. Topics include the use of bonding/bridging social capital, the historical and contemporary case for tribally-chartered higher education, the economic impact of tribal colleges on their local economies, and opportunities/challenges of broad and diverse collaborative networks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecological Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Synthesis across the notion of “utility” as represented in environmental/natural resource economics, as well as the notion of “ecology” in ecological economics. Focus will be on the influence the community and ecosystem have on one another, and the potential for complementarity between the two.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sustainable Communities
htmlparse.Course.description: The management of natural capital as linked to other community-based actions around resource allocation and the impacts on quality of life. The literature on community-based natural resource management will be examined and alternative ways of valuing natural capital will be assessed. Contrasting theories of the role of natural capital in communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Impact Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: The basics of economics and fiscal impact analysis are explored, including the scenario construction, basics of input-output analysis, careful use of multipliers, estimations of local revenues and expenditures and discounting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Local Economic Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: This course teaches economic base theory, a theory of regional economics, multipliers and how local economics are affected by external events. Basic methods for the analysis of a local economy are covered, including trend analysis, location quotients, shift share analysis and retail trade analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Developer as Community Educator
htmlparse.Course.description: A graduate level course on education strategies and tools for use in community development. This course will develop students’ identities as community educators and provide knowledge on appropriate methodologies for working with adults in community settings as well as develop their creativity and critical thinking skills. Students will engage in peer-to-peer teaching and critical analysis of community education activities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Participatory Action Research Methods (PAR)
htmlparse.Course.description: A graduate level course to develop participatory action research knowledge and skills through real-world applications. PAR is a method of collecting information by community members in collaboration with a researcher that respects, places community central to, and reflects the experiences and culture of the people most directly impacted by the issue under consideration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Governance and the Community Development Process
htmlparse.Course.description: Course focus is on the understanding of the various levels of government and the diversity of governmental forms across the states, reservations, and among nations. Students will compare roles of governments in international settings in relation to community development, and study strategies of evaluating policies that impact community development opportunities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership for Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Course focus is on the role of leadership in community development and change, including situating leadership in the community development process, reviewing the effectiveness of different leadership styles, and relating leadership to community. Skills and processes that facilitate effective shared leadership, including facilitation, conflict resolution, use of participatory techniques, etc, are explained.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonprofit Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Managing nonprofits including the role of nonprofit organizations in addressing various social problems. Focus: growth of the nonprofit sector and impact on the community as a source of citizen empowerment. Topics include individual giving/volunteering, board and executive leadership, government and nonprofit relationship, ethics and accountability, and issues and challenges in nonprofit management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grantwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: The intricacies of grantsmanship provide the focus of this course. Topics covered will include identification of fund sources, procedures for proposal preparation, composition of grants, and the effects of organizational and personal linkages. Students will prepare a grant application based upon an RFP or to a continuous funding source.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Leadership and Capacity Building
htmlparse.Course.description: Explorations of the various approaches to leadership and leadership development, evaluation of leadership projects and the relationship of leadership to community capacity building. Topics include defining leadership and applying it to the workplace, and understanding the potential link between leadership and community capacity, as well as identifying strategies for leadership development in communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Immigrants in Communities
htmlparse.Course.description: International migration has historically impacted rural and urban communities around the world. Taking a comparative approach, this course examines community-immigrant interactions and influences on community development and immigrant inclusion. Readings relate theories of immigrant and community change to case studies. Students will gather primary data to assess the capacity of communities to include new international immigrants.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Economic Development for the 21st Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the basic theories, concepts, and skills necessary to be a part of a productive community economic development team. Focus is on the importance of organizational values, mission and vision, as well as six approaches to development. The course will cover the five community functions, development strategies, action planning, and organizing for action.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic Development Strategies and Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: Course explores theories of local economic development and addresses the development issues faced by communities in the 21st century. Students will understand and apply concepts from economic development planning, economic analysis, business development, human resource development, community-based development, and high-technology development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Land Development Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the process of land development in the United States, and its impacts from the perspective of developers, financial institutions, community planners, and city administrators. Focus is on the understanding of the land development process in meeting community goals, and shaping land development to meet community expectations for the improvement of the community.

htmlparse.Course.title: Policy and Politics of Coastal Areas
htmlparse.Course.description: One half of the world’s population lives on a coast and two-thirds of the world’s largest cities are located on a coast. This course addresses the environmental, land use, and other critical issues affecting these areas worldwide.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Community Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study on special topics of interest in community development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of a minimum of fifteen (15) credit hours in the Community Development program and proposal acceptance by their academic advisor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizing for Community Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the role of society in community planning efforts. Focus on change within communities and the roles of government, planners, and citizens in reacting to or shaping change. Dimensions of social capital and the context of change and the implications of economic and demographic shifts on strategies and tactics for change will be explored.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to research methods relevant to community development. Topics include how to formulate and begin a research effort, methods of data collection and how conceptual frameworks are used to develop the questions and analyze data. Also included are strategies for reporting findings and applying findings in community action.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CDPLN 705 or concurrent enrollment, access to and proficiency in using an office productivity suite of software, including word processing and spreadsheets (such as Microsoft Office XP).

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles and Strategies of Community Change
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of the principles and practices of community change and development, using case studies and the students’ communities of reference. the course will relate Community Development approaches to conceptual models from diverse disciplines. Conceptual models include conflict, neo-classical economic growth, participatory democracy, and others.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community and Regional Economic Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: The course introduces concepts of communities and regions, theories of economic growth, drivers of economic growth, the economic base of a community, sources of growth or decline in the community, roles of local government and institutions, analytical tools, and strategies for local economic development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community and Regional Economic Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will develop a substantive grounding in the theories and practice of measuring community economic dynamics plus build solid foundation skills for applied community economic analysis. Elements include basic descriptive tools of community economic analysis, such as economic base evaluation, industrial mix analysis, trade area assessment, and industrial and occupational composition analysis, input-output industrial accounting for economic impact analysis and the development of fiscal impact assessment techniques, and measures of public policy effectiveness.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community and Natural Resource Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the breadth of consideration involved in community resource management. Included are theoretical frameworks, methodological investigation and applied practices to enhance the ability of community development professionals to work with their communities to plan, develop, and monitor the conversion and development of natural resources with multiple functions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Community Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of selected concepts and trends in community development. Students electing this course offering will be preparing a specialization paper as their final project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of a minimum of twenty (20) credit hours in the Community Development program, and proposal acceptance by their academic advisor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Community Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Original research and advanced study in community development, and related fields for the master’s report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of a minimum of twenty (20) credit hours in the Community Development program and proposal acceptance by their academic advisor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: Engineering Assembly
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to careers in civil engineering (environmental, geotechnical, structures, transportation, and water resources). Overview of CE educational requirements. History of the CE profession. Engineering ethics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Civil Engineering Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will include drafting, technical sketching, projective geometry, multiview drawings, reading and interpreting drawings, sectioning, dimensioning, and computer aided design (CAD) to produce basic civil engineering drawings.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
The course will be taught in one lecture and one lab per week.
The following Student Outcome applies: 1.4.
Each student will demonstrate the ability to use modern computational, laboratory, and field techniques/tools used in civil engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Surveying Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Coordinates, directions, distances, and elevation. transverses. boundary surveys. Leveling, national rectangular coordinate systems. property descriptions: public land subdivision and metes and bounds. Topographic surveys. surveying, planning, and estimating.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil and Foundation Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: The origin, distribution, and predictable variation of soil; soil testing and mechanics as applied to practical problems; soil investigations; foundation types, application, and construction; ground water, drainage, and dewatering; earth moving including stable cuts in embankments.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Not open to engineering students.
Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strength of Materials A
htmlparse.Course.description: Behavior of materials subjected to tension, compression, shear, and bending; design of beams and columns.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strength of Materials A Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Tests to determine the physical properties of various structural materials. Analysis and interpretation of test data.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 120 or 100 with grade of A or B, and one course in graphics. Prerequisite or concurrent enrolllment: CE 331.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statics
htmlparse.Course.description: Composition and resolution of forces; equilibrium of force systems; application of general laws of statics to engineering problems, including use of vector algebra, friction and force analyses of simple structures, cables, and machine elements; center of gravity; moments of inertia.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Route Location and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Highway location and the geometric design of highways considering the driver-vehicle-roadway system characteristics; curves and earthwork; and surveying pertaining to the alignment of highways.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Open to students in the College of Engineering honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Mechanics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification, classification, and engineering properties of soils; theory and application of consolidation, compressibility, and strength of soils; ground water retention and movement; slope stability and lateral earth pressures; stress distribution in soil.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundation Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Prediction of soil variation, soil investigations; stress distribution and bearing capacity; dewatering analysis and procedures; retaining structures and lateral earth pressures; shallow foundations, pile foundations; underpinning and grouting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 522. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CE 544.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statics and Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: A shortened combined course in (1) statics, including a study of force systems, free-body diagrams, and problems in equilibrium, friction, centroids, and moments of inertia; and (2) dynamics, including a study of the kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies using the method of force-mass acceleration.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanics of Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary theories of stress and strain, behavior of materials, and applications of these theories and their generalizations to the study of stress distribution, deformation, and instability in the simple structural forms which occur most frequently in engineering practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 333 or CE 530. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: MATH 222.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanics of Materials Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Determination of selected mechanical properties of several engineering materials, including iron-carbon alloys, aluminum alloys, concrete, wood, and plastics; relationship between structure and mechanical properties of these materials; elementary problems in experimental stress analysis and structural behavior; test procedures, instrumentation, and interpretation of results.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lab instruction and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Structural Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Elastic analysis of determinate and indeterminate beams, frames, and trusses; construction of shear and moment diagrams and influence lines; calculation of deflections using conjugate beam and virtual work; solution of indeterminate structures by slope-deflection, moment distribution, and matrix stiffness method; with microcomputer applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 533. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CE 380.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Engineering in Steel
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to design of steel structures. Theoretical, experimental and practical bases for proportioning members and their connections.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Engineering in Concrete
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the theories of reinforced concrete and of its characteristics as a construction material; design of reinforced concrete structures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Resources Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to: surface water hydrology, design of water handling structures, flood protection, pipe flow hydraulics, pump selection, and flow in soils.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week. Not available for students with credit for BAE 530.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hydraulic Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of the principles of fluid mechanics to control and use of water; reservoir, dam, and spillway design; enclosed conduit and open-channel design; hydraulic machinery and hydro-power development; principles of fluid measurement; laboratory-flow and velocity metering, hydraulic models, pipe losses, open-channel flow.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ME 571. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CE 550.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Activity Center Traffic
htmlparse.Course.description: The planning and design of any activity center (shopping mall, business center, sports stadium) must consider vehicular access/egress and parking. If not properly planned and designed, the impact on the surrounding streets and the center can be chaotic. The course will cover techniques of determining parking needs, parking layout, internal and external circulation design, and design of access/egress and the adjacent street system to minimize the impact on the surrounding street network.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Engineering Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic physical, chemical, and biological concepts and the applications to the protection of the environment with emphasis on techniques used in water and wastewater treatment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water and Wastewater Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of municipal water and wastewater treatment systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 550, CE 563, PHYS 214 and ME 571.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transportation Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of transportation planning. Historical development and current status of techniques used in travel demand forecasting; trip generation, trip distribution, mode choice, and traffic assignment. Current microcomputer models and applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 380 or equivalent and junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Highway Engineering, Planning and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of the principles of traffic engineering and capacity analysis techniques to analyze, design and maintain street and highway systems. Fundamentals of transportation planning; site planning and design; traffic impact studies; fundamentals of pavement design and management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 411 and 522 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: AI Applications in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A review of the available techniques in artificial intelligence and a survey of applications in the different areas of civil engineering (structures, transportation/materials, geotechnical, hydraulics/water resources, and environmental engineering). Knowledge representation, inference mechanisms, system development and evaluation, object-oriented programming. Use of expert system shells, neural networks and fuzzy logic. Hands on applications on microcomputers in the MS-Windows environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation for 10 days. Afternoon lab hours additional in computer lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Civil Engineering Project
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive civil engineering project, to be taken in the last semester of the B.S. program. Requires integration of skills acquired in civil engineering elective courses. Students must prepare and present written and oral design reports.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 415 and 6 hours of CE electives. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: 6 additional credit hours of CE electives.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and two three-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Geoenvironmental Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to soil formation, structure, flow and mass transport in soils, mass transfer principles, waste containment and isolation, and physical, chemical, and biological remediation principles.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Civil Engineering Materials I
htmlparse.Course.description: Properties and behavior of structural metals, timber, portland cement concrete, and bituminous concrete; standard specification and methods of test; inspection and control; long-term protection and durability.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 534 and ENGL 415. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: Either CE 528 or 542 or 544.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Groundwater Flow Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to fundamental, mathematical and physical concepts of groundwater flow; application of simple analytic models; introduction to field methods; application of computer modeling tools to address design with practical significance.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Unit Operations and Processes in Environmental Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory study of various physical, chemical and biological operations and processes used in the professional practice of environmental engineering. Topics covered will be selected from reactor hydrodynamics, oxidation-reduction, coagulation-flocculation, chemical precipitation, ion exchange, adsorption processes, biological oxidation, anaerobic digestion and the activated-sludge process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CE 565 and CE 552.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economics of Design and Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Selection of alternative engineering design and construction solutions through study of unit cost determination, cost estimating, and financing procedures. Introduction to construction scheduling.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing in engineering or graduate standing for non-engineering majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected Topics in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Responsibility in Engineering: Codes & Professionalism
htmlparse.Course.description: Course designed to help engineers, scientists, and technical managers to: understand fundamental “canons” of professional societies, establish or revitalize personal ethical standards using these canons, realize when situations are ethical dilemmas, and to develop a process to solving dilemmas. Key activities are: interviewing peers, analyzing current environment for potential challenges, developing ethics workshops, and writing individual code of ethics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or senior with instructor approval.

htmlparse.Course.title: Responsibility in Engineering: Leadership & Diversity
htmlparse.Course.description: Course designed to help engineers, scientists, and technical managers to: understand leadership approaches that promote high ethical conduct, and to understand the ethical value and challenges associated with a diverse workplace. Key activities are: interviewing peers; analyzing current environment for potential challenges; developing a workshop related to ethics, leadership and diversity; and writing individual code of ethics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or instructor approval.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Photo Interpretation
htmlparse.Course.description: Photo interpretation techniques, types of aerial photographic film and their uses; application in land use studies, land surveying, site selection, rainfall runoff and stream flow, location of construction materials, and in the determination of soil properties; other applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and consent of instruction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Designing with Geosynthetics
htmlparse.Course.description: History of geosynthetics; overview of geosynthetic functions, applications and properties; relationship between testing and applications. Designing with geotextiles, geogrids, geonets, geomembranes, geosynthetic clay liners and geocomposites.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seepage in Permeable Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of seepage; groundwater movement in slopes, embankments, dams, and earth-supporting structures; construction of flow nets; dewatering systems; filter and drain design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Geotechnical Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies of soil investigations; design of retaining structures and reinforced earth walls, sheet piles, anchored bulkheads, underground conduits and tunnels; analysis and repair of failed structures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Structural Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Plane truss and frame analysis by direct stiffness method; equivalent nodal forces; thermal and settlement effects; stiffness by energy methods; analysis of space frames and trusses; grid structures; advanced topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Civil Engineering Materials II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of civil engineering materials including concrete, steel and bituminous concrete.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Steel Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Plastic design of steel structures; stability problems in plastic design; design of complex steel structures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Reinforced Concrete Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced theories and methods of design and analysis of reinforced concrete structures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to fundamental concepts in structural dynamics; free and forced vibration of single and multiple degrees of freedom systems with and without damping, numerical methods for linear and non-linear dynamic analysis, and basics of the earthquake response and design of structures.
