htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 240, ME 512, CE 537 or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hydraulics of Open Channels
htmlparse.Course.description: Properties of open-channel flow; types of open channels; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy; critical, uniform, and gradually varied flow; design of erodible channels; rapidly varied flow.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Hydrology
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of basic principles; point and regional rainfall and flood frequency analyses; hydrologic and hydraulic flood routing; drainage and flood control facilities design; hydrologic modeling and simulation flood plain analysis and planning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Engineering Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current advances in research and practice of environmental engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour seminar biweekly.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Treatment Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical and chemical process principles and their application to water treatment plant design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wastewater Engineering: Biological Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Biological process principles and their application to the design of wastewater treatment plants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geoenvironmental Engineering Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A team design project in geoenvironmental engineering focused on resolving interdisciplinary issues related to containment of pollutants and remediation of soil and groundwater.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One of the following: AGRON 605, AGRON 746, BAE 690, CE 625, CE 654, CHE 531 or GEOL 611.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Travel Demand Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical development and current status of techniques used in urban transportation planning and travel demand forecasting; trip generation, trip distribution, mode choice, and traffic assignment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 572 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hot Mix Asphalt Mixture Design and Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the properties of constituent materials for asphalt concrete mixtures. Marshall and Superpave methods for hot-mix asphalt design. Theory and practice of asphalt concrete mix for pavements, including specifications and construction methods for hot-mixes and surface treatments. Maintenance and rehabilitation of flexible pavement. Relationships of material engineering properties to pavement design and performance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One two-hour lecture and one three-hour lab session per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pavement Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of evaluating the load-carrying capacity of soil subgrade, subbase, and base courses; critical analysis of the methods of design for flexible and rigid pavements; methods of increasing the load-carrying capacity of highway and airport pavements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Traffic Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Traffic operations of roads, streets, and highways; traffic engineering studies; use of signs, signals, and pavement markings as traffic control devices; highway and intersection capacity, design and operations of traffic signals; current microcomputer models and applications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Portland Cement Concrete Pavements
htmlparse.Course.description: Portland cement concrete mix design and production. Paving operations. Saw and seal operations. Subgrade preparation. Base selection. Drainage selection, design and construction. Bonded and unbonded concrete overlays. Whitetopping and ultra-thin whitetopping. Concrete pavement restoration; quality assurance and quality control in concrete pavement construction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Land Development for Civil Engineers and Planners
htmlparse.Course.description: Engineering problems involved in site planning and design. The comprehensive planning process, zoning and subdivision regulations; design and location of streets and highways, water supply and sanitary facilities, drainage and public utilities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 572 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Original investigation or advanced study in some field related to the practice of civil engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Materials Sampling and Testing
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the proper use of aggregates and concrete materials (Portland cement and asphalt) in construction. Sampling and testing methods conform with current testing standards.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plane Surveying
htmlparse.Course.description: A beginning course in the theory and practice of field measurements and notes for surveying. Emphasis is placed on accuracy and avoidance of common errors and mistakes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problem Solving with Computer Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: In depth preparation with computer operating systems, spreadsheets, scheduling software and Visual Basic for construction applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and one hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of forces and their effects on the bodies upon which they act.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soils and Foundations
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the identification and classification of soils by the Unified method and the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials method. Routine field tests are covered and used in the laboratory.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Safety
htmlparse.Course.description: How to maintain safe working areas within unsafe working conditions. Particularly the recognition and prevention of unsanitary, dangerous, or hazardous conditions to workers in the construction industry. Instruction focuses on federal safety standards related to construction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Methods and Estimating
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the basic equipment needs, usage, costs, and quantity determinations for planning and estimating construction projects. Field trips through construction sites and visitations with inspectors assist in developing reporting procedures and inspection responsibilities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Construction Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present construction engineering technology topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transportation Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of transportation systems with emphasis on traffic operations and control, planning, design, and drainage for highways, and urban roadways.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A course combining design of components of structures in steel and reinforced concrete. Basic stress calculations and design concepts are studied for use in either a simplified design, detailing, or inspection role.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and analysis of construction materials, their properties, selection and use.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Route Location Surveying
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the geometric methods of horizontal and vertical curve alignment. In addition, transitional spirals are examined and calculated. The laboratory portion provides a grounding of these concepts in the field by actual calculation and staking of control for roads, streets, and various types of routes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanical and Electrical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the use of mechanical and electrical systems within constructed buildings. Students develop skills related to plumbing, heating, air conditioning, wiring, power, and lighting systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: The way mechanical systems, including plumbing, heating, ventilation, and air conditioning are used by contractors to construct a building.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 151 and PHYS 113. Corequisite: CET 241.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electrical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: The way electrical systems, including design and wiring, and power and lighting systems are used by contractors to construct a building.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 151 and PHYS 113. Corequisite: CET 241.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of site construction problems and procedures, site survey and investigations, review of site plans, construction layouts, earthwork calculation, excavation/shoring methods, and computer applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MET 111, CET 130, PHYS 113, and CMST 108.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Techniques and Detailing
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of construction methods and procedures in the assembly of building materials.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Managerial and Engineering Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Economic analysis of problems as applied in the management of technology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: Engineering Assembly
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Topics in Chemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Recent advances in chemical engineering and the impact of the profession on society.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Process Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to chemical engineering with emphasis on material and energy balances.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent: CHM 230 or 250 and MATH 222.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure of materials, with particular emphasis on metals and semiconductors.  Mechanical, electrical, and magnetic properties. Multiphase equilibrium and modification of properties through changes in microstructure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure of materials especially metals. Mechanical properties emphasized. Multiphase equilibrium and modification of properties through change in microstructure. Effect of heat treatment on microstructure and properties.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Concepts in Materials Science and Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure of materials with crystal structures of metals and their defects emphasized.  Two component phase diagrams, multiphase equilibrium, and the microstructures that result.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Mechanical Properties
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the mechanical properties of materials, especially metals, and the modification of these properties through changes in microstructure.  Effect of heat treatment on microstructure and mechanical properties.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Electrical Properties
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the electrical properties of materials including conductors, semiconductors, and dielectrics, and their basis in the band theory of solids.  Multiphase equilibrium and modification of properties through changes in microstructure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computional Techniques in Chemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of computational techniques in chemical engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours of lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Research in Chemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to chemical engineering research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Chemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor.  Open to students in the College of Engineering honors program. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the first and second laws of thermodynamics, real gases, heat of solution and reaction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHE 320. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: MATH 240.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of the study of the second law, thermodynamic analysis of processes, phase equilibrium, chemical reaction equilibrium.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CHE 416. Prerequisite: CHE 520.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transport Phenomena I
htmlparse.Course.description: A unified treatment of the basic principles of momentum, energy, and mass transport.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transport Phenomena II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Transport Phenomena I with special emphasis on mass transfer.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CHE 416. Prerequisite: CHE 530.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transport Phenomena Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory experiments in momentum, heat, and mass transfer.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Eight hours of laboratory per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Unit Operations Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory experiments on classical unit operations, e.g., distillation, absorption, extraction, and on chemical kinetics and process dynamics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHE 535, 550 and 560. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CHE 561.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Eight hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied chemical kinetics and catalysis including the analysis and design of tubular, packed bed, stirred tank, and fluidized bed chemical reactors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Separational Process Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of the basic theory and design of separational processes such as distillation, gas absorption, liquid extraction, adsorption, and ion exchange.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Process Dynamics and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the unsteady state behavior and control of chemical processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Engineering Systems Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of process economics and process optimization with application to the synthesis and design of chemical processing systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Engineering Systems Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: The solution of comprehensive systems design problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Chemical Engineering or Materials Science
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to chemical engineering research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioseparations
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of separations important in food and biochemical engineering such as leaching, extraction, expression, absorption, ion exchange, filtration, centrifugation, membrane separation, and chromatographic separations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Conversion of Biorenewable Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the conversion of biorenewable resources into biobased products and biofuels.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Life Cycle Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the process and methodologies associated with life cycle analysis. Application of the methods developed in the course to a project to gain experience in defining and quantifying uncertainty associated with human perturbation, management and utilization of biofuels and other complex processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Processing of Composite Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of composite materials, including ceramic, metal, and polymer matrix composites; properties and processing of fibers; role of interfaces in composites; basic concepts in mechanics, failure, and testing of composite materials.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hazardous Waste Engineering Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in hazardous materials management and control, waste reduction and minimization, hazardous substance tracking, and hazardous waste engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ceramic Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure and bonding in glasses and ceramics; phase equilibrium and transformation kinetics; defects and microstructure within ceramic materials; mechanical, thermal, optical, electrical, and magnetic properties of ceramics and glasses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Polymer Science and Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to polymeric materials, including chemistry, structure and formation; physical states and transitions; and, basic physical and mechanical properties.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Processing of Materials for Solid State Devices
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure, properties and processing of materials for solid state devices. Crystal growth, epitaxy, oxidation, diffusion, lithography, and etching as applied to device fabrication.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental and Ecological Risk Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of processes and methodologies associated with human environmental and ecological risk assessments. Application of the methods learned to a project to gain experience in defining and quantifying uncertainty associated with human perturbation, management and restoration of environmental and ecological processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electrochemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Thermodynamics, electrode kinetics, and transport phenomena of electrochemical systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sustainability Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in environmental sustainability, green engineering, life cycle analysis, sustainable development, and sustainability science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Materials II
htmlparse.Course.description: The structure and bonding in crystalline and amorphous materials; crystallography; thermodynamic stability in materials; equilibrium diagrams and the phase rule; rate theory and kinetics of solid-state transformations; mechanical behavior of engineering materials; dislocations; failure mechanisms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Surface Phenomena
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and applications of interfacial phenomena, including capillarity, colloids, porosity, adsorption, and catalysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHE 520, CHM 585, ME 513, or PHYS 664.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis and design of biochemical processing systems with emphasis on fermentation kinetics, continuous fermentations, aeration, agitation, scale up, sterilization, and control.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biotransport Phenomena
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of transport phenomena applied to biological and physiological processes. Membrane transport processes, circulatory system transport phenomena, transport and distribution of drugs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Engineering Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: The mathematical formulation of problems in chemical engineering using partial differential equations, vector and tensor notation. Solution of these problems by analytical and numerical methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis of Physiological Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of process and systems analysis applied to problems in biology and medicine. Analysis of mixing in-flow systems, principles and applications of tracer analysis, analysis of kinetic and adsorption processes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Air Quality Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in air quality including health effects, toxicology, measurement, characterization, modeling, management, and control.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geoenvironmental Engineering Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone design project in geoenvironmental engineering focused on resolving issues related to containment of pollutants and remediation of soil and groundwater.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One of the following: AGRON 605, AGRON 746, BAE 690, CE 625, CE 654, CHE 531, or GEOL 611.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chinese I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamental linguistics and cultural characteristics of the Chinese language and its writing systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Chinese II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Chinese I.  Development of functional skills for familiar situations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Chinese III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Chinese II.  Further development of functional skills. Intensive practice of spoken and written Chinese.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Chinese IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Chinese III.  Presentation of more advanced elements of the Chinese language, with intensive practice of spoken and written Chinese.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Chinese V
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of communication skills through application activities. Enhancement of vocabulary and intensive practice in grammatical structures and their usage.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Chinese VI
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Chinese V.  Development of functional skills for general situations. Further enhancement of vocabulary and intensive practice in grammatical structures and their usage.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Chinese
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Chinese
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, laws, and theories of chemistry; important metallic and nonmetallic substances.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 010 or at least one year of high school algebra.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week. An optional laboratory course, CHM 111, is available for an additional hour credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Chemistry-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, laws, and theories of chemistry; important metallic and nonmetallic substances.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 010 or at least one year of high school algebra.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week. An optional laboratory course, CHM 111, is available for an additional hour credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Chemistry Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to supplement the material of CHM 110.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Chemistry Laboratory-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to supplement the material of CHM 110.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Frontiers in Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: An undergraduate seminar designed to introduce students to research being carried out within the Kansas State University Chemistry Department and to offer perspectives on other issues of interest to chemistry majors and those considering chemistry as a major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: First course of a two-semester study of the principles of chemistry and the properties of the elements and their compounds.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One year of high school chemistry and MATH 100 (or two years of high school algebra).
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Concurrent enrollment in CHM 210 lab is required.
Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week.
Students entering the university with Advanced Placement chemistry examination credit may earn the following grades: (Score 5) A in Chemistry I and A in Chemistry II; (Score 4) A in Chemistry I and B in Chemistry II; (Score 3) B in Chemistry I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemistry I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: First course of a two-semester study of the principles of chemistry and the properties of the elements and their compounds.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One year of high school chemistry and MATH 100 (or two years of high school algebra).
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Concurrent enrollment in CHM 210 lab is required.
Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week.
Students entering the university with Advanced Placement chemistry examination credit may earn the following grades: (Score 5) A in Chemistry I and A in Chemistry II; (Score 4) A in Chemistry I and B in Chemistry II; (Score 3) B in Chemistry I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemistry I Recitation
htmlparse.Course.description: An optional recitation class that requires concurrent enrollment in CHM 210 Chemistry I. The objective is the development of skills for solving chemical problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Instruction will be via a small class format.
For credit/no credit only. Credit independent of grade for Chemistry I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Chemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: First course of a two-semester study of chemical principles.  Intended for students with a strong background in chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One year of high school chemistry and MATH 100 (or two years of high school algebra); ACT Composite of 26 or higher.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture and three hours lab a week. Concurrent enrollment in CHM 220 lab is required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Second course of a two-semester study of the principles of chemistry and the properties of the elements and their compounds.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week. Concurrent enrollment in CHM 230 lab is required.
Students entering the university with Advanced Placement chemistry examination credit may earn the following grades: (Score 5) A in Chemistry I and A in Chemistry II; (Score 4) A in Chemistry I and B in Chemistry II; (Score 3) B in Chemistry I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemistry II Recitation
htmlparse.Course.description: An optional recitation class that requires concurrent enrollment in CHM 230 Chemistry II. The objective is the development of skills for solving chemical problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Instruction will be via a small class format.
For credit/no credit only. Credit independent of grade for Chemistry II.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Chemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of CHM 220, covering the principles of chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture and five hours lab a week.
Intended for students with a strong background in chemistry. Concurrent enrollment in CHM 250 lab is required. Laboratory has emphasis on quantitative chemical analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Science: A Chemistry Perspective
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of important technological developments and their impact on society and on the earth’s environment; ethical issues raised by technological advances. History, matter and energy, ecosystems, population issues, air pollution, water pollution, hazardous substances, environmental policies, and decision making are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: General Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of types of organic reactions important to biological science, including pre-veterinary and certain agriculture and human ecology programs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week. Concurrent enrollment in CHM 351 is urged.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Organic Chemistry Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: General Organic Chemistry Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One five-hour lab and one hour of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of chemical equilibria and quantitative analysis: gravimetric, titrimetric, spectrophotometric, electroanalytical, and separations methods.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and five hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forensic Chemistry and Criminalistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction of forensic science and chemistry. Collecting physical evidence at a crime scene and examining it in the laboratory. Soils, glass, hair, fibers, drugs, explosives, poisons, castings, inks, and arson and rape situations are investigated.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to students in the arts and sciences honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Undergraduate Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Undergraduate research in the chemical sciences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to non-Chemistry Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Undergraduate Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems may include classroom and/or lab work.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Physical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary principles of physical chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 230 or CHM 250 and MATH 210 or MATH 220, and PHYS 114 or PHYS 213.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organic Chemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics to be covered include fundamental concepts in organic chemistry such as hybridization, molecular orbitals, structure and bonding, acids and bases, kinetics and thermodynamics, stereochemistry and chirality, and conformational analysis. The basic knowledge will be used to study the syntheses, reactions, and mechanisms of functional groups such as alkanes, haloalkanes, and alkenes. Structural determination using infrared spectroscopy and nuclear magnetic resonance will also be included.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One five-hour lab and one hour of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Separations
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of modern separation techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 250 or 371, CHM 532 and CHM 550.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organic Chemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of Organic Chemistry I (CHM 531). CHM 550 represents the second semester of a two-semester survey of organic chemistry. Topics to be discussed include syntheses, reactions, and mechanisms of alkynes, aldehydes and ketones, carboxylic acids and their derivatives, amines, benzene and its derivatives, organometallic chemistry, conjugated unsaturated systems and pericyclic reactions, polymers, carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Structural identification will be studied using various spectroscopic methods.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Organic Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced Organic Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One five-hour lab and one hour of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumental Methods of Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to theory and practice of electrochemical methods, molecular and atomic spectroscopy, surface science, mass spectrometry, separation methods, and electronics in analytical chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 250 or 371; CHM 531; and CHM 500 or CHM 585.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Chemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary chemical thermodynamics and kinetic theory of gases.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 350 or CHM 531, MATH 222, and PHYS 214.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Chemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary quantum chemistry, spectroscopy, statistical thermodynamics, and chemical kinetics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 350 or CHM 531, MATH 222, and PHYS 214.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Methods Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Experiments that relate to physical and instrumental methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 566 and MATH 221 and PHYS 114 or PHYS 214.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three to six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Thesis Research
htmlparse.Course.description: A final written report and oral presentation are required.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Scientific Glassblowing
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic techniques of bending, sealing, and blowing glass used to fabricate scientific glassware.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing in physical sciences.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours of laboratory including one lecture demonstration a week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Safe Chemical Laboratory Practices
htmlparse.Course.description: A general safety course for persons working or teaching in a chemical laboratory.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
One hour of lecture per week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Traces the beginnings of chemistry from 3500 B.C. to 1920 A.D. Early metallurgy, Greek thought about atoms, alchemy, atomic theory, discovery of gases; definition of elements, chemical bonds, organic, inorganic, and physical chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Inorganic Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: The preparation, characterization, and study of transition metal, main group, and organometallic compounds using techniques commonly encountered in industrial and academic research.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Teaching Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and methods of instruction in laboratories and recitation classes in chemistry, including one semester of supervised experience as an instructor in a chemical laboratory. This is a required course of all teaching assistants in the Department of Chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing in chemistry or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Inorganic Chemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: Atomic and molecular structure, bonding concepts used in the practice of inorganic chemistry. Applications of symmetry and group theory to structure, bonding, and spectra.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture a week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Inorganic Chemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure, reactivity, and mechanistic aspects of main group and transition metal complexes. Organometallic reactions, catalysis, and bioinorganic chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture a week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of organic compounds and fundamental types of reactions.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture a week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Case Studies in Green Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an interdisciplinary course that looks at concepts and issues in green chemistry by examining case studies in which polluting processes have been transformed to reduce their environmental impact. Focus will be on understanding the chemistry involved and the green principles that have been applied.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 350 or 531, or graduate standing in chemistry or chemical engineering, or by consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture/discussion per week.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practical NMR Spectroscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental aspects of 1D and 2D nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, as applied to the Chemistry Department’s Varian 200- and 400-MHz spectrometers.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing in the physical sciences, or by consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems may include classroom or laboratory work. Not for thesis research.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation of professional problems and practices by students, faculty, and industry professionals associated with computing and information sciences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture per week. Required of all undergraduate students new to the department.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computing Systems, Information Search, and Security
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic computer and Internet security including basic computer security and privacy issues, computer networks, malware protection; effective use of the Internet as a resource including website evaluation and effective search tools and techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture, two hours scheduled laboratory, and two hours unscheduled open laboratory each week. Course meets in one contiguous block of four weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Spreadsheet Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Designing, building, and modifying spreadsheets. Addressing techniques and formatting. Use of formulas and functions. Spreadsheets as management and decision tools. Charting of data.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture, two hours scheduled laboratory and two hours unscheduled open laboratory each week. Course meets in one contiguous block of four weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Database Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Design, create, modify, and maintain relational databases. Create relationships. Add and modify data. Search and query database. Design and create screen forms and reports.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture, two hours scheduled lab, and two hours unscheduled open lab each week. Course meets in one contiguous block of four weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Word Processing Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic features of word processing. Create and edit a document. View, format, and customize document. Revise, update, and rearrange text. Add graphics. Support features. Merge documents.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture, two hours scheduled lab, and two hours scheduled open lab each week. Course meets in one contiguous block of four weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to computer problem solving; basic programming logic; algorithms; control structures; and data structures. The focus is on the control flow of programming with an elementary introduction to object-oriented design. Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to write simple computer programs.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Consists of one hour lecture and one hour recitation per week for 8 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to programming. Principles and applications of programming fundamentals: state, control structures, methods, and arrays. Programming projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computing Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the discipline of Computing Science and its interaction with other disciplines, incorporating historical development, theories, and tools of Computing Science (algorithm design and programming). Topics include: mechanical computers, digital computers, bioinformatics, microcontrollers, robotics, security, scientific computing, simulation, and web technologies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Computing and Information Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics of special interest in computing and information sciences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Programming Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of algorithm design and their application to procedural programming: state, control structures, methods. Patterns of conditional and iterative control structure.  Program testing. Introduction to arrays, classes, and objects.  Programming projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: MATH 100 and either CIS 115 OR ECE 241.
Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: C Programming for Engineers
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of computers to engineering problems. Abstraction and problem solving; algorithms; control structures; input/output; functions; arrays and array processing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 220. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, two hours lab each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Data and Program Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of common data and program structures together with associated algorithms. Topics include interfaces, design patterns, arrays, stacks, queues, lists, trees, hash tables, recursion, binary search, and tree traversals. Experience with both use and implementation of these structures and algorithms using a modern programming language. Discussion of tradeoffs involving performance and software maintainability.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 200. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Logical Foundations of Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Logical formalisms used to model and reason about computer systems. Propositional and predicate logic, syntax, semantics, and proof theory; soundness and completeness issues. Mathematical induction. Program verification: invariants and program logics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 200. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: C/C++ Language Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of programming in C and C++; applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Business Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to basic business programming techniques including file manipulation operations and sorting. The COBOL language will be used as an implementation tool.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 200. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Seminar in Computer Science

htmlparse.Course.title: Computers and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the impact of computers and associated technologies on society, including such topics as ethics of computer use, computer fraud, protection of privacy; legal, moral, and public policy-making responsibility of computer professionals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Architecture and Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to modern computer architectures: register transfer abstraction, addressing modes, basic operations (data transfer, arithmetic/logic, and control operations). Basic Operating System concepts and operations. Understanding relationships of higher-level language constructs to corresponding assembly instruction sequences generated by compilers. Introduction to interrupts and low-level I/O operations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECE 241. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CIS 308.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Current topics in computer science.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Varies with the announced topic.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research/Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. A report/thesis is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Repeatable.
Open to students in the College of Engineering honors program and to seniors in the College of Arts and Sciences honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Architecture and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and patterns for design and structure of software, development of object-oriented models, examples of software architecture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Programming Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: History, programming language concepts including type, scope and extent, abstraction mechanisms and control; programming paradigms, including one or more of logic, functional, and object-oriented programming, and programming languages supporting the selected paradigms; interpreters, compilers and virtual machines for the selected languages; storage management and garbage collection; type checking and type inference.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300, CIS 301. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operating Systems I
htmlparse.Course.description: Operating systems concepts, services, and implementation: interrupt processing, processes, concurrency, deadlocks, resource scheduling and system structure; resource management: real and virtual storage, input/output systems, disk scheduling and file systems; design and construction of concurrent programs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 450 or ECE 431; CIS 308, and CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time Programming Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Project-oriented introduction to asynchronous processes and related systems software: device drivers, event-driven operations, hierarchical and time-sliced process scheduling, spooling operations, interjob and intermachine communications. Projects will be built on a single-use environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECE 241 and CIS 350, concurrent enrollment CIS 520. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Data Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic data structures such as stacks, queues, lists, and priority queues, and algorithmic techniques for sorting, searching and hashing. Emphasis on modularity and reuse. Introduction to the concept of object-oriented design and interface specifications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week. Course meets in one contiguous block of five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Concurrent Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to concurrent programming techniques based on message passing primitives (send/receive) and shared memory (semaphore based P/V operations and monitor-based wait/signal operations).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C, or C++ programming and CIS 300 or CIS 522. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week. Course meets in one contiguous block of five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Telecommunications and Data Communication Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts including OSI 7 layer model, data transmission methods, medium access, link control, connections management; network applications including electronic mail, file transfer, distributed computing, window systems; network management including OSI and Internet management frameworks.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Interface Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental principles and best practices of interface design, web service design, advanced web interfaces, web development frameworks, web standards and accessibility issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501, CMST 135. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental background in intelligent systems for undergraduate students. Intelligent agents, problem-solving, uninformed and informed (heuristic) search, game tree search, foundations of knowledge representation and reasoning using logic and probability, and a first introduction to planning and machine learning. AI topics include the problem areas of natural language processing (NLP) and perception and methodologies such as artificial neural networks and genetic and evolutionary computation. Applications to practical design and development of intelligent systems will be emphasized, leading to individual projects on current topics and applications in AI.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300, CIS 301 and MATH 312 or 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to computer graphics for undergraduate students. Mathematical foundations (e.g., linear, affine, and projective transformations) and fundamental topics in realistic rendering: view normalization, clipping and culling, scan conversion of lines and polygons, shading and illumination, texture mapping, user interfaces, picking, and collision handling. Intermediate topics include shaders, procedural textures, particle systems, basics of animation, fractals, color theory, and ray tracing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308 and either MATH 205 or MATH 220. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three (3) hours lecture a week.
Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 636.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Engineering Project I
htmlparse.Course.description: The first semester of a two-semester capstone course. Current practices of software development, requirements, design, prototyping, measures and evaluation. Specification, design, and prototyping of a software system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308, 501, and STAT 325 or 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 543.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Engineering Project II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of CIS 540. Final implementation, integration, and testing of a software system. Introduction to configuration management, project management, and software maintenance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 540 (which must be taken in the preceding semester). Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Engineering Design Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Current practices of software development, requirements, design, prototyping, measures and evaluations. Specification, design, and prototyping of a software system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308, 501, and STAT 325 or 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 540.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Software Design and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced concepts and practicum in object-oriented analysis, modeling, design, implementation, testing, and use of CASE tools; relationships among structural, static, and dynamic models; relationship among conceptual, system, and implementation models.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 744.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics related to the management of software, including organization, project planning, process models, life cycle models, TQM, software quality assurance, cost estimation, configuration management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 562. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer and Information Security
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to computer and information security, including common attack techniques, application of cryptography in security, authentication and authorization, network security, enterprise network defense, web security, and analysis of design flaws that render a system vulnerable. Course projects provide hands-on experience on both the defense and offense aspects in cyberspace.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 450 or 520. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours recitation a week.
Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 751.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intro Applied Cryptography
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of cryptography, including mathematical background, classical ciphers, public key encryption, block and stream ciphers, cryptographic hash functions, digital signatures, common attacks, and basic security protocols.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300, MATH 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours recitation a week.
Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 753.

htmlparse.Course.title: Database System Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts, approaches, and techniques in database management. Representation of information as data, data storage techniques, foundations of logical data models, data retrieval, database design, transaction management, integrity and security.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300, CIS 301, and MATH 312 or 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Enterprise Information Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Conceptual models for E-Commerce and for business applications, database management systems, relational data model, normal forms, query language, security features, web access and scripting languages, development process and management, issues in management of enterprise information systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Formal Language Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Formal languages, automata, regular expressions, grammars, introduction to computability theory. Reading and writing informal mathematical proofs pertaining to these topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Algorithm Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to mathematical analysis of time- and space-complexity of algorithms, including worst-case, average-case, and amortized complexity. An examination of various algorithmic designs, such as greedy algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, and dynamic programming algorithms. Techniques for proving correctness of algorithms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Game Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental principles of programming games. Foundational game algorithms and data structures. Two-dimensional graphics and physics simulation. Development for multiple platforms. Utilization of game programming libraries. Design of multiple games incorporating topics covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501, MATH 221 and prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: PHYS 213 or PHYS 223.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Game Engine Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Current practices of game engine development. The game engine as a soft real-time multi-agent simulation.  Three-dimensional graphics and animation techniques, scene management, physics simulation, event systems, resource management, and network game architectures.  Design and prototyping of a general use game engine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in computer science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Systems Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed studies: selection and completion of a project; may include collaboration with other students; may include design, analysis, and implementation. Completion of a plan, two progress reviews, and a final report with literature review and project evaluation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 562 and senior standing in information systems. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Science Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed studies: selection, investigation and report on some topic not covered in prior courses; may include an implementation and/or experimentation component; may be done in collaboration with other students. Completion of a plan, two reviews, and a final report with literature review and project evaluation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 560 and senior standing in computer science. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Set Theory and Logic for CS
htmlparse.Course.description: Informal and axiomatic set theory, propositional and predicate logic, proof techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time Programming Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Relationship between C/C++ constructs and corresponding assembly code generated by compilers. Introduction to special techniques used to implement micro-controllers, such as initialization of programmable CPU modules/peripheral devices, techniques to link assembly and C/C++ codes, producing ROM-able code, and EPROM burning/Flash programming.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or C ++ programming, and CIS 523 and either CIS 300 or CIS 522. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week. Course meets in one contiguous block of five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time Operating Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic real-time operating systems concepts and services; interrupt processing; process and thread models; real-time software architectures and development environments. Detailed study of design and implementation of real-time applications using real-time operating systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 621. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week. Course meets in one contiguous block of five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concurrent Software Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Architecture, design, modeling, implementation, and verification of concurrent, parallel, and distributed software; aspects such as real-time programming, parallel simulation; fault-tolerant programming; grid computing, embedded systems control.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer-Based Knowledge Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the applications of artificial intelligence concepts to solving knowledge-dependent tasks. Review of knowledge-representation ideas. Survey of expert system design. Introduction to existing knowledge-based tools available on personal computers. Development of an intelligent system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: Devices and software for graphics display and user interaction, development of software for direct graphic manipulation applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multimedia Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to computer graphics devices, user interaction; history and scope; multimedia structure, encoding methods and standards, mark-up and scripting languages, software tools, and applications; readings in current literature; class presentation; multimedia project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300, senior standing. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Testing Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of software testing methodologies; evaluation of software testing strategies; experience in a variety of software testing practices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Development Environments
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of current development environments and/or an in-depth study of one development environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Implementation Project
htmlparse.Course.description: The department will suggest various design or implementation projects for individuals or groups in areas such as translators, interpreters, microprogramming, minicomputer operating systems, graphics, numerical software, etc.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar in Computer Science

htmlparse.Course.title: Programming Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Programming language concepts, including typing, scoping, abstraction and exceptions; programming paradigms, including one or more of logic, functional, object-oriented and concurrent programming, and programming languages supporting the selected paradigms; introduction to programming language semantics; programming language design; development environments.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 505 and MATH 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Translator Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: Compilers and interpreters, including description of languages, finite state scanners. LL(1) parsing, symbol tables, syntax-directed semantics, simple code generation. Constructing a simple compiler.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501, and CIS 605. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Simulation Experiments
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of digital computer simulation; discrete simulation method, statistics of simulations; implementations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Operating Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Process synchronization and communication, distributed programming primitives, transactions and concurrency control, distributed scheduling, distributed storage, deadlock, security.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 520. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: The design of hard real-time embedded systems, including language and operating system support, scheduling, schedulability analysis, fault tolerance, and design tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 520 or both CIS 622 and ECE 633. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operating System Practices
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure and functions of modern operating systems. Emphasis on reading and modifying the source code of a working operating system. This includes memory management, input/output, process management, file systems, and network interconnection software construction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 520. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Computer Networks
htmlparse.Course.description: Network algorithms; routing and congestion control; protocol engineering; protocol decomposition, specification and verification, synthesis; protocols for high speed networks; parallel implementations, light-weight protocols.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 520, and CIS 525. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced World Wide Web Technologies
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course on the technologies that make up the World Wide Web. WWW site designs and analysis, WWW software architecture, server-side technologies, dynamic executable scheduling, digital libraries, WWW security.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 520, CIS 525. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Artificial Intelligence
