htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamental concepts and techniques of AI: problem solving, search and planning, knowledge representation and qualitative reasoning, expert systems, natural language processing and cognitive modeling, computer vision, and machine learning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Learning and Pattern Recognition
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and methodology of inductive learning, including decision trees, artificial neural networks, probabilistic and instance-based learning, and inductive logic programming; unsupervised and reinforcement learning, bagging and boosting; genetic algorithms and genetic programming; and applications to data mining.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Genomics and Bioinformatics
htmlparse.Course.description: A problem solving approach to understanding genomics and bioinformatics. Practical use of databases and web-based tools used to study biological problems. Introduction to the algorithms behind these tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Either BIOL 450 or CIS 300, and instructor permission. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one-and-a-half hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in computer representation and display of images and graphic interaction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Software life cycle, requirements, specifications, design, validation, measures, and maintenance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 540. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Software Analysis and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced concepts and practicum in object-oriented analysis, modeling, design, implementation, testing, and use of CASE tools; relationships among structural, static, and dynamic models; relationship among conceptual, system, and implementation models.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 540. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 544.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Measurement
htmlparse.Course.description: Measurement theory; development, validation and use of software measures; software measures in the life cycle, including cost estimation, design measures, software complexity and software reliability.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 540. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Software Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics related to the management of software, including organization, project planning, process models, life cycle models, TQM, software quality assurance, cost estimation, configuration management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 740. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Computer Architecture Experiments
htmlparse.Course.description: Characteristics of various computers including those with execution support of multiprocessing, multiprogramming, microprogrammable, high-level language, stack processing, and communication architectures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 450. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer and Information Security
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive coverage of computer and information security. Basic cryptography, access control, authentication, authorization, network security, software security, and social aspects of security. The lectures discuss when and where things can go wrong and how design flaws in a system can be exploited to compromise security. Common attack techniques are introduced, and students have the opportunity to work on course projects that cover both the defense and offense aspects in cyberspace.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 450 or 520. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 551.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Cryptography
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of cryptography, including mathematical background, classical ciphers, public key encryption, block and stream ciphers, cryptographic hash functions, digital signatures, common attacks, and basic network security.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 300, MATH 510, or equivalent. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours recitation a week.
Not available for credit to students with credit in CIS 553.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Computer and Information Security
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth coverage of advanced theoretical and practical security techniques with emphasis on construction of new systems and auditing and repair of existing security-critical systems using rigorous design, risk analysis, and engineering methods and application of state-of-art theoretical tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisites: CIS 551 or CIS 751. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Data Base Management Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Data models and languages, hierarchical, network, relational systems; implementation and operational requirements; programming projects using data base management systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 560, CIS 604. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Office Automation
htmlparse.Course.description: Characteristics of information work; modeling systems for characterizing aspects of office environment; form-based systems; office automation and description languages, ergonomics, local area networks and tools used in the automation of offices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 525, 560. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Database Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Conceptual, logical, physical, and user interface design for database management systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 501. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Formal Language Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Regular languages, finite automata, context-free languages, pushdown automata, context-sensitive languages, linear bounded automata, recursively enumerable languages, Turing machines.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 510. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Specification
htmlparse.Course.description: Formal logic or specification of software components; algebraic vs. model-based specifications; common abstract types; verification of properties of specifications; introduction to specification of concurrent systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 301. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis of Algorithms
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and application of techniques and procedures used in the analysis of algorithms including the worst and average cases of both time and space. Study of the P and NP classes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 575. Students may enroll in CIS courses only if they have earned a grade of C or better for each prerequisite to those courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Prerequisite varies with the announced topic.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the field of computer technology with an emphasis on the foundational concepts of how computers work. Topics include binary numbers, digital logic and hardware, computer architecture, operating systems, low-level and high-level programming languages, and algorithms.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Program Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A language-independent introduction to computer programming logic. Topics include an overview of systems development and a detailed examination of problem definition, problem analysis, and general and detailed design. Students are introduced to the tools and techniques utilized in structured and object-oriented design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Database Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to using a database management system on a personal computer. Students begin with elementary database commands and progress to more sophisticated database applications. Students are required to complete assignments on the computer, some of which are completed outside of class.

htmlparse.Course.title: PC Desktop Software
htmlparse.Course.description: The use and application of popular software application packages. Topics include word processors, electronic spreadsheets, database management systems, and presentation software. Students are required to complete assignments on the computer, some of which are completed outside of class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Visual Basic
htmlparse.Course.description: Computer programming using Visual Basic for students who are not majoring in computer systems technology or web development technology. Topics include variable and constant declarations, data types, arithmetic expressions, decision structures, repetition structures, sequential files and arrays. Emphasis on problem solving and program structure.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graphics Software Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to popular graphics software application packages. Emphasis is on design concepts, color usage, image and concept development and creative problem solving using graphics software. Students are required to complete assignments on the computer, some of which are completed outside of class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to PC Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the maintenance and configuration of personal computer hardware and software. Topics include proper hardware configuration, computer upgrades, and installation of system and user software.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Page Development I
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts of communications across the Internet, differences in browsers, and the technology required to create web pages. In-depth coverage of web page design and implementation with HyperText Markup Language (HTML). Students are required to complete several laboratory assignments outside of class.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Visual Literacy
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the elements of visual design essential to communication with digital technology. Topics include design elements, color theory, graphics creation and optimization, and multimedia. Students receive hands-on experience with the elements and principles of visual literacy and working with 2-D and 3-D organization.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Photography
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduces basic photographic techniques and computer assisted image manipulation. Topics include: basic camera functions, basic digital image processing, visualization and design skills and digital manipulation techniques needed in today’s market place. Students have opportunities to create portfolio pieces.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Page Development II
htmlparse.Course.description: Extends the concepts covered in Web Page Development I to refine design techniques and include greater use of graphics and animation. Web page development tools are introduced and compared for ease of use and productivity. Topics include interacting with the user, gathering and sending information, and querying information from a database. Web page laboratory assignments will be completed outside of class time.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Database Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to properties and design principles of relational databases. Topics include database terms, E-R Modeling, relational table design and normalization, the relational algebra, Structured Query Language, and the database life cycle. Laboratory work includes the design and implementation of a database.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Media I
htmlparse.Course.description: Hands-on experience dealing with the elements and principles of digital communications working with industry standard software for photo editing, illustration and page layout. Students have the opportunity to produce portfolio pieces.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Java Programming I
htmlparse.Course.description: The syntax and semantics of the Java programming language. Topics include expressions, statements, classes, methods, forms of dynamic storage allocation, console I/O, two-dimensional graphics, GUI, event handling, arrays, inheritance, and polymorphism. Students are required to complete programming assignments using Java to solve a variety of problems in business, mathematics, and engineering technology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Networking I
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of computer networking concepts and terms. Topics include local area networks, wide area networks, protocols, network topology, and transmission media.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Unix
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to using the Unix operating system for programming and system administration. Topics include using the Unix command line interface, file attributes, editing text files, and programming with shell script and other interpreted languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Computer Systems Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present computer systems technology topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applications in C Programming for Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to structured program design and implementation using the C programming language. Topics include use of the C language in calculations, input, output, and file handling. Students design, implement, and test programs applicable to engineering technology majors.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 101 or other college-level programming language.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Media II
htmlparse.Course.description: An intermediate course dealing with the elements and principles of digital communications working with industry standard software involved in video editing, audio editing, photo editing, vector drawing and page layout. Students have the opportunity to produce portfolio pieces.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Visual Basic Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of Visual Basic as an object-oriented language for students having had previous college-level computer programming courses. Topics include advanced database manipulation, MDI programming, creation of controls, web forms, and help files. Assignments focus on large programming projects. Students design, implement, and present a final capstone course project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 180; and CMST 247 or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Networking II
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of network and server administration in a Windows Server environment. Topics include network design, hardware and software selection, server and client installation, management of network services, Active Directory administration, configuration of permissions and policies, and server monitoring and tuning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: C# Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the Microsoft C# language and its applications. C# is a development tool within the .NET framework. Students use the language to develop a wide variety of applications including stand-alone applications and those providing access to databases and Web services.

htmlparse.Course.title: Game Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to computer game programming.  Topics include game mathematics and physics, tile-based virtual worlds, artificial intelligence,and game graphics. Students design, develop, and present a functioning computer game as a capstone course project.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Page Layout and Type
htmlparse.Course.description: An intermediate course dealing with typographic design concepts, color usage, image development, idea development, and creative problem solving. Addresses typographic principles, techniques and development of a personal style to create typographic designs that are technically sound and visually interesting.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Development Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Each student implements a major web site. Students apply system analysis concepts to design a working website using graphics, security, and information processing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Technology Project Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides sophomores with the capstone experience of developing a computer information system. Students learn the phases of the software development life cycle and work in teams to follow a project management plan in order to analyze, design, and implement an information system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 180. Corequisite: Level 2 programming language elective.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers server-side programming used in web development. CGI and scripting languages are covered and applied. Students create web applications, some of which include database components.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 135 and CMST 180, and CMST 247.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class involves significant laboratory assignments completed outside of class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Media Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides sophomores with the capstone experience of developing a professional quality project in digital media. Students learn problem solving through the design process used in digital media development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: C++ Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of C++ as an object-oriented programming language for students having had previous college level computer programming courses. Students write Windows applications using classes,  MFC, and managed and unmanaged code. Programs involve Windows interfacing, exception handling, database access, COM and the creation of DLLs. Each student individually completes a final capstone course project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internetworking
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts and principles of internetworking with TCP/IP. Topics include IP addressing, subnetting, transport services, internet architecture, routing strategies, and TCP/IP applications. Students implement and analyze various internet topologies and router configurations through hands-on activities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Java Programming II
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of Java as a web programming language. Topics include exception handling, file I/O, advanced programming techniques and data structures, Java applets, multithreaded programming, client/server communication, and database and web connectivity. Students design, implement, and present a final capstone course project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Unix Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: The essentials of administering the Unix operating system. Topics include Unix installation and loading, an in-depth look at its file system, software installation, user configuration, handling security, modems, networking, and configuration of network services.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Network Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts and techniques of developing computer programs that communicate over a network using the TCP/IP and UDP/IP protocols. The course examines the use of sockets to communicate between a client and a server focusing on application-layer protocols commonly used on the Internet.  Application layer topics and protocols studied include DNS, web (HTTP, HTML, and XML), electronic mail (SMTP, MIME, POP, and IMAP) and secure communication (SSL and TLS). Asynchronous and multithreaded programming technologies are studied as client and server applications are developed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Business Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to computer programming for business applications. Topics include the nature of business programming, sequential file processing, detail and summary reporting, control break processing, and data validation. Lab work includes writing programs using the COBOL language.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 200; or CMST 102 and CMST 103.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Data Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: A systematic study of data structures and algorithms organized around the unifying concept of data abstraction. Topics include abstract data types, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, hash tables, heaps, sorting, and searching. The implementations of these data types using object-based constructs are studied and compared with respect to algorithms running times.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operating Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the concepts of basic operating systems and the services they provide. Topics include memory and file management, process control, input, output, and control of computer hardware. The features of modern, popular operating systems are highlighted.

htmlparse.Course.title: Software Architecture and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of varied software architectures and their viability. Architectural analysis includes the influences of operating systems, programming languages, data distribution, user interaction, marketing methods, and deployment. Additional topics include software licensing, metering, certification, configuration management, installation, and security.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 332 or CMST 334; and CMST 370.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Database Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the theoretical foundations of database design, implementation, and management as well as social and ethical issues associated with database design. Topics include the enhanced E-R model, object-oriented model, distributed databases, advanced SQL, security, data warehousing and mining. Students design, implement, and present a capstone course project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 180 and level 2 programming language elective.

htmlparse.Course.title: Network Security
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the information and skills needed to design, install, configure, secure, and administer the interface between a LAN and the Internet. Emphasis is on designing and implementing secure systems communicating within a TCP/IP environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systems Analysis and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of software engineering methodologies for the analysis, design, and implementation of software systems. Topics include structured analysis and design, object-oriented analysis and design, implementation and testing strategies, and software principles and metrics. Students work in teams to design, implement, and present a final capstone course project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 332 or 334; and senior standing. Corequisite: CMST 370.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Technology Senior Project
htmlparse.Course.description: A sequel to CMST 460 in which students work individually or in teams to develop a significant project in their area of interest. Students are expected to apply the software engineering methodologies from CMST 460, write project documentation, and make verbal presentations. Whenever feasible, real-world projects are solicited from local businesses.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Algorithm Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques of algorithm design including greedy, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, backtracking and branch-and-bound. Covers algorithmic solutions to problems from a variety of application areas including games, graphs and encryption. Emphasis is on programming assignments that enable students to develop their problem solving and algorithm design skills.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CMST 370 and level 2 programming language elective.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Systems Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present advanced computer systems technology topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation of professional problems and practices by students, faculty, contractors, architects, and various organizations associated with the building industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. One hour lecture a month.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Science and Management Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to construction science and management; emphasis on relationship of construction science and management to the building design and construction industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Applications in Engineering and Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental applications of computer programming and software using engineering and construction problems, primarily advanced use of spreadsheets with macros, data tables, embedded graphics, and presentations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and MATH 150, or equivalent course in trigonometry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statics A
htmlparse.Course.description: Composition and resolution of forces; equilibrium of force systems; application of the principles of statics to problems, including force analyses of simple structures.  Centroids; moments of inertia.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 150 or equivalent, PHYS 113, and MATH 220.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and analysis of construction materials, their properties, selection, and use.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Techniques and Detailing
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of construction methods and procedures in the assembly of building materials.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Drawings
htmlparse.Course.description: Production of a set of construction drawings. Emphasis on construction procedures. Introduction to shop drawings.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of site construction problems and procedures, site survey and investigations, review of site plans, construction layouts, earthwork calculation, excavation/shoring methods, computer applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Construction Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Applications in Construction Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of specialized computer techniques to the solution of problems in construction science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: By appointment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: The elastic analysis of determinate and indeterminate structures. Emphasis on equilibrium equations, shear and moment diagrams and solving forces in trusses. Includes solutions of indeterminate structures by moment distribution and matrix stiffness method with microcomputer applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Timber Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of design, fabrication, and erection of timber structures including both solid and laminated materials.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Steel Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of design, fabrication, and erection of structural steel in conformance with codes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concrete and Masonry Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of design, fabrication, and erection of concrete and masonry structures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Heating and Air Conditioning
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of designing, applying, and installing heating and air conditioning systems for buildings.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electrical and Lighting
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic design and construction of building electrical, lighting, and distribution systems with emphasis on the National Electrical Code and installation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Supply and Plumbing
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of the design and layout of plumbing and fire protection, and individual waste treatment systems for buildings including code requirements and estimating.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Methods and Equipment
htmlparse.Course.description: Operations, costs, productivity of construction equipment. Investments/life cycle costing of the equipment. Equipment selection criteria and analysis. Construction methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethics and Professional Standards
htmlparse.Course.description: An application of the concepts of ethics as applied to the professional standards of the design and construction industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Construction Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of specific design problems under the direct supervision of a member of the construction science faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Heavy Construction Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of asphalt, asphalt and concrete paving operations, concrete batch plant operations, heavy construction equipment and applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Engineered Metal Buildings
htmlparse.Course.description: Pre-engineered metal building systems: history, components, erection procedures and sequencing, delivery considerations, quality control, safety, and quantity surveying and plan reading.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Professional program standing in construction science and management or graduate student in architectural engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tilt-up Concrete Structures in Construction Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Basics of concrete, principles of tilt-up concrete, construction operations of tilt-up projects, planning procedures for job site erection, and safety procedures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Systems Commissioning
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and methods of proper procedures for installing, commissioning and maintaining efficient performance of building envelope and support systems including mechanical and electrical systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Either CNS 534, 535, and 536 or ARE 533, 534 and 536.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Estimating
htmlparse.Course.description: Understanding estimating procedures, quantity surveying, specification reviews, pricing of an estimate, market analysis, subcontractor and supplier solicitation, and risk management, following the CSI format.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CNS 325 and 540. Concurrent enrollment: CNS 645. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CNS 642.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the business of construction; study of legal considerations, contract documents, bonds and insurance. Evaluation of the characteristics of the construction firm, organization structure, and financial performance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Construction Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Topical material of importance in the management of construction such as marketing, ethics, personnel management, etc.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Scheduling and Cost Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Construction cost reporting and control. Construction planning, both long-term and short-interval, construction scheduling, monitoring, and controlling. Computer application.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CNS 540 and concurrent enrollment in CNS 641.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Safety
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to safety and safety programs, workers’ compensation, OSHA organization and structure, safety policies and record keeping, safety standards. Emphasis will be on communication and job-site safety management. On-site safety inspections will be required within class presentation and written reports to be submitted.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CNS 535 and CNS 540.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Trends in Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Broad overview of relevant topics in the construction industry in the areas of project management, field supervision, estimating, contracting, and various other special topics, taught by industry professionals who specialize in their area of expertise.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CNS 641, 642, and 645. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CNS 650.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Shop drawing and submittal processes, field and office practices, change orders, construction safety standards and practice, pre-construction planning, expediting, short-interval planning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CNS 641, CNS 642, and CNS 645. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: CNS 650.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanical and Electrical Estimating
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of mechanical and electrical building systems estimating. Procedure for evaluating relative costs of different plumbing, HVAC, and electrical/lighting systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARE 534 or CNS 534, ARE 536 or CNS 536, and prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ARE 533 or CNS 535.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Speaking IA
htmlparse.Course.description: Alternate to COMM 106. Principles and practice of message preparation, audience analysis, presentational skills, and speech criticism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Primarily granted for students whose curricula require a 2-credit hour course. Credit not granted for both COMM 105 and 106.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Speaking IA-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Alternate to COMM 106. Principles and practice of message preparation, audience analysis, presentational skills, and speech criticism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Primarily granted for students whose curricula require a 2-credit hour course. Credit not granted for both COMM 105 and 106.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Speaking I
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practice of message preparation, audience analysis, presentational skills, and speech criticism permitting greater practice in oral presentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit not granted for both COMM 105 and 106.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Speaking I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practice of message preparation, audience analysis, presentational skills, and speech criticism permitting greater practice in oral presentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit not granted for both COMM 105 and 106.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Speaking 1A, Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors speech preparation and delivery; a survey of topics basic to rhetoric, communication, and linguistics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For arts and sciences honors students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Human Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the traditions, foundations and contexts of human communication that are studied and practiced in society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forensics Participation
htmlparse.Course.description: Intercollegiate debate or individual events.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of director of the activity.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for 4 credit hours maximum credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Trial Advocacy
htmlparse.Course.description: A hands-on introduction to communication in the legal process, with a primary focus on basic techniques attorneys use to develop and present a persuasive case.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Business and Professional Speaking
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practice of speaking in an organizational setting. Areas of emphasis will be oral reports, interviewing, interpersonal communication, and working in groups.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Business and Professional Speaking-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practice of speaking in an organizational setting. Areas of emphasis will be oral reports, interviewing, interpersonal communication, and working in groups.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Forensics
htmlparse.Course.description: Current practices and theories for competitive intercollegiate forensics activity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of director of the activity.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May not be taken concurrent with COMM 210.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Human Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of basic theories of human communication focusing on sending, receiving, and responding to messages face-to-face.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Speaking II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced principles and practice of speech composition, audience adaptation, and delivery.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interpersonal Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the dynamics of face-to-face interpersonal interaction. Focus is on applying principles of relational communication.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonverbal Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of nonverbal communication in human interaction; theory and research in kinesics, proxemics, and paralinguistics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Argumentation and Debate
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic theories of argumentation with emphasis on the construction and criticism of well reasoned and supported positions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Group Discussion Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of small group decision making. Projects emphasize participation in and analysis of communication in the small group.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Interviewing
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of interviewing as it occurs in a variety of situations, including journalistic, diagnostic, persuasive, and managerial. Emphasis on developing practical skills in planning, managing interviews, and interpreting data in the professional context.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Rhetoric in Western Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the figures, concepts, and trends in the development of rhetorical theory from classical to modern times.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar Small Group Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to qualified students in the arts and sciences honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of gender as a variable in interpersonal, organizational, and public communication processes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Organizational Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Review the literature and develop research projects regarding basic variables of communication in organizational contexts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coaching and Directing Speech Activities
htmlparse.Course.description: Current practices in coaching curricular and extra-curricular speech activities with practical experience in the problems and procedures of directing a forensic program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of general communication or theatre courses that are 200 level or above, COMM 325, and THTRE 263.

htmlparse.Course.title: Freedom of Speech
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of communication and legal principles pertaining to freedom of expression, and an examination of their implications for competing interests such as public order, national security, morality, civil rights, and fairness.

htmlparse.Course.title: Criticism of Public Discourse
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of public influence based on study of historical and contemporary models of rhetorical criticism. The students’ critical experiences will focus on a broad array of public discourse including political, social, and cultural messages.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: The Rhetoric of the American Presidency
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the American presidency from a rhetorical perspective, emphasizing the symbolic resources and duties of the office and those who hold it. Special attention paid to the public discourse of recent presidents during moments of national crisis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of the concepts, methods, and tools by which communication research is designed and conducted.  Methods covered in this course include: focus groups, surveys, experiments, and content analysis.  By the end of this term, students should be able to critically consume communication research, understand the process of using social science to solve communication problems, and have experience in conducting your own research project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: In this course you will work both individually and as part of in-class teams.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rhetoric and Social Movements
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the scope and functions of persuasive communication in contemporary social movements.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of political discourse. Attention is directed to theory that encompasses political discourse as it affects political behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Collaborative Communication and Event Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the role communication plays in collaborative interactions, including program/conference/event planning and civic commemorations. Application of organizational communication theory through planning, analysis, deconstruction, and critique of various collaborative events.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Human Discourse
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of selected subjects in the analysis in human communication.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Trial Advocacy
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study in theory and techniques of courtroom persuasion, emphasizing the complexities of case analysis, courtroom procedures, theme development, and the use of evidence.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rhetoric of Community Building
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the symbolic processes of community building. Specifically, the study of the role language plays in sustaining the viability of rural community.

htmlparse.Course.title: Legal Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the vital role communication plays in the practice of law, with an emphasis on communication in the courtroom.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: COMM 105 or 106, and instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercultural Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the relationship between language and culture and its impact on human communication. Examines how language and culture differ among people and how differences are handled through the process of communication.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Argumentation Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced study of prominent argumentation theorists, with an in-depth examination of special topics concerning the philosophy, theory, and practice of argumentation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Persuasion
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of communication as persuasion; examination of contemporary approaches to persuasion.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication and Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the ways in which leadership in differing contexts is defined and exercised through communication. Constructs examined include: credibility, charisma, vision, power, myth, and public memory.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Relational Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of theories and research on the role of communication in social and personal relationships. Emphasis is on observing and evaluating communication behaviors using real-life media examples.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication & Democracy
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the ways in which democratic citizenship and participation in the public sphere are defined and enacted through communication.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: A demonstration of the mastery of vocabulary, theory, and the ability to make practical applications of the study of rhetoric and communication will be required of all senior communication studies majors. Mastery will be demonstrated by completing a senior capstone project and presenting the result of that project to the assembled communication studies faculty and majors in a required colloquium.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Honors Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Thesis Colloquium.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to seniors in Arts and Sciences Honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Communication Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will work for/within an organization during the course of a semester.  Interns must complete a minimum of 100 work hours to earn course credit.  The internship work experience is intended to help apply formal classroom education to “real World” work experience.  Ideally internships are pre-professional and project based experiences allowing students the opportunity to make meaningful contributions to the organization.  Each intern will complete a series of deliverables to the internship director as well as work under a site supervisor at the host organization.  Prior to registration, the internship director must approve all internships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Rhetoric and Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study of selected topics in communication and rhetoric.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Communication Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to descriptive and experimental methodologies in communication, including conceptualization and operationalization of communication concepts, strategies of research design, and logic of inquiry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Group Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Review literature and develop research projects pertaining to the communication processes in small task groups. Topics include group communication processes, barriers to group communication, and style-specific theories of effective group communication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Perspectives on Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of current perspectives on the communication process. Materials cover assumptions, principles, implications and selected research within each perspective.

htmlparse.Course.title: Language and Social Interaction
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the epistemological, social, and behavioral functions of language in communication. Examination of the processes by which language functions to construct one’s worldview and guide individual action.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: COMM 320 or LING 280 or ANTH 220; junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instructional Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of theory and practice of communication in the classroom including both teacher and student communication. Topics include: integration of modes of communication, language choices, power, humor, communication strategies for instruction, and impact of communication on learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of American Public Address
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of American speakers, from the time of Jonathan Edwards to the present, including their education, major speeches, and contributions to the rhetorical history of the United States.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Persuasion
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey and analysis of advanced theory and experimental studies in persuasion.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical Rhetorical Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of rhetorical theory and criticism from early Greek to Roman times.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Rhetorical Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of major European and American contributors to rhetorical theory in the twentieth century.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rhetorical Criticism
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of traditional and contemporary approaches to the analysis of public discourse.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Rhetoric of Social Movements
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the theory and criticism of social movement rhetoric. Topics may include the development of movement studies as a distinct genre of scholarship within the field of speech communication, questions and controversies in the rhetorical study of movements, and the rationale for protest tactics, from nonviolence to terrorism.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the role that public discourse plays in attaining, enacting and constraining leadership in a democratic society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Relational Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of theories and research on the role of communication in social and personal relationships. Emphasis is on observing and evaluating communication behaviors using real-life media examples.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political and Corporate Speechwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the principles and practice of professional speechwriting with a special emphasis on the role of speechwriting in a democratic society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Communication and Conflict
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised application of communication theory in self-selected conflict situations in culturally diverse settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: COMM 120 and any other required course at or above 300 level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercultural Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the relationship between language and culture and its impact on human communication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Speech
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to students in any communication studies area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is for record keeping purposes to allow the University Honors Program and the College of Technology and Aviation to monitor and track students who are a part of the Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Humanities Through the Arts
htmlparse.Course.description: A general introduction to the humanities, focusing on what they are and their basic importance. Painting, sculpture, architecture, literature, drama, music, dance, film, and photography will be explored. Emphasis will be on participation, involvement, guest speakers, tours, and appreciation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the University Honors Program including directions, goals and student requirements for completion of the program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Acceptance into the Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Arts, Sciences, and Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Opportunity for advanced independent study in specific subject areas in Department of Arts, Sciences, and Business.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Subjects are selected by the student and the instructor. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Experiential learning program in an off-campus setting. Written documentation and oral presentation of project goals, experiences, and accomplishments.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Approval of faculty internship advisor and sponsoring company.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems in Arts, Sciences and Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Opportunity for advanced independent study in specific subject areas in the Department of Arts, Sciences, and Business.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the Professional Master of Technology student with the opportunity to gain a thorough understanding of basic aviation industry management practices in use today combined with historical perspectives.  Includes case study analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Feedlot Health Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Health of cattle in a commercial feedyard. Includes health risk assessment, cattle handling, processing, vaccination protocols, identification/treatment of sick cattle, necropsy techniques, using computer data to make management decisions for feeder cattle, other management issues. Discussion of disease syndromes and foreign diseases.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cow-Calf Health Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Management of animal well-being and efficient production in a cow-calf system. Includes the areas of health, growth, nutrition, pharmaceutical management, and reproduction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medicine I
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of medical and pathophysiologic aspects of diseases affecting the urinary, endocrine, integumentary, respiratory, hemic and neuromuscular systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four 1-hour lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medicine III
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the etiology, clinical signs, diagnosis, treatment, and control of common diseases which affect horses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medicine II
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of the medical and pathophysiological aspects of diseases affecting the gastrointestinal, cardiovascular, and ophthalmic systems, oncology, and dentistry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four 1-hour lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Animal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the etiology clinical signs, diagnosis, treatment and control of diseases which affect cattle, swine, and sheep.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beef Production Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of the veterinarian in livestock production units, including interactions with producers, nutritionists, investors and others in decision analysis. Emphasis is on the professional services that veterinarians provide to beef production systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: A focus on practical aspects of nutrition as it relates to performance, health and animal well-being of food-producing animals and, programs designed for health and well-being of small animals including exotic animals. Nutritional aspects of the mechanisms of health and disease are taught primarily at the individual and population level with some molecular and cellular aspects included. Designed for all students to be able to properly nourish animals in their care during their career.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine or graduate student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory and principles of x-rays, production and interpretation of radiographs and exposure factors, special radiographic methods, film storage and handling, processing, safety measures, and biologic effects of radiation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supplemental Equine Theriogenolgy
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth exposure to methods of maximizing reproductive efficiency in the mare and the stallion. Advanced equine reproductive physiology, diagnostics, and therapeutics are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Diagnostic Imaging I
htmlparse.Course.description: Radiographic, ultrasonographic and nuclear imaging in the clinical setting, with emphasis on making/identifying images of diagnostic quality, interpretation, indications for imaging, and radiation safety.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Anesthesia
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical instruction in the skills and techniques used in the practice of clinical veterinary anesthesia of both large and small animals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Externship and/or Programmed Study
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the professional student with the opportunity to study with specialists not available at Kansas State University or in unique areas of veterinary medical practice or research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine and the approval of the externship or program of study by the course coordinator.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ophthalmology
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the surgery and medical diagnosis and treatment of ocular disease in animals in the setting of the veterinary medical center. Problem solving, differential diagnosis, diagnostic procedures and medical and surgical therapy will be emphasized using veterinary patients.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theriogenology-Companion Animal Core
htmlparse.Course.description: First 5 weeks, consideration of prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disease, and maintenance of health and productivity of the genital tract of all species. Second 5 weeks students review companion animal (equine, canine, and feline) content.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Surgery I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the basics of veterinary anesthesia, surgical techniques, and patient management by a systems design. Problems common to all species of domestic animals will be presented to provide foundations of surgical knowledge and experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of all required second year veterinary courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture and one hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Surgery II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of Veterinary Surgery I. Introduction to the basics of veterinary anesthesia, surgical techniques, and patient management by a systems design. Problems common to all species of domestic animals will be presented to provide foundations of surgical knowledge and experience.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Diagnostic Techniques in Equine Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: This elective course emphasizes the techniques needed for internal medicine. Lectures and labs covering endoscopy, bronchoalveolar lavage, transtracheal wash, ultrasound, spinal tap, dentistry and epidural will emphasize skills, indications, and complications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pleasure Horse Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is intended to present topics of interest to equine interested veterinary students. The objectives of the course will focus on diagnosis and clinical management as will be performed in practice. The primary goal of the course is to supplement the equine interested veterinary student with topics that are not offered in the core curriculum, yet will be encountered in an equine or mixed practice setting. The format will use a case and problem-based discussion to present and apply clinically relevant information.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exotic Pet Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Entry-level knowledge base for the species likely to be encountered in a private practice setting including snakes/small reptiles, caged birds, and small mammals (ferrets, gerbils, hamsters, chinchillas).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Oncology
htmlparse.Course.description: The approach to diagnosis and treatment of cancer-bearing patients will be emphasized. Skills to master include fine needle aspirates and basic cytology, biopsy techniques (punch, wedge, pinch and tru-cut), bone marrow aspirate and core biopsy procedures and chemotherapy administration. A greater depth of understanding of the biologic behavior and treatment options of commonly seen tumor types (lymphoma, mast cell tumors, hemangiosarcoma, osteosarcoma, etc.) and chemotherapy safety will be emphasized. Medical management of cancer-related problems as well as treatment of therapy-induced side effects will also be covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dermatology/Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to emphasize dermatology diagnostic work-up and management of dermatologic cases. May include proper techniques for performing procedures such as skin scraping, bacterial and fungal culturing, performing cytology, obtaining skin biopsies, ear clearing and trichography.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Emergency Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentations of cases in the ICU or cases that were recently seen on emergency. Current literature that is relevant to the case will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Practice Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a foundation in business management and marketing to prepare veterinary students for success in private veterinary practice. Lectures include personal marketing, business organizational structure, gauging and monitoring production, management practice finance, recruitment, personnel management, effective practice marketing (internal and external), achieving better client satisfaction and retention, and the road to practice ownership.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: Demonstration, instruction and experience in physical examination and diagnostic skills necessary for routine veterinary practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Equine Theriogenology
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will participate in routine procedures that develop skills in handling horses, rectal exams, ultrasonography, semen collection, artificial insemination, uterine therapies and minor surgical procedures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine and CS 728 or CS 783.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systems Integration of Small Animal Internal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Elective course in small animal internal medicine. This course will provide in-depth learning of complex issues regarding case management of the canine and feline patient with an integrated systems approach. The course will also introduce controversial and emerging topics in small animal internal medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Animal Local Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the role of the veterinarian in the practice of clinical medicine in livestock production units. Students will work under faculty supervision in ambulatory and local practice settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Animal Medicine & Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of individual food animal medicine and surgery. Students will work under faculty supervision in an in-house setting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will offer general exposure to equine internal medicine and theriogenology. Students will be responsible for diagnoses, treatment and nursing care of out-patients, in-patients, and emergency duties.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will offer general exposure to equine surgery and theriogenology. Students will be responsible for diagnoses, treatment, and nursing care of out-patients, in-patients, and emergency duties.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Animal Internal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of internal medicine in the setting of the Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital. Students will be engaged in the diagnosis and management of complex cases referred to the internal medicine service.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Animal General Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of preventative medicine, general practice medicine, and specialty medicine. Students spend three weeks with the Pet Health Center learning the various aspects of outpatient services.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Small Animal Soft Tissue Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to train senior or elective veterinary students in the diagnosis and treatment of small animal soft tissue and general surgical diseases through participation in the Small Animal Soft Tissue Service of the Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Small Animal Orthopedic Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Course is designed to train senior or elective veterinary students in the diagnosis/treatment of small animal orthopedic surgical diseases though the Orthopedic Service of the Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Cardiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to expose students to the cardiovascular system of domestic animals, emphasizing clinical management and understanding of common congenital and acquired cardiac diseases.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Lameness I
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures will cover common causes of lameness emphasizing specific portions of the lameness exam providing the foundation for diagnosis and treatment of specific equine musculoskeletal diseases.  Students will perform lameness exams including diagnostic imaging to correctly diagnose the “unknown lameness” and prescribe appropriate therapeutic options.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of all required second year veterinary courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 12 lectures, 3 labs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Lameness II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of Equine Lameness I. This course will complete the review of the most common lameness problems in horses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 12 lectures, 3 labs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Exotic Pet Medicine/Introduction to Zoological Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the diseases, medicine, and captive management of non-traditional species including companion birds, reptiles, rabbits, ferrets, and rodents; and an introduction to zoo animal and wildlife medicine.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Global Veterinary Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the role of veterinarians around the world. Topics include international uses and attitudes about animals, problems the world faces pertaining to livestock production, and social tensions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second or third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine, or enrolled as a graduate student with instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture each week. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supplemental Food Animal Local Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of beef cattle herd health and production. Students will be exposed to advanced training for beef cattle practice. Areas of focus will be herd level reproduction, nutrition, infectious disease epidemiology, economics, and data analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory Animal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of laboratory animal medicine or comparative medicine to include colony health monitoring, preventive medicine, surgery, investigator support, and regulatory oversight.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beef Cattle Breeding Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Female breeding soundness and pregnancy detection in beef cattle through rectal palpation with and without ultrasound technology. Some discussions of infectious diseases that impair reproduction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 3-hour lab each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Food Animal Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced food animal medicine, surgery, reproduction, and herd health in an integrated format. Students are placed into a practice setting where individual food animal practice is placed in context with production medicine/herd health activities. Field trips and problem-solving exercises applying concepts of production analysis, disease prevention and feedlot management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Animal (Mixed) Practice Mentorship
htmlparse.Course.description: Structured one week (45 contact hours) mentorship in a large animal (bovine) practice designed to promote clinical skills training in a private practice setting with practitioners who have completed orientation training and have expressed an interest in training and mentoring veterinary students. To be completed during the first 3 years of veterinary school, prior to entering the fourth year.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Animal Practice Mentorship
htmlparse.Course.description: Structured one week (45 contact hours) mentorship in a small animal practice designed to promote clinical skills training in a private practice setting with practitioners who have completed orientation training and have expressed an interest in training and mentoring veterinary students. To be completed during the first 3 years of veterinary school, prior to entering the 4th year.

htmlparse.Course.title: Non-Traditional Practice Mentorship
