htmlparse.Course.description: Structured one week (45 contact hours) mentorship in a nontraditional veterinary setting designed to promote skills training and awareness of nontraditional or exclusive practice experiences in a private or public practice setting with veterinarians who have completed orientation training and have expressed an interest in training and mentoring veterinary students. To be completed during the first 3 years of veterinary school, prior to entering the fourth year.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Feedlot Production Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Students desiring feedlot/stocker production training. Focus on effects of nutrition, preventative medicine, environment, personnel training and other issues on the health of growing/finishing cattle.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Cow-Calf Production Management
htmlparse.Course.description: For students desiring in-depth cow-calf production training including management and assessment of production data, nutrition and ration balancing, reproductive strategies, quality assurance and economic and Standardized Performance Analysis of cow-calf enterprises.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Dentistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Skills and concepts common to general dentistry practice in the feline and canine, pre-operative exams, day-long wet lab to take and interpret digital intraoral radiographs, extract teeth, and perform dental nerve blocks. Also may participate in the evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of primary care patients.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Field Service
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will offer general exposure to equine field service and theriogenology. Students will be responsible for diagnoses, treatment, and nursing care of out-patients, in-patients and emergency duties.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Veterinary Phytotherapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of phytotherapy: traditions of herbal medicine, evaluating research, regulation of products, interactions with conventional drugs, introduction to medical botany, conserving medicinal plant species, issues using medicinal plants within evidence-based veterinary medicine.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AP 770, DMP 801, third-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Rural Food Animal Business Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An elective course that incorporates economic and food animal practice management skills. Course will focus on business aspects of agricultural industries and skills to manage a food animal practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Primary Care Externship
htmlparse.Course.description: Externships emphasizing primary care for small animal, large animal or mixed species at an approved location. Facility must have a veterinarian on-site all day, every day.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Urinary
htmlparse.Course.description: This elective builds on the case-based urinary section of CS 711.  Focus of the class will be on the disease pathophysiology and treatment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicing Veterinary Medicine in a Multicultural Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Diversity in the broadest sense of the word (cultural, racial, sexual, gender, age, religious, etc.) will be explored in the context of the practice of veterinary medicine. Understanding diversity issues can positively affect the bottom line of nearly every veterinary practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First, second or third year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Basics of Bovine Theriogenology
htmlparse.Course.description: This class is designed to provide students enrolled in the veterinary curriculum a very practical knowledge base regarding bovine reproduction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First, second or third year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Pharmacology
htmlparse.Course.description: Course focuses on the clinical application of drugs in veterinary species.  Clinical pharmacologists and clinicians from multiple clinical specialties will focus on commonly used drugs.  Students will be expected to review and build upon their previous pharmacology and medicine courses.  Emphasis will be placed on administration (including routes, dosing calculations, and methods), avoiding adverse drug reactions and interactions, evaluating patient response, written and verbal client communication, and utilizing reference resources to select and properly use veterinary therapeutics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Medicine Elective
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to be complementary to CS 710. The material presented in this class will focus on diagnostic procedures and case presentations that will not be covered in the core curriculum.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theriogenology Companion Animal Elective
htmlparse.Course.description: Five weeks of equine, canine, and feline theriogenology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Soft Tissue Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Increase student exposure to soft tissue surgical theory, techniques and importance of veterinary literature in practice. Course will provide practical, hands-on surgical experience that mimics small animal general practice by utilizing both cadavers and appropriate clinical cases. Course allows students interested in surgery in private practice or those considering internship and residency training an opportunity to further explore the field.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine and must have completed CS 754 prior to participating in this course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Care and Management of South American Camelids
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide detailed information regarding nutrition, herd health, breeding management, medicine, neonatal care, and surgical problems of llamas and alpacas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: First, second or third year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lab required.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Learning Curve of Equine Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Elective will cover various aspects of equine practice, not usually covered in traditional didactic lectures. Topics include equine husbandry, communication issues and insurance, horse colors, genetics, and genetic related diseases, aspects of equine practice and practice management, drug and medication rules for performance horses, and preventative medicine.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second or third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pain Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of the mechanisms of pain, certain pain syndromes, and the drugs and techniques available to provide analgesia.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Equine Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will have opportunities for routine and advanced clinical skills training and case management. Course discussions and case presentations will be targeted for the equine interested student and will therefore present advanced material; case discussion and rounds materials.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theriogenology-Production Animal Core
htmlparse.Course.description: First 5 weeks, consideration of prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of disease, and maintenance of health and productivity of the genital tract of all species. Third 5 weeks, students review production livestock (bovine, porcine, ovine, caprine) content.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Therio Production Animal Elective
htmlparse.Course.description: Five weeks of production livestock (bovine, porcine, ovine, caprine) theriogenology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Implications of Animal Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the behavior of different species of domestic animals: normal and abnormal behavior, clinical disorders, separation anxiety, identification of dominant breeds, communication, socialization and reproductive behavior.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 1st, 2nd, or 3rd year student standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Veterinary Soft Tissue Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Technical and intellectual lectures will cover aspects of soft tissue surgery.  Technical lectures will include: instrument handling, hand ties, suture material, stapling devices and surgical lasers.  Intellectual lectures will include: surgical approaches to the body cavities, intra-operative complications and post-operative management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of all required second year veterinary courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 12 lectures, 3 labs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Surgical Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: Manual surgical skills will be taught using surgical models and cadaver tissues. Students will be taught the following skills and techniques: instrument handling, speed and efficiency, hand ties, ligature under tension, suture patters, closure under tension, anastomosis and enterotomy technique and excision of circular lesions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CS 729 - Surgery I and 3rd year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Czech for Travelers
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the Czech language with emphasis on everyday expressions and vocabulary. History, social life, politics and other cultural issues are also introduced.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Recommended for students participating in study abroad programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Dance I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to principles of modern dance. Emphasis on correct body alignment, movement efficiency, and creative potential of the individual.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ballet I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basics of classical ballet training includes terminology, body positions, movement vocabulary, and principles of body alignment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Dance I
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic course in jazz technique and style, focusing on isolations, rhythmic articulation, and the control and release of energy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tap I
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for beginning dancers, this course develops skills, knowledge, vocabulary, and appreciation of tap dance as an art form through the presentation of fundamental tap techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Improvisational Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of personal creative sources for spontaneous movement through improvisational structures. Emphasis on solo and group problem-solving in creating a performance work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anatomy for Dancers
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of human skeletal structure. Application and implication for performance, teaching, and injury prevention.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dance as an Art Form
htmlparse.Course.description: Dance in its religious, social, and artistic forms. Film, slides, demonstrations, and lectures will trace the function of dance in society, the influence of society on dance, how dance relates to other art forms, and current trends in the dance world.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Dance Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination and application of computer, audio, and video technology to dance. Includes instruction and use in performance, choreography, education and research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rhythmic Notation for Dance
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic elements of meter, tempo, rhythm, and notation. Application and practice to dance pedagogy, performance, and choreography.

htmlparse.Course.title: Performance Styles
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and practice of technique and performance of specific period/historical, character, or ethnic/specialty dance styles.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated three times.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pointe Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers classical ballet pointe technique. Focuses on the development of both technique and artistic expression.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dance Composition I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the principles of the choreographic craft. Practical experience in development of movement phrases. Culminating presentation and critique of work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Dance II
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern Dance II
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DANCE 120 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 8 hours. Only 2 of these hours may be applied toward humanities requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Dance III
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern Dance III
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DANCE 323 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 8 hours. Only 2 of these hours may be applied toward humanities requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ballet II
htmlparse.Course.description: Ballet II
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DANCE 165 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 8 hours. Only 2 of these hours may be applied toward humanities requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ballet III
htmlparse.Course.description: Ballet III
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DANCE 325 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 8 hours. Only 2 of these hours may be applied toward humanities requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: West African Styles of Social Dance and Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores several styles of dancing and drumming from West Africa.  Instruction includes technique in the traditional social dances, drumming/musical skills, and songs for the social dances.  History, traditions, and social context of the dances.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: No prior experience is necessary. All musical instruments are supplied for class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Dance II
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate course in jazz technique and style focusing on development of isolations, rhythmic articulation, and the control and release of energy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 8 hours. Only 2 of these hours may be applied toward humanities requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Dance III
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced course in jazz technique and style focusing on development of isolations, rhythmic articulation, and the control and release of energy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DANCE 371 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 8 hours. Only 2 of the hours may be applied toward humanities requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Musical Theatre Dance
htmlparse.Course.description: History, technique and performance of musical theatre dance.  Rehearsal and performance of selected examples of Broadway choreography.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tap II
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed as an intermediate dance class that targets the development of skills, knowledge, and appreciation of tap dance through the presentation of fundamental techniques and other movement experiences. Topics include: concert, rhythm, and fundamental tap dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tap III
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed as an advanced dance class that targets the development of skills, knowledge, and appreciation of tap dance through the presentation of techniques and other movement experiences. Topics include: Broadway and concert dance, rhythm, and Funk Tap dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to qualified students in the arts and sciences honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Movement Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Study, analysis, and application of movement theory to dance training, education, creation, and performance. Scientific and somatic principles are emphasized in the art form and body therapies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Movement Exploration and Creative Dance for Children
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of scientific principles to the teaching of basic movement concepts and creative dance for grades K-6. Emphasis upon a guided discovery and problem-solving approach.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 320, 330, and 335 (or any two and concurrent enrollment in the third).
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dance History I
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers dance, particularly ballet and modern dance, from beginnings until the turn of 20th century.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dance History II
htmlparse.Course.description: History of Dance from the 20th Century until the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dance Composition II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced training and directed experiences in dance composition. Development of theme, phrasing, and style with particular emphasis on group forms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Dance
htmlparse.Course.description: Individually directed research/creative endeavor in dance, normally as a preliminary to writing a senior honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, membership in the honors program of the College of Arts and Sciences, and permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once to a total of 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts and Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Performance Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in the techniques of dance production and performance. Emphasis is on practical application.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated four times.

htmlparse.Course.title: K-State Tap Dance Ensemble
htmlparse.Course.description: A performing ensemble that dances for the K-State and Manhattan communities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Audition required in April.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods and Materials of Teaching Dance
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth survey of the development of dance education and a practical examination of dance for its educative, artistic, disciplinary, and therapeutic values.  Emphasis on role of dance education, pedagogy, and advocacy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DANCE 205, 405, and 504 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dance Education Fieldwork
htmlparse.Course.description: A semester of supervised fieldwork incorporating dance as an educative tool in the classroom, in a therapeutic setting, or in an advocacy position. Application of dance education theory under faculty supervision and conference.

htmlparse.Course.title: K-State African Dance and Music Ensemble
htmlparse.Course.description: A performing group that is open to all students and does not require an audition.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Student creates and presents major performance, choreographic or written project demonstrating advanced level of achievement.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Studies in Dance
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in dance.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Maximum of 3 hours applicable toward degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Laboratory Science (Medical Technology)
htmlparse.Course.description: Enrollment in this course allows students attending a hospital-based clinical program to complete the 30 credit hours of clinical work required for the bachelor’s degree in clinical laboratory science (medical technology).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of the 94 credit hours of undergraduate course work required for the clinical laboratory science (medical technology) degree.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students participating in the University Honors Program and who are enrolled in the College of Arts & Sciences must enroll each semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the English Language Program
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose for DAS 030 is to provide a monitoring mechanism for English Language Program students.  It also allows the ELP, International Programs and International Pre-admissions to track new international students.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
This course is for zero credits.
May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Training in Organization, Wellness, Academics, Responsibilities and Discipline in the ELP
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to engage English Language Program (ELP) students who are at risk due to repeated non-performance in ELP classes.  Explores good study skills, healthy living habits, community involvement, self-discipline, and guided study sessions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One credit required for students after one semester of non-performance, two credits required for continued enrollment for those with repeated non-performance over consecutive semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: National Student Exchange
htmlparse.Course.description: Enrollment in this course would be required for students participating in the National Student Exchange program.  Enrollment in this course would serve primarily as a placeholder and enable the student to maintain full-time enrollment status at K-State.  A grade of I (incomplete) would be posted at the end of each term (semester) of enrollment.  Upon receipt of the transfer transcript from the chosen exchange institution, the DAS 050 course and would be removed from the student’s record and would be replaced by a text entry detailing participation in the National Student Exchange program.  The actual hours earned would be reflected as transfer credit from the institution attended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ambassador Service and Leadership in the College of Arts and Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: For students who have been chosen as ambassadors for the College of Arts and Sciences.  Students are required to enroll to be ambassadors.

htmlparse.Course.title: First Year Seminar in K-State Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the intellectual and cultural life of the university.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Student Governance
htmlparse.Course.description: Practicum in Student Governance
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Careers in Science and Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to career opportunities with emphasis on gaining perspective from practicing professionals from multiple science and engineering disciplines through weekly seminars held throughout the semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two lab hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic English syntax, writing, reading, speaking, and listening for native speakers of other languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beginning English I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic English syntax, writing, reading, speaking, and listening for native speakers of other languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Beginning English II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic English syntax, writing, reading, speaking, and listening for native speakers of other languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate English I
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate study of basic English sentence structure, writing, reading, speaking and listening for native speakers of other languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate English II
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate study of basic English sentence structure, writing, reading, speaking and listening for native speakers of other languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced English I
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of English writing, reading, speaking, and listening with emphasis on university-level tasks.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced English II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of English reading, writing, listening, and academic communication. Providing a refinement of language skills for international students beginning academic coursework.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to American Academic Research Writing for International Students
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to American conventions of research paper writing with emphasis on American academic standards.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by the English Language Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to American Academic Presentation for International Students
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to American rhetorical patterns of academic speaking, focusing specifically on deductive and inductive organization patterns and expectations of American audiences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by the English Language Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation to the American Higher Education System
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to support English Language Program students as they transition to K-State, the English Language Program (ELP), and the Manhattan community.  Introduction to the campus resources available.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital English for International Students
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in online language and communication for international students in order to develop strategies and skills for working effectively in academic digital interaction and collaboration.  Includes study of function and use of different web 2.0 tools, communication skills for intercultural collaboration, and the English language styles and rhetoric appropriate in specific online settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Corequisite: Concurrent enrollment in DAS 154 or DAS 152.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Grammar in Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of basic English grammar; practice of basic grammar in writing; review of grammar usage in academic writing; practice in proofreading and editing of work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by the English Language Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reading Skills for Non-Native Speakers of English
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course designed to improve reading skills and increase academic vocabulary of non-native speakers of English engaged in academic classes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Written Communication for Non-Native Speakers of English
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in academic reading and writing skills in order to develop reading skills, increase reading speed, and improve writing of reports, analyses, and summaries. Includes grammar review, the study of style, and development of an academic vocabulary.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by the English Language Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Listening Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction to improve listening, comprehension, and note-taking skills. Instruction in conversational speaking, with an emphasis on developing oral fluency and the effective use of vocabulary and idioms. Includes pronunciation practice, group work, and short academic presentations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by the English Language Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pronunciation and Speaking Skills for Non-Native Speakers of English
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction in speaking for non-native speakers of English to improve comprehension of non-simplified conversational English. Practice in asking for clarification, responding appropriately to requests, and encouraging interaction, as well as the pronunciation of troublesome English sounds and intonation patterns. Also brief introduction to American culture, especially the American educational system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Placement by the English Language Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Integrated Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced, combined-skills course to improve the reading, writing, and speaking skills of non-native speakers of English.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practical Training in ESL
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to practical classroom skills for the non-education major planning to teach ESL abroad as part of a study abroad or internship abroad experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by the English Language Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching and Cultural Orientation for International Teaching Assistants
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to American undergraduate education, American culture, and university policies. Discussion of effective teaching techniques, nonverbal language, and coping techniques. Practice focusing on pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and interactive speaking skills. Individual tutorials based on video-taped teaching presentations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission by English Language Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exploration of American Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: This course explores America and the impressions that international students may have about American society and customs. Students will further their experience of American culture through readings, lectures, and films, allowing them to integrate and interpret their experiences inside and outside of the classroom during their stay here.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DAS 186, AMETH 160, or instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Directions and goals for the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent Reading Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Pre-Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Forty hours spent observing the practice of dentistry, medicine, or optometry. Students are under the supervision and direction of individual dentists, physicians, or optometrists.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, permission of the health professions advisor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Great Conversation: Primary Texts Certificate Core Course
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary, team-taught course, required for students enrolled in the Certificate in the Study of the Arts and Sciences Through Primary Texts.  This course can be taken by students not in the certificate, and for Honors credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Origins
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary general education course examining how scholars in the sciences and humanities approach knowledge about the universe, the planet earth, and life itself.  How did the universe begin?  How did life begin and how does it evolve?  How has the planet changed throughout its history?  How were answers to these questions discovered?  How do we construct narratives about these events, and how do those texts reveal our assumptions and values?

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in the Humanities (Study Abroad)
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an umbrella course for numerous individual courses offered to students in the humanities in Italy program and other study abroad experiences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of the director of the individual study abroad experience.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Nonviolence Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory and practice of nonviolence as a method of social change and as a personal way of life.  This class will engage students in the consideration of violence and nonviolence, from dynamics that occur within ourselves to those that affect the future of the Earth and its many life forms.  Students will share with each other from their own lived experience and will learn from the writings of people who have practiced nonviolence in their lives and work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: A scholarly investigation related to activities in a place of employment or in a volunteer situation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrence of a faculty advisor and approval of the arts and sciences honor program advisory council.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Written and oral presentations are required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory and laboratory study of pathogenic bacteria, viruses, richettsiae, fungi, and parasites. Includes morphology, physiology, taxonomy, and medical significance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and laboratory study of analytical biochemistry, incorporating both routine and special chemical procedures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Hematology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of blood cell derivation, maturation, and function, principles of hemastasis, and blood coagulation. Methodology used in routine and special hematology studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Immunology
htmlparse.Course.description: Immunohematology, the study of fundamentals of antigen-antibody reactions, blood groups and types, crossmatches, blood components, and the laboratory methods used in immunohematology studies; and serology, the theory of immunologic responses and procedures used in determination of serological studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Clinical Laboratory Science (Medical Technology)
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic principles and practices of the medical laboratory, techniques and special projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Research in Latin American Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Senior Research in Latin American Studies
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Research in International Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: A research paper or project on an international topic.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of 15 hours of course work in international studies secondary major.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary colloquium in which topics vary by semester. Consistently incorporates perspectives from more than one discipline and area among the arts, humanities, social sciences, and sciences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Membership in the honors program; one honors course in addition to introduction to the honors Program in the College of Arts and Sciences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Violence, Nonviolence and Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: This course reviews historical and contemporary responses to violence around the world by studying ideas, strategies, organizational approaches, and societal impacts on nonviolence and social change. Emphasis is placed on historical antecedents to recent violence and nonviolence, and on the analysis of up-to-date resources as they relate to social change.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Sciences Senior Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual exploration of an area of physical sciences culminating in a final formal written report.  Capstone course required of physical sciences interdisciplinary major.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of physical sciences advisor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in the Humanities (Study Abroad)
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an umbrella course for numerous individual courses offered to students in the Humanities in Italy program and other study abroad experiences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of the director of the individual study abroad experience.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resources/Environmental Sciences Project (NRES)
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive project in NRES. Requires integration of information and understanding acquired in NRES secondary major courses. Students must prepare and present written and oral reports.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: All writing and oral communications courses required for major. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: Fifteen hours of approved courses in NRES secondary major.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Nonviolence
htmlparse.Course.description: The capstone experience for the Undergraduate Certificate in Nonviolence Studies, includes field placement in a campus or community organization in which student will have a skill-and-research-based experience in nonviolence-related social change project.  Projects can be local, regional, national, or international in scope.  Concurrently, students will engage in academic readings and class sessions that address feminist and nonviolent approaches to social change, program design, and participatory action research.  This course will provide students with professional and academic skills that relate to employment and graduate work in diverse fields.
htmlparse.Course.crosslisted: WOMST 590 Women’s Studies Practice and Theory

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students accepted into the College of Education honors program must enroll each semester.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore or higher standing, 3.5 cumulative grade point average, acceptance into the honors program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Study Skills Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Helps the student to learn effective study methods, analyze difficulties in reading and studying, and prepare for and improve performance in examinations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation to Teacher Education at KSU
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a general orientation to the university, the College of Education, and the teacher education program. Examines the unit’s conceptual framework, program requirements including the student portfolio, advising and enrollment procedures, and policies and resources.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Professional Laboratory Experiences
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experiences in education designed to facilitate orientation and investigation of teaching through the teacher aide program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Maximum credit of 3 hours. No more than 1 credit per semester. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of topics in the field of education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the University Honors Program including directions, goals, and student requirements for completion of the program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Educational Technology for Teaching and Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduces pre-service teachers to the use of contemporary instructional technologies to enhance instruction and to facilitate professional productivity. Attention is given to issues of access and diversity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of topics in the field of education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research projects under the supervision of a professor in the College of Education.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A minimum of 2 hours credit in DED 320 or 1 hour credit in DED 320 and 1 hour selected from GENAG 310, DAS 399, GNHE 399.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students participating in the University Honors Program and who are enrolled in the College of Engineering must enroll each semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conditional Admittance Support for Transfer Students
htmlparse.Course.description: Transfer students who have been conditionally admitted to the College of Engineering must enroll in this course. This course will provide frequent communication and support in the areas of study skills and time management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: By appointment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reinstatement Support
htmlparse.Course.description: Students who have been reinstated into the College of Engineering must enroll in this course. This course will provide frequent communication and support in the areas of study skills and time management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: By appointment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Engineering Enrichment Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the academic and intellectual demands of an engineering curriculum from a multicultural perspective. Develop group cohesiveness and an attitude of mutual support by engaging in collaborative learning. Help students acquire effective study methods, analyze/compare learning/teaching styles, prepare for and improve examination performance, promote optimum utilization of campus resources, develop leadership and communication skills and enhance self-esteem.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit may not be applied towards an engineering degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Careers in Science and Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to career opportunities with emphasis on gaining perspective from practicing professionals from multiple science and engineering disciplines through weekly seminars held throughout the semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two lab hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to engineering and engineering design. Students work in teams, practice communication skills, and apply problem- solving methods to the design, build, test process. Related topics include a review of the various fields of engineering and career opportunities. The availability of campus resources and the use of academic skills such as time management and goal setting are also emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One recitation and one seminar a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the University Honors Program, including directions, goals and student requirements for completion of the program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Kansas State Engineer Publications
htmlparse.Course.description: Editorial, business, and production staff work on the Kansas State Engineer magazine, Kansas State Engineer online, and the Critical Angle electronic newspaper. Staff members write, edit, photograph, illustrate, and design publications that report on the engineering arena, locally and globally, from the student perspective.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Repeatable.
One hour recitation staff meeting a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Amateur Radio Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of amateur (“ham”) radio operation. Basics of radio electronics, antennas, FCC regulations, Morse code; successful completion of the course should ensure passing the FCC Novice and “no-code” technician examinations.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Credit may not be applied toward an engineering degree.
Two hours recitation a week for ten weeks (includes examinations).

htmlparse.Course.title: Amateur Radio Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of amateur (“ham”) radio operation. More basics of radio electronics, antennas, FCC regulations, Morse code; successful completion of the course should ensure passing the FCC General class examination.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DEN 201 or FCC Novice or “no-code” technician.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Credit may not be applied toward an engineering degree.
One hour recitation and one hour Morse code lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Building and Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the art and science of building. Historical review from ancient to contemporary including related construction methods, equipment, and systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Engineering Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of DEN 120. Emphasis on career exploration and development, introduction to graduate school options, preparation and responsibility for advising process, tips on breaking the failure cycle, behavior modification strategies, and developing and utilizing leadership skills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit may not be applied towards an engineering degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Total Quality Management and Six Sigma
htmlparse.Course.description: Learn about the basic philosophies of Six Sigma, Total Quality Management (TQM) and other continuous process improvement concepts. Topics include leadership concepts, supplier-customer relationships, employee involvement, data gatherings, and related organizational issues. Class time includes opportunities for team building and hands-on application of statistical process control tools.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Problem Solving in Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of major topics related to creative thinking, including idea development, overcoming personal and professional obstacles, managing change, effective problem solving, and teamwork productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Project Management For Engineers and Technical Professionals
htmlparse.Course.description: This online course will provide fundamental concepts of project management.  The course will include a step-by-step process to plan, implement, and evaluate each project; will demonstrate how to assess other peoples abilities to complete their part of the project; will provide strategies for making other people able and communicating with them on progress; and will show how to steer a project around a lack of resources, wrong parameters and political maneuvering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Personal and Professional Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of major topics related to personal and professional development, including communication, leadership, teamwork, continuous total quality improvement, and ethics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and one hour activity a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drawing Interpretation
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic mechanical two-dimensional engineering  drawings.  Topics include basic drawing elements (formats, title block, parts list, revision block, etc.), part views (multiview, auxiliary, and isometric), section views, general dimensions, tolerances, finish symbols, and welding symbols.  For most modules, there are drawing assignments, a quiz, and supplementary information.
htmlparse.Course.notes: A drawing packet is included as reference material that shows 5 detail drawings and an assembly drawing for the parts of a Trolley Wheel. The package includes flat and round parts and a casting. Intended for individuals working in design, drafting, quality, procurement, tooling, production, and manufacturing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Engineering and Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of problems or topics in a specialized area of engineering or technology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Approval of department head or dean.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Colloquium in Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics of general interest.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to students in the engineering honors program for one semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Alternative Energy Sources
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to solar, geothermal, wind, tidal, thermal sea gradients, breeder reactor, and fusion energy sources. Concepts, devices, potential, economics, and status of each energy source. Introduction to the all-electric economy.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours recitation a week.
Open to all non-engineering and first- and second-year engineering students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Energy and Environmental Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course for nonengineering students. An introduction to the technology employed in analyzing energy and pollution control processes. The course emphasizes energy problems, control of water and air pollution, food and land use problems, and material recycling concepts.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture a week.
Not open to engineering students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing
htmlparse.Course.description: Geometric dimensioning controls used on mechanical engineering drawings.  The theoretical and practical concepts of each of the geometric controls are explained relative to the areas of design, tooling, production, and inspection.  All ten modules include a quiz.  For most modules, there are drawing assignments and supplementary information.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The parts of a directional-change gearbox are used as platforms for the geometric controls. The assembly includes shafts, gears, bearings, keys, lip seals, castings, and threaded fasteners. Intended for employees working in design, drafting, quality, procurement, tooling, production, and manufacturing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing
htmlparse.Course.description: Most frequently used geometric dimensioning controls used on mechanical engineering drawings.  The basic applications of position are explained in greater detail: fixed and floating fastener, zero tolerance, size feature datums, and composite versus two single segments.  Several possibilities of how to control the size and location of nonsize features with profile are explained.  Coaxial relationships and control of rectangular features are also covered.  All nine modules include a quiz.  For most modules, there are drawing assignments and supplementary information.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The parts of an Idler Wheel assembly are used as platforms for the geometric controls. The assembly includes a shaft, pulley, weldments, bushings, and threaded fasteners.

htmlparse.Course.title: Impact of Technology on Society
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of social, economic, and environmental problems as a function of technology. Study of effect of various significant technological developments on present society and parallels with present developments. Study of current problems, detection of causes, and analysis of solutions. Implications for the future; governmental, industrial, and individual responsibility in detection of potential problems and methods of control or solution.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor.  Written report is presented at end of second semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Open to seniors in the engineering honors program for two semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Law
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to concepts of law pertinent to engineering practice. These include contracts, torts, products liability, business associations, engineering licensing, real and personal property law, commercial law, and taxes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resources/Environmental Sciences Project (NRES)
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive project in NRES. Requires integration of information and understanding acquired in NRES secondary major courses. Students must prepare and present written and oral reports.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 415, COMM 105. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: 15 hours of approved courses in NRES secondary major.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students participating in the University Honors Program and who are enrolled in the College of Human Ecology must enroll each semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Practicum in Research, Teaching, Administration, or Extension
htmlparse.Course.description: Practicum completed in collaboration with a faculty member that enhances skills in research, teaching, administration, or extension programming.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: College of Human Ecology honors program member and consent of honors program coordinator.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Directions and goals for the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conducting Honors Research
htmlparse.Course.description: This one credit seminar provides an overview of the process of conducting an honors project, which could be undergraduate research or other scholarly project. The seminar is designed for a sophomore and junior participants in the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Human Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in human ecology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: For students in honors program only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Public Health
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an introductory survey course designed to provide a history of public health, an overview of the five core disciplines (epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, social and behavioral health, and health policy and management), and information about career options in public health. Using these introductory materials as a foundation, students will investigate and analyze contemporary issues in public health such as bioterrorism, threats to the nation’s food supply, burden and distribution of infectious diseases on a global population, and the role of public health in disaster preparedness and management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Public Health and Food Safety
htmlparse.Course.description: Organization and function of food inspection services; principles of disease transmission; diseases transmitted to humans through the food chain.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Jointly with HMD 650.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Pathobiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Pathobiology
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Enrollment is by consent of the instructor. The format and credit hours for the course are determined by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Veterinary Immunology
htmlparse.Course.description: Innate and adaptive defense mechanisms in domestic animals. Topics include vaccinology, immunopathology, autoimmunity, immunodeficiency, and immunomodulation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the principles and methods of veterinary epidemiology: emphasizing how diseases affect populations (and associated implications for individuals), and application to disease diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Bacteriology and Mycology - Lecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Morphology, biology, and classification of pathogenic bacteria and fungi and their relation to the causes of disease.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Bacteriology and Mycology - Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: This lab is designed to assist the 2nd year veterinary student with the basic knowledge and skills for isolation and identification of bacterial and fungal agents of veterinary significance, from clinical and non-clinical samples and is designed to provide adequate knowledge and necessary training for veterinarians in practice.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three (3) hours of lab each week is required and 2nd year standing in the veterinary curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Etiology, pathogenesis, lesions, and termination of processes of disease, including inflammation, necrosis, regeneration, oncology, and disturbances of metabolism, circulation, and growth.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Parasitology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of helminth, arthropod, and protozoan parasites of companion and food animals. Emphases are on diagnosis, clinical signs, lesions, treatment, control, epidemiology, and public health aspects of parasitic disease.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: AP 710, 737, 747 and DMP 705 and 708.
Must be 2nd year student in the Veterinary Curriculum.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systemic Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Pathology of the organ systems of domestic animals including gross and microscopic study of lesions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Virology
htmlparse.Course.description: Morphology, biology, and classification of viruses and their relation to the causes of disease.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cross-Course Integration III
htmlparse.Course.description: Vertical and horizontal integration among semester courses to improve student cognitive retention and understanding of course content. Structured-function relationships will be emphasized to facilitate student assimilation and provide clinical relevance to basic science content.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cross-Course Integration IV
htmlparse.Course.description: The course activities will include interactive discussion sessions with pathologist, radiologist, clinical pathologist, and other veterinary specialists and will be aimed to integrate topics learned in courses taught during the first four semesters of the veterinary curriculum with special emphasis on the topics learned in the current (fourth) semester.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Second-year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine or consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Public Health
htmlparse.Course.description: The linkages between human health and animal health and production. Topics include zoonotic disease, emerging and exotic animal diseases, disaster preparedness, regulatory and community health issues focusing on the role of the veterinarian in all.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine and DMP 708.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the basic principles and methods of epidemiology in order to recognize and understand how disease affects populations (and the associated implications for individuals).  This course will prepare students to use epidemiologic methods to solve current and future challenges to diagnose, treat, prevent, and control disease during their professional training and throughout their career.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Management and health of common species of laboratory animals.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture a week.
Taught as an elective to second-year veterinary students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Emerging Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: An investigation into recently identified emerging diseases, the conditions that enable their emergence, and the human health implications of each disease.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 3 hours of Biology above a 700 level.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This class is open to all students with some biology background, as well as veterinary students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, application, and interpretation of clinical laboratory procedures, and experience with applicable techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and four hours case discussion or lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory Diagnosis
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory techniques in hematology, cytology, urology and quality control as applied to the diagnosis of animal diseases.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Third year elective, online format through Division of Continuing Education (DCE).

htmlparse.Course.title: Diagnostic Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience in necropsy procedures and laboratory findings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Research in Laboratory Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Methodology to conduct research in laboratory medicine. A laboratory study to introduce the procedures to plan, conduct, and evaluate research in clinical pathology, microbiology, parasitology, immunology, or epidemiology. Students will develop a research proposal, including preliminary data, following the guidelines of a peer-reviewed granting agency.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and twelve hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: New Student Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: Assemblies are held once a month for new electrical engineering and computer engineering students to provide them information on the department. The students get an opportunity to meet student leaders, department faculty, and learn about department activities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all undergraduate students in their first two semesters in the ECE department.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic circuit theory including voltage, current, Kirchoff’s laws, and Ohm’s law. Introduction to circuit elements, application circuits, complex impedance and power, and additional theory fundamental and the EE curriculum. Includes laboratory work (e.g., with multimeters and oscilloscopes) and circuit construction techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and 2 hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Number systems, Boolean algebra fundamentals, gates, flip-flops, shift registers, memories, etc.; basic engineering aspects of computer architecture; introduction to hardware description languages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Circuit Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to linear circuit theory; analysis of linear circuits containing resistance, inductance, and capacitance. Mutual inductance and transformers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microcontrollers
htmlparse.Course.description: Architecture, assembly language programming, serial and parallel input/output, interface circuits, and applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Digital Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of combinational and sequential systems including asynchronous circuits; testing of digital systems. Emphasis is placed on hardware description languages, computer-aided design tools, and simulations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Electrical and Computer Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. Open to students in the College of Engineering honors program. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronics Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Design, simulation, construction and testing of electronic circuits.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Circuit Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of electric circuits using differential equations, transform techniques, and linear algebra. Transmission lines and applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Linear Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Time- and frequency-domain analysis of signals and systems. Concepts include signal classification, convolution, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, filters, signal sampling, and discrete transforms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electric Circuits and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of direct-current circuits and machines, alternating-current circuits and machines, electronics, and application to instrumentation and control.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture a week. Not open to ECE students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of electronic components (e.g., diodes, MOSFETs, BJTs, op amps) and electronic circuits.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Electronics I, with emphasis on performance measures, including frequency response. Additional topics include Miller’s theorem, cascoding, and the application of negative feedback.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Control Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Modeling, analysis, and design of control systems. Topics include feedback control; time response and stability of dynamic systems; introduction to root locus and frequency response design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Scientific Computing for Engineers
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of the C programming language with emphasis on solving various classes of numerical problems.  General topics, such as the precision of floating point numbers are also discussed.  Statistics, linear algebra and optimization are the primary classes of numerical problems addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Local Area Networking
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to data communication concepts used in the network, data link, and physical layers of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. Hardware and software aspects of data communications as well as modern Local Area Network (LAN) standards will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electromagnetic Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: Vector analysis, electrostatics, magnetostatics, Faraday’s Law, Maxwell’s Equations, plane waves, and applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of engineering applied to clinical medicine and the life sciences. Topics include sensors and instrumentation to acquire physiologic data, imaging techniques, biomechanics, health care information technology, assistive technology, telemedicine, home care, emergency services, battlefield medicine, and biomedical career opportunities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Energy Conversion I
htmlparse.Course.description: Three-phase systems, magnetic circuits, transformers, and DC and AC machines.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wind Energy Research
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an opportunity to pursue one or more longer-term research questions related to wind engineering, including small-wind siting and installation and meteorological-tower installation and data analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of oral and written communication skills, engineering ethics and career topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Electronics
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of semiconductor devices to the control and conversion of electric power, control of DC and AC machines, and design of electronic power circuits such as controlled rectifiers, converters and inverters.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Instrumentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of electronics in the design of analog and digital systems for the measurement of physical variables and in the transduction of these variables into a useful form for both recording and control.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microcomputer Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and engineering application of 32-bit microcomputers to instrumentation and control. Investigate the relationship of the C language and assembly language. Timing and other interfacing problems will be covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308 or 209 or ME 400; ECE 431; ECE 525 or 519.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time Embedded Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Interconnection of peripherals, such as CAN networks, DA/AD converters, and Timers. Implementation of device drivers on top of micro-kernels. Build a simple real time distributed embedded system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week. Course meets in one contiguous block of five weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the software, hardware, and algorithmic aspects of graphics generation. Programming assignments will provide experience in implementing interactive interfaces via application-level graphics libraries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308 or 209; CIS 300; and MATH 222 or 551.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Digital Design using Logic Synthesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of hardware description languages (HDLs) for the design of complex digital systems. Topics include designing and simulating using HDLs, logic synthesis into FPGAs and ASICs, optimization techniques, timing issues, hardware verification, and design for testability.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Engineering Design Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: The design and construction of a small computer system using simple programmable devices. The design and construction of computer interfacing systems for PCs based on USB devices and simple microcontroller chips.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 308 or 209; and ECE 441. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ECE 649.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Electronics
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of high-performance digital electronics and systems. Topics include design metrics, device modeling, transmission-line models for wiring, signaling conventions, transmitter and receiver circuits, noise analysis and management, power distribution, timing and synchronization techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Filtering
htmlparse.Course.description: Difference equation characterization of digital filters, transient and steady-state analysis of digital filters using the Z-transform, spectral analysis of digital signals, design and implementation of digital filters.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multimedia Compression
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to multimedia creation and representation. Design of multimedia systems, which incorporate audio, image and video. Topics will include the analysis and design of multimedia compression, streaming, delivery, security and authoring. Emphasis will be placed on current multimedia standards and applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECE 512 or MATH 551; CIS 308 or 209.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts of computer design.  Information representation, instruction sets and addressing modes.  Arithmetic and logic unit design for fixed and floating point operations. Hardwired and microprogrammed control design. Concepts of pipelining, CISC and RISC architecture. Memory system design including virtual memory, caches and interleaved memories. I/O design methods, interrupt mechanisms, DMA and system integration.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Systems I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the analysis and design of analog and digital communication systems. Topics include analog and digital modulation schemes, digital encoding of messages, mathematical modeling of communications systems, noise in communication links and calculation of performance measures for practical links.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Systems II
htmlparse.Course.description: Error-correction code design and analysis with emphasis on block and convolutional coding and decoding; Trellis-coded modulation. Modeling of bandlimited systems and pulse-shape design, optimal receiver design for bandlimited systems, linear and nonlinear equalization. Multiple-access techniques, orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing and receiver design for CDMA schemes. Simulation of practical digital transmission systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Communication Circuits
htmlparse.Course.description: The design of communication circuits and systems operating from baseband to UHF frequencies. Topics include tuned-RF amplifiers, oscillators, mixers, LC and ceramic bandpass filters, and demodulators. Projects involve the design, construction, and performance testing of a complete radio receiver.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Applications of Machine Intelligence
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of machine intelligence and fuzzy logic concepts and applications in engineering problem domains. As a term project, develop a fuzzy expert system for a specific problem domain that runs on a personal computer and develop the supporting documentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wind and Solar Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Wind and solar energy resource assessment, operation of renewable-energy systems, photovoltaic and wind-turbine physics, and design of complete systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to power systems and device analysis. Course includes lecture and laboratory experience in aspects of power flow, system operation, power quality, power electronics, and economic analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive study of modeling of the electric power system components and computer simulation of interconnected power systems in steady state. Vector-matrix descriptions are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Systems Protection
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of symmetrical and unsymmetrical faults on power systems using symmetrical components technique. Study of protective relaying for protection of power systems against faults. Vector-matrix descriptions and computer solutions are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Electrical and Computer Engineering
