htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Electrical and Computer Engineering
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Optoelectronics
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied geometric and physical optics, optical radiation, and the interaction of light and matter. The theory and application of photodetectors, lasers, and other photoemitters. Introduction to fiber optical waveguides, sensors, and systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integrated Circuit Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of silicon integrated circuits with emphasis on CMOS analog and digital applications. The course covers basic device structure and modeling, circuit analysis, system design, IC design methodology and economics plus IC fabrication processes. Computer-aided tools are used to simulate and layout circuits designed by student groups. The circuits are fabricated by an external service (MOSIS).
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electroacoustics
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic principles of sound; modeling of, and analogous circuits for, mechanical and acoustical systems; microphones and loudspeakers; Thiele-Small parameters; the analysis and design of, and measurements on, common loudspeaker systems and crossover networks. Projects involve the design, simulation, construction and performance-testing of a complete loudspeaker-and-enclosure system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Audio Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Solid-state and hollow-state analog electronics applicable to high-fidelity audio. Emphasis is on the analysis, design and construction of audio amplifiers. Projects include design, implementation, and performance-evaluation of a reference-quality audio power amplifier.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analog Electronics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis, design, and evaluation of BJT and CMOS operational amplifiers. Core topics include frequency compensation and closed-loop stability, slew-rate optimization, wide-bandwidth design, low-noise design, and macromodeling for simulation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integrated Circuit Devices and Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrated circuit fabrication processes including oxidation, diffusion, ion implantation, lithography, etching, crystal growth, process monitoring, and device characterization. Design of discrete and IC devices through laboratory experiments and computer simulations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mixed Signal Measurements
htmlparse.Course.description: Signal classification, noise and uncertainty, TRMS conversion, quantization and ADCs, repetitive sampling and signal recovery techniques, vector voltmeters, basic network analyzers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Control Systems Analysis and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of classical analysis techniques for control system compensation. State space control theory fundamentals are presented in addition to an introductory treatment of several major systems areas.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Microcomputer System Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and engineering applications of 16 and 32 bit microprocessors. Utilization of peripheral and co-processor chips.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time Embedded Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and implementation of a comprehensive team project of a complete embedded real-time system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Discrete-Time and Computer-Control Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and design of discrete-time, sampled-data, and computer-control systems using discrete-state equations and Z-transforms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fault Diagnosis in Digital Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Hazards, fault detection in combinational circuits, and sequential machines using path sensitizing and fault-matrix methods, state table analysis, etc.; system reliability through logical redundance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ECE 541 or 631.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Signal Processing Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Digitization of analog signals; demonstration of aliasing problems; spectral analysis of digital signals using Fourier and other signal representation techniques; digital filtering problems; applications related to biomedical and speech data.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECE 512. Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ECE 647.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of alternate computer hardware structures. Investigation of engineering tradeoffs in implementation of alternative instruction sets and computing structures. Emphasis will be placed on a quantitative approach to cost/performance evaluations including simulation of hardware structures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electromagnetic Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of ECE 557.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wireless Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: This course exposes seniors and first year graduate students to important physical layer concepts in wireless communications. Topics include: cellular architecture, large scale and small scale fading channel models, diversity receivers, DS-CDMA transmitter and receiver design, multi-user detection, multi-carrier CDMA and OFDM performance analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Microwave Circuits
htmlparse.Course.description: The design of communication circuits and systems operating at microwave frequencies. Topics include antennas, transmission lines, microstrip matching networks, S-parameters, frequency synthesizers, and downconverter components such as LNAs, mixers, and microstrip bandpass filters. Projects involve design, simulation with electronic design automation tools, and laboratory measurements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hour lecture and three hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Radio Hardware Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in digital radio communication systems. Topics include the design and application of state-of-the-art RF and baseband circuits found in products ranging from cordless and cellular phones to wireless local area networks. System-level issues including coding, duplexing, and multiple access techniques are also covered, and a team-based project provides experience with RF hardware research and development activities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment: ECE 696; Prerequisite: ECE 622 or ECE 764 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Control Theory Applied to Bioengineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of mathematical models used in the study and analysis of physiological control systems providing techniques for varying pertinent biological parameters.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent: ECE 530 or ME 640, and a basic physiology course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory and Techniques of Bioinstrumentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical aspects of biological signals, electrodes, transducers, digital imaging and computer-based data acquisition directed toward ECE and other science department majors.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in ECE 773 (ECE majors only) and AP 773.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioinstrumentation Design Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and testing of hardware and software for acquiring and analyzing biological signals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECE 502 and concurrent enrollment in ECE 772 and AP 773.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Speakers from industry, academia, and government present topics related to power systems engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Electronics
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey course designed to provide an overview of basic direct and alternating current circuits and an introduction to linear and digital electronics. Laboratory exercises reinforce circuit theory and provide skills in the use of common electronic instruments.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Corequisite: MATH 100 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Direct Current Circuits
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course in basic circuit theory emphasizing the analysis of passive circuit networks containing resistance, capacitance, and inductance operating in direct current conditions. Topics include equivalent circuits, network theorems, capacitance, RC-circuit response, inductance, RL-circuit response, and computer simulation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Semiconductor Electronics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course in electronic devices. Topics include PN-junction theory, diodes, transistors, transistor biasing, transistor modeling, operational amplifiers, voltage regulators, and field-effect transistors (FET).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100. Corequisite: ECET 101, and MATH 150 or 151.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Alternating Current Circuits
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of passive networks containing resistance, capacitance, and inductance operating in alternating current conditions. Includes sinusoidal waveforms, polar and rectangular complex algebra, inductive and capacitive reactance, impedance networks, power factor correction, resonance, magnetic circuits, and an introduction to three-phase power distribution.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Linear Circuit Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and design of analog circuits including differential amplifiers, oscillators, linear and switching power amplifiers, applications of operational amplifiers, advanced semiconductor devices, and heat sinks.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Manufacturing
htmlparse.Course.description: A practical course in the details of electronic system design and fabrication. Topics include 2D CAD; printed-circuit board design, layout, and fabrication; electronic-system design principles; fabrication, packaging and assembly techniques for electronic systems; and through-hole and surface-mount technologies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Logic
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of basic logic elements including gates, flip-flops, counters, and registers. Includes Boolean algebra, logic reduction methods, and digital logic applications. Emphasis on computer simulation and PLD implementation of logic circuits.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Electronic and Computer Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present electronic and computer engineering technology topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electric Power and Devices
htmlparse.Course.description: Industrial applications of direct and alternating power, devices, and systems. Topics include electrical and electronic power devices, controllers, servomechanisms, and actuators; DC and AC motors and generators, motor speed control and drive systems; electrical power distribution, and industrial electronics applications.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Communication Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of analog and digital communication techniques and systems including modulation, transmission line concepts, radio-wave propagation, antenna theory, and the effects of noise.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Controls
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of electronic circuits and systems encountered in industrial environments. Topics include power control devices and applications, power system design, sensors, transducers, PLCs, computer-based data acquisition, and automatic control concepts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microprocessor Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts of microprocessor architecture, programming, and interfacing. Topics include assembly language programming, data conversion methods, and microprocessor-based system development tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECET 250 and college-level programming language course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Circuits and Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of programmable logic, including microprocessors, and microcontrollers. Students use software design tools such as simulators and cross compilers to design systems and analyze system performance. Data conversion methods and peripheral interfacing techniques are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Circuits Design
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the theory and design of electronic circuits for communications emphasizing the implementation and analysis of common radio-frequency (RF) building blocks. Topics include s-parameters, the Smith chart, component behavior, RF test equipment, computer simulation, filter design, impedance matching, amplifiers, oscillators, mixers, and demodulators.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Telecommunication Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to data communications and a survey of modern communication systems. Topics include Fourier analysis, data encoding, data link control, fiber-optic systems, cellular systems, satellite systems, and the modern telephone system.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Network Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of various network topics including Laplace transforms, signal flow graph models, transfer functions, network response, and differential equations and linear approximations of physical systems. The theory of control systems and their applications are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Systems and Computer Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of advanced digital design techniques. Topics include VHDL-based design, simulation, and synthesis; testing and validation; system-level interfacing; and computer architecture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of electronic principles and the design methodology to solving a significant design problem in a team context. Includes determining customer requirements, exploring and choosing design alternatives, scheduling, and project management. Significant milestones are the project’s conceptual, preliminary, and critical design reviews, which require written and oral presentations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECET 320 and ECET 352. Corequisite: ECET 430.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of ECET 480. Includes the implementation, testing, and delivery of the project initiated in ECET 480 Electronic Design I. Significant milestones are the project prototype, design report, and final presentation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Electronic and Computer Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present advanced electronic and computer engineering technology topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic facts, principles, and problems of economics; determination of the level of output, employment, and the price level; the monetary and banking system; problems and policies of economic instability, inflation, and growth; principles of economic development; other economics systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Probability of a grade of C or higher (PROB ≥ C) of at least 40 percent according to the economics component if the ACT Student Profile, a score of 18 or higher on the Math placement exam, or a Grade of B or higher in MATH 010.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Macroeconomics-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic facts, principles, and problems of economics; determination of the level of output, employment, and the price level; the monetary and banking system; problems and policies of economic instability, inflation, and growth; principles of economic development; other economics systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Probability of a grade of C or higher (PROB ≥ C) of at least 40 percent according to the economics component if the ACT Student Profile, a score of 18 or higher on the Math placement exam, or a Grade of B or higher in MATH 010.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Macroeconomics - Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic facts, principles, and problems of economics; determination of the level of output, employment, and the price level; the monetary and banking system; problems and policies of economic instability, inflation, and growth; principles of economic development; other economics systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Participation in honors program and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Microeconomics
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic facts, principles, and problems of economics including study of the determination of prices; the determination of wages, rent, interest, and profit; theory of the firm; monopoly and government regulation; international economic relations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Probability of a grade of C or higher (PROB ≥ C) of at least 40 percent according to the economics component of the ACT Student Profile, a score of 18 or higher on the Math Placement Exam, or a grade of B or higher in MATH 010.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Microeconomics-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic facts, principles, and problems of economics including study of the determination of prices; the determination of wages, rent, interest, and profit; theory of the firm; monopoly and government regulation; international economic relations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Probability of a grade of C or higher (PROB ≥ C) of at least 40 percent according to the economics component of the ACT Student Profile, a score of 18 or higher on the Math Placement Exam, or a grade of B or higher in MATH 010.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: For sophomores in honors program-scheduled irregularly. Readings and discussions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to students in the honors program not majoring in economics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sophomore/Junior Seminar in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to economics as a science and a profession. The course introduces students to the skills and tools that make economics an attractive and enjoyable field as well as an overview of economic data and current debates.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to economics majors and those contemplating an economics major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts and Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary survey of the development of civilization in India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan, including geography, history, religion, culture, language, literature, current economy, and significant social movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three hours of social science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May not be counted toward economics major or minor.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Japanese Economy
htmlparse.Course.description: Analyzes Japan’s growth, productivity change, income distribution, government policies, agriculture, industrial structure, labor relations education and technology, and international trade and finance. Emphases will be on U.S.-Japanese competition and comparisons.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Macroeconomics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the behavior of the economy as a whole, including an analysis of the national income account, consumption, investment, money, interest, the price, level, the level of employment, monetary and fiscal policy, and economic growth.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110, ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Microeconomics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the theories of consumer behavior and demand, and the theories of production, cost, and supply. The determination of product prices and output in various market structures, and an analysis of factor pricing. Introduction to welfare economics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students cannot receive credit for both ECON 520 and ECON 521.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: A mathematical approach to intermediate microeconomics. Emphasis is placed on the use of optimization techniques to examine consumer demand, production and cost, behavior of the firm, market structure and welfare.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121; MATH 205 or 220.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students cannot receive credit for both ECON 520 and ECON 521.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Resource Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the economic forces influencing wage and employment determination, income differentials, unemployment, and the production and acquisition of human capital. Emphasis on public policy, labor unions, and other relevant institutions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May not be counted toward economics major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sports Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: An economic analysis of professional and amateur sports. Pay determination of professional athletes, monopsony power of owners, discrimination, the importance of leagues, competitive balance, antitrust issues, collective bargaining, the financing of sports stadiums, and current economic issues in sports.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Economics of environmental market failure and the efficient use of exhaustible and renewable resources. Topics include the application of markets and government policies to greenhouse warming, air and water pollution, and recycling.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.

htmlparse.Course.title: Money and Banking
htmlparse.Course.description: Nature, principles, and functions of money; development and operation of financial institutions in the American monetary system, with emphasis on processes, problems, and policies of commercial banks in the United States.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Fiscal Operation of State and Local Government
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for students who plan careers related to state or local government. Selected topics in state and local taxation and expenditure.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110 and permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: The transition by Russia, Ukraine, Eastern and Central Europe, and Central Asia to market economics; economic reform in China, India, and other countries; and Marxian critiques of capitalism.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110 or 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Managerial Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Microeconomic topics applicable to understanding and analyzing firm behavior: optimization, demand, estimation, production, and cost theory. Applications to business problems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121; an introductory-level statistics course (STAT 325, STAT 340, or STAT 350); and MATH 205.

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban and Regional Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the determinants of the economic performance of urban and regional economies, including theory, problems, and policy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Seminar in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics for class discussion include history of economic thought, research methods in economics, and current economic issues. Students will prepare and present papers written with faculty guidance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 510 and ECON 520 or ECON 521; STAT 351, 511 or 705 or concurrent enrollment in one of the three.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all economics majors; open to others with permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual study is offered in international trade, labor relations, money and banking, public finance, transportation, general economics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Courses on special topics to be taught on demand.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: To be set for each topics course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Labor Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Economics of the labor market–theory and empirical evidence. Labor force composition and trends, labor supply, labor demand, human capital, wage differentials, migration, trade unions, and current issues.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Labor Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on current research and public policies dealing with such matters as full employment, poverty, discrimination, social security, unemployment insurance, health care, minimum wages, training, and education.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 620 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Econometrics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the analytical and quantitative methods used in economics. Applications to specific problems with an emphasis on computer analyses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or 121; MATH 205 or 220; STAT 351, 511, or 705.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Transportation
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the transportation market from the shippers’ point of view by examining the impact of transportation on business firm decisions such as location, markets, and prices. Also covers the costs, prices, and service characteristics of railroads, motor carriers, water carriers, oil pipelines and airlines. The role and impact of government in the transportation market is examined from both a promotion and regulation perspective.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Course seeks answers to questions such as: Which goods should be provided by the private sector and which by the public sector (government)? With what criteria are public expenditures evaluated? What is an equitable and efficient tax system? Who bears the tax burden? What aspects of existing taxes need reform?
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of measures and determinants of industrial concentration, and an analysis of market structure, conduct, and performance, and policies related to performance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of international trade and finance, including production, exchange, commercial policy, resource movements, balance of payments, foreign currency markets, and policies for internal and external balance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110; ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Development Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Factors affecting the economic modernization of the less-developed countries. Emphasis on capital formation, human capital, investment allocation, technical progress, income distribution, population growth, and the international economics of development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Fluctuations and Forecasting
htmlparse.Course.description: Types of business fluctuations; measurement of business cycles; theories of the causes of business cycles; proposals for stabilizing business activity; techniques of forecasting business activity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110; ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Health Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: This course applies the tools of microeconomics to the health-care sector. It analyzes the behavior of consumers and providers of medical care, the functioning of insurance markets, and the roles of government and the private sector. International comparisons are made.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.

htmlparse.Course.title: Monetary, Credit, and Fiscal Policies
htmlparse.Course.description: Goals of aggregative economic policy, conflicts among goals, and measures to resolve conflicts; money markets; targets of central bank control; the relative strength of monetary and fiscal policies; rational expectations hypothesis and policy ineffectiveness debate; terms structure of interest rates.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Social Sciences Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminars of special interest will be offered on demand.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 120 or AGEC 120 or AGEC 121.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Economic Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of economic ideas and doctrines and the relation of these to conditions existing when they were formulated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microeconomic Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Demand, cost, and production theories; price and output determination in different market structures; the theory of factor market pricing; an introduction to general equilibrium and welfare analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematical Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of mathematical tools of concrete problems in micro- and macro-economics; mathematical treatment of models of consumption, production, market equilibrium, and aggregate growth.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 520, MATH 205 or 220, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Foundations and Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in professional education.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Maximum of 3 hours applicable toward degree requirements.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Contemporary overview of the field of international education and an introduction to three of its parts. Comparative education, intercultural education, and development education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Basic Education Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on providing students with an understanding of the selection, utilization, and development of adult basic education reference, resources, and other materials.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Related occupational or professional experiences in approved industry, school, Cooperative Extension Service, or similar agency setting under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women, Education, and Work
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasizes the collective and individual educational needs of women in and out of the work force and the part that occupational/educational preparation contributes to their participation in the work force.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Basic Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Evolving adult basic and high school equivalency education concepts will be examined. Program implementation, supervision, methods, and materials are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Adult teaching experience or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Learners and Integrating Technology into Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: This course includes an in-depth study of methods for integrating innovative technologies into the curriculum for adult learners. With an indepth understanding of adult learners, students will analyze learning theories and appropriate technologies for revlevance, effectiveness, and alignment with course curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Foundations and Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings in research and application in specialized areas in education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of adult education. Consideration given to articulation with other levels of education. Identification of changing needs within the field are reviewed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Educational Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: For both the practitioner and those interested in educational gerontology as a field of inquiry. It will examine education for and about aging, with particular reference to the role, needs, and ability of persons in the later years as learners.

htmlparse.Course.title: Designing Classroom Instruction and Curriculum for Adult Learners
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the systematic approach to instructional design for adult learners. A comprehensive discussion of all major components of curriculum design from instructional objectives, course sequencing, instructional strategies, formative assessments and summative evaluations will be included. A major focus will also be on transfer of learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current topic in area of specialization of faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Varied topics offered each semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Characteristics of the Adult Learner
htmlparse.Course.description: For teachers and administrators in adult and occupational programs who need a familiarity with the major characteristics of adulthood which affect the adult as a learner.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hospital and Industry Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to principles, roles, organization, procedures, and problems of adult education in hospitals, industry, and related agencies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of specific problems in the areas of adult or occupational education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Healthful and Safe College Life
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses pertinent health education topics that impact college students and explores the effect of lifestyle choices on academic achievement. Topics include sexual health, mental health, nutrition and fitness, alcohol/drugs/tobacco, injury and illness prevention education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not intended to replace the HN 352 Personal Wellness course when required in a curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: The University Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the university experience through participation in weekly small group meetings and informational lectures. Study of such topics as academic skills, including communication and critical thinking, academic and career planning and goal setting, and social issues that challenge many college students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: New students or instructor consent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Academic and Career Decisions
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses general principles of academic and career choice through lectures, class discussions, and individual research. Topics include decision-making models and principles; exploration of interests, abilities, and values through career assessments; and academic and career investigation using interactive software, library materials, online resources, and experiential learning opportunities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Career and Life Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Applies theory research concerning assessment of inserts and career choice-making to individual’s planning and decision-making. Focuses on increasing understanding of the complexities of the world of work and on skills of integrating such understanding with each persons’ planning experience, characteristics, motives, and values in the career exploration process. Reviews resume writing, interviewing skills, and job search techniques.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership Training Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: General principles of leadership as applied to small groups. Study of the role of the leader, group processes and interaction, defining group goals, and techniques of observation. Workshop and supervision in small group leadership.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Offered only at the Manhattan campus.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interaction and Guidance for the Paraprofessional
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of a systematic approach to interaction skills in a paraprofessional helping relationship. Includes background knowledge of listening skills and practice in emitting skills which influence interaction quality.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sexual Health Awareness Peer Education (SHAPE)
htmlparse.Course.description: This course prepares students to become peer health educators with a specific emphasis in sexual health. Information, peer education, helping, communication, and leadership skills that are required to present sexual health information to various campus groups or classes will be addressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: The application of psychological principles to the teaching-learning process with special emphasis on principles of learning, motivation, information processing, individual differences, and assessment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: Admission to teacher education, and FSHS 110.
Elementary students must take this course concurrent with DED 318, EDSP 324, and EDEL 320.
Secondary education students must take this course concurrent with EDSP 323 and EDSEC 376.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in professional education.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Repeatable.
Maximum of three hours applicable toward degree requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interpersonal Relations in the Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: A didactic and experiential course designed to develop an understanding of human relations skills in the schools. Provides knowledge and skills necessary to work effectively with students, parents, and school personnel. Particular emphasis is on the basis for interpersonal relations in education, communication skills, the facilitative relationship, working with students in groups, and conducting meetings with parents and school personnel.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDSEC 376, EDSP 323, EDCEP 315. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, 477.

htmlparse.Course.title: Middle School Classroom Guidance
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques of integrating guidance principles for pre- and early teens into a middle school concept; investigation of classroom dynamics for middle school teachers as members of the guidance team; involvement of teachers in model guidance programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of development, administration, evaluation, and constructive instructional use of paper-pencil, product, and performance assessments. Focus on norm-and criterion-referenced uses of teacher-made and published measures as an integral part of effective decision making in education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mental Health in Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines mental health and risk factors in the context of schools and student learning. Topics include: characteristics and behaviors of at-risk students; and prevention, intervention, and referral strategies to facilitate and promote mental health and a positive learning environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Teacher and Child Abuse
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of child abuse and neglect with specific references to legal and moral responsibilities of teaching. Suggestions for detection, reporting, and responsive instruction for suspected cases of child abuse and neglect.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drug Abuse Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on the development of effective drug abuse education programs with attention given to the role delineation for schools and teachers. Materials and procedures for developing values and attitudes in an education setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: College Student Athletes
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of college student athletes. Topics include the role of intercollegiate athletics, pressures and challenges on student athletes, student development theory, life skills programming, National Collegiate Athletic Association policy, diversity, and gender issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intercollegiate Athletics and the College Student Athlete
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines policies and procedures of the NCAA, roles and responsibilities within a department of intercollegiate athletics. Topics include marketing, fundraising, external relations, sports information, coaching, academic support, among others.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings in research and application in specialized areas in education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current topic in specialization of faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Varied topics offered each semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected students are permitted to secure specialized training appropriate to the needs of the individual.  The student’s project may involve intensive library investigation in a special field or the collection and analysis of data pertinent to a given problem.  All work is done independently under the direction of a faculty member.  As many conferences are held as necessary to assure successful completion of a project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses necessary for the problem undertaken and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Bilingual/ESL Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the history and foundations of bilingual education, as well as an in-depth examination of contemporary programming models and trends in bilingual education. The dynamics of bilingualism at the individual, system, and societal levels will also be an emphasis of study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration and Supervision of Vocational Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on the duties and responsibilities of administrative and supervisory personnel responsible for the promotion, development, and coordination of comprehensive vocational-technical education programs at the local level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Occupational Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to various techniques used in analyzing occupations and jobs. Emphasis on developing and organizing related instructional materials and content.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Prior or concurrent enrollment in EDSEC 620.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reading and the Bilingual Child
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will focus on appropriate instructional literacy and reading skill development among second language learners. A particular emphasis will be the development of literacy skills among students whose dominant language is other than English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reading in the Content Areas
htmlparse.Course.description: Information concerning the reading process and techniques for helping students develop reading and study skills needed in the content areas. Course is designed for classroom middle level and secondary teachers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Learning Technologies
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the roles that computers, teachers, and learners may take in any learning setting: ways of integrating technology into a curriculum; and issues involved in using technology in K-12 settings.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course is offered on the Web.

htmlparse.Course.title: ESL/Dual Language Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of contemporary approaches, methods, and strategies for the appropriate instruction of second language learners. Also provided is a foundational perspective on ESL/Dual Language approaches, including the communicative, cognitive, and grammatical.

htmlparse.Course.title: Study Skills Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Approaches and methods are presented for teaching study skills in academic and workplace settings. Approaches include personal, contextual, organizational and performance study skills. Includes study skills information for parent education and school improvement planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Applications in Subject Areas
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of using computer software to enhance teaching and learning in specific subject areas. Subjects covered will vary.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable for credit in different subject areas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Education of the Disadvantaged
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of the life-space of the disadvantaged learner and its relationship to curriculum, organization, and interpersonal relationships in schools. The development of realistic, relevant goals for the teacher of the disadvantaged.

htmlparse.Course.title: ESL/Dual Language Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the theoretical underpinnings of language acquisition and linguistics that educators need to understand, in order to better plan appropriately adapted curriculum and instruction for second language learners. The course encompasses problematic aspects of English language learning, the ways in which languages may differ, and certain universal aspects of languages.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Career Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Related occupational or professional experiences in approved industry, school, Cooperative Extension Service, or similar agency setting under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Materials for Ethnic Diversity
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination and analysis of recent materials and practices of schools serving multiethnic student bodies, particularly minorities from disadvantaged backgrounds. Materials include any items used by the school in implementing the curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Materials for Nonsexist Teaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of recent materials from perspective of concern with their potential for sex-role stereotyping. Examination of teaching resource materials for curriculum intended to facilitate nonsexist teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Business and Office Occupations
htmlparse.Course.description: Related occupational or professional experiences in approved industry, school, Cooperative Extension Service, or similar agency setting under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coordination of Cooperative Vocational Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on legal aspects and other minimum requirements essential to conducting cooperative vocational education programs at the secondary and postsecondary levels.

htmlparse.Course.title: Culture and Language in Classroom Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines ways teachers can address diversity in their classrooms with attention to issues such as critical reflection on practice; effective collaboration with families; diversification of the learning environment; use and adaptation of the grade-level curriculum; the differentiation of classroom instruction for cultural and linguistic diversity; and advocacy skill development.

htmlparse.Course.title: ESL/Dual Language Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth examination of key issues/challenges in the appropriate language assessment of culturally and linguistically diverse students. Among focal topics in theory, research and practice discussed will be: pre-and post-instructional assessment, authentic and alternative assessment, language testing and placement for programming in ESL/Dual language classrooms.

htmlparse.Course.title: ESL/Dual Language Elementary Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: The practicum is a portfolio-based experience providing the student with application experiences in ESL/Dual Language methods, assessment, and multicultural competence as well as the opportunity to demonstrate understanding of second language acquisition. Students will be required to spend 60 hours in a school setting where they can practice and implement ESL/BE lessons/methodology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: ESL/Dual Language Secondary Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: The practicum is a portfolio-based experience providing the student with application experiences in ESL/Dual Language methods, assessment, and multicultural competence as well as the opportunity to demonstrate understanding of second language acquisition. Students will be required to spend 60 hours in a school setting where they can practice and implement ESL/BE lessons/methodology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Education
htmlparse.Course.description: The selection, adaptation, and development of environmental education K-12 curriculum materials: procedures for an integrated curricular implementation; the selection of appropriate instructional strategies. Background in environmental studies recommended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Emerging Technologies in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Emerging technologies, tools, and instructional applications that impact teaching and learning will be examined. Specific pedagogical methods, skills, and strategies will be applied in creating standards-based classroom/program technology implementation plans.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Issues in Teaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the socio-cultural forces that influence the American educational system. Considers curriculum and instruction implications of human differences, and analyzes ways to promote equitable, quality education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tradebooks across the Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines the use of children’s literature in the K-8 literacy classroom. It focuses on recently published books in several literary genres across curricular areas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reading/Writing Connections
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines teaching language arts in an integrated manner, exploring the relationships between reading and writing from a developmental perspective. Teaching methods for a holistic environment are highlighted.

htmlparse.Course.title: Action Research in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces the theoretical and practical dimensions of school-based action research about curriculum and instruction topics, and students conduct an action research project. Access to the research site is required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instructional Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Implications of the major theories and models of instructional design to the development of instructional programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Distance Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current issues, theories, research, and methods for designing and teaching online courses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCI 718 or permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Enhancing Instruction Through Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Ways to use technology in instruction are examined as a means to enhance teacher presentations and student interpretations, teacher and student access to information, and professional communication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods for Second Language Acquisition/Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the development of second language instruction, both historical and current. Syntax, morphology, discourse analysis, and global proficiency evaluation are foci for analysis of methods and for the development of a personal method of teaching. Twenty-four (24) credits in one second language at 200 level and above or equivalent is recommended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings in research and application in specialized areas in education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching in Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Several instructional approaches consistent with the characteristics of the emerging adolescent student (grades 5-9) will be examined in relation to current research. Direct development of alternative curricular programs. Appropriate use of interdisciplinary activities and nontraditional materials will be emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Primary School Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A course for those interested in the kindergarten and primary school child. Emphasis will be placed on curriculum development, pertinent research, and innovative practices in early education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Kindergarten Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A specialized study of the kindergarten in the American school: methods and materials for working with the kindergarten child, including communication and explanation skills and readiness for reading.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching the Theoretical Foundations of Constitutional Government
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the theories (e.g., natural rights, classical republicanism, and constitutionalism) and theorists (e.g., Aristotle, Locke, Hobbes, and Montesquieu) that most influenced constitutional thinking in the United States.  Explores how to teach effectively about these theories and theorists.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching the Historical Origins of Constitutional Government
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines seminal ideas, documents, and events in the creation of the United States Constitution such as problems with the Articles of Confederation, the characteristics of good government, the debates at the Philadelphia Convention, the Federalist Papers, and the Antifederalist Papers.  Explores how to teach effectively these ideas, document, and events.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching the Development of Constitutional Principals
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the development of political ideas and constitutional thinking since the Founding.  Focuses on how the Bill of Rights, the amendment process, judicial review, and the Fourteenth Amendment are used to empower and limit government.  Explores how to teach effectively about developments in constitutional thought.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching the Institutions of Government
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the powers, limits, and development of political institutions such as Congress, the President, the Supreme Court, and political parties.  Explores how to teach effectively about these institutions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching the Bill of Rights
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the rights protected by the United States Constitution and the ways that rights protected by the United States Constitution and the ways that rights empower citizens, limit government, and contribute to constitutional government.  Explores how to teach effectively about rights.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current topic in area of specialization of faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Citizenship
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines development of the rights, responsibilities, and challenges of citizenship in the United States.  Explores how to teach effectively about citizenship.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Methods of Teaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines popular theories, important principles, research-based strategies, and best practices associated with effective teaching.  Provides a venue to apply theory to practice; connect ideas and action; and link content and pedagogy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of a specific problem in curriculum or instruction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching as a Career
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the roles, responsibilities, and dispositions of effective teachers; characteristics of the teaching/learning environment; the design of K-State’s teacher education program; ways teachers change during their careers; and self-assessment about the commitment to teaching and preferences to grade levels or subject areas. An overview of the teacher education program is provided, the unit’s conceptual framework is discussed, and the portfolio requirements are initiated. The skills of reflection and the dimensions of caring and ethical practice are introduced.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment required in EDEL 230 and sophomore standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Includes 40 hours of supervised field experiences examining selected aspects of teaching and the learning environment, including students and learning, content and pedagogy, planning, instruction, and professionalism. Requires written reports, analyses, and reflections for each weekly school visit.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 200 and sophomore standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Health and Movement Education in Elementary Classrooms
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses major concepts of health education, human movement, and physical activities to enable elementary teachers to promote healthy lifestyles for all students in their instruction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing. Prior or concurrent enrollment in EDEL 200.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two classroom hours and two lab hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the historical, political, philosophical, and sociological foundations of education in the United States including the evolution of career and technical education and changing demographics; ethical and legal issues; governance and financial support; and contemporary curriculum issues. Includes critical thinking and reflective decision making about educational issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Prior or concurrent enrollment in EDEL 200, EDSEC 200, or AGED 300. Requires sophomore standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: All EDEL 310 and EDSEC 310 sections are available to both Secondary and Elementary students. Take prior to or concurrent with Block A (EDEL) or Block I (EDSEC).

htmlparse.Course.title: Core Teaching Skills and Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines instructional planning, differentiating instruction, direct and indirect instructional strategies, strategies to promote student understanding, managing lesson delivery, classroom management, assessing student performance, and working with colleagues and parents.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to teacher education. Concurrent enrollment in DED 318, EDCEP 315, and EDSP 324.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Includes a lab session each week for detailed analysis of the issues and skill building.

htmlparse.Course.title: Middle-Level Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of the characteristics of middle schools; the social, psychological, and physical characteristics of early adolescent development; middle-level curriculum; ways to organize for instruction; and the teacher’s role in the guidance of students at the middle level.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Block B Practicum: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: A field experience designed to give students opportunities in applying teaching methods in literacy and science in elementary grades. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DED 318, EDCEP 315, EDSP 324, and EDEL 320. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 411, 412, 413, and 414.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Literacy: K-2
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides emergent literacy theory to foster language development, create optimal learning environments, assess and evaluate literacy learning, and provide differentiation and interventions for all learners. Comprehensive, evidence-based primary literacy programs include modeled, guided, and direct instruction; skill and strategy teaching; integration of reading/writing, listening/speaking, and viewing/visual representation. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DED 318, EDCEP 315, EDSP 324, and EDEL 320. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 410, 412, 413, and 414.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Science: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the principles and methods of teaching science in elementary grades, including the nature of science, student learning, curriculum, instructional methods and activities, equity issues, and student assessment. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DED 318, EDCEP 315, EDSP 324, and EDEL 320. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 410, 411, 413, and 414.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classroom Assessment: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the role of assessment in elementary classrooms in teaching; characteristics of high-quality assessments; diagnostic, formative, and summative assessments; preparation of classroom tests and test items; performance and portfolio assessments; affective traits; assessment of students with special needs and characteristics; grading and reporting; and standardized tests.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DED 318, EDCEP 315, EDSP 324, and EDEL 320. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 410, 411, 412, and 414.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Learners
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines multicultural education and the characteristics of diverse learners in the classroom, including culturally and linguistically diverse learners. Curricular and instructional implications of these differences are examined in an effort to differentiate instruction to meet the needs of all learners.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DED 318, EDCEP 315, EDSP 324, and EDEL 320. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 410, 411, 412, and 413.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Block C Practicum: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: A field experience designed to give students opportunities in applying teaching methods in literacy, social studies, and mathematics in elementary grades. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDEL 410, 411, 412, 413, and 414. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 461, 462, 463, and 464.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Literacy: Grades 3-6
htmlparse.Course.description: This course extends literacy theory to the intermediate grades to focus on language development, create optimal learning environments, assess and evaluate literacy learning, and provide differentiation and interventions for all learners. Comprehensive, evidence-based intermediate literacy programs include modeled, guided, and direct instruction; skill and strategy teaching; content area literacy; integration of reading/writing, listening/speaking, and viewing/visual representation. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDEL 410, 411, 412, 413, and 414. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 460, 462, 463, and 464.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Social Studies: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods and resources for teaching social studies in elementary grades with the goal of helping students develop the ability to make informed and reasoned decisions for the public good as citizens of a culturally diverse, democratic society in an independent world. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDEL 410, 411, 412, 413, and 414. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 460, 461, 463, and 464.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Mathematics: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: The teaching of mathematics in elementary grades, including the nature of mathematical processes, curriculum, methods of instruction, instructional materials, and the evaluation of outcomes. Includes using technologies to enhance instruction and facilitate professional productivity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDEL 410, 411, 412, 413, and 414. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 460, 461, 462, and 464. Prior or concurrent enrollment in MATH 320.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classroom Management and Discipline: K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines ways to establish and maintain a positive learning environment in elementary classrooms and specific strategies to address misbehavior. Emphasis is placed on creating an effective management system, establishing a positive learning environment, addressing individual and group motivation, and preparing to deal with misbehavior.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDEL 410, 411, 412, 413, and 414. Concurrent enrollment in EDEL 460, 461, 462, and 463.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Elementary Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in professional education. Maximum of 3 hours applicable toward degree requirements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Internship in Elementary Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and teaching participation under the direction of selected elementary teachers.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDEL 310, 410, 411, 412, 413, 414, 460, 461, 462, 463, 464, and admission to student teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foreign Language Elementary School Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of teaching and organization for the foreign language program in the elementary school. A score of “2” or “Advanced” on the Oral Proficiency Interview (OPI) is required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or corequisite: EDCEP 315. Concurrent enrollment required for EDEL 621.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foreign Language Elementary School Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: A teaching experience to apply the methods of teaching and organization for the foreign language program in the elementary school.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Leadership Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides opportunities for all interested students to be introduced to leadership skills application, with emphasis on practice in supervised clinical settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in professional education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Maximum of 3 hours applicable toward degree requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Educational Change and Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with educational change, teaming, and information literacy. Three thrusts are considered: the emerging technologies and educational change, shaping change with technology, and the use of technology/information literacy to transform teaching and learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings in research and application in specialized areas in education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current topic in area of specialization of faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Varied topics offered each semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected students are permitted to secure specialized training appropriate to the needs of the individual. The student’s project may involve intensive library investigation in a special field or the collection and analysis of data pertinent to a given problem. All work is done independently under the direction of a faculty member. As many conferences are held as necessary to assure successful completion of a project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developmental Reading Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Improves the college student’s study strategies, comprehension, and time management skills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching as a Career
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the roles, responsibilities, and dispositions of effective teachers; characteristics of the teaching/learning environment; the design of K-State’s teacher education program; ways teachers change during their careers; and self-assessment about the commitment to teaching and preferences to grade levels or subject areas. An overview of the teacher education program is provided, the unit’s conceptual framework is discussed, and the portfolio requirements are initiated. The skills of reflection and the dimensions of caring and ethical practice are introduced.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment required in EDSEC 230 and sophomore standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Includes 40 hours of supervised field experiences examining selected aspects of teaching and the learning environment, including students and learning, content and pedagogy, planning, instruction, and professionalism. Requires written reports, analyses, and reflections for each weekly school visit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Scientific Principles of Coaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Physiological, psychological, and kinesiological principles of coaching. Topics include training and conditioning, motivation, psychological factors affecting sport skill in performance, and mechanical principles underlying sport performance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not for kinesiology majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coaching and Officiating Basketball
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of rules, theory, and practices; methods of coaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coaching and Umpiring Baseball
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of rules, theory, and practices; methods of coaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coaching and Officiating Track and Field
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of rules, theory, and practices; methods of coaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coaching and Officiating Football
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of rules, theory, and practices; methods of coaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coaching and Officiating Volleyball
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of rules, theory, and practices; methods of coaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the historical, political, philosophical, and sociological foundations of education in the United States including the evolution of career and technical education and changing demographics; ethical and legal issues; governance and financial support; and contemporary curriculum issues. Includes critical thinking and reflective decision making about educational issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Prior or concurrent enrollment in EDEL 200, EDSEC 200, or AGED 300. Requires sophomore standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: All EDEL 310 and EDSEC 310 sections are available to both Secondary and Elementary students. Take prior to or concurrent with Block A (EDEL) or Block I (EDSEC).

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Data Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of competencies in the usage of integrated software packages as they apply to the automated business environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Core Teaching Skills: Secondary/Middle
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on core teaching skills, including best practices in all spects of planning and preparation, classroom management, assessment, differentiated instruction, collaboration in the professional community.  Includes a required supervised field experience in schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to teacher education, EDSEC 200, (or AGED 300); FSHS 110 and Corequisite: EDCEP 315 and EDSP 323.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture and two of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Middle-Level Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of the characteristics of middle schools; the social, psychological, and physical characteristics of early adolescent development; middle-level curriculum; ways to organize for instruction; and the teacher’s role in the guidance of students at the middle level.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
