htmlparse.Course.title: World Wide Web-Based Searching/ Researching
htmlparse.Course.description: The main topics of this course are formulating search strategies; critically evaluating information; using and evaluating major search engines, search tools, and other sources; and assessing the impact of the web on self and society, particularly with regard to how people learn and interact with others in this environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching in a Multicultural Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of multicultural understandings to teaching in a multicultural society. Strategies for working effectively with students to achieve educational equity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 477, EDCEP 525 and subject area methods and corresponding practicum.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Office Systems and Procedures
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops competencies needed for careers in the business office, evaluates and utilizes automated office systems and procedures, and applies technical knowledge and decision-making skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Content Area Literacies and Diverse Learners
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of content area literacies to include concern for culturally and linguistically diverse learners.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDCEP 525 and subject area methods and corresponding practicum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Content Area Methods in the Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to content area instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Secondary Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in professional education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Maximum of 3 hours applicable toward degree requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Career Pathways in Family and Consumer Sciences Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and procedures in planning and organizing family and consumer sciences-related career pathways are explored. The course includes curriculum design elements and instructional methods unique to programs that emphasize technical skill proficiency, competency-based applied learning, and preparation for education and training beyond the secondary education classroom.

htmlparse.Course.title: Block II Lab: Content Area Methods and Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of specific content area with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, 477, 500, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Studies Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: Application and integration of theories and practices of content disciplines into instruction. Emphasis on design and presentation of lessons through lenses of social studies disciplines.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 544 and EDSEC 545, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Art Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to art instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 531, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding

htmlparse.Course.title: Art Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of art with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 530, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to business instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 533, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of business with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 532, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family and Consumer Science Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to family and consumer sciences instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 535, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family and Consumer Science Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of family and consumer sciences with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 534, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Language Arts Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to language arts instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 537, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding

htmlparse.Course.title: Language Arts Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of language arts with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 536, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematics Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to mathematics instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 539, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematics Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of mathematics with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 538, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Language Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to modern languages instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 541, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Language Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of modern languages with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 540, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Science Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to science instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 543, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Science Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of science with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 542, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Studies Methods for Secondary and Middle Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of teaching applied to social studies instruction in the secondary and middle schools including: motivation, organization of subject matter, lesson/unit planning, assessment and reporting, organization and management of the classroom, and methodology and materials of the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 545, and EDCEP 525.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Studies Methods Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Field-based experience to help the pre-professional teacher practice the incorporation of social studies with reading methods and demonstrate application of technology into teaching and assessment in the secondary and middle schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSP 323, and EDSEC 376. Concurrent enrollment required for EDSEC 455, EDSEC 477, EDSEC 544, and EDCEP 525.

htmlparse.Course.title: Art for Exceptional Children
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of art courses and activities to meet the needs of the mentally retarded, physically impaired, emotionally disturbed, or gifted child.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Experience and Interpretive Understanding Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Participation in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and teaching under the direction of selected music teachers in elementary, middle level, and secondary school music programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Participation in Secondary Schools and Professional Development Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Guided observation, teaching participation, and study of teaching practices under direction of selected teachers in middle/junior and senior high schools. Student teachers will participate in seminar sessions to discuss issues and experiences encountered during this school-based experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDSEC 455, 477, EDCEP 525 and corresponding content area methods and practicum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervised Practicum for Athletic Coaches
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and coaching participation under the direction of selected coaches in public school, club, city recreation, or other nonpublic school sport settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coordination Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Acquaints students with techniques in selecting, implementing, and coordinating occupational programs between the school and the business community.

htmlparse.Course.title: Job Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Acquaints students with techniques of analyzing jobs and tasks related to occupations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory Techniques in Teaching Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Rationale for laboratory in secondary school science. The design and implementation of laboratory activities and demonstrations in a high school science program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Concurrent enrollment recommended for EDSEC 542 and EDSEC 543.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles and Philosophy of Career and Technical Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of career and technical education in Kansas and other states and countries; principles and philosophy underlying such education, relation of career and technical education to school objectives and community, state, and national needs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Planning in Career and Technical Education
htmlparse.Course.description: The program development and planning process; development of guides for teaching a evaluating reimbursable secondary programs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exceptional Students in the Secondary School
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for regular classroom teachers in meeting the needs of exceptional adolescents. Support strategies for teachers and exceptional students in the mainstream of education.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to teacher education and FSHS 110.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exceptional Child in the Regular Classroom
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for general education teachers in meeting the needs of exceptional children. Support strategies for teachers and exceptional children in the mainstream of education will be explored.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to teacher education. Elementary students must take this course concurrent with DED 318, EDCEP 315, and EDEL 320.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Human Exceptionality
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of history and legal aspects of service, etiologies, characteristics, and special needs of exceptional individuals.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in professional education. Maximum of three hours applicable toward degree requirements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Education of Exceptional Individuals
htmlparse.Course.description: A general study of special education, with emphasis on legislation, Individual Education Plans, cross-cultural assessment and intervention, and strategies for exceptional students at the preschool, elementary, and secondary levels.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315 and EDSP 323 or EDSP 324.

htmlparse.Course.title: Characteristics of Cognitive Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Etiological, psychological, sociological, and educational aspects of cognitive disabilities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Characteristics of Emotional and Behavioral Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of conceptual models for understanding emotional and behavioral disorders of childhood and adolescents, and their implications for educators.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315 and EDSP 323 or EDSP 324.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interventions: Emotional and Behavioral Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Educational planning assessment, instructional methods, curricular modification, media and materials, teacher competencies, and model programs for students with emotional and behavioral disorders.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interventions: Academic Disabilities
htmlparse.Course.description: Educational planning, instructional methods, and curricula modifications for students with academic learning disabilities.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Consulting Process in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A course to prepare special education teachers with skills for consulting effectively with classroom teachers, related services personnel, administrators, and parents about curriculum and program alternatives for exceptional children. Emphasis is upon developing collaborative consultation processes through communication, cooperation, and coordination techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDSP 323 or 324 or 500, and EDSP 742 or 743.

htmlparse.Course.title: Characteristics and Needs of Individuals Who are Gifted
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of historical perspectives related to gifted child education, various facets of intellectual and creative functioning, national and state guidelines for planning and implementing gifted programs, modifying curriculum and classroom strategies to nurture gifted potential, current issues in gifted education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Guidance of the Exceptional Individual
htmlparse.Course.description: Strategies for teachers in working with the academic, vocational, personal, and social adjustment of the exceptional individual. The course will focus on the individual in preschool, elementary, secondary, postsecondary, and adult settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings in research and application in specialized areas in education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Behavior Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical and practical applications of behavior analysis in schools with emphasis on preventing and remediating behavior problems of students with disabilities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technology for Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to help special educators develop an awareness of assistive technology (AT) and related legislative guidelines, which can assist in the lives and learning of students receiving special education. This course will explore assistive technology devices and services and software appropriate for students with special needs. Internet resource and AT evaluation systems related to special education will also be covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: DED 318 Educational Technology for Teaching and Learning or related professional experiences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Adaptive Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and participation in teaching individuals with exceptional educational needs under the supervision of selected teachers in special education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current topic in specialization of faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Topics vary each semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Experiences in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and supervised activities in schools, camps, clinics, or institutions related to student’s area of special interest or preparation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected students are permitted to secure specialized training appropriate to the needs of the individual. The student’s project may involve intensive library investigation in a special field or the collection and analysis of data pertinent to a given problem. All work is done independently under the direction of a faculty member. As many conferences are held as necessary to assure successful completion of a project necessary for the problem undertaken and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses necessary for the problem undertaken and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Writing Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory practice in writing for all students who need review in fundamentals of composition. Especially for students who have difficulty in meeting standards in Expository Writing I and II, but also designed to assist students who desire to improve their composition skills. Hours are not applicable toward degree requirements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developmental English-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Basics of standard edited (written) English with emphasis on grammar, usage, and sentence structure. This course does not fulfill requirements for the associate degree.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expository Writing I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to expressive and informative writing. Frequent discussions, workshops, and conferences. Offers extensive practice in the process of writing: getting ideas, drafting, analyzing drafts, revising, and editing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expository Writing I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to expressive and informative writing. Frequent discussions, workshops, and conferences. Offers extensive practice in the process of writing: getting ideas, drafting, analyzing drafts, revising, and editing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expository Writing II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to writing persuasively. As with ENGL 100, uses discussion, workshops, and conferences, and emphasizes the writing process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expository Writing II-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to writing persuasively. As with ENGL 100, uses discussion, workshops, and conferences, and emphasizes the writing process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors English
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical reading and writing for students enrolled in the Honors Program.  Each individual section will concentrate on themes determined by the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fiction into Film
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical analysis of literary texts and their film adaptations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical Cultures
htmlparse.Course.description:
Courses examine Western culture through literature, philosophy, religion, art, and music. Introduction to Western Humanities courses: ENGL 230, 231, 233, 234 may be taken individually and in any order.

This course examines Ancient Greek and Roman cultures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medieval and Renaissance
htmlparse.Course.description:
Courses examine Western culture through literature, philosophy, religion, art, and music. Introduction to Western Humanities courses: ENGL 230, 231, 233, 234 may be taken individually and in any order.

This course examines Middle Ages to mid 1600s.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reformation to Enlightenment
htmlparse.Course.description:
Courses examine Western culture through literature, philosophy, religion, art, and music. Introduction to Western Humanities courses: ENGL 230, 231, 233, 234 may be taken individually and in any order.

This course examines the Beginnings of Protestantism through the 18th century.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern
htmlparse.Course.description:
Courses examine Western culture through literature, philosophy, religion, art, and music. Introduction to Western Humanities courses: ENGL 230, 231, 233, 234 may be taken individually and in any order.

This course examines the 19th century to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of fiction, poetry, drama, and nonfiction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Literature-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of fiction, poetry, drama, and nonfiction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Short Story
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of short stories from world literature with emphasis on American, British, and Continental.

htmlparse.Course.title: British Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected writers from various periods of British literary history.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Designed for students not majoring/minoring in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected writers from various periods in American literary history.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Designed for students not majoring/minoring in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Studies in World Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of a particular theme or genre in World literature or culture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taught in English. Topics vary.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to American Ethnic Literatures
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of ethnic and multicultural literatures of the United States, such as African American, Asian American, Latina/o, Jewish, and Native American.  May offer cross-cultural comparisons of different ethnic traditions or may focus on a single ethnic tradition.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Great Books
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to world classics from past to present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Studies in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected studies in literature, language, rhetoric, and cultural studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic. May not be used for English major credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities I
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of selected major works of history, literature, and philosophy of central importance in the Western cultural tradition. Emphasis on classroom discussion and writing interpretive essays.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Limited to entering freshmen.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of ENGL 297.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 297 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Topics in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings and colloquia in selected topics in literature or language.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Open only to arts and sciences honors program students and to others completing ENGL 100 or 200 and 110 or 125 with a 3.5 GPA.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expository Writing III
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced practice in writing a variety of expository forms: personal essays and informative and persuasive reports. Additional work on style and the demands of various rhetorical situations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technical Writing-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: This writing course will provide students from a number of business, technology and aviation disciplines with intensive practice writing the kinds of documents that are common in their future professional lives.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Literary Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Elements of literary form and style: an introduction to criticism for English majors. Intended as a first course in the analysis of form and technique, an introduction to literary terms commonly used in later courses, and practice in critical writing. Readings from a broad range: poems, plays, essays, and novels.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cultural Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces the theories and methods of cultural studies through practical application to particular topics in culture and/or literature. An introductory class that addresses such issues as gender and sexuality, power relations among social groups, the construction, communication, and preservation of knowledge. The course typically features theoretical cultural studies material and a variety of media, including traditional and nontraditional literature, film, comics, television, the Internet, and other popular culture platforms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature and Technology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will read in a variety of literary, civic, and professional genres about technology and its effect on society; through writing, understand technology in terms of humanistic themes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fiction
htmlparse.Course.description: Fiction selected from various periods and cultures. Concern for form and critical analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Film
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of film as genre from historical beginnings through classic Hollywood to contemporary cinema. Emphasis on form and critical analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Poetry
htmlparse.Course.description: Close reading of poems and analysis of poetic genres, with emphasis on modern poetry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drama
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of drama from classical times to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Shakespeare
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of representative comedies, histories, and tragedies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature for Children
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey emphasizing the reading and evaluating of books for children. Required for licensure in elementary education.

htmlparse.Course.title: British Survey I
htmlparse.Course.description: British literature from Anglo-Saxon times to 1700.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Will apply to survey requirement for English majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: British Survey II
htmlparse.Course.description: British literature from 1700 to the present.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Will apply to survey requirement for English majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Survey I
htmlparse.Course.description: American literature from pre-colonial times to the Civil War.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Will apply to survey requirement for English majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Survey II
htmlparse.Course.description: American literature from the Civil War to the present.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Will apply to survey requirement for English majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected American Ethnic Literatures
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative study of ethnic and multicultural literatures of the United States, such as African American, Asian American, Latina/o, Jewish, and Native American. May focus on a single ethnic tradition outside of the four federally recognized minority groups.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: African American Literatures
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of African American literatures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Will apply to the diversity overlay for English Majors.
May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Indian Literatures
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of American Indian literatures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Will apply to the diversity overlay for English majors.
May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Asian American Literatures
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of Asian American literatures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Will apply to the diversity overlay for English majors.
May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Latina/o Literatures
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of Latina/o literatures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Will apply to the diversity overlay for English majors.
May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fable and Fantasy
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of modern works in the fabulous or fantastic modes in relation to the traditions underlying them.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected studies in literature and language.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings and colloquia in selected masterpieces.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Expository Writing for Prospective Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: Expository writing and a brief introduction to the history and theory of teaching writing, primarily for candidates for Secondary licensure in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Written Communication for Engineers
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and intensive use of writing forms characteristic of professional practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Enrollment in the College of Engineering with junior or senior standing and ENGL 100 or equivalent with A or B credit or ENGL 200.

htmlparse.Course.title: Written Communication for the Workplace
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and intensive writing practice for students entering the workplace.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and ENGL 200 or 210.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Film
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected studies in film analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Structure of English
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematic study of the structure of the English language and a consideration of the current theories of analysis: traditional, structural, and transformational-generative.

htmlparse.Course.title: Linguistics for Teachers of English
htmlparse.Course.description: Pedagogical aspects of the structure, history, and use of the English language.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students seeking secondary licensure in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Themes in Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the literary treatment of important and recurring themes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literary Kinds
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the characteristics, the growth and development, or the uses of specified literary genres.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Literature in relation to social and cultural patterns and influences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature and Society-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Literature in relation to social and cultural patterns and influences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exploring Creativity
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of creative thinking.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 200 or ENGL 210 or ENGL 415.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Fiction Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: A practical introduction to short fiction writing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: A practical introduction to poetry writing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction
htmlparse.Course.description: A practical introduction to creative nonfiction or what can be called ”the literature of fact.” Writers of creative nonfiction use many of the stylistic and literary tools that fiction writers and poets use, but in the service of rendering factual, literally accurate prose.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Creative Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics vary.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Bible
htmlparse.Course.description: Literature, history, and cultural backgrounds of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament) and/or the New Testament and early Christianity.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: American English
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematic study of the English language as it has been and is spoken in the continental United States. Topics may include Tall Talk, Americanisms, Colonial and Modern dialects, and American dictionaries.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Rhetoric and Literacy
htmlparse.Course.description: Content may emphasize visual rhetoric and literacy, literacy theory, and persuasion, and how such topics are understood in particular contexts and cultures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Development of the English Language
htmlparse.Course.description: Depicts the English language in its place among other world languages, and introduces students to the major ways in which English has changed through time. Considers both internal and external influences as causes of language change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Humanities Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Study in depth of selected major figures and movements in Western arts, ideas, and literature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Appropriate introductory humanities course (or an equivalent background, such as courses in Western civilization, art, or world literature) with consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: English Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Choice between research and service learning internships. A research internship works with English professor on semester-long research project. A service learning intern works with a community organization or other external office to develop written and other materials on behalf of that entity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Investigations in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation in authors, genres, periods of literature or language.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of preparation needed for investigation undertaken.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Individually guided study in which the student will formulate and explore a narrowly defined topic in literature or language.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be used to initiate research for senior honors thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Writing Center Theory and Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings in and applications of writing center theory in a peer tutoring context.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Professional Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive practice in applying rhetorical principles to a number of genres common in non-academic professions and workplaces; an introduction to allied topics such as document design and editing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Written Communication for the Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and intensive writing practice for students in the basic and applied sciences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and ENGL 200 or 210. Will not substitute for ENGL 415.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of literary works by or about women.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature for Adolescents
htmlparse.Course.description: Selecting, reading, and evaluating books for adolescents.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required for those seeking middle school and high school licensure in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Law, Politics, and Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Classic and contemporary works of literature, including novels, plays, short stories, and poems, are used to explore themes in law and politics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 200 or junior standing or POLSC 301 or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected World Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses writing by authors whose native origins lie outside Europe or the United States. Content may vary with instructor. May examine literature from several countries or regions, concentrate on literature from one country or region, or focus on a topic which transcends national or regional boundaries. Works are written in or translated into English.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with a change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literary Studies Abroad
htmlparse.Course.description: Travel abroad, with selected readings, lectures, and discussions which explore the relationships between literary texts and their physical and cultural environments.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Topic varies with instructor.
May be repeated with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Research in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation in authors, genres, periods of literature, or language. Background of preparation needed for investigation undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Phonetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Description and classification of speech sounds according to point and manner of articulation. Transcription in the International Phonetic Association Alphabet. Includes sounds of English, French, Spanish, German, and others.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Internal and comparative reconstruction of earlier forms of languages. Genetic relationships in language families, and various typological considerations. Includes French, Spanish, and others.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on a special-topic in linguistics: decipherment of ancient writing systems, linguistics applied to the teaching of English or other languages, discourse analysis (especially of spoken texts), etc. Topic to be announced for semester in which offered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit on a different topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expository Writing Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Course emphasizes stylistic analysis of modern non-fiction prose in the sciences, social sciences, and humanities. Extensive writing required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Medieval Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is one within a sequence of period studies covering the chronological range of English and American literature. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the periods.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.
The courses require junior standing and may be repeated with change of subject matter.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Creative Writing: Prose Fiction
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of prose fiction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Playwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical study and practical application of techniques of playwriting with regard to plot, characters, and production; emphasis on the one-act form.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Creative Writing: Poetry
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of poetry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Creative Writing: Nonfiction
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of prose creative nonfiction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: A writing- and discussion-intensive course that provides a culminating experience to the English major.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Twenty-one (21) credit hours in English beyond ENGL 310.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Topic varies according to instructor and semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Old English
htmlparse.Course.description: The elements of Old English grammar, with readings in prose and poetry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Critical Approaches to Children’s Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to advanced study of children’s and young adult literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory and Practice of Cultural Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of selected approaches to the study of culture and of their current application in English studies, including psychoanalytic, feminist, Marxist, and poststructuralist approaches.

htmlparse.Course.title: Studies in a Literary Genre
htmlparse.Course.description: The specific contents will vary by semester and instructor, but the studies courses will reflect concerns with literary and rhetorical forms and genres; with specific authors, periods, or literary movements; with perspectives from social, intellectual, and cultural studies; with literary themes; or with language or linguistics.

htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to major theories of composition and/or rhetoric.

htmlparse.Course.description: A writing-intensive course intended for advanced undergraduate students, graduate students, and working professionals in business.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 200 or 210 or 415 or 417 or 516 or graduate standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Writing Workshop: Short Fiction
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of short prose fiction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated twice for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Playwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Further study in the writing of drama; emphasis on problems of writing the full-length play.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 9 credit hours by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Writing Workshop: Poetry
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of poetry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated twice for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Writing Workshop: Creative Nonfiction
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of creative nonfiction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable twice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Writing Workshop/Special Topic
htmlparse.Course.description: Special topics vary.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Writing Workshop: Novel/Novella
htmlparse.Course.description: Creative Writing Workshop: Novel/Novella
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated twice for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the English Language
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of British and American English from Indo-European origins to the present.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literary Criticism
htmlparse.Course.description: A historical survey of literary theory and criticism.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Writing Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Faculty-supervised professional experience, emphasizing application of writing skills in professional contexts. Student projects must be approved by on-site supervisor and faculty supervisor. Report must be submitted at the end of the semester.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 510 or ENGL 665 or ENGL 759 or ENGL 765.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in major authors, genres, and periods of English and American literature and language.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for problem undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Classification, life histories, habits, and principles of control of important economic insects. For agriculture majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.
For the 2 credit option, students must have completed ENTOM 305 or 312 or 320 for full credit, and must receive permission from the instructor. Students who take the course for two credits will only have to meet during approximately weeks 6 through 16 of the semester, which covers strategies of control and pests of commodities. The 3-credit option is available to students who wish to take the entire course for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insects and People
htmlparse.Course.description: Intended for undergraduate non-majors as part of the university general education curriculum. The focus will be on the global impact of insects and their relatives on human concerns, from acting as disease vectors, agricultural pests, and pollinators to their roles in art, history, and religion.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one one-hour interactive session a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Health Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to biology of arthropods that affect animal health. The main focus is on strategies to manage arthropods that negatively affect the health and productivity of animals, including beef and dairy cattle, swine, poultry, horses, sheep, goats, pets, and urban wildlife. This course is particularly recommended for students interested in animal science, pre-veterinary medicine, and other agricultural curricula.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture/demo a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Animal Health Entomology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: This laboratory course complements ENTOM 305 and offers hands-on experience in identification and management of arthropods of veterinary importance. Includes field trips to food animal operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One two-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic study of insects and related arthropods, their structure, physiology, behavior, and relations to plants and animals, including man.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Entomology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification, food preferences, and habitat preferences of the common insects.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Biological principles and management considerations for insects and related arthropods affecting horticulture. Practical application of classification and life history information for accurate recognition, monitoring, and pest management decisions. Control tactics and conservation of beneficial species.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.
For the 2-credit option, students must have completed ENTOM 300 or 305 or 312 for full credit, and must receive permission from the instructor. Students who take the course for two credits will only have to meet during approximately weeks 6 through 16 of the semester, which covers general pest management concepts and procedures and specific applications for horticultural entomology. The 3-credit option is available to students who wish to take the entire course for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turfgrass Insects and Their Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology, diagnosis and integrated management of turfgrass insect pests.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 582 or concurrent enrollment and HORT 515 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the last five weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Undergraduate research and/or independent study in various areas of entomology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Pest Diagnosis
htmlparse.Course.description: Diagnosis of plant damage by insects and mites, recognition of harmful insects and mites and beneficial insects. Emphasis on field crop pests but pests of other crops will be considered if there is sufficient interest.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insecticides: Properties and Laws
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to insecticides as arthropod control agents, including their classification, formulation, properties, mode of action, metabolism, resistance, benefits and environmental impact, and federal and state laws that regulate the development, sale, use and storage of insecticides.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integrative Behavioral Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide an overview of the genetics, ecology, and evolution of insect behavior, emphasizing research done in insect systems. The topics covered in this course will include: (1) Conceptual and empirical framework for studying behavior, (2) the genetics of behavior, (3) “kinds” of behaviors, and (4) detailed examples of each “kind” of behavior.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aquatic Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology and ecology of aquatic insect orders and families, their roles in aquatic ecosystems, relationships to people, and use as sensitive biomonitoring agents to detect ecological disturbances. Labs teach sampling techniques and use of keys to identify aquatic insects to family and selected genera.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one two-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Abiotic and biotic factors underlying the distribution, abundance, and dynamics of insects. How to measure these factors, how they affect insect population processes, interactions, and community structure, especially in agricultural systems. Emphasis on basic concepts and their application, experimental methods and field techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOL 303, BIOL 529, or ENTOM 312.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and 2 hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Taxonomy
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory study of insect Order and family-group identification. Proper preparation and maintenance of adult insect collections. Lecture stresses the principles of systematics, legal principles of nomenclature, and the phylogeny of insects and their near relatives.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ENTOM 300, or ENTOM 312 and ENTOM 313.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
For beginning graduate and advanced undergraduate students.
One hour lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Plant Resistance to Pests
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of the biology, ecology, genetics and breeding for pest resistance in plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENTOM 300 or PLPTH 500 or ENTOM 312 and ENTOM 313, and one course in plant or animal genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture and discussion a week. Meets first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Resistance to Insects
htmlparse.Course.description: Plant resistance in crop plants including transgenic plants. Insect behavior, physiology, and ecology as affected by resistance. Discussion of methods of assessing and quantifying plant resistance.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, in even years, during second half of semester

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Pest Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A presentation of the items necessary to consider in order to develop a sound pest management program, from identification of a problem to recommendations made to growers for dealing with a pest.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: For nonthesis or nondissertation studies. Work in various fields of entomology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
htmlparse.Course.description: The foundation course in the program, this course examines the entrepreneurial process. We will focus on business start-up but will also address organizational entrepreneurship or “intrapreneurship.” We will address the process of creativity and innovation and its impact on the success of business start-up. Specific topics covered include new venture planning, marketing, financing, and management. This course will serve as a  strong foundation for those aspiring to own and operate their own businesses as well as a real-world heads-up course for students who acknowledge that their future in businesses could very well benefit from examining projects in an entrepreneurial way.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Entrepreneurship
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of the entrepreneur is examined in the conception, start-up, organization, and development of new independent businesses.  New venture problems to be studied include identification of possible new products and services, evaluation of practical commercial potential, and development of a business plan, with attention to financing, operating, and marketing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450, MANGT 420, MKTG 400. Instructor may waive prerequisites based on appropriate business experience.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Must be declared Entrepreneurship major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Business
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of how social media, mobile technologies and digital business tools have enabled new businesses development and existing business transformation. Five major, interrelated components: social computing, social media, content sharing, filtering, and Web applications will be explored within the context of business application and development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Entrepreneurial Consulting
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide students and faculty in the Entrepreneurship program the opportunity to give business assistance to small firms in the University community.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Student admitted in the major or minor in Entrepreneurship.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students participating in the University Honors Program and who are enrolled in the College of Architecture, Planning & Design must enroll each semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Directions and goals for the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Design Studio I
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundation studies introducing principles, processes, and vocabularies of environmental design. Instruction in two and three dimensional visualization of objects and spaces. Instruction in the use of instrument-aided drawing, freehand drawing, and model building to represent and communicate design ideas at different scales of observation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the College of Architecture and Design or permission of the dean.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Design Studio II
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundation studies introducing principles, processes, and vocabularies of environmental design. Instruction in two and three dimensional visualization of objects and spaces. Instruction in the use of instrument-aided drawing, freehand drawing, and model building to represent and communicate design ideas at different scales of observation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the  College of Architecture and Design or permission of the dean.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Survey of the Design Professions
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the design professions. Comparative study of the working methods, and societal and occupational roles of the architect, interior architect, landscape architect, and planner.

htmlparse.Course.title: Indian Art, Architecture and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to assist students in understanding India and its cultural, artistic, and architectural heritage so that students can develop a deeper understanding and appreciation for Indian culture, people and their way of life.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Designed Environment I
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of the designed environment from ancient times to the 12th century.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Designed Environment II
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of the designed environment from the 12th century to the mid-18th century.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENVD 250 or permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Basic Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of specified problems in elementary environmental design under the guidance of a member of the staff.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian Art, History and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The course provides a synthesis of art, history, design and culture in the context of the Italian Peninsula and the Mediterranean region over time.  Integration of material covered in lectures with field trips in Italy is expected.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Field Study
htmlparse.Course.description: Group observation of design precedents (ancient to present day) of a selected region, conducted in situ, to study significant aspects of environment, culture, and technology as expressed in vernacular and designed environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Environmental Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of specific environmental design problems under the direction of a member(s) of the departmental staff.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Materials of Nuclear Reactor Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: The properties and behavior of fuel and nonfuel materials used in nuclear reactor systems are considered. Selected nuclear fuel cycle topics are covered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Reactor Technology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to nuclear and neutron physics, including: interaction of netrons, gamma rays, and beta and alpha particles with matter; production of neutrons and the neutrons life cycle; basic neutron diffusion principles; and the nuclear fuel cycle.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Reactor Technology Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied numerical analysis emphasizing solutions of elementary differential equations with a very strong emphasis on applications in nuclear reactor technology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Reactor Technology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of diffusion and slowing down of neutrons with application to subcritical and reactors; introduction to the time behavior of reactor systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiation Detection and Monitoring
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of operation of detectors used in the measurement and monitoring of ionizing radiation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Reactor Thermal Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to conduction, convention, and radiation heat transfer as applied to reactor cores and systems. Consideration of nuclear reactor safety and power reactor systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiation Protection Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of radiation protection environmental effects of radiation and an introduction to nuclear reactor shielding.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Technology Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to university life and the skills necesary for personal and professional success after college. Activities include discussions, hands-on projects and opportunities to meet and learn from professionals. Topics explore the responsibilities of a college student and the benefits of a university education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Approximately 16 contact hours during the semester. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in specific topics in engineering technology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems in Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced independent study in specific topics in engineering technology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Science & Industry Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the food science & industry programs, activities, resources, faculty and career opportunities.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all freshmen in food science & industry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Food Science
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is the beginning course in food science designed to acquaint the student with the breadth and scope of the food industry and the role of science in the preservation, processing, and utilization of foods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Food Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of some basic ingredients used in food processing, principles of preserving and processing of foods, and food packaging. Food science and industry majors should take before the senior year. Taught in cooperation with the Departments of Horticulture, and Grain Science and Industry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Microbiology for Meat and Poultry Processors
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to basic food microbiology and food safety concepts with application and integration of principles to the meat and poultry processing industry, microbiological techniques for products and environmental samples, antimicrobial intervention strategies, employee hygiene, Good Manufacturing Practices (GMPs), food plant sanitation, and introduction to Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points (HACCP) programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Products Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of sensory evaluation of dairy, poultry products, meat, and other agricultural food products. Study of taste, smell, texture, visual appearance, and other senses related to organoleptic examination and its application to the food processing industry. Introduction to sensory testing methods, including sampling techniques and test forms.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Science Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of recent developments in the food science industry and in food science research. Food science literature and intradepartmental research will provide source material.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all food science undergraduates in agriculture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth coverage of the chemical structures of major food components and the chemical reactions occurring during storage and processing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with the isolation, identification, enumeration, and characterization of bacteria, yeasts, molds and other microbes associated with foods and food processing. Effects of physical and chemical agents on micro-organisms will be studied. Microbiological problems in food spoilage, food preservation, food fermentation, and food-borne diseases will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Microbiology Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory procedures involving isolation, identification, enumeration, and characterization of bacteria, yeasts, molds and other microbes associated with foods and food processing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two two-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Science Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised professional field experience in food science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Science Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Research or related work with others, or a literature search. Written reports are required. Any field of food science for which the student has adequate background.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Study Experience in Food Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar and travel course designed to prepare students before the experience and for students to analyze, critique, and report their experiences of an international experience associated with study tours or short courses. Course will focus on appropriate oral and written documentation of the student learning objectives for course experience. The academic topics will vary with each international activity.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of HACCP
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive study of the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point System and its application in the food industry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: Junior Standing.
Recommended prerequisite: BIOL 198 and CHM 110.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Plant Management
htmlparse.Course.description: The integration of food science knowledge in managing a food processing operation to produce high quality food products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quality Assurance of Food Products
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive course covering all aspects of quality assurance practices in the food industry. Emphasis is placed on interrelations of food chemistry, microbiology, sanitation, processing, and laws and regulations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Kosher and Halal Food Regulations
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an introduction to the origin and application of Jewish and Muslim dietary laws and their application in commercial food production and processing with some coverage of home practices. Hebrew, Yiddish, and Arabic words and phrases will be presented and explained as they relate to kosher and halal food production, processing, and consumption. Religious festivals and customs, and the associated food products, will also be presented. Current food-related topics and issues in both the Jewish and Islam communities will be discussed. Food scientists should be aware of what constitutes a kosher or halal product and the importance of regulations dealing with the production and processing of these products.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
This is a web-based lecture course intended for off-campus distance education students.
Lecture material is supplemented with web-based demonstrations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rapid Methods and Automation in Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Rapid methods and automation is a dynamic area in applied microbiology dealing with the study of improved methods in the isolation, detection, characterization, and enumeration of microorganisms and their products in clinical, food, industrial, and environmental samples. The knowledge and techniques of this course are useful for students interested in medical, food, industrial, and environmental microbiology for early detection of beneficial as well as harmful microorganisms in their work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, methods, and techniques necessary for quantitative, instrumental, physical, and chemical analyses of food and food products for off-campus students using an audio/video taped format. The analytical principles will be related to standards and regulations for food processing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Only offered by Distance Education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Methods of Food Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods for quantitative, physical, and chemical analyses of foods and food products. Analytical techniques covered will include spectroscopy, chromatography, mass spectrometry, immunochemistry and atomic absorption. The analyses will be related to standards and regulations for food processing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week for eight weeks. Meets during first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Methods of Food Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of physical and chemical methods and instrumentation for measuring protein, fat, moisture, and ash content. Determination of fat and oil quality characteristics. Physical measurements of food properties: color, water activity, water holding capacity, textural characteristic. Determination of properties and stability of emulsions, foams, and gels.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation, and three hours lab a week for eight weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: A Multidisciplinary Overview of Food Safety and Security
htmlparse.Course.description: Multidisciplinary food safety and security perspectives provided by numerous subject matter experts. Topics include food safety policy, ag bioterrorism, border security, animal ID, food defense and site security, risk analysis, crisis communication, epidemiology, HACCP, and more.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A course in biology or chemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Protection and Defense–Essential Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: This course presents foundational concepts relevant to protecting the food supply from intentional contamination, including the nature of the food and agriculture system as a critical infrastructure, threats to food and agricultural systems, as well as concepts and strategies related to response and mitigation of food protection incidents.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Effective Summer 2010

htmlparse.Course.title: Research and Development of Food Products
htmlparse.Course.description: All aspects of new food product development from concept to store shelves will be covered, including market screening; focus groups; idea generation; prototype development; ingredient functionality and interactions; statistical designs for product development; processing; packaging; scale-up of operations; regulatory issues; labeling; physical, chemical, microbiological and sensory evaluations; quality control procedures; and HACCP plans.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Toxicants
htmlparse.Course.description: Quantitation metabolism and mechanisms of action of major foodborne toxicants. Toxicant defense and control systems, risk analysis and assessment and application of food laws.
