htmlparse.Course.notes: GPIDEA course

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Laws and the Regulatory Process
htmlparse.Course.description: History of the development of the current federal and state food regulations. Guidelines that govern the practice of regulating the wholesomeness of red meats, poultry, and eggs. Presentations by state and federal food regulators.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three credits in food science coursework at 200 level or above.
htmlparse.Course.notes: GPIDEA course

htmlparse.Course.title: Risk Assessment for Food, Ag, & Vet Med
htmlparse.Course.description: Risk assessment principles as applied to biological systems. Exposure and effects characterization in human and animal health and ecological risk assessment. Risk analysis frameworks and regulatory decision-making. Introduction to quantitative methods for risk assessment using epidemiological and distributional analyses. Uncertainty analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A course in statistics or instructor consent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: GPIDEA course

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Application of HACCP Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of control parameters and methodology at critical control points, validating and auditing the effectiveness of critical control points, critical limits, monitoring tools, corrective action procedures, recordkeeping and verification procedures in addressing biological, chemical, and physical hazards that may be present in food products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Personal Investing and Risk Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides a framework for identifying, analyzing, and managing the lifetime financial risks faced by the average person. An overview of the types and mechanics of investment instruments, development of personal risk profiles and investment plans, asset allocation methods, diversifiable and non-diversifiable risk, and risk avoidance and hedging methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the basic principles of finance, including discounted cash flow analysis, risk-return tradeoff, asset pricing models, and financial and real asset valuation. Applications of these concepts to the firm’s investment and financing decisions and performance analysis will be discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Finance-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the basic principles of finance, including discounted cash flow analysis, risk-return tradeoff, asset pricing models, and financial and real asset valuation. Applications of these concepts to the firm’s investment and financing decisions and performance analysis will be discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Integrated Investment Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a survey of the investment management industry.  The course examines various aspects of the investment management industry including discussions of investment markets, products, companies, and strategies.  The course also examines the business of investment management by surveying each of the functional areas of investment management industry: accounting, finance, management, and marketing.  The course introduces students to the basics of investment management and the course provides a survey of the legal and ethical environments in the investment management industry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Careers in Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the various types of career opportunities available in the field of finance, and how to prepare for them.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Should be taken prior to first semester of senior year.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insurance
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of life, property, casualty, and health insurance from the purchaser’s point of view with additional emphasis on the operation and contribution of the insurance industry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Internship program and selected projects appropriate to the student’s program of study.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head based on background courses appropriate to the project selected.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Investment Management Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction and study of the issues and skills involved in successful investment management. This course will survey the role of capital markets, the basics of fundamental and technical analysis, behavioral finance, the basic of financial statements, client development, and management skills necessary for investment management success.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Institutions and Markets
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of financial institutions and markets from a risk management point of view. The role of  financial institutions in the marketplace, the determinants of interest rates, and the impact of inflation on asset returns will be examined. Risks in financial institutions will be analyzed and management of these risks will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450. May be taken concurrent with FINAN 520.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Investments
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of investment securities from the investor’s point of view. Topics covered include the mechanics of investing in securities and market basics, the risk-return tradeoff, asset pricing models, market efficiency, the valuation of securities, portfolio performance measurement, and an introduction to derivatives.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450. May be taken concurrent with FINAN 510.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial Banking
htmlparse.Course.description: An application of financial management concepts to the liquidity management, investment portfolio analysis, capital budgeting, and capital structure decision-making process required by a commercial bank to perform effectively its financial intermediation role within the financial system’s institutional, regulatory, and competitive environment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Real Estate
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices including legal, economic, and social implications from the viewpoint of the real estate practitioner, investor, and society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Finance for Entrepreneurs
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive set of knowledge and tools to start, run, and exit an entrepreneurial or small business. These tools include financial forecasting and business planning, financing operations and capital investments, evaluation of asset acquisitions, tax planning, short-term capital management, mergers/acquisitions, and evaluation of exit strategies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Short-Term Financial Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of financial concepts to the firm’s short-term investment and financing decisions. Topics include cash collection, cash concentration, cash disbursement, banking relationships, receivables and payables management, hedging, risk management, and international short-term finance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 510 and FINAN 520 or FINAN 815.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of a firm’s investment and financing decisions, firm performance measurement and financial planning for a business enterprise. Topics include financial statement analysis and forecasting, capital budgeting, risk considerations in capital budgeting, cost of capital, capital structure theory and practice, distribution policy, leasing and mergers and acquisitions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students taking FINAN 815 or 860.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Financial Management
htmlparse.Course.description: The international (cross-currency) aspects of financial management. Topics include currency markets and exchange rate determination, parity conditions, foreign exchange exposure and management, and valuation of international projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Either FINAN 510 and FINAN 520 or FINAN 815.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Security and Portfolio Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis and valuation of securities and the management of investment portfolios. Students analyze the composition of, make buy/sell recommendations for, and evaluate the performance of an actual portfolio.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 510 and FINAN 520 or FINAN 815.

htmlparse.Course.title: Derivative Securities and Markets
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure and operation of markets for futures, swaps, options, synthetic options, and futures on options. Valuation of futures contracts and options. Applications of derivatives to hedging and speculating strategies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 510 and FINAN 520 or FINAN 815.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Financial Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the principles and practices of professional financial planning using an integrated planning model. Topics include the planning environment, concepts, tax management, asset acquisition and management, credit management, risk management, investments, retirement planning, and estate planning. Contemporary applications, professional opportunities, and legal/ethical standards are emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cases in Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Capstone course in finance utilizing real world cases to integrate and apply financial concepts and theories, with emphasis on analytical and written and oral communication skills.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 575, and senior level students admitted in a College of Business Administration degree track or graduate standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forest Resource Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of forest management including: forestry heritage in the United States, importance of forests, multiple-use concepts, management practices, utilization, protection, policy, and the profession of forestry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dendrology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification, classification, silvical characteristics, distribution, and economic significance of North American angiosperm trees.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dendrology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification, classification, silvical characteristics, distribution, and economic significance of North American gymnosperm trees.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Natural Resource Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of historic and present-day uses, problems, and basic management approaches associated with our renewable and nonrenewable natural resources. The impact of society, economics, law, politics, and philosophy on the management and use of our natural resources will also be examined.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forestry for Park Managers
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of managing forest resources in the park setting. Special emphasis will be given to tree management in high use areas such as parks where human visitors present special problems for tree survival and development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Forest Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is a study of urban and community forest administration. It considers the urban forest ecosystem involving an in-depth look at ownerships. composition, distribution, benefits, values, and administrative operation. The policies and politics of successful administration will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Forestry Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Work is offered in various fields of forestry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation for Summer School Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Orientation for Summer School Program

htmlparse.Course.title: French I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of modern French, emphasizing the spoken language with practice in the language laboratory.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: French II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of French I, completion of basic presentation of the structure of French. Emphasis on spoken language, use of language lab.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Accelerated Beginning French
htmlparse.Course.description: Course covering material from French I and II in one semester. Listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Includes one hour lab per week in language laboratory or other language opportunities outside of class time.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students with one or two years of previous French instruction or advanced learners of other languages who desire a faster pace.

htmlparse.Course.title: French III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of French II, presentation of more advanced elements of the French language. Emphasis on spoken language, use of the language lab.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: French IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of French III, presentation of more advanced elements of the French language. Emphasis on spoken language, use of the language lab.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Recommended to have taken FREN 211 or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary French Conversation
htmlparse.Course.description: Practice in basic conversational French. Normally taken concurrently with FREN 211 or 313.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 112 or equivalent is recommended.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated twice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Studies in French
htmlparse.Course.description: Offered only to participants in study abroad programs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Prior consultation for approval is expected.
At the discretion of the department, the course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: French Literature in Translation
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected readings in English of works representing important literary trends.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken by majors and minors if all assignments are completed in French.

htmlparse.Course.title: French Phonetics
htmlparse.Course.description: The fundamentals of French phonetics. Intensive practice in diction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern French Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: French culture since World War II with special emphasis on social, economic, historical, and artistic developments of that period. Taught in English.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not accepted for major credit in French.

htmlparse.Course.title: French Composition and Grammar
htmlparse.Course.description: Review in depth of the structure of the language. Intensive practice in written and conversational French.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary France
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to French culture with special emphasis on social and historical developments since World War II.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: French and Francophone Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of French and Francophone culture from the Middle Ages to the present, including but not limited to, developments in art and architecture, music, and literature.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in French
htmlparse.Course.description: Practice in reading a variety of literary, journalistic, and specialized texts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial French
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced grammar necessary for adequate oral and written expression in international business and diplomatic situations, including specialized terminology, conversation and discussion, and translation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced French Conversation
htmlparse.Course.description: Practice in spoken French, with emphasis on idiomatic expression. Course not open to students whose primary language is French and whose competence has been demonstrated in the language at this level.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in French
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in French
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 213 or equivalent and consent of department head and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to French Literature I
htmlparse.Course.description: The reading and discussion of major works of French literature from the early nineteenth century to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to French Literature II
htmlparse.Course.description: The reading and discussion of major works of French literature from the Middle Ages to the end of the eighteenth century.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in French Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the students the opportunity to investigate in detail a particular theme or genre in French literature or culture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: At least one course taught in French at the 500 level.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with a change in focus and texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medieval French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to literary forms, style, and the thought from the eleventh century to the fifteenth century in France. Readings in modern French in Chanson de Roland, Chretien de Troyes, Roman de la Rose, etc.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sixteenth-Century French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading and discussion of selected prose and poetry of the French Renaissance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seventeenth-Century French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Various literary forms of the French Baroque and Classical period. Reading of representative texts by Corneille, Pascal, Moliere, Racine, La Fontaine, and others.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two 500 level courses, including FREN 520 or FREN 521 or with the consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Eighteenth-Century French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical study of the literature of the Enlightenment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Romantic French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of preromanticism and romanticism.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Realist French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of realism, naturalism, and symbolism.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary French Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of major themes and trends in the novel, drama, and poetry since 1900 as reflected by major authors as Proust, Camus, Sarraute, and others.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two 500-level courses, including FREN 520 or FREN 521 or with consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, or Spring in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Spoken and Written French
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced, intensive study of French prose style. Introduction to the techniques of translation from English to French. Intensive practice in oral style and diction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in French Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: A seminar with various topics centered on literature and culture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or FREN 521 or with the consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Francophone Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of French colonial and postcolonial literature and culture with an emphasis on the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Regional focus may vary from Quebecois, Caribbean, Sub-Saharan or North African literature and culture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other course at a 500 level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature for Second Language Acquisition
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and interpretation of cultural and literary texts from French-speaking countries, with emphasis on the development of interpretive skills and materials, and their application to the French curriculum at all levels.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or instructor consent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with a change in focus and texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Culture for Second Language Acquisition
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and interpretation of cultural resources from French-speaking countries, with emphasis on the development of interpretive skills and materials, and their application to the French curriculum at all levels.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or FREN 521 and one other course at a 500 level, or instructor consent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FREN 520 or 521 and one other 500 level course, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation to FSHS
htmlparse.Course.description: A general introduction for new majors in Family Studies and Human Services on the school’s academic programs, advising procedures, and career opportunities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Financial Planning as a Career
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an introduction to career opportunities in the field of financial planning for families with an emphasis on academic preparation, acquisition of professional credentials, and career opportunities. A survey of the history, scope, and trends of the financial planning industry will be explored.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated up to two credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Money 101
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an introduction to resources and tools available to assist students in developing beginning personal finance skills that will assist them throughout their lifetime. Application exercises will allow students to apply personal finance knowledge in solving real-life problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course has an online format.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Personal and Family Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental principles for making financial decisions. Analysis and evaluation of personal and family money management strategies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Human Development
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of life span human development through an individual’s awareness and understanding of his or her own physical, social, and psychological growth and relationships with family, peers, and others.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent or small group study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Helping Relationship
htmlparse.Course.description: Characteristics of the helping relationship; consideration of personal qualities necessary for recognizing needs of individuals and families; identification of effective procedures for referral to appropriate professions and agencies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 110 or PSYCH 110; FSHS, GNHE, and FCSED majors only.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Human Sexuality
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the role and meaning of sexuality in human relationships across the life course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developing Intimate Relationships
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will explore topics related to intimate relationships, which include attraction, communication, casual encounters, cohabitation and conflict. Students will critically evaluate current theory and research concerning the elements of healthy relationships. This course will include a didactic and experiential opportunities for the development of a body of knowledge concerning committed relationships, the development of interpersonal skills, increasing personal awareness, and establishing appropriate expectations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Violence
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will focus on the different types of violence within the family system: child abuse/neglect, dating violence, intimate partner violence, and elder abuse. Students will learn about the common forms of abuse, prevalence rates, risk factors, impact, and beginning interventions on family violence. Attitudes and myths regarding family violence will be explored through critical thinking.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Marriage and Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed as an introduction to the theory and practice of MFT. It includes a study of the philosophical, conceptual, and theoretical background of family therapy. The course will review theoretical formulations, common family problems, and effective treatment strategies. Readings and class discussions will provide students with practical examples of the concepts and offer opportunities for students to examine their own family dynamics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Childhood
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of growth and development of children from conception across the early childhood years, including familial, societal, and other ecological factors affecting young children’s development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Infant Observation Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation of the behavior and development of children from infancy through toddlerhood.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Prior or concurrent enrollment with FSHS 310.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Professional Experiences in Early Childhood Unified
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and participation in diverse early childhood settings serving children with and without disabilities, aged birth through kindergarten.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Restricted to Early Childhood Education and FCSED majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transition to Parenthood
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an empirically based evaluation of The Transition to Parenthood from the onset of pregnancy to three years after the child’s birth.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Sciences and Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of normal communication processes and communication disorders and an introduction to the fields of speech pathology and audiology that are responsible for the clinical management of these disorders.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Phonetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic information about speech sounds and their use in human languages, including physiological, perceptual, and acoustic phonetics. Transcription of English will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work. Corequisite: FSHS 442, 361.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Relationships and Gender Roles
htmlparse.Course.description: Effects of family interaction upon individual development and gender roles; consideration of premarital, marital, and parent-child relationships.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 110 or PSYCH 110 or SOCIO 211.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Relationships and Gender Roles-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Effects of family interaction upon individual development and gender roles; consideration of premarital, marital, and parent-child relationships.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 110 or PSYCH 110 or SOCIO 211.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anatomy of the Speech Mechanism
htmlparse.Course.description: Anatomy of the structures involved in speech production. The course includes histology of the larynx and an overview of speech physiology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hearing Science
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to hearing science concepts. Areas of focus include anatomy and physiology of the hearing mechanism, quantification of sound, sound generation, and sound transmission. Information on the role of the auditory system in the encoding and processing of simple and complex signals is also presented.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work.
Corequisite: FSHS 347, 442.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family and Consumer Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Issues and problems confronting consumers. Emphasis on current economic issues and their potential for impacting families and society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110 or concurrent enrollment; FSHS, GNHE, and FCSED majors only or by permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Personal and Family Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth applications of personal and family money management principles with emphasis on credit, savings, insurance, and budgeting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 105 with grade of “B” or better.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Early Childhood Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the diversity in contemporary early childhood roles and settings, awareness of professional competencies and standards of practice, and recognition of philosophical and historical foundations of the profession.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Manual Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of background information in current trends in the use of sign language. Restricted to sign language used in the United States. Includes instruction in the American Manual Alphabet and Vocabulary for about 700 signs. Primary focus will be application of beginning skills for communication with those who depend on this form of communication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interaction Techniques with Young Children
htmlparse.Course.description: A developmental approach to the acquisition of interaction techniques conducive to healthy emotional and self-concept growth in the child from birth through kindergarten.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 310 and FSHS 313. Early Childhood Education majors only or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exceptional Development in Early Childhood
htmlparse.Course.description: Exceptional development in early childhood (birth through kindergarten), including developmental delays, physical and sensory impairments, communication disorders, mental retardation, learning and behavioral disorders, and health related concerns: emphasis on IEPs and IFSPs and the family’s role in the assessment/referral/intervention process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developmental Psycholinguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of research and theory of early development of language comprehension and production, involving vocalization, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics. Includes discussion of the relationship between cognition and language, as well as other variables influencing language acquisition.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work.
Corequisite: FSHS 347 and 361.

htmlparse.Course.title: Language Assessment and Intervention I
htmlparse.Course.description: The characteristics and nature of language disorders in the preschool-age populations, as well as general principles of language assessment and intervention are presented. Specific language assessment and intervention procedures for individuals 0-8 years of age are reviewed. Communication profiles associated with a variety of language impairments are examined.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work.
Corequisite: FSHS 446 and 567.

htmlparse.Course.title: Disorders of Articulation and Phonology
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory, research, and principles of (a) normal/abnormal phonetic and phonologic development, (b) transcription of speech sound disorders, (c) assessment of speech sound disorders, and (d) intervention for speech sound disorders.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work.
Co-requisite: FSHS 443, 567.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environments in Early Childhood
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, promoting, and maintaining physically and psychologically safe and healthy learning environments for young children.  Fostering active, healthy lifestyles and enhanced quality of life for young children through understanding major concepts for nutrition and health education, human movement and physical activity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Middle Childhood and Adolescence
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of growth and development during middle childhood and adolescence, including familial, societal, and other ecological factors affecting development of youth.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 110 or PSYCH 110 and FSHS majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Development and Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of issues, research, and problems in aging and human development throughout adulthood, with particular emphasis upon the later years.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory in Acoustic Phonetics
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of speech perception and production through acoustic analysis. Laboratory experience in the use of computer-based speech analysis systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Seminar in Early Childhood Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of programs for young children, including philosophical and theoretical foundations. Implementation and evaluation of program models and related issues and research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Trauma and Traumatic Stress
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will introduce and review the theoretical and historical beginnings of the concept of trauma, which includes the inclusion of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) as a diagnosis in the DSM III.  It will highlight the other forms of recognized traumatic events and stressors that have more recently been brought to light.  It will discuss various trauma reactions, effects of stressful events, as well as the treatment of trauma.  Resilience and transcendence of trauma will be outlined, with an emphasis on the importance of self-care for clinicians and helping professional working in this area.

htmlparse.Course.title: Core Conflict Resolution
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on a set of core skills and strategies for managing and resolving disputes. It is designed to (1) help individuals deal with differences and address conflict on a personal level, and (2) provide detailed knowledge of a structured approach for third party conflict resolvers.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Conflict Resolution across Cultures & Contexts
htmlparse.Course.description: The course explores the cultural components of conflict by examining the dynamics of interpersonal beliefs and socialization, cross cultural conflict theory, and issues related to application in a variety of settings. This course is designed to be an exercise in critical thinking, cultural exploration, and self-reflection.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CCONRS or RCATS or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Prevention & Intervention of Violence
htmlparse.Course.description: This course includes an introduction to a range of violence intervention and prevention approaches developed for use as the interpersonal, intergroup, and societal level. Various theories of human aggression and violence and their underlying assumptions about human nature and the causes of violence will be examined.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CCONRS or RCATS or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring (on campus and distance education) Fall (distance education only)
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Conflict in Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the causes and sources of conflict within organizations and groups, dispute systems assessment and design, and how conflict resolution professionals work as interveners and agents of change. Students will also explore and identify their own professional consultation strengths and interests.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: CCONRS or RCATS or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Divorce & Child Custody Mediation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on mediation as an approach for couples wishing to create divorce settlements through a cooperative, confidential, and private process. Divorce and child-custody is considered as a family problem and not a legal problem. It addresses the psychological, financial, and legal dimensions of divorce in conflict resolution settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CCONRS or RCATS or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring (on campus and distance education) Summer (on campus only)
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Conflict and Trauma in International Settings
htmlparse.Course.description: This course study will examine the historical, political, and religious roots of conflict in an international setting.  The focus of study will also include an analysis of the area’s cultural traditions and exploration into the ways in which divided societies cope with attendant political, economic, and social problems.  Prospects for continued and sustainable peace in this region, as well as how progress is being made will also be examined.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum for Cognitive and Language Development of Young Children
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning for the enhancement of cognitive and language development. The application of child development theory to the planning of programs for young children within the major curriculum areas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 310, 313 and admission to teacher education. Concurrent with FSHS 541. Prior or concurrent with FSHS 565.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum for Emotional, Social, and Physical Development of Young Children
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning for the enhancement of physical, social and emotional development. The application of child development theory to the planning of programs for young children within the major curriculum areas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 310, 313 and 420 and admission to teacher education. Concurrent with FSHS 540.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reflective Practice: Infants and Toddlers
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of developmental principles and evidenced-based practice to the diverse learning environments for infants and toddlers with and without special needs across content areas including the integration of the family and community and public policies that affect programs for young children.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Admission to teacher education required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reflective Practice: Preschoolers and Kindergartners
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of developmental principles and evidenced-based practice to the diverse learning environments for preschoolers and kindergarteners with and without special needs across content areas including the integration of the family and community and public policies that affect programs for young children.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 540 and 541. Corequisite: FSHS 554 and 555 required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Admission to teacher education required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Childhood Program Lab II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced application of principles and techniques for developmentally-appropriate programs for young children.  Planning, implementing, and evaluating activities in a supervised lab setting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 545 and admission into teacher education. Concurrent with FSHS 540 or 541.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Procedures in Communication Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Orientation to clinical practicum. Opportunities for clinical observation of speech, language, and hearing evaluation and treatment. Study of diagnostic tools, treatment materials, equipment, and clincial procedures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior, CSD major. Prerequisite or corequisite: FSHS 443, FSHS 446.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Family
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of the family throughout the family life cycle; developmental tasks at each stage. Use and impact of family support services.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 350, 12 hours in FSHS courses; FSHS and GNHE majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Families and Diversity
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics for understanding families in multiple contexts. Implications for professionals working with individuals and families.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS majors, junior or senior standing, 15 FSHS credits.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Childhood Practicum I: Infants and Toddlers
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and implementation of developmentally and functionally appropriate learning experiences, in a variety of formats, addressing content in the areas of early language and literacy, mathematics, science, social studies, the arts, and technology for infants and toddlers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Admission to teacher education required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Childhood Practicum II: Preschoolers
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and implementation of developmentally and functionally appropriate learning experiences, in a variety of formats, addressing content in the areas of early language and literacy, mathematics, science, social studies, the arts, and technology for the preschool child.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Admission to teacher education required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Childhood Practicum III: Kindergartners
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and implementation of developmentally and functionally appropriate learning experiences, in a variety of formats, addressing content in the areas of early language and literacy, mathematics, science, social studies, the arts, and technology for the kindergarten child.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 540 and FSHS 541. Corequisite: FSHS 544.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Admission to teacher education required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Research in Communication Sciences and Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Logic and methods of clinical research with emphasis on those most frequently used in speech-language pathology and audiology. Experience reading, planning, and evaluating research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: STAT 325 or equivalent, FSHS 443 and 446 or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Language Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the development of speech and language skills in children.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Emergent Literacy
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of literacy development from birth through kindergarten, including concepts relevant to pre-emergent, emergent, and developing literacy; procedures for designing developmentally and culturally appropriate experiences; factors impacting literacy acquisition and assessment; and intervention procedures for children at-risk for reading and writing problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Restricted to Early Childhood Education majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Audiology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to audiology concepts and basic audiology testing procedures. Areas covered include disorders of the auditory system, testing procedures, and audiometric interpretation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: CSD major, completion of 57 credit hours and an overall 3.0 GPA, including both K-State and transfer course work.
Corequisite: FSHS 443 and 446.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation to FSHS Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration and application of professional knowledge and skills necessary for selection and placement in a social agency for a supervised experience in direct service to clients.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 110 and 350 with a grade of B or better; senior standing; and minimum GPA of 2.50; FSHS majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: FSHS Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: A block field placement in local agencies. Faculty-supervised experience in direct service to clients: individuals, groups, and communities. Weekly seminar during placement emphasizes theory underlying the practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 110, 350, and 579 with grades of B or better; senior standing; and minimum GPA of 2.50; FSHS majors only.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Seminar in FSHS
htmlparse.Course.description: Capstone course for students completing the internship.  Consideration of professional roles and responsibilities of human service providers, ethics, career development, and characteristics of client populations. Focus on skills required in the delivery of human services with diverse groups.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 579, Senior standing and FSHS majors only. Corequisite: Concurrent enrollment in FSHS 580.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone Experience in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Capstone course for students NOT completing the internship.  Consideration of professional roles and responsibilities of human service providers, ethics, career development, and characteristics of client populations.  Focus on skills required in the delivery of human services with diverse groups.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and FSHS majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Topics in Communication Sciences and Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of current topics in speech-language pathology and/or audiology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours with a change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Seminar in Family Financial Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of professional issues in family financial planning, including ethical considerations, regulation and certification requirements, communication skills, and professional responsibility. Development of skills needed for family financial planners working with families in meeting their financial needs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Home, School, and Community Partnerships
htmlparse.Course.description: Strategies to enhance home-school communication with specific focus on families as the primary decision-makers for young children, with or without special needs. Emphasis on the development of family focused and culturally sensitive collaborations involving parents, schools, and the community to support child development, learning, and well-being.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 350 and FSHS 428 or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Student Teaching in Early Childhood Unified
htmlparse.Course.description: Design, implementation, assessment of developmentally and individually appropriate evidence-based curriculum for children with and without disabilities birth through kindergarten.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 543, 544, 553, 554, 555 and admission to teacher education.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Prearrangement and consent of instructor required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Coping with Life Crises
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to provide students with resources related to managing stress and coping with crises across the lifespan that can be utilized in both their own lives and in the lives of those families they serve. Students will be introduced to the biopsychosocial nature of stress; methods of coping with stress, anxiety, and conflict; models of effective family functioning in the presence of stress and crises; and the current literature on how families cope with a variety of life transitions and crises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Manual Communication II
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in an additional 400-500 signs in the SEE system. Introduction to elementary ASL techniques. Discussion of other augmentative communication systems. Research will be conducted in the use of various manual communication systems with special populations, including aphasic, language disabled, mentally handicapped, and others.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 415 or basic sign language skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Family Financial Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of family financial planning by integrating concepts and issues with planning and counseling applications. Students will be introduced to the key concepts of family financial planning, including: insurance, tax, investments, retirement, and estate planning. The family financial planning process is introduced with an emphasis on the integration and application of concepts in meeting individual and family financial goals and objectives. Other topics presented include an ethics overview, compensation trends within the industry, and regulatory frameworks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Death and the Family
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of contemporary attitudes toward death and dying; related influences on individual development and family life.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marriage Preparation and Enrichment
htmlparse.Course.description: History, processes, components, goals, and research support base for contemporary marriage preparation and enrichment programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Working with Parents
htmlparse.Course.description: Approaches to parenting and parent education with emphasis on programmatic implications of life-span developmental principles within a family context.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Study in Family Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experiences in financial planning, financial counseling, community action, or consumer services.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study on aspects of human development and family studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Interpretation and evaluation of information on varied topics relating to family members.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Nine hours of FSHS or other social science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of nine credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Speech-Language Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised practice in the use of the methods and materials of speech-language pathology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Audiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised practice in the use of equipment, materials, and methods of audiology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of recent research and theory related to exploration of methods and family and interpersonal processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated more than one semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Policy and Family Economic Well-Being
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of conceptual models for policy choices. Impact of socioeconmic and public policy factors as family economic well-being including the special issues faced by financially disadvantaged and nontraditional households.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Nine hours in FSHS or other social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Child Care: Components and Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional development and leadership; skills, services, and resources supporting quality early childhood care and education.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Fifteen (15) credit hours of either social science and/or FSHS.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Youth Development
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines the fundamentals of youth development and the youth development profession. Through this introduction to the field, students will explore the ethical, professional and historical elements of youth development as it has evolved toward professionalization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Youth Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Community Youth Development focuses upon the national emphasis of a strength-based or asset approach to community youth development. Emphasis is placed upon research, theory, and practice applied in communities throughout the United States. Students will explore existing models, theoretical and applied literature and current community efforts as a basis for understanding community youth development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adolescents and Their Families: Implications for Youth Professionals
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers adolescent development as it is related to and intertwined with family development. The reciprocal influences between adolescents and their families will be examined. Working with youth vis-a-vis the family system will be highlighted.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Design, Evaluation, and Implementation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an overview of the program development process and out come evaluation of community, children, and family programs. Mode of outcome scholarship and their implications for community-based programs are discussed. Students will develop knowledge through participating in a community-based project involving the practical application of program design and evaluation methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth Issues and Life Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will present three strands: issues faced by youth today and associated risk and resiliency factors; life skills for youth; and helping skills necessary for youth professionals who work with young poeple.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Contemporary Youth Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will present issues faced by youth today and associated risk and resiliency factors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated more than one semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines various federal and state policies designed specifically for youth. This course will be divided into three sections: (a) what is policy and what youth policies exist? (b) policies specifically designed for to “protect the well-being” of youth (e.g., zero tolerance, restorative justice, juvenile justice and reform), and (c) targeted youth policies (e.g., foster care, policies for youth with disabilities, homeless youth).

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth Professionals as Consumers of Research
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to help youth development professionals understand and apply research results and theories to practice. Emphasis will be placed on research and theory reports related to the youth development with particular attention to research procedures and outcomes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Administration and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the development, administration and management of youth, family, and community service organizations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth Development
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the developmental period of adolescence. The theory and research of positive youth development will be the lens through which this developmental period is examined. Through a critical examination of the theoretical and research literature, the course will help students recognize and become familiar with the major issues and transitions adolescents face as they successfully navigate this developmental stage.

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth and Cultural Contexts
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide participants with an understanding of the cultural heritage of differing family structures, types, and social and educational processes experienced by youth in these families through in-depth reading, writing, discussion, critical listening, viewing of contemporary videos, and informal interviews with youth. Students will gain further knowledge of how ethnic groups fit historically into our society, and the results of how history has shaped our present day situation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Youth Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in youth development practice and service provision in organizational setting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Consent of practicum supervisor as well as on-site supervisor required.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Army Family: from Challenge to Resilience
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the culture and complexities of the contemporary Army family, and the issues related to community-based support and service to Army family members.

htmlparse.Course.title: Augmentative and Alternative Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines the area of augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) for people across the lifespan. The etiologies and communicative needs of current and prospective users of AAC, as well as procedures for evaluation are addressed. The course includes strategies and procedures for implementing AAC systems for people who are permanently or temporarily severely communicatively impaired.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Approaches to Family Health and Illness
htmlparse.Course.description: Clinical approaches to health behaviors and chronic illness management are generally focused on the individual. This course will address contextual and relational factors that impact health and illness within family contexts. The course will explore ways to develop an integrated clinical approach to assess individuals and families attempting to manage a variety of medical conditions across the life span.

htmlparse.Course.title: Assessment of Young Children
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of individual assessment of handicapped and normal children, infancy to age eight, including cognitive, language, fine and gross motor, social, and self-help skills. Focus on selection, administration, interpretation, and evaluation of screening and comprehensive evaluation instruments for assessment and individual program planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Childhood Program Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional practice and organizational management of early childhood care and education programs; financial and personnel management, program development, and community relations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 450 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Play Facilitation
htmlparse.Course.description: The emphasis of this course is the empirical study and practice of play as an educational, evaluative, and therapeutic intervention with young children.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FSHS 540 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fluency Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Research and theory concerning etiology, characteristics, assessment, and treatment of individuals with disfluency problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Language Assessment and Intervention II
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and research concerning language disorders in school-aged children are presented. Specific language assessment and intervention methodologies for this population are reviewed. Dialectal and bilingual considerations for assessment and intervention are addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Impairments in Autism Spectrum Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD), including characteristics, diagnosis, and etiologies. Interventions used by speech-language pathologists for enhancing the communication of individuals with ASD across the lifespan will be presented, with a focus on using evidence-based practice guidelines to determine programs of treatment. Current developments and research findings related to assessment and intervention will be discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aural Rehabilitation
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of habilitation and rehabilitation techniques for individuals diagnosed with a hearing disorder. Specific areas of interest include hearing evaluation techniques, speech and language development for the hearing impaired, hearing aid amplification, cochlear implants, and central auditory processing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Neuromotor Speech Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to motor speech disorders including an overview of the neurological system. Research and practical knowledge concerning etiologies, evaluation, and principles of treatment are addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cleft Palate
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of communicative disorders related to cleft palate and other structurally-based conditions affecting velopharyngeal function. Research and practical knowledge related to the characteristics, assessment, and treatment of these communicative problems are addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Voice Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: The etiologies and characteristics of voice disorders, as well as general principles of assessment, prevention, and treatment of these disorders, are presented. The role of the speech-language pathologist in rehabilitation planning following treatment for laryngeal cancer is also addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conflict Resolution: Core Skills and Strategies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course presents communication theories and interpersonal skills relevant to conflict resolution, including the understanding of, analysis of, and management of conflict. Completion of the course meets the Kansas Office of Dispute Resolution’s training requirements for state approval in core mediation [K.S.A. 5-501 and Rule 902(e)].

htmlparse.Course.title: Culture and Conflict
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an exercise in critical thinking, cultural exploration, and self-reflection. It explores the cultural dimensions of conflict, including the role of culture in defining conflict for individuals and groups. The dynamics of interpersonal beliefs and socialization, cross cultural conflict theory, and issues related to application are also examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Violence Prevention and Intervention
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines various theories of human aggression and violence, exploring their underlying assumptions about human nature, and the causes of violence. Included is an introduction to a range of violence intervention and prevention approaches developed for use at the interpersonal, intergroup, and societal level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizational Conflict
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of the theories, methods, and practice issues involved in identifying and assessing sources of conflict. Students will learn about organizations, organizational development, causes and sources of conflict within organizations, dispute systems design, and how conflict resolution professionals work as interveners and agents of change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Mediation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses the multi-dimensional aspects of divorce, including the legal divorce, the psychological divorce, and children of divorce. The second half of the semester focuses on how mediation can empower families, teens, and parents to resolve their interpersonal conflicts using a neutral third party.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and research regarding the interactive process between the client and the practitioner, including communication techniques, motivation and esteem building, the counseling environment, ethics, and methods of data intake, verification, and analysis. Other topics include legal issues, compensation, uses of technology to identify resources, information management, and current or emerging issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Behavior Assessment Consulting
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will learn characteristics, cultural factors, support issues, confidentiality and facilitation of discussions concerning the personal involvement, the family involvement, and the financial professional involvement in financial planning and counseling. The intent is to provide financial planners and counselors a framework for guiding individuals and families in restructuring dysfunctional developmental financial behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Housing/Real Estate
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the role of housing and real estate in the family financial planning process from a theoretical perspective. Taxation, legal aspects, mortgages, and financial calculations related to home ownership and real estate investments are included. New and emerging issues in the context of housing and real estate will be emphasized. The role of ethics in family financial planning with housing and real estate will also be included.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Trauma and Traumatic Stress
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will introduce and review the theoretical and historical beginnings of the concept of trauma, which includes the inclusion of post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) as a diagnosis in the DSM III. It will highlight the other forms of recognized traumatic events and stressors that have more recently been brought to light. It will discuss various trauma reactions, effects of stressful events, as well as the treatment of trauma. Resilience and transcendence of trauma will be outlined, with an emphasis on the importance of self-care for clinicians and helping professionals working in this area.

htmlparse.Course.title: Families, Employment Benefits, and Retirement Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of micro and macro considerations for retirement planning. Survey of various types of retirement plans, ethical considerations in providing retirement planning services, assessing and forecasting financial needs in retirement, and integration of retirement plans with government benefits.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Conflict & Trauma
htmlparse.Course.description: This course study will examine the historical, political, and religious routs of conflict in an international setting.  The focus of study will also include an analysis of the area’s cultural traditions and exploration into the ways in which divided societies cope with the attendant political, economic and social problems.  Prospects for continued and sustainable peace in the region, as well as how progress is being made will also be examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Investing for the Family’s Future
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of investment options for clients, this course will include common stocks, fixed income securities, convertible securities, and related choices. Relationships between investment options and employee/employer benefit plan choice will be studied. Current and emerging issues, and ethics will be an integral part of the course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crises Across the Lifespan
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to provide students with resources related to managing stress and coping with crises across the lifespan that can be utilized in both their own lives and the lives of those families they serve.  Students will be introduced to the biopsychosocial nature of stress; methods of coping with stress, anxiety, and conflict; models of effective family functioning in the presence of stress and crises; and the current literature on how families cope with a variety of life transitions and crises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Estate Planning for Families
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to fundamentals of the estate planning process. Includes property transfer, tax consequences, probate avoidance, powers of appointment, and various tools/techniques used in implementing an effective estate plan.

htmlparse.Course.title: Military Personal Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course gives an overview of the topics relevant to the financial planning process. The course adapts the topics to address the unique needs, terminology, benefits, and resources that impact military service members and their families. Topics covered are: status of service member; financial readiness; financial management; recordkeeping; cash flow management; risk management; credit and debt management; savings, education planning, and investment management; tax management; retirement management; estate management; and special topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insurance Planning for Families
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of risk management concepts, tools, and strategies for individuals and families, including: life insurance; property and casualty insurance; liability insurance; accident, disability, health, and long-term care insurance; and government-subsidized programs. Current and emerging issues, as well as ethical considerations, relative to risk management will be discussed. Case studies will provide experience in selecting insurance products suitable for individuals and families.

htmlparse.Course.title: Personal Income Taxation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides in-depth information of income tax practices and procedures including tax regulations, tax return preparation, the tax audit process, the appeals process, preparation for an administrative or judicial forum, and ethical considerations of taxation. New and emerging issues related to taxation will be covered. Family/individual case studies provide practice in applying and analyzing tax information and recommending appropriate tax strategies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumental Measurement for Clinical Application
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses instrumentation and measurement procedures for clinical purposes. Particular emphasis is placed on measurement of physiological aspects of speech breathing and acoustic and physiological aspects of phonation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations Family Services
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the field of family studies and related professions that involve working with individuals and families in communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of theories of family function and dysfunction, techniques of assessment, and models of family interventions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lifespan Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Human development from both lifespan and bio-ecological perspectives focusing on major theories of development and current research on micro-macro relationship.

htmlparse.Course.title: Resilience in Families
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of resilience approaches to the study of families and human development across the life cycle.

htmlparse.Course.title: Parenting Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of theories, models, methods, research, and skills related to parenting and parent education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agriculture Scholars Program
htmlparse.Course.description: For all undergraduate students in the College of Agriculture Scholars Program. Students should enroll every semester while active in the program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Acceptance into the College of Agriculture Scholars Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students participating in the University Honors Program and who are enrolled in the College of Agriculture must enroll each semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ag Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Objectives, organization, and procedures of the College of Agriculture and the university are studied. Historical developments and projected trends in agriculture and the application of basic sciences to agriculture are presented.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of freshmen in agriculture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the University Honors Program including directions, goals, and student requirements for completion of the program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected issues in agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human and Cultural Diversity in the Food and Agricultural Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce agriculture students to the concepts of diversity by learning about cultural awareness, issues and the contributions made by different ethnic groups to the field of agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Scholarship and Discovery
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and tours designed to introduce new honors students to a variety of current research projects and scholarly activities on campus and to stimulate project ideas for undergraduate honors and scholars students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Acceptance into the University Honors Program or the College of Agriculture Scholars Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Topic Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Activities and projects designed to help undergraduate honors and scholars students in the College of Agriculture explore current research issues, develop individual research project topics, and identify potential faculty mentors.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and acceptance into the University Honors Program or the College of Agriculture Scholars Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Proposal and Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Undergraduate honors and scholars students work with a faculty mentor to prepare an individual undergraduate research project proposal. Class presentations focus on techniques for conducting honors projects including design of experiments and surveys, research methods, safety and compliance issues, and tips for presenting results.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and acceptance into the University Honors Program or the College of Agriculture Scholars Program.
