htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Citizenship and Ethics in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of agriculture’s relationship with society while encompassing ethics and personal development. Current controversial issues and multidimensional policy topics facing the agricultural industry will be explored with an emphasis on moral and philosophical debates. Issues regarding professional ethics and decision making will also be an emphasis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminars treat topics relevant to students participating in the University honors program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Acceptance into the University Honor Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: A travel-study program which is intended to acquaint students with agriculture of other countries and other parts of the United States and how it differs from Midwest-Great Plains agriculture relative to climate, crops, soils, livestock practices, marketing, and cultural attitudes toward agriculture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors/Scholars Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Completion of an independent undergraduate research project or scholarly activity required for the University Honors Program or the College of Agriculture Scholars Program. Oral presentation and written report required. Taken during the semester when the project will be completed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resources/Environmental Science Project (NRES)
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive project in NRES. Requires integration of information and understanding acquired in NRES secondary major courses. Students must prepare and present written and oral reports.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: All writing and oral communications courses required for major. Prerequisite or corequisite: 15 hours of approved courses in NRES secondary major.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Agricultural Resources and Environmental Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary, international study of agricultural and natural resource management sustainability.  Discussion of agro-ecologic, economic, and social science perspectives; sustainability criteria; issues of scale and culture; disciplinary methods; and systems-level approaches.  Applications to important natural resources and environmental management issues in Kansas, U.S., and in other countries.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in International Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of international agriculture topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Occupational and Agricultural Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses the identification, evaluation, and control of health hazards in occupational and agricultural settings.  Topics include occupational toxicology, air contaminants, noise, radiation, thermal stress, ergonomics, biological hazards, emerging health risks, and health risks of special populations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a Distance course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Occupational and Agricultural Injury Prevention
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores traumatic injuries and their prevention in occupational and agricultural settings.  Topics include falls, workplace violence, animal handling, mobile equipment, fixed machines, work tools, electrical hazards, fires, and explosions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a distance course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Occupational and Agricultural Safety and Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the design and evaluation of behavioral interventions to prevent occupational and agricultural injuries and illnesses. Topics include theories of safety and health behavior; effective communication and persuasion strategies; planning, conducting and evaluating interventions; interventions for diverse populations; and intervention strategies in evolving occupational and societal contexts.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a Distance course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Topics in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics studied to provide an in-depth understanding of current agricultural issues.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with change in topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: All students participating in the University Honors Program and who are enrolled in the College of Business Administration must enroll each semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: A general orientation to the university and the College of Business Administration, study skills, the enrollment process, and to the various career options in business.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required for all students with fewer than 45 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Foundations
htmlparse.Course.description: In a highly interactive learning environment, topics in accounting, business creation, finance, information systems, management, marketing, and operations are covered, while integrating ethics and responsible business citizenship. The course demonstrates how core business areas are interrelated and the importance of creativity and innovation to business. In this applied class, students well engage in the process of making business decisions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Information Technology Skills Proficiency
htmlparse.Course.description: In this course, students will demonstrate skills and knowledge of working effectively with spreadsheets, databases, word-processing and presentation software in a business setting. This proficiency is demonstrated by passing the Information Technology Sills Proficiency Exam administered through this course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the University Honors Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the University Honors Program including directions, goals, and student requirements for completion of the program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Colloquium in Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and lectures on topics of interest to business students.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to freshmen and sophomores in the honors program for the College of Business Administration. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: New Venture Creation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines the entrepreneurial process, especially as it relates to creating a business plan and launching a venture. We will address the process of creativity and innovation and its impact on the success of business start-up.  Specific topics covered include new venture planning, marketing, financing, and management. This course will serve as a strong foundation for those aspiring to own and operate their own businesses as well as a real-world heads-up course for students who acknowledge that their future with larger businesses could very well include dealing with entrepreneurs/small businesses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GENBA 340, ENGL 455, student admitted in the minor in Entrepreneurship.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: International Business Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: An international business experience that requires travel to a foreign country. The length of the tour varies from one week to 16 weeks. This course enables students to complete an international experience that would include study, research, or work in a foreign country. The course provides enriched experience in the financial and business practices in a foreign country and enhances students’’ global and cultural awareness.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation of business communications, reports, and correspondence, and analysis of communication systems within an enterprise structure.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: The Honors Seminar is designed as a follow-up course to the Honors colloquium and it prepares students for the honors capstone project that culminates into the honors project.  It also provides a forum for all honors students who are working on their capstone honors project to share and discuss their project ideas.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Although students are encouraged to focus on a business-related topic, the choice of topic is open to all disciplines. The selection of an area of study is subject to the approval of the Honor Director (or Honors Committee). Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Business Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth analysis of special problems in general business including study of current literature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and consent of instructor and the department head.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: A business honors project is an independent study in an intellectual endeavor (research or creative activity) under the supervision of a faculty member.  The project must be approved by the College of Business Honors Director in consultation with the faculty supervisor and the University Honors Program Director.  Deliverables of an Honors project may include a paper presented at a student or professional conference, a paper presented at a faculty/student seminar, a paper appearing in a poster presentation or a paper submitted for a national competition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to juniors and seniors in the honors program for the College of Business Administration. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Gender
htmlparse.Course.description: Surveys major contemporary United States theories of gender and their development, including impact of feminist movement on the development of theory, interactions of race and gender, women’s culture and men’s roles. Compares approaches of social sciences and humanities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of Women’s Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Business Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: An international business experience that requires travel to a foreign country. The length of the tour varies from one week to 16 weeks. This course enables students to complete an international experience that would include study, research or work in a foreign country. The course provides enriched experience in the financial and business practices in a foreign country and enhances students’ global and cultural awareness.

htmlparse.Course.title: World Regional Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to geography structured on a framework of major world regions and countries. With the regional approach is an explicit dicussion of the essential concepts of certain systematic specialties, such as political, social, economic, and urban geography.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: A geographical assessment of the way human activities shape landscapes throughout the world. The course is especially appropriate for students interested in the social and behavioral sciences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Geography (Honors)
htmlparse.Course.description: Spatial aspects of human organization and behavior are examined through selected concepts in modern geography. The course is especially appropriate for students interested in the social and behavioral sciences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Membership in arts and sciences honors program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Physical Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic physical geography course examining the atmosphere, biosphere, geosphere and hydrosphere, with emphasis on processes, patterns, and physical background.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one two-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Atmospheric Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive scientific study of the physics, chemistry, and dynamics of the earth’s atmosphere, from the earth’s surface to several hundred kilometers.  Fundamental topics covered include atmospheric composition and variability, subdivisions of the atmosphere, energy and mass transfers within the Earth-atmosphere system, atmospheric circulation, and accurate prediction of atmospheric phenomena.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Tourism
htmlparse.Course.description: The geography of tourism is concerned with the structure, form, use, and conservation of the landscape as well as with such spatial conditions as the location of tourist areas and the movements of people from place to place. This course addresses such concepts as the economic, environmental, social, and cultural impacts of tourism as well as examining the tourist geography of each of the world’s regions, focusing on the major tourist areas.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Cartography and Thematic Mapping
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to cartographic history, theory and principles, thematic map design, symbolization, map perception, color theory, typography, and digital cartographic research. Laboratory work will familiarize students with the latest cartographic software that will be used to produce a series of thematic maps.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The course will consist of two hours of lecture and two hours of lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Kansas
htmlparse.Course.description: Perceptions of Kansas, and a regional analysis of the state including discussion of climate, landforms, soil, water, and minerals as well as patterns of settlement, population, agriculture, industry, transportation, and urban development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Japan
htmlparse.Course.description: Geographical survey of Japan from prehistoric times to the present day, which may include material on society, politics, and culture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to China
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the geography, history, politics, and culture of China from prehistoric times to the present day.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Natural Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: The distribution, significance, and environmental consequences of world agriculture, fishing, forestry, and mining, emphasizing the principles which account for the spatial variation in the extraction and consumption of natural resources.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Earth System Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic physical geography course emphasizing the geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and biosphere, including the processes, patterns, and physical science background required to understand related issues such as natural hazards and human modification of earth systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Offered in an on-line format during summer semesters only through the Division of Continuing Education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sustainability Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of sustainability concepts, approaches, and decision-making.  Relation of sustainability to environmental, economic, and social considerations at global, regional, and local scales.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biogeography
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers: 1) the spatial and temporal patterns of the distribution of living organisms on Earth (including plants, animals, and microbes), and 2) the biological and physical processes responsible for these patterns. Biogeography has crucial insights to offer regarding conservation of rare species, global changes such as climate change, and human domination of the Earth surface.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in geography, life science, or physical science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Economic Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: The location of manufacturing industries and patterns of commercial activity. Case studies and simulations are used with emphasis on modern concepts of site selection and community development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Dimensions of Global Change
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the complexity of forces driving global change, with an emphasis on change related to population growth, technological development, and sociocultural and socioeconomic institutions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOG 221 and either GEOG 100 or 200.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Geography
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone Seminar in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: An integrative capstone seminar requiring geography majors to synthesize knowledge and skills acquired in prior geography courses. Students pursue independent projects in consultation with a faculty member and present their findings in written and oral reports. The course exposes students to and helps prepare them for a variety of professional and scholarly opportunities available after graduation.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Meets for two hours once a week. Required of and restricted to geography undergraduate majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual directed research and study of a topic in geography, normally as a preliminary to writing a senior honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, membership in the honors Program of the College of Arts and Sciences, and permission of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once to a total of 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of the United States
htmlparse.Course.description: A regional analysis of the United States with special attention to the historical, political, economic, and social factors which contribute to areal differentiation within the area.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary survey on the development of civilization in India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, and Afghanistan, including geography, philosophy, social, economic, political institutions, and historical movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three hours of social science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of South Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide a survey of the physical and human geography of South Asia. More specifically, it will cover the major environmental, economic, demographic, and cultural geography patterns, processes, and issues of the region. Problems related to religious, ethnic, and linguistic diversity, along with environmental problems associated with global climate change and others will be examined in the context of modernization and economic development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three hours of Social Science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: This will be a lecture type course and each relevant topic will be covered in some detail.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geographic Information Systems I
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the major theories, concepts, and operations in geographic information systems (GIS). Topics include: the structure of geographic data models, geographic data acquisition, spatial database management, data processing methods. Vector and raster GIS operations, and general approaches to GIS-based spatial modeling.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: The course will consist of two hours of lecture and two hours of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of the American West
htmlparse.Course.description: A broad survey of the geography of the American West with a focus on the distinctive human and environmental characteristics of the region. Historical, cultural, ethnic, resource, land use, and physical landscape patterns are examined through lectures, readings, videos, and discussions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A previous course in geography and sophomore standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Climatology
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of climatology on global, regional, and local scales, with emphasis on the physical processes and environmental factors that influence and control climate. Climatic change and its impact on human activities are explored.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Mountain Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: A broad survey of the human and physical geography of mountains. The course utilizes lectures, discussion, videos, and photographs to examine the human-environment interactions, cultural symbolism and sacredness, recreation and tourism, and sustainable development of mountain landscapes. The regional focus is primarily on the American West, but other mountains throughout the world will also be studied.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A previous course in geography and junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Mapping and Geographic Visualization
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic cartographic principles, advanced methods for representing spatial data, approaches for exploratory spatial data analysis, and practical applications of thematic maps, animated and Internet-based maps, and geographic visualization techniques. Students will prepare a series of maps and visualization products using modern geographic information system and illustration software.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The course will consist of two hours of lecture and two hours of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Remote Sensing of the Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Remote sensing and its application to earth study, especially environmental problems and land use. Course employs both readings and the use of imagery.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in physical science and one in biological science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, two hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geographic Information Systems II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced principles of and applications for geographic information systems (GIS). Examines the nature and accuracy of geo-referenced data and methods of data capture, storage, retrieval, modeling, and digital map display. Students will use modern GIS software packages and digital geographic data from physical and/or cultural sources to explore software procedures and techniques of spatial analysis, decision support, and geographic visualization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOG 302 and 508 (or consent of instructor).
htmlparse.Course.notes: The course will consist of two hours of lecture and two hours of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Faculty-supervised field experience, emphasizing the application of geographical topics and/or techniques. Student projects must be approved by both the on-site director and the faculty supervisor, and a report must be submitted at the end of the semester.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor and junior standing in geography is required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mexico, Central America, and Caribbean
htmlparse.Course.description: A broad survey of the physical and human geographic patterns of Middle America (Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean), past and present, with emphasis on the changing landscape features in the successive patterns of human occupancy and globalization.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of South America
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the physical and human patterns of South America, past and present, with emphasis on the changing landscape features in the successive patterns of human occupancy and globalization.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: People and their environment, their cultures, problems, and prospects in Europe west of the Soviet Union; trends of development as affected by changing political and economic factors.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of East Asia/China
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the human and physical geography of East Asia, with emphasis on China. Examines this region’s physical, cultural, and socioeconomic patterns and changes, as well as interactions with other parts of the world.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Regional Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar in Regional Geography
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Geography of the United States
htmlparse.Course.description: Interpretation and analysis of the American landscape and its regions from c. 1500 to c. 1950, with particular emphasis on landscape as both place and history. Also introduces and examines such current research topics as identity, contested places, landscape-as-text, and cultural politics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOG 100 and one course in American history.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Analysis in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Quantitative methods employed in modern geographical research. Applications of both statistical and mathematical approaches will be treated. Emphasis will be placed on interpretation and evaluation of techniques employed in spatial analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Qualitative and Mixed Methods Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Qualitative research techniques and integration of qualitative with basic statistical research techniques (mixed methods). Consideration of ethics, data collection, and data analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography Field Research Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores methods and techniques employed in modern field research. Stresses research design, field data acquisition techniques, and data analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and at least 6 hours in geography.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Remote Sensing
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of a selected remote sensing topic in an area of faculty specialization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internet GIS and Distributed Geographic Information Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduces the development and deployment of Internet maps and GIS-related web services. Students will use virtual globes and Internet map servers to learn the techniques of Internet mapping and development/delivery of geodata and geoprocessing services via the Web.  Studio-style classes will focus on building the necessary skills for creating, as well as the practical applications of, customized GIS map applications and “mashups”, web-based GIS services, and mobile GIS applications.

htmlparse.Course.title: World Population Patterns
htmlparse.Course.description: Geographical processes that govern population distributions, growth rates, and migrations. Emphasis on international comparisons and implications for world society of continued differential growth rates.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Public Lands
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of public lands systems, including distribution and uses of public lands, with an emphasis on United States federal lands. Historic and recent controversies regarding the public lands will be addressed. Seminar course with discussion and independent research components.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Land Use
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical factors affecting land use, scarcity, and management examined in a regional, national, and global context; land use classification system and variation of land use patterns.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Water Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: Interpretation and analysis of the physical geography of water and water as a resource. Evaluation of water, emphasizing quality, hazards, institutions, and selected domestic and global issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Climatology
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of a selected climatology topic in an area of faculty specialization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fluvial Geomorphology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is a basic introduction to the field of Fluvial Geomorphology, the study of the forms and processes found within streams and rivers. Topics will include: Review of watershed hydrology and hill slope processes, mechanics of open channel flow, sediment entrainment and transport, channel geometry, longitudinal profile and gradient, effective flows/formative events, channel patters, pool- and river management and restoration.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOG 221 or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The course meets for three hours of lecture per week with one required weekend field trip.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Biogeography
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of selected biogeography topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of geographic principles relating to the distribution, function, and structure of cities: a geographic analysis and classification of urban settlements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science or planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Impact on the Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Assessment of human impacts on the natural environment. Surveys changing human impacts on and attitudes towards the environment, and details alteration of water systems, the atmosphere, landforms, plants, and animals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geography of Natural Hazards
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines important emergency management issues related to hazard mitigation, preparedness, disaster response, and recovery, including sociocultural and physical components of disaster process. Assesses human vulnerability and risk to environmental calamities, such as droughts, floods, tornadoes, hurricanes, and earthquakes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Nine hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Perception of the Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the way people perceive their geographic environment and the role of perception in spatial behavior. Perceptions of neighborhoods, cities, states, nations, frontier regions, and environmental processes are explored.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science with one course above the introductory level, and 6 hours of natural science with one course above the introductory level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cultural Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the forms of human occupancy of landscapes, with consideration of innovations in the use of landscape, the origins and the dispersals of these innovations, and human attitudes toward the natural environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar in Geography
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Geographic Information Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected geographic information science topic in science topic in an area of faculty specialization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOG 302 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Earth in Action
htmlparse.Course.description: The earth’s physical, structural, and dynamic features; the most common minerals and rocks; processes affecting the earth.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Earth in Action-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: The earth’s physical, structural, and dynamic features; the most common minerals and rocks; processes affecting the earth.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geology Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in earth science chosen to illustrate current research of scientists and methods chosen to study the physical universe. At each offering of this course a syllabus will be available giving the topics to be studied and the details of administration of the course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once. Not open to geology majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Earth Through Time
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the immensity of geologic time and a review of the history of the earth and the life upon it.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Field and laboratory investigation of minerals, rocks, and fossils; use of maps; environmental studies, erosion, transportation, sedimentation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOL 100, 102, 105, or 125 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geology Laboratory-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Field and laboratory investigation of minerals, rocks, and fossils; use of maps; environmental studies, erosion, transportation, sedimentation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOL 100, 102, 105, or 125 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Oceanography
htmlparse.Course.description: The oceans: their boundaries, contents, and processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Geology, Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of earth materials, features, and processes. Higher level of sophistication and challenge than GEOL 100.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Major reservoirs of Earth and the hydrologic cycle; minerals and rocks on the surface and in subsurface environments; minerals and rock-water interactions; compositional variations of waters; surface and ground water pollutions; atmospheric pollutions; waste disposal problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Age of Dinosaurs
htmlparse.Course.description: Reconstructs the world of the dinosaurs, and places it in the context of Earth’s dynamic physical and biological history. The inferred biology and ecology of dinosaur species will be discussed, and the theories concerning their origin, evolution, and extinction will be presented.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Disasters
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of geological phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, landslides, and floods, with particular emphasis on their causes, effects, and significance as hazards.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Earth Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin and geologic settings of energy, water, and mineral resources. Additional emphasis will be placed upon exploration and development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar discussion of subjects of current interest in geology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A course in natural science at the 100 level or higher.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Honors Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed research and preparation of an honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to seniors in the arts and sciences honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent reading; field or laboratory investigations, or both, of geologic problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mineralogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Crystallography; physical and chemical properties of minerals; emphasis on mineral identification through laboratory analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOL 100 and GEOL 103; CHM 110 and CHM 111 or CHM 210.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Petrology
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of physical and chemical processes forming ingeneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks. Mircroscopic examination of rock mineralogy and textures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical and chemical qualities of natural environments and health from a geologic perspective-detection and prediction of environmental changes, identification of sources of pollutants and their movements in soils, rocks, and waters.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Geology of Planets
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin, evolution, and surficial geology of the extraterrestrial planets and satellites.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Earth Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical study of the atmosphere, weather, climate, composition, and processes of the earth; also, the interaction of these in producing the pattern of landforms and human activity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GEOL 100 or GEOG 221 or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geology of the National Parks
htmlparse.Course.description: Stratigraphy, structure, and geological history that produced the scenery of the national parks. Selected national monuments also will be studied.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geomorphology
htmlparse.Course.description: Classroom, laboratory, and field studies of landforms and surficial deposits, with an emphasis on earth-surface processes. Classroom lectures and discussions; laboratory exercises; and field investigations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Mechanics of the earth’s crust; origin and interrelation of structures of the earth.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ice Ages and Environmental Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of the recent geologic past, especially of the last major ice age to the present. Causes of glaciation and climactic change, ways of reconstructing past geologic environmental and geologic environmental changes during the time when human civilization developed, including recent historic time.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to methods used to collect geologic data in the field. Emphasis is placed on map-reading, rock description, use of aerial photographs, and construction of geologic maps and cross sections.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Invertebrate Fossils
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematics, biology, ecology, and preservational environment of ancient life, with emphasis on marine invertebrates and calcareous algae.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab/lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed research and preparation of a senior thesis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once to a maximum of 3 hours credit. Open only to seniors in geology or geophysics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mineral Exploration
htmlparse.Course.description: Geological, geochemical, and geophysical prospecting techniques and their application in the exploration for metallic mineral deposits.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Geochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the use of inorganic geochemistry in the investigation of geologic processes in the crust, mantle, and surface environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hydrogeology
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin, geologic occurrence, and migration of subsurface water; laws governing ground water flow and yield of acquifers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Volcanology
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines processes associated with active volcanoes as revealed by volcanic deposits. Emphasis on influence of volcanoes on human civilizations including economic deposits, climate change, or volcano monitoring.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stratigraphy-Sedimentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Description, classification, correlation, chronology, and paleogeography of sedimentary rock systems and the depositional environments in which they formed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Geophysics
htmlparse.Course.description: Acquisition and computer processing of geophysical data such as those from seismic reflection, seismic refraction, gravity, magnetic and electrical methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Field projects in the Rocky Mountains designed to give students practical experience in apply geologic knowledge and skills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three six-day weeks in the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Geology and origin of metallic mineral deposits and of some nonmetallic deposits.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic Geology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory activities related to metallic and nonmetallic mineral deposits, including detailed studies of selected deposits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Paleoenvironments
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of biological, physical, and chemical factors in modern marine environments to the understanding of ancient marine environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biomineralization
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and critique of current and classic research in biomineralization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sedimentary Geochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Geochemical principles and processes in deposition and diagenesis of sediments; different chemical pathways in the exogenic cycle.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Resources Geochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Geochemistry of ground and surface waters; emphasis on mineralogical, biochemical, and hydrologic controls on inorganic and organic interactions in natural waters.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Geochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of chemical principles to igneous, metamorphic systems; emphasis on equilibria, oxidation-reduction, crystal chemistry, and thermodynamics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rock Microstructures and Geologic Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of mineral shapes, orientations and assemblages (rock fabric) as a record of geologic processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hour lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dating Earth Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Discusses how ages are measured for rocks, minerals, waters, and sediments by analysis of isotopes produced by radioactive decay or cosmic rays.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quaternary Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Quaternary stratigraphy as the framework for studying the geomorphic, climactic, archaeological, and biological changes of the last two million years, with emphasis on the North American record.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week and one field trip a semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Petroleum Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin, migration, and accumulation of petroleum; stratigraphy and structure of important fields.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Regional Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Interpretations of structural, stratigraphic, igneous, and tectonic history of selected sites in North America.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Geophysics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to geophysics, its uses in studies of the earth’s interior, its utility of illuminating subsurface geological features, and its applications in fields such as groundwater studies and the development of energy resources.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation, and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exploration Geophysics
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and applications of seismic, gravity, magnetic, and other geophysical methods used in energy, mining, and other industries to locate subsurface targets of interest.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computational Geophysics
htmlparse.Course.description: Computer skills and techniques used in geophysical data processing and analysis such as linear and nonlinear inversion, forward modeling of gravity, magnetic, and seismic data, seismic tomography, seismic anisotropy, and seismic wave attenuation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geologic Evolution of Planet Earth
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of the various geologic disciplines into a broad-based understanding of the history and dynamics of the earth. Specific regions, such as the western U.S., will be selected each year for detailed study. Guest lectures will make up a significant part of the course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of, or concurrent enrollment in, all other courses required for the BS or BA degree in geology (except summer field courses).
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Subsurface Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and applications of subsurface geology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Work is offered in mineralogy, paleobiology, paleoecology, stratigraphy, structural geology, igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary petrology, geomorphology, planetary geology, hydrogeology, geochemistry, and isotope geology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for problem undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Multidisciplinary introduction to the field of aging. Examines social, psychological, developmental, organizational, and economic aspects of aging. Theoretical, methodological, and applied issues of aging related to contemporary American society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Culture Change in Long-Term Care
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will cover the basic characteristics of traditional and culture change nursing home models. Student will learn about the various processes of organizational change, the steps toward change, and potential regulatory, environmental and social barriers to major change. The course will include discussions about the necessity to change the way care is provided in such areas as dining, bathing, family/relationships, and environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This overview is recommended as the first course for students unfamiliar with culture change and is delivered on-line.

htmlparse.Course.title: Measuring Change in Long-Term Care
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics covered will include process and outcome measures in nursing home change as well as the importance of and the utility of measurement for the advancement of quality of life issues in long-term care. Students will gain an understanding of how regulatory support will be more likely to occur if culture change features can show a cost savings as well as improvements in the quality of life of residents.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This on-line course should be taken after or concurrently with GERON 501.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creating Home in Long-Term Care
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will gain a better understanding of the interdependent networks within nursing homes, environmental factors in the development of community and culture in a nursing home, learn how fostering resident, family and staff interactions can improve quality of life for all those groups, understand the role of structural redesign and innovation, and consider how environmental change can improve relationships within the larger community.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This on-line course should be taken after or concurrently with GERON 501.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strengthening Staff in Long-Term Care
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics covered will include the development of deeper relational bonds within the nursing home environment, benefits of permanent staffing as a key component of building a relationship centered culture, how these types of changes can benefit and empower staff, and models for bridging cultural divides between long-term care administrators and staff to benefit the residents. A review of the impact of traditional models of managed care that focus on providing food, shelter, and medical attention and factors that hinder purposeful, proactive interactions between residents, families and staff.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This on-line course should be taken after or concurrently with GERON 501.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dining in Long-Term Care
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will develop an appreciation of the impact dining has on the quality of social, physical and emotional health and quality of life of nursing home residents, become aware of the meanings/customs that residents may associate with the dining experience, recognize the importance of the dining experience in the overall culture of the home and develop an understanding of various institutional dining styles.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This on-line course should be taken after or concurrently with GERON 501.

htmlparse.Course.title: Activities in Long-Term Care
htmlparse.Course.description: A review of common activities in long-term care, their importance in resident care, the importance of meaningful activity and relationships, how the long-term care culture impacts resident individuality/choice, and individualized care plans.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This on-line course should be taken after or concurrently with GERON 501.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary course organized topically, with students presenting papers on aging-related issues that draw upon the students’ previous and concurrent academic experience. Provides supervised independent study and subsequent discussion, allowing students to integrate and order their perceptions about gerontological issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of 15 hours of course work in gerontology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an aging-related setting as a practical application of gerontological knowledge and skills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Long-Term Care Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Administration principles involved in the planning, organizing, and directing of long-term care agencies. Includes in-depth exposure to federal and state standards and regulations governing long-term care.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: January Intersession, Fall of odd numbered years
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Long-Term Care Administration Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Includes: (a) field experience in the general administration of long-term care programs and/or facilities; planning, budgeting, program management, and service delivery; (b) exposure to federal and state standards and regulations governing long-term care; and (c); professional leadership development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing, GERON 315, MANGT 420, ACCTG 231, GERON 610, six hours of electives from approved list, GPA of 2.5 or above (3.0 or above in long-term care administration coursework).

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of selected problems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses required for problem undertaken and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mental Health & Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the issues involved in aging and mental health using a systems framework covering the major emotional and psychiatric problems encountered in old age. Includes discussion of personality disorders, dementia, cognitive problems, substance abuse, suicide and barriers to treatment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gerontechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the understanding of the biological, environmental, and social spheres where technology and gerontology meet.  Topics include the interrelationship between population dynamics and technological change, technological research and devices that may improve elders’ lives, particular issues for rural communities, and the social and cultural meanings, challenges, and benefits of gerontechnologies.  Particular emphasis will be given to placing both population aging and technological change in a broader social perspective.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Social Sciences Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Creativity and Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: What happens to creativity as a person ages?  This unique class will help students to understand developmental and pathological changes in the brain that can lead to changes in creative output over time.  Through hands-on experiences and direct association with older adults, students will grow an appreciation for creativity produced and inspired by older people.  This course is intended to provide experiences that will help the student to create art programs for older adults.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics of Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of recent research and theory related to specialized issues in gerontology or long-term care.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated more than one semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Perspectives in Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of basic concepts in gerontology through current and classic research. Themes and issues include stereotypes and myths of aging, theories of aging, research approaches in aging, and related social issues facing the elderly.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Evaluation and Research Methods in Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of program evaluation, research methods, and grant writing in gerontology. Includes application of quantitative and qualitative methods in professional settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Policy: Economic and Social Impacts on Older Adults
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of policy development and public policy programs associated with aging. Attention is given to the impact of policies on older adults and economic impacts of and for an aging population.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aging and the Family
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigates the issues that relate to family life in the later years from the perspective of older adults, the family and society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Seminar in Gerontology
htmlparse.Course.description: Students apply and integrate knowledge gained in earlier courses and strengthen skills in ethical decisions-making through applications in gerontology-related areas such as advocacy, professionalism, family and workplace issues. Students from a variety of professions bring their unique perspective to bear on topics of common interest.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Ecology Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: Special topics for human ecology majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Human Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Human ecological theory, disciplines and professions represented in the College of Human Ecology, the history of human ecology and family and consumer sciences, career paths, and contemporary issues in the field. Learning activities include case studies; critical thinking and evaluation; analysis of history, trends and issues; and career planning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Suggested enrollment during first year in General Human Ecology or other Human Ecology degree program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Needs
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of theories of human needs from a human ecological perspective, with emphasis on the impact of human, economic, and material resources. Analysis of developmental, ethical, cultural, and public policy factors that influence need satisfaction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in General Human Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Human Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Transition from a baccalaureate degree program to career paths in human ecology professions. Topics include analysis based on human ecological theory; analysis of trends and issues in human ecology disciplines and professions; the demography of career paths in human ecology professions, and development of a professional portfolio and web site.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in General Human Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation into work in general human ecology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Adult TESL: Oral Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods and techniques for teaching oral communication (listening comprehension, speaking, and pronunciation) provide a foundation for planning and teaching activities. Students demonstrate ability to communicate content to students at varying levels of English proficiency, control of basic classroom management techniques, and use of a variety of techniques to assess student performance in their practice teaching. Small group discussions and ESL class observations aid students in the development of a teaching portfolio.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Adult TESL: Written Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods and techniques for teaching written communication (reading, vocabulary development, grammar, and writing) provide a foundation for planning and teaching activities. Students demonstrate ability to communicate content to students at varying levels of English proficiency, control of basic classroom management techniques, and use of a variety of techniques to assess student performance in their practice teaching. Small group discussions and ESL class observations aid students in the development of a teaching portfolio.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water and Society: Interdisciplinary Foundation
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary course focused on the natural and human elements of water resource systems; introduction to traditional disciplinary procedures, theory, and models; cross-disciplinary approaches to understand and quantify dynamic system relationships; case study for integrated problem solving, management and policy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation for Summer School Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Orientation for Summer School Program

htmlparse.Course.title: German I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of modern German. Practice of the spoken language with additional experience in the language lab.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: German II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation to the introduction of modern German. Practice of the spoken language, additional experience in reading and with a variety of additional media.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: German III
htmlparse.Course.description: Conclusion of the introduction to modern German. Continued practice of the spoken language, reading, and additional experience with a range of audio and visual media.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary German Conversation
htmlparse.Course.description: Practice in beginning conversational German and review of grammar.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Courses not open to fluent speakers of German. Course normally taken concurrently with German III or IV.

htmlparse.Course.title: German IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of select points of German language structure accompanied by practice in conversation, speaking, reading, and writing, as well as additional experience with audio and visual media.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Studies in German
htmlparse.Course.description: Offered only to participants in study abroad programs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: At the discretion of the department, the course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours. Prior consultation for approval is expected.

htmlparse.Course.title: German Literature in Translation
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected readings in English from such major German authors as Mann, Brecht, Hesse, Grass, and Kafka.

htmlparse.Course.title: German Film
htmlparse.Course.description: In English. Addresses various topics within a German historical-cultural context. Students will consider what makes cinema a distinct form of artistic expression.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for major credit if assignments and discussion are completed in German. Normally taken concurrently with German IV.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in German Cultural Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: In English. Specific course content will vary by semester and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
May be taken for German major credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in German
htmlparse.Course.description: Practice in reading a variety of literary, journalistic, and specialized texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Topics in German Literature and Culture of the 18th and 19th century
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses constitute a sequence of introductory period studies covering the chronological range of German literature from about 1750 to the present. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Topics in German Literature and Culture of the 20th and 21st century
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses constitute a sequence of introductory period studies covering the chronological range of German literature from about 1750 to the present. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: German Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: Course emphasizes writing and includes select grammar review.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course not open to students whose competence has been demonstrated in the language at this level.

htmlparse.Course.title: German for Reading Knowledge I
htmlparse.Course.description: The grammar and syntax of German and the reading of basic material selected from modern German texts. (This course is designed for students who need to be able to read German.).

htmlparse.Course.title: German for Reading Knowledge II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued reading of material from modern German texts. (This course is designed for students who need to be able to read German.).

htmlparse.Course.title: Business German
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced grammar necessary for adequate oral and written expression in international business and diplomatic situations, including specialized terminology, conversation and discussion and translation. Cultural aspects of business are also considered.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced German Conversation
htmlparse.Course.description: Course emphasizes proficiency in oral expression and includes select grammar review. Course not open to students whose competency has been demonstrated in the language at this level.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Topics in German Language and Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to topics in German Linguistics, with special emphasis on the connection between language structure and use or language structures and learning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: GRMN 223.
Other requirements: GRMN 523 or 527 or 526 should be taken before GRMN 528 or concurrently with GRMN 528.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with a change of subject matter.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in German
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in German
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head and instructor involved.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: German Cultural Studies and History
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses cultural and historical topics not confined to a single period. Specific course content will vary by semester and instructor. It may emphasize cross-national subjects, the development of a theme or discourse over time, new perspectives from social, intellectual, or cultural studies, or non-traditional texts and topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior or concurrent 500-level German language class or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Each semester’s offerings will be described more specifically in university and department publications before each enrollment period.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Medieval German Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. These courses constitute a sequence of period studies covering the chronological ranges of German speaking literature and culture. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Eighteenth Century German Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. These courses constitute a sequence of period studies covering the chronological ranges of German speaking literature and culture. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Nineteenth Century German Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. These courses constitute a sequence of period studies covering the chronological ranges of German speaking literature and culture. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Early Twentieth Century German Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. These courses constitute a sequence of period studies covering the chronological ranges of German speaking literature and culture. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in German Literature and Culture since 1945
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. These courses constitute a sequence of period studies covering the chronological ranges of German speaking literature and culture. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Twentieth and Twenty-First Century German Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. These courses constitute a sequence of period studies covering the chronological ranges of German speaking literature and culture. Within these historical periods, the specific course contents will vary by semester and instructor. They may emphasize literary figures and movements, historical and cultural contexts, or different genres and forms within the period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Each semester’s offerings will be specifically described before each enrollment period in university and department publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Open Topics Seminar in German Language and Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses topics in German Linguistics. It may emphasize a specific area of linguistics, a specific research approach, or the connection between language and society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: At least one GRMN 500-level course preferably GRMN 528.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable with change of subject matter.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the German Language
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the development of the sounds, forms and syntax of standard German.

htmlparse.Course.title: Open Topics Seminar in German Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Open Topics courses are designed for undergraduates and graduate students. Course addresses topics not confined to a single period in a national literature. Specific course content will vary by semester and instructor. It my emphasize cross-national subjects, literary or cultural criticism or theory, works of one or a pair of related authors, the development of a theme or genre over time, new perspectives from social, intellectual, or cultural studies, or non-traditional texts and topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One prior 500-level German literature course.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated with change of subject matter.
Each semester’s offerings will be described more specifically in university and department publications before each enrollment period.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced German: Speaking and Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Course combines practice in speaking, writing, and reading, and select advanced grammar review.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRMN 523 and GRMN 527 or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Course not open to students whose competence has been demonstrated in the language at this level.

htmlparse.Course.title: German Culture and Literature in Second-Language Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and interpretation of cultural and literary text from German-speaking countries, with emphasis on the development of interpretive skills and materials, and their application to the German curriculum at all levels.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once with a change in focus and texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain Science & Industry Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the grain science & industry programs, activities, resources, faculty and career opportunities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Required of all freshmen in grain science & industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Grain Science and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an introductory course to grains and their processing/utilization in food and non-food products, as well as exposure to career opportunities in grain and related industries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grain science student or freshman/sophomore standing or instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Milling
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to grain and feed milling processes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: MATH 100 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Milling Laboratory
