htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Principles of Milling (GRSC 150). Laboratory exercises in grain and feed milling processes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRSC 150 or concurrent enrollment. BSM, FSM and MSM majors have to take GRSC 150 and GRSC 151 concurrently.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamental Baking Calculations
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the type of mathematical calculations used in the baking industry. It will cover ratio and proportion, true percent, baker’s percent, how to convert a straight dough to a sponge and dough, proper water temperature calculations, specific gravity as it applies to cake making, density, specific volume as it applies to bread making, flour blending calculations in order to achieve a specific flour protein content, flour calculations for proper baking performance and purchasing, major ingredient substitutions, pie filling calculations, parts per million calculations, and baking powder neutralization values.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: This class has no prerequisites, and can be taken by an incoming freshman.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course will be offered as a 20-module distance education course.

htmlparse.Course.title: CAD Flow Sheets for Grain Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to teach students the basic concepts of professional 2D drawing designs and drafting using AutoCAD. By the end of the semester, the students will be able to use AutoCAD for preparing process flow drawings and interpret a grain processing flow.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRSC 150 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two three-hour lecture/demonstrations/studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Materials Handling
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to introduce students to how materials including grains, ingredients, mixes and finished products are physically moved and handled in the receiving, storage, formulation, production and shipping of grain related products.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 101, GRSC 150 and GRSC 210.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three one-hour lecture/demonstration per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain Analysis Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and instrumentation available for testing cereal and other grains and their food and feed products.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: CHEM 230, BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and 351, and STAT 325.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Research in Grain Science
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an opportunity to earn college credit while conducting an independent research project. The overall objective of the course is to introduce students to scientific research methods and procedures in grain science and related areas through hands-on experience and individual mentoring.  Students will learn how to design, conduct, analyze, and present scientific research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Sophomore, junior or senior standing in BSM, FSM, or MSM; minimum GPA of 2.5/4.00.
A GSI faculty must agree to serve as research advisor/mentor prior to enrollment. A list of participating faculty and project areas will be available.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Variable credit. Students are expected to invest at least 3 hours of effort per week for every hour of credit enrolled.

htmlparse.Course.title: Milling Science I
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of wheat flour milling with full-scale equipment including grain storage, blending, cleaning, conditioning plant, and a modern pneumatic flour mill, with instrumentation and automation, etc.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: A course in physics. Prerequisite: GRSC 150 and GRSC 210, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Milling Science I Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Milling Science I (GRSC 500). Laboratory exercises in wheat flour milling with full-scale equipment including grain storage, blending, cleaning, conditioning plant, and a modern pneumatic flour mill, with instrumentation and automation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: GRSC 500 or concurrent enrollment.
MSM majors have to take GRSC 500 and GRSC 501 concurrently.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Milling Science II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the entire gradual reduction system of wheat flour milling and the many unit process systems that constitute the milling system. The theory and practice of mill control are studied in detail. Processing of other cereal grains and oil seeds are covered as well as general mill management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: GRSC 210 and 500 and 501, or consent of instructor.
Recommended prerequisite: STAT 325 and PHYS 113 and MATH 205.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two one-hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Milling Science II Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: The processes for milling other grains such as corn, oats, sorghum, different classes of wheat, and rye are studied in the laboratory and by practice on small scale milling units. Concepts of material handling properties of grain products and material handling equipment in dry milling operations will be presented. Concepts of statistical process control and spread sheet modeling in the decision making process will be introduced.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRSC 502 or concurrent enrollment or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Feed Technology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to formula feed manufacturing, including principles of conveying, grinding, mixing, pelleting, and other processing techniques, the formulation of concentrates, premixes, and rations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Feed Technology I Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Feed Technology I (GRSC 510). Laboratory exercises in formula feed manufacturing, principles of conveying, grinding, mixing, pelleting, and other processing techniques; formulation of concentrates, premixes, and rations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: GRSC 510 or concurrent enrollment.
FSM majors have to take GRSC 510 and GRSC 511 concurrently.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Applications to Grain/Food Products
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of grain/food industry analytical processing concepts including mass and energy balances, fluid flow, heat transfer, dehydration, evaporation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 205 or 220. Recommended prerequisite: PHYS 113 or 115, CHM 210.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Applications to Grain/Food Products Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory experiments supplementing GRSC 540-Engineering Applications to Grain/Food Products.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One-three hour lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain Drying, Storage, Aeration and Pest Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the scientific principles and engineering practices required for the successful management of post-harvest quality grains.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
This course is not available to on-camus students.
This course is offered as a distance education course only, and it is only available to distance education students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electricity and Its Control for the Grain Processing Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Major emphasis will be given to application of electricity to machinery for grain processing and electrical code.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRSC 500 or 510 or 635, and PHYS 114 or 214, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Flow Sheets
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of flow diagrams for dry milling processes. Uses a combination of methods that lead to practical applications and analytical techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRSC 210 and 500, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Milling Processing Technology Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone course for milling science and management students. The objective is to familiarize students with the latest technology utilized in cereal milling systems; the investment/business principles utilized in evaluating new milling technologies; mill management/leadership development and the food/employee safety requirements in the industry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GRSC 502 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain Science Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Study in an area pertinent to grain processing and utilization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For undergraduate students. Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial Feed and Food Manufacturing Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: A practical application of feed and food manufacturing technology during an eight-week summer internship with an active commercial feed and food manufacturing company. The course will stress applied aspects of commercial feed and food manufacturing, which can include, but not be limited to, plant operations, maintenance, personnel and labor relations, business management, warehousing, ingredient procurement, quality assurance, and fleet management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Bakery Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and hands-on laboratory experience with commercial production scale baking equipment for breads and rolls, cookies and crackers, and cakes and sweet doughs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Upper-class bakery science and management majors or permission of the instructor. Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 635 and 636.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: One week intensive course during the January intersession.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cereal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: The characteristics of cereals, legumes, their components and their processing to foods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and 351.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Extrusion Processing in the Food and Feed Industries
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to provide the student with an understanding of extrusion technology and the ability to apply it to product development and production through a “hands-on” approach. Major emphasis is on laboratory exercises in which students will operate pilot scale extrusion equipment to produce readily-recognizable commercial products such as cheese curls, breakfast cereals, pasta, pet food, etc.  Emphasis will also be placed on process and product development, analysis, and problem solving techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture plus one three-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Flour and Dough Testing
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical and chemical methods used in evaluating wheat flour and doughs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two one-hour lectures and one three-hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management Applications in the Grain Processing Industries
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with management principles and their specific application to the processing industries. Industry and allied trade personnel in management positions will give a number of lectures in their field of expertise. Special emphasis is placed on grain industry organizations, labor contracts, supervision, scheduling and planning, regulatory agencies and cost control.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended prerequisite: ECON 110; GRSC 510, 500, or 635.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week

htmlparse.Course.title: Baking Science I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to chemical and physical properties of flour and other principal ingredients used in production of yeast-leavened bakery foods. Study of major processing methods for making yeasted doughs such as breads, sweet goods, frozen dough, and partially baked goods. Examination of ingredient specifications role of quality control, keeping properties of bread products, and nutritional attributes of various types of breads.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and 351.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Baking Science I Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Baking Science I (GRSC 635).  Laboratory exercises in theory and production of yeast-leavened baked products.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 635 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Baking Science II
htmlparse.Course.description: Course includes study of physical, chemical, and functional properties of ingredients and processes used in production of bakery products, including cakes, cookies, doughnuts, breads and related products. Shelf-life control and packaging of baked products is also discussed. Total quality programs, specification programs and management of distribution and purchasing systems will also be included in lectures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Baking Science II Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Baking Science II (GRSC 637). Exercises and experiments in production of chemically-leavened and yeast-leavened bakery foods including various cakes, cookies, doughnuts, bagels, icings, and fillings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 637 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pet Food Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to provide students with an understanding of pet foods, including food products meant for dogs, cats, pet rodents, pet snakes, ornamental fish, exotic and captive wild animals, and the various processing technologies that are deployed for their production. Extrusion, baking, canning, and injection molding technologies will be covered. Other important aspects of pet food production, such as ingredient handling and compounding, quality control, HACCP and sanitation, and packaging will also be discussed. A concurrent laboratory section will allow students to produce pet foods, visit pet food production facilities, and personally explore selected topics in depth.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: CHM 230, PHYS 114, ASI 318 or HN 132, Junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three one-hour lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pet Food Processing Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Pet Food Processing (GRSC 645). The laboratory course is intended to reinforce the theory and concepts with actual experience producing a variety of pet foods. Students will gain first-hand knowledge of ingredient selection and handling and produce foods by a variety of processes, including extrusion, baking, canning, and injection molding.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 645 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food and Feed Product Protection
htmlparse.Course.description: Sanitation in relation to processing, handling, and storage of human and animal foods. Emphasis on contaminants, control of causative agents, equipment and plant design, applicable laws and regulations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: Junior standing.
Recommended prerequisite: BIOL 198, BIOL 455.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cereal Food Plant Design and Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with principles of modern grain processing plant design, feasibility and equipment selection for plant improvements and new plant construction. Emphasis is placed on the effects of design on plant operating efficiency, finished product quality, and construction costs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 500 or 510.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three-one hour lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pneumatic Conveying of Dry Solids
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to introduce students to a comprehensive knowledge of the design, operation and capabilities of pneumatic conveying systems for transportation of dry, powdered and granular materials. The student will study the components of pneumatic conveying systems, the requirements for designing efficient and reliable pneumatic conveying systems, and troubleshooting existing systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing, GRSC 210, GRSC 310, GRSC 500 and 501, PHYS 113 or 213, MATH 205 or 220, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Qualities of Feed Ingredients
htmlparse.Course.description: The course provides an integrated overview of the physical, biological, chemical characteristics of common feed ingredients. Quality control and evaluation of ingredients and complete feed is emphasized to ensure the productions of safe feed/safe food.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 510 and 511, BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and 351.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bakery Layout
htmlparse.Course.description: The layouts of facilities to produce baked goods are studied. Students prepare their own bakery layout. Current problems in a bakery production setting in the baking industry are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100, PHYS 113, GRSC 210, and GRSC 636.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One two-hour lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Feed Technology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of engineering principles applicable to flour and feed plant operations, equipment selection, and processing systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: GRSC 510 and GRSC 511 or GRSC 500, PHYS 114 or 214, and STAT 325.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Feed Technology II Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to accompany Feed Technology II (GRSC 688). Laboratory exercises and advanced studies on engineering principles applicable to flour and feed plant operations, equipment selection, and processing systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
GRSC 688 or concurrent enrollment.
FSM majors have to take GRSC 688 and GRSC 689 concurrently.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Faculty-Led Study Abroad
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar and travel course designed to prepare students before the experience and for students to analyze, critique, and report their experiences of an international experience associated with study tours or short courses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor for undergraduates, consent of major professor for graduate students

htmlparse.Course.title: Vibrational Spectroscopic Analysis and Chemometrics
htmlparse.Course.description: Infrared and particularly modern near-infrared spectroscopic analysis of foods, natural products, and synthetic substances is accomplished with direct sampling and the use of multivariate statistics. This course is intended to enable the student to understand the principles and successfully apply this technology to practical analytical problems with emphasis upon food. Method development will be taught using specific analytes in selected products. Theoretical background, working of modern instrumentation and associated software is presented in support of achieving practical competence.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and CHM 351 or CHM 371.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Chromatographic Analysis of Food
htmlparse.Course.description: High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is the primary focus of this course. This will be supported by including treatment of topics in contemporary gas chromatography and supercritical fluid chromatography and extraction. Optimizing chromatographic conditions through knowledge of the column chemistry will be covered in addition to detector options, instrumentation, and sample preparation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and CHM 351 or CHM 371.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biomaterials Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed for students who are interested in plant biomaterials processing. This course will teach technologies of biobased materials processing including starch extraction (wet milling), plant oil extraction and refining, plant protein extraction and processing, cellulose processing, biofuel production, chemicals bioconversion, and drying technologies of biomaterials.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Bioprocessing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed for students who desire a clear understanding of bioprocessing principles as applied to the emerging bio-based industry. This course covers the fundamentals of mass and energy balances, fluid dynamics, heat and mass transfer, as applied to bioprocessing. The microbial growth, kinetics and fermenter operation will be covered in detail. Fundamentals of downstream operation as applicable to bioprocessing will be covered in this course. Industrial bioprocessing case studies that involve the integration of the course contents will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: MATH 205 or 220, PHYS 113 or 115, and BIOCH 265 or CHM 350 and 351 or CHM 210.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grain Science Problem
htmlparse.Course.description: Graduate study in an area pertinent to grain processing and utilization.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
For graduate students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of modern Hindi. Listening, speaking, reading, and writing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Hindi I, completion of the basic structural and linguistic principles of Hindi.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Hindi II. Listening, speaking, reading, and writing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Hindi III. Listening, speaking, reading and writing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to History
htmlparse.Course.description: What history is, how it is produced, and what its functions are. Designed for freshmen who want an introductory course which explains the methodology, purposes, and career options of the discipline.

htmlparse.Course.title: Western Civilization: The Rise of Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: Major trends in Western history from the beginnings of European civilization to the end of the seventeenth century. The scope of this course includes classical antiquity, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, the Reformation, and early modern Europe, but chronological and topical emphases vary with individual sections.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Not open to juniors and seniors except with consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all majors in history.

htmlparse.Course.title: Western Civilization: The Modern Era
htmlparse.Course.description: Principal developments in Western civilization from the beginning of the eighteenth century to the present. The scope of the course includes the Enlightenment, the French Revolution, the Industrial Revolution, nationalism, imperialism, communism, fascism, and the two world wars, but chronological and topical emphases vary with individual sections.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Not open to juniors and seniors except with consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all history majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Overseas European Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected aspects of European history and culture with readings, lectures, and discussions which will relate historical events to places visited.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Western Civilization: The Rise of Europe (Honors)
htmlparse.Course.description: Major trends in Western history from the beginnings of European civilization to the end of the seventeenth century. The scope of this course includes classical antiquity, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, the Reformation, and early modern Europe, but chronological and topical emphases vary with individual sections.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Not open to juniors and seniors except with consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all majors in history.

htmlparse.Course.title: Western Civilization: The Modern Era (Honors)
htmlparse.Course.description: Principal developments in Western civilization from the beginning of the eighteenth century to the present. The scope of the course includes the Enlightenment, the French Revolution, the Industrial Revolution, nationalism, imperialism, communism, fascism, and the two world wars, but chronological and topical emphases vary with individual sections.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Not open to juniors and seniors except with consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all history majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: World History to 1450
htmlparse.Course.description: Major developments in the history of the world from the earliest civilizations to the eve of European expansion in the fifteenth century. Comparison of key trends and conditions in different parts of the world. Topics include the agricultural revolution, the birth of the city, the formation of states and empires, and the emergence of world religions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: World History From 1450
htmlparse.Course.description: Major trends in the history of the world from the 15th century to the present. Global patterns of contact, mutual influence, and interdependence.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in History for Freshmen and Sophomores
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of the historical dimensions of a particular topic or theme.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once. Topics vary.

htmlparse.Course.title: Western Warfare Since 1618
htmlparse.Course.description: Introductory survey that uses a ”battles and leaders” component as a starting point to engender a deeper understanding of the development of Western military practices and institutions as well as greater insight into the evolution of Western society and the nation-state in modern times.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian Culture and Civilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Russia’s past and present in the light of principle ideologies with emphasis upon fine arts, literature, music, religion, politics, and education. Equal time will be given to the Tsarist and the Soviet periods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Knowledge of Russian language is not required.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the United States to 1877
htmlparse.Course.description: Includes ethnic, social, military, political, economic, diplomatic, and ideological themes. The chronological emphasis varies with instructor. The aim of the course is to achieve a broad understanding of American civilization to 1877.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the United States Since 1877
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethnic, social, political, economic, and diplomatic history. The goal of the course is to achieve a broad understanding of American civilization since 1877.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities I
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of selected major works of history, literature, and philosophy which have been of central importance in the Western cultural tradition. Considerable emphasis is placed on classroom discussion and writing interpretive essays.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Limited to entering freshmen students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of HIST 297.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HIST 297 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Historical Thinking
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduces the history major to the major principles of historical thinking as well as providing an introduction to the methodologies of historical research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin American History and Civilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduces the history of Latin America from the earliest times to the present. Argentina, Brazil, Cuba, Mexico, and Peru will receive special attention. Themes treated will include race and ethnicity, cultural survival, revolution and authoritarianism, women and family, and the role of economic development in Latin American history.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Technology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the development of technology from ancient times to modern day, with emphasis on technology and its impact on American society from colonial times to present. Students will prepare a portfolio project that will feature a research or service learning component.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of East Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: East Asian history from earliest times to the present. Social structures, beliefs, and values during key periods of Chinese and Japanese history. Major developments in religion, philosophy, literature, and the arts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Japan
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical survey of Japan from prehistoric times to the present day, which may include material on society, politics, and culture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to China
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of the history, geography, politics, and culture of China from prehistoric times to the present day.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in History
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in history.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Membership in honors program or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Senior Thesis

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Japan’s Samurai Age
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of Japan from earliest times to the fall of the Tokugawa shogunate in 1868, including major developments in political institutions, social structures, and religious beliefs. Examines the rise and development of the warrior class that dominated society and government for much of this period.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Off-Campus American Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Short-term, intensive, and in-depth study of selected topics in American history that will supplement readings, lectures, discussions and other traditional classroom assignments with on-location activities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Study in International Setting
htmlparse.Course.description: Course work that enhances the experience of international travel and study. Requires an historical engagement with the travel experience through readings, lectures, discussion, and written work.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Intellectual History of Early China
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the development of Chinese thought during the period from about 1200 BC to 100 BC, with emphasis on the foundational ideas of Confucianism, Daoism, and Legalism and their incorporation within the emerging imperial order.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary survey of the development of civilization in India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, and Afghanistan, including geography, philosophy, social, economic, political institutions, and historical movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Three hours of social science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern India and South Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh since 1500, beginning with Mogul rule and continuing through European colonialism, the anti-imperial struggle, and the troubled transition to independence.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: China Since 1644
htmlparse.Course.description: China from the founding of the Manchu Qing dynasty to the present. Includes the western imperialist challenge in the nineteenth century, the Revolution of 1949, and the post-Mao Reforms. Emphasis on social, political and intellectual changes in the context of increasing contact with western nations and Japan.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Modern East Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of China, Japan, and surrounding countries including the arrival of Europeans in the sixteenth century, reactions to Western imperialism, the rise of nationalism, and revolution. The impact of the two world wars, the era of post war developments, communism in China, democracy in Japan, and the end of Western colonialism are also examined.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japan Since 1550
htmlparse.Course.description: Japan from reunification in the sixteenth century through the Tokugawa and Imperial eras to the postwar recovery. Emphasis on understanding modern Japan as the product of traditional culture, the Meiji Restoration, and World War II.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: World War I
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the origins, events and consequences of the “war to end all wars.” The impact and influence of the war on colonialism, imperialism, and popular culture will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental History
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to environmental history as an academic specialization through selected reading and topical lectures. The course emphasizes the study of people in nature through time; it stresses people’s response to environmental change through three broadly defined periods: pre-industrial, modern industrial, and contemporary.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in European History
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of women in primitive European societies, in preindustrial times, and in the industrial era. Emphasis will be upon the position and role of women within the society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Battles and Leaders
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will emphasize military organization, tactics and strategy, generalship and grand strategy, manpower and logistics, and the wartime ramifications of war on land, at sea, and in the air.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: World War II
htmlparse.Course.description: Origins, conduct, and consequence of World War II. Films from the TV series “The World at War” form an integral part of the course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Sport
htmlparse.Course.description: The historical development of sport (especially in Europe and North America) including the growth of competition, the rise of mass spectator sports, elitism, and the changing function of sport. History of sport as business and history of the relationship between sport and other institutions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Science and Technology in the United States
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of United States science and technology from the colonial era to the present, with special attention to how the wider social context, including the role of institutions and government, affected processes of scientific and technological development. Coverage also of the challenges of addressing the social problems that arose in connection with scientific and technological development throughout United States history.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Death and Dying in History
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines European and American attitudes toward death and dying in various historical periods. Topics include: death and dying in the European Middle Ages and in nineteenth and twentieth century America, the impact of the Nazi Holocaust on modern opinions about death, suicide as a historical problem, the fear of cancer in modern times, and others.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Christianity
htmlparse.Course.description: A history of the Christian religion from the era of Jesus Christ to the present with special emphasis on people and ideas.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Religion in American History
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the impact of religion on American culture and of American culture on religion, the Social Gospel and related issues, and the interrelationship of Christianity and politics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: A History of the Occult and Witchcraft
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the history of the occult and witchcraft in Western civilization with special attention to religious, intellectual, and social issues and influences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The History of Baseball in American Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of baseball from its origins in the early nineteenth century to the present, with emphasis on the major leagues and their collateral organizations but also with attention to semi-pro and amateur baseball and to the old Negro Leagues. The history of the game will be examined in the context of American history with special reference to social issues, politics, religion, literature, music, and the medial.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Colonial America
htmlparse.Course.description: About 1450 to 1763. Includes the European background of North American colonization, the rivalry for new world empire, seventeenth century English colonial foundations, and development of the various colonial societies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The American Revolution
htmlparse.Course.description: Eighteenth century colonial background of the Revolution and the revolutionary era itself, 1763-1789. Stresses ideological and other causes of the Revolution, the course of the war, its social results, the Confederation and its demise.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives; Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Early National Period
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundations of the new nation from the adoption of the Constitution to the conclusion of the War of 1812, approximately 1789-1815. Stresses the contest between Hamiltonians and Jeffersonians for philosophical dominance of institutions; other topics include diplomacy, westward expansion, military developments, the social and intellectual life of the era.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: America in the Age of Jackson
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the Age of Jackson, opening with Jackson’s election as America’s seventh president in 1828 and closing in 1850 as the tumultuous debates over the expansion of slavery tear the country apart.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Civil War and Reconstruction
htmlparse.Course.description: 1848-1877. Examination of the sectional controversy, the failure of the political system to resolve peacefully the conflict between North and South, the resort to arms, the nature of the post-war settlement. Emphasis is on the attempt of mid-nineteenth-century American leaders to deal with the complex problems of slavery and race.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: United States in the 19th Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the history of the United States during the 19th century and traces the transition of the country from a fragile, uncertain republic to a robust imperial power standing in the first rank of the world’s nations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The United States in the Twentieth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the creation of modern America, 1890 to the present. Emphasis on the social and cultural roots, and political consequences, of Progressivism, World War I, the Great Depression, World War II, the Sixties, and Post-Vietnam America.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in the History of the Americas
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides instructor and students the opportunity to investigate in detail a particular theme, event, or problem in the history of North, Central, or South America. Topics vary.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social History of Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of the development of American social thought and practices regarding health care from colonial times to the present. The course stresses changing cultural attitudes toward disease as well as alterations in social practices and institutions related to healing. Special emphasis is given to the institutional development and professionalization of modern medicine.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The American West
htmlparse.Course.description: Primary emphasis on the nineteenth century when Americans were rapidly spreading across the continent. Also examines the earlier developments of the frontier and considers the twentieth century role of the trans-Mississippi region.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Indians of North America
htmlparse.Course.description: A discussion of Indian-white relations from 1492 to the present. Special emphasis given to federal government policy and the cultural decline of the native people of North America. Also includes an examination of Indian reservations and urban Indians.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in Sport
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the history of the female athlete, with special emphasis on the significance of women in sport in the United States. Themes covered include the evolution of the social roles of sport, the relationship between sport and gender, and athletes’ construction of identity.

htmlparse.Course.title: African-American History
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the African-American experience from the seventeenth century through the civil rights movement. Emphasizes social, legal, economic, political, and intellectual aspects of black history as well African-American contributions to American life and culture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in America, 1600 to the Civil War
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the history of American women from the beginning of the European colonization to the Civil War. Women’s changing social role and its relation to the major transformations in American culture and society during this period is stressed. Special emphasis is given to ethnic, racial, and class variations among women.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in America, Civil War to the Present
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the history of American women from the end of the Civil War to the present. Examines women’s changing role in modern industrial society with special emphasis upon the women’s rights movement of both the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: U.S. World Affairs to 1920
htmlparse.Course.description: History of United States foreign relations from its origins in the colonial era through World War I.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: U.S. and World Affairs since 1920
htmlparse.Course.description: History of United States foreign relations from the end of World War I through the present day.  Explores how the United States engaged the world as a global power.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: War in the Twentieth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Considers the military theory and practice, the technology, and the political and ideological constraints of World Wars I and II, the Spanish Civil War, the Korean War, and the Indochinese wars. Students are to gain an understanding of the varieties of military experience in the twentieth century, including civil wars, “total war,”and guerrilla warfare.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of American Military Affairs
htmlparse.Course.description: Deals with the development of military institutions in colonial America and the United States, civil-military relations and conflicts between political constraints and strategic demands, popular attitudes toward the military, and the rise of the military-industrial complex.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic History of the United States
htmlparse.Course.description: Major topics in American economic history from the colonial period to the present.  Focus is on nineteenth- and twentieth-century issues, including the rise of big business; the expanding role of the government in the economy; the Great Depression; the postwar boom and its end; issues of class, race, and gender; America’s shifting roles in the global economy.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Family Violence
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the history of family violence in America as a social, cultural, legal, and public policy issue from colonial times to the present. Stress is placed upon the cultural roots and evolution of domestic law. The development of state-controlled social welfare agencies as well as the emergence of the “battered women’s movement” is particularly emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of American Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Main emphasis is on political, religious, and social thought and ideology, 1620 to present.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the South
htmlparse.Course.description: Topical analysis of important issues in Southern history. Compares the plantation myth of popular films with interpretations by important historians. Emphasis on plantation agriculture, slavery, race relations, class, and gender in the Old South. Post-Civil War topics include federal Reconstruction efforts, segregation, economic reform, and the modern Civil Rights movement.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Constitutional History
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of constitutional and legal development from colonial times to the present. English constitutional ideas and the common law in the American colonies, formation of the Constitution, the role of the Supreme Court, development of the modern American legal system, growth of the legal profession, the problem of civil liberties. The course offers insight into the relationship of constitutional-legal institutions to American society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bill of Rights in American History
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a topical survey of the American Bill of Rights from the colonial era to the present. It begins with the origins of American rights in England and colonial America. An analysis of the need for a Bill of Rights at the founding and Supreme Court interpretations in 1835 and during the Reconstruction era follow. The bulk of the course is concerned with the nationalization and expansion of the Bill of Rights in the twentieth century and its meaning in the everyday lives of American citizens.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of American Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Concentrates on the period since 1850 in an attempt to acquaint the student with the political and economic history of American agriculture. No attempt will be made to present the scientific or technological side of agriculture in detail, but agriculture will be shown in relation to the life of the entire United States. The life of the farmer and his family, the relationship between agricultural changes and other parts of the economy will be part of this course. Special attention will be paid to agriculture in Kansas and the Great Plains.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Kansas
htmlparse.Course.description: Land, people, and cultural developments in Kansas, from the earliest written records to the present. Provides the student with an intimate understanding of the state of Kansas.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Aztecs, Inca, and Maya
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the history of Ancient Mesoamerican and Andean civilizations through a multi-disciplinary approach combining materials from the fields of history, art history, anthropology, and archaeology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin American Nations
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of economic, social, and political developments of the Latin American nations from independence to the present decade with emphasis on Argentina, Brazil, Peru, Chile, and Mexico. Stresses reform and revolution of the last 50 years.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Colonial Hispanic America
htmlparse.Course.description: Iberian and indigenous American background, exploration, conquest, settlement, and development of Latin America. Stresses growth of mestizo culture, colonial styles of living, and wars of independence.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Mexico
htmlparse.Course.description: Brief survey of lines of national development, 1821-1910, and major emphasis on the twentieth-century revolution and its reforms (1910-1940) as well as its subsequent implications.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Mass Communications in America
htmlparse.Course.description: Growth and development of media and media technology in the United States and their economic, political, and social significance.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Culture of Greece
htmlparse.Course.description: The rise of civilization in the ancient Near East, the migrations of the Greeks and the Heroic Age, the Greek city-states, commerce and colonization, the Persian invasion, Athens’ leadership of Greece, the war between Athens and Sparta, Alexander the Great, and the total Hellenic achievement.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Culture of Rome
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the various theories of Rome’s origin, the causes, problems, and influences upon the republican government, political and economic problems of Roman expansion, and the Roman world. Various reforms including those of the Gracchi, Caesar, and Augustus. Contact with Greece and the older areas of civilization. The Roman imperial system, the many causes of Rome’s fall, and Rome’s role as a synthesizer of the ancient classical culture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Europe in the Middle Ages
htmlparse.Course.description: Europe from the fall of the Roman Empire to the thirteenth century. Investigates the conflict and interaction of Roman, Christian, and Germanic ideals and attitudes in the early Middle Ages, and the increasing complexity and sophistication of society, culture, religion, and government of the high Middle Ages.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: The Renaissance
htmlparse.Course.description: The Italian Renaissance as a major phase in the history of Western civilization and its spread to northern Europe.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: The Reformation
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the Protestant, Catholic, and Radical Reformations with special attention to Luther, Calvin, the origins of the Church of England and the Presbyterian Church, the Anabaptists, the Puritans, and Roman Catholic Reform, and the impact of religious developments on the political, economic, social, and intellectual history of the Western world. Covers the period from approximately 1500 to 1660.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Europe in the Seventeenth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Surveys the economic, social, political and intellectual history of western Europe in the seventeenth century, a period marked by economic depression, international conflict, and domestic revolutions as well as by cultural achievement. Emphasizes the complex interaction among social groups; the rise of a European state system; the development of constitutional monarchy in England and absolute monarchy in France; and the change in values generated by the scientific revolution.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Eighteenth-Century Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: Europe from the death of Louis XIV in 1715 to the fall of Napoleon in 1815. The origins and development of the French Revolution and the Napoleonic legacy, also examines reform and counter-revolutionary movements in England, Italy, Russia, Poland, and the Germanies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Nineteenth Century Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of Europe from the French Revolution to the end of the first World War. Major topics covered will include the rise of conservatism as an ideology and its application in practice, the nature of liberalism and socialism, the impact of science and technology, the origins and course of World War I.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth Century Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the political, social, and intellectual developments of Europe in the period of the two world wars. Emphasis on the failure of democracy and the rise of competing antidemocratic and nondemocratic mass movements and ideologies. The course will also deal with the attempted system of collective security, its failure, and the origins and course of World War II.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Europe since World War II
htmlparse.Course.description: Postwar European society, politics, economy, and culture. The effects of total war on the population; restoration and reconstruction. The influence of the U.S. and U.S.S.R. on Europe. Capitalism, socialism, and communism in technological society. European unity movements and their conflicts with traditional values.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: European International Relations to 1815
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature, evolution, and function of the diplomatic system for the Ancient World to 1815. Analyzes the Greek and Roman diplomatic tradition, international relations during the Medieval, Renaissance, and Early Modern periods, and the works of various theorists.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: European International Relations Since 1815
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature, evolution, and functions of the European diplomatic system from 1815 to the present. Focuses on the Vienna settlement, the Eastern Question, the Crimean War, Italian and German unification, origins of World War I, international developments between the two world wars, the cold war, and the post-cold war era. Includes analysis of major theorists.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Central Europe, 1500-1914
htmlparse.Course.description: The diplomatic, military, political, cultural, and social aspects of the Hapsburg empire in Central Europe from its foundation to its dissolution in the twentieth century.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: The British Isles to 1603
htmlparse.Course.description: English, Scottish, and Irish culture in the medieval and pre-modern periods. Early folk societies, feudalism, the church in society and politics, the origins of representative institutions and the religious reformations are studied topically.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: The British Isles Since 1603
htmlparse.Course.description: English society and politics in modern times with reference also to Scotland and Ireland. Emphasis on topics such as the three orders of society (king, lords, and commons), the churches and religion, the appearance of parliamentary sovereignty, the industrial revolution, and the extension of democratic institutions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Eastern Europe Since 1914
htmlparse.Course.description: The growth of nationalism, the formation of nation-states after World War I, the devastation of World War II, the establishment of Soviet rule, the dramatic revolutions of 1989, and Yugoslavia’s ethnic wars.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: History of France, 1400-1715
htmlparse.Course.description: France from the conclusion of the Hundred Years War to the death of Louis XIV. French economy, society, and royal administration, and the changes generated in these areas by significant events: the Reformation and the Wars of Religion; the rise of France to world power; peasant uprisings and constitutional crisis; and the reforms of Richelieu, Colbert, and Louis XIV. Trends in art, architecture, and philosophy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Medieval Religion and Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: The interrelationship of religion and politics from the late Roman Empire to the Conciliar Epoch. Christianity in the Roman Empire and the barbarian kingdoms, the development of royal theocracy, the rise of the papacy, the conflict of church and state, the secularization of government, the Avignon papacy, the Great Schism, and conciliarism.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminar in History
htmlparse.Course.description: An undergraduate seminar that focuses on the intellectual principles of the historical discipline as well as the fundamental research techniques and writing skills used by historians. Each section of the seminar will center on a particular topic or historical problem. The students will prepare a research paper on a relevant subject of their choice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of History courses at or above the 500 level.
htmlparse.Course.notes: All history majors must take this seminar to complete the requirements for their degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nineteenth-Century Imperial Germany
htmlparse.Course.description: Central Europe in the French Revolutionary era, the revolutions of 1848, German unification, imperial Germany, emphasizing social changes, especially the transition from agrarian to industrial society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Nazi Germany and the Holocaust
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the political, social, economic, and intellectual developments in Germany from World War I to the end of World War II, including the Nazi ideology and the Holocaust.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: The Russian Empire
htmlparse.Course.description: Imperial Russia from the earliest Slavic tribes through 1881, with emphasis on Russia’s heritage as a multi-ethnic state and the phenomenon of Russia’s revolutional intellectuals.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth Century Russia
htmlparse.Course.description: The turbulent history of modern Russia, including the upheaval of the Russian Revolution and Civil War, Stalin’s transformation of Soviet society, World War II, failed attempts to transform the Soviet system, and the fall of the Soviet Union.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: The Vietnam War
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines the origins, actions, and consequences of the Indochina wars fought by the French, Japanese, and Americans during the last century. Particular emphasis is placed on America’s experience in Southeast Asia. Videos from the PBS series, “Vietnam: A Television History,” are used in the course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: French Revolution, 1789-1815
htmlparse.Course.description: The political, economic, cultural, and social development of France from the origins of the Revolution to the Congress of Vienna.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in European History
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides instructor and students the opportunity to investigate in detail a particular theme, event, or problem in European history.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Non-Western History
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides instructor and students the opportunity to investigate in detail a particular theme, event, or problem in non-Western history.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Topics vary. May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in History
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical professional experience involving at least three weeks in an archive, museum, historical library, or business. Student projects must be approved in advance and a report submitted at the end of the work period.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Overseas European Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Short-term, intensive, and in-depth study of various aspects of European history and culture with readings, lectures, discussions, and on-the-spot experiences which will relate historical events to the places visited.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in History
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will read on a central theme, attend weekly discussions, and write a final report.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in History
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study of a particular phase of history. Students will attend weekly discussions and write a major research paper on their findings.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation to Hotel and Restaurant Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A general orientation to the university, the College of Human Ecology, the Department of Hospitality Management and Dietetics. Students will develop an understanding of academic career planning, the enrollment process, basic interviewing skills, resume building tools, and other issues as they apply to students in the hotel and restaurant management program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: HRM majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the Hospitality Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of the hospitality industry. Survey of the history, scope, trends, and career opportunities that comprise the four segments of the industry: food service, lodging, travel and tourism, and meeting and convention planning.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Careers in Nutrition and Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to career opportunities in the field of nutrition and dietetics with emphasis on academic preparation, acquisition of professional credentials, and career laddering. Guest speakers from various areas of professional practice will supplement lectures and student assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Issues in Hospitality
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of environmental issues that impact the hospitality industry. Includes: principles of foodborne disease function and transmission, bloodborne pathogens, Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) system, food safety principles and applications, and workplace safety, conservation of natural resources, solid waste management, air quality, and governmental regulations in the hospitality industry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, 30 hours or more.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Hospitality
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to professional challenges in the hospitality industry. Development of professional and academic skills as they relate to the hospitality industry including academic career planning, study abroad opportunities, resume development, business etiquette, meeting management, and ethics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HRM majors only. Corequisite: HMD 120.

htmlparse.Course.title: Issues in Tourism
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the history and implications of travel and tourism focusing on the understanding of tourism from the perspectives of travelers and communities, while identifying tourism’s economic, socio-cultural, and environmental impacts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structured Field Experience in HMD
htmlparse.Course.description: Planned experience in a hotel, restaurant, foodservice, or healthcare operation; minimum of 200 hours exclusive of course work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HMD 120, consent of advisor, and sophomore standing, 30 hours or more.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required for hotel and restaurant management majors who have completed 30 hours of course work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Club Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of topics involved in club management. Topics discussed are history and current trends of public and private clubs, food and beverage service, marketing, and event and financial management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Controlled Beverages
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of historic, social, ethical, physiological, and legal issues relating to alcoholic beverage service and use in contemporary America with emphasis on responsible and knowledgeable service of beer, wine, and spirits in hospitality operations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Food Production Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic principles and theories of foodservice systems; menu planning; development, standardization, adjustment, and costing of quantity recipes; procurement and production of quality food; foodservice computer applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HMD 220 or BIOL 455 or concurrent enrollment in either.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Production Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Application and principles of food production that includes procurement, quantity food production and controls, work simplification, food service systems, quality food; commercial equipment use, and Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HMD 341 and HN 413 with a minimum grade of “C” in each; HMD 220 or BIOL 455 with ServSafe Certification.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture,one hour recitation, 3 hours lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Lodging Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of the lodging industry and current trends. Organization and administration of lodging operations including front desk, housekeeping, laundry, sales/marketing, management, and other positions common to lodging operations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lodging Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experiences in housekeeping, maintenance and other operational areas in a lodging property. Forty hours of practicum experience within an assigned property.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Convention, Meeting and Event Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Through lecture and experiential activities, this course introduces the roles of convention, meeting, and event planner; identifies environmental and technological trends in the industry; and exposes the students to meeting, convention, and even management systems from inception to delivery.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Business of Wedding and Event Consulting
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will introduce the student to the competencies required to become a professional wedding and even consultant. Students will analyze essential services that provide the necessary infrastructure for a wedding event and will examine the business, creative, and practical aspects of coordinating the wedding environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foodservice Work Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: A 300-hour planned experience that combines observation, and employment within commercial or noncommercial foodservice operation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: HMD 341, HMD 275; HRM majors only and consent of academic advisor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Convention, Meeting and Event Management Work Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: A 300-hour planned experience that combines observation, and employment within convention, meeting, and/or event management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: HMD 363, HMD 275; HRM majors only and consent of academic advisor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lodging Work Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: A 300-hour planned experience that combines observation, and employment within a lodging operation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: HMD 362, HMD 275; HRM majors only and consent of academic advisor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hospitality Service Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the complexities of quality and service within all segments of the hospitality industry. Focus on developing problem solving skills, process management skills, work methods, team development skills, and evaluation of service systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Cost Controls in Hospitality Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of accounting principles to analyze control measures used in lodging meeting/conventions/events, and commercial and noncommercial foodservice operations. Includes managerial, financial, and ethical considerations associated with procurement and human resources.

htmlparse.Course.title: Facility, Risk, and Security Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation and selection of equipment, maintenance contracts, layout, design, and sustainability of hospitality operations, facility renovation, and selection of consultants. Assessment of safety and security measures and development of risk management programs to increase guest/customer safety.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HMD 375 or HMD 376 or HMD 377.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Hospitality Marketing and Sales
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of marketing principles to lodging, foodservice, and tourism industry through analysis of marketing mix, marketing strategies, and sales techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Management in Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of financial management principles used to control costs and generate revenue in dietetics practice and noncommercial foodservice operations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ACCTG 231 with a grade of B or better, HMD 342 or concurrent enrollment. Enrollment restricted to dietetics majors, non-majors completing CADE requirements, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Travel and Dining Auction Event Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of event planning principles by analyzing previous travel and dining auctions, managing and executing the current year’s travel and dining auction, and evaluating the results.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HMD 275, HMD 363; instructor’s permission required.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Wines
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of wine varietals and major wine regions of the world, tasting and identifying wine varietals based on their specific characteristics, proper purchasing and service of wines, and using wines to complement foods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Wines
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of wine varietals and major wine regions of the world, tasting and identifying wine varietals based on their specific characteristics, proper purchasing and service of wines, and pairing wines to complement foods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lodging Management Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and interpretation of key lodging statistics including occupancy percentage, average daily rate, revenue available per room, customer profiles, etc.  Overview of forecasting methods and pricing and distribution channel strategies.  Emphasis on concepts and practices of revenue management in the hotel/lodging industry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in the Hospitality Management Industry
