htmlparse.Course.description: Planned and supervised experience in a foodservice or hospitality operation; minimum of 400 hours.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: For HRM students: junior standing, HMD 275 and 421; and HMD 375, 376, 377; consent of program director.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Resource Management in the Hospitality Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasizes the role of the hospitality manager and dietitian as facilitator, trainer, and motivator of employees. Focuses on the fundamentals of successful training and development of a service-oriented work force. Special attention is given to the unique problems associated with the labor intensive hospitality and foodservice industries.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Clinical Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Through a series of case studies and projects, this course introduces the student dietitian to the basics of the practice of clinical dietetics including review of the medical record, nutritional assessment and documentation of medical nutrition therapy in the medical record.  Students gain practical experience by completing shadowing experiences with a dietitian in clinical practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Golf Course Internship in Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Four hundred hours of supervised hospitality experience in a golf industry setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Hospitality Management and Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study under the supervision of a faculty member.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Clinical Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation for entrance into the clinical supervised practice experience. Review of medical record content; current practice protocols in clinical dietetics; practice case studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission into the coordinated program in dietetics; concurrent enrollment in HMD 521.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four day workshop.

htmlparse.Course.title: Counseling Strategies in Dietetic Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of interviewing, counseling, and educational techniques in dietetics, including individual and group methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 110 or SOCIO 211 with a grade of C or better; HN 450 with a grade of B or better. Enrollment restricted to dietetics majors, non-majors completing CADE requirements, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Competencies in Dietetics Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Assessment of audiences and development of effective food/nutrition messages in community settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Competencies in Dietetics Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of principles learned in HMD 516 Communication Competencies in Dietetics Practice to the development, implementation, and evaluation of a community project under the guidance of a community mentor.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission into the coordinated program in dietetics; concurrent enrollment in HMD 516 and HMD 521.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Clinical Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of clinical nutrition principles through case studies, independent research, discussion, groups, and oral presentations. Case studies will focus on medical nutrition therapy and education of persons throughout the life cycle and nutrition intervention for individuals with multiple disease states in various healthcare settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the coordinated program in dietetics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Dietetic Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised clinical/community experience in the nutritional care of patients/clients. Practicum experiences are arranged with participating healthcare facilities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Must be taken concurrent with HMD 520.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Management in Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Management and leadership in dietetic practice. Discussion of current issues affecting practice including human resources, outcomes management, accreditation/quality assurance, financial resources, marketing, technology and recent trends in various fields of management practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HMD 426. Admission to the didactic or coordinated program.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring (on campus) and Spring, Summer (distance)
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Management in Dietetics Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised practice experience in the application of management principles in foodservice operations or other dietetics practice settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to Coordinated Program; HMD 560 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Management in Dietetics Practicum Recitation
htmlparse.Course.description: Focused discussion of significant occurrences during the supervised practice experience and the application of management principles in foodservice operations or other dietetic practice settings. Behavior-based assessment and progression is utilized to encourage self-development and entry-level competence in dietetics practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the coordinated program in dietetics; concurrent enrollment in HMD 561.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Research in Dietetics Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to basic research design in dietetics with application of the research to evidenced based practice using the Evidence Analysis Library of the American Dietetic Association.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission into the Didactic Program or admission into the Coordinated Program or intent to apply to the coordinated program; HMD 426 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Hospitality Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Legal aspects of managing hospitality operations and responsibilities for the operations, patron civil rights, governmental regulations, franchising, and commercial transactions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Procurement in the Hospitality Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and theories of procurement of food and supplies for hospitality operations. Includes management, financial, safety, and ethical considerations in the procurement process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Entrepreneurship in Hospitality Management and Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and management of small businesses or private practice within the dietetics or hospitality industry. Business plan development, marketing, cost considerations. Overview of consulting to healthcare and hospitality operations and examination of skills required for success.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Understanding and appreciating how to communicate effectively in writing about food and food-related topics.  Hands-on experience in research and writing for various audiences and types of publications.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Foodservice Systems Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone course in foodservice management that focuses on the management, analysis, and evaluation of food and beverage systems. Emphasis on planning, coordinating, and improving commercial and noncommercial operations. Development of analytical and decision-making skills for solving managerial and operational problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Convention, Meeting, and Event Management Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A capstone course in convention, meeting and event management that focuses on the management, analysis and evaluation of conventions, meetings and events. Emphasis will be placed on strategic planning, budgeting, contract negotiation, vendor selection, evaluation and ethical issues.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Lodging Management Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of management theories to the lodging industry including yield management, multicultural issues, marketing strategies, environmental issues, and future trends.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Implementation in Foodservice and Hospitality Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of computer development in foodservice and hospitality operations; development of criteria for implementation of a computer system; analysis of foodservice and hospitality hardware and software.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CIS 101; and HMD 480 or 560 or MANGT 420.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Foodservice and Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed study of current literature in foodservice and hospitality management and related areas.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Health Care Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive review of current health care institutions and their response to the economic, social/ethical, political/legal, technological, and ecological environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Foodservice Systems Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional experiences in approved foodservice organization as a member of the management team under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent: HMD 342; and HMD 480 or 560 or MANGT 420.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Public Health
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an introductory survey course designed to provide a history of public health, an overview of the five core disciplines (epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, social and behavioral health, and health policy and management), and information about career options in public health. Using these introductory materials as a foundation, students will investigate and analyze contemporary issues in public health such as bioterrorism, threats to the nation’s food supply, the importance of health promoting behaviors in the prevention of disease, burden and distribution of infectious diseases on a global population, and the role of public health disaster preparedness and management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to athletic training for first year athletic training majors. Emphasis will be on sports medicine team, legal concerns, pre-participation physicals, basic principles of injury prevention, policies and procedures.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Athletic training majors only, and concurrent enrollment in HN 121.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students must be concurrent enrolled in HN 121.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Athletic Training Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to athletic training for first year athletic training majors. Students will be required to complete a competencies skill list with a passing grade. Clinical hours in the athletic training room will give the student the opportunity to use the knowledge, skills, and techniques learned in this course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Athletic training majors only, and concurrent enrollment in HN 120.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The student must complete clinical hours that do not count toward their practicum requirements, but are required for application to the professional phase of the athletic training education program. Students must be concurrent enrolled in HN 120.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts of human nutrition applied to personal food choices and health.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Trends, Legislation, and Regulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Current trends in market forms, packaging, and utilization of various foods.  Food laws, regulation, labeling, additives, and residues.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Care and Prevention of Athletic Injuries
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of treatment, taping, and care of minor athletic injuries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 220, EDSEC 250, or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 340.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Personal Wellness
htmlparse.Course.description: Impact of the effect of personal actions on lifelong wellness. Practical methods of assessing, maintaining, and improving behaviors to reduce the risk of illness and disability. Emphasis on developing skills to make informed, responsible health decisions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutrients, their function, metabolism, and relation to health and disease: the digestion, absorption, transport, utilization, and storage of nutrients in humans.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Science of Food
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemical, physical, sensory, and nutritional properties of food related to processes used in food preparation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutritional Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of nutritional assessment in humans to evaluate dietary intake and body composition; use of biologic markers of human nutritional status.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 400 or concurrent enrollment in each.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.
For HN and DT majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised individual project to study current topics or participation in research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours in HN and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Life Span Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Physiological and environmental influences on nutritional requirements; nutritional problems and eating patterns of age groups throughout the life cycle.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated more than once for a maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition Education in Extension
htmlparse.Course.description: The process of and strategies for providing nutrition education outreach to diverse community audiences, including those with limited resources.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Any college-level nutrition course and junior or senior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Energy Balance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will cover metabolic principles as they relate to energy intake (diet) and expenditure (exercise). Specific topics will include: obesity, anorexia/bulimia, bioenergetics, substrate selection/regulation (especially exercise and diabetes), body composition; methodology to assess each; and metabolism related disease.

htmlparse.Course.title: Evaluation of Athletic Injuries of the Extremities
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to familiarize the student athletic trainer with the principles of orthopedic assessment and to apply these principles to specific regions of the body. Knowledge gained in this course may be applicable to other individuals interested in health related professions which require systematic examination of the body.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 320 with a B or better and BIOL 340.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Emergency Procedures and Evaluation of Core Athletic Injuries
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to familiarize the student athletic trainer with the procedures of emergency management of athletic injuries and to apply these procedures both on the field and off the field. The student athletic trainer will become familiarized with the principles of orthopedic and emergency medical assessment and to apply these principles to the core of the body. Knowledge gained in this course may be applicable to other individuals interested in health related professions which require systematic examination of the body in emergency settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 320 with a B or better and BIOL 340.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Pharmacology in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of medications commonly encountered in the practice of athletic training. Includes categories of drugs, generic and trade names of common drugs, the use, effects and precautions for common drugs and drug-interactions. Focuses on how various drugs affect the patient response to activity, exercise and other therapeutic interventions.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Medical Conditions in the Athlete
htmlparse.Course.description: Course covers the recognition, evaluation, management, and prevention of the most common medical conditions that affect athletic participation. Emphasis placed on the appropriate history, physical exam, indications for referral, and treatment for each condition.

htmlparse.Course.title: Therapeutic Modalities in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory and application of the various energy systems used in the treatment of athletic injuries. Practical experiences will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 320 with a B or better, PHYS 115, and BIOL 340.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Rehabilitation and Conditioning for Athletic Injuries
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of applied rehabilitation and conditioning techniques used by athletic trainers.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 551, HN 552 and KIN 330, HN 555 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Athletic Training Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of issues affecting athletic trainers in their roles as administrators in the areas of role delineation, budget designs, legal aspects of sport, facility design, and drug testing and drug education.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum I in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised, clinical experience at approved clinical settings. The athletic training student will apply principles taught in HN 320.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 120, HN 121 and HN 320 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken second year, first semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum II in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised, clinical experience at approved clinical settings. The athletic training student will apply principles taught in the classroom and practiced in the lab throughout the curriculum program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of HN 583 Practicum I with a grade of C or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken second year, second semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum III in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised clinical experience at approved clinical settings. The athletic training student will apply principles taught in the classroom and practiced in the lab throughout the curriculum program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of HN 584 Practicum II with a grade of C or higher and concurrent enrollment in HN 551.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken third year, first semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum IV in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised, clinical experience at approved clinical settings. The athletic training student will apply principles taught in the classroom and practiced in the lab throughout the curriculum program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of HN 585 Practicum III with a grade of C or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken third year, second semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum V in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised, clinical experience at approved clinical settings. The athletic training student will apply principles taught in the classroom and practiced in the lab throughout the curriculum program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of HN 586 Practicum IV with a grade of C or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken fourth year, first semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum VI in Athletic Training
htmlparse.Course.description: A supervised, clinical experience at approved clinical settings. The athletic training student will apply principles taught in the classroom and practiced in the lab throughout the curriculum program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of HN 587 Practicum V with a grade of C or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken fourth year, second semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Public health nutrition issues for various segments of the population; nutritional components of community assessment; program planning and evaluation; and policy issues pertaining to the nutritional status of the population.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrient Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of the mechanisms of actions, interactions, and the processes of cellular assimilation and utilization of nutrients in humans. Emphasis on the coordinated control of nutrient utilization among the major organs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 400; BIOL 340 or KIN 360; and BIOCH 265 or BIOCH 521, or CHM 550 with concurrent enrollment in BIOCH 521.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Nutrition I
htmlparse.Course.description: First course of a two semester study of the application of nutrition principles in disease; includes physiological basis of nutritional care, effects of disease on nutrient metabolism, medical nutrition therapy, in-class team diagnoses presentations, and nutrition counseling.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Nutrition II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of the application of nutrition principles in disease; includes physiological and biochemical basis of nutritional care, effects of disease on nutrient metabolism, medical nutrition therapy for critical care needs, standardized language in advanced professional nutrition diagnoses and care of selected diseases.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition and Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: The interrelationships among diet, nutrition, and exercise. Topics covered include physical fitness, weight control, nutrient metabolism during exercise, and athletic performance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 132 or HN 400 and a grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 335.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised professional field experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 450 and HN 600 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once for a maximum of 6 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition and Food Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on the physiological, environmental, cultural, and economic factors that influence the use of food. Identification of appropriate methodology to study these factors as well as programs to modify food behavior.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 110 or SOCIO 211 or ANTH 200; and HN 400.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sensory Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Sensory analysis of appearance, texture, aroma, flavor; physiology of sensory receptors; laboratory and consumer panels; and interpretation of data.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hour recitation and three to six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition in Developing Countries
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional problems in developing countries, including an analysis of factors which contribute to malnutrition, effects of undernutrition, methods for assessing nutritional status, and interventions to combat nutrition problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pet Food Sensory Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Sensory analysis of food and other products for non-food animals (e.e. dogs and cats with mention of other species) with an emphasis on methods (descriptive, discrimination, consumer, sensory-related instrumental) used in the laboratory and in the field.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: STAT 325 or STAT 702 or STAT 703 or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Health and Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is on the physiological theories of aging, the relationship between normal aging processes, and the major chronic and acute diseases of the elderly, and community health promotion/maintenance programs for older adults.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition and Wellness
htmlparse.Course.description: Epidemiology and pathophysiology of chronic disease related to nutrition (e.g., obesity, cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, hypertension, diabetes, cancer). Nutritional risk and protective factors will be examined as they relate to public health and individual nutrition.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Course in basic nutrition and statistics at the undergraduate level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Energy Balance
htmlparse.Course.description: Lifestyle, metabolic, and endocrine factors affecting energy balance and the development of obesity. Research methods to assess and apply energy balance data will also be discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised individual project to study current issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated more than once for a maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Internship in Horticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the internship program in horticulture; planning for a rewarding internship experience; requirements for completing an internship; how to prepare an oral presentation using visual aids; participation in presentations by previous year’s interns. Course designed to be taken the first fall semester on campus, or as early as possible in the academic career.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture per week. For department majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Horticultural Science
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic principles of plant science and the environment that apply to horticulture; survey of the industry; plant taxonomy, anatomy, morphology, and physiology; environment and plant growth; plant propagation, pest management, plant breeding.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: High school biology/botany or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 198.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concepts of Floral Design
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the use of flowers and related products with emphasis on fundamentals of design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours studio a week. For majors or non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the Horticultural Therapy Profession
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will consist of a practical exploration of the field of horticultural therapy services in various settings. Students will learn about major job duties such as facilitation techniques, programs, clients, staff, budgets, facilities, and equipment and the variety of populations with which professional horticultural therapists work.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Dimensions of Horticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to horticulture applied in schools, psychiatric and medical hospitals, corrections, vocational rehabilitation centers, elderly programs, and consumer horticulture settings. Networking the art and science of horticulture with architecture, business, social sciences, health care, horticulture, and education.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the landscape design process including historical perspectives and contemporary issues; development of planning, graphical presentation, and communication skills; and application of design principles to horticultural garden design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticulture Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Experiential approach to learning horticulture through teaching. Students will assist faculty with specific horticulture courses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 201, junior standing, and successful completion of practicum assistance course with at least a C.
htmlparse.Course.notes: No more than 3 credits may be used as horticulture specialization electives nor may it substitute for a required horticulture course in the horticulture or horticultural therapy curricula.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Organic Farming
htmlparse.Course.description: This class will cover the history of organic farming principles, practices, and policies.  USDA standards will be compared to similar standards in other countries, and to “green labels” that compete with organic products in the marketplace.  Industry trends as well as the basics of how to certify farms and food processors will be included.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Propagation
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to develop proficiency in various skills and techniques necessary for propagation of horticultural plants. Basic fundamentals of seed structure and vegetative makeup of plants are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Horticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth presentation and discussion of techniques and requirements for the management and administration of a public horticultural facility.  Topics include oral and written presentation skills, proposal development, public relations, budgeting, fundraising, dealing with governing boards, interpersonal relationships and managing horticultural operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Plants I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to landscape plant identification of trees, shrubs, and cultivated herbaceous cultivated plants, including perennials, annuals, biennials, and bulbs. Topics covered in the course include classification and nomenclature, plant growth characteristics and their landscape use. Weekly labs consist of lengthy walking campus tours to observe and identify plant specimens. A field trip may be required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: BIOL 198 or HORT 201 or AGRON 220.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Plants II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued identification of cultivated landscape tree, shrubs, and herbaceous plants, including perennials, annuals, biennials, and bulbs. Topics covered in the course include classification and botanical nomenclature, plant growth characteristics and their landscape use.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Weekly labs consist of lengthy walking campus tours to observe and identify plant specimens. A field trip may be required.
Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plants in the Interior Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification, ornamental characters, culture, propagation, and use of foliage plants in the interior environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticulture Topics
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and discussion of topics of importance to undergraduate majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Issues in the Lawn and Landscape
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will examine critical water issues related to irrigation in urbanizing watersheds, with an emphasis on water quality and quantity. Factors impacting water scarcity and quality will be discussed. Successful completion of this course will help students understand the interrelatedness of incorrect irrigation practices and water quality/quantity, and will equip them to help protect water resources through application of science based irrigation practices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: Junior standing or one year of experience in the lawn/landscape maintenance industry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a distance education course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: Understanding and implementing the maintenance requirements of existing landscapes focusing on a holistic approach to cultural, environmental and human inputs.  Students will learn how to analyze and assess landscape maintenance practices more effectively for the care of young trees, shrubs, annuals, and perennials.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: HORT 201; HORT 374 or HORT 375 or FOR 330 or FOR 340; and AGRON 305.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week for the first 11 weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: Reinforcement of the horticultural design process as applied to the use of native and introduced plant materials. Emphasis on functional and aesthetic arrangement of plants in small-scale design to meet site design objectives and adaptation to microclimates.  Students expected to develop site adapted plant palettes and graphic ability to present their design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 275 and two plant materials courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two three-hour studio periods a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Turfgrass Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Turfgrass identification and adaptation; establishment and maintenance of turf for home lawns, parks, and commercial/institutional grounds.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week for first 11 weeks of the semester.
Course available via distance education for off-campus students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intensive Culture of Golf and Sports Turf
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in golf and sports turf maintenance, focusing on practices unique to intensively used and managed turf.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the last five weeks of the semester.
Available via distance education for off-campus students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Golf Course and Sports Turf Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Strategies involved in golf course and sports turf operation, including development of cultural practices, effective communication, personnel management, and budgeting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fruit Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of cultivating fruit and nut crops commercially.  Laboratory offers experiences in pomological practices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 201 or equivalent and HORT 350.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticulture for Special Populations
htmlparse.Course.description: An intensive study of the concepts and methods of using plants and gardening as therapeutic activities with developmentally disabled, geriatric, economically and socially disadvantaged, emotionally disturbed, or educationally deprived clients.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Therapy Case Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Guest lecturer and student presentations of topics relating to professionalism, current issues, or goals of horticultural therapy. The course is intended to help students focus expectations and assumptions about a professional career in horticultural therapy and to give them practice in articulating their understanding of the field. Client case management is used as part of career practice.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Therapy Field Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Students under supervision will plan, conduct, and evaluate horticultural therapy activities at Manhattan institutional sites selected according to student’s interest. A weekly discussion session addresses evaluation and issues of professionalism.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Therapy Field Experiences
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised training at institutions with horticultural therapy programs to gain experience in the application and use of horticultural activities for special populations. Six months (1,000) hours continuous internships required in psychiatric and correctional programs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two 3-month (500 hours) internships may be completed at two different sites. Students are required to complete 6 credits of field experience before graduation.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Applications in Horticultural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to a variety of computer software packages that students may encounter in the nursery/garden center environment. These include planning, routing, and estimating packages.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Irrigation Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of the principles and practices of landscape irrigation which involve sprinkler system installation, maintenance and scheduling, electrical troubleshooting, basic hydraulics, and drip irrigation as these topics pertain to residential and commercial landscapes and golf courses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: MATH 100; HORT 201; and AGRON 305.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Business of Landscape Contracting
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of contracts and specifications, and the bidding and estimating processes as applied to landscape contracting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week, for the first seven weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Landscape Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: The interpretation and implementation of small-scale landscape construction (hardscape) projects.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week, for the last 11 weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Fundamentals of Landscape Irrigation Design
htmlparse.Course.description: The goal of this course is to learn landscape irrigation design for efficient use of our water resources.  This course will discuss basic hydraulics, sprinkler performance, plot plans, sprinkler layout, pipe sizing and zoning, and electrical considerations of the design process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 550 or two years of irrigation experience related field work approved by the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the last 11 weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vegetable Crop Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of production principles and cultural practices involved in the growing of vegetable crops.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab or field trips a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Greenhouse Operations Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Greenhouse systems operations and management including greenhouse layout; structures; glazing materials; heating, ventilation, irrigation, lighting, benching, growing medium handling, and fertilization systems; traffic flow; crop handling, processing and shipping.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nursery Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the various practices and methods of operating a commercial nursery for the production of woody ornamental plants for the landscaping industry. Nursery layout, planting systems, nutrition management, plant maintenance, and harvesting technologies will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week. Field trips may be required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Horticultural Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis is on horticultural design projects with clients, working with the design process, design articulation and communication with the clients.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Horticultural Pest Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Pesticide use and handling, horticultural pesticides and their characteristics, integrated pest management approaches, and pesticide applicator certification.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: HORT 201 and an entomology, plant pathology, or weed science course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the first five weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Arboriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of maintaining shade and ornamental trees under urban environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turfgrass Diseases and Their Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology, diagnosis and integrated management of turfgrass diseases.  Emphasis is on diseases of intensively maintained turfgrass.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 582 or concurrent enrollment and HORT 515 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the first five weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turfgrass Weeds and Their Managment
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology, diagnosis and integrated management of turfgrass weeds.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 582 or concurrent enrollment and HORT 515 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the middle five weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turfgrass Insects and Their Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology, diagnosis and integrated management of turfgrass insect pests.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 582 or concurrent enrollment and HORT 515 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the last five weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticulture Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of commercial or public horticulture activity including exposure to multiple phases of the working horticulture operation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: HORT 190, HORT 201, plus one 500-level horticulture commodity course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Students will be placed according to specific interest. Required for horticulture majors after having completed 60 hours.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Horticultural Professional
htmlparse.Course.description: Completion of horticulture program assessment tools. Completion of modules associated with professional development during careers in horticultural disciplines, including diversity and ethics in the workplace, job search skills, and providing leadership in the profession.

htmlparse.Course.title: Herbaceous Landscape Plant Production
htmlparse.Course.description: The principles and commercial practices for producing annual and herbaceous perennial landscape plants from seed and cuttings.  Analysis of crop production costs will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Floral Crops Production and Handling
htmlparse.Course.description: The principles and commercial practices for producing floral potted crops and cut flowers crops emphasizing the physical responses of plants to their environment. Aspects of post-harvest physiology will be covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 201. Recommended prerequisite: BIOL 500, HORT 350 and HORT 570.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Viticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is on aspects of grapes, from vine anatomy to final products produced from them.  Includes cultivars, propagation, canopy management, diseases, weed control, physiology, anatomy, irrigation, wine production, climates and soils.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems and reports in floriculture, olericulture, ornamental horticulture, pomology, turfgrass and horticultural therapy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Permaculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of a thinking/design methodology that seeks to provide for the physical needs of humans, including food, water, shelter, energy, etc. while doing so in an environmentally-friendly, sustainable manner.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turfgrass Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Water, temperature, light, soil, and management stresses affecting turfgrass growth; cultural practices that reduce injury.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Cell, Tissue and Organ Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Course will cover the principles and laboratory exercises that demonstrate major concepts and practical techniques in plant cell, tissue and organ culture. The history and use of plant cell-, tissue-, and organ-culture for crop improvement will be explained. The variety of tissue-culture techniques will be highlighted. Selected readings and practical tissue culture projects will be required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Interiorscaping
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is the physiological principles and industry practices in the production, moving, care, and maintenance of interior plants.  This course will provide students the career tools to design, install and maintain interior plantscapes through knowledge of interior plant physiology, care and maintenance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Nursery Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Cultural practices used with nursery production will be presented with focus on the adoption of best management practices, conservation of resources, scientific research-based investigations related to nursery cultural practices, potential risks to nursery personnel, and off-site movement of air-borne materials and effluents to surrounding areas and public watersheds.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Postharvest Technology and Physiology of Horticultural Crops
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the principles and practices involved in the harvesting, handling and storage of horticultural products. The relationship of plant structure and physiology will be emphasized in discussing effects of postharvest handling and storage to maximize quality and shelf life of products.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One horticulture commodity course and BIOL 500.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Issues in Horticultural Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will explore human issues in horticulture generally, and human issues in horticultural therapy specifically. Consideration of selected topics and issues such as people-plant relationship theories, horticultural therapy as a specialized allied health field, health-care gardens and their use, societal impacts on horticultural therapy, and research issues. Provides students with a knowledge and understanding of the literature in horticultural therapy and develops an appreciation of the interrelationships involved in this multidisciplinary area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: A course in research methods and a course in statistics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticulture in Horticultural Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of horticulture principles and practices in therapeutic settings; considerations for greenhouse systems operations and management in therapeutic settings; landscape maintenance, fruit and vegetable gardening, and production horticulture as part of a therapeutic program; and plant propagation for production and therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Skills in Horticultural Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of horticultural therapy skills and methodology is facilitated through real-life case studies. Includes instruction, practice, and evaluation of clinical skills with population groups typically served through horticultural therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Horticultural Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: The practicum is a means of demonstrating the interconnections between ‘theory’ and ‘practice’. By conducting a practicum project, students demonstrate the ability to apply concepts and ideas from their study of horticultural therapy to a specific population or setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Management for Horticultural Enterprises
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is on developing a detailed business plan for the service, design and production businesses in horticulture that incorporates considerations of start-up capitalization, insurance, investments, legal accounting and employee compensation.  Strategic decision-making and aspects of a horticulture firms that are unique to its industries, such as product seasonality and perishability, will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Breeding Methods in Horticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is on introductory plant breeding principles with emphasis on traditional methods of developing improved cultivars of crosspollinated, self-pollinated, and asexually-propagated horticultural crops, and the genetic principles on which breeding methods are based.  The course provides a general background in all areas of plant breeding as a foundation for mastering more complex breeding principles.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: ASI 500 and STAT 300-level or above.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Health-Promoting Phytochemicals: Fruits and Vegetables
htmlparse.Course.description: The course deals with various aspects of phytochemicals in plant-based foods including fruits and vegetables and their impact on human health and well-being. It includes potential effects of phytochemicals in promoting human health, preventing various diseases and fostering wellness. It also includes biosynthesis and metabolism of phytochemicals in plants. Emphasis is placed on developing strategies to improve the phytochemical content of food crops through approaches involving crop management, environmental and biotechnology tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and CHM 110 or CHM 210.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sustainable Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical perspectives of the sustainable agriculture movement in the United States and world-wide will be examined and critiqued.  Components of sustainable agriculture such as agroecosystem theory, permaculture, energy use efficiency, and organic standards will be compared and evaluated.  Students will demonstrate their understanding and application of the material by conducting research on a topic within sustainable agriculture and presenting the topic to the rest of the class.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will become familiar with a wide variety of urban agriculture types, methods of implementation, and the skill sets necessary to supervise such projects. The course will include background readings, case studies, guest speakers, student-facilitated class discussions, and lectures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Food Production Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will complete a 400 hour practicum in an approved urban agriculture setting to gain exposure to a broad range of tasks facing the urban farmer. This includes planning, production and marketing of crops in high tunnels and open field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Architectural Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in the fundamentals of architectural technology with emphasis on the concepts and principles necessary for developing an integrated approach to building design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 115 or 113 and admission to a professional program in the college.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design and Material Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: People’s personal characteristics or social position can be expressed by the products they purchase, the possessions they own, and the physical environments they create. Design has become a major factor influencing one’s final decision for purchasing these products. This course examines material culture which is created from the influences of human behavior, design, history, marketing, economics, politics, geography, the arts, and sociology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: IAPD Design Studio I
htmlparse.Course.description: Design vocabulary, form and space generation, application of design process, idea generation, creativity, and diagramming are all general topics that underpin the second year. Projects that utilize these topics will include an introduction to residential and light construction; space layout with furniture, color, and materials selection; human scale and anthropometrics; perspective as applied to small scale spaces; environmental analysis and introduction to structure in design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENVD 202 and admission to the professional program in interior architecture and product design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: IAPD Design Studio II
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis, synthesis, and design of various types of products associated with the interior environment, integrating such human factor determinants as anthropometrics and ergonomics. Construction prototype products associated with the human environment developed concurrently within the design studio.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 307; no grade lower than a C in any interior architecture and product design studio course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Contemporary Design Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on current interior architecture, product design, and furniture design that illustrate principles and practical concerns that motivate design with readings, class discussion, student presentations, research papers or projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Open to non-majors accepted in the College of Architecture, Planning and Design; third-year standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity in U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in IAPD
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of specific interior architectural problems under direct supervision of a member of the department.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Workshop I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to shop procedures, equipment, design materials, joinery, and elementary design experiences in turning and shaping various materials. The course also includes identification and application of specific interior finishes and provides the student the opportunity through a series of small projects to be exposed to the total creative design process by researching, designing, constructing, and evaluating finished products.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Materials and Finishes
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to materials, textiles, and finishes specific to interior applications. Criteria for evaluation, selection, and application of interior materials and finishes with the building fabric and their impact on building design. Preparation of written and graphic communications to illustrate and direct the construction process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the professional program in interior architecture and product design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Digital Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to software and digital means to investigate, visualize, model, and represent design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 307 and admission to the professional program in interior architecture and product design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six (6) contact hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drawing in Black and White
htmlparse.Course.description: Freehand representational drawing of architectonic space using graphite pencil and ink pen. Emphasis is on the development of the visual perception of space and the communication of the perceived space through drawings that are clear and expressive.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Workshop I Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Studio component of IAPD 407 Design Workshop I.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Furniture
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the social, political, and religious influences on furniture design from ancient Egypt through the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Furniture Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design theory related to analysis, materials, and construction techniques from the early American period through the contemporary movement.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the professional program in architecture, interior architecture, or landscape architecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Visual Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will be challenged to visualize and communicate in a three-dimensional language using constructed perspective, computer-generated perspective with rendering and animation techniques, and constructed models as tools of the profession. Rapid graphic visual techniques using various medias will be studied enabling quick exploration of multiple design options in a spatial environment. Graphic arts including photography, typesetting, silk screening, and reproduction as applied to board presentations will be introduced. Throughout the entire semester the study of color theory and its application will be used in all presentations.

htmlparse.Course.title: IAPD Design Studio III
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced design projects involving products related to the interior environment. Synthesis of the design, materials, construction, and finishing of prototypical products relevant to human use. Exercises in various rendering techniques and involvement in different media presentations associated with product design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 320, no grade lower than a C in any interior architecture and product design studio course.

htmlparse.Course.title: IAPD Design Studio IV
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will build upon and extend the knowledge and skill base gained by students in studios I and II. This course will include the introduction of programming methodology and its relationship to the design and organization of interior space. Emphasis will be placed on the appropriate selection of furniture, finishes, fixtures, and equipment within the context of their relationships to form, function, task and users’ needs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 435, no grade lower than a C in any interior architecture and product design studio course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Product Design Illustration
htmlparse.Course.description: Exercises in various rendering techniques and involvement in different media presentations associated with product design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Product Design
htmlparse.Course.description: History and design theory related to analysis materials and construction in product design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Graphics Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the use of colored pencils, to render and present form and space using different techniques. Emphasis on the visual perception and composition of elements in design drawings and presentation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Studio 6
htmlparse.Course.description: This semester of study provides an option for an interdisciplinary collaborative studio course oriented towards replicating the learning experience and interactive activities that takes place in the modern multidisciplinary professional office or a validated equivalent studio completed in an approved study program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 433 and IAPD 801, and no grade lower than a C in any interior architecture and product design studio course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Lighting in IAPD
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of design and technical issues related to luminous environments in building interiors. Topics include color and light, vision, light sources, luminaire selection and design, and the evaluation of lighting solutions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 435, ARCH 413, and Corequisite: ARCH 514.

htmlparse.Course.title: Building Construction Systems IA
htmlparse.Course.description: A technical capstone course that demonstrates student comprehension of previously learned material through exercises culminating in a construction document set including information about structural, mechanical, electrical, plumbing systems, and millwork details, construction details, codes and the American with Disabilities Act with appropriate drawings illustrating ways in which they come together.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Sixteen weeks off-campus work study in professional offices specializing in interior architecture: field and office experience.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Internship Report
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose is to develop the student’s communication skills and awareness of the importance of written communication and record keeping in interior architectural office practice. The required report will provide a detailed documentation of the student’s experiences encountered during internship.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Foreign Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course allows the student to study outside of the United States for one semester. The semester will expand their global perspective of design professions, cultural, political, and economic views. One semester studying interior architecture in a foreign university.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 603, ARCH 433, not more than one grade of D in an interior architecture design studio and approval by the foreign studies coordinator.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Foreign Studies Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Taken in conjunction with IAPD 646. The purpose is to develop the student’s written communication skills as well as increase awareness of written communication and record keeping in interior architecture office practice. The report will provide detailed documentation of the student’s experiences during the foreign studies program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Summer Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Ten weeks off-campus work study in professional offices specializing in interior architecture: field and office experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 433, IAPD 440 and IAPD 628 and no grade lower than a C in any IAPD studio course. Corequisite: IAPD 665.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Summer Internship Report
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose is to develop the student’s communication skills and awareness of the importance of written communication and record keeping in interior architectural office practice. The required report will provide a detailed documentation of the student’s experiences encountered during internship.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Study Abroad Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Courses taken from a university in an approved foreign studies program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced 3-D Computer Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Lighting, materials, animation, advanced modeling techniques, sound, and storyboarding are methodologies required to successfully build a digital presentation for projection in a two dimensional, or 3-dimensional environment using the vision domes. Projects that utilize these topics will include an introduction to 3D modeling, animation, sound, titling, lighting, and a material editor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Product Design Studio II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced design projects involving products related to the interior environment. Synthesis of the design, materials, construction and finishing of prototype products relevant to human use.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 605 or IAPD 644 and IAPD 645, or IAPD 646 and IAPD 647; not more than one “D” in an interior architecture design studio course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Product Design
htmlparse.Course.description: History and design theory related to analysis materials and construction in product design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Architecture Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings and discussion of contemporary thought and movements within the field of interior architecture with special emphasis on the societal factors that produce and effect change.

htmlparse.Course.title: IAPD Design Studio 5
htmlparse.Course.description: This semester of study provides an option for an interdisciplinary collaborative studio course oriented towards replicating the learning experience and interactive activities that takes place in the modern multi-disciplinary professional office.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 440 and no grade lower than a C in any IAPD studio course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Workshop II
htmlparse.Course.description: Design Workshop II is intended to further develop the student’s understanding of the three dimensional design process through research, design, prototype construction, evaluation, and redesign. Enhance and increase the student’s understanding of the structural characteristics of materials and increase their proficiency at communicating ideas through working and presentation drawings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 407, IAPD 412, and no grade lower than a C in any IAPD studio course. Corequisite: IAPD 803.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Workshop II Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Studio component of Design Workshop II.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 412, IAPD 407 and no grade lower than a C in any IAPD studio course. Corequisite: IAPD 802.

htmlparse.Course.title: IAPD Capstone Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Students are to pursue design projects that encompass their previous educational experience validating their knowledge of the IAPD program studies. The project will be based on extensive research and review. The project presentation will suggest unique and applicable solutions with clearly identified methodology of implementation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 606 or IAPD 644 and IAPD 645.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Identify evaluation criteria appropriate for design research and problem solving; analysis of literature; construction of problem statements, development and documentation of design problem proposals and reports.

htmlparse.Course.title: Furniture Design Workshop Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Studio component of IAPD 814 Furniture Design Workshop.

htmlparse.Course.title: Furniture Design Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Design, construction, and finishing of contemporary furniture and accessories.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IAPD 803 and IAPD 606. Corequisite: IAPD 813.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Studio Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Research of programming methodologies culminating in a programmatic document used as the basis for the design project in IAPD 822, 823, or 824.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminar in IA
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced readings and discussions of environmental issues related to the practice of interior architecture. Readings, discussions, reports.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced IAPD Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of interior space planning, product design, and interior design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Product Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Students explore projects programmed under the previous semester IAPD 815 programming course. Projects may be client or manufacture based with design analysis, directed research and concept formulation and proposed manufacturing processes including cost and marketing analysis. An exhibition of the student’s work will be required at the completion of the course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced IA Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Utilizing a client-based design project, the student works directly with clients to produce a completed moderately scaled design project. Students must demonstrate knowledge of interior specification writing, materials selection, and advanced presentation techniques. An exhibition of the student’s work will be required at the completion of the course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Furniture Design Studio & Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced design, construction, and finishing of contemporary furniture. Experimentation in the design of spatial components utilizing advanced construction techniques and materials. The course includes directed research involving market analysis, specifications, and adaptation to manufacturing processes. An exhibition of the student’s work will be required at the completion of the course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Interior Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of specific interior architectural problems under direct supervision of the departmental staff.

htmlparse.Course.title: Facilities Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the methods of managing the physical assets of large facilities-corporate, institutional, and governmental-through a review of current literature, presentations by professionals active in the field, and case studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Design Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced instruction in the design, construction, and finishing of contemporary furniture and accessories. The course involves the development of a concept for a complex furniture prototype and includes research, program development, design development, criteria examination and determination, design development, working drawings, complete prototype development, and presentation drawings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of conventional and newly developing modes of professional design practice. presented are the relationships of interior architects, architects, and landscape architects and other design professionals to users, clients, building industry, society, government, and one another.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Design
htmlparse.Course.description: A visual survey of selected works of current interior architecture, product design, and furniture design, which illustrate principles and practical concerns that motivate design. Extensive writing requirement which will focus on the various topics, issues, and discussions given during the course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non IAPD majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: First Year ID Student Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: First Year Assembly is structured to engage and support students during their first semester of study. The course is focused on learning strategies and resources that build toward successful outcomes for the remainder of their college studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Admission to the Interior Design Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course is Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design and Behavior in the Interior Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Developing awareness of aesthetic and behavioral relationships fundamental to interior design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 1
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to two-dimensional and three-dimensional design fundamentals including design elements and principles. Introduction to the design process.  Introduction to interior design theory and its application. Introduction to fundamental design communication methods including drawing and model building.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Admission to the College of Human Ecology interior design program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 2
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of two-dimensional and three-dimensional design fundamentals. Introduction to color theory in spatial design. Introduction to light, shade, and shadow. Introduction to rendering, constructed perspective, and paraline drawing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 225 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Construction Methods and Materials for Interior Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to theories, concepts, selection, and application of construction processes, materials, and finishes.  Introduction to codes, regulations, representation of construction methods, and sustainability.
