htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 245 with C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Interior Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: A historic survey of furniture, textiles, and the minor arts from antiquity to 1850. Progressive development of design and ornamentation characteristics as related to interiors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 3
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced spatial design fundamentals.  Application of human factors and theories of human behavior in the built environment.  Selection of materials and colors.  Emphasis on design conceptualization and creativity.  Advanced visual communication methods including rapid visualization and constructed two-point perspective drawing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 245 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 4
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of interior design theory and evidence-based design in small scale projects.  Introduction of project programming for interior design.  Application of codes and regulations.  Continued emphasis on design communication skills.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 325 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Interior Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of modern design evolution in furniture, textiles, and the minor arts from 1850 to the present. Concepts, development, and application of modern technology to contemporary design and interiors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised off-campus professional experience in an appropriate design-related setting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 and 415 with a C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Housing and Its Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Socioeconomic, political-legal, and consumer overview of housing. Includes individual, family, and public decisions related to residential alternatives, their acquisition, and housing and environmental standards.
htmlparse.Course.semesters:
Fall, Spring
(This is a rotating elective course taught every 3-4 semesters and may be either a Spring or Fall offering.)
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer-Aided Visual Communication in Interior Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to and application of digital technologies used by interior design professionals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 310 and 325 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours of studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 5
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of theory and research in medium scale projects.  Focus on construction systems, materials, and methods.  Continued emphasis on communication skills, programming, spatial design, and application of codes and regulations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 and 415 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Systems for Interior Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to lighting, heating, ventilating, air conditioning, and acoustic systems; principles, performance requirements, and components related to function, behavior, and aesthetics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 101 and 103 or PHYS 115; ID 310 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lighting for Interiors
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration and application of technical, functional, and aesthetic considerations in lighting design with an emphasis on selection and specification.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 and 435 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.semesters:
Fall, Spring
(This is a rotating elective course taught every 3-4 semesters and may be either a Spring or Fall offering.)
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 6
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and execution of working drawings and specifications for interior design projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 425 and 435 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Interior Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for maximum 9 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Interior Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Problem-solving in interior design.  May substitute for Interior Design studio ID 445, ID 545, or ID 645.  Students should plan to substitute this course for the next level studio in sequence.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 315, ID 345, ID 435, and admitted to the interior design major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Practices and Procedures
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethics, business procedures, and professional development; contract services and administration; and preparation for job market entry as applied to the practice of interior design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 425 with a C or better and admission to the interior design program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 7
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of design theory to create solutions for complex, large-scale interior spaces. Projects require implementation of all phases of the design process. Students will gain greater understanding of the interior designer’s responsibilities within the context of the design professions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 445 and 530 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Eight hours studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised off-campus professional experience in appropriate design-related firms, government agencies, or the housing industry.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 445 and ID 530 with a C or better and admission to the interior design program and a 2.2 cumulative GPA and 2.5 GPA in professional areas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Study Tour
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised off-campus tour to acquaint the student with rich artistic and cultural locations around the world and expand student’s global perspectives of the design profession. Lectures and tours target important interior/architectural design and furniture collections.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Repeatable for a maximum of 9 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Advanced Interior Design Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of contemporary social and cultural influences on design theory and applications within the interior design profession.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for maximum of 9 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio 8
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of design theory to create solutions for complex, large-scale interior spaces. Projects will conform to professional standards regarding design process, protection of health, safety, and welfare, and construction methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 445 and 530 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Eight hours studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Design and Behavior in the Interior Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: The design of interior environments explored in an ecological, behavioral, and cultural context.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.semesters:
Fall, Spring
(This is a rotating elective course taught every 3-4 semesters and may be either a Spring or Fall offering.)
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design for Supportive Environments
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the age and ability related needs and challenges faced by children, older adults, and persons with disabilities. Team approaches to providing living and work environments that accommodate both universal and special human needs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 with a C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture. Two hours studio/recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Kitchen and Bath Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Functional and research basis for planning and arranging based on activity analysis, equipment, materials, lighting, and ventilation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 345 and ID 435 with a C or better and admission to the interior design program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historic Fabric Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Interrelationships of fabric design and social, cultural, political, economic, and geographical environments from prehistoric times to present.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HIST 101; and AT 260; or AT 265 and AT 266.

htmlparse.Course.title: Housing and Facilities Management Processes/Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of theories, principles, and practices used in managing physical facilities and the residents or workers they house. Issues and problems encountered by professional managers in providing quality living or working environments within cost-effective operations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 410, MANGT 420 or 720, and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Housing Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Developing local and regional housing needs assessments and strategies to meet the challenges faced by lower-income people and racial and ethnic minorities. Analysis of current housing and community development programs and public-private partnerships for affordable housing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour seminar.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historic Preservation and Restoration of Interiors
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, guidelines, and qualities of preservation and restoration of interiors. Research and application.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ID 320 and 360; or ENVD 250 and 251.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring (This is a rotating elective course taught every 3-4 semesters and may be either a spring or fall offering.)

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Assembly
htmlparse.Course.description: Assemblies are held once a month for practicing industrial engineers to make presentations to the students. Students are given an opportunity to interact with the visitors. The purpose is to provide an opportunity to learn about various companies and their products and operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable. Required every semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Plant Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Trip to industrial centers for study of facilities of special interest to industrial engineering students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing in industrial engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction of Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the core areas of industrial engineering including ergonomics, operations, research, quality control, management, engineering economics, resource management, production systems and inventory control.  Both engineering ethics and careers in industrial engineering will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Manufacturing Processes and Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an introduction to manufacturing processes and systems. The history and impact of manufacturing on society will be explored. A review of manufacturing processes and the products to which they are best suited will be emphasized. The impact of product design on manufacturability will be introduced. The role of engineers in designing good manufacturing processes and systems will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Manufacturing Processes Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: General introduction to foundry, welding, and machining. Includes safe manufacturing practices, metrology, and hands-on experience in foundry, welding, and machining operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Welding Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to welding. Includes safe welding practices and lab experiments in gas, spot, and arc welding.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Net Shape Manufacturing Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Includes safe manufacturing practices and experiments in casting and injection molding.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machining Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Production of machined parts. Includes metrology, safe machining practices, reading shop drawings, and good machining practices.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Numerical Control Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to computer numerical control. Part programming for CNC lathes and mills will be accomplished.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. Open to students in the College of Engineering honors program. A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic functions in an industrial organization and their interrelationships; management considerations involving product, process, plant, and personnel.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Economic Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis of the economic aspects of engineering/industrial projects. Focus on decision making among competing alternatives, including replacement decisions. It includes: cost estimating, time-value of money and effects of depreciation and taxation. Methods of comparing alternatives are developed, including: equivalent worth, rate of return, break even analysis, and benefit-cost ratio.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course period lasts the first ten weeks of a semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Project Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis and selection of engineering/industrial projects. This course is a continuation of IMSE 530. Topics in addition to IMSE 530 includes: risk/uncertainty, impact of inflation, capital rationing, multiple criteria decision making, and determining the MARR.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
This course must be taken concurrently with IMSE 530 in the same semester.
This course period lasts the last five weeks of a semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Quality Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Normal, binomial, and frequency distributions. Seven process improvement tools. Control charts on means and variances for variables and attributes. Design of experiments for process and product design. Acceptance sampling plans.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Facilities Layout and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of industrial facilities with emphasis on manufacturing engineering and material handling.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Operations Research I
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the methods of operations research including model formulation and optimization. Topics include: linear programming, sensitivity analysis, network flows, and graph optimization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Manufacturing Processes Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The effects of operating variables on manufacturing processes such as machining, metal forming, casting, welding, plastics, etc. Emphases are on manufacturing process theory, process variables measurement, and the technical inferences of collected data. Strength of materials, manufacturing process theory, instrumentation, computer data acquisition, and data analysis concepts are included. Laboratory testing of manufacturing processes and the engineering design of experiments for process variable measurements are used to develop efficient manufacturing processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Product and Process Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the interrelationships between product design and production process selection. Emphasis is on the development of economic production systems for discrete products in a competitive manufacturing environment. Concepts of design for manufacture and assembly, tool engineering, and manufacturing systems design are included.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IMSE 250 and IMSE 251 and IMSE 530.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Manufacturing Systems Design and Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive design and analysis of a manufacturing system: integration of the undergraduate industrial engineering and manufacturing engineering courses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent: 24 credit hours of IMSE 500 level and above courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Design Project I
htmlparse.Course.description: Students organize themselves in teams, not exceeding five students in each team. Each team is responsible to establish a client. The teams select a general subject agreeable to the client, formulate a specific design project, and gather data and resources needed to support the project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent: 24 credit hours of IMSE 500 level and above courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Design Project II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of IMSE 591 in which student teams complete engineering design projects formulated and approved in IMSE 591.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures on recent topics in industrial engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study of Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: This course involves independent study at the introductory graduate level.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Industrial Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Contemporary management philosophies and their impact on engineers and engineering managers. Topics include: planning, organizing, leading, and controlling.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Occupational Safety Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of factors affecting safety in organizations, emphasizing analysis techniques and design strategies. Topics include occupational safety, accidents, fire protection, industrial hygiene, hazardous waste, toxicology, radiation safety, product liability and federal standards. A project involving a hazard analysis and the design of a solution for a field location is required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Ergonomics
htmlparse.Course.description: Process analysis and charting; principles of motion economy and ergonomics; work stations and environments; micromotion analysis and an introduction to standard data systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Work Environments
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic structure and performance of the human, viewed as a component in information processing and control systems. Effect of visual, auditory, toxic, and thermal environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Production Planning and Inventory Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, techniques, and applications of production planning and inventory control. The course covers strategic planning tools such as forecasting and aggregate planning as well as tactical tools such as inventory management and scheduling.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IMSE 250. Prerequisite or concurrent: IMSE 560.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quality Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the modern practice of quality engineering concepts, systems, strategies, and tools to both manufacturing and service industries. Topics include advanced techniques related to statistical process control, international quality standards, quality data management, and automatic inspection.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Simulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of computer simulation modeling of manufacturing, production, service and other stochastic systems. Use of a commercial simulation software environment to build, analyze, verify and validate models. Use of models as a system design tool through statistical and optimization techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operations Research II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of IMSE 560. Topics include: integer programming, nonlinear programming, Markov chains, and queuing theory.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Aided Manufacturing
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts in CAM, integrated control of machine tools and transport devices with production control. Concepts of CAM and automated assembly in small lot production environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IMSE 251 and CIS 209, or 200, or ME 400.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operations Research III
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of IMSE 660.  Covers more advanced aspects of LP and NLP.  Introduces three new topics: normative theory of decision and games, dynamic programming and Markov decision systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IMSE 660. Prerequisite or concurrent: IMSE 530.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Problem Solving Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of decision making techniques. Topics covered include: linear, integer and nonlinear programming; network flows and stochastic processes. A focus of the course will include modeling and the use of software to solve these problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Manufacturing Information Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the theory and concepts of information for manufacturing. Design of manufacturing systems such as MRP, SFRS, CAD/CAM, etc. Concerns of integration and man-machine interface in manufacturing systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Normative Theory of Decisions and Games
htmlparse.Course.description: Bayes theorem, Bayesian estimators, utility, loss function and risk, minimax strategies, elementary game theory.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stochastic Calculus Financial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will serve as an introduction to the basic concepts and computing techniques of financial engineering and its real-life applications. These basics can be applied in many other aspects of industrial engineering used throughout stochastic processes, probability theory, system simulation, portfolio/risk management, and supply chain optimization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: IMSE 530, 660, and CIS 209 or 200, or ME 400.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Operations Research
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is intended to give an overview of OR at the graduate level. After this course, the student will have the general basic knowledge in OR and a better idea about the usefulness and interrelationships of the various subjects in OR. Topics to be covered include the various optimization techniques, stochastic processes and optimization, and the various approaches in the treatment of uncertainty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian for Travelers
htmlparse.Course.description: A function course designed to prepare students for everyday situations on a visit to Italy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian IL
htmlparse.Course.description: Language laboratory. Strongly recommended for students taking Italian I. Concurrent enrollment in Italian I required.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: For credit/no credit only. Credit given only upon receiving a passing grade for the concurrent section of Italian I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian IIL
htmlparse.Course.description: Language laboratory. Strongly recommended for students taking Italian II. Concurrent enrollment in Italian II required.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: For Credit/No Credit only. Credit given only upon receiving a passing grade for the concurrent section of Italian II.

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of modern Italian.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation and completion of the study of modern Italian grammar, using the facilities of the language laboratory for audiolingual practice.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian III
htmlparse.Course.description: Grammar review and reading selections from Italian literature.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Selective review of grammar and reading of examples of modern Italian literature.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Italian
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Italian
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head and instructor involved.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japanese I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamental linguistics and cultural characteristics of the Japanese language and its writing systems (Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji).
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japanese II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Japanese I. Development of functional skills for familiar situations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japanese III
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to grammatical patterns and sentence structure. Extensive practice of spoken and written Japanese.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japanese IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Japanese III. Enhancement of speaking and writing skills, and reading and listening comprehension.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Japanese
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Japanese
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Culture of Japanese Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to verbal and nonverbal cultural aspects of Japanese discourse. Includes comparative study, followed by discussion on application of knowledge in cross-cultural context.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japanese V
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of communication skills through application activities such as problem-solving tasks and role plays. Enhancement of vocabulary, structures, and their usage. Emphasis on extended discourse.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Japanese VI
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Japanese V.  Development of functional skills for general situations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Japanese
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Japanese
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Strength and Conditioning
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of topics and participation in activities of importance in strength and conditioning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Aerobic Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of topics and participation in activities of importance in aerobic exercise.

htmlparse.Course.title: Swimming I
htmlparse.Course.description: Beginning instruction for students who have no previous experience with swimming.

htmlparse.Course.title: Swimming II
htmlparse.Course.description: For the beginning swimmer who has had some previous swimming experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: Swimming III
htmlparse.Course.description: Swimming III
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 105 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in the College of Arts and Sciences, no more than 4 credit hours in lifetime sports and exercise activity classes may be applied toward a degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fitness Swimming
htmlparse.Course.description: Fitness Swimming
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 106 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in the College of Arts and Sciences, no more than 4 credit hours in lifetime sports and exercise activity classes may be applied toward a degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Public Health
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory survey course designed to provide a history of public health, an overview of the five core disciplines (epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, social and behavioral health, and health policy and management), and information about career options in public health. Investigation and analysis of contemporary issues in public health such as bioterrorism, threats to the nation’s food supply, the importance of health promoting behaviors in the prevention of disease, distribution of infectious diseases on a global population, and the role of public health in disaster preparedness and management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerobic Dancing and Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: Aerobic Dancing and Exercise
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in the College of Arts and Sciences, no more than 4 credit hours in lifetime sports and exercise activity classes may be applied toward a degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fitness and Conditioning
htmlparse.Course.description: Fitness and Conditioning
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in the College of Arts and Sciences, no more than 4 credit hours in lifetime sports and exercise activity classes may be applied toward a degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jogging
htmlparse.Course.description: Jogging
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in the College of Arts and Sciences, no more than 4 credit hours in lifetime sports and exercise activity classes may be applied toward a degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Weight Training
htmlparse.Course.description: Weight Training
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in the College of Arts and Sciences, no more than 4 credit hours in lifetime sports and exercise activity classes may be applied toward a degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Exercise and Water Fitness Instructor Training
htmlparse.Course.description: Skills and knowledge to develop competency in participating, designing, and leading different types of water exercise, as well as administering all aspects of water fitness classes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and one hour lab each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biobehavioral Bases of Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: Current perspectives from the biological and behavioral domains of kinesiology will be used to explore the significance of physical activity for optimal health.  Topics include physiology of physical activity, social and behavioral epidemiology of physical activity and health, control and biomechanics of human movement.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture and two hours of lab experiences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Measurement and Research Techniques in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and techniques of measurement and research in the biological and behavioral aspects of kinesiology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Motor Learning and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Issues of motor learning and development as they relate to the application of instructional techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biomechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Mechanical and anatomical aspects of human movement.  Kinematic and kinetic principles applied to the analysis of human movement.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiology of Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: The responses of the human body to exercise. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the structure-function relationships of the respiratory, cardiovascular, and muscular systems and how their function is integrated to support the dynamics of muscular contraction. Limitations to exercise performance will be examined in health and disease and the adaptability of the human body to physiological (i.e., exercise training) and environmental (e.g., hypoxia) stressors will be examined.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiology of Exercise Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course to supplement the material of KIN 335.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social and Behavioral Epidemiology of Public Health Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: And introduction to the social and behavioral epidemiology of physical activity in public health: outcomes, influences, and promotion in individuals, settings and communities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 220, PSYCH 110; SOCIO 211 with a grade of C or better, concurrent enrollment in KIN 346.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours of contact time per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory Experience for Social and Behavioral Epidemiology of Public Health Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory experience for KIN 345.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of contact time per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Anatomy and Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Anatomy and Physiology of the organ systems of the human body. Laboratory includes physiology experiments, study of anatomy from computer simulation, dissection demonstrations, X-rays, and slide work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198 taken at K-State (with a C grade or better) or transferred introductory biology credit.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours lecture and two three-hour lab sessions a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of a selected topic in an area not covered in the curriculum or involving application of theory presented in a related subject core course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated as topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in kinesiology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Choreographing Aerobic Dance and Exercise Routines
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of choreography and methodology in teaching aerobic dance and exercise routines in various educational settings. Emphasis upon preparation and progression of routines. Selecting music, designing routines, and methods of presenting to various age groups.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Lifetime Sports
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised students assist in lifetime sports classes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory Practicum in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised students assist in laboratory.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and appropriate background for problem undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individually directed research in kinesiology, normally as a preliminary to writing a senior honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, membership in the honors Program of the College of Arts and Sciences, and permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once to a total of three hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Sport
htmlparse.Course.description: The historical development of sport (especially in Europe and North America) including the growth of competition, the rise of mass spectator sports, elitism, and the changing function of sport. History of sport as business and history of the relationship between sport and other institutions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Fitness Settings
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experiences in the fitness setting such as observation and participation in exercise testing and prescription, exercise leadership, and record keeping and program management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 335, CPR & First Aid Certification, and consent of instructor

htmlparse.Course.title: Prac/Public Health Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experiences in the public health setting, such as observation and participation in public health physical activity program planning and evaluation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Issues and problems involving integration of the subdisciplines of kinesiology and professional areas of application.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of all or concurrent enrollment in final kinesiology core courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Exercise and Sport Injury
htmlparse.Course.description: Underlying effects, treatment of psychological consequences, and physical trauma of exercise and sport injury. Topics include the impact of injury on exercise behavior, the athlete at risk, behavioral risk factors, injury assessment, treatment of injury, and psychological factors addressed by the sports medicine team.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 340 and a grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and KIN 345.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sport and Exercise Personality
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of personality in sport, sport performance and exercise behavior. Theories relevant to sport and exercise personality will be examined to provide a theoretical framework for understanding and applying research. Assessment instruments and relevant research will be examined and critiqued.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 345.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of a selected topic in kinesiology involving either an in-depth study or application of theory presented in a related core course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated as topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Studies in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in kinesiology. Maximum of 3 hours applicable towards a degree.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of theory and research related to physical activity participation. Topics will include: mental health effects of exercise, behavior change theories applied to physical activity, physical activity correlates and intervention strategies used to increase and maintain physical activity participation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 345.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cardiorespiratory Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the structure and function of the respiratory system and the manner in which oxygen passes from the atmosphere to its site of utilization in the mitochondria. Exercise and environmental stresses will form the basis for examining the capacity, plasticity, and limitations to respiratory function.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and KIN 335.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender Issues in Sport and Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the impact of exercise and fitness trends on women in contemporary society with particular emphasis on how society presents obstacles to exercise and fitness. Topics include the relationship between exercise patterns and family structure, cosmetic fitness, eating disorders, and social class.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 345.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Cardiovascular Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the structure and function of the cardiovascular system as it pertains to acute and chronic exercise. Topics include the control of blood pressure, vascular volume, and blood flow during orthostasis and exercise.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 335.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Exercise and Mental Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of research and theory related to mental health consequences of physical activity. Topics will include the role of exercise in developing self-esteem and body image as well as the use of exercise as a therapy for emotional and behavioral disorders.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 345.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in the Biological Basis of Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of a selected topic in the biological basis of kinesiology involving either an in-depth study or application of theory presented in a related course area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 335.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in the Behavioral Basis of Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of a selected topic in the behavioral basis of kinesiology involving either an in-depth study or application of theory presented in a related course area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 345.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Muscle Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Subcellular, cellular, and tissue structure of skeletal muscle and the relationship of these structural characteristics to the functioning of the muscle. Examines energy pathways available to the muscle to support the various functions, mechanisms underlying changes in exercise tolerance that accompany exercise training and detraining, and diseases that affect skeletal muscle.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and KIN 335.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Body Image, Eating Disorders & Obesity
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of research and theory related to body image, eating disorders and obesity from psychological, behavioral, and physical activity and public health perspectives. Topics will include epidemiological trends, psychosocial and environmental factors, diagnostic criteria and ethics, as well as prevention and treatment strategies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or higher in KIN 345.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the physiological adaptations to acute and chronic challenges imposed by the environment. Topics will focus on how different physiological systems respond to different environmental stressors (heat, cold, deep sea diving, high altitude).
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Planning and Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories and models and the stages and activities of planning, implementing, and evaluating health promotion programs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Built Environment and Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of neighborhood and community design characteristics that contribute to more active living and improved health.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Exercise Testing and Prescription
htmlparse.Course.description: Benefits and risks of exercise testing and prescription with healthy populations, individuals at risk, and patients with cardiovascular and metabolic diseases. Includes experiences with exercise test technology and methods of exercise prescription.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310, KIN 335, proof of current CPR, BLS, and First Aid certification.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition and Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: The interrelationships between diet, nutrition, and exercise. Topics covered include physical fitness, weight control, nutrient metabolism during exercise, and athletic performance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HN 132 or HN 400 and a grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 335.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Development of Motor Control
htmlparse.Course.description: A multi-level analysis of the neurophysiological activation of muscle, reflexes, sensory integration during movement, and theories of voluntary movement.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 340 and a grade of C or higher in KIN 310.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fitness Promotion
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the implementation and promotion of preventive health programs for populations at work, hospitals, and community fitness settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and 345.

htmlparse.Course.title: Therapeutic Use of Exercise in the Treatment of Disease
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of pathophysiology associated with a number of different diseases and the impact on exercise performance as well as the use of exercise as a therapeutic modality.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: A grade of C or higher in KIN 310 and KIN 335.

htmlparse.Course.title: Minority Groups in Sport
htmlparse.Course.description: The contributions by, problems of, and discrimination against minority groups in sports.

htmlparse.Course.title: Health-Fitness Instructor Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in settings such as Hospital Wellness Centers, YMCA, YWCA, municipal recreation agency, or industrial fitness agency.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: KIN 335/336, KIN 520, 625, 655, and consent of instructor
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be completed with half-time assignment for 12-16 weeks or full-time assignment for 6-8 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship/Public Health Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in settings such as public health departments, foundations, government offices, or research programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in exercise physiology involving either greater in-depth study, or application of theory presented in a related course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated as topic varies. Only 6 hours may be counted toward degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Public Health Physical Activity Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in public health physical activity behavior involving either greater in-depth study, or application of theory presented in a related course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated as topic varies. Only six hours may be counted toward degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Field Trip
htmlparse.Course.description: Field trip requirement: each spring third-year students will be required to participate in a 4- to 5-day field trip.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Design Studio I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to design processes as the means to translate and apply abstract thinking to organize and articulate solutions to small-scale landscape architecture projects. Emphasis placed on diagramming, spatial definition and ordering, introduction to the literature, introductory application of site analysis and design communication.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the LA professional program. Prerequisite or corequisite: LAR 510.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Materials and Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: To provide the student a basic understanding of materials and methods commonly utilized in the practice of landscape architecture as a basis to pursue subsequent land design and land construction course work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 113, 115 or 213. Prerequisite or corequisite: LAR 520.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Graphics and Visual Thinking
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of graphic communication techniques for the exploration and presentation of landscape architecture design ideas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the LA professional program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Design Studio II
htmlparse.Course.description: Small- to medium-scale site design studies with emphasis placed on design process, response to cultural and natural conditions, detailed articulation of space including definition and use of materials, and design communication.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LAR 220. Prerequisite or corequisite: LAR 520.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Issues and Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the relationship of the natural environment to the life within it and as a factor in environmental design ethic.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Plant Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification, ornamental attributes, cultural considerations, and use of important native and ornamental trees, shrubs, vines, and ground cover. Additionally, there will be an introduction to herbaceous plants. Weekly lab consists of outdoor walking tours on campus to reinforce identification characteristics of plant specimens as well as develop appreciation of plant character for integration into the landscape.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to the LA professional program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Planting Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Design studies emphasizing functional, aesthetic, and ecological uses of plants. projects emphasize design process and the relationship between plants and the built environment; elements and principles of planting design; plant selection; preparation of planting plans; specification writing; and design implementation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LAR 320. Prerequisite or corequisite: LAR 520, HORT 374.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Systems and Site Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on ecological issues in design, natural systems, and site analysis in planting design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Admission to LA professional program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and six hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Theory of Landscape Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: The influences of social, political, economic, and climatic factors on historic landscape styles; theory of landscape design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Implementation I
htmlparse.Course.description: Lecture and studio problems in the basic aspects of land construction to include professional service proposals, site mapping, topography, site design, site grading and earthwork estimation methods.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Implementation II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of LAR 438. To include site layout, landscape irrigation, area and landscape lighting, construction detailing, construction specification writing, bid proposals, and cost estimating.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LAR 438. Prerequisite or corequisite: LAR 540.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and five hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Planning and Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Medium- to large-scale design studies with emphasis placed on developing comprehensive and detailed solutions that demonstrate the application and integration of knowledge in site analysis, site design, planting design, construction, and design communication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Career Planning Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration and preparation for a landscape architecture internship.

htmlparse.Course.title: Site Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory, principles, and elements of site planning and design. Lectures, readings, short problems, and site visits dealing with site analysis, ecological consideration, grading drainage, circulation and parking, lighting, planting design, materials and details, management and maintenance, and cost factors.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ARCH 401 or concurrent with ARCH 401.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Seminar I
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current trends in landscape architecture and related fields by students, faculty, and invited speakers.  Required of all fourth- and fifth-year landscape architecture majors.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two 2-credit-hour seminars are required for a total of four hours for the BLA program.
May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Tech Module I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introductory theory, methods, and application of technological skills and support of concurrent landscape architecture studios and courses. Emphasis is on data collection and management and mapping and analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Tech Module II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introductory theory, methods, and application of technological skills and support of concurrent landscape architecture studios and courses. Emphasis is on CAD and 3-D modeling.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Tech Module III
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate theory, methods, and application of technological skills and support of concurrent landscape architecture studios and courses. Emphasis is on CAD and 3-D modeling and surveying.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Tech Module IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate theory, methods, and application of technological skills and support of concurrent landscape architecture studios and courses. Emphasis is on CAD and 3-D modeling and presentation graphics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Tech Module V
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced application of technological skills and support of concurrent landscape architecture studios and courses. Emphasis is on CAD and 3-D modeling, thematic mapping, and geoprocessing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Tech Module VI
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced project specific applications in data collection and management, CAD modeling, thematic mapping and GIS, and presentation graphics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Golf Course Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of golf course planning and design, including: history, management, design, facilities, aesthetics, and technical development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing within landscape architecture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Internship Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Confirmed employment with a landscape architecture, architecture, planning, or engineering sponsor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Presentation of a summary exhibition board and oral report by each student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design studies focused on community planning and design issues and their communication. Emphasis placed on responding to socio-cultural, political and natural site conditions at multiple scales ranging from large scale land use plans to detailed site plans and design communication.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LAR 442 and PLAN 315. Corequisite: LAR 502.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Implementation III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of LAR 439 to include large scale site design, road alignment, large area grading, soils and excavation methods, storm drainage, and utilities routing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Specialization Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Diverse topic-specific studios that are supported by corresponding graduate seminars. Focused exploration of landscape architecture practice.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Seminar II
htmlparse.Course.description: Literature review and discussion of current issues and trends in community planning and design. Readings and discussion in preparation for field trip.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in the MLA program. Prerequisite and corequisite: Admission to the LAR program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Professional Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Twenty-eight week internship with an approved landscape architecture, architecture, planning or engineering sponsor subject to the approval of the departmental faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Project Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Research and the development of a program directed toward the advancement of a capstone project for LAR 705 Master’s Project and Report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LAR 648, LAR 750. or Corequisite: LAR 750.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Off-Campus Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Off campus design studies fulfilled in an approved professional design office or in an approved international studies program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Landscape Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to and understanding of environmental planning, design and management of natural and social landscape systems at a regional, watershed, or ecosystem scale. Studies focus on systems inventory, analysis and impact assessment, and geoprocessing theory and methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive application of research and design study through individual studies approved by the department faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Lands and Natural Resources Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Legal aspects of land use and natural resource management on the federal public lands. A brief history of the acquisition and disposition of the public domain and a review of legal authority on the public lands are followed by an examination of key legal issues concerning the resources of water, minerals, timber, range, wildlife, recreation and wilderness.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course surveying the basic philosophies and methodologies of science and research as they apply to the field of landscape architecture. Special emphasis will be placed on those methods appropriate for investigating human response to the built environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Golf Course Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced methods and strategies of golf course and resort planning and design.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
One hour of lecture and three hours of lab a week.
May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Landscape Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Specific problems and/or reports in the area of landscape architecture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Advanced undergraduate or graduate standing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Italian Landscape Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of Italian culture, landscape and communities through analytical readings and/or drawings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of conventional and newly developing methods of professional design practice. Instruction in the relationships of architects, landscape architects, interior architects, and other professionals to users, clients, construction industry, society, government, and one another.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one hour recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Design Studio I
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary design studio involving large-scale design; projects with extensive time implementation sequence; responses to socioeconomic, cultural, environmental, and technical needs; and implementation strategies. Design methods are applied to selected urban areas of the Midwest.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PLAN 315 or equivalent and concurrent enrollment in PLAN 745.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Architecture Seminar III
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies and discussion of topics related to specialization studio.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Parks and Recreation Areas
htmlparse.Course.description: Site planning of national, state, municipal, and private parks, and specialized recreation areas.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design for Special Populations
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of exterior environment to accommodate the handicapped and disadvantaged individual.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Advanced undergraduate or graduate standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Resource Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: The determination of the impact of physical project design upon the natural and man-made environment. Studies of existing site conditions and projections of the effect of such projects upon the site and vicinity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Planting Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Special studies in advanced planting design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Landscape Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Special studies and design in advanced landscape architecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Landscape Architecture Construction
htmlparse.Course.description: Specialized study of large-scale landscape planning involving landscape construction and grading.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proposal Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of procedures of planning, design, scheduling, organization, and management of a landscape architecture research project.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LAR 438, LAR 648, LAR 725 or ARCH 725.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive application of research and design study through individual studies approved by the department faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Landscape Architecture
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigations in landscape architecture and related areas, of such caliber as to form the basis for a graduate thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in landscape architecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin and Greek for Scientists
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed specifically to provide students of the biological sciences with a background in Latin and Greek roots of scientific terms. emphasis on prefixes, suffixes, and word derivations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: No prior knowledge of either Latin or Greek is required. Course may not be applied toward the fulfillment of either language or humanities requirements for any degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory study of the structure of Latin.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation and completion of the study of the structure of Latin.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin III
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of Latin grammar and reading of an anthology of Roman prose and poetry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of the study of Latin syntax and grammar, based upon the reading of Roman prose and poetry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical Literature in Translation
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected readings in English from the works of such major classical authors as Homer, Euripides, Vergil, Horace, and Terence.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Latin
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Latin
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of the department head and instructor involved.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Leadership Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is organized to provide students with a broad overview of leadership theories, an introduction to ethical decision making, identification of personal leadership styles, and current societal issues for leaders.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Culture and Context in Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is organized to provide students with an opportunity to integrate the course and leadership experiences in light of contemporary issues in the study of leadership behavior across cultures and contexts. The course is based on the current research and writing that introduce and discuss the impact of culture and context on the concept of leadership and development of individuals as interculturally competent leaders.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership in Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an opportunity to practice leadership and followership in an experiential setting followed by an in-depth classroom discussion.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Nonprofit Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of nonprofit organization leadership by integrating concepts and theories with applied practice.  Students will demonstrate an understanding and application of competencies (knowledge and skills) necessary for professional success as a nonprofit organization leader.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LEAD 212, LEAD 350 and LEAD 405. Corequisite: Junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses issues related to leadership as it intersects with women’s studies scholarship, such as: women’s styles of leadership, women and competition, sexism in the workplace, gender differences in communication, and feminist models of leadership. This course will explore issues related to women’s leadership development in the theoretical contexts of leadership studies and women’s studies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Seminar in Leadership Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundation texts of leadership studies as well as current research will be highlighted. The goal of this course is to assist students in the integration of their academic leadership course work and leadership experiences in preparation for their roles as members of the contemporary work force.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonprofit Organization Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a capstone opportunity for students in the nonprofit leadership focus of the leadership studies minor to document and present their achievement of the foundation and professional development competencies required by American Humanics national certification in nonprofit leadership through coursework, co-curricular and work experiences, and their 300-hour internship experience.  Current texts focusing on the leadership of high impact nonprofit organizations will be incorporated into this process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: LEAD 212, LEAD 405, LEAD 420, LEAD 502-Ethical Dimensions of Leadership. Corequisite: Senior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Leadership Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in leadership studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Phonetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Description and classification of speech sounds according to point and manner of articulation. Transcription in the International Phonetic Association alphabet. Includes sounds of English, French, Spanish, German, and others.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Internal and comparative reconstruction of earlier forms of languages. Genetic relationships in language families, and various typological considerations. Includes French, Spanish, and others.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on a special topic in linguistics: decipherment of ancient writing systems, linguistics applied to the teaching of English or other languages, discourse analysis (especially of spoken texts), etc. Topic to be announced for semester in which offered.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable for credit on a different topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: The scientific study of language, with examples from English, Spanish, French, German, and others. Overview of language origins, phonetics, phonology, syntax, semantics, language acquisitions, dialects, language change, and writing systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The department is currently not able to offer coursework in linguistics. If you have questions about the linguistics program, please contact the department head of Communication Studies, Theatre and Dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Phonetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Description and classification of speech sounds according to point and manner of articulation. Transcription in the International Phonetic Association Alphabet. Includes sounds of English, French, Spanish, German, and others
htmlparse.Course.notes: The department is currently not able to offer coursework in linguistics. If you have questions about the linguistics program, please contact the department head of Communication Studies, Theatre and Dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Internal and comparative reconstruction of earlier forms of languages. Genetic relationships in language families, and various typological considerations. Includes French, Spanish, and others
htmlparse.Course.notes: The department is currently not able to offer coursework in linguistics. If you have questions about the linguistics program, please contact the department head of Communication Studies, Theatre and Dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on a special-topic in linguistics: decipherment of ancient writing systems, linguistics applied to the teaching of English or other languages, discourse analysis (especially of spoken texts), etc. Topic to be announced for semester in which offered.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated with a different topic.
The department is currently not able to offer coursework in linguistics. If you have questions about the linguistics program, please contact the department head of Communication Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Total Quality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of major topics related to Total Quality Management (TQM), including managerial and engineering aspects.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Technology for Business
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive view of the role of information technology in satisfying organizations’ information requirements. Problems and techniques concerning the management of responsive information systems with special attention to managers’ use of systems outputs. Cases and hands-on exercises emphasizing the use of information systems in decision making, information gathering and organizing, use of modeling techniques, and presentation of information.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Demonstrate competence in use of computer spreadsheets.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Technology for Business-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive view of the role of information technology in satisfying organizations’ information requirements. Problems and techniques concerning the management of responsive information systems with special attention to managers’ use of systems outputs. Cases and hands-on exercises emphasizing the use of information systems in decision making, information gathering and organizing, use of modeling techniques, and presentation of information.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Demonstrate competence in use of computer spreadsheets.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Systems Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Business-oriented problem solving using information technology for decision making. The course focuses on the utilization of state-of-the-art hardware, software, and programming tools for small systems development, networking, Internet, and world wide web.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Law I
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of law as it relates to business, including court procedures and systems, contracts, torts, agency and employment law, and business crimes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences
