htmlparse.Course.title: Business Law I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of law as it relates to business, including court procedures and systems, contracts, torts, agency and employment law, and business crimes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Law II
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of civil law as it affects commercial transactions, including corporations, partnerships, property, commercial paper, and secured transactions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Management Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: Managing organizations through fundamental processes of developing plans, structuring work relationships, coordinating effort and activities, directing and motivating subordinates, and controlling.  Also includes managerial roles and responsibilities, effective decision making, productivity improvement, and models and theories of human behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management Concepts-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Managing organizations through fundamental processes of developing plans, structuring work relationships, coordinating effort and activities, directing and motivating subordinates, and controlling.  Also includes managerial roles and responsibilities, effective decision making, productivity improvement, and models and theories of human behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Operations Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Description and analysis of problems related to the output of goods and services, operations planning and control, and systems management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Operations Management-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Description and analysis of problems related to the output of goods and services, operations planning and control, and systems management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 205 or MATH 220 and STAT 325 or STAT 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Storage Management Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive study providing an understanding of the varied components, concepts and principles of modern information storage management. Provides a comprehensive introduction to information storage technology which enables managers to make informed business decisions in an increasingly complex IT environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: ERP Configuration Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops an understanding of enterprise-wide computing system configuration issues. Focuses on strategic and operational uses of organizational data structured around a general theme of ERP configuration and business process integration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Eight weeks of business experience between junior and senior years designed to coordinate the interests of students and firms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450, MANGT 420, MKTG 400, completion of junior year, and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and analysis of current issues in management, including topics related to new theory, the practice of management, and management development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Studies in Management
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth analysis of special problems in management including study of current literature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing, consent of instructor, and 12 hours of management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizational Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of psychological and sociological variables important in understanding individual motivation, group functioning, change, creativity, and leadership in organizations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Quantitative techniques, models, and the integrative nature of management systems. Includes PERT, CPM, linear programming, and inventory models.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GENBA 166 or CIS 101, 102, 103 or 200 and lab, MANGT 420, MATH 205, and STAT 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operations Planning and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of concepts and understanding of planning and control systems for allocating resources and scheduling activities in business firms. To guide and coordinate the flow of materials, labor inputs, and goods and services through physical productive systems. Topics include: aggregate planning, master production scheduling, production activity planning and control, operations information systems, inventory control, material requirements planning, and total quality control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial and Labor Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic course in industrial and labor relations. Broad coverage of the institution of collective bargaining and its environment, the goals and operation of labor unions, the impact of unions on management, and labor relations law.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial and Labor Relations-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic course in industrial and labor relations. Broad coverage of the institution of collective bargaining and its environment, the goals and operation of labor unions, the impact of unions on management, and labor relations law.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Resources Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of the human resource systems and processes needed to achieve organizational effectiveness and strategic success. All key functional areas including human resource planning, staffing, performance management, employee development, and compensation are addressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Resources Management-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of the human resource systems and processes needed to achieve organizational effectiveness and strategic success. All key functional areas including human resource planning, staffing, performance management, employee development, and compensation are addressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Employment Law
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey course designed to acquaint students with the broad and controlling aspects of prominent laws which affect human resource management. Topics include ADA, ADEA, OSHA, Title VII, etc.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Quality
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of quality as a management philosophy through the study of ideas from contemporary quality philosophies of Deming, Juran, and Taguchi. Statistical process control charting as a process and quality improvement tool and product and process design as important components of quality.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizational Training and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: The process of training and developing the human resources in organizations, which includes organizational diagnosis, needs assessment, program design, appropriate methodologies, program implementation, transfer of training, and the evaluation of program effectiveness. Current trends in the content and process of training and development activities are also examined.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Diversity in the Workplace
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a framework for understanding how diversity interfaces with all aspects of business. Topics will include multicultural competencies, global diversity trends, theories for managing diversity, personal and organizational communication, diversity recruitment and retention, and other management practices for a diverse workforce and customer base.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Systems for Finance and Investment Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An integrated course examining the interrelationship between finance/investment management and information technology taught using a mixture of theory/concepts and hands-on activities. Topics include spreadsheet design and use in finance and investments, decision support systems and artificial intelligence used in risk analysis, financial database design, and information technologies used to transmit financial and investment information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced application of concepts learned in information systems fundamentals course.  Focus on the application and integration of different design methodologies using structured programming languages, and various structured design techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Local Area Networks
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of telecommunications and its impact on business organizations. Coverage of networking models, hardware, software, distributed systems, and standards issues. Emphasis on Local Area Networks (LANs) and hands-on project management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Strategy
htmlparse.Course.description: An integration of previous courses through the study of problems in policy formulation and implementation. Cases and current topics with emphasis on strategic planning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450, MANGT 420, MKTG 400, and senior level students admitted in a College of Business Administration degree track (major).
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to seniors or non-business graduate students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business, Government, and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: The interrelationships and interactions of business with the social, political, and economic institutions. The impact of changes in the external environment on business and the managerial task.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450, MANGT 420, MKTG 400, and senior level students admitted in a College of Business Administration degree track (major).
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Entrepreneurship
htmlparse.Course.description: Social entrepreneurship is one of the fastest growing disciplines to emerge in management and is increasingly getting recognition as an important policy strategy at the national level. It is concerned with how to engage the talents and tools of professional entrepreneurship to address critical social needs both within and beyond the market. Social entrepreneurship is situated within a framework of social institutions, organizations, and entrepreneurial change in response to human and citizen rights and needs. The relevant social institutions include government, the market, education, philanthropy, and the family. Organizations may be for profit or non-profit, but all organizations, regardless of their legal structure, are seen to have a social purpose. Several non-market venues for sustainable social change will be examined in addition to the traditional delivery of goods and services through the market. The course provides a number of crucial tools and resources that may better orient and equip the prospective social entrepreneur to identify and act on opportunities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Compensation and Performance Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth critique of compensation system design and performance management strategies needed to attract, retain, develop and motivate the human capital required for organizational effectiveness and strategic success.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Human Resource Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth analysis of selected topics in human resource management including study of current research and literature.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Constraint Management and Continuous Improvement
htmlparse.Course.description: The intent of this course is to provide an overview of the application of Theory of Constraints (TOC). TOC suggests that every process or system has at least one constraint that prevents the operation from being more efficient. TOC offers methodologies that are specifically developed to identify and manage constraints to enable the operation to achieve its goals. Students will be taught the skills required for the identification and management of constraints within an operation system.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Project Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an in-depth coverage of project management concepts and methodologies required for service and manufacturing operations. Topics to be covered include, but are not limited to: project selection and evaluation, project dynamics, motivation and evaluation of project team members, project scheduling, project budgeting, and project closure.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systems Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of systems analysis techniques viewing information systems as an integral component of organizational strategic planning. Emphasis on systems planning, use of CASE tools, process and data modeling, quality and systems reengineering.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Supply Chain Planning and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides a framework of how the demand side of the supply chain should interface with supply side. The focus will be on integrating specific tools and emerging issues including strategy, forecasting, inventory management, risk pooling, coordination, information sharing, and global supply chain management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Procurement, Logistics and Supply Chain Design
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses the interrelationship between operations and other functions required to deliver value to the end customer of a supply chain. Topics include major processes to manage the flow of goods, services and information through core functions such as logistics, operations and purchasing in the supply chains of both goods and service providers.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MANGT 421, or with permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Analytics and Data Mining
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth study of a broad range of topics and techniques in business intelligence (BI), data mining, and database marketing (DM). Emphasis on fundamentals of relational database management, data warehousing as a business practice, customer relationship management (CRM), customer segmentation, various data mining techniques, data visualization, business performance management, use of scorecard/dashboard, and advanced BI and data mining software tools.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applications of Data Models in Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of interrelationships between managers and database designers from the user’s perspective. Database design strategies for the functional areas of business such as accounting, marketing, and manufacturing management with a focus on making data responsive to changing information needs and supportive or organizational plans and goals.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systems Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the interrelationship of organizational information systems and how these systems support managerial decision making. The analytical/ programming tools used to perform the systems administration function will be implemented through a term project.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of business decision parameters and strategy in a multinational context. The influence of cultural, economic, political, and social differences on decision making and the operation of American enterprises in the international environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450, MANGT 420, MKTG 400, or FINAN 710.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Algebra
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparatory course for MATH 100. Includes arithmetic (signed numbers, polynomials, algebraic fractions, exponents, and roots), solutions to equations (linear, quadratic, polynomial, root, and fractional), graphs (linear and quadratic), and geometry (area, perimeter, and the Pythagorean Theorem).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two units of mathematics in grades 9-12 and a College Algebra (PROB ≥ C) of 43 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 7 on the mathematics placement test; or a score of at least 26 on the arithmetic placement test.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Algebra-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparatory course for MATH 100. Includes arithmetic (signed numbers, polynomials, algebraic fractions, exponents, and roots), solutions to equations (linear, quadratic, polynomial, root, and fractional), graphs (linear and quadratic), and geometry (area, perimeter, and the Pythagorean Theorem).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two units of mathematics in grades 9-12 and a College Algebra (PROB ≥ C) of 43 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 7 on the mathematics placement test; or a score of at least 26 on the arithmetic placement test.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Algebra Review-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Supplemental algebra lab that is required to be taken in conjunction with MATH 010.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week. The student will receive 2 hours credit which will not count toward graduation.

htmlparse.Course.title: College Algebra Review-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Supplemental algebra lab to be taken in conjunction with MATH 100 for students who need additional instruction in algebra.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Two hours recitation a week.
Students are placed in this course on the basis of their score on the placement exam. The student will receive 2 hours credit which will not count toward graduation.

htmlparse.Course.title: College Algebra
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental concepts of algebra; algebraic equations and inequalities; functions and graphs; zeros of polynomial functions; exponential and logarithmic functions; systems of equations and inequalities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: B or better in MATH 010; or two years of high school algebra and a College Algebra (PROB≥C) of 60 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 18 on the mathematics placement exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: College Algebra-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental concepts of algebra; algebraic equations and inequalities; functions and graphs; zeros of polynomial functions; exponential and logarithmic functions; systems of equations and inequalities.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: B or better in MATH 010; or two years of high school algebra and a College Algebra (PROB≥C) of 60 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 18 on the mathematics placement exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plane Trigonometry
htmlparse.Course.description: Trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions; trigonometric identities and equations; applications involving right triangles and applications illustrating the laws of sines and cosines.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 100; or two years of high school algebra and a score of 25 or more on Enhanced ACT mathematics; or a score of at least 20 on the mathematics placement exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plane Trigonometry-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions; trigonometric identities and equations; applications involving right triangles and applications illustrating the laws of sines and cosines.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 100; or two years of high school algebra and a score of 25 or more on Enhanced ACT mathematics; or a score of at least 20 on the mathematics placement exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Plane Trigonometry-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Trigonometry and inverse trigonometric functions, trigonometric identities and equations; applications involving right triangles and applications illustrating the laws of sines and cosines. Emphasis is placed on applications to engineering technology, tool and machine design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Students are placed in this course on the basis of their score on the College of Technology and Aviation math placement exam or ACT score.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Contemporary Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Mathematics as used in the contemporary world. Combinatorics and probability; descriptions of data; graph theory; and various additional topics selected by the individual instructors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Mathematics Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics of special interest to undergraduates in mathematics, including orientation to the mathematics curriculum, possible careers in mathematics, and cultural and professional aspects of mathematics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Calculus and Linear Algebra
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to calculus and linear algebra concepts that are particularly useful to the study of economics and business administration with special emphasis on working problems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100 with C or better grade (College Algebra in the preceding semester is recommended).

htmlparse.Course.title: General Calculus and Linear Algebra-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to calculus and linear algebra concepts that are particularly useful to the study of economics and business administration with special emphasis on working problems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100 with C or better grade (College Algebra in the preceding semester is recommended).

htmlparse.Course.title: Technical Calculus I
htmlparse.Course.description: A condensed course in analytic geometry and differential calculus with an emphasis on applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: B or better in MATH 100 and C or better in MATH 150; or three years of college preparatory mathematics including trigonometry and a Calculus I (PROB≥C) of 55 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 26 on the mathematics placement test.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technical Calculus II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of MATH 210 to include integral calculus with an emphasis on application.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 210.

htmlparse.Course.title: Calculus I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Course content includes a brief review of pre-calculus materials of algebra and trigonometry, functions, limits, differentiation, applications of differentiation, integration, and applications of the definite integral. Theory is presented in a style tailored for first-semester students of mathematics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 100; and MATH 150 or MATH 151.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Calculus II-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: An extension of MATH 215, Calculus I, to include integration, differentiation, and applications of transcendent functions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus I
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytic geometry, differential and integral calculus of algebraic and trigonometric functions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: B or better in MATH 100 and C or better in MATH 150; or three years of college preparatory mathematics including trigonometry and Calculus I (PROB≥C) of 55 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 26 on the mathematics placement exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytic geometry, differential and integral calculus of algebraic and trigonometric functions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: B or better in MATH 100 and C or better in MATH 150; or three years of college preparatory mathematics including trigonometry and Calculus I (Prob≥C) of 55 or more on the ACT assessment by K-State; or a score of at least 26 on the mathematics placement exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 220 to include transcendental functions, techniques of integration, and infinite series.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 220.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus II-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 220 to include transcendental functions, techniques of integration, and infinite series.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 220.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 221 to include functions of more than one variable.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 221.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Differential Equations
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary techniques for solving ordinary differential equations and applications to solutions of problems in science and engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: C or better in MATH 222.

htmlparse.Course.title: Finite Applications of Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Systems of equations, vector operations, linear algebra, and linear programming. Practice in setting up, solving, and interpreting mathematical models which arise in social sciences and business.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computational Number Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in number theory selected from: divisibility, primes, modular arithmetic and special types of numbers. Emphasis is on computations. Primarily for prospective elementary school teachers of mathematics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematics for Elementary School Teachers I
htmlparse.Course.description: Mathematical problem solving and reasoning, development of whole number concepts and the whole number system, computation and estimation with whole numbers, number patterns and number theory, integers, fractions and rational numbers, decimals and real numbers, geometry and measurement.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For education majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intuitive Geometry
htmlparse.Course.description: Geometric figures and patterns, properties of geometric figures, transformation and coordinate geometry, measurement.

htmlparse.Course.title: Academic Excellence Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides enriched supplementary instruction to selected students enrolled in selected lower-division courses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in qualifying lower-division mathematics course and written permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for different qualifying courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Seminar in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts and Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Topics in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading courses in advanced undergraduate mathematics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for topic undertaken and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematical Theory of Interest
htmlparse.Course.description: Extensive introduction to the mathematical theory of interest with applications to the field of actuarial science. Prepares students to take the second professional examination administered by the Society of Actuaries and the Casualty Actuarial Society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematical Foundations of Actuarial Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to calculus-based applications and models with an emphasis on applications to insurance. Prepares students to take the first professional examination administered by the Society of Actuaries and Casualty Actuarial Society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 222 and STAT 510 or concurrent enrollment in STAT 510.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Number Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Divisibility properties of integers, prime numbers, congruences, multiplicative functions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Discrete Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Combinatorics and graph theory. Topics selected from counting principles, permutations and combinations, the inclusion-exclusion principle, recurrence relations, trees, graph coloring, Eulerian and Hamiltonian circuits, block designs, and Ramsey Theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Algebraic Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Properties of groups, rings, domains and fields. Examples selected from subsystems of the complex numbers, elementary number theory, and solving equations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Modern Algebra
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the basic algebraic systems, viz., groups, rings, integral domains, and fields, often drawing from elementary number theory. Special emphasis will be given to methods of theorem proving.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
htmlparse.Course.description: Finite-dimensional vector spaces, linear transformations and their matrix representations, dual spaces, invariant subspaces, Euclidean and unitary spaces, solution spaces for systems of linear equations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of sets and sequences, neighborhoods, limit points, convergence, open and closed sets in the real line and in the plane, the concept of a continuous function.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Real Number System
htmlparse.Course.description: An extensive development of number systems, with emphasis upon structure. Includes systems of natural numbers, integers, rational numbers, and real numbers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Ordinary Differential Equations
htmlparse.Course.description: First-order scalar equations: geometry of integral curves, symmetries and exactly soluble equations; existence, uniqueness and dependence on parameters with examples. Systems of first-order equations, Hamilton’s equations and classical mechanics, completely integrable systems. Higher-order equations. Initial value problems for second order linear equations, series solutions and special functions. Boundary value problems with applications. Introduction to perturbation theory and stability.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Matrix Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Matrix algebra, solutions to systems of linear equations, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, linear programming, approximation techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Topology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the basic topological concepts. Topological spaces, metric spaces, closure, interior, and frontier operators, subspaces, separation and countability properties, bases, subbases, convergence, continuity, homeomorphisms, compactness, connectedness, quotients and products. The course will include a brief introduction to proof techniques and set theory. Other topics in topology also may be included.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the development of mathematics from ancient to modern times.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Geometry
htmlparse.Course.description: Euclidean, non-Euclidean, and finite geometries; role of axioms; practice proving theorems in a formal system; synthetic, metric, and transformation approaches to Euclidean geometry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mathematics for Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics of importance for teachers of mathematics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Courses on special topics to be taught on sufficient demand.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Digital Image Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic ideas and techniques in digital image processing stem from mathematics, engineering, and computer science. This course focuses on ideas and techniques such as spatial filtering, frequency filtering (Fast Fourier Transform), scale filtering (Fast Wavelet Transform), and their applications to image compression standards and image recognition. The course will place equal emphasis on the mathematical ideas and their applications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Complex Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Complex analytic functions and power series, complex integrals. Taylor and Laurent expansions, residues, Laplace transformations, and the inversion integral.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Partial Differential Equations
htmlparse.Course.description: Orthogonal functions, Fourier series, boundary value problems in partial differential equations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Calculus I
htmlparse.Course.description: Functions of one variable; limits, continuity, differentiability, Riemann-Stieltjes integral, sequences, series, power series, improper integrals.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Calculus II
htmlparse.Course.description: Functions of several variables; partial differentiation and implicit function theorems, curvilinear coordinates, differential geometry of curves and surfaces, vectors and vector fields, line and surface integrals, double and triple integrals, Green’s Theorem, Stokes’ Theorem, and Divergence Theorem.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dynamics, Chaos, and Fractals
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to one dimensional real and complex dynamics: attracting and repelling cycles, iterations of quadratic polynomials, bifurcation theory, chaos, Hausdorff measures and Hausdorff dimension, fractals, Julia and Fatou sets, and Mandelbrot sets.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Numerical Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Error analysis, root finding, interpolation, approximation of functions, numerical integration and differentiation, systems of linear equations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 221, a computer language, and either MATH 515 or 551.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Numerical Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of MATH 655. Linear programming, numerical solutions of differential equations, and the use of standard packages for the solutions of applied problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematical Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction of modeling procedures. Case studies in mathematical modeling projects from physical, biological, and social sciences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Four mathematics courses numbered 500 or above.

htmlparse.Course.title: Set Theory and Logic
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to logic, mathematical proof, and elementary set theory. Topics include elementary logic, relations, partitions, functions, cartesian products, disjoint unions, orders, construction of the natural numbers, ordinal and cardinal numbers, the Axiom of Choice, and transfinite induction. Special emphasis will be given to proving theorems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Topology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to axiomatic topology including many examples and a study of metric spaces, quotient spaces, compactness, connectedness, local properties, separation axioms, the fundamental group, and the classification of covering spaces.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Topology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary topics in topology, which may include: basic facts about topological and differentiable manifolds, concepts from the knot theory, PL topology, tilings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 633 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the Theory of Groups
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to abstract group theory, permutation groups, homomorphisms, direct products, Abelian groups. Jordan-Holder and Sylow theorems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computational Math
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics from complex analysis, vector calculus, higher-dimensional calculus, ordinary differential equations, liner algebra, and geometry of curves.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Numbers
htmlparse.Course.description: Divisibility, congruences, multiplicative functions, number theory from an algebraic viewpoint, quadratic reciprocity, Diophantine equations, prime numbers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Category Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Categories, duality, special morphisms, functors, natural transformations, limits and colimits, adjoint situations, and applications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Category Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Set-valued functors and concrete categories, factorization structures, algebraic and topological functors, categorical completions, Abelian categories.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Applied Matrix Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: A development of the concepts of eigenvalues by considering applications in differential equations, quadratic forms and estimation problems. Supporting topics include the Jordan canonical form, functions of matrices, vector and matrix norms, convex sets, with selected topics from the theory and application of the simplex algorithm, Markov chains, Leslie population models, Leontieff input-output model.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Mathematics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of numerical methods for linear algebra.  Perturbation theory and error analysis, matrix factorizations, solutions to linear systems, least-squares, problems, techniques for special matrix structures, symmetric and nonsymmetric eigenvalue problems, iterative and direct methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 515 or MATH 551 or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Mathematics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Linear operator theory applied to matrix, integral and differential equations. Spectral theory, the Fredholm Alternative, least-squares and pseudo-inverses. Banach and Hilbert space techniques, Fourier series and wavelets, theory of distributions, Green’s functions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 240 and MAT 515 or 551; or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Recitation 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Real Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Limits, continuity, uniform convergence, completeness, differentiation, Riemann integration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of functions of several variables, including differentiability, partial differentiability, maxima and minima, inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem, integration, Fubini’s theorem.

htmlparse.Course.title: Abstract Algebra I
htmlparse.Course.description: Groups, rings, fields, vector spaces and their homomorphisms. Elementary Galois theory and decomposition theorems for linear transformations on a finite dimensional vector space.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 512 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Abstract Algebra II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 730.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 730 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Calculus of Variation
htmlparse.Course.description: Necessary conditions and the Euler-Lagrange equations. Hamilton-Jacobi theory, Noether’s theorems, direct methods, applications to geometry and physics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
htmlparse.Course.description: First-order equations and applications, second-order equations and oscillation theorems, series solutions and special functions, Sturm Liouville problems, linear systems, autonomous systems and phase plane analysis, stability, Liapunov’s method, periodic solutions, perturbation and asymptotic methods, existence and uniqueness theorems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dynamic Modeling Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics to include equilibrium and stability, limit circles, reaction-diffusion, and shock phenomena, Hopf bifurcation and cusp catastrophes, chaos and strange attractors, bang-bang principle. Applications from physical and biological sciences and engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematical Control Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Mathematical analysis of dynamical systems governed by differential equations and their optimal processes, feedback, and filtering. Topics include: dynamical systems with controls, axioms of control systems, input-output behaviors, stability and instability, reachability and controllability, dynamic feedback and stabilization, optimal control processes, piecewise constant control and bang-bang principle, Pontryagin maximum principle, tracking, filtering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Probability Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the mathematical theory of probability. Material covered includes combinatorial probability, random variables, independence, expectations, limit theorems, Markov chains, random walks, and martingales.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Differential Geometry
htmlparse.Course.description: Curves and surfaces in Euclidean spaces, differential forms and exterior differentiation, differential invariants and frame fields, uniqueness theorems for curves and surfaces, geodesics, introduction to Riemannian geometry, some global theorems, minimal surfaces.

htmlparse.Course.title: Combinatorial Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Permutations, combinations, inversion formulas, generating functions, partitions, finite geometries, difference sets, and other topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mathematics for Secondary School Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics of importance in the preparation of secondary school teachers to teach modern mathematics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Courses on special topics to be taught on sufficient demand.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Major Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: An orientation to studies in mass communications for pre-majors. Provides an overview of the curriculum electives, extracurricular activities in mass communications, the advising process, and career options.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mass Communication in Society
htmlparse.Course.description: A historical, social, legal, economic, and technological study of mass communication and its role and impact in society.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to majors and non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Journalism in a Free Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasizes the role of journalism in building an informed citizenry in a democracy, serving as a watchdog of government, providing news in a context that gives meaning to the people, and being socially responsible in the midst of a changing economic structure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to majors and non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Communication in Society
htmlparse.Course.description: History and social impact of the World Wide Web as a mass communication medium, with emphasis on applications in information dissemination, such as entertainment, advertising and public relations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to majors and non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Advertising
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the advertising field and its relationship to marketing and journalism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to majors and non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: KSDB-FM Audition
htmlparse.Course.description: Production of music, news, and/or sports audio to be evaluated by faculty in preparing students for an on-air position with student station, KSDB-FM.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Public Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Contemporary persuasive social science principles, processes, and issues involved in the management of communications between an organization and its publics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to majors and non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: News and Feature Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction in information gathering and writing techniques for the various media.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of MC 110 with a grade of C or better and a passing score on JMC composition skills test.

htmlparse.Course.title: Visual Communication in Mass Media
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of concepts and theories of communicating through visual means, including the physiology and psychology of seeing and perceiving; the basics of design and aesthetic principles; and examination of the uses of these concepts and principles within the mass media.

htmlparse.Course.title: Writing for the Electronic Media
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of writing formats and the preparation of written material for news, commercial and promotional announcements, and entertainment programs for the electronic media.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 110 with minimum grade of C or better, passing score on JMC composition skills test and 2.5 GPA upon completion of 12 or more credit hours, majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advertising Strategy & Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Writing for the various media to reach or achieve advertising objectives. Setting communication goals within the context of writing to persuade and inform mass audiences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of MC 110 & MC 120 with grade of “C” or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Editing
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of micro and macro journalistic editing for print and digital media including industry standards, practices, and ethics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital News
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic audio, video, and web reporting, writing, and production.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concepts of Electronic Media Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers aesthetics, vocabulary, and pre-production planning for audio, video and multimedia production, with an emphasis on developing critical analysis skills.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200, MC 211, or MC 221 with grade of C or better, and a 2.5 GPA upon completion of 30 or more hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Relations Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines various forms of contemporary public relations writing, with special emphasis on preparation of messages for different media and audiences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 180 and MC 200 with grades of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in the study of mass communication principles and practices.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced News Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasizes reportorial principles and practices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Audio News Production
htmlparse.Course.description: The fundamental production skills associated with producing audio news, including basic news writing, audio recording, and editing techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sports Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of today’s sports media environment with an emphasis on reporting, writing, and producing sports stories for audio, video, print, Internet, and other platforms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer-Assisted Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: Issues and practices associated with using the computer as a tool in news gathering and data analysis, as well as other advanced reporting applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Photography for Mass Media
htmlparse.Course.description: Basics of composition, exposure, cropping and editorial judgment using converted analog and digital images and image-building software. Introduction to uses of digital photography in mass media such as newspapers, magazines, brochures and web sites.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 110 with a grade of C or better, or permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: News Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Design for both print and web versions of a news product, with emphasis on understanding the news in order to design visual components to enhance audience comprehension.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 241 with grade of C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students work on the Kansas State Collegian about six hours each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Relations Strategy and Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Public relations planning, including theory, techniques and models related to setting long-range and short-term goals and objectives; designing strategies and tactics; segmenting publics and designing effective messages; identifying appropriate message channels; communicating with top management; developing budgets; issue management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 180 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Relations Case Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of historic and contemporary public relations situations using a case-method approach. The course focuses on strategic planning and implementation by public relations managers. Students learn to assess and establish criteria for public relations programs under a variety of conditions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 180 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Media Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical work in student media operations of the school under supervision of an instructor, preparing students for work in the various media industries. Topics include newspaper, radio, yearbook, and video.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour of credit per semester, which equals a total of 120 work hours supervised by the instructor. May be repeated for a maximum of four hours. Enrollment requires a study and work plan approved by the instructor of record.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strategic Communication Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods and procedures involved in the formulation of a research problems particular to strategic communication.  Examines the process of inquiry, elements of the scientific method, the design of research in quantitative and qualitative studies, as well as ethics of conducting research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 2.5 GPA on 30 credit hours, MC 120 or MC 180, completion of a mathematics or statistics course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Seminar in Mass Communications

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Affairs Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigative reporting of local, state and national affairs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 303 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Digital News
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced techniques of reporting, writing, and producing news for audio, video, and Web-related media.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 251 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Producing Digital News
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced production course that emphasizes producing and directing techniques for video news and other information-oriented programming.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 406 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Yearbook Editing and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, editing, layout, writing, and financing a publication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Photojournalism
htmlparse.Course.description: The materials, principles, and processes of photography directed toward visual reporting in newspapers, magazines and other media.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 331 with grades of C or better, or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lectures, demonstrations and laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advertising Sales
htmlparse.Course.description: Advertising sales applied to print and electronic media. Includes designing and writing retail ads, campaign development, production and sales techniques. Legal, ethical, and regulatory issues covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 120 or MKTG 400 with a grade of C or better and a 2.5 GPA upon completion of 30 or more hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Magazine and Feature Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation of feature stories and articles; techniques of market analysis, and marketing of articles written in course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Magazine Production
htmlparse.Course.description: The practical application of theory to writing, editing, graphic reproduction, layout and management of magazines.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advertising Media Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: The selecting, scheduling, selling and buying of the various advertising media.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 221 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: KSDB Participation
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised participation in the university’s student FM radio station, emphasizing music announcing, board production, recorded production, news and sports play-by-play, and FCC operating regulations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Web Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Develop expertise in the construction of web sites with a solid emphasis on the appropriateness, integrity and quality of the content provided.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 200, MC 211 or MC 221 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Law of Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the legal issues relating to mass communication. Emphasis on defamation, privacy, copyright, administrative controls and other areas related to the mass media.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and MC 110 with a grade of C or better, or permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Audio and Video Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on aesthetics of audio and video writing, producing, directing, sound recording, lighting, camera work, editing, and mixing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 251 with grade of C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Field and studio assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advertising and Public Relations Design and Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Conceptual and strategic exploration of the process and effects that public relations and advertising messages visually convey to target audiences in a converged media environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC majors and minors and AG comm majors only, MC 221 or MC 280 with a grade of C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course includes a weekly two-hour lecture and a weekly two-hour studio component.

htmlparse.Course.title: Video Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of field and studio production, video editing and using video for web-based applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 276 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mass Communication Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Student works under professional and faculty supervision. Internships must be approved ahead by internship coordinator. with reports from student and supervisor required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Instructor permission. MC 280 and MC 380 or 382 for public relations students. MC 456 for advertising students. MC 406 for electronic journalism/digital media students. MC 303 for print journalism/digital media students.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members on the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Web Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Management of websites with a focus on solutions to the problems generated by vast quantities of information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervision of School Publications
htmlparse.Course.description: A methods course for those planning to teach secondary or community college journalism courses and advise high school or community college publications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication, Diversity, and Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Media-related social issues including race, sexuality, disability and class that reflect diversity in the U.S. and global societies, and the role of media and other communication strategies in enabling and facilitating social change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Media
htmlparse.Course.description: Challenges facing smaller-market news media, including rural and small-town economics, technological issues, local audience composition, access and accountability, community involvement, and job prospects in community media.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fund Raising in Non-Profit Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of public relations in non-profit organizations. Focuses on why and how people give to philanthropic causes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 280 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Advertising and Public Relations Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on individual enhancement of creative concept development, advanced technical skills, and portfolio development. Self-directed projects allow in-depth knowledge, understanding and practice of advertising and public relations production methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 456 or MC 480 with grade of B or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Mass Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Growth and development of media and media technology in the United States and their economic, political and social significance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Mass Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative study of world media systems and the role of mass communication in national development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethics in Mass Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Making ethical decisions in mass media fields and the principles on which those decisions are based.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multimedia Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of creating cross-platform multimedia productions, utilizing computer-based audio, video and graphics. Special emphasis on working with clients and preplanning.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Any of the following: MC 276, MC 303, MC 456 or MC 480 with a C or better, or instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mass Communications and Political Campaigns
htmlparse.Course.description: The roles of journalism, advertising and public relations in political campaigns.  Examines campaign communication strategies, staffing, and the role of political consultants.  Analyzes how voter decision making is affected by mass communications and how voters develop attitudes about candidates and issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 110 and either MC 200, MC 211, MC 221, or MC 280.

htmlparse.Course.title: Convergence Reporting
htmlparse.Course.description: Reporting, writing, and producing across multi-media platforms. Students produce stories for submission in multiple formats to be submitted to campus media outlets, including the Collegian, the e-Collegian, the Royal Purple yearbook, KSDB-FM and the Cable Channel 8 newscast.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 303 or MC 406, senior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Media Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Issues, ethics and practices in managing media companies, with special emphasis on problems and practices, in converged media operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lecture

htmlparse.Course.title: Issues in Mass Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in mass communication practices and principles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Producing and Directing for Video
htmlparse.Course.description: Practice experience in planning, producing, directing, and posting studio and field video productions. Special emphasis on advanced production techniques and managing project development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 276 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economics of Mass Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the various economic models applicable to the media industries and application of basic economic concepts and analytical tools to explain media industry behaviors, evaluate business strategies of media firms and assess the merits of public policies toward the media industries.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender Issues and the Media
htmlparse.Course.description: The portrayal of women and men by the media, and media employment issues based on gender.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and one course in MC or Women’s Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Advertising
htmlparse.Course.description: Issues associated with advertising in a global environment, including cultural impact, international media, regulation, ethics and digital media technologies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 120 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Media Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines management skills necessary for establishing, maintaining and evaluating a media relations program. Discussion includes working with journalists, conducting media events, preparing spokespersons and developing crisis communications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 280 with a grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advertising Campaigns
htmlparse.Course.description: The managerial development and execution of consumer, industrial, and institutional advertising campaigns.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 396, MC 446, and MC 456 with grades of C or better, senior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Relations Campaigns
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of an organization’s public relations needs. Includes researching the situation, analyzing audiences, and preparing strategic plans for approved clients.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 396 and MC 480 with grades of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Media Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: The principles, planning, and development of radio-television-cable programs, schedules and related regulation.

htmlparse.Course.title: International and Intercultural Public Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Global diversity in business, governmental, and charitable organizations and the demographic changes within countries and across communities that affect the role and practice of public relations worldwide.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 280 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Managing Integrated Strategic Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of managerial decision making in advertising and public relation programs. Emphasizes strategic and logical thinking in the decision-making process. Theories and practices from media management, social/cognitive psychology and integrated communication.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 120 or MC 180 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advertising and Social Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines social, ethical and legal issues and problems facing the advertising industry, and its relationship with the consumer.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing with a 2.5 GPA and completion of MC 120.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of the literature of mass communications.  Three significant books per credit hour with written analysis and oral presentation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing and consent of supervisory instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Public Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Contemporary topics in public relations practice, theory, and research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MC 280, MC 380, MC 382 with grades of C or better.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for problem undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Growth and development of the news media and mass communication media and systems in the United States and their economic, political, and social significance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing, or instructor permission with a 2.5 GPA and completion of a United States history course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Combines theoretical discussions with practical experience regarding communications about environmental issues and provides introduction to natural and applied science topics related to the communications plan.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethics in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Moral analysis, argument, and decision-making by the mass communicator.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing, or instructor permission with a 2.5 GPA and completion of a philosophy course.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative study of world media systems and the role of mass communications in national development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing, or instructor permission with a 2.5 GPA.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar on Issues of the Media
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of philosophical and technological advances in mass communications with emphasis on projected patterns of future growth and development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or instructor permission with a 2.5 GPA.

htmlparse.Course.title: Colloquium in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of selected topics in mass communications research and practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once for credit when topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Mass Communication Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of mass communication freedoms and limitations in such areas as defamation, privacy, copyright, censorship, obscenity, and advertising and electronic media regulation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strategic Health Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of effective communication through mass media and other communication strategies in health promotion and behavior change.  Includes the theories and strategies used to promote public health messages, services, or products for multicultural audiences, with a focus on human, environment and animal health.  Legal, ethical issues and gender issues in health communication will be given special attention.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing, or instructor permission with a 2.5 GPA.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication and Risk
htmlparse.Course.description: Promotes understanding of strategic communication and media as tools to prepare, mitigate, and respond to threats to public health and safety.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing, or instructor permission with a 2.5 GPA.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Science
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lecture

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of major communication theories as they relate to mass communications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing, or instructor permission with 2.5 GPA.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Journalism Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised practical work in professional journalism and mass communications. Includes laboratory investigation, field work, and internships.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of research methods used in the study of the mass media.

htmlparse.Course.title: Issues in Media Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar in the analysis of issues in media management and media economics research and practices.  Issues include leadership in converged media organizations, market research in media organizations, motivational behaviors in media organizations and developments in new technology as they relate to managing media organizations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the mechanical engineering curriculum and profession. Orientation for successful transition of new students to college life. Engineering approach to problem solving and computer use in all areas of mechanical engineering. Exchange of information regarding academic, technical, social, ethical, and professional matters between students, faculty, and practicing professionals.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Must be taken during the student’s first fall semester in mechanical engineering.
Two hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: Technical sketching, study of basic principles of projective geometry, multiview drawings, pictorials, reading and interpreting drawings, introduction to CAD, sectioning, dimensioning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected in consultation with instructor. Intended for interdisciplinary studies or innovative studies in mechanical engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Applications in Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The development and application of computer techniques to the problems of design and analysis in mechanical engineering, including computer programming (abstraction and problem solving; algorithms; control structures; input/output; functions; arrays and array processing).
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Research in Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problem selected with approval of faculty advisor. Open to students in the College of Engineering honors program.  A report is presented orally and in writing during the last semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Vector treatment of kinematics, Newton’s Laws, work and energy, impulse and momentum, with applications to problems of particle and rigid body motion.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 333. Prerequisite or concurrent: MATH 240.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermodynamics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Properties of the pure substance. The first and second laws of thermodynamics. Gas mixtures and psychrometry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermodynamics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Thermodynamics I. Energy analysis, thermodynamic cycles, generalized thermodynamic relations, and reactive systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Design I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the design and analysis of machine elements. Emphasis on materials, loads, stress, strain, deflection, failure theories, and finite element analysis. Applications include design and analysis of shafts, gears, and fasteners, weldments, springs, bearings.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Measurement and Instrumentation Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of mechanical engineering measurements, instrumentation, and computer-based data acquisition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and analysis of machine elements. Applications include design and analysis of bearings, gears, shafts, clutches, brakes, belt and chain drives, and hydraulic fluid power.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Control of Mechanical Systems I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to modeling and control of dynamic systems encountered by mechanical engineers. Topics include basic linear systems modeling and analysis; feedback control; time response and stability of dynamic systems; introduction to root locus and frequency response design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 240, ME 400, and ME 512. Prerequisite or concurrent: ME 535 or NE 612.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fluid Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical properties; fluid statics; dynamics of ideal and real fluids (for incompressible and compressible flow); impulse and momentum; laws of similitude; dimensional analysis; flow in pipes; flow in open channels; flow about immersed objects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ME 512. Prerequisite or concurrent: ME 513.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Heat Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of conduction, convection, and radiation; principles of heat exchanger design and dimensional analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interdisciplinary Industrial Design Projects I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to design theory, project management, team dynamics and socio-economic context of design, etc.; application of design principles, engineering analysis and experimental methods to an industrial interdisciplinary design project involving design, analysis, fabrication and testing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ME 535 or NE 612, ME 571. Prerequisite or concurrent: ENGL 415, or instructor approval.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation and six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interdisciplinary Industrial Design Projects II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of ME 574 with emphasis on in-depth project experience.  Also, discussion of career planning, graduate school, ethics, technical/professional societies, and engineering licensing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and five hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Finite Element Applications in Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The application of the finite element method to the solution of engineering problems. Topics include introductions to the methods, linear elastic stress analysis, thermal analysis, and modeling limitations and errors. Commercial computer codes are used in the applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 533. Prerequisite or concurrent: ME 573.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internal Combustion Engines
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of cycles, design and performance characteristics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Indoor Environmental Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Ventilation, heating and cooling system design for buildings. Application of thermodynamic, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics principles for determination of building heating and cooling loads. Determination of ventilation requirements. Sizing, design and integration of environmental control systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aerodynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: A general introduction to aerodynamics including the analysis of lift, drag, thrust, and performance for subsonic aircraft, and the application of aerodynamic principles to design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aircraft and Missile Propulsion
htmlparse.Course.description: Mechanics and thermodynamics of aircraft and missile propulsion systems; combustion; air breathing jet engines; rockets; applied compressible flow; propellants; performance and design of propulsion systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermodynamics of Modern Power Cycles
htmlparse.Course.description: The first and second law analysis of modern steam cycles for both fossil-fuel and nuclear-fuel installations, Cycle efficiency and factors affecting performance, such as cycle design, load factor, and auxiliaries. Thermal pollution resulting from steam cycles.
