htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dynamics of Flight-Stability and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of the general dynamic equations of motion for six-degree-of-freedom aircraft. Aerodynamic and propulsion force and moment models, linear and flat earth approximations, static and dynamic stability and control analysis. Longitudinal and lateral normal modes, stability augmentation and automatic control design and simulation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Control of Mechanical Systems II
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and analysis of control systems. Topics include linear and nonlinear systems modeling; parameter estimation/system identification; steady state errors; advanced root locus and frequency response design; controller implementation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Composites
htmlparse.Course.description: Design, fabrication and testing of various composite materials. Analysis of mechanical properties of laminated composites.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CE 533 and senior standing in engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and 3 hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Vibrations I
htmlparse.Course.description: A general consideration of free and forced vibration in machines for various degrees of freedom; critical speed; vibration isolation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Development of Computer Applications In Mechanical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Nature of design, graphical user interface development to support computer-aided design, algorithms and computer graphics in computer applications, feature-based design, applications to design problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: General vector principles of the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; applications to orbital calculations, gyrodynamics, and rocket performance; introduction to the energy methods of advanced dynamics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Fluid Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of ME 571 in the study of general topics in fluid mechanics. Conservation of mass and momentum principles with particular emphasis on analysis of inviscid (potential) flows, compressible flows, and more advanced viscous flows including boundary layers. Numerous applications utilizing numerical methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermal Systems Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Thermal systems design including economics, simulation, and optimization. Includes heating, ventilating and air conditioning design and control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Thermal Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of thermodynamic, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics principles of the thermal analysis of the human body. Mathematical analysis and computer modeling of human response to the thermal environment. Evaluation of heat stress and cold stress. Protection from heat and cold. Requirements for thermal comfort and impact on human performance..
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Control of ElectroMechanical Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Discrete modeling and analysis of dynamic physical systems in mechanical engineering. Sampling and data conversion and reconstruction. Real time implementation of control on a computer. Digital controller design and implementation. Laboratory exercises in control applications and design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of recitation and three hours of laboratory per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Control Systems Analysis and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of classical analysis techniques for control system compensation. State space-control theory fundamentals are presented in addition to an introductory treatment of several major systems areas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Stress Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Experimental methods of investigating stress distributions. Photoelastic models, photoelastic coatings, brittle coatings, and resistance strain gauges applied to static and dynamic problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of analysis employed in the solution of problems selected from various branches of engineering. Emphasis is on discrete systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Heat Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: Conduction, convection and radiation, mass transfer, phase change, heat exchangers, introductory numerical methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technical Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to computer aided design and drafting for learning and applying technical graphics concepts and techniques to produce finished drawings. National and international standards. Theory and applications of orthographic projection and pictorial drawings. Standards for symbols, section views, and dimensioning included. Descriptive geometry, including, orthographic solutions involving the point, line and plane projections, intersections as well as surface development of solids, bearings, slope, true length, and true size determination.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Corequisite: MATH 100 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanical Detailing
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation of shop drawings for manufacturing, fabrication, or assembly. Specifications of size, shape, material for manufacture. Cost and tolerance relationship. Introduction to geometric tolerancing. Selective assembly and stress calculations in interference fits. Computer techniques including CAD, spreadsheets, and mathematical analysis are applied throughout the course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MET 111 and MATH 100 and MATH 151.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Manufacturing Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to contemporary manufacturing processes and practices, including precision measurement and inspection, machining, forming, casting, and welding processes. Recitation and laboratory experience in manufacturing practices, including metrology and basic setup and operation of manufacturing equipment. Observation of applications in local industry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer-Numerical-Controlled Machine Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and practice of basic CNC programming and machining operations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MET 121 and MATH 100. Corequisite: MATH 151.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Automated Manufacturing Systems I
htmlparse.Course.description: A general survey of the various components and systems in automated manufacturing, including material handling, electropneumatic control, programmable logic control, robotics, tooling, inspection and quality control, CNC, and other production processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Materials and Metallurgy
htmlparse.Course.description: A broad view of materials used in industry, including structures of materials, how they react to stress and temperature, how the polyphase structures form, and how they are controlled to produce optimum properties. Students will examine through study and laboratory experimentation ferrous and nonferrous metals, polymers, composites, and ceramics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Material Strength and Testing
htmlparse.Course.description: Calculations of material strength and deformation are complemented with principles and practice of mechanical testing including instrumentation and measurement in the areas of loads, stresses, deformations, thermal stresses, and other quantities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dynamics of Machines
htmlparse.Course.description: Velocities, accelerations, and forces in existing mechanisms to produce motions. Work, energy, impulse and momentum concepts in kinetics. Vibrations in machine parts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fluid Power Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study, design, analysis, operation, maintenance, and applications of hydraulic and pneumatic power systems and components.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Design Technology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to application and selection of machine elements to design mechanical systems.  Covers primary machine elements such as shafts and shaft components, screws and fasteners, welded joints, springs, bearings, gears, clutches and brakes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mechanical Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present mechanical engineering technology topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Finite Element Analysis and Design Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to finite element analysis applied to mechanical design.  Study and application of advanced computer-aided modeling techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Material Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of MET 231 Physical Materials and Metallurgy. Emphasizes the understanding of material properties used to give various materials their function. Theory and laboratory work focus on controlling and testing material properties. Ferrous and non-ferrous metals, polymers and adhesives, composites, smart materials, effects of corrosion, failure analysis, and selection techniques for design.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: CHM 110 and CHM 111 and MET 231.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elements of Mechanisms
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental motion concepts of displacement, velocity, and acceleration are studied, as well as analytical and graphical analysis and synthesis of linkages, gear trains, cams, pulleys, and combinations of these elements.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Fluid Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental concepts of fluid mechanics. Study of buoyancy, energy equation, viscosity, and flow measurement. Selected applications of fluid mechanics in civil and mechanical technologies. Computer-aided solution of problems in fluid mechanics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Design Technology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued study of design of mechanical elements and systems including engineering mechanics and materials, investigation of failure theories under static and variable loading, stress analysis, stress concentration, and deflections.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quality Control
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course in quality concepts and techniques used in industry. Topics include fundamentals of statistics and probability, statistical process control charts, and quality improvement tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Instrumentation and Controls
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to process control systems for industrial applications. Course topics include concepts and terminology, first- and second-order systems, measurement of motion, gauges and transducers, signal processing, and measurement of properties.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tool Design for Manufacturing
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices involved in tool drawing and design concepts necessary for the manufacture of products. Emphasis on design of jigs and fixtures, gauging devices, dies, ease of operation, and methods of assembly. Production cost related to selection of parts and methods of production is stressed. Applied laboratory exercises illustrated through specific case studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MET 117 and MET 125, and MET 346.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Design Project I
htmlparse.Course.description: Selection, definition, and analysis of a project supervised by faculty. Includes consideration of project parameters, trade-off studies, alternative solutions, and justification of selected solution. Completion and presentation of a written project proposal included.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Design Project II
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and implementation of project proposal submitted in MET 462. Construction, packaging, and testing of project culminating in a senior design project report which may include full documentation and performance specifications, functional description, theoretical analysis, schematics, cost analysis, parts list, drawings, etc. Project results will be presented orally to a select committee at the end of the course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermodynamics and Heat Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: This course emphasizes thermodynamic laws and equations and the use of tables and charts for properties of important fluids. Applications to systems used for producing, transforming, and applying heat and mechanical energy are also studied. Conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer processes are investigated.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Automated Manufacturing Systems II
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers systems for manufacturing operations including facilities, supplies, materials, procedures, and control. Topics include design, programming, feedback for manufacturing, production set-up, automated work cells, and decision issues.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Work Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: The student will work as an intern with business and industry in mechanical engineering technology field. A report detailing duties performed and tasks accomplished is required at the end of the internship period.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of MET program coordinator.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an opportunity for faculty to present advanced mechanical engineering technology topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: A general study of marketing principles which lead to the development of marketing strategy. A review of environmental influences and key analytical tools used in formulating marketing plans. Product or service design, distribution, pricing, and promotional programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Marketing-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A general study of marketing principles which lead to the development of marketing strategy. A review of environmental influences and key analytical tools used in formulating marketing plans. Product or service design, distribution, pricing, and promotional programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Consumer Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of consumer motives, attitudes, and decision processes as these relate to product imagery and purchase symbolism. The sociological and psychological foundations of marketplace choice are analyzed, including life-style, social status, age, income, taste, habit, custom, fashion, self-concept, and opinion influences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Marketing Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Eight weeks of applied marketing business experience designed to coordinate the interests of students and firms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: FINAN 450, MANGT 420, MKTG 400, junior standing, and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and analysis of current and emerging issues in marketing, including topics related to new theory, new applications, and the practice of marketing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Financial Services Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and analysis of current issues in the marketing of financial services, including topics related to new theory, the practice of marketing, and marketing applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in marketing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Retailing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the role retailing performs in the distribution of consumer goods and services. The course will survey the retailing environment and incorporate strategic planning from the management point of view; study retail policies and organizations; merchandise control; personnel management; retail accounting and expense control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Selling
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on interpersonal communications between buyers and sellers, both oral and written. The mechanics and intricacies of personal sales presentations, which will be developed through practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Selling-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on interpersonal communications between buyers and sellers, both oral and written. The mechanics and intricacies of personal sales presentations, which will be developed through practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integrated Marketing Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on the management of promotional programs which include elements of advertising, personal selling, sales promotion, and public relations. Includes a review of concepts from economics, behavioral sciences, and mathematics which play a role in creating, executing, and evaluating promotional programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with the problems and perspectives of marketing across national boundaries. It also focuses on the tools and practices for structuring and controlling marketing programs related to overseas business. Emphasis is on the management of marketing functions in a global context. Topics include international trade organizations, international economic factors, foreign business customs, and the international marketing mix.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Marketing Channels
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the quantitative and qualitative factors involved in selecting, developing, managing, and controlling marketing channels of distribution. Includes decision models from industrial marketers through purchasing units.

htmlparse.Course.title: Services Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of the unique marketing challenges faced by service organizations. Major topics include the unique characteristics of services, creating and positioning a service in the marketplace, distributing, promoting and pricing services. An evaluation of marketing strategies from the perspective of a service firm.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Business
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides students with an appreciation of the opportunities and unique challenges in international business, an understanding of the strategic and operational options available to an international firm, and managerial decision making abilities required to be successful abroad. The course examines strategic and operational issues involved in international business activity and how to best manage these issues.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the nature of the industrial marketplace, concentrating on those aspects that differentiate it from the consumer markets. The major topics are analysis of market needs, market segments, organizational buying behavior, purchasing agent functions and activities, marketing strategy and mix for institutional customers, not-for-profit and services marketing, and buyer/seller relationships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sales Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Management of the sales force in non-retail settings including hiring, training, organizing, motivating, supervising, and evaluating sales representatives and techniques of sales forecasting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Selling
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide students the opportunity to enhance their personal selling skills through advanced instruction and skill development making extensive use of role playing and sales role play competitions.  Content will include building relationships, negotiating, adaptive selling and understanding communication styles in a sales context.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Intelligence for Strategic Decision Making
htmlparse.Course.description: Business intelligence is a systematic approach to harnessing customer data and competitive information to drive strategic business decision making. This course deals with how to collect and analyze business data to enhance quality of decision making in modern enterprises. Unlike courses based on data mining (inductive approach), this course will be largely based on regression techniques (deductive approach). The course will be based on lectures, case analysis, and hands-on exercises to make students comfortable with powerful computing tools used for data analysis. The cases and exercises will be bundled with data which will be used to apply concepts learned in class to real business situations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: STAT 350 Business and Economic Statistics I or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sports Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides students with the opportunity to study the nature and scope of marketing a sports franchise as well as marketing traditional products or services with the assistance of sports figures. Topics include sports franchise promotion, sports identification, consumer loyalty to a team and consumer loyalty to participation sports.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electronic Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide students with the awareness and understanding of how Internet and Web-based technologies can be utilized to create effective marketing programs. Major topics will include new product development, brand building, promotion, pricing, and distribution in an electronic commerce context.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marketing Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to acquaint the students with the marketing research literature, concepts, methods, and techniques. The emphasis in this course is on how to actually conceptualize and conduct a marketing research project as well as use research as an aid for marketing management decisions. Topics include the marketing research industry, defining the marketing research problem, research design formulation, data collection, data preparation and analysis, communicating the research project, and international and ethical dimensions of marketing research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: GENBA 166 or CIS 101, CIS 102, CIS 103, STAT 351, MKTG 400 and MKTG 450.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marketing Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of marketing situations which lead to appropriate management of the marketing program’s objectives. Capstone course integrates knowledge of marketing and other business management principles into marketing strategy, development, implementation, and control.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Undergraduates must be business students admitted in a College Business Administration degree track (major).

htmlparse.Course.title: Study Abroad
htmlparse.Course.description: Study Abroad
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hebrew for Beginners
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the Hebrew language and the culture of the people who speak the language. This general introduction includes skill development in reading, writing, and speaking basic Hebrew.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Designed specifically for English-speaking students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Studies in World Literature and Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the students the opportunity to investigate in detail a particular theme or genre in World literature or culture. Taught in English.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Topics will vary.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities I
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of selected major works of history, literature, and philosophy which have been of central importance in the Western cultural tradition. Considerable emphasis is placed on classroom discussion and writing interpretive essays.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Limited to entering freshman students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MLANG 297.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MLANG 297 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Studies in Foreign Language
htmlparse.Course.description: Offered only to participants in study abroad programs. Prior consultation for approval is expected.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: At the discretion of the department, the course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading and discussion of selected masterpieces of European literature in English translation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-language majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts and Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: European Literature in Translation
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected readings in English from the major authors of Europe and the Spanish-speaking world.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Courses taught in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Linguistics: Language Structure and Language Use
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of linguistic analysis, including the sound system (phonetics and phonology), word formation (morphology), sentence formation (syntax), meaning (semantics and pragmatics). Formal and functional (usage-based) perspectives. Application of linguistics to language acquisition theory and to pedagogy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: For ML majors & minors: GRMN 523 or 527, or FREN 513 or 518 or one 700-level class, or SPAN 410 or 420 or 510; For other majors: ENGL 200.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Foreign Language Pedagogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Second and foreign language pedagogical theory is combined with the examination of practical concerns in the teaching of languages, in order to provide future and current instructors with the necessary background for making informed decisions concerning classroom practices. Taught in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of 2nd Language Acquisition
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the major theoretical frameworks of second language acquisition (SLA). Reading, discussion, and analysis of SLA research on a variety of linguistic and learning issues. Of interest to students of both language acquisition and literature. Taught in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Variable topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamental Methods of Biostatistics
htmlparse.Course.description: A course emphasizing concepts and practice of statistical data analysis for the health sciences.  Basic techniques of descriptive and inferential statistical methods applied to health related surveys and designed experiments.  Populations and samples, parameters and statistics; sampling distributions for hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for means and proportions involving one sample, paired samples and multiple independent samples; odds ratios, risk ratios, simple linear regression.  Use of statistical software to facilitate the collection, manipulation, analysis and interpretation of  health related data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the principles and methods of veterinary epidemiology: emphasizing how diseases affect populations (and associated implications for individuals), and application to disease diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Health Care Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive review of current health care institutions and their response to the economic, social/ethical, political/legal, technological, and ecological environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the basic principles and methods of epidemiology in order to recognize and understand how disease affects populations (and the associated implications for individuals).  This course will prepare students to use epidemiologic methods to solve current and future challenges to diagnose, treat, prevent, and control disease during their professional training and throughout their career.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Military Science and ROTC
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic drill, physical fitness, rappelling, army values, military presentations and basic marksmanship.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two classroom hours, a required leadership lab, and three one-hour sessions of physical fitness per week. Participation in a weekend exercise is optional, but highly encouraged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Military Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of effective leading. Communication skills to improve individual performance and group interaction. Relation of military organizational ethical values to the effectiveness of a leader.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two classroom hours, a required leadership lab, and three one-hour sessions of physical fitness per week. Participation in a weekend exercise is optional, but highly encouraged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Self/Team Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethics-based military leadership skills that develop individual abilities and contribute to building effective teams. Oral presentations, leadership, land navigation, and basic military tactics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two classroom hours; a required leadership lab; participation in three one-hour physical fitness sessions. Participation in a weekend exercise.

htmlparse.Course.title: Individual/Team Military Tactics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to individual and team aspects of military tactics in small unit operations. Safety assessments, movement techniques, military orders process, rifle marksmanship, rappelling.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two classroom hours; a required leadership lab; participation in three one-hour physical fitness sessions. Participation in a weekend exercise is optional, but highly encouraged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leaders Training Course
htmlparse.Course.description: A five-week summer camp conducted at Fort Knox, Kentucky. The United States Army provides pay, travel, lodging and meal costs. No military obligation incurred.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Open only to students who have not completed all four of MSCI 101, 102, 201, and 202, and who pass a physical examination (paid for by ROTC).
This course is a summer camp and the student receives their grade in the Fall semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leading Small Military Organizations I
htmlparse.Course.description: Series of practical opportunities to lead small groups in situations of increasing complexity. Uses small unit defensive tactics and opportunities to plan and conduct training.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of the basic course. Instructor permission required for enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three classroom hours, a leadership lab, participation in three one-hour physical fitness sessions. Participation in one weekend exercise is required, and one or two additional weekend exercises are offered for optional participation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leading Small Military Organizations II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continues methodology of MSCI 301. Military missions and task analysis. Ethical decision making and lessons from leadership case studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of MSCI 301 and instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three classroom hours, a leadership lab, participation in three one hour physical fitness sessions. Participation in one weekend exercise is required; two other weekend exercises optional.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leaders Development and Assessment Course
htmlparse.Course.description: A five-week camp conducted at Fort Lewis, Washington, by members of Kansas State University and other university Army ROTC faculty. The U.S. Army provides pay, travel, lodging and most meal costs. Highly structured and demanding, stressing leadership at small unit levels under varying, challenging conditions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Military Leadership Studies and Practical Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent research, analysis and monthly discussion on related military topics. Small unit tactics and practical application of leadership skills and individual research projects.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three classroom hours per week, a leadership lab, participation in three one-hour physical fitness sessions. Participation in one weekend exercise is required; two other weekend exercises optional.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership Challenges and Objective-Setting
htmlparse.Course.description: Plan, conduct, and evaluate activities of the ROTC cadet organization. Articulate goals, put plans into action to attain them. Assess organizational cohesion and develop strategies to improve it. Develop confidence in skills to lead people and manage resources. Learn and apply various Army policies and programs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MSCI 301 and 302 or department head permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three classroom hours, a two-hour leadership laboratory, and weekly physical fitness activities. Cadets will also participate in a weekend field training exercise (FTX) and a formal military social event.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transition to Lieutenant
htmlparse.Course.description: Continues the methodology from MSCI 401. Identify and resolve dilemmas. Refine counseling and motivating techniques. Examine aspects of tradition and law as relate to leading as an officer in the United States Army. Prepare for a future as a successful United States Army lieutenant.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Cadets will also participate in a weekend field training exercise (FTX) and a formal military social event.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program and Advanced Military Science Curriculum (must have completed the Basic Military Science Curriculum or received United States Army Cadet Command credit through prior military service or completion of the Leaders Training Course).
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Transition to Lieutenant I
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent research, analysis and monthly discussion on related military topics. Personal, academic, and professional goals and objectives, development and maintenance of an officer evaluation report support form.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MSCI 401 and 402 or department head permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Transition to Lieutenant II
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent research, analysis, and monthly discussion on related military topics. Personal, academic, and professional goals and objectives, development, and maintenance of an officer evaluation report support form.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Recital Attendance
htmlparse.Course.description: Recital Attendance
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Piano Proficiency
htmlparse.Course.description: Required for graduation of all music majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Fundamentals
htmlparse.Course.description: Elementary instruction in the theory of music.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Limited to non-music majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Voice Class I
htmlparse.Course.description: A beginning course in the basics of singing for non-music majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Voice Class II
htmlparse.Course.description: Singing technique skills beyond the basics to include performance skills for non-music majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all K-State students without audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all interested wind and percussion performers without audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pep Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marching Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all interested wind and percussion performers without audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wind Ensemble I
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Collegiate Chorale
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all interested singers. Audition determines membership in this and other choral organizations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: K-State Singers
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Not open to music majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symphony Orchestra
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theatre Orchestra
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Men’s Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women’s Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Listening Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic introduction to music. Overview of Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classic, Romantic, and Twentieth Century stylistic periods; elements of music (melody, rhythm, harmony, form, timbre); and instrument recognition. The focus of the class is on developing listening skills and learning to write brief papers using the new language that has been acquired.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Rock and Roll
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of Rock and Roll from its origins through today, focusing on the development of rock styles from its roots in blues, folk, country, and pop.  Expansion of listening experience through study of song forms, musical instruments of rock, and the socio-political significance of song lyrics.  Examinations, research paper required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Student need not be able to perform or read music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Inventing the Future: Underground Rock: 1968-1993
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the underground rock music, musicians, and scenes from the 1960’s to the 1990’s that have proven most influential on modern popular music and culture.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vocal Techniques I
htmlparse.Course.description: A beginning course in the basics of singing and teaching skills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music education majors whose emphasis is instrumental music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vocal Techniques II
htmlparse.Course.description: Singing and teaching skills beyond the basics and presentation of materials suitable for private and public school instruction at the secondary level.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music education majors whose emphasis is instrumental music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Piano Class I
htmlparse.Course.description: For freshmen and transfer music students with no piano background.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Sections also available for non-music majors and non-degree students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Piano Class II
htmlparse.Course.description: For freshmen and transfer students with some piano background, as well as those who have failed some or all of the Piano Proficiency Exam.

htmlparse.Course.title: Guitar Class I
htmlparse.Course.description: Beginning-level group instruction in guitar performance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Guitar Class II
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate-level instruction in guitar performance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the basic language of music; scales, triads and seventh chords, and all simple intervals. Written and aural skills reinforce concepts of melody, rhythm, and harmony.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Tested knowledge of basic music reading and aural skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of the musical dimensions of a particular topic or theme. Topics vary.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Freshman Survey
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the elements of music; the major historical periods of western classical music; music of non-western cultures; popular styles.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors and minors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued experience with the language of music. Part-writing, analysis, composition.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 210 or tested knowledge of basic music theory and concurrent enrollment in MUSIC 231.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aural Skills I
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of aural skills through sight singing, rhythmic training, and ear-training; melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic dictation to reinforce concepts in Music Theory II.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 210 or tested knowledge of music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Teaching Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques, materials, and experiences for a variety of music classes will be examined through discovery.  Furthermore, lesson plan development, writing, and implementation will be examined in detail.

htmlparse.Course.title: String Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: A beginning course in the fundamentals of playing and methods for teaching stringed instruments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors only, and not open to string majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Percussion Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: The fundamentals of playing and methods of teaching percussion instruments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clarinet & Saxophone Woodwind Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the fundamentals of playing and methods for teaching single reed woodwind instruments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Double Reed and Flute Woodwind Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the fundamentals of playing and methods for teaching double reed and flute woodwind instruments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: High Brass Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the fundamentals of playing and methods for teaching high brass instruments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Low Brass Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in the fundmentals of playing and methods for teaching low brass instruments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to American Music
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the functions of music in American society and the elements of music, including a survey of the development of various types and styles of music in America.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Elements of music as represented in selected masterpieces of the standard concert repertory, designed to heighten the perception and the enjoyment of the listener who has limited musical knowledge.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For non-music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Study for Non-Music Majors
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied study for non-music majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Secondary Performance
htmlparse.Course.description: For students who wish to study an instrument or voice other than the major performance area. Instruction is offered every semester in voice and each of the following instruments: baritone, bassoon, clarinet, double bass, early winds, flute, French horn, guitar, harp, harpsichord, oboe, organ, percussion, piano, saxophone, trombone, trumpet, tuba, viola, viola da gamba, violin, and violoncello.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Students may enroll in more than one instrument simultaneously and may earn 1-2 hours per semester in each instrument.
May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lower-Division Performance
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and experience in solo performance is offered every semester in voice and each of the following instruments: baritone, bassoon, clarinet, double bass, early winds, flute, French horn, guitar, harp, harpsichord, oboe, organ, percussion, piano, saxophone, trombone, trumpet, tuba, viola, viola da gamba, violin, and violoncello.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Students may enroll in more than one instrument simultaneously and may earn 1 to 4 hours per semester in each instrument.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marching Band Techniques for School Music Educators
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical techniques of marching band in school music programs and the skills necessary to design, organize, instruct, and evaluate a marching band show.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lower-Division Ensemble Performance
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction is offered each semester in the following areas: brass, chamber music, concert jazz, jazz combo, strings, winds, percussion, and vocal ensemble.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Offered on demand, only in intersessions
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Admission is by audition and students may enroll in more than one ensemble simultaneously.

htmlparse.Course.title: Italian Diction
htmlparse.Course.description: Rules for pronouncing and translating Italian vocal texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: German Diction
htmlparse.Course.description: Rules for pronouncing and translating German vocal texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic fundamentals of jazz theory to develop critical thinking and performing skills.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 230 with grade of C or better.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate level fundamentals of jazz theory to develop critical thinking and performing skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Improvisation I
htmlparse.Course.description: Develop skills in the area of jazz improvisation in a performance lab setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Improvisation II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued development of jazz improvisational skills in a performance lab setting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 297 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Musical Instruments
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of musical instruments in each period of Western music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Theory III
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical concepts of eighteenth-century music. Modulations, secondary function chords, counterpoint, and some chromatic harmony. Identify and work with elements of musical structure through exercises, analysis and composition.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aural Skills II
htmlparse.Course.description: Sight singing, rhythmic training, and ear-training through drills and dictation to reinforce concepts in Music Theory III.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 231.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aural Skills Proficiency
htmlparse.Course.description: Required for graduation of all music majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lower-Division Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: Composition instruction through individual lessons and group seminar instruction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Studio Accompanying
htmlparse.Course.description: Piano student assigned to studio instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Accompanies lessons for at least two hours a week. Ensemble credit for pianists.

htmlparse.Course.title: Recital Accompanying
htmlparse.Course.description: Piano student assigned to a music major preparing for graduation recital.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Pianist accompanies student in lessons and presents the formal public program as course requirement.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Theory IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical concepts of late nineteenth-century music and twentieth-century music: chromatic harmony and twentieth-century compositional techniques, analysis, and composition.  Identify and work with elements of musical structure.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aural Skills III
htmlparse.Course.description: Sight singing, rhythmic training, and ear-training through drills and dictation to reinforce concepts in Music Theory IV.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 321.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Guitar Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Listening to jazz guitar literature, performing, and offering meaningful critique.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Music
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for studies undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Keyboard Pedagogy
htmlparse.Course.description: A systematic study of pedagogy which examines effective teaching methods and aids in the development of a philosophy of professional teaching.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Keyboard majors with concurrent enrollment in MUSIC 455.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: For selected sophomores.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all interested wind and percussion performers without audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wind Ensemble II
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Collegiate Chorale
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all interested singers. Audition determines membership in other choral organizations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symphony Orchestra
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music for Elementary Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: The contribution of music to child development in elementary schools. A study of music literature suited to children through the development of purposive listening and the expressive phases of music including rhythmic response, singing, playing, reading, and writing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Men’s Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women’s Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marching Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: University Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to all interested wind and percussion performers by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theatre Orchestra
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pep Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Admission by audition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conducting
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques of the baton gestures, signs, and cues as generally used in conducting choral and instrumental organizations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 320 and 321.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Jazz
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of jazz styles and personalities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For music majors and non-majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Salsa: Afro-Cuban Music of the Past and Present
htmlparse.Course.description: Appreciation, historical knowledge, mechanics, aesthetics, and cultural contexts of salsa.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz in Kansas City and the Southwest
htmlparse.Course.description: The history and development of jazz styles in Kansas City and the southwestern United States, emphasizing the influence on styles of other geographic areas.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Jazz
htmlparse.Course.description: Big bands; jazz pianists and styles; survey of combo jazz styles, etc.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced String Techniques and Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Playing and teaching skills beyond fundamentals and presentation of materials suitable for private and public school instruction at the secondary level.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all instrumental majors in music education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Upper-Division Performance
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and experience in solog performance is offered every semester in voice and each of the following instruments: baritone, bassoon, clarinet, double bass, early winds, flute, French horn, guitar, harp, harpsichord, oboe, organ, percussion, piano, saxophone, trombone, trumpet, tuba, viola, viola da gamba, violin, and violoncello.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Students may enroll in more than one instrument simultaneously and may earn 1 to 4 hours per semester in each instrument.

htmlparse.Course.title: French Diction I
htmlparse.Course.description: Rules for pronouncing and translating French vocal texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Songwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Composition of original small song forms including preparation of lead sheet and vocal score using guitar chord symbols.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For non-music majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Opera Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and techniques of operatic and musical theatre production, with emphasis on class rehearsal and performance of selected scenes from opera and musical drama; brief survey of the history of opera.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Offered jointly by the Departments of Music and Communication Studies. Vocal ensemble credit may be earned in this course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Upper-Division Ensemble Performance
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction is offered each semester in the following areas: brass, chamber music, concert jazz, jazz combo, strings, winds, percussion, and vocal ensemble.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Admission is by audition and students may enroll in more than one ensemble simultaneously.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumental Jazz Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Guides future instrumental teachers on techniques to teach jazz including beginning improvisation, combo, big band techniques, and school jazz literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vocal Jazz Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Guides future choral teachers on techniques to teach jazz including beginning improvisation, jazz choir, and school jazz literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Workshop in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Specialized interest areas for undergraduate students only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Collegium Musicum
htmlparse.Course.description: An ensemble devoted primarily to the performance of music written before 1700. Authentic instruments used when possible.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vocal Pedagogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of vocal production, exploring the scientific principles of breathing, resonance, timbre, and other vocal features.  Discussion of vocal health and teaching styles will be included.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods and Materials for the Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of teaching fundamental techniques; selection of teaching materials outlining courses of study. For undergraduate students in performance curricula. Taught in divisions according to the major. Practical application through supervised studio teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual directed research and study of a topic in music, normally as a preliminary to writing a senior honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, membership in the honors program of the College of Arts and Sciences, and permission of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once to a total of 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Half Recital
htmlparse.Course.description: Public performance; vocal or instrumental with suggested performing time of 25 minutes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Full Recital
htmlparse.Course.description: Public performance; vocal or instrumental with suggested performing time of 50 minutes.

htmlparse.Course.title: A Survey of Music Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide students with an overview of music therapy: its history, theoretical bases, training requirements, common settings for its use, and general techniques employed. Upon completion of this course, students will have a basic understanding of the music therapy profession, and  have knowledge of music therapy as a viable career option.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music in the Schools K-6
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the musical characteristics of children and development of appropriate curriculum, instructional materials and techniques, and related technology for teaching musical understanding, literacy, multi-cultural connections, and creative improvisation in grades K-6 instrumental, vocal, and general music.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Prerequisite of co-enrolled in EDCEP 315, EDSEC 376, EDSP 323.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course includes supervised field experiences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Program in Junior/Senior High Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Organization and administration of the comprehensive music program in junior and senior high schools; including the study of vocal and instrumental ensemble development, as well as techniques, materials and appropriate instructional technologies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite or concurrent enrollment in EDCEP 315, EDSEC 376, EDSP 323.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course includes a supervised field experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: Choral Conducting
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued mastery of the skills in Conducting I while emphasizing essential techniques and interpretation for choral ensembles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumental Conducting
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued mastery of the skills in Conducting I while emphasizing essential techniques and interpretation for instrumental ensembles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Upper-Division Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: Composition instruction through individual lessons and group seminar instruction. Emphasis on meeting professional standards of composition and score/part preparation and creation of a varied portfolio of works.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Submission of a portfolio of pieces for faculty review and approval.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumentation and Arranging
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of writing and arranging for the strings, woodwinds, brass and percussion as well as choral ensembles. Functional ranges and practical applications through score study and projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music History I: Ancient Greece through 1700
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of stylistic trends, major composers, repertoire of ancient Greece, the Middle Ages, Renaissance and early Baroque periods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 320.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music History II: 1700 to 1850
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of stylistic trends, major composers, repertoire of the late Baroque, Classical and early Romantic periods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 320.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music History III: 1850 to the Present
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the development of stylistic and culture trends, major composers, and repertoire of the late Romantic period through the present.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in MUSIC 320.

htmlparse.Course.title: Musical Comedy
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of operetta and music comedy from Offenbach to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Music
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Background of courses needed for studies undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Percussion Pedagogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of percussion instruments and related performance techniques, teaching methods and responsibilities, organization, and literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Upper String Pedagogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of violin technique and related teaching methods, also applicable to other bowed string instruments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The three credit-hour option includes additional assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lower String Pedagogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of low string technique and related teaching methods. Intended for teachers of string, concert/jazz bands and vocal music if they use a bass with accompaniment combos for pit orchestras or swing choirs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Theory Review
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students in music for whom additional work in the harmonic and formal aspects of tonal and chromatic music is needed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course does not fulfill degree requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: 18th Century Counterpoint
htmlparse.Course.description: Contrapuntal compositional techniques from the late baroque to Classical periods, including compositional procedures for the canon and fugue.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 322, 360, 361, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Contemporary Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to analytical and compositional techniques applicable to the predominately non-tonal music of the 20th and 21st centuries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 322, 360, 361, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate History Review
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students in music for whom additional work in music history is needed based on their performance on the Graduate Music History Entrance Exam.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course does not fulfill graduate degree requirements. A grade of an A or B is required to enroll in graduate level music history courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technology of the Electronic Music Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Instrumentation and systematic procedures as applied to the construction of electronic music. Principles of voltage-controlled systems, synchronous tape machines, and audio mixing. Individual and team projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Sound Synthesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of real-time interactive systems. Theory and application pertaining to the creation of instruments and scores using additive and FM techniques. Team projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Woodwind Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced techniques in the teaching of all woodwind instruments for music teachers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Brass Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced techniques in the teaching of all brass instruments for music teachers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert and Ethnic Percussion Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of percussion performance techniques commonly associated with concert band and percussion ensemble, as well as percussion techniques associated with music of other cultures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The three credit-hour option includes additional assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz and Marching Percussion Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of percussion performance techniques commonly associated with marching percussion and jazz idioms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The three credit-hour option includes additional assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Secondary Performance Area
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students who wish to study an instrument (or voice) other than the major performance area. Pedagogical methods and fundamentals are stressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Opera
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of selected masterpieces of musical drama, with emphasis on the relationship of music and drama, and on the unique qualities of opera as a collective artwork.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marching Band Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical and practical purposes of the marching band, and the skills necessary to design, organize, instruct, and evaluate a marching band show.

htmlparse.Course.title: Choral Ensemble Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical and practical study of the choral ensemble, and the skills necessary to design, organize, instruct and evaluate the choral program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Jazz Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic practices found in jazz education, including literature, teaching techniques, and resource materials.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Studies in Music Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced instructional methods and technologies related to the teaching of music in grades preK-12 implemented through field experiences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: EDCEP 315, EDSEC 376, EDSP 323, and prerequisite or concurrent enrollment in MUSIC 511 MUSIC 512.

htmlparse.Course.title: Arranging for Bands
htmlparse.Course.description: Assessing, evaluating, and applying the basic issues, techniques, and possibilities inherent in scoring and arranging for various wind band media. Primary attention will be given to concert and marching bands, but students will also spend time learning about various jazz ensembles and other possible combinations of wind and percussion instruments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Instrumental Rehearsal Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Explore, evaluate, and develop the musical understanding and skills necessary in leading instrumental ensembles toward significant musical expression through effective rehearsal techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Choral Rehearsal Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Explore, evaluate, and develop the musical understanding and skills necessary in leading choral ensembles toward significant musical expression through effective rehearsal techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organization and Administration of School Music Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides models and ideas on organizing program/teaching to enable the teacher and students to succeed and enjoy the music making process. Present strategies and philosophies on dealing with administrators, parents, peers, and students will be discussed, as well as motivation of self and student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Explore, evaluate, and analyze the masterworks of the wind, choral, and orchestral genres.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course will alternate annually between Instrumental and Choral literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Style Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Training in a comprehensive, systematic analytical approach to all style periods, and in verbalizing analytical perceptions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symphonic Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of orchestral music from the late Baroque to the present, with emphasis on selected symphonies of the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chamber Music Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: A selected survey of masterpieces of small ensemble music from 1750 to the present. Special emphasis on the string quartet.

htmlparse.Course.title: Song Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey, by historical period and national styles, of major solo vocal works.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Wind Bands
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of the wind band medium from the Renaissance to the present, with focus on the composers and literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Choral Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of standard choral masterpieces in both large and small forms from 1450 to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of School Choral Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of choral music in schools with focus on composers and literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Orchestration
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of orchestra and band scores. Exercises in orchestrating this type of music for different choirs of instruments, as well as scoring for full orchestra and symphonic band.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organ Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of significant compositions from the Renaissance to the present with emphasis on performance practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Piano Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Selective survey of music for piano from 1750 to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Studies in Music Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the repertory of a selected musical genre or medium of performance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Techniques of Music Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Students develop skills of notation, scanning, manipulating, sequencing, and recording necessary to integrate digital technologies into the practice of music making and teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in the Life and Works of an Individual Composer
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the career and achievements of a selected composer of major stature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in American Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of the various genres of American music.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual guided work in a selected area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 6 hours graduate credit in music.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
No more than three hours of Problems in Music may be applied to the master’s degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reactor Operations Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic course in reactor operator licensing, nuclear safety, and reactor operations with structured laboratory exercises.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and one three-hour lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Computational Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of digital computer methods to the solution of engineering problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Engineering Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to analytical, statistical, and numerical analysis, including computer programming, as applied to engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elements of Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of nuclear engineering concepts and applications. Nuclear reactions, radioactivity, radiation interaction with matter, reactor physics, risk and dose assessment, applications in medicine, industry, agriculture, and research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Radiation Detection
htmlparse.Course.description: Operating principles and general properties of devices used in the detection and characterization of ionizing radiation. Fundamental methods of data interpretation and presentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Specific studies in current and advanced problems in various phases of nuclear engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Reactor Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of neutron diffusion and thermalization with application to steady-state nuclear reactors.
