htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Reactor Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and measurement of nuclear and reactor parameters of fundamental importance to nuclear reactors and their operation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiation Protection and Shielding
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of radiation protection, doses, associated risks, and exposure limits. Properties of natural and other radiation sources, and evaluation of internal and external doses. Techniques for shield design including ray, point kernel, and transport theories for both neutrons and gamma rays.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiation Measurement Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of systems used to measure radiation. Applications to radiation monitoring, dosimetry, and spectroscopy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Topical material of importance in nuclear engineering, such as controlled thermonuclear reactions, numerical analysis, Monte Carlo methods in radiation transport, effects of nuclear explosions, etc.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophical Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to some of the main problems of philosophy, such as the nature of morality, knowledge, mind and body, political authority, and the existence of God.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophical Problems-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to some of the main problems of philosophy, such as the nature of morality, knowledge, mind and body, political authority, and the existence of God.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Critical Thinking
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic introduction to both deductive and inductive reasoning. Emphasis is placed on constructing, analyzing, and evaluating arguments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Critical Thinking-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic introduction to both deductive and inductive reasoning. Emphasis is placed on constructing, analyzing, and evaluating arguments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Formal Logic
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematic study of deductive reasoning (and possibly inductive reasoning) using the techniques of modern logic. Examines different types of valid inference, the logical structure of English sentences, and the validity of arguments generally. Involves the development and use of a symbolic system which models logical relations among sentences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Causal and Statistical Reasoning
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces students to some ideas about causation, and also to some elementary tools for thinking both critically and constructively about causal claims. The treatment is broadly formal, and introduces ideas from statistics, computer science, and philosophy, but requires no mathematical background beyond high school algebra. Some sections are taught using web-based course-ware.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Religion
htmlparse.Course.description: Arguments pertaining to the existence of God, the nature of religious experience, the problem of evil, the proper relation between reason and faith, and religious diversity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical problems concerning the concepts of art and aesthetic value, patterns of reasoning in art appreciation and criticism, and writing histories of art and artistic movements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the nature of science and how it differs from pseudo-sciences such as astrology, and raises questions about the nature of reality and social value of science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Moral Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical issues arising in and about morality, such as the nature of moral judgments, moral knowledge, moral justification, and the relation of morality to religion. Topics might be approached by a study of contemporary moral Problems, by reading of classical texts, or by both methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Moral Philosophy-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical issues arising in and about morality, such as the nature of moral judgments, moral knowledge, moral justification, and the relation of morality to religion. Topics might be approached by a study of contemporary moral Problems, by reading of classical texts, or by both methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Social and Political Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines rival theories of justice and applies them to current debates about economic inequality, gender, race, and sexual orientation. Combines some influential historical texts with contemporary philosophical literature on current political issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Mind
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical problems concerning the nature of human beings, including the relation between mind and body, the existence of the soul, the nature of consciousness, the possibility of artificial intelligence, human freedom and personal identity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Introduction to Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to philosophy through the study of major thinkers in the history of philosophy, such as Plato, Descartes, Hume. Topics may include the immortality of the soul, the existence of God, skepticism, reasons for being moral.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Feminism
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical examination of issues such as femininity and masculinity, the social conditions of gender equality, multiculturalism and gender, affirmative action, sexual harassment, and welfare policy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines fundamental issues concerning the nature and justification of legal institutions. Topics selected from: the nature of law and its relations to morality, criminal justice and punishment, responsibility and liberty, and legal interpretation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophical Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to provide students an introduction to philosophy while assisting them to further develop writing skills in preparation for Expository Writing II. Topics covered vary, but typically are related to understanding ourselves and our moral practices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENGL 100 and open only to freshmen and sophomores.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Central problems of philosophy, such as skepticism and knowledge, the nature of human minds, freedom, the nature of morality, justice and the existence of God.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in an honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to Moral Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical issues arising in and about morality. Topics selected from: the nature of moral judgments, moral knowledge, moral justification, and the relation of morality to religion.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in an honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities I
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of selected major works of history, literature, and philosophy which have been of central importance in the Western cultural tradition. Considerable emphasis is placed on classroom discussion and writing interpretive essays.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: For students in an honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Introduction to the Humanities II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of PHILO 297.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHILO 297 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Ancient Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Ancient Greek Philosophy, particularly in the writings of Plato and Aristotle. Pre-Socratic and/or Hellenistic philosophers may be represented as well.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy, major standing, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces students to the development of philosophical ideas from ancient Greece to the modern era, and develops skills in the critical interpretation of original texts.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy, or major standing, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophical Methods and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.description: Special knowledge, methods and skills needed to do philosophical research. Conceptual analysis, argument strategy, definitional strategy, thought experiments, counter-examples, applied to the mechanics of paper writing in philosophy and philosophical discussion.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy, major standing, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symbolic Logic I
htmlparse.Course.description: First order logic, covering truth tables and truth functions, and derivations in both propositional and predicate logic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Moral Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to ethics, surveying central issues in normative ethical theory with an emphasis on consequentialism, virtue theory, and deontology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy, major standing, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Social and Political Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to modern social and political philosophy, examining questions about central political values, such as equal citizenship, property rights, distributive justice, fairness, and democratic social and political institutions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy, major standing, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Justification and Reliable Knowledge
htmlparse.Course.description: This course offers an introduction to epistemology, surveying the historical development of important theories of knowledge, alternative conceptions of justification, and differing ideas about evidence and reliable inference.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One philosophy course, major standing, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Continental Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of selected figures (such as Kierkegaard, Fichte, Marx, Nietzsche, Beauvoir, Hegel, Schopenhauer, Sartre, Heideggar, Husserl, Wittgenstein, Gadamer, Ricoeur, Foucault, Lacan), or movements (such as Transcendental Idealism, Existentialism, Marxism, Phenomenology, Post-Modernism), or issues in continental philosophy (such as humanity’s relation to God, free will, the state, irrationalism, gender, philosophical methodology).

htmlparse.Course.title: Medical Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected moral issues which confront the medical professional, including experimentation on human subjects, informed consent, abortion, euthanasia, conflict of interest, and confidentiality.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy and Race
htmlparse.Course.description: The concept of race and racial identity, and contemporary controversies about the nature of racism and social justice, examined through fiction, movies, and readings in biology, anthropology, history, and philosophy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the principles of ethics as applied to cases arising in the practice of the various branches of engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the principles of ethics as applied to situations and practices in modern American business.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Ethics-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the principles of ethics as applied to situations and practices in modern American business.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Seminar in Philosophy

htmlparse.Course.title: Computers and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of ethical issues raised by the impact of computers and associated technologies on society, including such topics as ethics of computer use, computer fraud, protection of privacy; legal, moral, and public policy-making responsibilities of computer professionals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing plus concurrent enrollment in CIS 415; CIS 520.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symbolic Logic II
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced study of logical systems and problems in logical theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social-Political Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines key developments in contemporary political philosophy in such areas as liberalism, libertarianism, communitarianism, Marxism, and feminism, and on topics of special interest where these theories are applied.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical issues arising in the legal context, such as the nature of legal reasoning, the nature and scope of constitutional protections, the justification of punishment, affirmative action, and civil disobedience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy (PHILO 135, PHILO 160, or PHILO 330 recommended), or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: Epistemic methods and metaphysical presuppositions in the social sciences. Topics selected from: models, measurement, reduction, explanation, theories of function, theories of ideal types, and rational choice theory.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy, one of which must be PHILO 100 or 320.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Aesthetics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of selected topics in aesthetics and the philosophy of art.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines key developments in moral philosophy. May focus on issues in metaethics, ethical theory, or history of ethics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of selected topics in applied ethics, applied philosophy, or the continental tradition.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethical issues that arise from the use and exploitation of the environment, such as the value of biodiversity, obligations to future generations, obligations to non-humans, and the ethics of environmental risk management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in philosophy (PHILO 330 recommended), or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Issues in the History of Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Particular sets of issues in the history of philosophy or in-depth examination of the thought of a particular philosopher. Emphasis on issues in metaphysics and epistemology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy and consent of instructor. Depending on topic, PHILO 300 or 301 required.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Religion
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts of religion, including truth and faith, God and atheism, reason and revelation, morality and religion, evil, humanity, sin, salvation, eschatology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy. PHILO 305, 320, or 340 recommended.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: The Development of Analytical Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of analytic philosophy from 1870 to 1960, examining the works of most of the following philosophers: Frege, Russell, Wittgenstein, Moore, the logical positivists, and Quine.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy, one of which must be PHILO 110 or 320.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: The Philosophy of Language
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical problems concerning the nature of language and such concepts as meaning and truth.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy, one of which must be PHILO 110 or 320.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Metaphysics
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of theories about objects and their qualities, causality, space, and time. Both traditional and contemporary sources may be used, but emphasis will be placed on the latter.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy. PHILO 305, 320, or 340 recommended.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Epistemology
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical issues relating to human knowledge. Issues selected from: the difference between knowledge and belief, whether knowledge is really attainable, whether we have epistemic duties and what they might be, what counts as justification for belief. Special topics may include self-knowledge, a prior knowledge, inductive knowledge, and naturalism.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy. PHILO 305, 320, or 340 recommended.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: The Philosophy of Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical problems concerning science, its methods. Topics selected from: qualitative and quantitative confirmation theories and the nature of scientific theories, laws, and explanation in the physical and biological sciences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy, one of which must be PHILO 110 or 320.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: This course offers an exploration of the conceptual foundations of modern physics, including topics from relativistic space-time theories, quantum mechanics and gauge theories, and related topics in the philosophy of science, including the nature of physical laws, reduction, the measurement problem and non-locality.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will introduce a range of topics in the philosophy of biology, including: the conceptual foundations of evolutionary theory, interpretations of fitness and selection, group selection, definitions of species, epistemological problems in phylogenetic inference, design arguments, explanation in biological sciences and reliable modeling in ecology and evolutionary biology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosphy and the Origins of Ancient Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the development of ancient science, with special attention paid to the interrelationship in antiquity of philosophical and scientific accounts of the world. Topics will include developments in mathematics, optics, astronomy, mechanics, and medicine, among others.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy and the Origins of Modern Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the development of modern science from roughly the 16th century, with special attention paid to the interrelationship in early modern philosophical and scientific accounts of the world. Topics will include developments in physics, astronomy, biology, mathematics, and medicine, as well as related areas of metaphysics, epistemology, and philosophy of religion.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy or four natural science courses, with at least two of them in physics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rationality and Action
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical issues connected with human action and reasons for action, such as the existence of objective reasons to act one way rather than another, the existence of reasons to act that do not stem from desires, the difference between reasoning about how to act and reasoning about what is true, the nature of intention and desire and their specific roles in action.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Mind
htmlparse.Course.description: A philosophical examination of major theories about the nature of the mind, mental causation, consciousness, intentionality, cognition and psychological explanation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in philosophy. PHILO 305, 320 or 340 recommended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in contemporary ethical theory.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHILO 330 and one other philosophy course.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Moral and conceptual foundations of modern economic systems. Topics selected from: the relations between “economics rationality” and the quality of life, the just distribution of wealth, the nature of property rights, and the value of technology in society.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Social-Political Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of a single topic in contemporary philosophical literature, with application to current political issues. Topic selected from: multiculturalism, minority rights, nationalism, justification of democracy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHILO 525 and one other philosophy course.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Philosophy of Law
htmlparse.Course.description: A current issue in analytical jurisprudence (such as the nature of law, the relation between law and morality, the proper standards for constitutional interpretation) or normative jurisprudence (such as basis for tort liability, whether and when strict criminal liability is justified, the rights of criminals).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHILO 535 and one other philosophy course.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent Study in Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Topics in Metaphysics and Epistemology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected philosophical issues of current interest in analytic metaphysics and epistemology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHILO 340 and two additional philosophy courses.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall or Spring, in alternate years
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Philosophy
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in metaphysics, epistemology, philosophy of science, philosophy of language, or philosophy of mind.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHILO 320 and additional background courses required for topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Metalogic
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in the analysis of first-order theories and the foundations of mathematics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Colloquium in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Weekly lectures on topics of current interest in physics by faculty and visiting scientists.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physical World I
htmlparse.Course.description: The courses the Physical World I and II are designed to present an overview of the physical sciences for students who have little or no previous physical science. The Physical World I is principally classical physics with some discussions of modern physics. The observations and phenomena are simple and basic.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week. Not available for credit to students who have credit in PHYS 106.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physical World I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: The courses the Physical World I and II are designed to present an overview of the physical sciences for students who have little or no previous physical science. The Physical World I is principally classical physics with some discussions of modern physics. The observations and phenomena are simple and basic.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week. Not available for credit to students who have credit in PHYS 106.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physical World II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of PHYS 101. Topics may include nuclear physics, atomic theory, quantum mechanics, chemistry, geology, molecular biology and astronomy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 101 or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physical World I Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Two hours lab a week.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physical World I Laboratory-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Two hours lab a week.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physical World II Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concepts of Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory course in physics which emphasizes the topics of physics normally presented to elementary school children. A qualitative approach with integrated laboratory, this course is recommended for students preparing for careers as elementary school teachers.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not available for credit to students who have completed PHYS 101.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Physics I
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic development of the principles of mechanics, heat, fluids, oscillations, waves and sound.  Emphasis is on conceptual development and numerical problem solving.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 150 or one and one-half units of high school algebra and one unit high school trigonometry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one hour recitation, one hour quiz, and two hours lab week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Physics I-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic development of the principles of mechanics, heat, fluids, oscillations, waves and sound.  Emphasis is on conceptual development and numerical problem solving.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 150 or one and one-half units of high school algebra and one unit high school trigonometry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one hour recitation, one hour quiz, and two hours lab week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Physics II
htmlparse.Course.description: The continued treatment of the fundamentals of electricity and magnetism, light and optics, atomic and nuclear physics.  These concepts are used to understand D.C. and A.C. circuits, motors, and generators.  Emphasis is placed on conceptual development and problem solving.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one hour recitation, one hour quiz, and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Physics II-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: The continued treatment of the fundamentals of electricity and magnetism, light and optics, atomic and nuclear physics.  These concepts are used to understand D.C. and A.C. circuits, motors, and generators.  Emphasis is placed on conceptual development and problem solving.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one hour recitation, one hour quiz, and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Descriptive Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: A one-semester course in physics covering mechanics, electricity, heat, light, sound, and atomic theory. It presents a survey of the major fields of physics with a concentration on how physicists work to understand and describe physical phenomena.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture, one hour quiz, one hour recitation, and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics Today I
htmlparse.Course.description: The first of a two-semester study of problem solving in physics. Introductory physics problems as well as problems encountered in research will be discussed. Introductory problems will focus on mechanics and thermodynamics. Research discussions will center on topics of current interest at K-State and elsewhere.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Physics major or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One class of two hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics Today II
htmlparse.Course.description: Second of a two-semester study of problem solving in physics. Introductory physics problems as well as problems encountered in research will be discussed. Introductory problems will focus on electricity, magnetism, and optics. Research discussions will center on topics of current interest at K-State and elsewhere.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 122 and physics major or permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One class of two hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Descriptive Astronomy
htmlparse.Course.description: A qualitative study of the earth, sun, planets, stars, galaxies and the universe; a survey of what is known about the universe and how we know it.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two (2) hours lecture and 2 lab hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Physics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Mechanics and heat; for students of science and engineering.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one hour quiz, and four hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Physics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Sound, electricity, magnetism, light, and modern physics; for students of science and engineering.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, two hours recitation, one hour quiz, and four hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics I, Mechanics, and Thermodynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: For physics majors. Lecture and quiz in common with PHYS 213. Special studio.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 122 or permission of lecturer required, MATH 220 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics II, Electromagnetism, and Sound
htmlparse.Course.description: For physics majors. Lecture and quiz in common with PHYS 214. Special studio.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in PHYS 123 or permission of lecturer required, PHYS 223, MATH 221 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics in Relation to Other Disciplines
htmlparse.Course.description: Variable content, offered only by prearrangement with the physics department and with the instructor. A brief syllabus will be available for each offering of PHYS 300 outlining the objectives and organization of the course for the semester in which offered.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics III, Relativity, and Quantum Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to modern physics as exemplified by atomic, nuclear, condensed matter, and particle phenomena.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PHYS 224 or 214; MATH 222 or concurrent; and a working knowledge of spreadsheets and use of computers as data analysis tools.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture and one two-hour lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions of topics of current interest in physics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students must be enrolled in the arts and sciences honors program or have permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent theoretical or experimental investigation of a topic for physics majors or for a senior honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit up to a maximum of 6 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Contemporary Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: A non mathematical introduction to twentieth century physics: relativity, quantum mechanics, the physics of solids, and fundamental particles.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not open to physics majors. Credit is not granted for both PHYS 451 and PHYS 452.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Physics: Problems and Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to twentieth century physics; relativity, quantum mechanics, the physics of solids, and fundamental particles. The lectures are in common with PHYS 451.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One year of college physics (PHYS 113 and 114 or equivalent), college algebra, and trigonometry.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Three hours lecture and two hour lab each week. The laboratory will include the quantitative aspects of the subject matter.
Not open to physics majors. Credit is not granted for both PHYS 451 and PHYS 452.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Topics in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Special topics in physics not completely treated in other courses.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Astronomy
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in modern astronomy. Use of a telescope for observational astronomy will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours independent observational astronomy a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Research in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Individually directed research in atomic physics, condensed matter, particle physics or physics education.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior in physics and permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated once.
Students in the Arts and Sciences honors program should enroll in PHYS 498 and PHYS 499 instead of PHYS 497.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Individually directed research in physics, normally taken as a preparation for writing an honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated once to a total of three credit hours.
Open only to students in the arts and sciences honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Physics Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: The completion of experiments of current and/or historical interest in contemporary physics. Students develop skills in and knowledge of measurement techniques using digital and analog instruments. Various data analysis techniques are used.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four (4) class hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics for Science Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of current topics in physics, with laboratory experience and demonstration of the processes or phenomena under consideration. Topics and activities will be directed toward providing teachers with material for demonstrations and student experiments or projects. Examples of topics are: solar power, laser applications, holography, and subnuclear particles, relativity, or the historical development of some physical concept.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One year of college physics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of statistics and dynamics of systems of particles and rigid bodies. Topics include Newton’s laws for one particle, non-inertial reference frames, central forces, system of particles, rigid body statics and motion in a plane and in three dimensions, Lagrangian mechanics and Hamilton’s equations, oscillating systems and normal coordinates.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture and one hour recitation per week The recitation will focus on mathematical methods and techniques applied to problem solving.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electromagnetic Fields I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to electricity and magnetism. The first of a two semester study of Maxwell’s equations in both integral and differential forms. Topics include electrostatics with vector calculus; electrostatic potential solutions in rectangular, cylindrical, and spherical coordinates; dielectrics; electrostatic energy and capacitance; magnetostatics with vector calculus; Biot-Savart law; vector and scalar potentials for magnetism; magnetic permeability; Faraday’s law in integral and differential form; magnetic energy and inductance; displacement current; lumped oscillations and LCR systems; impedance.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture and one hour recitation per week. The recitation will focus on mathematical methods and techniques applied to problem solving.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching University Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: A discussion of techniques which will aid in the development of understanding the concepts in physics. Emphasis is placed on models of learning and teaching techniques which can be applied to the teaching of contemporary physics to university students. These models and techniques are used to analyze a teaching approach of topics, such as quantum mechanics, which is important to today’s physicist.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three class hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electromagnetic Fields II
htmlparse.Course.description: Second of a two semester study of Maxwell’s equations in both integral and differential forms. Special relativity; Lorentz transformations; relativistic invariants; transformation properties of electric and magnetic fields and potentials; Lorentz force and electrodynamics; electromagnetic fields of a point charge; electromagnetic waves; solutions to the wave equation in rectangular, cylindrical, and spherical geometries; wave propagation in matter; reflection, refraction, and transmission; wave guides and fiber optics; Fresnel equations; polarization; dipole radiation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Measurements Instrumentation
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory-oriented course to acquaint students with electronic circuits, their interfacing with measuring instruments, and their use in making physical measurements.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four (4) class hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computations in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to applying computational and numerical techniques to solve problems of interest to physicists. Topics include the application of computational analysis and solution to physical problems in both classical, and quantum physics including particle structure and motion, interaction of particles with fields, and model building for simulation of physical phenomena. A practicum is an integral part of the course. Students will use both personal computers and advanced workstations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture, two hours of computer lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the structure of the nucleus, radioactivity, and nuclear energy; the application of quantum mechanics to describe nuclear physics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Optics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to modern concepts in optics: electromagnetic waves, propagation of light through media, geometrical optics of lenses, mirrors and simple optical instruments, polarization, interference, coherence, and diffractions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taught in a studio format; three hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Optics and Optical Measurement
htmlparse.Course.description: Topical approach oriented toward measurements including coherence, Fourier Optics, holography, light scattering, interferometry, laser technology.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring, in alternate years following PHYS 651
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physics of Solids
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the physics of solids with an emphasis on energy band structures, electrical and optical properties of solids and solid state devices.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts and mathematical models of quantum physics. Solutions to the time independent Schrödinger equation, descriptions of one-electron and multi-electron atoms, electron spin and magnetic moments.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one hour recitation per week. The recitation will focus on mathematical methods and techniques applied to problem solving.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to thermodynamics developed from the concepts of statistical physics. Applications include the gas laws, concepts of heat and work, phase transitions, and kinetic theory with applications to statistical physics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Astrophysics
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the application of physical principles to understanding astronomical objects. Topics include properties of stars, stellar evolution, galaxies, and cosmology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Cosmology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the physics and astrophysics of the hot big bang model to the Universe.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Particle Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An experimental and phenomenological introduction to high energy physics. The course will emphasize understanding the experimental basis of what is known about the subnuclear domain. Students will be asked to design simple conceptual experiments in addition to solving problems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cosmology
htmlparse.Course.description: A general-relativity-based discussion of the physics of the hot big bang model of the Universe.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Special topics courses. Topics and credits announced for the semester in which offered. May be given in conjunction with lecture series by visiting scientists.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or senior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Quantum Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of Schrödinger’s theory of quantum mechanics and its application to one electron atoms, multielectron atoms, quantum statistics, spectra of molecules and selected topics in quantum excitations of solids, nuclear physics, and elementary particles.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Physics of Lasers
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory of lasers including Light-matter interactions, atomic rate equations, threshold and oscillation; resonators and cavity modes; and laser dynamics including Q-switching and mode-locking.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: This lecture course introduces basic cellular biology for students lacking a biological background and established connections between molecular and cellular phenomena (such as photosynthesis, cellular foraging, and nerve stimulation) and experimentally verifiable models built from physical (classical, statistical, and quantum mechanical, as well as electromagnetic) considerations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Field Trip
htmlparse.Course.description: Field trip requirement: each spring students will be required to participate in a 4- to 5-day field trip.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to City Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: The origins and evolution of planning in response to economic, social, political, physical, and environmental issues. The planning process and its relationship to the design professions and the social and behavioral sciences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Principles Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of the principles and process of regional and community planning as practiced by the profession. The tools, skills and knowledge of the planning professions are presented in a focused introduction to the profession.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Corequisite: PLAN 315, admission to the Regional and Community Planning program.

htmlparse.Course.title: World Cities
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces undergraduates from a variety of disciplines to some of the major urban areas in the world, how and why they developed, what makes them unique, what it might be like to live there, and what issues they may face in achieving a sustainable future. This course gives students a way of thinking about cities in a global context that highlights both their differences and their similarities. Through lectures, text and other multi-media formats, students explore some of the main opportunities and challenges facing the inhabitants of large cities in today’s world.

htmlparse.Course.title: Career Planning Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration and preparation for a planning internship.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tech Module
htmlparse.Course.description: Introductory theory, methods, and application of technological skills and support of concurrent required courses. Emphasis is on data collection, management, mapping and analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Design and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of recent and historical developments of urban form and space, presented through lecture and discussion. Criteria and methodology for urban design and planning as well as the role of historic preservation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Housing and Development Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: Review and evaluation of historical and current housing issues, production, and financial systems, including consideration of racial, ethnic, income, and gender issues as they relate to the role of housing developments and programs in community development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Land Development Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the process of land development in the United States, and its impacts from the perspective of developers, financial institutions, community planners, and city administrators. Focus is on the understanding of the land development process in meeting community goals and shaping land development to meet community expectations for the improvement of the community. Conflict resolution and negotiation skills represent a communication emphasis.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Development Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of past and present approaches to community development planning in the United States. Review and assessment of community development planning policies, programs and practices.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Development Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: The organization, planning, design, development, and evaluation of community development projects with real clients and actual locations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Professional Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Internship with an approved planning sponsor subject to the approval of the departmental faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in the area of regional and community planning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Off-Campus Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Off campus studies fulfilled in an approved professional office or in an approved international studies program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive application of research and planning through individual studies approved by the department faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Infrastructure and Plan Implementation
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of infrastructure systems, the transportation process, land-use, and development standards; consideration of policy options and strategies; review of financing options and regulatory requirements associated with the various infrastructure elements. The course also reviews social and other issues that affect and are affected by infrastructure related decisions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Functions of a planning administrator, including city organizational structures and the role of the planner in city administration and management; budgeting and capital improvements programming, including a study of the roles that bonds, taxation and intergovernmental grants play in the financing of various community based activities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Community and Rural Area Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Synthesis of small community and rural area change, including socio-economic-political determinants as bases for community design and planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Metropolitan Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of urban form and the making of livable and sustainable metropolitan regions from an urban design perspective.  Introduction to public and private roles in the creation of urban form at regional, city, neighborhood, and site scales; consideration of regional and global consequences of local decisions; examination of design tools and methods used to shape decision making in urban development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Mixed lecture/seminar/workshop format. Interdisciplinary course open to students in architecture, landscape architecture, regional and community planning and related disciplines.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the evolution and current state of land use regulation within constitutional limits. Introduction to zoning, subdivision, and other police power controls within the comprehensive planning process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Growth Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the process of city growth and change in relation to planning techniques and socio-economic-political determinants. Criteria and methodology for the growth management are reviewed and applied to the contemporary city.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Methods I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to quantitative methods in planning used to measure change in the demographic characteristics of communities, and changes in the economic structure of the community. Emphasis is on the location and interpretation of Census data, population projection methodologies, and processes of community economic analysis, including the application of computer concepts to problem solving and data analysis in the planning profession.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PLAN 315 or with concurrent enrollment in PLAN 315.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Methods II
htmlparse.Course.description: The application of computer concepts to problem solving and data analysis in the planning profession, for community economic analysis, market analysis, including the development of user skills in the application of various software packages for producing multimedia presentations. Included are elements of producing video and multimedia presentations of planning projects for use in public meetings, as well as professional report preparation and graphic displays of the material for public viewing. Material developed in PLAN 801 and 802 form the subject matter of the presentations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is on the analytical tools for the selection, collection, analysis, and interpretation of regional and community policy planning activities. Included is the development of survey instruments and interpretation, work flow and work measurement skills, performance standards and program evaluation techniques for policy planning and analysis at the local governmental level.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: STAT 325, STAT 350, STAT 702, or STAT 703.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Assignment to a planning staff for a period of at least 10 weeks; supervision by a professional planner with periodic reports of activities to planning faculty.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Completion of two semesters of graduate study in planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planning Theory, Ethics and Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of the basic theories of regional and community growth and change, analysis of the process of urbanization in relation to societal determinants and environmental constraints, and the study of a process of planning for professional practice. Exploration of societal and human values in relation to issues of equity, social justice, economic welfare, and efficient use of resources, as well as ethical approaches to these issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Plan Preparation
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of the principles and elements of city growth and change, with application to the preparation of a comprehensive community plan for a community in Kansas. Criteria, standards, and methodology for city analysis and planning are applied to the practice of planning. Emphasis is on collaborative group participation in a practical planning process using skills developed in the RCP program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of selected concepts and trends in regional and community planning and development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proposal Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of procedures of planning, design, scheduling, organization, and management of a regional and community planning research project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Thesis students enroll for 2 credit hours. Master’s Project and Report students enroll for 3 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Project and Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive application of research and planning through individual studies approved by the department faculty.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Requisite: PLAN 897. Co-requisite: PLAN 705 or PLAN 836.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Original research and advanced study in regional and community planning, urban design, and related fields for the master’s report/thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PLAN 803 or LAR 725 or ARCH 725 and completion of two semesters of graduate study in planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microbes, Plants, and the Human Perspective
htmlparse.Course.description: Intended for undergraduate non-science majors as part of the university general education curriculum. The relationship of the biological world (specifically microbes) to our personal and cultural perceptions of how the world works and what our place is in it. The course focuses on microbes as they interact with plants, the plant environment, and the human connection to plants as a resource. Topics include: events and historical context of germ theory, symbiosis as a biological phenomenon and analogue for human social structure, and popular perception of genetically-engineered plants and microbes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture one hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory class in the nature of plant pathogens and the cause, effect, and control of plant diseases. Diseases of field and horticultural crops will be addressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one 2-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and lectures on important areas and contributions in the field of plant pathology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and lectures on important areas and contributions in the field of plant pathology.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
Credit/No Credit.
Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crop Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of plant diseases associated with Kansas crops, with an emphasis on identification and management strategies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hour lecture and four hour lab a week. To meet first half of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turfgrass Diseases and Their Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology, diagnosis and integrated management of turfgrass diseases. Emphasis is on diseases of intensively maintained turfgrass.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: HORT 582 or concurrent enrollment and HORT 515 or concurrent enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and two hours lab a week, for the first five weeks of the semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of plant diseases associated with Kansas greenhouse and nursery production systems as well as landscape settings, with an emphasis on identification and management strategies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and one lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Undergraduate Research in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Research experience is offered in classical and molecular plant pathology and biotechnology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: The use of biotechnology and molecular genetic approaches in plant and animal sciences. Emphasis is on the use of molecular techniques for plant and animal improvement.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Biotechnology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory course designed to provide practical applications of recombinant and genomic techniques related to agricultural biotechnology. Typical techniques include genetic analysis, bioinformatics basics, DNA isolation and molecular analysis, PCR applications, southern-and northern-blot analysis, linkage mapping, genetic and disease ID through DNA-based approaches, ELISA assays, gene manipulation, eukaryotic transformation techniques.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Genomics Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to applications of genomics technologies to the analysis of genomes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 450 or ASI 500. Recommended prerequisite: BIOCH 521.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three one hour lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioinformatics Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of genetic and genomic data, focusing on practical use of public computational resources.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship for Applied Genomics and Biotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: Approved and supervised work-study programs in various areas of agribusiness.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Project reports required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fusarium Laboratory Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: A one-week laboratory/lecture course on the identification, systematics, physiology, mycotoxicology, genetics, and molecular biology of fungi in the genus Fusarium. Students should not be enrolled in any other class while attending this workshop.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 455 or BIOL 604; and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Nematology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the morphology, taxonomy, and ecology of phytoparasitic and free-living nematodes found in plants, soil, and fresh water. Emphasis is on the identification and control of plant parasitic nematodes and on lab techniques used in their study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture, one 2-hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Plant Resistance to Pests
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of the biology, ecology, genetics and breeding for pest resistance in plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ENTOM 300 or PLPTH 500 or ENTOM 312 and 313, and one course in plant or animal genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture and discussion a week. Meets first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Work is offered in general plant pathology, plant virology, plant nematology, disease physiology, epidemiology, and disease diagnosis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Resistance to Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of recent literature on conventional and novel strategies for obtaining durable resistance to plant diseases. Several well-characterized host/pathogen systems will be selected for in-depth analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture a week. To meet second half of semester for four hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gene Expression Analysis Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: One-week lecture and laboratory on RNA isolation and handling, cDNA preparation, microarray and sequence based gene expression analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: One of the following courses: PLPTH 610, AGRON 610, BIOCH 521, BIOCH 522, BIOL 675, BIOL 676.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real-Time PCR Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Four half-day lecture and laboratory sessions on real-time PCR primer/probe design, experimentation, and data analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: One of the following courses: PLPTH 610, AGRON 610, BIOCH 521, BIOCH 522, BIOL 675, BIOL 676.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Science Colloquium
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in political science chosen to illustrate current research of political scientists and approaches to the study of politics. Each time the course is offered, a syllabus will outline the topics to be studied and the way the course will be administered.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not open to political science majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to politics, public policy, and governmental processes from a political science perspective, studying political power, political thought, public opinion, groups, parties, institutions, public law, careers in politics, and related topics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Political Science, Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to politics, public policy, and governmental processes. Distribution and use of political power, political thought, public opinion, groups, parties, institutions, public law, careers in politics, and related topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Membership in arts and sciences honors program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: United States Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: The national government with emphasis on constitutional principles, basic structure, functions, and the political process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of politics in both ”developed” and ”developing” countries. Though some attention will be given to abstract and theoretical concepts, the emphasis will be on the actual political process in the countries selected for study.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Political Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the major themes and leading writers in political philosophy and a discussion of their application to modern politics. This course emphasizes learning how to read and appreciate classic texts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Kansas Politics and Government
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the political institutions of, the political behavior in and surrounding, and the public policies flowing from governmental units in the state of Kansas.

htmlparse.Course.title: United States Politics, Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: The national government with emphasis on constitutional principles, basic structure, functions, and the political process.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Membership in an honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: World Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the study of politics among nations-states and other world actors, including a survey of major contemporary problems of world politics and focusing on the pursuit of power, order, wealth, and safe environment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Political Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Each week a different political science faculty member or guest authority explains and analyzes current developments in state, national, and world affairs, using the news media as text material.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not for major credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and analysis of selected political topics of immediate relevancy and concern.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and analysis of selected political topics of immediate relevancy and concern.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Practical Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Strategies and techniques of running for office, organizing a campaign, mobilizing community resources, direct action lobbying, and related practical aspects of local level citizen politics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Public Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: The process of public policy formation and analysis with emphasis on the relationship between decisions taken, values maximized, and the social impact of these decisions in over 10 policy areas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 110 or 325 or another social science course.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Seminar in Political Science

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Inquiry and Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Underlying principles and techniques used in the conduct of political science research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Introductory social science course or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Different subjects in politics are selected for intensive study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 6 hours with advisor’s approval.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts and Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the principles of political sociology. Processes of political socialization, participation within and outside established organizational channels, recruitment of elites, communication and influence, power, decision making, and policy outputs. Data are presented from a cross-national perspective.

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary survey of recent and contemporary civilization in India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, and Afghanistan, including geography, philosophy, social, economic, political institutions, and historical movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 3 hours of social science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Public Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic concepts of public administration, with emphasis on orientation for citizen understanding; the place of administration and the role of the administrator in the American political process; the organization and activities of government in carrying out public policy; administrative functions, organization, accountability, finance, and personnel.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Chinese Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Principal components of Communist Chinese ideology, conditions determining organizational structure, composition of present leadership, role of social forces, impact of external relations on other Asian nations and on the major world powers.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: U.S. National Government and Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced overview of United States national government. Especially tailored to meet content area needs of prospective K-12 teachers. Topics to be addressed include: the constitution and the American founding; political and electoral processes; institutional structure and function; and, public policy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Non-majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Security Threats
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of global threats to the security of societies and individuals emphasizing issues outside the traditional scope of international relations theory.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Politics of the World Economy
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses the reciprocal relationship between politics and economics in the management and functioning of the world economy. Explores the political influences on worldwide trade, financial, and investment flows as well as development policies and financial institutions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: American Foreign Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of American external relations since 1945 and evaluation of processes involved in the formulation and conduct of contemporary foreign policy of the United States.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Politics of Developing Nations
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of politics in emergent states with emphasis on process of modernization and nation building.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 110 or 344 or sophomore standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Defense Strategies
htmlparse.Course.description: Contemporary international strategies and defense policies with emphasis on nuclear, conventional, and guerrilla war, arms control and disarmament, diplomatic and political roles of the military.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Senior Honors Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Open to senior majors who have attained a 3.0 grade point average in political science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mass Communications and Political Campaigns
htmlparse.Course.description: The roles of journalism, advertising and public relations in political campaigns. Examines campaign communication strategies, staffing, and the roles of political consultants.  Analyzes how voter decision making is affected by mass communications and how voters develop attitudes about candidates and issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Extensive exploration of a specific problem in political thought. American government, comparative politics, international relations, or public administration.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Parties and Elections
htmlparse.Course.description: Origins, structure and function of political parties. Dynamics of the two-party system. Roles of third parties. Analysis of election results and voting behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interest Groups and Public Opinion
htmlparse.Course.description: Group theory and politics. Structure, internal politics, and techniques of interest groups and their impact on public policy. Formation and measurement of public opinion.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: The American Presidency
