htmlparse.Course.description: The presidency as an institution, its evolution, congressional relationships, executive organization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender and Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the role of gender in political behavior, including gender differences in voting and political participation, legal and cultural restrictions on women’s rights and political activity, and women’s liberation and other gender-based political movements.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Legal analysis of the rule-making, adjudicatory, and enforcement functions of administrative agencies, with emphasis on constitutional framework, judicial review, requirements of procedural fairness, and rights of public employees.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in political science, United States history, or legal or political philosophy.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Legislative Process
htmlparse.Course.description: Legislative decision-making in modern democracy with emphasis on the United States, the concept of representation, and political behavior of participants in the legislative process.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Judicial Process
htmlparse.Course.description: The structure, process, and politics of the American judicial system. Analysis of important issues concerning law and courts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Constitutional Law I
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of the American political system as prescribed by the Constitution and interpreted by Supreme Court decisions, with emphasis on the institutions and powers of the national government, federalism, and property rights.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in political science, United States history, or legal or political philosophy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Constitutional Law II
htmlparse.Course.description: The Constitution as a limitation on governmental power, with emphasis on Supreme Court decisions defining fundamental civil rights and liberties.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in political science, United States history, or legal or political philosophy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental problems of political power and decision making in urban suburban governmental settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Agriculture Politics and Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative examination of agricultural politics and policy with emphasis on decision making processes and the socio-political impacts of agricultural policy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: State and Local Government
htmlparse.Course.description: The United States system of federalism with emphasis on a comparative analysis of the government and politics of the fifty states and their subdivisions.

htmlparse.Course.title: West European Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of British, French, German, and Italian democracies, political systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Latin American Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of selected political systems of Latin America emphasizing political inputs, political organization, and political outputs. special consideration is given to problems of political change.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 110 or 344 or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of selected political systems of South Asia.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Middle East Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of selected political systems in the Middle East including nationalism and the conflict of differing ideologies. Validity and usefulness of various theories of political development are tested.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: East Asian Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of selected political systems in East Asia, including consideration of the democratization process in the region.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: African Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of selected political systems of sub-Sahara Africa, including consideration of problems of nationalism and development.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Eastern and Central European Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of comparative politics and policy in the countries of Easter and Central Europe.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Civic Engagement
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar on the role of voluntary organizations and civic groups in American political life and the factors that lead citizens to participate in both electoral and non-electoral activities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Development Policy and Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative examination of development policy, politics, and administration.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Politics of Russia and the Former Soviet Union
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the major factors influencing the evolution of politics in Russia and the Soviet Union. Special emphasis is placed on the problems associated with the transition from a communist to a non-communist more democratic policy.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethnic Conflict
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethnic Conflict in Comparative Prospective.  Comparative examination of ethnic conflicts across regions with the emphasis on Africa.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Conflict
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the nature of international political conflicts and the types of such conflicts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Human Rights
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to human rights in the global system with a focus on the philosophical foundations, historical evolution, institutional development, and important actors in global human rights.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Politics of Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: Relationships among the countries of Europe since World War II. With emphasis on efforts to create a more unified European Community. Among the organizations that will be studied are the former Warsaw Pact, NATO, the European Parliament, and the European Union.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Law
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories of international law, and general problems, such as: recognition, responsibility, war crimes, sources, evidence, codification, and settlement of disputes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Not-For-Profit Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Unique management issues in terms of policy setting, participation, administrations, and accountability of non-profit organizations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Organization
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure, functions, values, and effectiveness of international organizations with emphasis on the United Nations, European Union, and other regional arrangements.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Politics of South Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of regional problems of South Asia and of international roles and foreign policies of South Asian states.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Politics of the Middle East
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of the Arab-Israeli conflict, inter-Arab relations, foreign policies of Middle Eastern states, and the impact of the major foreign powers on the area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 333, 344, or three hours of other social sciences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Politics of Africa
htmlparse.Course.description: The course analyzes contemporary relations among African countries including economic and political security, border claims, formal and informal economic relations, and regional groupings. The course also examines the relations between African countries, the United States and the former Soviet Union, and between African countries and the former colonial rulers.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Politics of Latin America
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of international relations of Latin America. Examining theoretical approaches to the study of Latin America’s relations, United States Latin American relations, and comparative foreign policies of Latin American states. This course also explores special topics such as regional integration and geopolitics.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Thought: Classical to Sixteenth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematic study of ideas about law, politics, and government of great philosophers of Western civilization from Greek antiquity to the sixteenth century.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Thought: Since the Sixteenth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the development of Western political thought from the sixteenth century to the twentieth century.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 110, 301, or 325 or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: American Political Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: Political ideas underlying the American union, including the doctrine of rights, the nature of union, liberty, property, and democracy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 110, 301, 325 or three hours in other social sciences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Law, Politics, and Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Classic and contemporary works of literature, including novels, plays, short stories, and poems, are used to explore themes in law and politics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Political Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of contemporary political ideas and social thought.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Ideologies: Their Origins and Impact
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores ideologies, including liberalism, conservatism, socialism, communism, and fascism. Their philosophical origins, transformation into systems of thought with mass appeal, and practical consequences are discussed. The conflict between ideology and philosophy is examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Religion and Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on religious life in America and its changing relationship to politics and government. Examination of the American founding as it relates to church/ state issues, the controversy over meaning of the First Amendment’s establishment and free exercise clauses, and contemporary political agendas of mainline and evangelical churches.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 110, 301, 325, or 3 hours in other social sciences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of research design, of measurement of political phenomena, and of methods for collecting and analyzing political data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer and Quantitative Analysis in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced data management, data analysis, and computing skills involved in conducting political science and public policy research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Administrative Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of public administration concepts and the morphology of administrative systems. Included are U.S., British,and French models and attempts by Third World countries to adapt these to their local cultures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Personnel Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Personnel aspects of administration at all levels of government, including recruitment, selection, discrimination law, pay, and motivation. Emphasis on to those features unique to the public sector, e.g. civil service systems, public unions, and public sector ethics law.

htmlparse.Course.title: Policy Analysis and Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of policy analysis and evaluation. Includes a discussion of the relationship between public policy and the distribution of values in society. Students analyze policies in an area of their choice; e.g., agriculture, business, health, income, trade.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Ethical issues, approaches, and strategies in public service.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: POLSC 325 or 507 or graduate standing, or consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Game Theory for Political Scientists
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to game theoretic models as applied to problems in American politics, international relations and comparative politics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Civil-Military Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: A look at civil-military relations in the United States, Russia, Germany, and Spain. Primary focus will be on understanding the political role of the military in totalitarian, authoritarian, and democratic states.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Organization Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories of the structure and mission of public organizations. Explores the use of analytical questioning of various theories, to solve organizational problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Budgeting
htmlparse.Course.description: Budgeting as apart of our political system and as a fiscal process assists in allocating scarce resources. Overview of the budgetary decision-making process and the various budgetary approaches.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intergovernmental Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Evolution of the intergovernmental system in the United States and internationally.  Emphasis on federal, state, and local interrelationships.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Professional Diplomat and Foreign Policy Formulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Present day foreign policy formulation in the United States government, including the role of professional diplomats and foreign affairs specialists in the State Department and embassies abroad, as well as within other United States government agencies.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Political Economy
htmlparse.Course.description: The course introduces students to the political and historical dimensions of the international economy, dimensions that include trade, monetary systems, foreign investment, aid, dependency, and global interdependence. This course also examines various theories and practices of the international system, the state, bureaucracies, interest groups, international organizations, bargaining processes, and distributive norms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: ECON 110 and 120, POLSC 333, 344, and 541, or junior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Government, Public Administration, and Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field work at the international, national, state, and local levels of government or with political parties or other politically oriented voluntary organizations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and a minimum of two courses in political science, at least one of which must be relevant to the internship area.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed reading and discussion of a selected topic in political science.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will complete a research project and prepare an original paper under the supervision of a faculty member.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Extensive exploration of a specific problem in political thought. American government, comparative politics, international relations, and public administration.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 6 hours in two sub-fields. Since topics will cover different areas in political science, prerequisites will be determined by the department as appropriate when the course is offered.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pro-Seminar in Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and analysis in various areas of the discipline with emphasis on critical evaluation of political conflicts and issues.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Portuguese I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of the Portuguese language, stressing Brazilian usage, and emphasizing oral and written skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Portuguese II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Portuguese I, completion of the basic presentation of structural and linguistic principles of the Portuguese language.

htmlparse.Course.title: Portuguese III
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive review of syntax and a comprehensive structural review of modern Portuguese, stressing Brazilian usage, with emphasis on composition and conversation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Portuguese IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading and discussion of selections from contemporary prose, emphasizing Brazilian writings, and review of grammatical structures as needed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Portuguese
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Portuguese
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 15 hours of Portuguese and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Pilot Glider
htmlparse.Course.description: The subject areas necessary for completion and passing of the FAA Private Pilot Written Knowledge Test for Gliders are presented.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Pilot
htmlparse.Course.description: The subject areas necessary for completion and passing of the FAA Private Pilot Written Knowledge Test are presented.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Instrument Pilot
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the procedures, regulations, and techniques required to safely fly in instrument meteorological conditions within our national airspace system. The course will prepare the student to pass the FAA Instrument Airplane Written Knowledge Test.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Pilot Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction of the fundamentals of flight. Solo flights to include all flight operations and maneuvers necessary for meeting the aeronautical experience for the FAA Private Pilot Certificate.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Instrument Pilot Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Instructional flight training necessary to maneuver the aircraft safely in actual or simulated instrument meteorological conditions within the national airspace system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Pilot Helicopter Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the flight operations and maneuvers necessary to  meet the aeronautical experience for the private pilot rotocraft helicopter class rating.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrument Helicopter Pilot Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Flight training necessary to maneuver a helicopter safely in actual or simulated instrument meteorological conditions within the national airspace system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: VFR Pilot Proficiency Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training necessary to safely operate an aircraft to meet the Federal Aviation Regulations. This course provides the student the opportunity to review and demonstrate proficiency to satisfactorily meet the FAA regulations for the current ratings held.

htmlparse.Course.title: IFR Pilot Proficiency Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction, simulator, and flight training necessary to safely operate an aircraft, to meet and maintain the Federal Aviation Regulations currency requirement of Instrument Competency, and maintain instrument currency and proficiency.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aviation Safety
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an introduction to the field of aviation safety with an emphasis on promoting a safety culture.  Various safety programs and their relevance in the field of aviation are discussed.  Students will examine numerous accident reports and discuss safety issues facing the aviation industry today.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Commercial Pilot
htmlparse.Course.description: The subject areas necessary for passing the FAA Commercial Pilot Knowledge Test.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Commercial Pilot Flight Lab I
htmlparse.Course.description: Instructional cross country flight training necessary to maneuver the aircraft safely in actual or simulated instrument meteorological conditions within the national airspace system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Commercial Pilot Flight Lab II
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to complex airplane operations and a review of those operations required of a commercial pilot. The completion of this course readies the student to take the commercial FAA Practical test.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Extended Cross Country
htmlparse.Course.description: A characteristic of aviation is that aircraft can cover a large geographic area. Aircraft operations in other geographic areas may differ greatly from a student’s training base. The experience of long-range navigation can be a great learning experience as well as a confidence booster. Selection of a destination that allows the student to increase their knowledge of aviation also aids in producing a more well-rounded, responsible professional.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mountain Flying
htmlparse.Course.description: A characteristic of aviation is that aircraft can cover a large geographic area. Aircraft operations in mountainous areas may differ greatly from a student’s training. The experience of reduced aircraft performance caused by high-density altitudes can be a great training into operations with aircraft exhibiting marginal performance. Learning of weather patterns, hypoxia, and survival allows the student to increase their knowledge of aviation and also aids in producing a more well-rounded, responsible professional.

htmlparse.Course.title: Altitude Chamber
htmlparse.Course.description: This course offers a 1-day aviation physiology course for civil aviation pilots through the CAMI’s Aeromedical Education Division in Oklahoma City, OK. In addition to the basic academic contents, this course offers practical demonstrations of rapid decompression and hypoxia in a hypobaric chamber, as well as a practical demonstration of spatial disorientation. Upon completion of the course students will receive a certificate noting that they have completed the FAA’s Physiological Training course. The FFA requires a current Aviation Medical Certificate.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Glider Towing
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training necessary to obtain a logbook endorsement in the techniques and procedures for the safe towing of gliders.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial Pilot Helicopter Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Ground instruction covering helicopter aircraft to develop the aeronautical knowledge to meet the ground school requirements for a commercial pilot rotocraft helicopter class rating.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Single Engine Seaplane Transition
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training necessary to add the seaplane rating to the commercial pilot certificate.  Course requires a one-week trip to a specified contract training location.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Preventive Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will give the student hands-on experience with the maintenance tasks allowed under FAR 43 entitled preventive maintenance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial Pilot Helicopter Flight Lab I
htmlparse.Course.description: Flight instruction and experience to build time for the Commercial Pilot rating.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial Pilot Helicopter Flight Lab II
htmlparse.Course.description: Flight instruction and experience in a helicopter to develop the aeronautical skills to meet the requirements for a commercial pilot rotocraft helicopter class rating.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Pilot Glider Transition
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training in the design, performance, operating characteristics, and flight proficiency for the safe operation of glider aircraft that will lead to an Private Pilot Glider certificate. This course provides students the opportunity to enhance and develop their skills in this segment of aviation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Commercial Pilot Glider Transition
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training in the design, performance, operating characteristics, and flight proficiency for the safe operation of glider aircraft that will lead to a commercial pilot glider certificate. This course provides students the opportunity to enhance and develop their skills in this segment of aviation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Private Pilot Helicopter Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Ground instruction covering helicopter aircraft to develop the aeronautical knowledge to meet the ground school requirements for a private pilot rotocraft class rating.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Multi-Engine Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Ground instruction covering multi-engine aircraft to develop the aeronautical knowledge to meet the ground school requirements for a multi-engine land class rating.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Multi-Engine Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Flight instruction and experience in a multi-engine aircraft to develop the aeronautical skills to meet the requirements to add a multi-engine land class rating to the student’s existing pilot certificate.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrument Helicopter Pilot Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Ground instruction covering helicopter aircraft to develop the aeronautical knowledge to meet the ground school requirements for an instrument helicopter rating.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multi-Engine Crew Coordination
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction, simulator and flight training necessary to operate a multi-engine aircraft as a member of a crew. Enhances multi-engine, instrument and cross country skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tailwheel Transition
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training in the design, performance, operating characteristics, and flight proficiency for the safe operation of conventional-geared (tailwheel) aircraft that will lead to an endorsement allowing the student to act as pilot-in-command. This course provides students the opportunity to enhance and develop their skills in this segment of aviation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Flight Instructor Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction techniques, practices, and procedures necessary to provide skill in organizing and presenting lessons. This course will prepare the student for the FAA Certified Instructor Knowledge Test.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Flight Instructor Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: The needed flight skills and proper display of teaching ability will be emphasized. The demonstration of flight maneuvers with recognition of common errors in students performing the demonstrated maneuvers is stressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Flight Instructor Glider
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction techniques, practices, and procedures necessary to provide skill in organizing and presenting lessons.  Prepares the student for the FAA Certified Instructor Knowledge Test Glider.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Flight Instructor Glider Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the opportunity to apply and demonstrate concepts learned in the flight instructor glider ground instruction course (PPIL 315).  Requires demonstration of flight maneuvers and the ability to recognize common errors in student performance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Aircraft Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Electrical, environmental, hydraulic, fuel, ignition, and lubrication systems, including theory of operation and calculations. Principles, systems, analysis, operation, and limitations of advanced electronic navigation, flight director, and automatic flight control systems, including Inertial Navigation Systems and GPS.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Flight Instructor Helicopter
htmlparse.Course.description: Ground instruction covering helicopter aircraft to develop the aeronautical knowledge to meet the ground school requirements for a certified flight instructor rotocraft helicopter class rating.

htmlparse.Course.title: Flight Instructor Helicopter Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Flight instruction and experience in a helicopter to develop the aeronautical skills to meet the requirements for a helicopter instructor rating.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Helicopter Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundational instruction for helicopter operations in varying terrain and environmental conditions. Topics include helicopter flight in diverse terrain and climate, principles of flight close to the earth, and avoidance of both natural and man-made hazards. Emphasis on aeronautical decision making and cockpit resource management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or instructor consent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Turbine Transition
htmlparse.Course.description: To provide required knowledge to meet FAA requirements to operate as second-in-command in KSU transportation aircraft. Covers systems performance and emergency procedures for turbine aircraft. In conjunction with simulator training, students will be qualified to operate as co-pilots on university transportation trips.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Airline Transport Pilot Rating
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the student with the aeronautical knowledge necessary to prepare for the FAA Airline Transport Pilot Knowledge Test. The demonstration of flight maneuvers, with recognition of proper control of emergencies in compliance of the Airline Transport Pilot Practical Test Standards will be stressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crew Resource Management I
htmlparse.Course.description: This course involves using all available resources for a safe and efficient flight.  Aircraft crew performance is reviewed to include the background and philosophy of Crew Resource Management (CRM) communication, decision behavior, team building, workload management, and situational awareness. Students accomplish two flight scenarios using a Canadair Regional Jet advanced aircraft training device.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Aviation
htmlparse.Course.description: To provide the student an opportunity to apply aviation education to the improvement of skills previously learned as designated by the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Repeatable.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Upset Training and Recovery
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction and flight training necessary to develop an understanding and flight proficiency in basic upset flight attitudes. This course provides the student the opportunity to develop a better understanding of aircraft and safety of flight in other than normal flight attitudes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crew Resource Management II
htmlparse.Course.description: Utilizing a Canadair Regional Jet advanced aircraft training device, special emphasis is placed on systems knowledge, flight profiles and cockpit flows of the CRJ 200.  Students fly Line Orientated Flight Training (LOFT) missions and self-critique their performance.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and two three-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Instrument Flight Instructor Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Instrument instruction techniques, practices, and procedures necessary to provide skills in organizing and presenting lessons in instrument flying procedures. This course will prepare the student for the FAA Certified Instrument Flight Instructor knowledge test.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Instrument Flight Instructor Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Instrument instruction techniques, practices, and procedures necessary to provide skills in organizing and presenting lessons in instrument flying procedures. This course will prepare the student for the FAA Certified Instrument Flight Instructor practical test.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PPIL 314. Prerequisite or corequisite: PPIL 482.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Instrument Flight Instructor helicopter Flight Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Instrument instruction techniques, practices, and procedures necessary to provide skills in organizing and presenting lessons in instrument flying procedures. Prepares the student for the FAA Certified Instrument Flight Instructor practical test.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Multi-Engine Flight Instructor Ground School
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the student with the aeronautical knowledge necessary to meet the requirements for the addition of an airplane, multi-engine rating to the flight instructor certificate.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Certified Multi-Engine Flight Instructor Lab
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides the student with the aeronautical skills and experience necessary to meet the requirements for the addition of an airplane, multi-engine rating to the flight instructor certificate.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PPIL 314. Prerequisite or corequisite: PPIL 492.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Helicopter Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: The in-depth study of helicopter operations in civil operations. Topics will include helicopter operations in law enforcement, EMS, petroleum industry, etc. Advanced helicopter systems, multi-crew and multi-engine helicopter operations will also be addressed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or instructor consent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Freshman Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: An orientation and introduction to the field of psychology for freshman psychology majors only. Additional emphasis on the means by which psychological principles can be used to adapt to college life.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory survey of the general content areas of psychology, including methods, data and principles.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: General Psychology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory survey of the general content areas of psychology, including methods, data and principles.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: General Psychology (Honors)
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory survey of the general content areas of psychology, including methods, data and principles.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Junior Seminar in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of professional, research, and educational methods and objectives in psychology. Acquaints psychology majors with psychology as a profession, and with the various options available to them at various levels of training.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Should be taken during first semester of junior year. Offered Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drugs and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Effects of drugs on human performance, cognition, and physiological processes will be discussed and the empirical evidence surveyed and critically evaluated in relation to both use and abuse of drugs in society.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Childhood and Adolescence
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of behavioral development from birth through adolescence.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Innovative Studies in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected in consultation with the instructor. To be used for interdisciplinary and innovative approaches to psychological topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Innovative Studies in Psychology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected in consultation with the instructor. To be used for interdisciplinary and innovative approaches to psychological topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Methods in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory investigation of learning, motivation, social-personality processes, and perception and sensation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Includes three hours recitation and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Brain and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: A general overview of human brain function using case studies as a primary means for understanding the relationship between behavior and brain mechanisms.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Teaching Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in presentation of psychological concepts in various classes. May be taken only with approval of the instructor of a psychology class under whose supervision the student will obtain this experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor; nine hours of psychology including PSYCH 110; junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problem Solving and Decision Making
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides both the psychological background and practical aids to help solve problems in everyday decision making. Skills to be covered include creativity, methods of problem solving, memory aids, decision-making tools, avoiding biases of judgment, etc.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Forensic Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of psychological principles and facts in areas such as perception, cognition, neuropsychology, social psychology, personality, and decision making, as they apply to forensic psychology. Topics include: polygraph (lie detection), eyewitness testimony, jury decision making, and profiling.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Applications of Memory
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the applications of memory in such diverse areas as courtroom testimony, expert performance, mnemonic procedures, and advertising. Relevant theories and research in each area are examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cognitive Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the manner in which people extract and use relevant information from their environment as a basis for behavior. Topics may include memory storage and retrieval, attention, imagery, mnemonic devices, decision making, and other cognitive processes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychobiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Behavior from a biological point of view. Topics include: behavioral neuroscience techniques, sensory coding, food and water intake, sexual behavior, sleep and waking, memory, and learning.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the principles of learning and their relevance to the understanding of the behavior of animals and humans.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Perception and Sensation
htmlparse.Course.description: Empirical and theoretical approaches to phenomena of sensation and perception.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Tutorial in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual directed research and study of a topic in psychology, normally as a preliminary to writing a senior honors thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, membership in the honors program of the College of Arts and Sciences, and permission of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once to a total of 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Abnormal Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory study of behavior pathologies, with emphasis on their etiology and treatment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Behavior Modification
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the principles of behavior modification and applications to human behavior. Emphasis on the learning principles and research in behavior modification.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology Applied to Work
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the basic theories and practices used by industrial and organizational psychologists to enhance individual and organizational effectiveness and well-being. Topics include personnel selection, training, performance management, job attitudes, work motivation, leadership, occupational health, and group processes at work.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Health Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Psychosocial factors relevant to general health maintenance, recovery from disease or injury, and the achievement of health. Topics include stress-management techniques, personality characteristics associated with disease, cognitive-emotional effects of diet and exercise, and theories of pain and pain management. Concepts of prevention and behavioral medicine are also included.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Life Span Personality Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories and research in the development of personality from infancy through old age. Origins of personality in heredity and early experience, socialization practices, life crises and choices at various stages throughout life, and problems of aging.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: The psychological effects of mass communication on behavior and thought, including advertising, stereotyping of women and minorities, effects on children, violence and sex in the media, effects of news on behavior, and the promotion of prosocial behavior through the media.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Psychology of the individual in society. Survey of empirical studies and theoretical models of social perception, attitudes, and social behavior (e.g., attribution, ethnic and gender prejudice, conformity). Relationship of these topics to personal and media influence, social mores, and social systems is also included.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Women
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of psychological processes of women. A developmental sequence with emphasis on major life events for women. Female physiology, early socialization into sex roles, friendship, achievement motivation, sexuality, marriage, childbearing, work, and mental health.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women’s Mental Health Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigates prevalent women’s mental health issues such as incidence of depression/anxiety, eating disorders, sexuality, relationship concerns. Also covers the efficacy of traditional treatment modalities and newer therapies that target women’s unique mental health needs such as feminist or nonsexist therapies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Consumer Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of psychological principles and facts in perception, learning, attitude formation, personality, etc., as they apply to behavior of consumers.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Psychological Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will read primary literature, design research studies, employ the instruments and technology currently used in psychological research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 350, STAT 325 or equivalent. Corequisite: Majors only, Grade of B or better in PSYCH 350.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduce and familiarize students with the concept of multicultural psychology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Psychology of Ethnic Humor
htmlparse.Course.description: Reviews the structure, dynamics, and social functions of ethnic humor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Varieties of Consciousness
htmlparse.Course.description: Traditional and contemporary approaches of both Western science and Eastern metaphysics to study of ordinary mind consciousness, unusual states of awareness, and efforts to expand the powers of mind. Topics include sleep, dreaming, biofeedback, meditation, psychoactive drugs, brain area dominance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychological Testing
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of psychological testing in industrial, clinical/counseling, and research environments. Topics include technical issues such as reliability, validity, norming, selection, placement, discrimination, etc. Also covers procedures for selecting, administering, and interpreting psychological tests.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of human behavior and psychological principles in an industrial/personnel context. Topics include: recruiting, selecting, and training personnel; evaluating their job performance; conducting job analyses; and implementing compensation strategies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory in Industrial Psychology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in personnel psychology including classifications, analysis, and evaluation of jobs.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory in Industrial Psychology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Additional supervised experience in personnel psychology including interviewing, EEOC regulations, training, and performance appraisal.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender Issues in the Workplace
htmlparse.Course.description: Psychological experiences of women and men in the world of work, with emphasis on traditional and nontraditional sex-role behavior, sexual discrimination and harassment, and relevant socialization experiences.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Relationships between individuals, groups, and organizations. How organizational factors contribute to individual behavior, and how individuals affect groups and organizational functioning. Emphasis is on such traditional topics as work motivation, job satisfaction and other attitudes, leadership, communication, socialization, and organization and job design.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Occupational Health Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of occupational health issues for juniors and seniors. Provides students with a background in psychologically related health issues occurring at work. The basic processes for identification, prevention, treatment, and well being of workers will be identified and explored.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychopharmacology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of basic principles of neural communication and pharmacology, the etiology and bio-behavioral bases of substance abuse, and chemical treatments of psychiatric disorders.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Natural and Physical Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Sexual Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of psychological determinants and consequences of human sexual behavior; roles of personality, attitudinal and emotional factors will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Concepts in Clinical Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical analysis of the profession. Review of theoretical and empirical bases of such areas as intelligence and its measurement, personality and diagnosis, psychotherapy, and other modes of behavioral change.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 110, 505, and 3 additional hours of psychology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Laboratory in Clinical Concepts
htmlparse.Course.description: May be taken only in conjunction with PSYCH 585. Supervised practice in, demonstration of, and orientation to selected psychological techniques and practices.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Placement
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an agency or institutional setting in the application of psychological techniques to individuals, groups, or organizations. Regular supervision emphasizes relationship between theory and application and the evaluation of outcomes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 585 and 586, or 560; 561, and 562 and consent of psychological technician training committee.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 500-level psychology courses cannot be taken for graduate credit by students in psychology graduate programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interdisciplinary Topics in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected in consultation with the instructor, covering interdisciplinary and innovative approaches to psychological topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of selected problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Social Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced look at some of the core topics in social psychology (e.g. the self, social influence, personal relationships, prejudice and discrimination, group processes) with a strong emphasis on applying the theory in these areas to current social problems and students’ daily lives.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Personality
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of different approaches to the study of personality.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of behavioral factors in the design and operation of machines and equipment.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Neuropsychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of brain-behavior relationships in humans. Brief review of human neuroanatomy followed by a major emphasis on brain function in learning, memory, language, and other cognitive behaviors. Also includes an examination of behavioral alterations following brain damage.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 198 and PSYCH 110, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Natural and Physical Sciences Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Language
htmlparse.Course.description: Experimental study of language, including sentence comprehension and memory, language acquisition and development, speech perception, and effects of context, perception, reasoning, and linguistic structure on processing of language.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: The psychological aspects of human aging. An analysis of the contributions of experimental, developmental, and personality-social psychology to the study of aging. The psychopathology of aging and psychological intervention strategies are also covered.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Current Trends
htmlparse.Course.description: A review of the contributions of individuals and intellectual movements to the development of modern psychology. A survey of theoretical systems currently of influence.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 110 and 9 additional hours of psychology; senior standing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 110 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: PSYCH 110 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Recreation Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of topics and activities of importance in recreation resources.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course can be repeated an unlimited number of times.

htmlparse.Course.title: Firearms and Firearms Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will cover the types and functions of firearms used in hunting/shooting sports to include rifles, shotguns and handguns. Basic firearms maintenance will also be covered in this course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class held off campus at Fancy Creek State Shooting Range over a weekend. Minimum 15 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rifle and Handgun Range Design, Construction and Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers the design and construction of rifle/handgun shooting ranges based on national standards. The course will also cover operational issues including events planning and implementation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class held off campus at Fancy Creek State Shooting Range over a weekend. Minimum 15 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bowhunting Equipment and Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers the bowhunting equipment currently used for hunting. Bowhunting skills to include distance estimation, shot placement, etc. are also covered in this course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class held off campus at Fancy Creek State Shooting Range over a weekend. Minimum 15 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hunter Education Instructor
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide information and training necessary for qualification as a certified hunter education instructor.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Some sessions will be held off campus at Fancy Creek State Shooting Range. Minimum 15 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sporting Clays Range Development and Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will cover the history and present day rules of sporting clays, the development of sporting clays ranges and their ongoing operations and maintenance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class held off campus at Flint Oak Hunting/Shooting Resort, Fall River, Kansas over a weekend. Minimum 15 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Trap and Skeet Range Development and Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will cover the development of “trap” and “skeet” shooting ranges. Operating principles will be covered to include staffing, event planning and implementation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class held off campus at Flint Oak Hunting/Shooting Resort, Fall River, Kansas, over a weekend. Minimum 15 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wildlife Habitat/Food Plot Installation and Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers existing wildlife habitat management techniques plus the renovation of deteriorated habitats and the creation of new habitat areas/food plots to support wildlife species.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: AGRON 305; available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Class held off campus at selected Tuttle Creek Reservoir sites operated by KSU and Kansas Department of Wildlife and Parks. Minimum 30 contact hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Life and Leisure
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of recreation and leisure fundamentals and history, and the public and private organizations that facilitate and deliver leisure services. Designed to enhance the future leisure service professional’s understanding of the significance of recreation and leisure and the contribution each makes to life satisfaction.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers the wildlife and outdoor enterprise management business and profession in North America and worldwide.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Outdoor Recreation Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will help students effectively communicate the importance of outdoor recreation and natural resource conservation to the public. Students will gain experience in group dynamics and a variety of leadership approaches involving nationally recognized environmental education programs. Some local field trips are required.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Parks and Recreation Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Required professional employment (240 hours, 6 weeks): a survey and application of the principles of park and recreation areas management and operations. Studies of selected aspects of natural resource management for recreation. Preparation and presentation of a comprehensive analysis of a specific assigned problem.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Sophomore in park management and conservation or recreation park administration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program and Event Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the design, supply, and marketing of recreation programs by a variety of public, private, and commercial recreation and park agencies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Parks and Recreation
htmlparse.Course.description: An intensive, paid practical experience with an approved agency, extending over a 10-week, 400-hour span.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For seniors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles and Practices of Big Game Hunting and Guiding
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional principles and practices associated with hunting North American Big Game to include: ethics, species habitat requirements, daily and seasonal activity of each species, methods of harvest, post harvest handling and clientele interactions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two weekend field trips required. Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles and Practices of Upland Gamebird, Turkey and Waterfowl Hunting
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional principles and practices associated with hunting upland game birds and waterfowl species in North America to include: ethics, laws, species habitat requirements, daily and seasonal activities of each species, methods of harvest, dog handling, post harvest handling and clientele interactions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
Recommended prerequisite: RRES 375, BIOL 433, BIOL 684.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two weekend field trips required. Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles and Practices of Freshwater Fishing and Guiding
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional principles and practices associated with freshwater fishing in North America to include: Ethics, laws, species habitat requirements, daily and seasonal activities of each game species, methods of harvest, post harvest handling and clientele interactions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites:
Prerequisite: Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
Recommended prerequisite: RRES 375, BIOL 433, BIOL 684.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two weekend field trips required. Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship for Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive, paid practical experience with an approved hunting and/or shooting sports and/or fishing business. This is a seven month continuous experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing. Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Water Resources for Leisure
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the management of water resources for leisure time uses. The course investigates the use of rivers, lakes, reservoirs, and marine resources. Management considerations, including agency policy formation, legal rights, use conflicts, and use valuation are covered.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Park Operations and Facilities Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A focus on the principles and practices of operating and maintaining park and recreation areas and facilities. Special emphasis will be given to the operation of community parks, campgrounds, trails and OHV areas, marinas, zoos, shooting ranges, aquatic facilities, and multipurpose sports complexes and recreation centers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management Senior Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will be used as a capstone course for the Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management curriculum; to include case studies and field experience reviews.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing. Available only to Wildlife and Outdoor Enterprise Management majors.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Historical Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Environmental Interpretation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on principles and techniques necessary to communicate environmental and cultural values to visitors in park areas. The philosophy, theory, design, and application of interpretive media to communicate information about the environment is studied.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours recitation and three hours lab a week. Field trips required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Environmental Interpretation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course builds on the principles and interpretive techniques which are introduced in RRES 635. Specifically, labs emphasize development of personal interpretive skills and students are introduced to interpretive media not covered in RRES 635 (e.g., video equipment, computers, etc.). The lecture and readings focus on the philosophy of interpretation and the theoretical framework for designing and evaluating interpretive strategies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lecture and four hours lab a week. Field trips required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Parks and Recreation Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will introduce students to the use of specific practices to effectively manage a contemporary leisure service enterprise. Special emphasis is placed on financial management, human resource management, policy development, risk management and general administrative operations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian IL
htmlparse.Course.description: Language laboratory. Strongly recommended for students taking Russian I.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Concurrent enrollment in Russian I required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For Credit/No Credit only. Credit given only upon receiving a passing grade for the concurrent section of Russian I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian IIL
htmlparse.Course.description: Language laboratory. Strongly recommended for students taking Russian II.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Concurrent enrollment in Russian II required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For credit/No credit only. Credit given only upon receiving a passing grade for the concurrent section of Russian II.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of modern Russian. Emphasis on the sounds of Russian, the use of the Cyrillic alphabet, and oral drills with added practice in the language laboratory.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of the study of Russian grammar and oral communication.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian Culture and Civilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Russia’s past and present in the light of principal ideologies with emphasis upon fine art, literature, music, religion, politics, and education. Equal time will be devoted to the Tsarist and Soviet periods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Knowledge of Russian is not required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian III
htmlparse.Course.description: Completion of the study of Russian grammar. Reading of selected prose on the intermediate level.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive review of Russian grammar. Exercises in reading selected modern Russian texts in the original.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Studies in Russian
htmlparse.Course.description: Offered only to participants in study abroad programs. Prior consultation for approval is expected.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: At the discretion of the department, the course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian Literature in Translation: The Nineteenth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of principal writers of Tsarist Russia with emphasis upon Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, and Chekhov.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Courses taught in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian Literature in Translation: The Soviet Period
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of Russian literature since the Revolution, with emphasis upon Mayakovsky, Sholokov, Pasternak, and Solzhenitsyn.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Courses taught in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian V
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading of Russian short stories of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including works by Pushkin, Lermontov, Dostoevsky, and Chekhov.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Survey of Russian Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: A history of Russian literature from its beginnings until the present, with emphasis on the works of the nineteenth century, including those of Pushkin, Lermontov, Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, and Tolstoy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Russian Conversation and Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion in Russian. Extensive practice in writing Russian compositions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Russian
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Russian
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head and instructor involved.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: Development, structure, and functioning of human groups; social and cultural patterns; and the principal social processes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Sociology-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Development, structure, and functioning of human groups; social and cultural patterns; and the principal social processes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Sociology, Honors
htmlparse.Course.description: Development, structure, and functioning of human groups; societal and cultural patterns; the nature of sociological inquiry. Lecture, discussion, and independent study.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised independent and/or interdisciplinary study projects.
