htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of social problems such as drug use, crime, juvenile delinquency, mental illness, unemployment, and family instability.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Criminal Justice Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major components in the American criminal justice system and how these reflect and are affected by norms and changes in our society. Special emphasis is placed on issues of gender, race/ethnicity, and class within criminal justice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Police and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines in detail the policing function in society and the role police play in the criminal justice process.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of globalization and contemporary social problems around the world. Emphasis on non-Western, low-income countries. Examines food and hunger, global warming, debt crisis, democratization, ethnic conflict, and structures of economic and political inequality.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: Readings and discussion of selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open to non-majors in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Organization and Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis of community organization and change in American communities, with special emphasis on non metropolitan places. Issues include the analysis of internal community organizational ties, the interaction between the local community and its external environment, and the exploration of various methods affecting community development and social change within communities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sport and Contemporary Society
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of sport and its role in contemporary society. Course creates a greater awareness of the social significance of sport in society and fosters the capacity to use critical thinking in the analysis of significant sport issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Organization
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and processes of the organization and structure of human societies. Examines how people create social institutions and how these organizations and structures shape human relations and experience. Analysis of capitalism and other forms of social organization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Social Interaction
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of theories of social interaction and social psychology with special attention to research on principles of interpersonal relations in social situations, group formation, maintenance, and change.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Youth and Crime
htmlparse.Course.description: Nature, extent, and causes of delinquency; characteristics of delinquents; means of prevention and treatment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gangs in American Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Covers the historical development and current status of gangs in America.  Focus on gang types/forms, criminal activities and sociological impact on communities.  Also examines gang control mechanisms as well as classic and modern research conducted about gangs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Social Sciences Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Criminal Justice System and Family Violence
htmlparse.Course.description: This course critically examines the incidence and prevalence of family violence in society, emphasizing how the criminal justice system responds to this social problem.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Prisons and Punishment
htmlparse.Course.description: The historical development and current status of the correctional system. Major institutional components include jails, prisons, probation, parolee, and other forms of community corrections. Modern issues such as offender and victim rights and electronic monitoring are also covered.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociological Perspectives on Contemporary Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of a selected topic of contemporary interest. Topics vary from semester to semester and might include: impact of public policy on rural life; white collar crime; student-athlete education; social change in the Third World.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proficiency Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrative review of sociological concepts and skills under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and superior performance in relevant course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: For single students or groups of students. Not applicable to major field requirements. Not repeatable. For undergraduate credit only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the principles of political sociology. Processes of political socialization, participation within and outside established organizational channels, recruitment of elites, communication and influence, power, decision making, and policy outputs. Data are presented from a cross-national perspective.

htmlparse.Course.title: South Asian Civilizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary survey of the development of civilizations in India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, and Afghanistan, including geography, philosophy, social, economic, political institutions, and historical movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 3 hours of social science or junior standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: International Development and Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the socioeconomic and political dimensions of international development, with attention focused on developing world contexts. Special attention is given to understanding post-war development trends, including the debt crisis, globalization and neoliberalism, and movements for social change, such as the anti-globalization and the fair trade movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Welfare as a Social Institution
htmlparse.Course.description: The development and present status of social welfare in meeting changing human needs and the requirements in other parts of our social system; the analysis of present-day philosophy and functions of social welfare.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Social Theories
htmlparse.Course.description: A systematic survey of major theoretical approaches in sociology. The works of Marx, Weber, Durkheim, and other classical theorists are examined, along with selections from major contemporary perspectives such as functionalism, symbolic interactionism, structuralism, critical theory, and feminist theory. Current debates over structure versus agency, postmodernism, and other controversies are considered.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Social Research I
htmlparse.Course.description: Treatment of the logic and procedures involved in the formulation of a research problem and the difficulties encountered in conducting research. Examines problems of explanation and prediction, the process of inquiry, elements of the scientific method, the design of research, and analysis in the social sciences.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211, STAT 325 or equivalent. To include 1 credit hour of lab and field research experience.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociological Field Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to field/qualitative methods. Includes collection and analysis of data using techniques such as interviewing, observation, and unobtrusive measures. Taking field notes, report writing, and ethical issues are also stressed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Urban Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: Growth, development, and structure of the city as determined by geographical, ecological, and social factors; relation of rural and urban communities; problems of the city and various approaches to their solution.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rural Society
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of United States rural society, including change in agricultural structure, rural demographic shifts, growth of the rural service sector, rural class structure, decline and transformation of rural communities, and linkages to urban society. Examination of selected rural institutions such as education and religion.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Population Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: World population trends and their implications for economic development, public policy, and social and cultural change. The interaction of fertility, mortality, and migration with the size, distribution, and structure of populations in nations and world regions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: The interrelations among human societies, social institutions, and the biophysical environment. Emphasis on the reciprocal links among technological change, economic structure, and the ecological basis of human societies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Wealth, Power, and Privilege
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of social inequality, particularly within the contemporary United States. Competing explanations for unequal wealth, status, power, etc. Emphasis on explanations related to class, occupational structure, gender, and ethnicity.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Gerontology: An Introduction to the Sociology of Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the phenomenon of human aging in its individual, social, and cultural aspects with special attention to the problems of aging populations in Western societies.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Sociology of Women
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines patterns of gender in contemporary society and corresponding experiences of women. The course emphasizes both interactional and structural approaches and provides an overview of theoretical work in the field. Particular attention is paid to how gender interacts with ethnicity, class, and sexuality.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Bureaucracy in Modern Societies
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature and types of bureaucratic organizations in modern societies. Selected aspects of their internal structure, such as peer group and hierarchical relations in organizations, processes of communication, management, and impersonal mechanisms of control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Criminology
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses basic concepts, theories, and research methods used in the study of crime, with an emphasis on critical perspectives on crime as a social phenomenon. The course provides an overview of the nature and extent of major categories of crime as well as the integration of current issues dealing with crime.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Study of Serial Murder
htmlparse.Course.description: The course critically examines the social construction of serial murder as a phenomenon that has long existed but only recently has been polarized as a concern of the criminal justice system and the public in general. The objective of the course is to synthesize historical and social scientific analysis of serial murder, assess public and media debates centered on both offenders and victims, and evaluate the portrayal of serial murder in contemporary literature and film.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Empirical and Quantitative Reasoning Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Program and Policy Formulation and Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of policies and programs developed to cope with various social problems. Emphasis will be on analysis of existing programs and policies and the formulation of alternative policies. Attention will be given to policy change through legislative action.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Internship Orientation
htmlparse.Course.description: This course prepares students for internship placements. Resumes are written, interview procedures discussed, agency interviews conducted, internships selected, and agency orientation completed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Criminology and Sociology Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in various agencies within the criminal justice systems or other public or private organizations in areas involving applied sociological analysis or practice. Criminology majors wishing to pursue careers in the field of criminal justice are strongly encouraged to complete an internship. General sociology students may take this course under the direction of a faculty member who agrees to serve as their internship advisor. Does not fulfill sociology or criminology elective requirements.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Must be taken concurrent with SOCIO 569.

htmlparse.Course.title: Criminology and Sociology Professional Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrates field experience and everyday practices with relevant bodies of sociological and criminological theory and research.  Must be taken concurrent with SOCIO 568.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Race and Ethnic Relations in the USA
htmlparse.Course.description: This survey of racial and ethnic relations focuses on discrimination and conflict now as well as on background factors of the past to enlarge understanding of dominant and minority groups.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of the Death Penalty
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies data, public opinion, execution patterns and methods, and debates regarding capital punishment as public policy in the U.S. from early history to 21st century.  Examines selected cases and issues such as general deterrence, methods of execution, and constitutional challenges.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Social Science Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: The Construction of the Criminal Mind
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines interaction between social forces and physical experiences, such as cognitive impairment and/or abuse.  Critically reviews history of criminology and biological theories of crime; explores how remnants of these feature in current explanations of crime.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Social Science Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Religion in Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature of religion and its manifestations in different cultural systems.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender, Power, and International Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of various models of development and their impact on roles of women and men in various cultures. Emphasis upon Africa, Asia, and Latin America. Comparisons of public, service, and economic sectors, including agriculture, marketing, and industry. Examination of policy issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 or ANTH 200 and 3 additional hours in sociology or cultural anthropology.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Human Trafficking
htmlparse.Course.description: The course explores a range of topics related to human trafficking, anti-trafficking institutions, and legislation in the context of globalization. Analysis of contemporary forms of slavery-like practices (forced labor, child trafficking, domestic servitude, and others), with primary focus on sex trafficking of women.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of the Family
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin and development of marriage customs and systems of family organization; the preparation for family life under present conditions.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Religion
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of religion as an institution in American society. An assessment of the functions of religion and an exploration of contemporary trends and movements, including information on traditional denominations and emerging sects and cults.

htmlparse.Course.title: Post-Communist Societies
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of divergent scenarios of post-communist social transformation, primarily in the countries of Eastern Europe and Eurasia. Discussion of the history of communist societies, changing social institutions, and social stratification in the post-communist contexts.  Examines post-communist space and mobility, class and gender inequalities, political democratization, youth culture and prospects, crime, global connections of the transformation, human rights and  civil society, security and conflict, religion and ethnicity, and the changing family.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Work
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the world of work, both paid and unpaid. Examines changes that affect the organization of work and the distribution of income, and examines how change alters class, gender, and ethnic relations.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Crime
htmlparse.Course.description: Nature and extent of criminal offending among women and women offenders’ interactions with legal and criminal justice systems; women’s victimization, including rape and intimate violence; women workers in the criminal justice system, specifically in law, policing, and prison work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 561 or SOCIO 545 or other women’s studies course at the 500-level or above.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Diversity and Social Interaction in the Workplace
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines changes in the world of work; examines various contexts of work, such as business, the professions, education, and home; analyzes the social organization of work, both in terms of formal arrangements, such as authority and hierarchy, and in terms of informal structure, such as gender, race, class, and other categories of social difference; provides hands-on experience in dealing with interpersonal relations, management styles, communication, diversity issues, and conflict and stress management.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Sociology
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Migration
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive examination of international migration dynamics with a focus on immigration to the United States. Introduces current theoretical debate on migration and examines global migration trends, integration and community formation of immigrants, construction of immigration policies, and impacts on United States society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Society and Change in South Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines recent studies of family and community, population, mobility, urbanization, and modernization in the India-Pakistan region, with focus on social change.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCIO 211 or ANTH 200 and either a 500-level course in South Asian studies or one in social change and development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work: The Helping Profession
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the profession of social work and the various fields of social service by observing, experiencing, and analyzing social work and its place in society. An opportunity for the student to test social work as a possible career choice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Skills for Working with People
htmlparse.Course.description: Course develops basic skill components for the helping professions. Students learn fundamentals of interpersonal communication.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Social Work
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised independent study projects.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Communication for the Agriculture and Food Science Community
htmlparse.Course.description: This course develops communication skills among the scientific community to improve discourse with lay persons. Fundamentals of active listening as well as techniques to diffuse tense situations are addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the relationship among biological, social, psychological, and cultural systems as they affect or are affected by human behavior as it relates to social world models of practice. Emphasis on social systems understanding of human development.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Two courses in the social sciences and sophomore standing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Dynamics of Working with Older Adults
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide students in all fields a unique foundation upon which successful interaction with older adults is built. Specific communication techniques will be taught along with the knowledge, skills and values necessary to understand working with, or on the behalf of, older consumers, clients, patients and family members.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work Research Methods and Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: First of two research courses. Emphasis on social work research methodology and statistical analysis of small sample data sets. Content examines the ethics and processes of research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Social work majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proficiency Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrative review of social work concepts and skills under faculty supervision.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and superior performance in relevant course.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
For single students or groups of students. Not applicable to major field requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Welfare as a Social Institution
htmlparse.Course.description: The development and present status of social welfare in meeting changing human needs and the requirements in other parts of our social system; the analysis of present-day philosophy and the functions of social welfare.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One course in each of the following areas: sociology, economics, and political science.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of SOCWK 315, with a focus on large systems (organizations and communities). Social systems and ecological perspectives as a framework for understanding macrosystems. Structure and function of large systems and their impact on people. Institutional racism and other forms of institutional discrimination, and the importance of recognizing the functions and the effects of racial, ethnic, and other forms of community diversity.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 315. Must be taken concurrent with SOCWK 560.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work Research Methods and Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Second of two research methods courses. Emphasis on designing and conducting social work research projects appropriate for baccalaureate social work practice. Attention given to research strategies for the evaluation of social work practice.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Social work majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Practicum Preparation
htmlparse.Course.description: Social work majors take this course in the semester before enrollment in SOCWK 562 Field Experience, in preparation for the field practice experience. Students explore various fields of practice and social work settings and work with the instructor to plan their practicum for the following semester.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Senior standing and instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Social work majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work Practice I
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued development of social work practice skills. The social systems perspective is used to guide the development of a problem-solving methodology with attention to information gathering, assessment, and problem identification. Values clarification and self awareness are emphasized and the skills needed for intervention, termination, and evaluation are introduced.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 100, 200, 315, and 510; junior standing and permission of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Social Work majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work Practice II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of SOCWK 560 with emphasis on skill development in intervention techniques, and practice evaluation from a social systems perspective. A variety of intervention strategies and techniques is presented with emphasis on the development of a social work frame of reference.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 560 and senior standing and permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in community agencies and programs as a practical application of social work knowledge and skills gained from major course work. Emphasis on direct work with clients, whether individuals, groups, or communities. Seminars make use of student’s experiences to analyze social work theory and practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 550 and 561; senior standing; permission of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Social work majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Practice of Social Work in Rural Areas
htmlparse.Course.description: A review of characteristics and social problems of rural areas. The development of practice competency in social work roles and skills necessary for rural practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work Professional Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: A review of various theories in the behavioral sciences which influence the practice of social work. Primary focus of the course is on the use of these theories in implementing change in various client systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: To be taken concurrent with SOCWK 562.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Social work majors only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of policies and programs developed to cope with various social problems. Emphasis will be placed on analysis of existing programs and policies and the formulation of alternative policies. Attention will be given to policy change through organizational and legislative action.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 510; one course in each of the following areas: sociology, economics, and political science; and one course in social science research methods.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work Practice III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of social work practice sequence with focus on skills development for macro-level social work practice. Community and organization intervention strategies are presented with emphasis on the development of a social work frame of reference.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 560; senior standing; open to social work majors only.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taken concurrent with SOCWK 561.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Work with Groups
htmlparse.Course.description: Taken concurrently with SOCWK 561. Course provides the theoretical framework for effective generalist social work practice with groups, facilitates the development of group leaders who possess an understanding of group dynamics and effective leadership skills through group discussion, experiential exercises and leadership experiences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Social Work
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised independent study projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SOCWK 100 plus 6 hours of behavioral science foundation courses and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Communication for the Agriculture and Food Science Community
htmlparse.Course.description: This course develops communication skills among the scientific community to improve discourse with lay persons. Fundamentals of active listening as well as techniques to diffuse tense situations are addressed. Students will apply the skills learned to their career field through a final research project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orientation for Summer School Abroad Program in Zacatecas/Cuernavaca, Mexico
htmlparse.Course.description: Orientation for Summer School Abroad Program in Zacatecas/Cuernavaca, Mexico
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Offered only to participants in study abroad programs.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conversational Spanish for the Workplace-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the basic Spanish conversational skills focusing on everyday language used in the workplace with an emphasis on technical terms and concepts, supplemented with grammar and writing.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish 1
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for students with no prior Spanish experience.  Develops basic languages skills and cultural awareness to function in everyday situations in Spanish-speaking communities.  Conducted in Spanish with practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Less than 1-year previous Spanish study, or permission from Spanish Coordination Office.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Heritage speakers of Spanish see SPAN 365.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish 1-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for students with no prior Spanish experience.  Develops basic languages skills and cultural awareness to function in everyday situations in Spanish-speaking communities.  Conducted in Spanish with practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Less than 1-year previous Spanish study, or permission from Spanish Coordination Office.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Heritage speakers of Spanish see SPAN 365.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish 2
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Spanish 1.  Develops basic languages skills and cultural awareness to function in everyday situations in Spanish-speaking communities.  Conducted in Spanish with practice in speaking, listening, reading, and writing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SPAN 161, 1-2 years high school, or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Heritage speakers of Spanish see SPAN 365.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish 3
htmlparse.Course.description: Enhances skills in reading and analysis to develop intermediate proficiency in Spanish.  Grammatical structures presented in context through literary and informational texts, media, and other to promote cultural awareness.  Conducted in Spanish.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SPAN 162, 3-4 years high school or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Heritage speakers of Spanish see SPAN 365.

htmlparse.Course.title: Elementary Spanish Conversation IIIA
htmlparse.Course.description: Improves oral proficiency in communicative situations in Spanish-speaking communities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Concurrent enrollment in SPAN 261 is recommended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish 4
htmlparse.Course.description: Bridges to more advanced language, culture, and literature courses.  Grammatical structures studied in context through literary and informational materials.  Conducted in Spanish.  Practice in researching and presenting the history and cultures of Spanish-speaking countries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: SPAN 261, 4-5 years high school, or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Heritage speakers of Spanish see SPAN 365. This course applies toward major or minor requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish Conversation IVA
htmlparse.Course.description: Improves oral proficiency in communicative situations in Spanish-speaking communities.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Concurrent enrollment in SPAN 361 is recommended. This course does NOT fulfill major or minor requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish for Heritage Speakers
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for multilingual students who learn Spanish at home and wish to reactivate their use of the Spanish language, while expanding their academic Spanish language skills and cultural knowledge.  Emphasis on speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension, in response to students’ specific needs.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course is equivalent to SPAN 361, and applies toward major or minor requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Studies in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: Offered only to participants in study abroad programs. Prior consultation for approval is expected.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: At the discretion of the department, the course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Spanish Grammar
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of the verbal system (subjective mood, conditional, perfect tenses, aspectual contrast of preterit and imperfect) and other features of written and spoken Spanish.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended prerequisite: SPAN 410 or equivalent facility as determined by modern languages faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Offered for students who do not meet grammar requirements for enrollment in 400 and 500-level courses. May be taken with SPAN 410.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish Composition and Grammar
htmlparse.Course.description: Writing-intensive course with targeted grammar review to develop written communication abilities in Spanish.  Composing and revising various types of essays, honing usage of grammar and vocabulary, developing research techniques, using Modern Language Association style.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course not open to those students whose writing competence has been demonstrated in the language at this level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish Conversation
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive practice in conversation to develop listening and speaking skills, expand vocabulary, and review grammatical structures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken with SPAN 410. Course designed for students whose primary language is not Spanish or whose competence has been demonstrated in the language at this level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Listening Skills
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops aural comprehension skills for communicative situations with focus on Spanish phonetics and interpretation of oral texts.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Hispanic Readings
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on reading skills to develop critical and analytical thinking in Spanish, while learning about the cultures of the Spanish-speaking world.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Recommended as Literature requirement for Minors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Spanish: Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops culturally appropriate oral and written communication skills in business-related professions.  Specialized content and vocabulary, and experience in professional writing and translation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Spanish: Health and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops culturally appropriate oral and written communication skills in health and human services.  Specialized content and vocabulary, and experience in professional writing and translation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Literature in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops critical thinking, reading, and analytical skills applied to Spanish-language literary texts.  Different literary genres and literary terminology in critical analysis.  Language skill development through reports, presentations and papers, to acquire the formal conventions of literary research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Recommended for Majors before taking SPAN 567 or 568.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to U.S. Latino/a Literature and Culture in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the development of literature and other media representing the experience of Latinos/as in the United States since the Mexican-American War.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taught in Spanish, may include some texts in English.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish Civilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops critical understanding of the historical, political, economic, social and cultural forces that have shaped the Iberian Peninsula.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish American Civilization
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops critical understanding of the historical, political, economic, social and cultural forces that have shaped Spanish-America from pre-Columbian times to the present.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature of Spain
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of representative works of Spanish literature from the Middle Ages to the present.  Develops an understanding of the periods, genres and contexts of course readings and the relationship among texts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literature of Spanish America
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of representative works of Spanish American literature from the pre-Columbian period to the present.  Develops an understanding of historical and cultural context within the framework of Spanish American literary criticism.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Studies in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: Special Studies in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of department head and instructor involved.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Spanish Translation
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to concepts of translation, including aspects of history, theory, and professional ethics.  Practice in bi-directional translation [Spanish-English-Spanish] of a variety of texts in different genres including literature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Minimum of 3 credit hours at the 500 level or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Linguistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of linguistic analysis, including the sound system, word and sentence formation, and semantic and pragmatic meaning.  Formal and usage-based perspectives.  Application of linguistics to language acquisition theory and to pedagogy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Minimum of 3 hours at the 500 level or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Taught in Spanish.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Spanish Grammar
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study of the structures of the Spanish Language for communicative and pedagogical purposes.  Comparison/contrast to English structures.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Medieval Spanish Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Texts and contexts in Medieval Spain, from jarchas to La Celestina.  Focus on the roles of ideologies, schools and genres.  Incorporates manuscripts and oral traditions.  Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Modern Literature of Spain
htmlparse.Course.description: Texts and contexts of Early Modernity: Renaissance and Baroque.  Focus on new directions in poetry and theater, and the birth of the novel.  Humanism, Reformation and Counter Reformation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cervantes
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading and discussion of the works of Cervantes and of his literary and cultural background.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Eighteenth and Nineteenth-Century Spanish Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Relevant literary and non-literary texts combined with media.  Neo-Classicism, Romanticism and Realism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth-Century Spanish Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Relevant literary and non-literary texts combined with media.  Modernismo, Avant-garde, Social Realism and Postmodernism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish Poetry
htmlparse.Course.description: Texts and contexts of poetry in Spain from the jarchas of the early Middle Ages through the 21st Century.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish-American Narrative: Origins to the Nineteenth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Contextualized discussion and analysis of narrative literature from pre-Columbian civilizations, the Spanish colonies, and independent nations. Indigenous texts, chronicles, the Baroque, Neo-Classicism, Romanticism, and Realism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish-American Narrative: Early Twentieth Century
htmlparse.Course.description: Contextualized discussion and analysis of early twentieth-century narrative literature.  Includes modernismo, the Avant-Garde, and criollismo/la novela de la tierra.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish-American Narrative: Contemporary
htmlparse.Course.description: Interpretation and analysis of representative texts by 20th and 21st century Spanish-American writers.  Literary movements within their cultural contexts (socio-political, philosophical, economic and historical).
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish-American Drama
htmlparse.Course.description: Interpretation and analysis of representative texts from pre-Columbian performance practices to the present with emphaisis on contemporary works.  Examines the impact of European theater in Spanish-America, the ways in which these practices were appropriated or transformed, and the contributions of Spanish-America to the world stage.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish-American Poetry
htmlparse.Course.description: Contextualized discussion, interpretation and analysis of poetry from its early pre-Columbian manifestations to the present time, with emphasis on contemporary works. Includes Pertinent literary criticism and theory and relevant media.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: U.S. Latino/a Literature and Culture in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: The border as a metaphorical concept in Latino/a literature and culture.  Analysis of literary texts and other media.  Multiple identities, positionalities, literary movements, language and counter-traditions that shape the aesthetic cultural legacy of Latinos/as.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hispanic Cinema
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical analysis of films representing a selected region, period, or theme, within their theoretical, cultural, socio-political and historic contexts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Spanish Translation
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and practice in bi-directional translation [Spanish-English-Spanish] of a variety of texts from a number of genres, including literary texts.  Discussion of professional opportunities for translators and interpreters.  Development of personal portfolio.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spain Today
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores key issues of contemporary Spain including the Spanish Civil War.  Relevant literary and non-literary texts combined with media.  Reading- and writing-intensive class.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Spanish America Today
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on the most significant cultural, social, political, ecological and economic issues affecting Spanish America in recent years.  Representative literary texts and media serve as a basis for developing a critical view of the region.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Spanish Language
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of Spanish from Latin to its present-day variation in the Spanish-speaking world.  Influence of and interaction with world cultures and languages across time.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Reading- and writing-intensive class.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hispanic Cultures and Literatures: Teaching Strategies
htmlparse.Course.description: An integrated teaching program that develops linguistic, cultural and literary skills through the analysis and interpretation of texts from Spain and Spanish-America.  Emphasis on student-centered cooperative and collaborative learning. Reading- and writing-intensive class.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: In depth exploration of a special cultural, linguistic and/or literary subject. Reading- and writing-intensive class.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Topics in Spanish
htmlparse.Course.description: A seminar with variable topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Literacy in the Age of Information
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is intended for majors in non-quantitative fields. Focus will be on the development of an awareness of statistics at the conceptual and interpretative level, in the context of everyday life. Data awareness and quality, sampling, scientific investigation, decision making, and the study of relationships are included. Emphasis will be on the development of critical thinking through in-class experiments and activities, discussions, analysis of real data sets, written reports, and collaborative learning. Computing activities will be included where appropriate; no previous computing experience required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Cannot be taken for credit if credit has been received for any other statistics course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: A project-oriented first course in probability and statistics with emphasis on computer analysis of data.  Examples selected primarily from social sciences, natural sciences, education and popular culture.  Descriptive statistics, probability, sampling, tests of hypothesis and confidence intervals for means and proportions, design and analysis of simple comparative studies, chi-square test for association, correlation and linear regression.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Cannot be taken for credit if credit has been received for STAT 340 or 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Statistics-Salina campus
htmlparse.Course.description: A project-oriented first course in probability and statistics with emphasis on computer analysis of data.  Examples selected primarily from social sciences, natural sciences, education and popular culture.  Descriptive statistics, probability, sampling, tests of hypothesis and confidence intervals for means and proportions, design and analysis of simple comparative studies, chi-square test for association, correlation and linear regression.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Cannot be taken for credit if credit has been received for STAT 340 or 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biometrics I
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic first course in probability and statistics with textbook, examples, and problems aimed toward the biological sciences. Frequency distributions, averages, measures of variation, probability, confidence intervals; tests of significance appropriate to binomial, multinomial, Poisson, and normal sampling; simple regression and correlation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Cannot be taken for credit if credit has been received for STAT 325 or 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biometrics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and interpretation of biological data using analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, and multiple regression. Negative binomial distribution and its applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: STAT 325 or STAT 340 or STAT 350.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business and Economic Statistics I
htmlparse.Course.description: A basic first course in probability and statistics with textbook, examples, and problems pointed toward business administration and economics. Frequency distributions, averages, index numbers, time series, measures of variation, probability, confidence intervals, tests of significance appropriate to binomial, multinomial, Poisson, and normal sampling; simple regression and correlation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Cannot be taken for credit if credit has been received for STAT 325 or 340.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business and Economic Statistics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of STAT 350 including study of index numbers, time series, business cycles, seasonal variation, multiple regression and correlation, forecasting; some nonparametric methods applicable in business and economic studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Seminar in Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be used to satisfy quantitative requirements for BS degree. Open only to students in the honors program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Probabilistic Systems Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Descriptive statistics and graphical methods; basic probability; probability distributions; several random variable; Poisson processes; computer simulation of random phenomena; confidence interval estimation; hypothesis testing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistics for Engineers
htmlparse.Course.description: First course in statistics with examples and problems toward engineering. Distributions, means, measures of variation, confidence intervals, graphical display of data, simple regression and correlation, philosophy of experimentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Must be taken concurrent with a laboratory course in engineering which uses statistics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistics for Engineers II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of STAT 490. Offered second half of the semester following STAT 490. Statistical tests, multiple regression, model fitting, simple comparative and factorial experiments. Emphasis on computer analysis of data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Open only to Arts and Science students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Probability and Statistics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Descriptive statistics, probability concepts and laws, sample spaces; random variables; binomial, uniform, normal, and Poisson; two-dimensional variates; expected values; confidence intervals; binomial parameter, median, mean, and variance; testing simple hypotheses using CIs and X<sup>2</sup>; goodness of fit. Numerous applications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Probability and Statistics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Law of Large Numbers, Chebycheff’s Inequality; continuation of study of continuous variates; uniform, exponential, gamma, and beta distribution; Central Limit Theorem; distributions from normal sampling; introduction to statistical inference.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamental Methods of Biostatistics
htmlparse.Course.description: A course emphasizing concepts and practice of statistical data analysis for the health sciences.  Basic techniques of descriptive and inferential statistical methods applied to health related surveys and designed experiments.  Populations and samples, parameters and statistics; sampling distributions for hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for means and proportions involving one sample, paired samples and multiple independent samples; odds ratios, risk ratios, simple linear regression.  Use of statistical software to facilitate the collection, manipulation, analysis and interpretation of  health related data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Methods for Social Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: Statistical methods applied to experimental and survey data from social sciences; test of hypotheses concerning treatment means; linear regression; product-moment, rank, and bi-serial correlations; contingency tables and chi-square tests.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Methods for Natural Scientists
htmlparse.Course.description: Statistical concepts and methods basic to experimental research in the natural sciences; hypothetical populations; estimation of parameters; confidence intervals; parametric and nonparametric tests of hypotheses; linear regression; correlation; one-way analysis of variance; t-test; chi-square test.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and equivalent of college algebra.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis of Variance
htmlparse.Course.description: Computation and interpretation for two- and three-way analyses of variance; multiple comparisons; applications including use of computers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Meets four times a week during first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Regression and Correlation Analyses
htmlparse.Course.description: Multiple regression and correlation concepts and methods; curvilinear regression; applications including use of computers.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Meets four times a week during second half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Basic Elements of Statistical Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: The mathematical representation of frequency distributions, their properties, and the theory of estimation and hypothesis testing. Elementary mathematical functions are used to illustrate theory.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MATH 205, 210 or 220 and STAT 325 or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sample Survey Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Design, conduct, and interpretation of sample surveys.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Meets four times a week during first half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Linear Statistical Models
htmlparse.Course.description: Matrix-based regression and analysis of variance procedures at a mathematical level appropriate for a first-year graduate statistics major. Topics include simple linear regression, linear models in matrix form, multiple linear regression, model building and diagnostics, analysis of covariance, multiple comparison methods, contrasts, multifactor studies, blocking, subsampling, and split-plot designs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Prior knowledge of matrix or linear algebra and one prior course in statistics. A student may not receive credit for both the STAT 704/705 sequence and STAT 713.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonparametric Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Hypothesis testing when form of population sampled is unknown: rank, sign, chi-square, and slippage tests; Kolmogorov and Smirnov type tests; confidence intervals and bands.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Meets four times a week during second half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Categorical Data Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of categorical count and proportion data. Topics include tests of association in two-way tables; measures of association; Cochran-Mantel-Haenzel tests for 3-way tables; generalized linear models; logistic regression; loglinear models.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Experiments
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning experiments so as to minimize error variance and avoid bias; Latin squares; split-plot designs; switch-back or reversal designs; incomplete block designs; efficiency.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Designs for Product Development and Process Improvement
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of statistically designed experiments which have proven useful in product development and process improvement. Topics include randomization, blocking, factorial treatment structures, factional factorial designs, screening designs, and response surface methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: STAT 704 and 705 or STAT 511 or STAT 713.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to the SAS Computing
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include basic environment and syntax, reading and importing data from files, writing and exporting data to files, data manipulation, basic graphics, and built-in and user-defined functions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One graduate level course in statistics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Splus/R Computing
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include basic environment and syntax, reading and importing data from files, data manipulation, basic graphics, and built-in and user-defined functions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: One graduate level course in statistics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multivariate Statistical Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Multivariate analysis of variance and covariance; classification and discrimination; principal components and introductory factor analysis; canonical correlation; digital computing procedures applied to data from natural and social sciences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Bioassay
htmlparse.Course.description: Direct assays; quantitative dose-response models; parallel line assays; slope ratio assays; experimental designs for bioassay; covariance adjustment; weighted estimates; assays based on quantal responses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Meets four times a week during second half of semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Graphics
htmlparse.Course.description: Visual display of quantitative information. Statistical graphics topics to include visual perception, basic graphics construction, quantitative univariate to multivariate statistical graphics, trellis displays, introduction to smoothing and graphics, introduction to density estimation and graphics, and categorical graphics. Modern graphics software will be used.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Statistics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Probability models, concepts of probability, random discrete variables, moments and moment generating functions, bivariate distributions, continuous random variables, sampling. Central Limit Theorem, characteristic functions. More emphasis on rigor and proofs than in STAT 510 and 511.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to multivariate distributions; sampling distributions, derivation, and use; estimation of parameters, testing hypothesis; multiple regression and correlation; simple experimental designs; introduction to nonparametric statistics; discrimination.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Statistics
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Swahili I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to Swahili. A foundation in listening, speaking, writing, and reading the basic grammatical structures and vocabulary of Swahili. Aspects of Swahili/African culture will be introduced and highlighted as essential components toward achieving communicative competence.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Swahili II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of Swahili 101. A foundation in listening, speaking, writing, and reading the basic grammatical structures and vocabulary of Swahili. Aspects of Swahili/African culture will be introduced and highlighted as essential components toward achieving communicative competence.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Swahili III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Swahili II.  Further development of functional skills.  Intensive practice of spoken and written Swahili.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Swahili IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Swahili III.  Further development of functional skills.  Intensive practice of spoken and written Swahili.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Theatre Forum
htmlparse.Course.description: Special topics presentations for theatre majors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Four semesters required for all majors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concepts of Theatre Production
htmlparse.Course.description: An orientation to the various areas of theatrical production in the rehearsal and performance process.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all majors in their second spring semester.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drama Participation
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in theatrical productions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of director of activity.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Four hours maximum credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Storytelling
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of oral performance skills in storytelling, with emphasis on cultural/ethnic diversities. Students will do individual research on cultural/ethnic area of their choice.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stage Movement
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the technique of stage movement and an investigation of the language of gesture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Acting
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of fundamental skills and techniques of acting. Major emphasis is on freeing and training the individual’s imagination, intellect, body, and voice through designed exercise and performed scenes.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours recitation per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Oral Interpretation of Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques of reading from the printed page, selecting portions from various forms of literature, including narrative poetry, essay, lyric, sonnet, nonfictional prose, scenes from plays, and selected short stories.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Improvisation I, II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the techniques of improvisation with the emphasis upon practical participation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Stage Costuming and Makeup
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic techniques of stage costume construction and stage make-up. Examination of the costume design process.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Concurrent enrollment in at least one credit of THTRE 211 required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Techniques of Makeup
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques of makeup for stage, movies, and television.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive introduction to theatre: basic elements of theatre and theatre production, theatre history, dramatic literature, multicultural theatre traditions and perspectives, and the theatre experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: Summer Theatre Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised participation in a summer theatre repertory/stock program.  Limited to freshmen and sophomores.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dramatic Comedy and the Theory of Laughter
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the origin, structure, and historical development of dramatic comedy, with a special emphasis on the psychology of laughter. Representative essays expounding various theories of the comic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Acting
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis upon expanding the actor’s capabilities through more advanced scene work and character study.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: THTRE 261 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Technical Production
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic techniques, equipment and materials used in scenery construction and theatrical drafting.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Concurrent enrollment in at least 1 hour of THTRE 211 is required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Theatrical Design
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of the four areas of stage design: sets, lights, costumes, and sound. Includes examination of relevant history and technology in these areas. Emphasis is on the design process and design development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dramatic Structure
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of play analysis for directors with emphasis upon concepts of form, style, characterization, discovery, and reversal. Includes practice in analyzing plays of various forms and styles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Opera Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and techniques of operatic and musical theatre production, with emphasis on class rehearsal and performance of selected scenes from opera and musical drama; brief survey of the history of opera.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Offered jointly by the Department of Communication Studies and School of Music, Theatre and Dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Stage Movement
htmlparse.Course.description: Study in the physical development of character and advanced techniques of stage movement.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 9 hours credit by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vocal Expression for Actors
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies and application of vocal techniques for stage productions; emphasis on development of the actor’s vocal mechanism.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 9 hours credit by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Storytelling
htmlparse.Course.description: A consideration of literary materials appropriate for children in nursery schools, kindergarten, and elementary schools. Major emphasis is on training in the art of storytelling.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Directing
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, processes and techniques of directing for the theatre.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rehearsal Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory course for students enrolled in performance and production classes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in THTRE 765 or 783 or 779.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for 6 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Scene Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the role of scene design in theatre, principles and techniques of design. Development, presentation, and synthesis of design images with the scripted play.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Technical Production
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture-lab course in advanced technical theatre problems of organization, planning, drafting and execution of scenery and lighting.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Musical Comedy
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of operetta and musical comedy from Offenbach to the present.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 150 or THTRE 165 or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Theatre I
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the development of the theatre from ancient times to 1700.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Theatre II
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the development of the theatre from 1700 to the present.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Stage Lighting
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of theatrical lighting design, control systems, projection equipment, and lighting consulting. Production work with KSU Theatre season required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Music Theatre Workshop
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and techniques of musical theatre production with emphasis on rehearsal and performance of selected scenes from musical theatre. Dance, music, and theatre are studied as integrated elements within the musical theatre genre. Culminates in a public performance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 202, two semesters of voice; THTRE 261; and DANCE 380; or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course may be repeated twice for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship In Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised participation in an internship at a professional theatre.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: THTRE 261 or THTRE 368; junior standing and consent of supervising faculty member and approval of faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in theatre.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with topic change to a maximum of 12 hours credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Costume Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in the theory and practice of costume design for stage and film.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Theatre Tour
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised viewing and analysis of professional theatre productions. Travel to one or more theatre centers such as New York, London, or Los Angeles. Students are charged an additional fee to cover travel expenses. Written critical reviews of the productions are required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Six hours of credit in theatre.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once by undergraduates.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of audition techniques including supervised preparation of appropriate material. Business aspects of professional theatre, including unions, contracts, and professional ethics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 12 hours in theatre, music, and/or dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Playwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical study and practical application of techniques of playwriting with regard to plot, characters, and production; emphasis on the one-act form.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Drama
htmlparse.Course.description: The development of creative imagination and personal well-being through theatre games, improvisation, storytelling, and puppetry for use in educational and recreational settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drama Therapy with Special Populations
htmlparse.Course.description: The therapeutic uses of drama in the development of creative imagination, self expression, and social relatedness with special populations such as clients who have developmental disabilities, physical disabilities, health issues, or are aging.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stage Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of stage management in the professional and nonprofessional theatre. Emphasis is on the organization of all areas of theatre knowledge needed for the running of theatrical productions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Period Styles for the Theatre 1
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of historical styles of architecture, furnishings, and clothing in relation to theatrical design and the history of the theatre from the Greeks to 1800.

htmlparse.Course.title: Period Styles for the Theatre 2
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of historical styles of architecture, furnishings, and clothing in relation to theatrical design and the history of the theatre from 1800 to present.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Opera
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of selected masterpieces of musical drama, with emphasis on the relationship of music and drama, and on the unique qualities of opera as a collective artwork.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: MUSIC 201 or MUSIC 250 or THTRE 370.

htmlparse.Course.title: American Ethnic Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Drama and stagecraft of ethnic groups in the United States, including the theatre of African, Asian, Hispanic, Jewish, and Native Americans.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theatre for Conflict Resolution
htmlparse.Course.description: Drama and theatre techniques used to explore the nature of conflict and how to promote collaboration through action.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drama Therapy with Adolescents
htmlparse.Course.description: The therapeutic uses of drama with adolescents, including normal development, youth-at-risk, ESL, SED, and BD adolescents.

htmlparse.Course.title: Drama Therapy with Older Adults
htmlparse.Course.description: The therapeutic uses of drama with older adults, focusing on the development of life review, social relatedness, and creative self-expression in the here and now.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Aesthetic Interpretation Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised participation in a position of major responsibility.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: THTRE 160 or 261 or 368; junior standing; consent of supervising faculty member and approval of faculty members are required.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Technical Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in creative techniques and investigation for technical theatre.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: THTRE 368 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theatre Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Theatre management, promotion, finance, organization; emphasis on contract negotiations and use of facilities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Drama Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of theory and practice in the use of drama as therapy, including assessment and treatment, individual and group practice, and psychodrama.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Acting
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in style, technique, and characterization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: THTRE 361 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with a change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Playwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Further study in the writing of drama; emphasis on problems of writing the full-length play.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 9 hours credit by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reader’s Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature, purpose, and production of oral interpretation of literature in the theatre; emphasis on monologue, lecture-recital, and play reading.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 6 hours credit by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early American Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in the drama and stagecraft of the colonies and the United States from the beginnings to 1900.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practice in Directing
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture-lab course with emphasis on directing dramatic productions under performance conditions.
