htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 9 hours credit by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Arts Therapies
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of five creative arts therapy modalities: drama/ psychodrama, art, poetry/bibliotherapy, music, and dance/movement. Instruction in theory and hands-on experience with each modality, as well as reading, discussion and methods for using modalities interdisciplinarily.

htmlparse.Course.title: Aesthetics of the Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Principal emphasis on theoretical problems of dramatic art.

htmlparse.Course.title: Repertory Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Concentrated studies in theory and practice of repertory theatre productions. Reading, demonstrations, study of play scripts; play selection and production methods; operation of and assistance in production of plays in repertory.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a total of 12 hours credit by qualified students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theatrical Design Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced problems in conceptualization and realization of design, including sets, costumes, lights and technical production. Emphasis on advanced techniques in research, analysis, and production problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women in Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: A history of the contributions made by women in theatre as playwrights, managers, directors, and performers; contemporary women in theatre and their experiments in expressing women’s consciousness.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practice in Acting
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies in characterization with emphasis on communicating with the director. Taught in conjunction with the Practice in Directing workshop.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: THTRE 361 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychodrama
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of psychodrama as a treatment modality for use in drama therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociodrama
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of sociodrama as a therapeutic and educational modality for use in drama therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Israeli Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Drama and stagecraft of Israeli Theatre from its origins through the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Projects in Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual guided work in selected area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated.
Only 3 hours may be applied to MA.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi/Urdu I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the structure of Hindi and URDU, two languages which are nearly identical in the grammatical structure of their everyday spoken style. Hindi is the dominant language of Northern India. URDU is the National language of Pakistan, also understood throughout the Hindi area.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi/Urdu II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Hindi/Urdu I with introduction of the Devanagari (Hindi and Sanskrit) script.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi/Urdu III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Hindi/Urdu II with gradual transition to more formal styles of language.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi/Urdu IV
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Hindi/Urdu III with readings in Hindi or Urdu literature according to needs of students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hindi/Urdu V
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual study in Hindi or Urdu. Readings, composition, or conversational practice relevant to the student’s interests and disciplinary needs.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems in Modern Languages

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to academic and community-based thinking about women’s lives: (1) how gender inequality in society restricts women’s development, limits their contributions to the dominant culture, and subjects women to systematic violence and (2) strategies with which women can gain power within existing institutions and develop new models of social relations. Particular attention will be paid to issues of race, ethnicity, class, and sexuality.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender, Ethnicity, and Class
htmlparse.Course.description: The diversity of women’s experiences within the United States and in other countries. Using a framework that examines how gender is shaped within the contexts of ethnicity and class, students will be introduced to multicultural feminisms through an active examination of history, literature, and social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Studies of Women and Gender
htmlparse.Course.description: Specific course content will vary by semester and instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with a change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Fundamentals of Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced examination of the origins of the Women’s Studies field, provides core concepts and research methodologies.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: Latina’s Life Stories
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary exploration of the nature of women’s life experiences, examining the complex process of constructing cultural identities. Students will gain an understanding of how knowing about, listening to, and telling of life stories intersects with issues of gender, race, ethnicity, and class, using the specific examples of Latina’s life stories.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Global Issues and Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Women & Aging: Looking at Multicultural Female Aging Through a Gendered Lens
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will explore, from a feminist perspective, multidisciplinary aspects of the aging process including, but not limited to physical, psychological, sociological, cultural and existential, experiences by women mainly in the United States, with some global comparisons. Experiential components include film, interviews, visit to a retirement community, research on a topic of interest to the individual student related to women’s experiences with the aging process from a women’s studies perspective.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Global Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: This course explores contemporary approaches that help meet the needs of women and their families in different parts of the world, including the Plains region. Students will learn how approaches to social change in the Third World influence women in North America, and how First World women relate to women’s movements and organizations in the Third World.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Resistance and Movements for Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines Women’s Resistance and movements against gender violence and discrimination in the context of colonialism, globalization, war, militarism, and occupation.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Historical Perspectives

htmlparse.Course.title: Feminist Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of a variety of feminist analyses of society, culture, and work, as well as visions for social change. The historical development of key feminist theories, contemporary debates, and multicultural and global feminism will be analyzed.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility

htmlparse.Course.title: The Stories of a Young Girl
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary examination of female adolescence, focusing in particular on the way it is depicted in literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Gender, Environment & Justice
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the philosophical, historical, and material aspects of the human/nature relationships and the intersection of gender, race/ethnicity, class and global location with environment and environmental justice.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Honors Project
htmlparse.Course.notes: Open only to Arts & Sciences students who are active members of the University Honors Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics vary.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent, interdisciplinary, supervised study in an area which does not fall within the boundaries of a traditional department.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once for credit with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course in practices of research in Women’s Studies, with attention to what distinguishes interdisciplinary, feminist research from traditional, disciplinary practices. Methods explored may include survey, interview, oral history, ethnography, hermeneutics, content analysis, case study, experimental, and action research.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Popular Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Images of women in a variety of popular media forms: fiction, film, television, music (including MTV), magazines, advertising, and material culture. Women are explored as objects, consumers, and producers of popular culture. Material is drawn from a variety of disciplines, including psychology, sociology, history, literary criticism, and cultural studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: WOMST 105 or at least 3 hours of Women’s Studies credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: The History and Politics of Family Violence
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the history of family or domestic violence in America as a social, cultural, legal, and public policy issue from the colonial period to the present. Stress is placed upon the cultural roots and evolution of domestic law. The development of state-controlled social welfare agencies as well as the emergence of the “battered women’s movement” is particularly emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Historical Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Violence
htmlparse.Course.description: The roots of male violence against women, cultural forms of sexual coercion and violence, and strategies for envisioning and enacting social change. Topics addressed include rape/sexual harassment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: WOMST 105 or at least 3 hours of Women’s Studies credit.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Ethical Reasoning and Responsibility Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Religion
htmlparse.Course.description: How gender relations and women have been shaped by religious traditions throughout history and in the contemporary world. Analysis of the construction of gender in the world’s major religions including Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Buddhism and Hinduism as well as in tribal societies, new religious movements and Humanism.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women and Islam
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the history and sources of Islam with particular reference to women in a variety of cultures, ranging from Southeast Asia, Africa, the Middle East to the Western World.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Global Issues and Perspectives Human Diversity within the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Women’s Studies Practice and Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: An active exploration of local-to-global change in relation to feminist and nonviolence theories, concepts, and methods. Includes a social change project consisting of 52 hours of skill and research-based field experience with a campus or community organization. Students will read and discuss academic writings on inclusive approaches to social change, participatory action research, community building, social movements and theory. This course provides students with professional and academic skills that relate to employment and graduate work in diverse fields.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: 3 hrs of women’s studies credit or by instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.kstate8: Human Diversity within the U.S. Social Sciences

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone Seminar in Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced seminar for in-depth investigation of a specific topic. Students will conduct independent research and produce a substantial project or paper.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an in-depth theoretical and empirical analysis of scholarly works relating to an interdisciplinary topic in women’s studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Junior standing or above and instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with a change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Women’s Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field work at the local, state, national, or international level in a community, volunteer, activist, or political organization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and two courses in women’s studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: A maximum of 3 credit hours can be counted toward the Women’s Studies minor, and a maximum of 6 credit hours towards the major.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study for Graduate Students or Advanced Undergraduate Students
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in problems, issues, topics in Women’s Studies. Topics vary.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Accounting and Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the nature of business transactions, including identification of relevant economic events and how those events are recorded in financial statements. Provides a working knowledge of analytical tools used for financial asset valuation and other decision making purposes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not open to Master of Accountancy students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Auditing
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth exposure to authoritative auditing pronouncements and specialized topics, e.g., statistical methods, EDP auditing, internal auditing, operational auditing, and audit management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Corporate Taxation
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the federal taxation of corporations with emphasis on tax planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Partnership Taxation
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study of the federal taxation of partnerships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Management Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of traditional management accounting systems and their limitations with emphasis on newly developed systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Accounting Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of accounting theory with emphasis upon information economics, agency theory, and capital market information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Taxation
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive examination of selected topics in taxation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management Accounting and Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: An investigation of human behavior effects on the collection and use of management accounting information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design of Accounting and Business Information Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on understanding and designing contemporary business and information processes in organizations, providing an introduction to database systems, project management and information systems controls and technology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810, MANGT 830 and instructor permissions for MBA students or ACCTG 331 for Masters of Accountancy students or instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of comparative international accounting systems, efforts to harmonize accounting standards internationally, problems of international financial analysis, accounting and tax issues of particular relevance to U.S. multinational enterprises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management Accounting and Business Problem Solving
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of managerial accounting information for decision making, planning, and control.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810, ECON 815, FINAN 815, MANGT 810, MANGT 820, MANGT 830, MKTIB 810 and STAT 702.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Not open to Master of Accountancy students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of specified topics in accounting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Enterprise Information Systems Assurance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on types of assurance available in an enterprise-wide information systems environment and methods for providing assurance from the view of management, external auditors and consultants. Assurance topics discussed include assurances related to systems security, fraud, business and information process integrity, and operational efficiency. Focus is on designing systems to increase the level of inherent assurance as well as auditability. This course also includes a service learning component.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810, MANGT 830 for MBA students or ACCTG 331 for Masters of Accountancy students or instructor permission

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminars in Professional Accounting
htmlparse.Course.description: Master of Accountancy students are required to take this seminar course during two regular semesters (Fall and Spring). The course will cover current topics relevant to Professional Accountants in both public and private practice. Seminars are designed to improve students technical accounting knowledge and professional skills and abilities. Seminars will be led by a variety of faculty and practicing accountants. As part of the class, students will be expected to complete written and oral assignments and may be assessed on their technical, oral, written, critical thinking, interpersonal and other skills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students should enroll for one credit hour in the first semester they complete the seminar and two credit hours during the second semester they complete the seminar.

htmlparse.Course.title: Scientific Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Written, visual, and oral communications for scientists. Attention is focused on literature reviews, scientific papers, graphics, poster presentations, and oral paper presentations. Grant applications, ethics, and communications with non-science audience are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and instructor permission.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory in Agricultural Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of major communication theories and theorists in the context of agricultural communications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Knowledge Management in Agriculture and Natural Resources
htmlparse.Course.description: Knowledge Management is a discipline that takes a comprehensive, systematic approach to the information assets of an organization by identifying, capturing, collecting, organizing, indexing, storing, integrating, retrieving and sharing them. This strategy turns an agricultural and natural organization’s intellectual assets into greater productivity and increased competitiveness. It encourages collaboration for the sharing of expertise and knowledge of the best practices. This course examines knowledge management as it is emerging and being applied in agriculture and natural resources.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Agribusiness Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of economic principles to problems of agricultural production and agribusinesses. Demand theory and economic forecasting will be used to examine changes in demand and business trends. Cost minimization and profit maximization will be used to examine firm and market issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Computer Decision Tools for Agribusiness
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of decision tools for agribusiness using spreadsheets. Topics include internet as a data source, budget development and analysis, financial calculations, regression, search techniques, and optimization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agribusiness Financial Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers financial management, long-term investment analysis, the performance of alternative investments, and the theory of efficient markets. Topics covered include comparative financial analysis, short-term budgeting, and capital budgeting. Applications include agribusiness decision making and project analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agribusiness Risk Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Various forms of risk inherent to firms operating in agricultural and food product markets are explored. Risk management techniques including diversification, insurance, forward contracting, hedging and options are examined through applied problems with the use of simulation. Emphasis is placed on managing risk associated with input prices, output prices, enterprise organization and financial instruments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Agribusiness Logistics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of agribusiness logistics and the fundamental concepts underpinning logistical decisions and their impact on a firm’s sustainability. Topics include supply chain management, transportation and storage, contracting and out sourcing, strategic logistic planning, network analysis, and B2B e-commerce in food and agriculture. Focus will be on agribusiness logistics issues in grain and grain-based food supply chains and in the livestock and meat supply chains, including global logistics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: AGEC 120 or ECON 120, and AGEC 505.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Econometric Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of econometrics to enhance agribusiness decision making is the focus. Concepts of simple and multiple regression and limited dependent variable models are presented. Econometric issues of functional form, relevant variables, predictive performance, and model diagnostics will be examined. Numerous applications of techniques to agribusiness problems are used.

htmlparse.Course.title: Optimization Techniques for Agribusiness
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an introduction to optimization techniques designed to provide quantitative support for agribusiness decision making. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to construct and evaluate optimization models useful for evaluating linear problems, integer problems, and nonlinear program.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Agribusiness and Policy Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Policies affecting agribusiness firms will be examined. These topics may include U.S. agricultural policies, fiscal and monetary policies, international trade agreements, environmental issues, and current policies influencing agribusiness firms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the demand for supply of agricultural commodities, alternative market structures, the dynamics of marketing institutions that affect market structures, governmental intervention in agricultural markets, futures markets in agriculture, and international agricultural commodities trade.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Price, Income and Trade Policies in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the effects of government price, regulatory, and tax and trade policies on (1) farm income levels and variability, (2) farm productivity and output, (3) economic structure of farming, and (4) performance of agricultural markets.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Farm Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of managerial techniques and processes applied to farm firms involved in production and marketing of agricultural products. This study includes managerial planning, evaluation, and control of farm businesses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Agricultural Development
htmlparse.Course.description: To study the principles of economic development when applied to the development of the agricultural sector. This includes the examination of national and international strategies and policies that inhibit and/or encourage the development of the agricultural sectors in low income countries. Individual study is encouraged to meet student interest: (a) in understanding the process and including an appreciation of the interdependence between low and high income countries and (b) receiving an introduction to agricultural project analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Production Economics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Economic theories of choice under conditions of imperfect knowledge (i.e. under risk and uncertainty) and the application of these theories to production decisions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: AGEC 500 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Natural Resource Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: The economic tolls of welfare analysis, non-market valuation, and dynamics are used to evaluate natural resource use, natural resource policies, and conflicts among users, conservationists, and preservationists.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: AGEC 505 or ECON 520; and MATH 205.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Markets and Agricultural Trade
htmlparse.Course.description: Pure and monetary theories of international agricultural trade. International trade policies and trade negotiations are evaluated in detail. Special consideration is given to the international trade policy influences on agriculture. The international agricultural trade arena, imperfect competition, and exchange rate economics are discussed. Institutions are policies of major trading nations are explored.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours. rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agribusiness Industry Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Applied industrial organization and competitive relationships in agriculture markets. Emphasis on the role of bargaining power, vertical coordination and integration, contracting, and other forms of vertical control. Product differentiation, branding and advertising of commodities and anti-trust laws.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Food and Agribusiness Management
htmlparse.Course.description: The objective of the course is to demonstrate how economic concepts underscore strategic management principles. Applications to food and agribusiness firms are used to show how managers and firms function when the assumptions of perfect competition are relaxed. Students will complete a market analysis study as part of the course requirements.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s report.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Research for master’s thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of scientific methodology in economic research including the history of various debates regarding methodology in economics. The course also deals with problem definitions, formulation of hypotheses, listing of hypotheses, and presentation of research results.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Demand and Commodity Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the demand for and supply of farm products, price information and markets, the causes of price variations and instability, the dynamic analysis of agricultural prices.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Agricultural Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of special problems and current developments faced by firms and agencies associated with the marketing process for agricultural products

htmlparse.Course.title: Economics of Agricultural Production
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of agricultural production response to prices; methods of estimating supply response and price expectations; the effects of government and institutions on agricultural supply and the role of risk, technical change, and the number and size of farms on agricultural supply.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Resource and Environmental Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Dynamics analysis of natural resource and environmental problems, including the optimal extraction of nonrenewable resources, optimal management of renewable resources, and the optimal regulation of stock pollutants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hour rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Topics in Agricultural Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of recent developments reported in the literature concerning quantitative methods of analysis in agricultural economics and economics. The study will include assigned projects to apply selected techniques of analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Agricultural Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Problems and current developments in agricultural economics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study of Advanced Topics in Agricultural Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced independent study of an agricultural economics topic based upon a student proposal approved by the student’s supervisory committee
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Completion of 24 credits of graduate study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Economics PhD Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Research for Ph.D. Dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Data Analysis in Communications and Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A course in measurement and analysis as related to social science research and evaluation. The course takes an applied approach to organizing data, analyzing data according to research and evaluation objectives and/or hypotheses, using descriptive and inferential statistics, and interpreting data. Students gain practical experience in data entry and using SPSS for calculating statistics through laboratory exercises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Education for Beginning Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: Securing and organizing information and planning teaching activities which will help the beginning vocational agriculture teacher.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduation from the curriculum in agricultural education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Young Farmer and Adult Farmer Education in Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Organization, objectives, and procedures of conducting young farmer and adult farmer classes. Designed for teachers in service.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Experience in teaching vocational agriculture.

htmlparse.Course.title: The History and Leadership of the Land Grant University
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will provide a historical overview of the evolution and development of land-grant colleges/universities. It will reflect on the fundamental beliefs of those who conceptualized and implemented the land-grant college and university system. The course will enable students to examine early public mandates and subsequent successes of these special institutions of higher education, as well as evaluate significant education, research, and public service developments and new initiatives needed for land-grants to effectively serve society in the future. It is expected that students will gain an understanding of and benefits derived from the institutions that comprise the land-grant college and university family, as well as envision developments and opportunities that will mold the future of these special institutions that represent the land-grant legacy.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Agriculture and Extension Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on a broad range of topic areas in the field of extension education as it impacts agriculture and rural community development. The primary purpose is to further students’ understanding about extension systems’ influence on agricultural development and the interface of agriculture with rural communities throughout the world. Emphasis will be placed upon research, theory, history and conceptual models of extension for establishing a strong philosophical foundation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Theory and Methods of Teaching Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will use contemporary and foundational theory and research on teaching and learning processes in the application and organization of instructional methods and techniques in formal and non-formal educational settings particularly in agriculture, food and natural resources disciplines.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Development in Agriculture I
htmlparse.Course.description: Curriculum problems; planning local programs in agriculture; developing facilities and plans for meeting current and advanced problems in the teaching of agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: One year of teaching in agriculture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Development in Agriculture II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of AGED 850.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Studies in Agricultural Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, organizing, and coordinating the various phases of the local program of vocational education in agriculture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Planning and Evaluation in Agricultural and Extension Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed for students who are interested in the development and evaluation of agricultural and extension education programs. The course is designed to help students in the following areas: Acquire an understanding of program development from theory to practice; Strengthen their skills in planning, designing, implementing, evaluating, and accounting for educational programs of targeted audiences; and Provide application of program planning and evaluation concepts through experiential learning and class projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Volunteers in Agricultural and Extension Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is intended to prepare students to be effective managers of volunteer programs, or to challenge those students already engaged in those roles to improve on their existing skills. Theory will be emphasized in the course, only in so much as it is essential to be grounded in theory in order to apply it. Major topics of the course will include, but are not limited to: volunteer recruitment, training, evaluation and reward. This is an active course where students will be required to be active in and outside of class sessions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Students select and prepare a project designed to improve their professional practice. It may be the construction of a professional portfolio or project to represent the student’s learning throughout the master’s degree program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: A master’s thesis presents the results of an original investigation or a problem or topic within the student’s classroom or educational field approved by the candidate’s supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant and Soil Chemometrics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the field of remote sensing chemometrics for characterizing the chemical and physical properties of organic and inorganic materials using a spectroradiometer.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours Lec/Rec. per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agronomy Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: A discussion of agronomic developments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the transport of water, heat, gases, and solutes in soil. Examples are presented that related to both agricultural and engineering land uses. Emphasis is given to understanding how soil physical properties and soil management practices influence transport processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Water Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Properties of water, terminology in plant and soil water relations, environmental aspects of plant-water relations, soils as a water reservoir, water as a plant component, water movement through the plant, special aspects of transpiration, development and significance of internal water deficits, drought resistance mechanisms, water consumption by crop plants.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Forage Quality
htmlparse.Course.description: The course provides an indepth study of the chemical characteristics of forage components and the interactions with ruminant physiology and digestion that influence forage feeding value and the laboratory procedures used to evaluate forages for grazing livestock. Students should have knowledge of the basic principles of chemistry, ruminant nutrition, and plant physiology so that they can develop an understanding of the chemical characteristics of forages and how they affect the value of forages to grazing livestock.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Recommended Prereq: AGRON 501 or AGRON 550, and ASI 320, and STAT 325, or equivalents.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Web-based distance AG*IDEA course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Herbicide Interactions
htmlparse.Course.description: Herbicide fate in plants and soils. Physiological and biochemical processes in plants and soils as affected by herbicides. Molecular biochemistry of herbicide resistance that have developed in the field. Biotechnologically derived herbicide-resistant crops.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Weed Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of advanced weed ecology topics including weed/crop interference, weed growth and development, herbicide resistance, biological control, spatial and temporal population dynamics, and ecological approaches to weed management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil and Plant Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories and procedures for the chemical analysis of soils and plant materials. Applications of analysis in soil fertility evaluations and in research work are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour rec. and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Genetics in Relation to Plant Breeding
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of statistical principles to biological populations in relation to gene and zygotic frequencies, mating systems, and effects of mutation, migration, and selection on equilibrium populations; partitioning of genetic variance, concept and methods of estimating heritability, theoretical basis of heterosis, diallel cross and combining ability, genotype by environment interaction, genetic advance under selection, models on phenotypic expression of various crops; genetics of autopolypoids.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: AGRON 770, STAT 704, and STAT 705.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grassland Plant Identification
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of plants that have ecological and/or agricultural importance in the Great Plains. Emphasis on plant identification, grassland ecosystems, and plant forage value, palatability, and utilization by both domestic livestock and wildlife. Cultural and historical uses of grassland.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: AGRON 501 and BIOL 198 or equivalents.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Web-based distance AG*IDEA course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrient Sources, Uptake and Cycling
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the behavior of plant nutrients in soils emphasizing nutrient sources, the interaction of nutrient with soils, and the role of plant root as nutrient sinks. Includes processes used in the formulation of chemical fertilizers and the assessment of available nutrients in non-commercial plant nutrient sources.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Crop Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of nitrogen metabolism, mineral nutrition, photosynthesis, growth substances, and hardiness applied to crop production.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will cover the basic physical-chemical properties and reactivities of soil organic matter and organic chemicals, the fundamental processes controlling the fate of organic chemicals, and the methods for estimating their environmental behavior in the soil-water system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Plant Breeding
htmlparse.Course.description: This course considers in detail the mechanics of an applied plant breeding program for agronomic crops.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: AGRON 630 or HORT 740, AGRON 770, and STAT 703.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agricultural Simulation Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Techniques for developing and testing computer simulation models for research, management, and design applications in agriculture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 705. Rec. Pr.: MATH 211 and AGRON 455.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three lectures and one three-hour work session per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation of a written report either of research or of problem work on a topic in the major field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Research on a problem which may extend throughout the year and furnish data for a master’s thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Micrometeorology
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive analysis of interactions between living organisms and their physical environment. Emphasis is placed on characterizing the transport of heat, water, and carbon within the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum. Includes discussions on aerodynamic transfer, surface energy balances, evapotranspiration, trace gas fluxes, and basic micrometeorology. The potential impact of climatic change on biosphere productivity will be considered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: PHYS 115 and AGRON 746 or BIOL 500.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Instrumentation
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory practicum on the methodology and instrumentation used to measure environmental parameters. Includes discussions on instrument selection, sensor deployment, and data acquisition. Measurement of temperature, radiation, moisture, wind, carbon dioxide.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Soil Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of physical chemistry to soils; cation and anion equilibria, ion activities, sorption, redox reactions, and other physiochemical phenomena in soils.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Plant Breeding
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on important papers and contributions in this field.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor. Joint listing with Department of Horticulture. See HORT 910.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Soil Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced study of the transport of water, heat, and solutes in soil. The theory of unsaturated water flow, coupled heat and water flow, and the convection and dispersion of reactive solutes will be studied in detail. Spatial variability of soil physical properties will be discussed, solute transport will be presented.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Soil Genesis and Classification
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced study of processes of soil formation and systems of soil classification including soil taxonomy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Plant Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on important papers and contributions in this field.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor. Joint listing with Department of Horticulture. See HORT 930.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Soils
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on important papers and contributions in this field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Mineralogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of methods for analyzing minerals in soil environments, including X-ray, electron optical, thin section, and wet chemical techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Crop Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of growth and development of crops in relation to the environment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: BIOL 500, 529, STAT 704, and STAT 705.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Soil Microbial Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories and concepts of the ecology and function of microorganisms in the soil environment. Discussions will include factors regulating microbial activity, the flow of energy (carbon), and nitrogen transformations as they relate to plant productivity and environmental quality.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Crop Physiology and Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on important papers and contributions in this field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Plant Breeding I
htmlparse.Course.description: Role of quantitative genetics in plant breeding, heritability, mating designs, selection techniques and theory, population improvement, breeding autopolyploid crops.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr. AGRON 860 and AGRON 830 or concurrent enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Tools for Genetic Analyses
htmlparse.Course.description: Role of biotechnology in plant breeding, mapping and linkage, genetic distances, marker assisted selection, crop evolution and origin, germplasm conservation and utilization, genotype x environment interaction, stability analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Research on a problem which may extend throughout the year and furnish data for a doctoral dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethnohistory
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to ethnohistory as an anthropological research method.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Physiology of Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the structure and function of the cardiovascular system as it pertains to acute and chronic exercise. Topics include the control of blood pressure, vascular volume and blood flow during orthostasis and exercise.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed primarily for graduate and senior students enrolled for graduate credit in physiology. Each student is required to give a report on some subject related to physiology. The course is intended to stimulate interest in research and evaluation of data.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Anatomy
htmlparse.Course.description: The gross and/or microscopic study of any system (or systems) of any domestic animal.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: AP 700 or 710 or equiv. and consent of staff.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stem Cell Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Cellular and molecular techniques and techniques on tissue culture. Lecture and laboratory hours to be determined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ultrastructural Interpretation of the Nervous System
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the fine structure of neurons, axons, synapses, neuroglia and choroid plexus, the interconnections among neurons, the location of specific tracers and antibodies which define synaptic terminals, and a survey of methodologies used with transmission electron microscopy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Cardiovascular Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive overview of cardiovascular physiology in domestic animals with special emphasis on the dog and horse, including current research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanisms of Drug Action
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of pharmacologic mechanisms at the molecular and cellular level, including receptors, second messengers, and pharmacokinetics. Specialized areas of pharmacology such as neuropharmacology and drug design will be discussed. Areas of current research interest will be emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Pharmacology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigations of the interactions of pharmaceutical compounds with living systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Equine Exercise Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive overview of the physiology of exercise in the horse with comparison to other species. Emphasis will be on cardiovascular, respiratory, and musculoskeletal systems, including current research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Responsible Conduct of Biomedical Research
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will focus on providing graduate/professional students an introduction to the regulations, practices, ethical considerations, and professional interactions that define responsible conduct of biomedical research. Investigator responsibilities associated with initiating and establishing a research program, conducting experimental studies, analyzing and reporting data, publishing in peer-reviewed journals, considerations for submitting grant applications, and understanding compliance issues and regulations will be emphasized. Students will learn through reading journal articles and discussion of pertinent topics to identify and consider issues that are germane to the biomedical research environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Research
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students in the field of anatomy or physiology working toward the M.S. Degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Neurobiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics of neurobiology are covered from a molecular perspective, including neurotransmitters and neuromodulators, the synapse, G-coupled receptors, pumps, ligand-gated and voltage-gated channels, sensory transduction, the action potential and other relevant phenomena.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The principles and techniques in the investigation of bioelectrical phenomena in relation to: (a) the physiology of the digestive organs, (b) myophysiology, (c) endocrinology, and (d) neurophysiology. Advanced physiological experiments will be conducted to provide an understanding of the applications of electronic equipment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: AP 747 and consent of staff.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Rec. and two three-hour labs a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Special problem-involving techniques utilized in studying the function of various organ systems of the body.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students working toward the Ph.D. Degree.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of staff. Animal science and industry courses. The M.or Ph.D. program of study shall include supportive course work from several departments including statistics, biochemistry, anatomy and physiology, biology, grain science and others. Graduate level courses offered in the Department of Animal Sciences and Industry are listed below.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Steel Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Structural design computations for beams, girders, columns and beam-columns. Design of connections (bolted & welded). Structural working drawings (plan, elevation and connection details). Overview of failure mechanisms and design procedures for plate girders. AISC requirements for prevention of various failure mechanisms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: ARE 524 or equivalent first course in Structural Steel Design.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Architectural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of a specific problem under the direct supervision of a member of the architectural engineering faculty.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Graphic Design/Visual Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Digital Media
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Practices
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics dealing with career preparation skills such as developing a professional and teaching portfolio, computer techniques for promoting one’s art, establishing relationships with galleries/museums, and agencies, basic techniques of exhibition design and installation, techniques of critiquing works of art, etc.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis upon the exchange of ideas and exploration of critical theory. Direct involvement in critiques, readings, discussions, and field trips. Each semester a different theme will guide a pertinent topic from within the field.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for two semesters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Sculpture Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Drawing Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Painting Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Printmaking Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Ceramics Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Metalsmithing and Jewelry Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced creative work with emphasis on technical and visual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Independent Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced individual work offered in studio areas of ceramics, graphic design, digital media, drawing, painting, printmaking, sculpture, and metalsmithing and jewelry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Art Theory and Criticism
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of the principal theories influencing production and criticism of contemporary art.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Studies in Photography
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on the conceptual nature of the photographic medium. Students will be encouraged to produce work useful for their graduate thesis. Course readings will be on photo theory and image relationships.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course may be taken after or concurrently with Graduate Independent Study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Art
htmlparse.Course.description: Research which may form the basis for the master’s of fine art thesis or report.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Science: Chemistry and Application
htmlparse.Course.description: Composition, structure and properties of foods. Chemical interactions affecting texture, color, flavor, and stability during processing and storage.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Pharmacology of Farm Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the basic principles of pharmacology as related to the proper and safe use of drugs and chemicals by the livestock industry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gametes, Embryos, and Stem Cells in Farm Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of gametes, embryos, pregnancy, and stem cells in farm species including supporting information from laboratory species and humans. Emphasis will be on the regulation of stem cells, gametes, and embryos and on the conceptus-maternal interactions to establish and maintain pregnancy and program conceptus and postnatal development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rumen Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: Metabolism, absorption, digestion, and passage of nutrients in the rumen; factors affecting the environment of the rumen; certain aspects of rumen function and dysfunction; techniques used in rumen research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three one-hour lec. A week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stress Physiology of Livestock
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrative physiology of livestock during environmental, management, and pathological stresses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutritional Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: The course focuses on the structures and function of the gastrointestinal tract, with an emphasis on digestive physiology in the small intestine. Details of gastrointestinal tract secretion, regulation, digestion, and absorption of the major nutrient groups are emphasized with species comparisons.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Neuroendocrine Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Neuroendocrine regulation of reproduction, growth, and metabolism, with an emphasis on neuroendocrinology of domestic livestock.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. per week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Reproductive Endocrinology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of molecular mechanisms that control gene expression in mammals, with an emphasis on genes and their products that control reproduction.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: BIOCH 521, ASI 710 and ASI 830.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. per week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ovarian Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Endocrine and physiologic control of ovarian functions in domestic livestock.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: BIOCH 521, ASI 710 and ASI 830.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week for 5 weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Techniques in Domestic Animal Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: A combined seminar and laboratory type course. Current and classical studies reported and discussed, relationships between behavior and other disciplines explored and methods of data collection examined. Small-scale demonstration experiments planned, executed and reported orally and/or in scientific written style.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour rec. and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical Techniques–Sample Preparation and Beginning Analyses
htmlparse.Course.description: Sample collection, processing and handling methodologies will be addressed as they pertain to research methods in the animal sciences. Basic laboratory techniques, sample collection, and analyses of moisture and nitrogen will be covered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., eight hours lab and one hour rec. a week for three weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical Techniques–Mineral Analyses
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the analysis of minerals in common feedstuffs. This course will cover sample preparation and atomic absorption, emission, utraviolet/visible and fluorimetric spectrophotometric methods of analysis of feedstuffs and biological fluids.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., eight hours lab and one hour rec. a week for three weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical Techniques–Carbohydrate and Lipid Analyses
htmlparse.Course.description: This course covers the analysis of carbohydrate and lipid components of feedstuffs and biological materials using conventional as well as HPLC and gas chromatographic methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., eight hours lab and one hour rec. a week for three weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical Techniques–Radioisotope Use
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of radioisotope use in physiological applications of research in domestic animals including radioactive decay, detection methodology, and isotope dilution.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., eight hours lab and one hour rec. a week for three weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical Techniques-Immunoassays
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of measurement of biological substances and hormones utilizing enzyme-linked immunoassays (ELISA) and radioimmunoassays (RIA).
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., eight hours lab and one hour rec. a week for three weeks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of research and technical problems in the discipline. Attendance required of all departmental graduate students. Maximum of two hours may be applied toward an advanced degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: A written report of either research or problem work on a topic in the major field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Research leading to the completion of a master’s thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Animal Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on important areas and contributions in the field of animal science not covered in present courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lipids on Food Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical and chemical characteristics of lipids with emphasis on their behavior and function in food systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Energy Utilization in Domestic Livestock
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive discussion of the development and application of energy systems used to guide livestock feeding, procedures used in energy experimentation, dietary/digestive/environmental factors that influence efficiency of energy utilization, and the efficiencies with which different energy substrates are used to support various maintenance and production functions. Emphasis will be placed upon ruminants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Protein and Amino Acid Utilization in Domestic Livestock
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive discussion of protein and amino acids and their role in digestion, absorption, metabolism, protein synthesis, and degradation in livestock. Emphasis on techniques and interpretation of results from experiments designed to evaluate protein utilization and factors which influence amino acid metabolism in monogastrics and ruminants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vitamin and Mineral Nutrition of Domestic Livestock
htmlparse.Course.description: A detailed examination of the vitamin and mineral nutrition of domestic livestock. Emphasis will be placed on current literature on the determination of vitamin and mineral requirements, practical considerations for vitamin and mineral supplementation in livestock feeding, and the potential for vitamin and mineral deficiency and toxicity in domestic livestock.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and two hour lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rumen Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Three hours lecture a week dealing with the microorganisms of the rumen, their habitat, diversity, structure, interactions, and biochemical activities. Techniques for enumeration, isolation and identification of ruminal microorganisms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Meat Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic biochemical, physiological, and histological properties of muscle and related tissues; muscle contraction, rigor mortis, and muscle hydration; maturation; processing by thermal, dehydration, and cold sterilization techniques; meat flavor chemistry; meat research techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ASI 777 or equiv.; and a course in biochemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Problem in Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth study of a topic supervised by a member of the graduate faculty.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Permission of supervising faculty member.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Animal Sciences Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Weekly evaluation of the scientific literature and the reasoning underlying the selection of research problems, the formulation and testing of hypotheses, and the evaluation and presentation of results.

htmlparse.Course.title: Doctoral Research in Animal Sciences and Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Research leading to the completion of a Ph.D. Degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Textile Surface Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Application and analysis of textile surface design to include color and image addition with natural and sustainable techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination and application of approaches for undertaking practice-based research in creative apparel and textile design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Merchandise Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Comprehensive understanding of theory, practices, and trends in international merchandise management. An analysis of the global merchandising system and the way goods are distributed to consumers in various countries.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Merchandising Implications
htmlparse.Course.description: The advanced study of financial trends in the merchandising industries. Focus will be on the financial implications of recent advances in the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strategic Merchandising
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the executive level planning process utilized to develop successful merchandising strategies; emphasis on the importance of a market orientation for building customer value and sustaining a competitive advantage.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fashion Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of historical, sociological, psychological, marketing, and economic concepts, theories, and research that contribute to current understanding of the fashion process in the apparel and textile field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strategic Economic Analysis of Apparel and Textile Industries
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the current economic situation in the U.S. apparel and textile industries; examination of the internal and external forces affecting global production and distribution of apparel and textile products with emphasis on formulating strategies for industry success.

htmlparse.Course.title: Apparel and Textile Product Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary teams generate ideas and develop concepts for innovative apparel and textile products or modifications of existing products; evaluate market and manufacturing potential; prepare marketing and technology transfer plan.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: AT 645 or permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Consumers in the Apparel and Textile Market
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of apparel and textile consumers and their decision-making processes; examination of internal and external factors influencing evaluation and purchasing behavior in order to predict future behavior consumption and purchasing patterns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of current literature with implications for future research; analysis of research methodologies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: A graduate-level course in statistics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed reading and study of selected topics in apparel and textiles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Topics in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of social and environmental factors related to apparel and textiles.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Eight hours of credit basic to field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in apparel design, textiles, history of costume, or apparel and textile marketing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Six hours credit basic to the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Preplanned and supervised off-campus experience in business, industry, museums, government agencies, or the cooperative extension service.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Twelve hours in the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Analysis of Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory, principles, and procedures in evaluating the physical properties of textile fibers, yarns, fabrics, and products for apparel, interior furnishings, and industrial uses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Project Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Research and written documentation for the M.S. Design Project Report option in Apparel and Textiles.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No credit

htmlparse.Course.title: Design Project Exhibit
htmlparse.Course.description: Design development for the M.S. Design Project Report option in Apparel and Textiles resulting in a body of original works to be exhibited on campus during the final semester of the student’s program.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No credit

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis Research in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in apparel or textiles for the master’s thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Proposal Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation and discussion of proposals for dissertation research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Six hours of statistics, three hours of research design or methods, and consent of major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grantsmanship and Publication
htmlparse.Course.description: Grant writing, identifying external funding, managing grants, preparing manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication, and preparing papers and poster for presentation at professional meetings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research in Apparel and Textiles
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in apparel or textiles for the doctoral dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Food Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Material and energy balances with application to food processing. Fluid flow and heat transfer in food processing. Thermodynamic properties and laws. Conc. enrollment in ATM 541 is urged.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: PHYS 113 or 115, BIOCH 120 or CHM 190, MATH 210 or 205.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Food Engineering Laboratory Exercises
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory experiments supplementing ATM 540.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Agricultural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The laboratories of the University are available for research in all areas of agricultural engineering. The results of such investigation may be incorporated in bulletins of the Agricultural Experiment Station.

htmlparse.Course.title: Particle Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Science and behavior of airborne particles or aerosols. Technology and methods for measuring, controlling, and utilizing aerosols in the agricultural and food industries. Specific topics include basic particle mechanics; principles of particle measurement; particle statistics; electrostatic precipitation; condensation; evaporation; dust generation; and filtration.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Agricultural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation and discussion of research philosophies, procedures, and results.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour rec. a week. Required of all graduate students in agricultural engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Agricultural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A course reserved for study of current topics in agricultural engineering. Topics announced when offered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 9 credit hours of graduate courses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated up to a maximum of 9 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Measurement Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of measurement systems for biological and agricultural systems with emphasis on sensors and data-acquisition systems for measurement of variables related to soils, plants, animals, machines, and processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Biomass Thermochemical Conversion
htmlparse.Course.description: Thermochemical methods to convert biomass to fuels and chemicals: liquefaction, pyrolysis, gasification, and heterogeneous catalysis. Analysis of the reaction kinetics and mass, heat, and momentum transfer in chemical reactors associated with these methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Req. Pr.: CHE 520 or ME 513 and CHE 550 or BAE 545.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Ecological Engineering Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of ecological engineering, systems and processes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week. Recommended background: Hydrology and Ecology. Not available for students with credit for BAE 665.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Watershed Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study and evaluation of process equations used in watershed-scale, water-quality models. Advanced application of watershed models.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week. Recommended background: Hydrology and GIS. Not available for students with credit for BAE 669.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar for graduate students in biochemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectroscopy of Macromolecules
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture and laboratory course on ‘state-of-the-art’ multi-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance methods and strategies in solving three dimensional structure of peptides, proteins, nucleic acids and other macromolecules.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Course to present timely topics in Biochemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Biochemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in biochemistry which may be used for preparation of the M.S. Thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training for research undertaken.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Plant Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced treatment of topics of current interest in plant biochemistry, including photosynthesis and carbon metabolism, nitrogen fixation and nitrogen metabolism, structure and function of the higher plant genome, and production of material of economic interest.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Insect Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures, readings, and discussion of topics of current interest in insect biochemitry. Topics will include biochemical molecules and processes specific to insects, such as biochemistry of the exoskelton and regulation of metamorphosis, as well as comparison of insect and mammalian biochemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lipids
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemistry of plant and animal lipids, their occurrence, metabolism, and industrial uses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biomolecular Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures on the basic principles and skills involved in computer modeling of biomolecules. Students will carry out projects that focus on practical aspects of utilizing publically available simulations and analysis tools to address questions in biochemical and biophysical research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nucleic Acids
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure and function of nucleic acids: structures and properties of DNA, RNA, and chromatin; recombinant DNA techniques; mutagenesis and carcinogenesis; protein-nucleic acid interactions; structural influences on replication, transcription, translation, and regulation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proteins
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and readings on the chemical nature of proteins; fractionation; purification, structure, chemical and physical properties of proteins and amino acids.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biochemistry of Cell Regulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of biochemical pathways and molecular mechanisms regulating cell growth, movement, differentiation, and death. Emphasis on molecular interactions and signaling cascades controlling gene expression, protein synthesis and folding, proteolysis, cytoskeleton, cell cycle, cell survival, and apoptosis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Protein Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Advances in protein biochemistry, including protein structure determination, dynamics, folding, stability, enzyme mechanism and regulation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Postdoctoral Research in Biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced level research in collaboration with a faculty member, involving projects in any area of biochemistry. Post-graduate training in first three years beyond doctorate.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Biochemistry II
