htmlparse.Course.description: Research in biochemistry which may be used for preparation of the Ph.D.Thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training for research undertaken.*Nonmajors lacking these prerequisites should obtain consent of instructor before enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Plant Physiology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern concepts and research in plant physiology. Respiration, photosynthesis, and water relations of plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: An introductory plant physiology course or general biochemistry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Plant Physiology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern concepts and research in plant physiology. Mineral nutrition, translocation, growth, and development of plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: An introductory plant physiology course or general biochemistry. Previous enrollment in BIOL 800 is not required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advances in Plant Stress Signaling
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern concepts and research in plant response to biotic and abiotic stress. Hormones in plant stress response; signal transduction in plant stress response.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Mycology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of fungi, with emphasis on structure, identification, classification, phylogeny, and economic importance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanisms of Eukaryotic Gene Regulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines important concepts in the mechanisms of gene regulation at the molecular level. Focuses on gene regulation in eukaryotes at the level of transcription, splicing and translation and on RNA’s diverse roles.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOCH 765 and BIOL 541 or BIOL 705, or BIOL 707.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Composed of a lecture (1 hr) covering important concepts and a student recitation (1 hr) of scientific articles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis of Ecological Gradients
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to analytical methods and conceptual approaches to evaluate patterns of communities across environmental gradients. Multivariate statistical techniques will be used to analyze data and quantify species abundance patterns in a variety of environments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Fisheries Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of theory and techniques related to managing freshwater fisheries. Emphasis will be placed on current research needed to support management practices such as sampling, indices, harvest regulations, predator-prey interactions, community structure, ecosystem management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Aquatic Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of advanced issues adn methodology in limnological sciences, including a workship on algal taxonomy, and an applied group project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two lecture hours, two laboratory hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Landscape Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Effect of spatial pattern on ecological processes. Course will emphasize how spatial complexity emerges and is maintained in ecological systems, the analysis of spatial pattern, scaling issues, the ecological consequences of spatial pattern and applications for conservation and ecosystem management in both aquatic and terrestrial systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two lecture hours, one discussion hour and three laboratory hours per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Demographic Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and methods of quantitative approaches for the study of population dynamics. Advances in matrix methods and mark-recapture statistics will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and one hour studio per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Evolution of Animal Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of mechanisms, ontogeny, and evolution of behavior stressing the adaptive nature of behavior.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., one hour discussion or assigned readings, and two to three hours lab a week. Lab format well be individual research projects requiring independent research skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrient Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: The cycling of elements in ecosystems with emphasis on macronutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorous, and major cations, and the influence of variables such as acid rain on nutrient dynamics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Conservation Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Considers in depth one or two topics important to conservation biology. Topics vary. Potential topics are: community based ecosystem management and policy implementation, habitat loss and fragmentation, demographics of small populations and population viability models, conservation genetics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Virology
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth readings and discussions of current topics in virology and the impact of viruses in today’s society with emphasis on recent research literature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOL 730 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with the consent of the intstructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cellular and Molecular Parasitology
htmlparse.Course.description: Biochemistry, immunology, and molecular biology of medically important eukaryotic parasites.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular and Cellular Immunology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and readings covering the molecular and cellular interactions during various phases of the immune response.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Immunology
htmlparse.Course.description: Current research in immunology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOL 670 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Biology of Cellular Membranes
htmlparse.Course.description: A general coverage of membranes with respect to theories of structure, chemical and physical methods of study, methods of isolation, transport mechanisms, assembly and function of components, and receptors. Some specific membrane systems will be covered in detail including a review of recent references.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Molecular Approaches
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to approaches and techniques used in the molecular analysis of biological systems, with a focus on modern molecular and cellular biological approaches. Format is primarily group discussion of primary literature, with the goal of instilling the ability to think critically and evaluate published studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Skills in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction for new graduate students in the mechanics of becoming a scientist and professional biologist. The course includes presentation of professional seminars, grant proposal writing and reviewing, manuscript preparation and submission, interviewing for jobs, teaching skills, effective communication of scientific data in graphs and tables, and other topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Responses to the Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern concepts and techniques for measuring the environment and plant ecophysiological responses. Instrument/sensor theory and operation, leaf energy balance, measurement and interpretation of plant carbon and water relations in the field.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: a course in ecology, a course in plant physiology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Plant Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of theory in population and community ecology as applied to higher plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOL 529 or a plant ecology course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Emphasis on current research in plant population ecology, species interactions, community structure, and four hours lecture/rec. per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Cellular and Developmental Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemistry, structure, and function of cellular systems in growth, development, and reproduction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Plant Systematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Taxonomy, phylogenetic inference and major themes in the evolution of vascular plants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOL 551 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., one hour discussion, and three hours lab per week. Lab format will include individual or small group research projects.

htmlparse.Course.title: Evolutionary Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the evolution of population, community, and ecosystem structure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and one hour rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Confocal, Fluorescence and Light Microscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to theories, functions and applications of confocal, fluorescence and light microscopy, and fluorescent molecules. Lab emphasis on students working on independent research projects requiring microscopy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture and three hours of lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electron Microscopy Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and techniques involved in using the transmission electron microscope for the study of biological materials. Includes individualized instruction on the operation of the Philips 201 electron microscope and techniques for processing biological samples.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Current participation in research requiring electron microscope.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced Topics in Biology

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced Problems in Biology

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Graduate Seminar in Biology

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research in Biology

htmlparse.Course.title: Postdoctoral Research in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced-level research in collaboration with a faculty member, involving projects in any area of biology.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Research in Biology

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Research in Microbiology

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Mechanics of Materials and Applied Elasticity
htmlparse.Course.description: Two- and three-dimensional deformation analysis , equilibrium, and elastic constitutive laws. Stress-strain transformations between coordinate systems. Advanced topics in bending, shearing, torsion and combined loads, with applications to engineering problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Numerical and Analytic Techniques for Engineers
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of linear algebra, differentiation, integration, optimization and complex variables to a broad range of engineering problems; introduction to solving partial differential equations using finite difference, finite element and boundary element methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Geostatistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of spatially-correlated data. Univariate, bivariate, and spatial description; global and point estimation; random function models; stationarity; intrinsic hypothesis; semivariogram; correlogram; ordinary and block kriging; cross validation; cross correlation and cokriging; experimental design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and one hour computer lab a day.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of intermediate level topics of interest in civil engineering. Topics announced when offered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and approval of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring, Summer, on sufficient demand

htmlparse.Course.title: Shear Strength and Slope Stability of Soils
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced theories of soil strength and failure; soil improvement; theories of lateral earth pressure with applications; stability analysis by both classical and numerical methods. Selected soil mechanics laboratory project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Properties of Cohesive Soils
htmlparse.Course.description: Mineralogy and structures of clay minerals; fabric and bonding of the clay particles; compressibility and strength characteristics of clays; moisture effects, retention, and movement through clay.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strength and Deformation of Geo-materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Mathematical and physical modeling in geotechnical engineering. Advanced laboratory testing of soils. Plasticity, dilatancy, failure and critical state. Finite element applications: Laboratory strength tests and/or simple field problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hrs. rec. per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Geotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: Soil/environment and soil/ pollutant interactions; pollutant effect on soil strength and behavior; design and performance of waste containment structures; clay liners, surface seals, and slurry walls; slope stability problems for landfills.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Soil Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Permeability and seepage analysis involving dams and sheet piles; stress distribution in earth masses, one- and three-dimensional consolidation theories; advanced study of compressibility of soil, numerical method applications in consolidation and seepage; analysis of settlement. Selected soil mechanics laboratory project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Structural Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Nonlinear structural analysis using classical solutions; nonlinear geometry analysis by matrix methods for trusses and frames; nonlinear material analysis by matrix methods for trusses and frames; solution of nonlinear equilibrium equations; modeling structural problems by commercial software to predict ultimate capacity and nonlinear response.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Energy Methods and Applied Variational Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and applications of virtual work, minimum potential, and variational principles using generalized coordinates, displacements, and forces to derive and solve advanced problems in structural, soil and hydrodynamic problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Stability
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of flexible members. Linear and nonlinear buckling of beams, frames, plates and complicated structural systems; post buckling behavior of steel structures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Prestressed Concrete Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of prestressing methods including strength and load-balancing approaches and their application to the analysis and design of beams, slabs, and axially loaded members. Flexural, shear, torsion, and anchorage-zone analysis. Study of deflection and time-dependent losses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis of Groundwater Flow
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of flow through porous media; applications of flow theory to well analysis and design; groundwater resource evaluation and regional groundwater systems analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Civil Engineering Design Using GIS
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigating the usage of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology to better solve engineering problems. Teams of students will use GIS to design solutions to various civil engineering related situations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and approval of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Engineering Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemical kinetics and equilibria, acid-base chemistry, complex formation, precipitation and dissolution processes, and applications to the analysis of environmental engineering problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Water Supply and Wastewater Collection Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and design of water distribution networks, pump stations and storage reservoirs; wastewater collection and pump station system design; computer applications and systems optimization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Unit Operations and Processes in Environmental Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A laboratory study of physical, chemical and biological phenomena operative in engineered environmental systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. or conc.: CE 762 and CE 766.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hr. rec. and six hrs. lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Wastewater Treatment
htmlparse.Course.description: Recent advances in municipal and industrial wastewater treatment. Wastewater microbiology, wastewater biochemistry, applications of biotechnology in wastewater engineering, recent advances in nutrient removal processes, wastewater treatment technologies, and water reclamation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transportation Safety
htmlparse.Course.description: Importance of transportation safety, crash data collection, common crash databases, traffic safety studies, accident data analysis, identification of high crash locations, traffic control devices as related to safety, special population group safety, traffic conflict studies, accident reconstruction, statistical methods in crash data analysis and traffic calming.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: CE 572 or consent from the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hrs. rec. per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning and design of a regional airport, including site selection in conformance with state and federal regulations; layout and design of runway system; size and layout of terminal buildings, landside facilities, parking lots, and circulation system.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sustainable Transportation Asset Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Recent advances in transportation asset management system. Inventory and condition data collection, life cycle analysis, prioritization, optimization, and implementation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Traffic Flow Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of traffic flow, traffic stream characteristics, car following models, shock wave analysis, queuing analysis, application of statistical methods to traffic engineering problems, traffic simulation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CE 775. Pr. or conc.: STAT 510.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current advances and research in civil engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour seminar biweekly.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Civil Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A course reserved for study of current topics in civil engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Eighteen hours graduate credit in areas approved by instructor.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring, Summer, on sufficient demand

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Geotechnical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of selected topics in geotechnical engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Eighteen hours graduate credit in areas approved by instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Structural Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of structures subject to dynamic loadings. Optimization of structural systems to minimize earthquake hazards.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Plates and Shells
htmlparse.Course.description: Equations and solutions of bending of thin plates of various edge conditions and shapes. Membrane and bending theory of shells of revolution. Nonlinear theory of plates and shells.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Structural Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of selected topics in structural engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Eighteen hours graduate credit in areas approved by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physicochemical Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of physical and chemical processes in the movement and removal of particulates and organics in natural and engineered systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Environmental and Water Resources Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of selected topics in environmental and water resources engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Eighteen hours graduate credit in areas approved by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Transportation and Materials Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of selected topics in transportation engineering and civil engineering materials.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Eighteen hours graduate credit in areas approved by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head. Doctor of veterinary medicine degree only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory I
htmlparse.Course.description: Laboratory experiments on momentum and heat transfer.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Five hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Materials Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Areas of current interest in materials including solidification, transformations, solutions, dislocations, creep, fracture, failure analysis, and failure prevention.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Biochemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Subjects of current interest in the broadest sense of biochemical engineering. These involve not only chemical engineering problems which contain biochemical biological, or medical elements but also applications of chemical engineering principles and methodologies to biochemical, biological, medical, and ecological problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Chemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Original investigations in transport phenomena, unit operations, thermodynamics, process dynamics, applied chemical kinetics and process development. The results of these investigations may be used for the master’s thesis or the doctoral dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in thermodynamics, with emphasis on a chemical and physical equilibria and the estimation of thermodynamic properties.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing in chemical engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Chemical Reaction Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of kinetics and catalysis in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, with applications in chemical reactor design and process development.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Unit Operations I
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of mass transfer operations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Biomass Thermochemical Conversion
htmlparse.Course.description: Thermochemical methods to convert biomass to fuels and chemicals: liquefaction, pyrolysis, gasification, and heterogeneous catalysis. Analysis of the reaction kinetics and mass, heat, and momentum transfer in chemical reactors associated with these methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: CHE 520 or ME 513 and CHE 550 or BAE 545.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of recitation a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Chemical Process Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: The dynamical behavior of chemical reaction systems and process equipment used in chemical plants. Control mechanisms for these systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing in chemical engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Transport Phenomena I
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced treatment of momentum, energy, and mass transport, with emphasis on momentum transport in chemical engineering applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Transport Phenomena II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced treatment of momentum, energy, and mass transport, with emphasis on energy and mass transport in chemical engineering applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Process Design and Optimization
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced problems in the optimal design and economic evaluation of plant equipment and processes for the chemical and allied industries.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Chemical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current advances and research in chemical engineering and related fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of department head and major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of department head and major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Reaction Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study in this field of such topics as complex reactions, catalysis, dispersion effects, fast reactions, reactions in fluidized beds.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CHE 822 and one course in chemical engineering numbered 851 or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Semiconductor Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Areas of current interest in semiconductor processing including solid state diffusion, plasma-assisted deposition and etching, thin film deposition processes, contamination control, and contact metallurgy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Transport Phenomena
htmlparse.Course.description: Subjects of current interest such as surface phenomena, turbulent transport, droplet mechanics, multicomponent systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Process Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the most recent methods for analysis of the dynamic behavior and control of complex systems and industrial processes. The use of Lyapunov theorems and the maximum principle are examples of the methods to be studied.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CHE 850 and one graduate course in chemical engineering numbered 851 or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Unit Operations
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of such topics as zone melting, foam fractionation, membrane permeation, thermal diffusion, and unsteady state operations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CHE 826 or 832 and one course in chemical engineering numbered 851 or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Process Design and Optimization
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of advanced methods of process design and optimization, such as modern variational methods and dynamic programming. Applications to be chosen mainly from the chemical and allied industries to include stochastic as well as deterministic problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Thermodynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study in this field of such topics as irreversible thermodynamics, solution theory, and surface phenomena.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CHE 815 and one course in chemical engineering numbered 851 or higher.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of department head and major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemistry in Outer Space and in the Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: The generation of reactive atoms and molecules in outer space and in the laboratory is covered, as well as their chemical reactions and spectroscopy. Extreme conditions of high and low temperatures, synthesis using atoms, nanoscale particles of inorganic materials, and matrix isolation are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Thermodynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: The laws, principles, and methods of thermodynamics and their applications to chemical systems. Statistical-molecular approach emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Materials Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts of materials chemistry developed from an understanding of the chemical composition and structure of materials, and their relationship to the properties of matter. Students will be introduced to the structures and composition of materials and the diverse range of materials, including metals, metal clusters, semiconductors, nanomaterials, supramolecular materials, sol-gel materials, liquid crystals, glasses, polymers and composites.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theoretical Chemistry I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics and atomic and molecular spectroscopy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Kinetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of experimental and theoretical aspects of dynamics of chemical reactions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Conditions, scope, and applications of reactions useful in synthetic organic chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organic Spectroscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: The principles of IR, UV-VIS, mass, and NMR spectroscopies applied to the problem of structure determination.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in analytical chemistry, inorganic chemistry, organic chemistry, and physical chemistry for the M.S. Degree.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Analytical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Graduate Seminar in Analytical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Graduate Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Graduate Seminar in Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Physical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation of topics from literature in physical chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical Separations
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory, instrumentation, and application of classical and modern separation techniques are covered in this lecture course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Methods in Inorganic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and application of infrared, Raman, visible, ultraviolet, NMR, ESR, NQR, Mossbauer, and mass spectrometry to inorganic chemistry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Homogeneous Catalysis
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of industrially important and synthetically useful catalysis of organic reactions by soluble metal complexes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CHM 712 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture course in inorganic chemistry in areas of specialization of the faculty, with emphasis on current developments. Specific topics will be changed from semester to semester, so a student may take the course for credit more than once.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applications of Surface Science to Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemical bonding in the solid state. Surface science and related techniques as applied to chemical problems. Special topics including data analysis and corrosion studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Analytical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture course in analytical chemistry in areas of specialization of the faculty, with emphasis on current developments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeat for credit with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Microscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory, instrumentation and applications of modern microscopic methods are covered in this lecture course. Emphasis is given to the study of chemically-important phenomena in material systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electroanalytical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and applications of electrochemical methods: chronoamperometry, chronopotentiometry, cyclic voltammetry, coulometry, polarography, potentiometry, and instrumentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Molecular Spectroscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: Experimental, and theoretical methods associated with ultraviolet and visible absorption, fluorescence, Raman scattering, and nonlinear optical spectroscopies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chemical Statistical Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of classical and quantum statistical mechanics to chemical phenomena.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theoretical Chemistry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Quantum theory of atomic and molecular structure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Physical Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture course in physical chemistry in areas of specialization of the faculty, with emphasis on current developments. Specific topics will be changed from semester to semester, so a student may take the course for credit more than once.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of orbital symmetry, thermochemistry, kinetics, and other topics applied to the understanding of reaction mechanisms.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week. Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Topics in Organic Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: A lecture course in organic chemistry in areas of specialization of the faculty, with emphasis on current developments. Specific topics will be changed from semester to semester, so a student may take the course for credit more than once.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in analytical chemistry, inorganic chemistry, organic chemistry, and physical chemistry for the Ph.D. Degree.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Unless otherwise stated, all chemistry courses numbers 600 or above require the following as minimum prerequisites: CHM 550 Organic Chemistry II; CHM 532 Organic Chemistry Laboratory; CHM 595 Physical Chemistry II; and CHM 598 Physical Chemistry II Laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Translator Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: LR parsing, storage allocation, code generation, data flow optimization, compiler generators.

htmlparse.Course.title: Semantics of Programming Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction of formal semantics description methods for programming languages; comparison of operational, denotational, algebraic, and axiomatic methods; analysis of relationship of formal semantics definitions to computer implementation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Logic Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics; constraint logic programming, deductive databases, concurrent logic programming, object-oriented logic programming, mathematical theory of logic programming specification and transformation of logic programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Theory of Asynchronous Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Safety and liveness properties, synchronous and asynchronous message passing systems, virtual circuit and datagram communication, process failure, concepts of composition and superimposition, temporal logic, reachability analysis, theory of concurrency control, atomic commitment, replica control.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Distributed Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Models of distributed computation, events and global states, failure semantics, communication abstractions, synchronization in distributed programs; distributed algorithms: election, termination and deadlock detection, broadcast programming and algorithms.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CIS 720; or CIS 725 and permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Protocol Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts of protocol design, specification languages and formal description techniques, safety and liveness properties, protocol validation, protocol synthesis, protocol translation and conformance testing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Topics in Artificial Intelligence
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced techniques and new ideas in artificial intelligence. Includes applications and case studies of artificial intelligence in action.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Retrieval and Text Mining
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practice of search engines for retrieving textual information; basic and advanced topics, with emphasis on newer technologies that go beyond simple keyword search; the use of MapReduce framework to process large collections of documents.

htmlparse.Course.title: Machine Learning for Bioinformatics
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will cover some of the most important machine learning algorithms (including semi-supervised and transfer learning algorithms) and their applications to bioinformatics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Either CIS 732 or CIS 734, and instructor permission.

htmlparse.Course.title: Verification and Validation
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical techniques for verifying and validating software including formal verification, software testing, reliability measurement and modeling.

htmlparse.Course.title: Specification and Verification of Reactive Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of formal specification languages; architecture of concurrent and reactive systems; specification methods including: Z, Petri nets, temporal logic, state transition models; development and evaluation of system specifications; verification structures including layered systems, serialization, and predicate automata.

htmlparse.Course.title: Agent-Oriented Software Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis, design, and implementation of large, complex, distributed, and adaptive software systems using agent-oriented paradigm. Will survey various modeling languages and agent-oriented methodologies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Database Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in database and intelligent information systems. Possible topics include active, temporal, object-oriented, and multimedia databases, warehousing and data mining.

htmlparse.Course.title: Data Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in database design and maintenance including performance monitoring, query optimization and tuning in centralized and distributed data systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Computability
htmlparse.Course.description: Formal models for computability; universal programs; Church’s thesis; unsolvable problems and reducibilities; partial recursive functions; recursive and recursively enumerable sets; s-m-n theorem and the recursion theorem.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics of the current state-of-the-art of computer science.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Prerequisite varies with the announced topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: MSE Project
htmlparse.Course.description: This course takes the student through the process of developing a project. This process typically takes more than one semester to complete. Includes reviews and walkthroughs of the requirements, design, and implementation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CIS 740, CIS 748, CIS 771, and three additional credits toward the MSE degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to computing as a discipline; the relationship of computing to other disciplines; the interaction of computing and ethics; the development of a written and oral research proposal.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: full graduate standing in CIS (CR/NCR only).

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report in CIS
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report in CIS

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Computer Science

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Translator Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics involving incremental, extensible, conversational compilers; program development systems, portability and validation of compilers; compiler generators.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Programming Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Formal definition languages; operational and formal semantic models; equivalence of semantic models; formal properties of programming languages.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Topics in Distributed Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics on current state-of-the-art research in distributed systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computation Structures
htmlparse.Course.description: Petri nets, flowgraph schemata, dataflow models, relationships between abstract computational models and hardware models and programming languages.

htmlparse.Course.title: Expert Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced theory and techniques in the development of expert systems. Focuses on knowledge acquisition and knowledge organization used in expert systems. Includes design, implementation, and evaluation of an expert system.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Topics in Software Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Research on one of the topics in CIS 840.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Data Base Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in data base systems including distributed data bases, integrity, security, normalization, data base machines, performance models, query languages.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Topics
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of current topics in computer science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Computer Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Computer Science

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Public Speaking
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar for graduate teaching assistants in strategies, techniques, and materials for the introductory public speaking course. Includes current practices and research in communication education. Enrollment limited to graduate teaching assistants in the Department of Communication Studies, Theatre and Dance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Writing in Communication Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the problems of writing and rewriting the results of scholarly investigations in communication studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Communication Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in communication studies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Research in Communication Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Descriptive and experimental methodologies pertinent to investigation in communication studies. Topics will include such techniques as content analysis, attitude scaling, and stylistic analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Field Research in Communication Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical and interpretive methodologies pertinent to investigations in communication studies. Topics will include participant observation, unstructured interviewing, ethnography, and discourse analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Competitive Forensic Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and study of current research in competitive debate and individual events.

htmlparse.Course.title: Masters Research in Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the relationship between language and culture and its impact on human communication.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training to carry on the line of research.

htmlparse.Course.title: RF Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the theory and design of electronic circuits for communications emphasizing the implementation and analysis of common radio-frequency (RF) building blocks. Topics include s-parameters, the Smith chart, component behavior, RF test equipment, computer simulation, filter design, impedance matching, amplifiers, oscillators, mixers, and demodulators. A report will be required of all graduate students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytical and Computational Tools for Engineering Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Ordinary differential equations, vector algebra, vector calculus, partial differential equations and the separation of variables technique for solving wave equations. Students also perform simulation and analysis using software tools including MATLAB and MATHCAD.

htmlparse.Course.title: Airport Planning and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the Federal Aviation Regulation Part 139 airport design standard and airport master planning process. Includes a study of the role of the airport in community development. Advanced course project required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Technical Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive writing practice, applying rhetorical principles to a number of genres common to non-academic professions and workplaces, including oral presentations. Introduction to allied topics such as document design and editing, and crafting technical presentations. Application of global information literacy and research methods will culminate in the preparation of a master’s project proposal.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Research Skills and Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of qualitative and quantitative research methods; use of a range of tools to develop applied research skills focusing on literature reviews. Examines applied research concepts, methods, and skills to foster enlightened decision making in professional practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Aviation Safety Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the development of safety and how safety management has become an important part of any company. Discusses Safety Management Systems and how this blueprint is becoming an integral part of most organizations, emphasizing specific governmental and corporate programs. Topics include management tools and techniques to aid in systematically controlling risk and developing a safety culture mind-set.

htmlparse.Course.title: Application of Lean Six Sigma Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Six sigma and lean tools within an enterprise to improve product and process development, production operations, and service activities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reliability Centered Maintenance of Plant Equipment
htmlparse.Course.description: Reliability modeling and assessment, reliability-centered maintenance, condition monitoring technologies, and computer tools.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Electromagnetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of electromagnetic wave phenomena primarily using transmission line theory to study practical applications such as antennas, cables, and waveguides. Includes a treatment EMI and related issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone Experience for Professional Master of Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Students formulate, research and execute a project for industry partners to gain hands-on experience under expert guidance while integrating knowledge to solve complex problems. Students write a convincing proposal for a capstone experience, gather and analyze data, draw conclusions and present results. Teams of first and second-year students may form to work on real-world projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor. Coreq.: COT 702.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated up to three semesters, up to a total of six credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Professional Master of Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Opportunity for advanced independent study of a specific topic in one of the following areas: Aviation safety, engineering technology, or technology management. Topics selected jointly by student and the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Professional Master of Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Offered on sufficient demand. Advanced topics in Professional Master of Technology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Medicine or Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: The course provides for the study of medical or surgical problems. The student, in conference with the major professor, outlines the methodology and procedures, conducts the study, and prepares a detailed report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supplemental Clinical Small Animal Soft Tissue Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Additional training in the diagnosis and treatment of small animal soft tissue and general surgical diseases through participation in the Small Animal Soft Tissue Service of the Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supplemental Small Animal Internal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Additional topics in internal medicine. The student may be required to participate in a special problem with a written or oral report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supplemental Equine
htmlparse.Course.description: An opportunity for students to pursue additional equine studies (medicine, surgery, etc.) in depth and assume substantial responsibility for care of hospitalized cases. Students will present a seminar on a medicine or surgical subspecialty and pursue a special problem.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Production Medicine of Small Ruminants
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures and other exercises emphasizing production medicine of small ruminants.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Third or Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Diagnostic Imaging II
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will receive advance training in radiologic interpretation and alternate imaging procedures. Emphasis will be on didactic and hands-on training in ultrasound imaging.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supplemental Clinical Small Animal Orthopedic Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Additional training in the diagnosis and treatment of small animal orthopedic surgical diseases through participation in the Small Animal Orthopedic Service of the Veterinary Medical Teaching hospital.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the KSU College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vet Medicine for South American Camelids
htmlparse.Course.description: The health concerns of South American Camelids are presented in terms of medicine, surgery, theriogenology, and associated disciplines.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Third- or fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine, DVM degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exotic, Wildlife, and Zoo Animal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of exotic, wildlife, and zoo animal medicine through participation in the clinical service in the Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital. Problem solving, differential diagnosis, diagnostic procedures, and medical and surgical therapy of nondomestic animals will be emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Companion Small Animal Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Additional elective studies of preventative medicine, general practice medicine, and specialty medicine. Emphasis on animal behavior, canine theriogenology, and general practice experience. The student may be required to participate in a special problem with a written or oral report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Life-Long Learning Skills for Professional Students
htmlparse.Course.description: Develop basic skills in veterinary students and other professional students to help them assess recent scientific literature and continuing education information and help them choose which information to incorporate into their professional skills and knowledge base.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: 3rd year standing in the veterinary curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Vet Study Tours
htmlparse.Course.description: Faculty-led trip for students to explore veterinary medicine in a foreign country. Prior to travel, students will learn about the country through lectures, research, presentations. During the trip they will interact with nationals in the veterinary profession and experience the culture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Enrolled as a 1st-3rd year or grad student in the College of Vet Med. Additional students admitted with discretion of faculty leading the tour.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Veterinary Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of animal welfare, food safety and other societal concerns for animals and the veterinary profession. This course will help students learn to utilize scientific literature along with current events media to critically evaluate these contemporary issues. This class will expose students to many issues that pet owners, food producers and veterinarians face every day. Guest lecturers or moderators will be included for proper background debated topics with a focus on effective communication of evidence based decisions through writing and public speaking.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: First, Second or Third-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine or Graduate School.

htmlparse.Course.title: Health and Management of Llamas and Alpacas
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide detailed information regarding nutrition, herd health, breeding management, medicine, neonatal care, and surgical problems of llamas and alpacas.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 1st, 2nd or 3rd-year standing in a College of Veterinary Medicine or enrolled as a graduate student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Management of Sheep and Goats
htmlparse.Course.description: Course content is delivered both as online seminars via KSOL and case-based discussions and problem solving exercises in the classroom on herd management, preventive health care, nutrition, medicine, diseases, reproduction, and surgery of sheep and goats.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Third year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine or graduate student on the Manhattan Campus of Kansas State University.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Management of Small Ruminants
htmlparse.Course.description: Course content is provided entirely online as seminars delivered via distance education in KSOL on herd management, preventive health care, nutrition, medicine, diseases, reproduction, and surgery of sheep and goats.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Second or third year standing in College of Veterinary Medicine other than KSU or graduate student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Ultrasonography
htmlparse.Course.description: Course content will be delivered both as online seminars via KSOL and case-based discussions. The physics, basic principles of use, and common artifacts of ultrasound will be covered as it relates to veterinary diagnostic imaging. Ultrasound imaging of the thorax (non-cardiac), abdomen, musculoskeletal system, and other areas (eye, thyroid/parathyroid) will be covered, predominantly in small animals. The course will cover both normal and pathologic ultrasound findings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CS715 Radiology, 3rd year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine or graduate student on the Manhattan campus of Kansas State University.

htmlparse.Course.title: Communication with the Agricultural Worker
htmlparse.Course.description: An elective course focused on improving communications between veterinarians and animal caretakers in production agriculture and equine industries. The course will use face to face discussions and online seminars in KSOL to teach communications skills with a focus on common terminology and vocabulary necessary for effective communication. Audio-visual teaching utilizing immersion philosophy is utilized to provide the material course work.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 2nd or 3rd year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine or graduate student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: An attempted solution of some of the medical and parasitological problems confronting the practitioner of veterinary medicine.

htmlparse.Course.title: Breeding Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies of the breeding diseases of domestic animals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: D.V.M. degree or consent of staff.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interpretation of Radiology Studies of Body Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced discussions of radiologic interpretation, indications and interpretation of alternate imaging procedures (MRI, CT, nuclear medicine, ultrasound).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM degree or consent of department head prior to registration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systemic Medicine I
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the medical aspects of diseases of the urinary, nervous, and integumentary systems and special senses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM degree or consent of department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systemic Medicine II
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the medical aspects of diseases of the cardiovascular, respiratory, musculoskeletal and endocrine systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM degree or consent of department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Orthopedic Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals, theory, and practice concerning genetic, metabolic, infectious, neoplastic, and traumatic diseases of bones and joints.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM degree or consent of department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Sciences Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: A seminar for all house officers and all Clinical Sciences graduate students.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One-hour seminar presentations each week. May re-enroll for total maximum of two credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Large Animal Surgery 1
htmlparse.Course.description: In depth review and discussion of current basic surgical science and foundations of sound surgical practices.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM (or equivalent) or permission of course coordinator.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Large Animal Surgery 2
htmlparse.Course.description: Concentrated examination of the pre-operative, surgical and post-operative requirements of soft tissue surgical disease/disorders of large animals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM (or equivalent) or permission of course coordinator.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Large Animal Surgery 3
htmlparse.Course.description: Concentrated examination of the pre-operative, surgical and post-operative requirements of orthopedic or hard tissue surgical diseases/disorders of large animals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM (or equivalent) or permission of course coordinator.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Diagnostic Imaging - Small Animal
htmlparse.Course.description: Case presentation/discussion of diagnostic imaging techniques used in small animal veterinary practice, including radiography, ultrasonography, nuclear imaging, magnetic resonance imaging, and computer tomography. Clinical cases will demonstrate imaging methods and technology used in the various body systems, with an emphasis on interpretation and clinical diagnosis. Students may re-enroll for a maximum of three credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Small Animal Internal Medicine I
htmlparse.Course.description: Various topics in small animal internal medicine will be presented. In-depth discussion of pathophysiology and recent advances in diagnostics and therapeutics. Different topis will be covered in various years at instructor’s discretion.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course may be repeated with approval of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Small Animal Internal Medicine II
htmlparse.Course.description: Various topics in small animal internal medicine will be presented. One topic will be covered in a one-hour conference weekly. In-depth discussion of pathophysiology and recent advances in diagnostics and therapeutics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course may be repeated with approval of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Diagnostic Methods in Feedlot Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience in feedlot operation and bovine necropsy diagnosis consisting of 40 hours in bovine necropsy and 320 hours of an on-location practicum in a cattle feedlot.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Successful completion of the first-year professional curriculum in the College of Veterinary Medicine with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or better and no grade below a C.

htmlparse.Course.title: Small Animal Endoscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of small animal (canine and feline) endoscopy, including respiratory and gastrointestinal endoscopy, laparoscopy and anthroscopy. Thirteen lectures with 2 laboratories will be offered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM degree and approval from course coordinator.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Offered Fall semester only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Small Animal Surgery
htmlparse.Course.description: Current and foundational information on techniques, theory, and management in small animal surgery.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DVM degree or approval on instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Pharmacokinetics
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of pharmacokinetics with emphasis on practical implications for the clinician, including bioavailability, bioequivalence, residues in food of animal origin, dosage forms and regimens, therapeutic drug monitoring, drug interactions, interspecies differences, and the effect of disease on the pharmacokinetics of drugs. Background in physiology and statistics strongly recommended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Pharmacokinetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the concepts and practical applications of pharmacokinetics for graduate students of veterinary clinical pharmacology, including the design and conduct of pharmacokinetic studies and the analysis and modeling of pharmacokinetic data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wound Healing
htmlparse.Course.description: Didactic lectures on the science of wound healing physiology and on the clinical application of wound healing principles. Laboratory sessions will be incorporated to cover the principles of reconstructive surgery.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Production Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced training in agricultural production medicine. Emphasis on answering production medicine problems through the appropriate design and interpretation of research models. Course is discussion-based and facilitated by a team of faculty members. Students will be expected to participate in weekly topic discussions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Design and Interpretation of Production Livestock Field Trials
htmlparse.Course.description: Designing appropriate studies to answer research questions that can be addressed in livestock production settings and to interpret and present the results in a suitable manner.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Ophthalmic Surgery Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures will cover ophthalmic instruments and proper surgical techniques for commonly performed ophthalmic surgeries. Cadavers will be available to practice adnexal and corneal ophthalmic surgeries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Ophthalmology or surgery resident at Kansas State University Veterinary Medical Teaching Hospital.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Small Animal Endocrinology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced topics in small animal endocrinology. Emphasis on comparative aspects of endocrine gland disease and its clinical manifestations in dogs and cats. Primary literature, review articles, and advanced texts will be the principle sources of information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Science Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced instruction in research topics and technologies, emphasizing various clinical disciplines.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of research design, grantsmanship, practical statistics, manuscript preparation, and ethics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: DVM degree or consent of department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Clinical Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research in any of the fields of Clinical Sciences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This work may form the basis for either the M.S. Thesis or the M.S. Report.

htmlparse.Course.title: Toxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: Effects of harmful substances on the animal body. Emphasis placed on toxicologic principles and management of the poisoned patient.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Second-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine, BIOCH 521, and AP 747.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours of lecture a week for half of the semester plus three one-to three-hour field trips.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Toxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course in toxicology stressing independent problem-solving utilizing data bases and technical resources to identify toxicological concerns, to define the problem, to consider possible remedial alternatives, and to select and implement the most appropriate management and recommendations for correction and future prevention.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Fourth-year standing in the College of Veterinary Medicine, or graduate students in toxicology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once per student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecotoxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: It will be an elective course in ecotoxicology aimed at DVM students with interests in wildlife and public health. Students will examine the interface between toxicology and ecology, including the toxic effects of natural and synthetic pollutants on ecosystem health and ecosystem services. Students will develop an appreciation and understanding of the mechanisms and processes that lead to ecotoxicity. They will also be introduced to the methodologies involved in assessing ecotoxic effects, and how ecotoxicological considerations impact industry and society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Completion of first-year DVM curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Toxins in the Biological System
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced toxicology course concerned with the cellular land subcellular effects of various groups of toxins on the intact animal organism.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOCH 521, CHM 531 or 550, AP 770 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Toxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced toxicology course concerned with the occurrence, biological effect, detection, and control of foreign chemicals in the environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Topics in Toxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced toxicology course providing in-depth examination of toxicological area of current relevance to and/or controversy on mammalian health.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Specific topics will change from semester to semester. Student in Ph.D. programs may repeat the course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Toxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigations into the interactions of chemical compounds with living systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cancer Pathogenesis
htmlparse.Course.description: This course, consisting of 2-hour lecture per week, will present an overview of the cancer development process at the cellular and molecular level, including regulatory networks involved in growth control and tissue organization and an introduction to animal, cell, and molecular techniques for studying progression, treatment, prevention of cancer.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multidisciplinary Thought and Presentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Training in critical thinking, writing, and speaking for the food, veterinary, plant, health, and related sciences. With emphasis on writing, students prepare technical reports, news releases, abstracts, and commentaries. Students prepare meeting agendas and present seminars. Committed students will emerge with enhanced critical-thinking and written-presentation skills.

htmlparse.Course.title: Trade and Agricultural Health
htmlparse.Course.description: This course considers the multilateral trading system as it relates to food safety, food security, animal health, plant health, and international cooperation. The course content will be of value to students interested in food safety and security, epidemiology, public health, agriculture, food science, security studies, political science, agricultural economics, veterinary medicine, and international relations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rumen Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: Metabolism, absorption, digestion, and passage of nutrients in the rumen; factors affecting the environment of the rumen; certain aspects of rumen function and dysfunction; techniques used in rumen research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three one-hour lectures a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Clinical Pathology Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical training in advanced techniques of clinical chemistry and hematology used in a large clinical pathology laboratory.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Analysis in Food Production Veterinary Medicine
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience manipulating numerical data bases and turning that information into usable knowledge to aid veterinary diagnostic strategies, implementing health management programs, and food animal production decision making processes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Successful completion of the first year in the veterinary curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an international, state, local, or district health agency or other appropriate health agency.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once, but only 6 hours may be applied toward the MPH degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Global Health Issues
