htmlparse.Course.description: A review of global health problems and various strategies to manage international health concerns. The class is open to graduate students, including veterinary students, with an interest in public health that have at least 12 hours in biology or related courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Safety Risk Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description:
Three hours of lectures on interwoven roles of risk assessment, management and communication – defined as risk analysis – will be applied to problems and policy development in food safety. This course will aid students in developing the ability to critically examine food safety risk issues from various stakeholder perspectives, leading to risk management and communication activities to reduce the impact of foodborne disease.

A significant portion of the course will focus on the importance of thorough research and good communication skills, as well as the suitability of communication efforts. The course will be presented through lectures, case study presentations, and Internet-based support material including text, audio and video through the extensive database maintained by Dr. Douglas Powell of Kansas State University and colleagues (foodsafety.ksu.edu; barfblog.com).

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathologic Technique and Diagnosis
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience in mammalian necropsy, avian necropsy, histologic techniques, and diagnostic laboratory procedures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Immunology of Domestic Animals
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to introduce graduate students to immune responses of domestic animals to pathogens and parasites.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathology of Body Fluids
htmlparse.Course.description: Alterations of the components of body fluids occurring in disease processes, and interpretations of these changes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour rec. and six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Histopathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced general and systemic histopathology. Extensive microscopic evaluation of organ systems for degeneration, circulatory disturbances, inflammation and neoplasia.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Exfoliative Cytology
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation, examination, and interpretation of aspiration, biopsies with emphasis on the recognition of inflammatory and neoplastic processes. Exfoliated material derived from various body fluids, tissues, and organs of the living clinic patient will serve as the basis of the study.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Epidemiologic principles of disease with a focus on measures of disease occurrence, association and impact, determinants of disease diagnostic test evaluation, study design and critical literature evaluation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DMP 708 or DMP 754 or equivalent AND STAT 703 or DMP 830 or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Disease Detection, Surveillance and Risk Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is focused on understanding the principles underlying quantitative risk assessments and disease detection/surveillance systems suited to a variety of animal health and food safety applications. These will then be used to advance the practical application of risk assessment and disease detection in the development of valid and useful herd, regional and national disease surveillance programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Veterinary Parasitology
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure, life cycle, pathology, immunology, public health significance, diagnosis, and treatment of protozoan and metazoan parasites of veterinary significance.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec., one hour rec., and four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Surgical Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical experience in examining and processing surgical biopsy specimens and writing histopathological reports.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three or six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathogenic Mechanisms
htmlparse.Course.description: Virulence factors of infectious microorganisms and the host response to infection. Topics include pathogenesis of human and animal diseases and mechanisms of immunity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Diagnostic Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Pathologic alterations of disease with emphasis on diagnostic characteristics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Domestic Animal Immunology
htmlparse.Course.description: Real-life immune problems of veterinary and zoonotic relevance and their application to domestic animal immune systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: DMP 850, DMP 705 or an immunology course in a veterinary curriculum. Co-req: Interested students who might not meet the enrollment pre-requisite can contact the course coordinator to request permission to enroll.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One 1-hour lecture and one 1-hour discussion per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Principles of Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Disease and its effects with emphasis on etiology and pathogenesis; morphologic change will be correlated with changes in chemical composition and function.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and three hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Diagnostic Veterinary Virology
htmlparse.Course.description: Viruses associated with diseases of veterinary medical significance with emphasis on diagnosis. Clinical observations, pathogenesis, lesions, epidemiology, immunity, and control will be considered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour rec. and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathology of Diseases of Laboratory Animals, Fish and Wildlife
htmlparse.Course.description: Pathology of diseases affecting laboratory animals, fish, and wildlife.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Nine hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Comparative Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics to assist pathology majors in their area of specialization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathobiology Seminar (MS)
htmlparse.Course.description: Oral presentations on topics in epidemiology, food safety, immunology, microbiology, molecular biology, parasitology, pathology, and toxicology. Reports will include critical review of the relevant literature; experimental design and methodology; and presentation and critical evaluation of data. The course is for MS students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Diagnostics of Infectious Diseases
htmlparse.Course.description: This graduate course is aimed at reviewing, and evaluating new and improved molecular diagnostic methods for infectious diseases. Theory, development, and applications of molecular diagnostic tests will be discussed in the context of current literature. This course will provide an opportunity for students to learn and apply recent advances in the development of molecular diagnostic test.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students without the prerequisites must have the permission of the course coordinator.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Laboratory Diagnosis
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical training in evaluation, interpretation, and written description of selected clinical pathology case materials.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Course may be repeated by pathology and microbiology majors for a maximum of four credit hours (M.S.) and eight credit hours (Ph.D.).

htmlparse.Course.title: Applications of Flow Cytometry
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and practical experience in the use of flow cytometry in diagnosis and research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Pathobiology (MS)
htmlparse.Course.description: A special problems course for graduate students working toward the MS degree in Pathobiology. The course is generally problems- or techniques-based in any of the disciplines in the Pathobiology program, conducted under the supervision of a graduate faculty in the Pathobiology Graduate Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Globalization, Cooperation, & the Food Trade
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will include 15, 45-minute lectures and/or reading assignments. They will be assessed through online quizzes and one essay project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Veterinary Hematology
htmlparse.Course.description: Morphology, physiology, and pathology of the blood of domestic animals. Emphasis is placed on the species variations and clinical application.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Pathobiology (MS)
htmlparse.Course.description: A special course for graduate students working toward the MS degree. Lectures, readings, and discussion of topics of current interest in any of the disciplines of Pathobiology.

htmlparse.Course.title: MS Research in Pathobiology
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students working towards the MS degree. Individual research in the fields of epidemiology, food safety, immunology, microbiology, molecular biology, parasitology, pathology, and toxicology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathogenic Mechanisms of Viruses
htmlparse.Course.description: The goals of the course are to learn various pathogenic mechanisms (virus-host interactions) of selected virus (RNA and DNA) and Prion diseases. The course will cover the molecular, cellular and immunological bases of pathogenesis both in vitro and in animal models.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rumen Microbiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Lecture dealing with the microorganisms of the rumen, their habitat, diversity, structure, interactions, and biochemical activities. Techniques for enumeration, isolation and identification of ruminal microorganisms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Necropsy Diagnosis
htmlparse.Course.description: Necropsy procedures and diagnosis. May be repeated each semester by pathology majors for a maximum of 10 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Systemic Pathology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Etiology, pathogenesis, gross and microscopic characteristics, and systemic effects of diseases of cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, and endocrine systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DMP 852 plus fours credits of DMP 935.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., one hour rec., and six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Systemic Pathology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Etiology, pathogenesis, gross and microscopic characteristics, and systemic effects of diseases of the skin, of musculoskeletal, genital, and nervous systems, and of special senses.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec., one hour rec., and six hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced theory and methods for designing, analyzing and interpreting epidemiologic research. Emphasis on observational study design and analysis issues including design identification and optimization, bias recognition and control, and appropriate analytical approaches for epidemiologic data.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DMP 854 and STAT 717, or equivalent training (recommended).

htmlparse.Course.title: Cellular and Molecular Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Biochemistry of the injured cell, relationship of intracellular parasitism to cellular metabolism, metabolic and genetic basis of inherited disease.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pathobiology Seminar (PhD)
htmlparse.Course.description: Oral presentations on topics in epidemiology, food safety, immunology, microbiology, molecular biology, parasitology, pathology, and toxicology. Reports will include critical review of the relevant literature; experimental design and methodology; and presentation and critical evaluation of data. The course is for PhD students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Pathobiology (PhD)
htmlparse.Course.description: A special problems course for graduate students working toward a PhD degree in Pathobiology. The course is generally problems- or techniques-based in any of the disciplines in the program, conducted under the supervision of a graduate faculty in the Pathobiology Graduate Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Pathobiology (PhD)
htmlparse.Course.description: A special course for graduate students working toward the PhD degree. Lectures, readings, and discussion of topics of current interest in any of the disciplines of Pathobiology

htmlparse.Course.title: Postdoctoral Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Postdoctoral research in collaboration with a faculty member, involving projects in any area of pathology or microbiology.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Pathobiology
htmlparse.Course.description: For graduate students working towards the PhD degree in pathobiology. Individual research in the fields of epidemiology, food safety, immunology, microbiology, molecular biology, parasitology, pathology, and toxicology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Power Electronics
htmlparse.Course.description: High-frequency switching dc/dc converters, resonant converters, analysis and control of power electronic systems, and thermal management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Instrumentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics related to the general field of electronic instrumentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Systems Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: State space description and analysis of continuous and discrete time dynamic systems including optimal control solutions. Both linear and nonlinear systems are considered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Engineering Methods for Analysis, Simulation, and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Computer-aided and numerical techniques applicable to problems in electrical and computer engineering. Emphasis is on implementation of these techniques on the computer.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Wide Area Networking
htmlparse.Course.description: Design and analysis of networks that span large distances or multiple local area networks (LANs). Topics include queuing theory, LAN standards, routing, switching, security, and higher-level protocols.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 410 or STAT 510, high-level programming language.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Parallel Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Parallel processing application in signal and image processing. Array processors, pipeline processors, systolic and wavefront arrays, interconnection networks, performance analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sequential Machines
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and mathematical framework of digital hardware will be developed. Limitations and fault detection of these machines will be explored using the theoretical basis of sequential machines.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computer Engineering Methods for Analysis, Simulation, and Design II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of ECE 840.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Computer Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics relating to current developments in computer engineering. Topics may include computer architectures, computer networking, multiprocessing, and computer interfaces.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Electromagnetic Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Mathematical development of electromagnetic wave theory.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Noise Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of noise phenomena and measurement; the representation of noise by statistical parameters, the noise factor of undesired noise sources, and the measurement applications of noise generators.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transform Processing of Digital Signals
htmlparse.Course.description: Orthogonal transforms in digital signal processing with emphasis on one- and two-dimensional signals, generalized Wiener filtering, feature selection in pattern recognition, and elements of adaptive filtering techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Digital Image Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic concepts and techniques of image formation, representation, analysis, restorations, enhancement, coding, segmentation, and description. Object recognition using shape descriptors and syntactic techniques. Image processing applications in remote sensing, computer vision, and medical diagnosis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Neural Networks in Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Engineering applications of artificial neural networks and machine intelligence. Particular emphasis will be placed on determining appropriate applications of alternate computing approaches and establishing efficient hardware support to implement these computational approaches.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Electric Energy Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Subjects of current interest such as computer methods, distribution and transmission systems, systems planning and economics, extra high voltage transmission, exotic power sources.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Quality
htmlparse.Course.description: Description, analysis, modeling, and solution of difficulties relating to distortion of the waveshape in alternating-current power systems. Problems of voltage regulation. Focus on harmonics, noise, filtering, and communications interference in power systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power Systems Operation and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Specific topics include economic dispatch, unit commitment, control of generation, power system security, and state estimation. Several analytical and computational techniques are used to solve different problems related to above mentioned topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Distribution System Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis, design and planning of electric distribution systems. Standard terminologies related to distribution systems are covered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Power System Stability and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to power system stability and control. System device modeling and control issues are introduced for the purpose of studying various aspects of power system stability. Transient, small signal, and voltage stability topics are covered. Several stability analysis projects for multimachine systems are included.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Electrical Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: For advanced study in specialized areas by M.S. Students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Solid-State Electronic Devices
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics, crystal structures, and the semiconductor material properties. Diodes, bipolar transistors, and field-effect transistor structures. Analysis of second-order effects in transistors.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Electrical and Computer Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation and discussion of current advances and research inelectrical and computer engineering. Required of all graduate students in electrical and computer engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Electrical Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Special research problems in electrical engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Control Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of advanced topics in optimal, time-varying, and stochastic control theory, or other recent developments in the control systems area.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics related to advanced computer hardware design, performance measurements, sequential machines, and/ or advanced computer architectures.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics related to the design and performance analysis of communication systems. Topics may include advanced modulation techniques, optimum receiver design, nonlinear channels, multipath analysis, diversity systems, and others.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Signal Detection Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of optimum signal detection principles for analog and digital communication over the linear additive noise channel. Includes series representations for random signals and the derivation of minimum mean square error (MMSE) receivers for AM and FM and maximum likelihood (ML) receivers for FSK, MSK, and M-Ary PSK.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Information as a measure of uncertainty, zero-memory and Markov sources, coding of information sources, channels and mutual information, reliable transmission via unreliable channels, error correcting codes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Digital Signal Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics related to adaptive digital filtering techniques; special purpose hardware for digital filtering; two-dimensional signal processing and classification.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Digital Filtering
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced treatment of the theory of digital filtering and digital signal processing. Emphasis is on analysis of random signals.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Bioengineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of complex physiological system simulation and analysis techniques, modern experimental and clinical electronic bioinstrumentation systems. Topics selected according to graduate student’s interests.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated. Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Monetary Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on recent literature of monetary economics; Federal Reserve control of the money stock; the demand for money; money and economic activity; monetary targets and indicators.

htmlparse.Course.title: Macroeconomic Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of macroeconomic theory including Classical, Keynesian, and Monetarist theory. An Introduction to modern analysis in macroeconomics with an emphasis on dynamic methods and general equilibrium analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economic Analysis for Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Microeconomic and macroeconomic theory with selected business applications. Theory of consumer and producer behavior and price determination in individual markets. Theory of aggregate economic behavior and the effects of fiscal and monetary policies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 110, ECON 120, and one semester of calculus. Not available for graduate credit in economics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced International Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical and policy issues related to the international monetary system, capital movements, exchange rate systems, the U.S. balance of payments, and trade of underdeveloped countries.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 681 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Econometrics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals of econometric analysis. The classical linear model, multi-collinearity, specification error, distributed lags, non-normal disturbances, dummy variables, generalized least squares, autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity. Applications to specific problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Sector Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Conditions for economic efficiency in the public sector; public good production functions; nonmarket decision making; rationale for public sector growth; systems analysis, cost-benefit and related techniques of allocating public goods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Managerial Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Economic analysis of production, cost, and demand functions. Application of economic models to managerial decision making.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 520, MATH 205, and one course in statistics with a prerequisite in the same department.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Course will provide seminars on specific topics in economics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Prerequisites vary with announced subject matter.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for no more than 6 credit hours total.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced individual study is offered in selected subject matter.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Background of courses needed for problems being studied. ECON 898. Master’s Report in Economics. ECON 899. Master’s Research in Economics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report in Economics

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research in Economics

htmlparse.Course.title: Macroeconomic Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of advanced topics in macroeconomic theory including general equilibrium analysis, economic growth, business cycle theory, and other developments in macroeconomic theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Macroeconomics
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of seminal and current research in macroeconomic topics such as growth, business cycles, or public policy. Topics will be related to the research interests of the professor and students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Macroeconomic Modelling
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines current topics in macroeconomics with an emphasis on empirical modelling. The course will be structured to allow the student an in-depth look at influential articles in the literature through presentations and required summary papers, and apply similar skills in an assigned original research paper.

htmlparse.Course.title: Labor Economics Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical analysis of wage theories, collective bargaining, and unemployment problems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 620 or consent or instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Location of Economic Activities
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the theory of location including central place theory, location of the individual producer, industrial location patterns, and urban land-use models. Also includes application of theoretical models to current urban problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Labor Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of studies in labor supply, labor demand, immigration, and current topics in labor economics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Econometrics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Econometrics I. Stochastic regressors, asymptotic results, instrumental variable estimation, systems of equations, maximum likelihood estimation, nonlinear least squares, and other miscellaneous topics in econometrics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Time Series Econometrics
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of recent advances in tome series econometrics. Economic forecasting, vector autoregressive modeling, unit root testing, cointegration, and other topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 930 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Microeconometrics
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of recent advances in microeconometrics, including panel data, treatment effects, and other topics, to provide students with the analytical tools used in economic research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of demand, production, and cost theories; a discussion of duality theory and the application of the Le Chatelier principle; an analysis of price and output determination in different market structures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of advanced topics in economic theory, including general equilibrium theory, welfare economics, and risk and uncertainty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Organization
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of industrial organization and its analytical techniques. Game theory; monopoly pricing; product and quality selection; vertical control; static and dynamic theories of oligopoly; product differentiation, price dispersion, and advertising; asymmetric information and strategic behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Economics of Regulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of regulatory economics and its analytical techniques. Principal-agent theory, theories of economic regulation, Ramsey pricing, peak-load pricing, non-uniform pricing, cross-subsidization, rate-of-return regulation, incentive regulation, and regulation in the presence of asymmetric and incomplete information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory and Methods of Regional Economic Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: A consideration of differences in regional and urban growth; comparison of alternative growth theories; methods of analyzing regional economics such as input-output analysis, linear programming, industrial complex, and spatial interaction models.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 925 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Trade Theory and Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of recent literature in trade theory and policy under imperfect competition. International trade in imperfectly competitive international markets, strategic trade policies, political economy of trade protectionism, welfare effects of trade liberalization and economic integration, and other issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Research in Economics

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Community Educational Development
htmlparse.Course.description: A comprehensive review of factors related to community change and the role of educational programs in dealing with them. Emphasis is on educational and economic problem-solving approaches and change-implementing programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Foundations of Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for adult and continuing education students and college or university personnel in sociology and related fields dealing with adults, this course focuses on the economic historical and sociocultural context in which learning takes place. Included is an in-depth examination of the relationship between adult education and culture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Teaching Adults
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will explore the theory and practice of teaching adults. Collaborative and active learning techniques will be emphasized in face-to-face and online environments. Students will examine the strengths, weaknesses, and appropriate application of a variety of methods to different adult education environments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory and Practice of Continuing Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Specific instruction on facilitating continuing education programs; emphasis on serving the institution, part-time students, community, and other interests.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Planning in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the basic situations in which adult education occurs and fundamental steps by which learning is made more effective in those situations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Learning and Motivation
htmlparse.Course.description: Core course of adult learning perspectives and motivation for learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Self-Directed Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Self-directed or independent learning is an important aspect of adult education because it represents a significant portion of all learning by adults. The concept was instrumental in distinguishing the fields of adult education. During this course, students will explore self-directed learning from both an academic and a personal perspective. Topics include its history and development, its research base, areas of current interest and implications for adult education practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Innovative Higher Education Programs for Adults
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to provide a conceptual understanding of innovative systems and structures currently serving higher education needs of adult learners. The course will provide a historical basis for the development of these programs as well as future trends. Included will be discussions of corporate colleges, external degree programs and distance/online learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Workplace Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an overview of various aspects of workplace learning initiatives as found in the related professional literature and from various practice-related venues. Major topics include evolution of the process of workplace learning and the profession of training; assessing and analyzing workplace learning needs; designing and delivering workplace learning programs; and measuring and evaluating the impact of workplace learning initiatives.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Evaluation in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide an overview of various methods and strategies for evaluating educational programs for adults. Students will have the opportunity to examine the literature that is related to the program evaluation process in adult education settings. Opportunities to study the manner in which the process of program evalution is conducted in modern adult education programs in governmental, educational, and private and public sector organizations will also be provided.

htmlparse.Course.title: Significant Literature of Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A seminar studying the significant literature of adult education from a current and historic perspective.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminars in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: These seminars will consider research and professional development on the special interests of the students in the several fields of education represented.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of adult education historical perspectives, contemporary institutions and programs, teaching-learning process, administrative practices, and conceptual roles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organization and Administration of Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical study of organizational procedures and administrative practices as related to the implementation and maintenance of an effective program in adult education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Development Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Study all pertinent adult development theories.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminars in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: These seminars will critically consider recent research in the designated fields. The emphasis will be upon individual studies and small group interaction. Enrollment is restricted to those students who have been admitted to the doctoral program in education and who have completed substantial amounts of graduate study in the designated fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Adult Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Field experiences in the development of programs in cooperating schools and educational or related agencies under the supervision of College of Education graduate faculty member.
htmlparse.Course.notes: A maximum of 6 credit hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Doctoral Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Doctoral Research
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training to carry on the line of research undertaken and consent of instructor. Pr.: Consent of Instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stress Management for Teachers, Counselors, and Administrators
htmlparse.Course.description: Systematic training in stress-management strategies and techniques for the professional educator and for use in classroom and counseling settings. Includes knowledge of self-directed and instrumental techniques, psychophysiology of stress, issues in stress management, and role of teacher and counselor in delivering stress-management training.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Philosophy of Higher Education
htmlparse.Course.description: History and development of higher education with a study of the philosophy, objectives, and functions of various types of institutions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Using Tests in Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on the use of tests as an integral part of counseling. Emphasizes interpretation of scores, issues of psychological and educational measurement, and selection and evaluation of instruments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide students with an overview of quantitative and qualitative research methods in education and to equip them with the knowledge to be competent consumers and producers of educational research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Methods in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An introductory yet comprehensive survey of common statistical analyses encountered in educational research. Computer oriented.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: A first course in college mathematics plus either STAT 702 or EDCEP 816.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of College Student Personnel Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, history, philosophy, current professional issues and future trends in college student personnel work; an introduction to the primary student services.

htmlparse.Course.title: Survey Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation, interpretation, use, and production of survey research in education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Individual Intelligence Testing
htmlparse.Course.description: Appraisal of individual intelligence with emphasis on techniques of administration, scoring, interpreting, and applying in school settings. Supervised practice in the use of WISC-III and other tests such as the Stanford-Binet, K-ABC, and WAIS-R.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: EDCEP 715 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of Guidance
htmlparse.Course.description: This is a foundation course for secondary school counselors and addresses issues relevant to secondary school guidance programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Counseling Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories, methods, and problems in counseling, relating the counseling process to dynamics of human behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Psychology of Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of the literature and applications of social/psychological studies of the student, student cultures, characteristics of educational institutions, and organizational change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Learning Principles
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of learning theories and an overview of research on factors that enhance academic performance, including psychosocial variables, learning styles, and learning strategies. The course covers strategies for enhancing student academic peformance, ranging from assessment to implementation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Diversity in Higher Education.
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses diversity in higher education administration and practice. Examples of topics examined in the context of diversity include recruitment and retention, program development, campus climate, and multicultural student organizations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Issues in Higher Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Current issues in higher education are examined. Students learn to identify current issues and how professional administrators effectively address these issues. Individual topics or issues that are part of the larger campus climate are studied.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creativity in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Clarification of creativity in education, discovery of creative talent, methods of encouraging creative talent; emphasis on learning models and research in creativity as compared with or contrasted with conformity; emphasis on divergent and convergent thinking and its role in creative teaching with major consideration given to the student’s involvement in creative study and/or teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Academic Advising
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the foundations of academic advising as essential componenets of student success and retention in higher education. Topics include developmental advising; research on academic advising; models and delivery systems; advising skills, including diverse populations; and evalution, assessment, and reward systems for advisors and advising programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interpersonal Relations for Academic Advising
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on developmental communications/interpersonal relations skills for academic advisors. Topics to be addressed include influences on the helping process, such as personal characteristics, verbal and nonverbal responses and behaviors, and ethical considerations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Academic Advising
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines and applies relevant theories, concepts, and models of academic advising, as well as issues and other factors related to the administration of academic advising in higher education.

htmlparse.Course.title: The College Student and the College Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the American college student and how he/she is influenced by institutional policies, practices, and other environmental variables. Special attention will be given to contemporary student development theory and research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Aspects of Academic Advising
htmlparse.Course.description: This course introduces students to the various cultural, ethnic, racial, and linguistic issues associated with advising practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Career Development for School Counselors
htmlparse.Course.description: Addresses the knowledge and competencies necessary for school counselors to use education, career, and labor market information resources, and career guidance and counseling techniques, methods, and technology in developing programs, services, and activities to meet the career development needs of students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Guidance in the Elementary School
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature and philosophy of guidance in the elementary school; the function of specialized child appraisal and counseling techniques in the unique interrelationships of the specialist and the teacher in the team approach to elementary school guidance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Guidance Program Management
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses the issues, knowledge, and competencies relevant to planning, implementing, andevaluating effective guidance and counseling programs to meet the needs of all students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Group Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to acquaint students with group procedures as basic tools in counseling, guidance, and other education services.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of adults and the problems they face in their educational, psychological, social, and career development. Particular emphasis will be given to counseling theories and strategies important for counselors working with adults experiencing these developmental problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Counseling Services for Adults
htmlparse.Course.description: Strategies for the development and implementation of counseling services for adults in school, community, business, and industrial settings. The course will focus on the integration of formal and informal educational, career development, and mental health programs developed for adults having life adjustment problems. Local, state, and federal programs and agencies and their role in adult counseling services will be examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leisure Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Course develops leisure counseling models for use in community and institutional recreational programs and to provide skills and competencies in assessing, interviewing, and counseling individuals and groups in the use of leisure experiences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Trends in Career Development
htmlparse.Course.description: This course addresses the role of work in people’s lives across the life span, with an emphasis on the application of career development theories, research, practice, and resources to higher education. Topics are presented to help professionals in higher education facilitate students’ academic and career development, planning, and decision-making within the context of the changing world of work.

htmlparse.Course.title: Consultation for Counselors
htmlparse.Course.description: This course acquaints students with the major models of consultation that may be used by counselors for intervention with individuals and organizations. Techniques, issues and ethical considerations are also addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of College Student Personnel Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, budgeting, personnel supervision and evaluation, office management, administrative use of computers, program evaluation and related applications in the primary college student personnel services.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: This is a developmental counseling skills course addressing influences on the helping process such as personal characteristics, theoretical orientation, verbal and nonverbal behaviors, and ethical considerations. Includes research applications, case conceptualization, evaluation, simulation, and supervised individual and group practice in the field.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 24 credit hours of prescribed counseling curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in College Student Personnel Work
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised professional experience in college student personnel services.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 18 credit hours in the CSP master’s degree program

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of a problem of current professional interest based on study of pertinent original literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Counseling Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: This supervised internship includes activities that a regularly employed school counselor would be expected to perform. The student will engage in individual counseling, group work, developmental classroom guidance, use within an ethical framework and a sensitivity to individual characteristics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 36 credit hours of School Counseling prescribed curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychological Bases of Educational Thought and Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: In studying educational applications of behavioral, social cognitive, and cognitive learning theories, attention is given to historical milieus of origin, relationships to major educational philosophies, relationships to features of instruction, and classroom motivation, and evaluation of impact on contemporary educational thought and practice.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Measurement
htmlparse.Course.description: A course designed to provide the theoretical background needed for students who wish to (1) develop greater competence in practical uses of tests in educational settings, (2) pursue academic study of measurement theory, and (3) develop instruments for research use.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Design in Educational Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophy, planning, and evaluation of research in education. Experimental designs appropriate for educational research with special emphasis on multivariate procedures. Computer oriented.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Educational Psychology: Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: The learning process, with special emphasis on human abilities and early and contemporary learning theories, with applications to selected recent developments in teaching and persistent problems and issues in education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Educational Psychology: Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies in physical, intellectual, emotional, social, and personality development across the lifespan with the focus on the importance of these factors to the educational process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Higher Education Law
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide students with an overview of legal issues in higher education, with an emphasis on legal developments and trends in student affairs administration in particular.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Vocational Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: A historical and contemporary analysis of systems and theories of vocational psychology and their implications for use in the counseling setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Higher Education Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: The purpose of this course is to provide an overview of finance in higher education. Current challenges related to public funding of higher education, from both the federal and state government, will be addressed in this course. Additional focus will be devoted to the structure and function of financial aid systems as well as to options for the reform of those systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Enrollment Management in Higher Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines enrollment management theories, concepts, and research and the application of these to higher education administration. Students demonstrate enrollment management strategies through the development of a comprehensive enrollment management plan for use in a college or university setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Higher Education Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Administration theory applied to the organization and administration of colleges and universities; special reference to structure, governing boards, administrative roles, decision-making, and analysis of selected problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Student Development Theory in College Student Affairs
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth examination of the major young adult and adult development models and their implications within the context of student affairs in higher education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Adaptations of generic counseling skills to meet the needs of diverse populations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Counseling Ethics
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of ethical standards developed by professional organizations of counselors. Current interpretations of standards and applications are developed through case studies, essays, reading, and literature review.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Group Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: The examination of selected group counseling theories and their relevance for the practice of group counseling in a variety of settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Group Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised group counseling experience in a variety of settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Counseling Appraisal
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced application of appraisal models and methods for use with clientele. Specific personality tests and classification systems will be addressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Counseling Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Intense supervised practice in counseling. Particular emphasis will be given to the development of skills for intervention into human problems and time-limited case management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Counseling Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Reading and analysis of primary sources in major counseling theories. Written reaction papers, presentations, discussion, and development of a major paper on a personal theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminar in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: These seminars will critically consider recent research in the designated fields. The emphasis will be upon individual studies and small group interaction.. Enrollment is restricted to those students who have been admitted to the doctoral program in education and who have completed substantial amounts of graduate study in the designated fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Counseling Supervision Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course in the theory, techniques, and problems of supervising persons being trained as counselors. Course emphasis is on actual supervisory experiences with beginning counselors. Open to advanced doctoral students only with consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of and field experiences in the development of programs in cooperating schools and educational or related agencies under the supervision of Counseling and Educational Psychology graduate faculty members. A maximum of 6 credit hours may be chosen from the areas listed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Counseling and Educational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation in the field of a student’s specialization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training to carry on the line of research undertaken.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Development
htmlparse.Course.description: An overall view of the entire school curriculum, patterns of organization, outlining of instructional fields, and specific helps in curriculum development for administrators and classroom teachers.

htmlparse.Course.title: In-Service Education for Beginning Family and Consumer Sciences Teachers
htmlparse.Course.description: For beginning teachers who desire assistance with career and technical program management, instructional planning and delivery, professional role development, and the organization of information related to career and technical family and consumer sciences teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of American Education
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of American education is explored critically through multiple perspectives. Complex forces governing changes in education are exposed–forces that are felt but unseen. By studying historical contexts, much about schooling today is seen as problematic and open to question–not as inevitable. This study pushes past a passive acceptance of the status quo via a vigorous, fresh analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of American Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophical thought in American Education is examined critically through multiple perspectives. The learning environment, the role of the learner, and the role of the teacher are issues central to analysis in the course as they manifest themselves in learning and teaching for social change and social justice. The questions of what are freedom, democracy, truth, power, and choice are central to the examination.

htmlparse.Course.title: Understanding and Teaching Reading
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundational issues in K-12 reading instruction. Focus on the reading process, the nature of the learner, the text, and the instructional setting.

htmlparse.Course.title: Approaches to Reading Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: A foundational study of research-based approaches, materials, and methods for effective K-12 reading instruction.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reading Comprehension
htmlparse.Course.description: Reviews comprehension theory and research; explores strategies for developing reading comprehension in readers. K-12; examines evaluative devices for assessing comprehension abilities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theoretical Models of Reading
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of reading with an emphasis on foundational theories and seminal research studies reflecting the complexity of the reading process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Language Arts
htmlparse.Course.description: An analysis of current methods, issues, and trends in teaching, speaking, listening, and writing through the study of significant literature and research findings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Methods in the Teaching of K-12 Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of selected topics in K-12 mathematics emphasizing new programs, trends, controversial topics, and new recommendations for persistent problems; findings of recent research stressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Social Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Current methods, materials, issues, and trends in developing social consciousness among K-12 students. Social science strategies usable by students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Family and Consumer Sciences Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of evolving trends and materials for Family and Consumer Sciences programs; application to teaching and curriculum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Issues in Teaching and Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of selected topics and contemporary issues in curriculum and instruction emphasizing new programs, trends, instructional strategies, and curricular issues. Findings of recent research are stressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Role, Organization, and Function of Community Colleges
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to give the student an overview of community colleges. Emphasis on philosophy, purposes, curriculum, organization, professional staff, student-personnel programs, and the role for the comprehensive community college in higher education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Improving Science Teaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation and implementation of psychological and philosophical foundations will be stressed in improving K-12 science teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervision of Student Teaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Organization and functions of student teaching programs; orienting, supervising, and evaluating student teachers in elementary and secondary schools.

htmlparse.Course.title: Literacy Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the collection, analysis, and interpretation of data from formal and informal assessment methods and instruments to enhance literacy instruction by documenting growth and literacy development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supporting Struggling Readers
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the identities of “struggling readers” across grade levels to address the importance of interest, motivation, gender, culture, and language on learning to read with an emphasis on differentiated instruction to support literacy development and lifelong reading.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Development in Family and Consumer Sciences
htmlparse.Course.description: The course focuses on current trends in career and technical family and consumer sciences curricula. Designed to assist family and consumer sciences teachers and supervisors in the articulation of secondary programs, analysis, and development of curriculum models for specific school situations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Directed Professional Development/Secondary
htmlparse.Course.description: Research and teaching under supervision in the secondary school. Open only to outstanding liberal arts graduates enrolled in the special program for the professional preparation of such graduates for teaching in critical areas in secondary schools.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research and Practice in Classroom Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Curriculum, educational technology, and assessment research and theory and examined and aligned with national models and standards for the integration of technology into instruction to support teacher effectiveness and student achievement. Internet access and e-mail are required. Familiarity with a web page construction kit is recommended.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Introductory educational technology course or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Online Course Design Project/e-Portfolio
htmlparse.Course.description: The portfolio as a professional development tool is developed using Association for Educational Communications and Technology standards. An online instructional design course project with assessment is developed and placed on an e-portfolio website.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to Digital Teaching and Learning Specialty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Online Course Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the use of instructional design as a theoretical basis for the design of online courses. Emphasis on course design, development, assessment, and evaluation using innovative technology, delivery models and methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Hypermedia for Educators
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines hypermedia as teaching and learning tools; also explores issues, research, and theory about learning from nonlinear media. Advanced techniques for designing hypermedia on the Web.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Science Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: National curriculum programs and projects at both elementary and secondary levels. Evaluation of appropriateness of content as it relates to a philosophy of science education. Modes for investigating scientific phenomena and their subsequent use in teaching the processes of the scientists.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Mathematics Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: Historical and current trends and influences in mathematics curriculum. Analysis of research on teaching, learning, and assessment in mathematics education.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Social Studies Curriculum in the Secondary School
htmlparse.Course.description: New trends, materials, and ideas in teaching K-12 social sciences, based on recent research and experimental programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Foreign Language Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: New trends and materials in teaching the foreign languages, based on recent research and experimental programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Language Arts Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: The changing scene in the teaching of English: trends, materials, and ideas in literature, composition, and grammar that have emerged from recent research and discovery.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Community College Curriculum and Instructional Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of community college curricula; reasons for revision, aims and objectives. Designed to familiarize student with the entire curricular offerings of the comprehensive community college.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching and Learning Models
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of ways to organize the curriculum, instructional strategies, and the teaching environment to promote learning. Various models of teaching are analyzed and critiqued.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of research or problems of current professional interest based on study of pertinent original literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proseminar I: Educational Computing, Design, and Distance Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Considers teaching and learning implications of computers in classrooms; design of learning environments; and aspects of distance education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proseminar II: Technology Change, Research, and Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Considers how learning technologies influence and support changes in the classroom and schools; research on learning with technology tools; and some of the theoretical underpinnings of the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Cognitive Issues in Educational Computing
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of cognitive issues, theories, and implications for the design of learning environments in which technology plays a key role.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Students select and prepare a project designed to improve their professional practice. It may be the construction of a professional portfolio or project to represent the student’s learning throughout the master’s degree program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: A master’s report is generally shorter than a thesis and presents the results of a more limited original investigation or a problem or topic within the student’s classroom or educational field approved by the candidate’s supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: A master’s thesis presents the results of an original investigation or a problem or topic within the student’s classroom or educational field approved by the candidate’s supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical concepts underlying significant curriculum developments. A systematic critique of current curricular theory. Consideration of model generation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multicultural Curriculum Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of multicultural curriculum principles to total school programming with particular emphasis on the cultural pluralism phenomenon. Includes analytic review of instruments on multicultural/multiracial curriculum evaluation as well as planning skills for equitable thrusts. Primarily involves elementary and secondary focus with some attention to postsecondary programming.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervision in Career and Technical Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophy and principles of effective supervision related to occupational education programs; application of principles to problems met by student teacher supervisors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership in Literacy
htmlparse.Course.description: A seminar to prepare reading professionals to work as literacy leaders, advocates, and coaches to support district and school literacy professional development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organization and Administration of Career and Technical Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of the organization of occupational education programs in agriculture, business, distributive education, health, family and consumer science, trade and industry, technical, and related fields and their administration. Emphasis on federal-state-local relationships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles of College Teaching
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of learning, learning theory, educational objectives, methods and techniques, college students, and evaluation in the classroom. Emphasis upon preservice and in-service help in improving instruction at the college level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Practicum in Reading
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised K-12 practicum with candidates working with individuals and small groups of readers using a wide range of evidence-based instructional practices, approaches, and curricular materials.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: EDCI 816, 818, 840, and 841. Prior or concurrent enrollment in EDCI 930.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Study of the Reading Process
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of selected theories of the reading process. Investigation of the interrelationships of the reading act: cognitive processes; language; social-emotional factors; and experience. Emphasis upon recent developments in the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Reading
htmlparse.Course.description: Professional field experience for candidates to demonstrate expertise by supporting reading development, analyzing building and district needs, developing action plans, and conducting related professional development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: These seminars will critically consider recent research in the designated fields. The emphasis will be upon individual studies and small group interaction. Enrollment is restricted to those students who have been admitted to the doctoral program in education and who have completed substantial amounts of graduate study in the designated fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of and field experiences in the development of programs in cooperating schools and educational or related agencies under the supervision of College of Education graduate faculty members. A maximum of 6 credit hours may be chosen from the areas listed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Curriculum and Instruction
htmlparse.Course.description: Doctoral research demonstrates the candidate’s ability to conduct significant original research related to curriculum and instruction, to analyze the information obtained from the research, and to present the results in a dissertation format appropriate to the educational field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethical Dimensions of Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: The course rests on the assumption that leadership is a subset of ethics rather than ethics being a subset of leadership. We will examine the ethics of what leaders are, what they do, and how they do it. Students will assess the public and private ethics of leaders, the ethical obligations of leaders and followers, the ways in which leaders shape the ethical environment of institutions, and the temptations of power. We will examine ethical issues related to leadership through case studies concerning leaders in a variety of contexts and cultures. The course looks at how leaders convey values through actions, language, and as role models. It aims to expand students’ ethical point of view by first considering personal ethics, then moving on to look at leadership and the common good, and finishing with an examination of ethics in learning communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical and Philosophical Analysis of Leadership in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course seeks to insure that students understand the historical and philosophical background that forms the foundation for current educational systems, offerings, and practices, with a focus on educational leadership. Students will be expected to gather information and research from both primary and secondary sources, be reflective practitioners, and apply higher level cognitive and affective skills. Abilities in writing and critical analysis will be required as students apply, analyze, synthesize, and evaluate a variety of writings regarding the history and philosophy of education in the United States, as well as international influences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Philosophy of Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical analysis of major educational philosophies with discussion of their impact on the problem of education for democracy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. Twelve hours of education and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Education Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of P-12 public school fiscal policy construction and daily operational issues, including evaluation of local, state, and federal fiscal support, tax structures, distributional formulas, finance reform strategies, and budget preparation and administration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strategic Leadership in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with an overview of educators becoming strategic leaders at the program, building, and district levels. Two central thrusts are considered: (1) professional and ethical leadership, and (2) information management and evaluation leadership. Emphasis is placed on knowledge, skills and attributes to identify contexts, developing with others vision and purpose, utilizing information, framing problems exercising leadership processes to achieve common goals, and acting ethically for educational communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political and Community Leadership in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the relationship between the school and the community, with special emphasis on the development of a comprehensive community education program. Organizational patterns, financing, program development, and interaction with other community agencies are analyzed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: One year of teaching experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Educational Facility Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the principles and processes involved in providing an appropriate physical infrastructure for P-12 education. Emphasis is placed on planning, financing, constructing, maintaining, and utilizing physical resources.

htmlparse.Course.title: Educational Law
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the legal status of educational institutions in the United States; the legal rights and responsibilities of educators including due process, tort liability, and contracts; student rights; landmark court decisions; federal and state legislation impacting on education, and resources available to assist in developing solutions to legal problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Strategies for Educational Change
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides educators with conceptual knowledge concerning the problems and processes of educational change. Case studies of change are analyzed in the attempt to develop models of educational change.

htmlparse.Course.title: The Principalship
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the principal’s role as he or she interacts with various referent groups. Applicable to both elementary and secondary administration.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: One year of teaching experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: School-Community Relations
htmlparse.Course.description: Interrelationships that exist between the school and the community and the role of the teacher and administrator in such relationships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Qualitative Research in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of theoretical and philosophical perspectives informing qualitative research is presented. In addition, methods (design, data collection, data analysis, and reporting) used in qualitative research for educational settings are examined and applied.

htmlparse.Course.title: District, Building, and Program Leadership in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with an overview of educators becoming leaders of instruction at the district, building, and program level. Four thrusts are being considered (1) instruction, (2) curriculum, (3) staff development, and (4) supervisory leadership. Considerable emphasis is placed on knowledge, skills, and attributes of learning leadership. Themes of planning, conducting, and assessing performance are covered in depth.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership for Diverse Populations
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed for educators to increase their knowledge of self and others regarding issues of diversity. An emphasis is placed on understanding the role of educators inpromoting practices and policies supportive of all stakeholders in the educational organization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Leadership in Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: This course identifies the major roles and responsibilities of school administrators in curriculum-related activities. Administrative skills necessary for developing and evaluating the curriculum will be examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Leadership in Staff Development
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focuses on the role of the administrator in developing, implementing, and evaluating staff development programs. Superintendent, building-level administrator, and staff development director leadership skills will be analyzed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administrative Leadership in Staff Supervision
htmlparse.Course.description: This course identifies the major roles and responsibilities of superintendents and building-level administrators as supervisors of staff in a K-12 school district.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technology Leadership for Administrators
htmlparse.Course.description: A course designed to provide an in-depth analysis of administrator technology leadership skills necessary for integrating technology in education. The roles and technologies of technology leadership will be studied in the context of staff development, supervision, and curriculum articulation. Considerable attention will be given to strategies necessary for creating district and building technology plans.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of a problem of current professional interest based on study of pertinent original literature.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring, Summer, on sufficient demand
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised on-the-job experience in school leadership.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research

htmlparse.Course.title: The School District Leader
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of research and practice, looking at the role of the school superintendent through the standards for School Leaders, as developed by the Interstate School Leaders Licensure Consortium (ISLLC) and adapted by the state of Kansas for licensure requirements for the district leadership license.
