Emphasis is placed on leading school improvement efforts, and forming and sustaining purposeful learning communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: District Leader Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Satisfies the internship requirement for the district leadership license recommendation. Students are required to document a minimum 150 clock hours guided field experience through a formal internship and other coursework (i.e., additional internship requirements beyond EDLEA 902 are also imbedded in many courses in the licensure sequence to assist in reaching the 150 clock hour requirement).

htmlparse.Course.title: Educational Human Resource Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Human resource administration practices in education are considered along with the implications of collective negotiations and professional accountability for human resource policies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizational Leadership in Education
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is an examination of the knowledge, skills, and attributes necessary to understand and improve organizations. It includes leadership theory, implementing plans, managing resources, and applying appropriate processes and procedures in varied educational settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced School Business Management
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course in school finance policy and budgeting practices, with particular consideration for hands-on application to school district leadership in Kansas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminars in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: These seminars will critically consider recent research in the designated fields. The emphasis will be upon individual studies and small group interaction. Enrollment is restricted to those students who have been admitted to the doctoral program in education and who have completed substantial amounts of graduate study in the designated fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Doctoral Internship in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of and field experiences in the development of programs in cooperating schools and educational or related agencies under the supervision of Educational Leadership graduate faculty members.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Educational Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation in the field of a student’s specialization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Assessment in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of assessment procedures used in the pre-referral, identification, and instructional phases of program planning for students with special needs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Special Education Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of administrative units for special education, placement procedures, federal and state legislation, and program reimbursement and funding.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interventions: Functional Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Curriculum content, methods, and organization of educational programs for children and youth with functional special education needs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Education in Secondary Schools
htmlparse.Course.description: Educational perspectives in service delivery options, educational planning, general instructional approaches, learning strategies, and adaptations and modifications of instructional materials and settings for the secondary student in special education.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Education Programming: Parental Involvement
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth consideration of the role of home and parents in the educational programming for exceptional children. Emphasis on practical and positive strategies used in working with parents.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interventions: Early Childhood Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Strategies, policies, and procedures for the education of young children (0-5 years of age) with disabilities. Areas of emphasis include Individual Service Plans, interagency collaboration, and specific strategies for parents and young children.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods and Materials for Learners who are Gifted
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories and strategies for differentiating the curriculum for gifted students, emphasis on appropriate methods and materials.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transitions in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of transition models, curricula, assessment, career development, community resources and agencies, and materials.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interventions: Autism Spectrum Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Assessment, curriculum content, educational considerations, interventions, and organization of programs for children and youth with Autism Spectrum Disorders.

htmlparse.Course.title: College Students with Special Needs
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to familiarize academic advisors with the increasing number of students with disabilities who now attend our institutions of higher education. The course will examine the legal foundations for students with disabilities in higher education, provide a framework for understanding the unique needs of students with learning disabilities, attention deficit disorders, mental health issues, as well as those on the autism spectrum, and examine the role of academic advisors in helping these individuals be successful thriving college students.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Education of Individuals with Functional Special Education Needs
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and participation in teaching individuals with functional special educational needs under the supervision of selected teachers in Special Education programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of research or problems of current professional interest based on study of pertinent original literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Externship in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: The course provides a forum for self-directed development of competencies in Special Education. Students conduct self-assessment and develop strategies for ongoing professional development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Practicum: Autism Spectrum Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation and participation in teaching individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorders under the supervision of selected teachers in Special Education programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seminar in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: These seminars will critically consider recent research in the designated fields. The emphasis will be upon individual studies and small group interaction. Enrollment is restricted to those students who have been admitted to the doctoral program in education and who have completed substantial amounts of graduate study in the designated fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies of and field experiences in the development of programs in cooperating schools and educational or related agencies under the supervision of College of Education graduate faculty members. A maximum of 6 credit hours may be chosen from the areas listed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Special Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation in the field of a student’s specialization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training to carry on the line of research undertaken.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Studies in English
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the methods and aims of advanced level research and scholarship in language and literature. Taken in the first year of study toward the M. A. in English as an orientation to the profession.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Teaching University Expository Writing
htmlparse.Course.description: Required of GTAs teaching Expository Writing in the English Department. Instruction in the theory and practice of teaching in a university expository writing program. Cannot count in the student’s program of study.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: graduate status and a GTAship in the English Department.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with different content. Cr/No Cr.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Language
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive research concerned with one or more topics in the structure and history of the English language.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Literature
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive research concerned with one or more literary genres, periods, authors, or issues/problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Cultural Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive research concerned with one or more topics central to the theory and practice of Cultural Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Composition and Rhetoric
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive research on materials germane to the history, structure, and processes central to the concerns of Composition and Rhetoric.

htmlparse.Course.title: Workshop in Playwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of drama.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ENGL 762 (or THTRE 762) or proof of equiv. Proficiency.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in English
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in English
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Permission, Director of Graduate Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insects of Stored Products
htmlparse.Course.description: Biology, ecology, and behavior of stored-product insects and current practices involved in their control.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ENTOM 300, or 312 and 313, or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experience in Extension Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Major emphasis is to give students a realistic view of the history, structure, philosophy, and position responsibilities assumed by entomology state and area specialists within the Cooperative Extension Service through hands-on experience.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biological Control
htmlparse.Course.description: The theory and practice of biological control with an emphasis on natural enemies of insect pests. Relationship and importance of insect ecology and integrated pest management to biological control. Experimental approaches, evaluation, recognition and life histories of beneficial species will be covered.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: ENTOM 300 or 312 or 320 or a college-level ecology course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture and two hours of lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Integrative Behavioral Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide an advanced overview of the genetics, ecology, and evolution of insect behavior, emphasizing research done in insect systems. The topics covered in this course will include: (1) Conceptual and empirical framework for studying behavior, (2) the genetics of behavior, (3) “kinds” of behaviors, and (4) detailed examples of each “kind” of behavior.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to use of molecular techniques to address fundamental and applies entomological problems, including systematics, marker-assisted selection of resistant genotypes of plants, mechanisms of insecticide resistance, insect transgenesis, risk assessment of genetically modified organisms, and other topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One 2-hour lec./ discussion per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant-Virus-Vector Interactions
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of modes of virus transmission, important arthropod vectors, plant responses to viruses and insects, and current literature and techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: one of the following: BIOCH 521, BIOCH 522, ENTOM 830, ENTOM 875, or PLPTH 500.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Immature Insects
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification of immature insects to the family level, with emphasis on terrestrial Holometabola and aquatic insects. Techniques for collecting and preserving immatures, with an emphasis on field collecting and identification in laboratory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Chemical Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: The overall objective of this course is to familiarize the student with the interactions among organisms, including insects and other arthropods, which are mediated by naturally produced chemicals.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: CHEM 350 General Organic Chemistry or its equivalent, or the consent of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biology of Disease Vectors of Human and Veterinary Importance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course focus will be vectors of medical and veterinary importance. Students will learn several underlying aspects involved in pathogen-vector-vertebrate host interactions, including those associated with cellular, molecular and innate immune response of insects to pathogens they transmit. Students will be introduced to current research programs and topics of interest in the field of medical entomology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: BIOL 198, ENTOM 312, and BIOL 450.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lec a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Scanning Electron Microscopy
htmlparse.Course.description: Use of scanning electron miscroscopy for studying organic, inorganic or synthetic materials. Includes theory of SEM operation, techniques for specimen preparation, one-on-one sessions with a technician on a Hitachi 3500N variable pressure SEM, and post-image processing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Toxicology of Insecticides
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of synthetic and naturally occurring insecticides with emphasis on distribution and elimination, metabolism, mechanism of action, resistance mechanisms, and current advances in new insecticide discovery and new approaches to insect control. The lab focuses on providing hands-on experience with techniques frequently used by toxicologists.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: CHM 350, or BIOCH 521, or ENTOM 620.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours of lecture and one 3-hour lab each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Morphology
htmlparse.Course.description: Morphology of insects with emphasis on the evolution and functional complexes of structures. Anatomy and structure of internal systems using microdissections and histol-ogical techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two one-hours lec., one three-hour lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Functions of insect systems for development, metamorphosis, and reproduction. Physiological and biochemical mechanisms underlying insect activities, behavior, and ecological adaptations.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture and one hour discussion a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conventional and Molecular Methods for Evaluation of Crop Plant Resistance to Pests
htmlparse.Course.description: A series of laboratories illustrating different modes of plant resistance to pests, quantification of resistance effects, resistance gene flow, plant DNA isolation & quantification, and molecular marker-assisted selection of resistance genes of interest. Students develop hands-on experience using both conventional and molecular techniques to identify and quantify genetic plant resistance to pests.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ENTOM/PLPTH 635 and ENTOM 745 or PLPTH 755.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Controversies in Insect Ecology
htmlparse.Course.description: Alternative and conflicting approaches to, interpretations, and applications of principles of insect ecology. Examination of history, assumptions, and experiments behind these controversies. Special attention to impact of these conflicts on insect pest management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: BIOL 529 or ENTOM 692 or a college-level ecology course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec./discussion per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report in Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Work in various fields of entomology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: For student majoring in entomology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Knowledge in special area and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Insect Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will initially describe the variety of genetic systems found in insects. Laboratory and statistical techniques will be discussed for studying genetic variation in insect populations. The final part of the course will focus on means for genetic manipulation of populations. The laboratory session will be used to discuss and/or demonstrate techniques for studying insect genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: 2 hours lecture and one 3-hour lab each week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Environmental and Physiological Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics for advanced study in insect behavior, biomechanics ecology, genetics, physiology, and related areas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in General and Systematic Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of taxonomy; advanced taxonomy; taxonomy of immature insects; acarology; biological literature; and teaching experience.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ENTOM 710 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conceptual Issues in Evolution
htmlparse.Course.description: This is an advanced lecture and discussion course in evolution. The topics covered include controversial and unresolved issues in evolution such as adaptation, evolution of sex, natural selection, neutral theory, parent-offspring conflict, kin selection, group selection, reciprocal altruism and cooperation, etc. Students will be exposed to primary and current literature as well as classic papers in evolution. Active student participation during discussions is expected and encouraged.

htmlparse.Course.title: Entomology Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Entomology Seminar
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consult seminar committee. Pass/fail grade only.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Entomology
htmlparse.Course.description: Dissertation credit for students majoring in entomology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Knowledge in special area and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Environmental Design & Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is intended to provide students an opportunity to focus on specific problems in environmental design and planning under the guidance of a member of the college’s graduate faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conceptual Approaches to Design and Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of contributions and limitations of various theoretical perspectives that inform the field of design and planning inquiry. Knowledge and theory construction. Nature, scope, and merits of scientific approach. Criticism of the scientific approach and examination of alternative approaches utilized in design and planning research and practice. Linking philosophy, research, and action/practice/application.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Design and Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of research methods in the fields of design and planning, including overall systems of inquiry, criteria for assessing quality, strategies and tactics. Strengths and weaknesses of various research designs. Methods covered include experimental and quasi-experimental research, correlational research, qualitative research strategies, simulation and modeling research, action research and design intervention, case study, and combined strategies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: For students who have completed all credit hour, full-time enrollment, preliminary examination, and residency requirements for the doctoral degree, and are writing and defending their dissertations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fermented Foods
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of the principles of microbiology to the understanding of the fermentation of various categories of foods. Chemical, biochemical and microbiological changes under controlled and uncontrolled conditions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: *Great Plains IDEA course

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Fermentation
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of the principles of microbiology to the understanding of the fermentation of various categories of foods. Chemical, biochemical and microbiological changes under controlled and uncontrolled conditions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Food Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: Relationship of chemical composition to properties and to physical and chemical stability of foods. Chemical reactions will be covered extensively. Special attention will be given to dairy and poultry products, red meats, vegetables, and cereal grains.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Food Microbiology & Biotechnology
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of food biotechnology, including introduction of molecular biology and enzyme immobilization. Theory and concepts of current biotechnology trends as it relates to food safety and security issues.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: A course in food microbiology or general microbiology, and a course in biochemistry
htmlparse.Course.notes: *Great Plains IDEA course

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an international, state, local, or district health agency or other appropriate health agency.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor. DMP 840, HN 840, and KIN 840.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once, but only 6 hours may be applied toward the MPH degree/program of study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Science Graduate Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide students with experience in developing and delivering a scholarly presentation on a specific topic. The course will include instruction on how to properly design technical presentations for effective communication. Students will learn how to use visual aids such as transparencies, slides and multimedia projectors. At least one technical presentation will be required. One credit required for an M.S. degree and 2 credits for a Ph.D. Degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report in Food Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A written report of either research or problem work on a topic in the major field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in Food Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Research leading to the completion of a master’s thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Dispersions
htmlparse.Course.description: Laws and theorems applied to the formation, mechanization and stabilization of food dispersions: properties of food dispersions; food solids, gels, batters, emulsions and foams.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Toxicology
htmlparse.Course.description: This course deals with the study of occurrence, detection, and control of microbial toxins and chemical toxins in fresh and processed foods. The genetics, physiology, and mechanisms of toxin production by microbial cells and the chemistry, formation, and interactions of chemical toxins with food systems during food processing will be addressed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Problem in Food Science
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth study of a topic supervised by a member of the graduate faculty.

htmlparse.Course.title: Doctoral Research in Food Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Research leading to the completion of a Ph.D. Degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Corporate Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced financial concepts and tools with emphasis on corporate valuation. Topics include risk and return, valuation techniques, capital budgeting, capital structure, options and futures, real options, and financial risk management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced International Financial Management
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the international dimensions of corporate financial management with an applied orientation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Market Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Development and analysis of conceptual framework for understanding (1) the functions performed by financial markets and their associated institutional arrangements, and (2) the contractual claims in transferring savings among business, household, and government participants in the economic system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FINAN 815 or FINAN 450 and ACCTG 433.

htmlparse.Course.title: Entrepreneurial Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide potential entrepreneurs a sufficient knowledge of applied finance needed to start and run an entrepreneurial business. Concepts covered will include the basic paradigms of finance such as risk and portfolio diversification. Discussions of the accounting environment of a small business and how the financial conditions can be analyzed will also be included. Finally, the course will focus on the financial skills a beginning entrepreneur will need to know to operate a small business, such as valuation, short-term capital management, financing decisions, and the exit strategies available to such enterprises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth study of selected contemporary issues in finance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems in Finance
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of selected advanced topic(s) in finance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: A written report of either research or problem work on a topic in the major field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Modern Languages

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Family Studies and Human Services Graduate Program
htmlparse.Course.description: Orientation for graduate students in FSHS. Assists with acclimating students to FSHS graduate study, emphasizing the importance of setting professional goals, identifying and utilizing resources for successful completion of graduate degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grant Development and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduces students to the grant development process and provides an overview of what happens after a grant is awarded. Topics include: identifying funding sources, generating fundable ideas, assessing needs, project planning, budget design, evaluation and project management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Brief Solution-Focused Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of Brief Solution-Focused Therapy which is a core model of therapy that can be used when students begin practicum the following semester. Students practice this therapeutic approach in role-play settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Methods in Family Studies and Human Services I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introductory course in the use of statistics in family and human services research. Examines the use of statistical methods from basic descriptive and univariate measures to multivariate measures including ANOVA and Multiple Regression Analyses as they are used in family and human services research. Emphasis is placed on the analytical and applied aspects of the statistical procedures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Child Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Behavioral characteristics and developmental processes in childhood and adolescence. Analysis of developmental trends and issues in terms of research evidence and theoretical expectations.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 310; and 3 additional hours in FSHS or child psychology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Infant Behavior and Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the infant as a developing individual within the family; examination of the theories and research relevant to development from conception through the second year.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Human Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Theories of development relating to physical, social, and psychological patterns of individuals’ growth and interaction with the family and the community.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 310; and three additional hours in FSHS or child psychology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Transition to Adulthood
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of theory, research and practice issues related to the transition period from adolescence to adulthood.

htmlparse.Course.title: Personal Integration
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of classic marriage and family therapy theories as they inform the professional identity and practice of the therapist. Students write capstone paper on selective use of research and theory.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 852, FSHS 853, FSHS 870, six hours of FSHS 885.

htmlparse.Course.title: Parent-Child Interaction: Theory and Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Developmental theories and empirical research concerning the reciprocal interactions between parents and their children focusing on the socialization of the child within the family.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Resource Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of current personal finance and family resource management literature to provide an overview of current consumer finance research from multiple perspectives.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Program Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the process and application of child development theory to early childhood program planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Practices in Family Financial Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Challenges of managing family financial planning practices including, but not limited to: business valuation, personnel, marketing, client services, ethics and technological applications. Relying both on theoretical as well as an applied approach, students will analyze case studies that provide relevant, practical exposure to practice management issues, with a strong emphasis on current research findings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Planning Case Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: This course examines professional issues in financial planning, including ethical considerations, regulation and certification requirements, communication skills, and professional responsibility. Students are expected to utilize skills obtained in other courses and work experiences in the completion of personal finance case studies, the development of a targeted investment policy, and other related financial planning assignments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Acquired Language and Cognitive Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of acquired language and cognitive-communicative disorders in adults. Content addresses research and applied knowledge concerning etiologies, evaluation, and treatment of aphasia and communication deficits that result from right hemisphere damage, dementia, and traumatic brain injury.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dysphagia
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of normal and abnormal swallowing in children and adults. Procedures for assessment, diagnosis, and intervention are explored.

htmlparse.Course.title: Adult Development and Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: Developmental aging research as related to individual, social, and family functioning throughout adulthood.

htmlparse.Course.title: Externship in Speech-Language Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Clinical practicum in off-campus sites, including supervised experience in evaluation and treatment of children and adults with communication disorders.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 705 and consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Topics in Communication Sciences and Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical review of recent research related to measurement and modification of speech, hearing, or language deficits.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 560, graduate standing, and consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hours with change in topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of family research literature to illustrate various approaches to the study of the family and to understand family changes within the life cycle.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Issues in Speech-Language Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of current professional issues in speech-language pathology. Primary topics include professional and ethical practices, scope of practice and service delivery, preparation for employment, and credentialing. Because this is a capstone course, the student must be within three semesters/terms of the graduate degree.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 705 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Family Theories
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of contemporary family conceptual frameworks and theoretical perspectives, with emphasis on the application of family theory in basic and applied family research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Systems in Cultural Context
htmlparse.Course.description: Helps students integrate an understanding of individuals, couples, and families within the context of culture. Helps participants to listen and respond in a thoughtful and sensitive manner to the individuals and families they serve professionally, especially those from diverse cultural backgrounds. Students will become more aware of their own cultural memberships, and develop a framework for appreciating the cultural context of the profession of family therapy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to the MFT program and/or instructor’s consent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Crisis
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature of stress in the family from a theoretical and research base, focusing on the genesis of family crisis and the family’s response to stress and crisis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Policy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the development, formation, implementation, and application of policy issues related to the family issues and social problems. Emphasis placed on how policy is made and how professionals can influence policy issues and outcomes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interpersonal Relationships
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth examination of interpersonal relationships, including theoretical perspectives, research methods, relationship forms, relationship processes, and how context affects relationships.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 350 and 550 or consent of instructor

htmlparse.Course.title: Single-Parent and Reconstituted Families
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of research literature regarding single-parent and reconstituted families. Demography, complexity, problems, strengths, and processes of adjustment of family units and their members. Implications for professionals working with these families.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Theory and Practice
htmlparse.Course.description: The body of theoretical content underlying the clinical practice of marriage and family therapy is surrounded in systems theory. This course is designed to introduce the student to the foundation of family therapy and provide a survey of the major schools of family therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Sexuality
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus on implications of personal and familial aspects of human sexuality throughout the life cycle.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 350 and six hours social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sex Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: A focus on the framework and skills for delivering therapy to individuals and couples experiencing difficulties with their own sexuality or with sexual functioning in their relationships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Practicum in Marriage and Family Therapy I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to master’s program in marriage and family therapy, including clinic policies and clinical observations. Restricted to students admitted to the marriage and family therapy program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Concurrent enrollment in FSHS 853 and FSHS 878.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pre-Practicum in Marriage and Family Therapy II
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation for screening into the clinical practicum in marriage and family therapy and participation in clinic research program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 867 and concurrent enrollment in FSHS 870.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systematic Treatment of Domestic Violence and Substance Abuse
htmlparse.Course.description: Framework and skills for helping individuals and families experiencing domestic violence and/or substance abuse with emphasis on assessment and treatment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to the MFT program and/or instructor consent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Couples and Sex Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of couple processes and clinical approaches to couple intervention and treatment, including evidence based approaches. The course will include a specific focus on contextual and systemic dynamics affecting couple relationships as well as the treatment of couples experiencing difficulties with their own sexuality or with sexual functioning in their relationships.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Life Education Foundation and Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Understanding of the field of Family Life Education, including professional responsibilities for working effectively with individuals and families in preventative, educational, outreach or consultative settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of the primary theories of Marriage and Family Therapy which are used in the treatment of whole families who present themselves for therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Individual and Family Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Assessment of individual and family functioning within multiple contexts; including an emphasis on client focused progress monitoring.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Studies in Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of professional issues, techniques, and responsibilities associated with working effectively with families in a family therapy setting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 864 or concurrent enrollment and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Systemic Assessment and Treatment of Psychopathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. Exploration of relational diagnoses and the interaction of individual disorders and relational functioning. Review of empirically supported treatments for individual and relational disorders.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in providing help and/or instruction in the several areas of human development and family studies presented in terms of the special interests of the students. Consent of practicum supervisor is required for each.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Family and Community Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in providing help and/or instruction in the several areas of human development and family studies presented in terms of the special interests of the students. Consent of practicum supervisor is required for each.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Study of Student Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in providing help and/or instruction in the several areas of human development and family studies presented in terms of the special interests of the students. Consent of practicum supervisor is required for each.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Early Childhood Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in providing help and/or instruction in the several areas of human development and family studies presented in terms of the special interests of the students. Consent of practicum supervisor is required for each.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Parent Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in providing help and/or instruction in the several areas of human development and family studies presented in terms of the special interests of the students. Consent of practicum supervisor is required for each.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Marriage and Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in marriage and family therapy. Designed for master’s level students.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 870; FSHS 878 and admission to marriage and family therapy program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Children and Families
htmlparse.Course.description: The course will examine the history of play therapy including the theories from which play therapy evolved, attachment theory, the fundamentals of play therapy, use of assessment with children and adolescents, sand tray play therapy, use of play therapy in the family context and special topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in FSHS I
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and application of family and human developmental methodology for research in graduate programs and professional careers.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of clinical work and course work resulting in a final clinical project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in FSHS II
htmlparse.Course.description: Intermediate level course with a focus on the applied aspects of family and human developmental research. Emphasis on applied quantitative and qualitative methodologies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. FSHS 888 and any upper division or graduate level statistics courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Family Survey Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and techniques for collection, coding, analysis, and interpretation of survey data from several family members. Computer-oriented.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Human Development Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Observation, modification, and reporting of behavior.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 890; course in methods of research; 9 other graduate hours in family studies and human services; consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Program Evaluation in Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and application of program evaluation approaches and methodology pertinent to evaluating programs in human service and education settings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 890 or another graduate level social sciences research course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Implications of research findings in preparation for professional work in counseling, teaching, and research in human development and family studies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Twelve hours in social-behavioral science; and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for a maximum of 9 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Principles and Techniques of Family Measurement
htmlparse.Course.description: The comparative reliability and validity of current measures of family interaction and analysis of their suitability for use in program evaluation of family life education and family therapy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 850 and a graduate-level research methods course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of care management issues and literature related to the application of advanced techniques in family therapy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 870 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: To be taken concurrently with FSHS 885.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Communication Sciences and Disorders
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced course providing critical analysis of recent theory and research in a designated topic area.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 560 and consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with a change in subject matter.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional and Ethical Issues in Family Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Capstone course for the master’s level. Emphasizes the research-theory-practice connection. Includes cutting-edge issues in the field, ethics and professional development.

htmlparse.Course.title: MS Research in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research problems which may form the basis for the master’s thesis or report.

htmlparse.Course.title: Qualitative Research Methods in FSHS
htmlparse.Course.description: Expands students’ skills in theories and methods associated with qualitative research. Emphasis on understanding foundations of qualitative methods, comparing and using various qualitative traditions and applying this knowledge to a research project.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Methods in Family Studies and Human Services II
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced applied statistics course designed for graduate students with a foundation and understanding of basic and multivariable statistics. Examines multiple variable analyses including log-linear, discriminate analyses, OLS and logistic regression and the issues involved using these techniques; principal component and factor analyses; path analyses; structural equation modeling; hierarchical linear and nonlinear modeling; and growth curve modeling.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Family Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical review and analysis of contemporary analysis techniques in family research, dealing with multiple members of family-like groups, including a variety of mixed model methodologies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 806, 888, 890, 906 or equivalent graduate level research or statistics courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Family Life Education and Consultation
htmlparse.Course.description: Recent research, theory construction, and program development; focusing on selected relevant topics. Designed for doctoral students in family life education and consultation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Personal Financial Planning
htmlparse.Course.description: Recent research, theory construction, and program development in personal financial planning, which will focus on selected relevant topics. Designed for doctoral students in personal financial planning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Marriage and Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of recent research, theory, and clinical practice related to marriage and family therapy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 870 and consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken up to 9 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Human Development Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of the continuous and systematic changes in the development of individuals as they interact with their physical and social environments.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for a maximum of 12 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Family Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of theoretical approaches to the study of the family unit from the perspective of interpersonal relationships. Emphasis on axiomatic theory construction in contemporary family studies literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Specialization in MFT
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar focusing on th development of a clinical specialty area in marriage and family therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Professional Issues in FSHS
htmlparse.Course.description: Capstone course for PhD students. Examines expectations and responsibilities of working in academia or other PhD-level professional positions: submitting and reviewing scholarly publications and presentations, serving as an expert witness, professional ethics, etc.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Completed at least 24 graduate credits.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Practicum in Family and Community Services
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in family life education and consultation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 871, 875, 881, and consent of instructor; may be taken for a maximum of 6 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marriage and Family Therapy Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of psychotherapy research in general and family therapy process and outcome research in particular. Covers a variety of approaches to clinical research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 870 and a graduate-level research methods course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervision of Marriage and Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Preparation of experienced marriage and family therapists for supervision roles within educational, medical and agency settings. Must be concurrently enrolled in FSHS 986 (Practicum in Supervision).

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Practicum in Marriage and Family
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in family therapy.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 880. May be taken for up to 9 hours.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Consent of instructor is required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Supervision of Marriage and Family Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience in supervision of marital and family therapy.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken for up to 9 hours. Consent of instructor is required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Clinical Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of marriage and family therapy clinical theories and the process of integrating these theories into a personalized model for utilization in both therapy and supervision.

htmlparse.Course.title: Conjoint and Group Techniques in Family Counseling
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced theory in marriage and family counseling with emphasis on group techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: FSHS 885 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Proposal Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation and discussion of proposals for dissertation research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Six hours of statistics, 3 hours of research design or methods, and consent of major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Family Studies and Human Services
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Research in Family Studies and Human Services

htmlparse.Course.title: Managing Occupational and Agricultural Safety and Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines program management and leadership issues in occupational and agricultural safety and health. Topics include business aspects of safety and health, management functions, workforce involvement, program development, motivation and leadership, program evaluation, ethics of safety and health, responding to the needs of a diverse workforce, and innovative program management for changing economic and societal contexts.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This is a distance course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Capstone for Agricultural Resources and Environmental Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Interdisciplinary, international application of agro-ecologic, economic, social science, and sustainability concepts and methods to important agricultural, natural resources and environmental management issues in Kansas, U.S., and other countries.

htmlparse.Course.title: MBA Professional Development
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will require the student to work with the director of the MBA program to outline a professional development program of 45 hours per hour of credit to enhance their MBA studies and to enhance their professional career.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to the MBA program.

htmlparse.Course.title: MBA International Business Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will consist of a faculty-led international experience designed to expose students to international business practices and culture.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to the MBA program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Strategy
htmlparse.Course.description: Through case analysis, a study of the functions, responsibilities, and point of view of general management and the problems which affect the total organization’s characters and success. The formulation and application of corporate and business strategies, specifically, analysis of interrelationships between the external and internal environments, choice of purpose, molding of organizational character, definition of what needs to be done, and motivation of resources for goal attainment.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810, FINAN 815, MKTG 810, MANGT 810, MANGT 820, MANGT 830, ECON 815, and STAT 702.

htmlparse.Course.title: Business Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: The analysis of business problems, using knowledge and tools from previous courses. Students, under the supervision of a team of faculty, will analyze actual business case problems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 860, FINAN 815, GENBA 880 and MKTG 810.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Business
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and analysis of current issues in business such as accounting, management, finance, marketing, etc.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Attendance of presentations and discussion of research procedures, results and philosophies. Required of all geography graduate students in residence.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geocomputation
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the application of computationally-intensive approaches to the study of complex spatio-temporal problems. Students will learn to simulate, model, analyze, and visualize geographic phenomena that do not lend themselves to other mathematical and statistical methods.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Enrolling students are strongly encouraged to have a strong background in GIS (e.g. GEOG 508 and GEOG 708) and familiarity with traditional statistical methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rural Population Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the population dynamics responsible for regional change in rural areas of the United States. Emphasis is placed on migration systems and changing population composition in Appalachia, Great Plains, rural South, and the Midwest.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 702 or GEOG 700 or equiv., and GEOG 715 or SOCIO 830.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geographic Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: History of geographic thought from ancient to modern times, emphasizing major themes and significant individual contributions.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required for all Master’s students in geography.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geographic Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: The nature of geographic research and the processes involved in its structuring, development, and articulation. Each student will produce and present a research proposal. Required of all Master’s degree students in geography.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Rural Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of rural geography concepts and research. Examines social, economic, cultural and environmental issues for rural areas and small towns, including natural resources and stresses and concerns related to sustainability of rural livelihoods and communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Sustainability Science, Thought, and Approaches
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of scientific, social, and philosophical aspects of sustainability, including concepts, approaches, and decision-making. Environmental, economic, and social considerations will be included.

htmlparse.Course.title: Rural Economic Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Applications of regional and community development models in rural areas of North America. Emphasis is placed on case studies of locational relationships between regional economic profiles, including changes in structure, and indices of betterment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Ecology of Land Cover Change
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to political ecology, concentrating on land use and land cover change.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: at least 6 hours in social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Environmental Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of post-European settlement land use and climate changes and their impact on rural landform stability. Emphasis is on the response of uplands and river systems to land use and climate change and the techniques for documenting historical landform change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Environmental Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Environmental Geography

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Cultural Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the development and distribution of the rural cultural landscapes, focusing particularly on elements of the material landscape. Emphasis placed upon research conducted in the Great Plains.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Economic Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Economic Geography

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Medical Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasizing the pattern of social and environmental conditions on health and disease, this course examines medical care systems and health issues in rural areas of both developed and developing countries.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Human Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Human Geography

htmlparse.Course.title: Spatial Data Analysis and Modeling
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of statistical techniques and models for analyzing spatial data, including global and local measures of spatial association, spatial cluster analysis, spatial autoregressive and geostatistical models, and geographically weighted regression (GWR).
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: GEOG 508 and GEOG 700 or equivalents.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Spatial Analysis Techniques
htmlparse.Course.description: Integration of spatial analysis techniques and models with tools such as Geographical Information Systems and Remote Sensing as applied to rural resource systems. Explores strategies for adaptation of various types of spatial models into the GIS framework. Sources of data for analysis will be considered with special emphasis placed on use of remotely sensed data.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: GEOG 705 and 708; GEOG 700 or STAT 702.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Spatial Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent advanced study of a selected topic. An example is the use of remote sensing and GIS in environmental modeling.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: For students enrolled in geography option B.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Registration in Graduate School, with sufficient training to carry on the line of research undertaken. Consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: For student enrolled in geography option A.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Registration in the Graduate School, with sufficient training to carry on the line of research undertaken. Consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods, Theory, and Models in Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of contemporary methodology of geographic explanation showing their development, current status and future trends. Examination of problems and techniques of design, data collection, analysis, and interpretation which accompany particular research themes.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: M.A. and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Problems in Rural Geography
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual study and research for students admitted to doctoral standing in the graduate school.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: M.A. and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Dissertation Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in geology, geochemistry, and geophysics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Paleobiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Detailed study of the functional morphology, ecology, biogeography, evolution, and classification of selected groups.

htmlparse.Course.title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected problems in the petrogenesis of igneous and metamorphic rocks.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
htmlparse.Course.description: Field and laboratory study of selected problems in the origin of igneous and metamorphic rocks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sedimentary Petrology
htmlparse.Course.description: Petrography, classification, and origin of terrigenous and chemical sedimentary rocks.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Sedimentary Petrology
htmlparse.Course.description: Field and laboratory study of selected problems in the origin of sedimentary rocks.

htmlparse.Course.title: Isotope Geology
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles, techniques, and applications of natural radioactive isotopes to geochronology; application of isotopes to problems of petrogenesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: GEOL 608 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geotectonics
htmlparse.Course.description: Origin and history of major tectonic elements of the earth, especially their interaction through time.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seismic Data Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of seismic data analysis and the application of industrial software package(s) to convert data from seismic arrays into a form useful for geophysical interpretation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seismic Data Interpretation
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of seismic data interpretation and the application of industrial software package(s) to convert processed data into 3D and 4D (time lapse) visualizations of subsurface geological features.

htmlparse.Course.title: Planetology
htmlparse.Course.description: Geologic principles applied to a study of the solar system.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: GEOL 530, 712, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Groundwater Contaminant Remediation
htmlparse.Course.description: Identification and mensuration of groundwater contaminants and consideration of means for their remediation strategies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Biogeochemistry of Soils and Sediments
htmlparse.Course.description: Review and discussion of current understanding of the chemical, biological, and mineralogical interactions of groundwater, soils, shallow and deep sediments. This course will deal with biotic controls on chemistry of the environment [and] with the geochemical control of the structure and function of ecosystems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clay Mineralogy
htmlparse.Course.description: Geologic occurrences, physical properties, atomic structures, and the identification of clay minerals, including thermal analytical methods and the study of X-ray diffraction patterns.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Seismology
htmlparse.Course.description: Mechanics of faulting and earthquakes; seismotectonics; advanced data analysis; seismic wave propagation in three-dimensionally inhomogeneous media; earthquake prediction and hazard analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour rec. and four hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Research or practice of geology summarized in a scholarly report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Enrollment in geology option B and permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in geology culminating in a master’s thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Enrollment in geology option A and permission of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Geology, PhD
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Geology, PhD

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the key issues in the theory, research, and application of leadership in organizations. This includes defining leadership, understanding situational characteristics that facilitate / hinder effective leadership, understanding effective / dysfunctional leadership, and gaining greater insight into one’s own leadership style and functioning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Leadership Practicum
htmlparse.Course.description: Develops the connections between leadership theory and practice. By conducting a practicum project, students demonstrate the ability to apply concepts and ideas from the study of leadership to a practical leadership problem within an organization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Homeland Security
htmlparse.Course.description: This introductory course provides the foundational framework for the Homeland Security program and surveys the major policies, practices, concepts, and challenges confronting practitioners in Homeland Security. Topics include an overview of threats to homeland security and an introduction to the roles, functions, and policies of organizations and government structures at the federal, tribal, state, and local levels. The National Response Framework (NRF) and National Incident Management System (NIMS) are studied.

htmlparse.Course.title: Homeland Security Threats
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will understand the various types of disasters, methodologies of disaster recovery, and roles and responsibilities of Federal, State, and local government. It will address the impact of disasters, including acts of terrorism, to include economic, physical, emotional, and psychological effects. Students will understand how disasters affect society, risk mitigation strategies, and how the levels of government coordinate to address disaster impacts.

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizations Amid Crisis
htmlparse.Course.description: The fundamental concepts and subject areas necessary for an organization to address in preparing for catastrophic emergency events and other events encountered by organizations as a result of homeland security are examined. It outlines the organization and practical steps required to develop an effective crisis response plan. The relationships between private and public service organizations, including governmental, nonprofit, and hybrid types are studied.

htmlparse.Course.title: Homeland Security Process and Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will understand strategic, political, legal, and organizational challenges associated with the defense of the U.S. homeland, efforts that are under way to meet these challenges, and possible policy options. Intergovernmental responsibilities and relationships of local, state, and federal agencies in an “all-hazards” approach to disasters are emphasized. Major policy and regulatory issues of emergency management, including the role of the military in response to disaster operations, are examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: A written report of either research or problem work on a topic in the major field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Modern Languages

htmlparse.Course.title: Particle Technology for Solids Handling and Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to provide students an overview of particle technology with an emphasis on practical applications in milling and grain based operations. Conveying, storage, size reduction and separation are the important unit operations of grain processing (food, feed, chemical, pharmaceutical) industries that involve particle sizes ranging from a fraction of a micron to a few millimeters. The particle characteristics as they relate to processing operations such as milling, sieving, mixing, pelleting, etc. will be covered in this course. Subjects include size and shape characterization, size distribution and measurement, characteristic dimensions, density, and their theories governing the behavior of the particles under different conditions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate student status, MATH 220, STAT 325, PHYS 213 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Fundamentals of Processing Grains for Food
htmlparse.Course.description: Unit processes in the receiving and storing of grains; grinding, sifting, mixing, separation, conveying, cooling, drying, etc. This course is not open to undergraduate majors in the department.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and three hours laboratory a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Extrusion Processing
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of the engineering principles of extrusion forming and cooking with a detailed focus on scale-up. A variety of extrusion systems will be studied in lab with associated group projects.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: GRSC 620 or previous extrusion experience.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hrs. lecture and three hrs. laboratory a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Novel Uses of Biopolymers
htmlparse.Course.description: Teach existing value-added technology of cereal polymers, and explore new processes and utilization in non-traditional food/feed and in non-food/feed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Properties of Cereal Polymers
htmlparse.Course.description: Physical properties of cereal polymers include physical attributes, rheological, mechanical, thermal, electrical, and optical properties. Thermal analysis methods will be taught. Thermal analyses include glass transition, gelatinization, denaturation, and thermal softening and settings of cereal polymers. Rheological properties associated with these thermal transitions will be discussed. Applications of thermal analysis in cereal chemistry, processing, and product quality control will be discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and discussion, and two hour lab.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Grain Processing Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview of unit operations used in the grain/food processing industry will be given. Specific applications of the unit operations will be covered in detail for dry and wet milling (wheat/corn/sorghum), masa manufacturing, oilseed processing, rice milling, and packaging systems. A term project, which will include an applied research component will be developed by each student.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Grain Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Basis for the M.S. Thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Grain Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Coverage of skills and abilities needed for success in graduate school.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. a week. Required of all newly enrolled graduate students in grain science during their first year.

htmlparse.Course.title: Starch Chemistry and Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Chemical and physical properties of cereal and legume starches. Isolation, structure, assay methods, and properties. Methods of modifying starches for industrial use, including chemical, physical, and enzymic modification.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: BIOCH 521, GRSC 602, PhD students, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Carbohydrates in Food
htmlparse.Course.description: Structure and properties of food carbohydrates, including sugars, oligosaccharides, and polysaccharides, and methods of their modification and analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: CHEM 350 or BIOCH 521, PhD students, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Enzyme and Bioprocessing Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: The course explores the applications of enzymes and microbial cultures in the bioprocessing industry, including food, feed, industrial chemicals and biofuels; and major microbial pathways for product synthesis including a clear understanding of enzyme and microbial kinetics at an advanced level.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: GRSC 820 or GRSC 740/BAE 740 or BIOCH 755.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three one-hour lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Grain Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and lectures on important areas and contributions in the field of grain science not currently covered in present courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Cereal Chemistry
htmlparse.Course.description: The chemistry of cereal components at the molecular level. The role and interactions of the various constituents, their functionality in producing an end product, and their influence on nutritional properties.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Professional Development in Grain Science
htmlparse.Course.description: A team instructed lecture course that provides doctoral students in the department with a suite of skills complimentary to their research experience but still necessary for professional career success.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 2nd year Ph.D. student; M.S. students with instructor consent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two one-hour lectures per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Grain Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Basis for Ph.D. Dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historiography
htmlparse.Course.description: Main currents in historical research, the writing of history, and the influence of the great historians from Herodotus to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Security Studies Methodology
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of commonly used research methods in history and political science. Students will investigate quantitative and qualitative humanities and social sciences methodology through selected readings and limited research exercises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the major historical developments and scholarly approaches in the fields of military history, international relations, and security studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Design in Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of research methods in history and political science culminating in a piece of original research in Security Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Security: East Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature relating to national and international security in East Asia.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HIST 801 or HIST 812/POLSC 812 or concurrent enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Security: Latin America
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature relating to national and international security in Latin America.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HIST 801 or HIST 812/POLSC 812 or concurrent enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Security: the Middle East
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature relating to national and international security in the Middle East.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HIST 801 or HIST 812/POLSC 812 or concurrent enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Security: Russia/Central Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature relating to national and international security in Russian and Central Asia.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HIST 801 or HIST 812/POLSC 812 or concurrent enrollment.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Security: South Asia
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature relating to national and international security in South Asia.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HIST 801 or HIST 812/POLSC 812 or concurrent enrollment

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in History
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research in History

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Historiography
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced work offered on demand and by arrangement, in main currents in historical research, the writing of history, and the influence of great historians.

htmlparse.Course.title: Renaissance and Reformation Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.

htmlparse.Course.title: Early Modern Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nineteenth-Century Europe
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.

htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.
