htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nineteenth-Century America
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.

htmlparse.Course.title: Twentieth-Century America
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the major historical problems and literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This survey course is intended to introduce students to the most important themes and issues in their respective fields. It aims to put the historical literature in broad context to help students prepare for teaching and for their general field exams.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Approaches to Security
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of theories and approaches to military history and the history of international relations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Historical Methods in Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Training in primary-source research in military history, foreign policy, and international relations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in History of Christianity
htmlparse.Course.description: This seminar is a course in which students are expected to study the primary source material for particular topics within a general area of study and to write a paper based on research using such sources. These courses are intended to develop graduate students’ skills in the use of research tools and methods, ability to conceptualize and organize an argument, and facility in presenting research findings. Within the general areas listed below, these courses may focus inter alia upon political, diplomatic, social, religious, intellectual, or environmental history. Specific topics will be listed in the class schedule for the semester in which they are offered.

Within the general areas listed below, these courses may focus inter alia upon political, diplomatic, social, religious, intellectual, or environmental history. Specific topics will be listed in the class schedule for the semester in which they are offered.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in History of Publishing
htmlparse.Course.description: A historical introduction and training in the central means by which historical knowledge is transmitted in written format.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Military History
htmlparse.Course.description: Discusses such problems as command, the military and diplomacy, the officer corps, training, and women in the military.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in American Military Affairs
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies the great writers of American military history and emphasizes student research into such topics as the War for American Independence, limited wars, the Civil War, the role of the President as commander in chief, and the militia.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of Military Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: The History of Military Thought from Machiavelli to the Present.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in History
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Research in History

htmlparse.Course.title: Casino Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation of the histories and overall operations of casino properties and their impacts on the foodservice and hospitality industry from the social, economical, political and environmental perspectives.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Junior standing, 60 hours or more.

htmlparse.Course.title: Food Production Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Production planning and controls in foodservice systems analysis in foodservice systems. Decision optimization and systems analysis in foodservice organizations. Consideration of various types of foodservice systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HMD 342; and HMD 480 or 560 or MANGT 420.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Techniques for Foodservice and Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey and application of research methodology in foodservice and hospitality management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Hospitality Management and Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual investigation of problems in foodservice and hospitality management. Conferences and reports at appointed hours.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HMD 342; and HMD 480 or 560 or MANGT 400.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Foodservice and Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions of research related to foodservice and hospitality management.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Foodservice and Hospitality Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of management applied to foodservice and hospitality organizations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Scanning and Analysis of Current Issues in Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of changes in the economic, social, ethical, political, legal, technological, and ecological environments in which dietitians practice. Implications of these changes for education, practice and research within the field with particular emphasis on the healthcare industry.

htmlparse.Course.title: Financial Management and Cost Controls for the Hospitality Industry
htmlparse.Course.description: Overview of fundamental knowledge of financial management, managerial accounting and operational cost controls for the hospitality industry. Important topics include review of managerial accounting concepts based on the Uniform System of Accounts for the Lodging Industry, value and risk analyses, budgeting, asset management, expansion via franchising and management contracts, cost-volume-profit analyses, and operational applications for financial performance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810; HMD 342; and HMD 480 or 560 or MANGT 420.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Foodservice or Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual research which may form the basis for master’s report or thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research and Applied Theories in Consumer Behavior in Foodservice and Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Critique of theoretical constructs and research applications in the study in foodservice and hospitality management. Emphasis on preliminary stages of research development including preparation of literature reviews and preliminary proposals for research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Administration of Dietetics and Hospitality Programs
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the development of dietetic and hospitality education and influence of the professional associations. Assigned observations and limited participation in administration of coordinated dietetics and hospitality management programs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: EDCEP 927 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advances in Foodservice and Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of selected topics and research in foodservice and hospitality management.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HMD 810 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Proposal Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation and discussion of proposals for dissertation research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Six hours of statistics, 3 hours of research design or methods, and consent of major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grantsmanship and Publication
htmlparse.Course.description: Grant writing, identifying external funding, managing grants, preparing manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication, and preparing papers and poster for presentation at professional meetings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Foodservice or Hospitality Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in foodservice or hospitality management for the doctoral dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition Education and Communication
htmlparse.Course.description: Apply principles of communication and learning technologies to nutrition education reseach and practice.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HN 510, HRIMD 515, and a statistics course with a grade of C or better; or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Macronutrient Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: Dietary, metabolic, and endocrine factors regulating food intake and selection, and the absorption, function, metabolism, and interrelationships of macronutrients under varying nutritional conditions, with emphasis on recent advances in macronutrient nutrition.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Micronutrient Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional roles and metabolism of vitamins and minerals. Functions, biological availability, hormonal regulation, requirements, deficiency and toxicity signs, and interrelations with other nutrients.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Basis of Nutrient Function
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is designed to explore the role that certain nutrients have at the gene and molecular levels in terms of their mechanism of action. The physiological consequences of nutrient gene-interaction from a tissue, organ and organism level, as well as the subcellular levels, are to be considered.

htmlparse.Course.title: Functional Foods for Chronic Disease Prevention
htmlparse.Course.description: Integrate and evaluate the regulatory principles, food science, nutrient science and nutritional metabolism for the development of funtional foods, nutraceuticals, and dietary supplements for chronic disease prevention.

htmlparse.Course.title: Descriptive Sensory Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Flavor and texture profiling and other descriptive techniques for use in product development, research, and quality control. Practical experiences in conducting tests and leading panels.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Sensory Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual experiences applying sensory testing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HN 841 or HN 831, and consent of instructor
htmlparse.Course.notes: Twelve hours of lab per week. May be taken more than once for a maximum of 6 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Clinical Dietetics
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the pathophysiology of nutritional disease. Those functional disorders which result in nutritional disease or those nutritional diseases which affect physiological function will be explored. The emphasis will be in the following areas: nutritional assessment, endocrinology, metabolism, gastroenterology, and organ failure.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Only available to distance students seeking a Masters in Dietetics through the Great Plains Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Clinical Nutrition Support
htmlparse.Course.description: Specialized nutrition assessment and support. Review of energy expenditure and substrate utilization in specific disease states. Current methods for the initiation and management of enteral and parenteral nutrition therapy including access, metabolic and mechanical complications. Evaluation of nutrition support methodology in selected disease states.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to the Masters in Dietetics program through the Great Plains Interactive Distance Education Alliance (GPIDEA).

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an international, state, local, or district health agency or other appropriate health agency.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once, but only 6 hours may be applied toward the MPH degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Consumer Response Evaluation
htmlparse.Course.description: Evaluation of consumer attitudes and perceptions of products to provide quantitative and qualitative information for research guidance. Design and implementation of consumer questionnaires and development of guides for focus groups and interviews.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture and four hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Nutrition: Nutrigenomics, Nutrigenetics, and Advanced Lipid Metabolism
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamentals as how the macronutrients; fat, carbohydrates and protein act to regulate gene expression(nutrigenetics) and how an individuals genotype may alter an individuals macronutrient requirements (nutrigenetics) and influence phenotype with respect to chronic disease and human health.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HN 620 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Only available to distance students seeking a Masters in Dietetics through the Great Plains Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutritional Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods and issues involved in understanding and conducting studies on the relationship between human diet and disease.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sensory Analysis Applications of Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of statistics to sensory data. Emphasis on appropriate analyses, software use, interpretation of data, and reporting.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr: HN 701, STAT 720 or STAT 722, STAT 730.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nutrition: A Focus on Life Stages
htmlparse.Course.description: Nutritional needs throughout the life span including pregnancy, lactation, growth and aging. Approaches to nutrition education for different ages.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: 3 hours undergraduate nutrition and 6 hours undergraduate natural sciences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Only available to distance students seeking a Masters in Dietetics through the Great Plains Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Maternal and Child Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of behavioral, physiological, and public health issues impacting dietary and nutritional factors that support normal growth and development. The course content focuses on the early stages of the life cycle: gestation, lactation, infancy, preschool, school age and adolescence. Topics include the fetal programming hypothesis, growth and nutritional requirements, breast and formula feeding of infants, infant weaning, and eating behaviors that lead to normal growth, growth faltering, and pediatric obesity.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Only available to distance students seeking a Masters in Dietetics through the Great Plains Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pediatric Clinical Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: The physiological, biochemical and nutritional aspects of disease processes relevant to infants and children up to 18 years of age. Medical nutrition therapy for a variety of medical conditions found in this Population will be discussed including inborn errors of metabolism, food hypersensitivity, obesity, and diseases of the major organ systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: HN 630 Clinical Nutrition or equivalent.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Only available to distance students seeking a Masters in Dietetics through the Great Plains Program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Human Nutrition
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of current research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey in depth of the literature.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in area of specialization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Nutrition Topics: Contemporary Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Contemporary concerns in health and disease from an advanced nutrition perspective.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once for credit for different topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Grantsmanship and Publication
htmlparse.Course.description: Grant writing, identifying external funding, managing grants, preparing manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication, and preparing papers and poster for presentation at professional meetings.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 720 or a graduate level research methods course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Doctoral Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Doctoral Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticultural Physiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions of recent advances in horticultural crop plant physiology, including improvements in horticultural crops resulting from applications of molecular biology and biotechnology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Nutrition and Nutrient Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on the macro and micronutrient elements and their function in the growth and development of plants. Emphasis will be placed on the roles of single elements, interactions/balances between elements, and nutrient deficiency/toxicity symptoms as they affect the physiology of the whole plant and management of nutrient applications. The relationships between crop nutrition and production and environmental considerations (yield, drought, temperature, pests) will be explored.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Agricultural Remote Sensing
htmlparse.Course.description: Focus is on the theory and application of remote sensing to quantifying soil and vegetation characteristics relevant to agriculture and natural biosystems, including turfgrass.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: AGRON 305 and PHYS 100-level or above.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of history and forms of plant science literature. Discussion on selecting experimental procedures, interpreting data, and reporting results.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: One statistics course or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Horticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures of important papers and contributions in this field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigations in pomology, olericulture, floriculture, ornamental horticulture, turfgrass, or horticultural therapy for preparation of master’s report.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research-MS
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigations in pomology, olericulture, floriculture, ornamental horticulture, turfgrass, or horticultural therapy for preparation of master’s thesis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advances in Plant Cell Culture
htmlparse.Course.description: Course will cover current topics in plant cell culture, applications and commercial practices, with emphasis on plant genetic improvement. Research-level skills in this area will be taught.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Regulators in Horticulture
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of synthetic plant regulators used to initiate, induce, promote, inhibit, or alter characteristics of horticultural plants and crops. Included are kinds and types of exogenous plant regulators used on crops, their activity, plant responses, benefits and problems, and application technology.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOCH 510 or BIOL 500, and one graduate plant commodity course.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One hour lec. and two hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Horticulture Graduate Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Student presentations and discussion of investigational works in the various branches of horticulture.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Plant Stress
htmlparse.Course.description: Physiological, biochemical and morphological factors involved in stress development and resistance will be discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Horticultural Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on important papers and contributions in horticultural therapy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Horticulture, PhD
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigations in pomology, olericulture, floriculture, ornamental horticulture, and turfgrass. Data collected may form basis for a thesis or dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Interior Design Studio VI
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studio experiences in residential interior environments.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: IDH 545 or 645; and IDH 651 or conc. enrollment, or IDH 760 or conc. Enrollment.
htmlparse.Course.notes:
May be repeated with a maximum of 6 hours applied toward a graduate degree.
The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Effects of the Housing Environment
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical analysis of the literature on the social influences on the family and the individual attributable to the nature of the housing and neighborhood environment. Alternative physical determinist and socio-cultural interpretations are developed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: IDH 410 and STAT 702 or STAT 703.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Methods in Household Equipment
htmlparse.Course.description: Philosophy of household equipment evaluation and experimentation; emphasis upon instrumentation, selection of variables, and data analysis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: A course in statistics and IDH 740.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Interior Design and Housing
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in interior design and housing.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Six hours of credit basic to field.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Interior Design and Housing
htmlparse.Course.description: Preplanned and supervised off-campus experience in business, industry, museums, government agencies, or the cooperative extension service.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Twelve hours in the field.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Interior Design and Housing
htmlparse.Course.description: Research which may form the basis for the master’s thesis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Housing Economics
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of economic research related to consumer and government decisions about housing, including financing, regulation, subsidy programs, energy conservation, and choice of characteristics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ECON 520, course in statistics, and two courses in housing, urban economics, or planning.
htmlparse.Course.notes: The Interior Design graduate program is temporarily suspended. We are not currently offering this course. Please e-mail atidinfo@humec.ksu.edu if you have questions or concerns.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Lectures on recent advanced topics in industrial engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Independent Study in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: This course involves independent study of recent advanced topics in industrial engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Research and Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Engineering administration; organization factors in decision-making.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Project Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, scheduling, and controlling engineering projects. Includes determination of appropriate project team, cost/benefit analysis, PERT and CPM scheduling techniques, reporting, and use of computerized project management tools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: IMSE 530 and IMSE 501 or MANGT 420.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Logistics Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The course provides comprehensive coverage of supply chain logistics components and system issues, including control of the movement of goods and information, coordination of supply and demand in creation and maximization of time and place utility. Emphasis is given to integrating workflow modeling, control, and design concepts and performance evaluation of logistic activities such as transportation, inventory, warehousing, and information technology. The systems viewpoint is explored at the individual firm level and from the perspective of inter-firm relationships among participants in logistics supply chains. Recognition is also given to important interrelationships between logistics and production, marketing, and financial management.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Production and Inventory Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytical and mathematical methods of making decisions on production, inventories, human resources, and shipping in modern industrial plants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Engineering Economy
htmlparse.Course.description: This course expands on the principles of the fundamental engineering economics analysis. Emphasis is placed on quantification and evaluation of risk and uncertainty factors, effects of inflation and taxes, economic consequences of estimating models, utility theory, engineering capital equipment replacement analysis and decision-tree and multi-attribute decision models.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: IMSE 530, or ME 560, or CE 680.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Tribology in Manufacturing
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to system approach to Tribology; Surface Topography; Physical, Chemical, and Geometric Nature of Surfaces; and the Mechanics of contact between surfaces. This course also investigates various theories of friction and wear; hydrodynamic; elastohydrodynamic, and boundary lubrication; frictional instabilities; rolling contact problems; and application of system methodology to tribological problems in engineering design and manufacturing.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Fuzzy Set Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: The emphasis will be on applicational aspects. Topics covered are elementary fuzzy set theory, fuzzy measure, possibility theory, fuzzy linear programming and other fuzzy optimization techniques, fuzzy linguistics and expert systems, fuzzy production and inventory control, and fuzzy operations research models.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Quality Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of current advances in quality engineering. Includes both off-line and on-line quality engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 704, 705; IMSE 641 and CIS 209, or 200, or ME 400.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Reliability Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: The mathematics of reliability theory. The hazard function. Calculation of failure density and mean life for series, parallel systems, and various types of standby systems. Hypotheses tests on mean life. Life testing with censoring.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ergonomics (Human Factors) Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: The design and analysis of applied experimental research on human behavior as applied to engineering systems. An experimental project.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. and three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Simulation of Industrial Management Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Simulating industrial management systems on computers utilizing Monte Carlo techniques and simulation languages. Numerical methods related to simulation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Stochastic Processes and Theoretical Simulation
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of stochastic processes and simulation. Topics covered include: discrete and continuous markov chains, random walks, queuing theory, renewal theory, random number generation, random variates and simulation modeling and analysis. Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Manufacturing Processes for Semiconductor Materials and Devices
htmlparse.Course.description: Research topics on manufacturing processes for semiconductor materials and devices. Processes covered include; crystal growing, slicing, edge profiling, lapping, wafer grinding, wet etching, polishing, cleaning, oxidation, lithography, dry etching, diffusion, metallization, CMP (Chemical-Mechanical Planarization), backside thinning, dicing, bonding, packaging, final testing.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Computer Integrated Manufacturing
htmlparse.Course.description: Modern issues of computerized manufacturing considering both hardware and software approaches and methods. Advanced concepts in intelligent machine programming and applications, group technology, computer aided process planning, and scheduling will be discussed. Research issues will be presented.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Forecasting Techniques and Applications
htmlparse.Course.description: The problems of model construction for industrial forecasting. The application of least squares, regression, exponential smoothing, and adaptive fitting will be studied in solving industrial engineering problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Systems Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis and synthesis of automatic control systems with application to machines and processes and industrial management systems. A study of optimal control, stability, and sensibility of industrial management systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor and IMSE 660.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Linear Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of the theory of linear programming and related topics including simplex methods, duality theory, integer programming, transportation methods, and stochastic linear programming. Application to industrial problems and the use of computer solutions are emphasized.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall (Odd years on campus; distance every year)
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Network Flows and Graph Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of topics from Network Flows and Graph Theory with an emphasis on algorithmic analysis. The topics covered include: Complexity Analysis, Shortest Paths, Maximum Flows, Network Simplex, Minimum Spanning Trees, Matching, Planar Graphs, Colorings, Perfect Graphs and Heuristics.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring, odd years (on campus), every year (distance)
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Integer Programming and Combinatorial Optimization
htmlparse.Course.description: Solution techniques to optimization problems invloving integer variables. The topics covered include: single-and multiple-branching, implicit enumeration, polyhedral theory and cutting planes, mixed integer programs, unimodular matrices and matroids.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Manufacturing Information Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of topics in Computer Integrated Manufacturing. Issues such as the Manufacturing Automation Protocol (MAP), representation of solids in CAD, storage and retrieval of such information are considered.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will provide students with effective methods to perform literature reviews, survey current solution methodologies, develop and evaluate research and present research results.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. or concurrent: at least one of IMSE 780, IMSE 641, or IMSE 811.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Methods in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: This class requires students to have at least 6 weeks of full-time work experience in a job related to Industrial Engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. Approval of major professor and department head.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course can be taken only once by a graduate student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Methods in Industrial Engineering II
htmlparse.Course.description: This class requires students to have at least 12 weeks of full-time work experience in a job related to Industrial Engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. Approval of major professor and department head.
htmlparse.Course.notes: This course can be taken only once by a graduate student.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Seminar in Industrial Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation and discussion of topics of contemporary interest in industrial or manufacturing engineering. M.S. and Ph.D. candidates make one presentation.
htmlparse.Course.notes: One one-hour seminar meeting a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Queuing Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the queuing process and theory of queues; analysis of single and multistation queues; application to production, materials handling, inventory and maintenance systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Scheduling Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Project scheduling, assembly line balancing, shop scheduling, basic structure, measures of performance, combinatorial and statistical aspects. Various approaches to the analysis of shop scheduling.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonlinear Programming
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of nonlinear models and their solution. Topics covered are nonlinear programming including Kuhn-Tucker theory, quadratic programming, separable programming, geometric programming, gradient and search methods, quasilinearization, and invariant imbedding.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Operations Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of topics related to operations research not covered in other courses. Selected according to the interests and needs of graduate students.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Multiple Criteria Decision Making
htmlparse.Course.description: Decision processes for problems involving multiple conflicting criteria; multiple attribute decision making; multiple objective decision making, and group decision making under multiple criteria. Various methods/approaches for different problems are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Physiology of Exercise
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of the physiological responses of the human body during exercise, the adaptations that occur with exercise training, and the laboratory techniques to assess these responses and adaptations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Activity and Human Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the theory and research related to the psychological antecedents and outcomes of participation in physical activity and exercise. Topics include models of exercise motivation, social cognitive theory of exercise and social ecological models of physical activity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Motor Development
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of psychomotor development. The focus is on the growth years, though developmental considerations for all age groups are considered. Implications for sport, exercise, and physical activity are discussed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Motor Learning and Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of learning principles to skill acquisition in sport and human domain; and practical applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: KIN 320 or 9 hours of graduate credit in psychology (500 level or above).

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Epidemiology of Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the social factors that contribute to an understanding of why people participate in physical activity. Topics include the consideration of individual social and demographic factors such as gender, race, socioeconomic status, education, and social support as well as social structural factors such as the role of the social institutions (e.g. family, work and school environments).

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of techniques of the research process including the identification of a research problem, the design of experimental and non-experimental strategies, and the presentation of written esearch.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social and Behavioral Bases of Public Health
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of behavioral, social, psychological, economic, environmental, and social structural factors in both the occurrence of health problems in groups and populations, and in the development of the risk factors that contribute to these problems. Principles of health behavior change and the application of these principles to a variety of health issues as well as an emphasis on how social structural factors impact health are examined to better understand health behavior and health inequities in contemporary society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate status in public health or kinesiology program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physical Activity Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of leadership as it pertains to physical activity environments for older adults. Emphasis placed on gaining a broad understanding of the current state of leadership research and the application of a conceptual model of leadership to physical activity outcomes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanical Analysis of Human Movement
htmlparse.Course.description: Mechanical principles and analysis procedures for the study of overt human movement. Applications to movements in exercise, sport, occupational, and daily living activities will be emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Public Health Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of the social and behavioral epidemiology of physical activity in public health: outcomes, influences, and promotion in individuals, settings, and communities.

htmlparse.Course.title: Group Dynamics and Physical Activity
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines the principles of group development and maintenance in physical activity environments. Topics include the nature of groups, group environment, important member attributes, group structure, group cohesion, group processes and tactics of group development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an international, state, local, or district health agency or other appropriate health agency.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once, but only 6 hours may be applied toward the MPH degree.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exercise Adherence
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and discussion of empirical research and theory as it relates to exercise adherence from psychological, behavioral, and public health perspectives. Topics addressed are epidemiological trends, conceptual issues of measurement, research design, statistical analysis, and interventions focusing on settings and populations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Exercise Psychology in Special Populations
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the psychological determinants and outcomes of exercise participation in special populations (e.g. arthritic, obese, cardiovascular disease). Emphasis in understanding the motive underlying involvement in exercise and physical activity and the situational and personal determinants associated with failure to initiate and/or adhere to exercise and physical activity programs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Independent Study in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive independent study in a topic or problem involving the integration, application, and synthesis of theory presented in a related course. The course culminates in the preparation of an original paper.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: KIN 815 and related graduate subject core courses.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Kinesiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in one or more of the research processes involved in the scientific method.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 702 or 703, KIN 815, and related graduate subject core course.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Thesis

htmlparse.Course.title: Community Planning and Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of the relationships between planning and design in the growth and development of cities and towns.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. and six hours studio a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Operations and Supply Chain Management
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of the role of operations systems in the provision of value for the customer. Operations systems design, capacity determination, resource requirements planning and control, theory of constraints, supply chain management, quality management and control and project management are discussed and analyzed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Behavioral Management Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth analysis of the development of the behavioral bases of individual and group behavior in business, governmental, educational, and other organizations with emphasis on current research literature and applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Open only to students in graduate business degree or certificate programs or with permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Business Law
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of civil law as it affects commercial transactions, including corporations, partnerships, property, commercial paper, and secured transactions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Information Technology Strategy and Application
htmlparse.Course.description: A practical exposure to information technology as it applies to business. Emphasis will be placed on problem-solving using spreadsheets, databases, and HTML based information systems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Entrepreneurship
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth examination of the nature of entrepreneurship including success factors, the requirements of successful new venture planning and implementation, and researching the current literature in the field. The study of new product identification, the assessment of commercial potential, and the elements of an effective business plan will be examined in detail, culminating in the preparation of a comprehensive plan for the development and marketing of a new product or service.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technology Entrepreneurship and Strategy
htmlparse.Course.description: In this course the student will learn how to recognize and screen technology opportunities in diverse areas such as telecommunications to biotechnology; learn the intricacies of intellectual property creation, protection and acquisition; effectively implement the commercialization process. A major objective of the course is to help students realize that technology may be the most under-utilized asset in either the private or public sector yet, in the form of licenses or rights to use, can be sold repeated with a relatively low cost of goods sold, resulting in a continual stream of income.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management of Legal, Ethical, and Public Policy Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the influence of political, economic, legal and social factors on contemporary business organizations. The course requires students to integrate concepts from core courses in order to formulate and implement strategic and ethical responses to issues posed by these environmental factors.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810, FINAN 815, MKTG 810, MANGT 810, MANGT 820, MANGT 830, ECON 815, and STAT 702.

htmlparse.Course.title: Enterprise Information Systems Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Concepts and information resource management techniques are integrated into a conceptual framework of enterprise information systems. The impact of current issues and new technologies on business is emphasized through discussion and application.

htmlparse.Course.title: Managing Animal Health Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Relevant theoretical concepts will be drawn from strategic management, management of change, human resource management, and the management of innovation to provide and intellectual grounding for understanding industry dynamics and the analysis of contemporary managerial challenges and issues for organizations in the animal health industry. Special emphasis will be given to proposing strategic solutions to solve major problems that companies face in the animal health corridor.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Operations Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Explores the global market context and the environment for multinational operations. Examines important tools, concepts, theories, models, and structures as defined and applied to manufacturing and service operations in other countries. Emphasis is placed on Japanese technology and practices. It draws upon those aspects of manufacturing and service operations that can help U.S. firms become increasingly competitive worldwide.

htmlparse.Course.title: Management Science
htmlparse.Course.description: The application of management science methods to business problems to provide a basis for rational decision making. Includes mathematical programming, inventory theory, simulation, model building, and heuristics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MATH 205, STAT 351 or STAT 702 (or concurrent enrollment).

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Management Contemporary Issues in Management
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and analysis of contemporary issues in management, including applications, development and study of relevant literature and research findings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Problems in Management
htmlparse.Course.description: As scheduled. An in-depth study of specified topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Twelve hours of management and consent of the instructor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Numerical Solution of Differential Equations I
htmlparse.Course.description: Single and multistep methods for initial-value problems for ordinary differential equations; discretization and round-off error; consistency, convergence, and stability of these methods; stiff equations and implicit methods; two-point boundary value problems; initial and boundary-value problems for partial differential equations; finite difference methods; marching schemes for parabolic and hyperbolic problems; consistency, stability, convergence, and the Lax equivalence theorem; treatment of boundary conditions; boundary-value problems for elliptic equations; relaxation, alternating direction, and strongly-implicit iterative methods; nonlinear problems; finite element method.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MATH 655 and knowledge of a programming language.

htmlparse.Course.title: Numerical Solution of Differential Equations II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 801.

htmlparse.Course.title: Higher Algebra I
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory of groups, theory of rings and ideals, polynomial domains, theory of fields and their extensions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Higher Algebra II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 810.

htmlparse.Course.title: Homological Algebra I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the basics of homological and cohomological delta functors with applications to specific categories. Topics include Abelian categories, functors, exactness, chain complexes and maps, cochain complexes and maps, projective and injective resolutions, left and right derived functors, homological dimension, double complexes, spectral sequences, Tor and Ext functors, cohomology of groups, Lie algebras, and Hochschild homology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Homological Algebra II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to special homology and cohomology theories. Topics include Galois cohomology, cyclic homology, local cohomology theories, localization, derived categories, and the calculus of fractions in Abelian categories.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lie Algebras and Representations I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to Lie algebras. Topics include ideals, homomorphisms, nilpotent and solvable algebras, radicals, killing forms, Cartan subalgebras, semisimple Lie algebras and root systems, classification of semisimple Lie algebras, conjugacy theorems, enveloping algebras and PBW theorems, Serre relations, and constructions of semisimple Lie algebras and their enveloping algebras.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lie Algebras and Representations II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to Kac-Moody algebras and their representations, Verma modules and BGG categories, and the Kac-Weyl character formula. In addition, special topics include quantum groups and their representations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Algebraic Geometry I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to affine algebraic varieties over algebraically closed fields. Topics include Hilbert Nullstellensatz, Zarski topology, morphisms, differentials, smoothness, separability, and normality, algebraic and projective varieties, sheaf theory, sheaf cohomology, and vector bundles.

htmlparse.Course.title: Algebraic Geometry II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to schemes. Topics include categories, representable functors, prime spectra, algebraic schemes, separable schemes, normal schemes, proper schemes, schemes with bases, completions, formal schemes, Zariski’s Theorem, Frobenius morphisms, and etale morphisms.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Algebraic Groups I
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to algebraic groups. Topics include a review of algebraic geometry on varieties and morphisms, Lie algebras of algebraic groups, actions of algebraic groups over algebraic varieties, Jordan-Chevalley decompositions, solvable and unipotent algebraic groups, radicals and unipotent radicals, Borel subgroups, and parabolic subgroups.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Algebraic Groups II
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to reductive and semisimple algebraic groups, Bruhat decompositions, flag varieties, cohomology groups of line bundles over flag manifolds, Chevalley groups and their representations, Weyl modules and classification of irreducible modules, group functors and schemes, Hopf algebras and their representations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Real Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Measure theory and integration, Lebesgue integration, L<sub>p</sub>-spaces, Hilbert spaces, integration on product spaces, Fubini’s theorem.

htmlparse.Course.title: Complex Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytic functions, the Cauchy integral theorem, power series, principle of the argument, conformal mapping.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geometric Function and Measure Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics include general measure theory, covering theorems, Hausdorff measure, area and coarea formulas, distributions, Sobolev spaces, Poincare’ inequalities, embeddings theorem, changes of variables, extentions, and capacity. Applications include quasiconformal and quasiregular maps in IR<sup>IN</sup> and analysis on fractals.

htmlparse.Course.title: Geometric Function and Measure Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Geometric Function and Measure Theory I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Complex Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Holomorphic functions, harmonic functions, the Cauchy integral theorem, normal families and the Riemann mapping theorem, and the Mittag-Leffler theorem.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MATH 822 or consent of department.

htmlparse.Course.title: Complex Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Analytic continuation, the Picard theorem, Hp-spaces, elementary theory of Banach algebra, the theory of Fourier transforms, and the Paley-Wiener theorems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical and Modern Fourier Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics include Fourier analysis on the circle, singular integrals of convolution type, Littlewood-Paley theory and multipliers, BMO and Carleson Measures, and boundedness and convergence of Fourier integrals (or singular integrals of nonconvolution type).

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical and Modern Fourier Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Classical and Modern Fourier Analysis I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Algebraic Number Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics include lattice theory, geometry of numbers, algebraic number fields, Dedekind domains, discrete valuation rings, ideal class group, group units, cyclotomic fields, Galois extensions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analytic Number Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Potential topicsi nclude; prime number theorem characters, L-functions, Diophantine problems, exponential sums, p-adic analysis, Diophantine approximations, Sieve Methods, Circle method.

htmlparse.Course.title: Differential Equations I
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic ordinary and partial differential equations. First-order ordinary differential equations: symmetries and solutions in quadratures; existence, uniqueness and dependence on parameters, systems of first order equations, analysis of equilibria. Second order equations: series solutions and special functions, initial- and boundary-value problems for second-order equations. Elements of integral equations. First-order partial differential equations. Basic second-order partial differential equations: wave equations, heat equations, Poisson equation, Schrodinger equation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MATH 634 or MATH 745 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Differential Equations II
htmlparse.Course.description: Where PDEs come from. Initial and boundary-value problems. A crash course in distribution theory: different spaces of distributions, Fourier and Laplace transformations of distributions, Sobolev spaces. The Poisson equation in bounded and in exterior domains; properties of solutions of elliptic equations. The classical evolution equations revisited. Energy estimates, existence and uniqueness theorems, regularity and other properties of solutions. Simple examples of nonlinear PDEs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Differential Equations III
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 841.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Probability I
htmlparse.Course.description: Review of measure theory notions specific to probability, including classical limit theorems, constructions of Brownian motion, Stochastic integration, the martingale representation theorem and martingale-based function spaces.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Probability II
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include stochastic processes, random matrix theory, free probability, random fractals and random analytic maps.

htmlparse.Course.title: Functional Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Topological vector spaces; locally convex spaces (Hahn-Banach Theorem, weak topology, dual pairs, Krein-Milman Theorem, theory of distributions); Banach spaces (Uniform Boundedness Principle, Open Mapping Theorem and applications, Alaoglu’s Theorem, analytic vector-valued functions, Krein-Smulian Theorem); C(X) as a Banach space (Stone-Weierstrass Theorem, Riesz Theorem); Lp spaces.

htmlparse.Course.title: Functional Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Banach Algebras (spectrum, Gelfand Fourier transform, holomorphic functional calculus); Hilbert spaces (geometric properties, Riesz’s Theorem, projections, the adjoint); functional calculus for normal operators; compact operators (spectral properties, Min-Max Theorem, Schatten-vol Neumann classes); Fredholm operators; other operator topologies on B(H); unbounded self-adjoint operators. Other topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics I
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the mathematical techniques of problem solving in the sciences and engineering. Construction of mathematical models; problem formulation, dimensional analysis and scaling; solution methods for differential equations and difference equations; methods for obtaining approximate solutions; regular and singular perturbations methods, asymptotic series, applications to specific equations and scientific problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics II
htmlparse.Course.description: A continuation of MATH 855. Asymptotic expansion of integrals; the methods of stationary phase and steepest descent; summations of series, the Shanks transformation and the Pade fractions; boundary layer theory; the WKB and Langer approximations; the method of averaging and the method of multiple scales.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonlinear Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: The course deals with studies of nonlinear operator equations, existence of their solutions, uniqueness of the solutions, numerical methods for finding solutions. Fixed point theorems, topological principles, nonlinear elliptic equations and evolution equations, ill-posed and inverse problems are discussed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. MATH 821, 822, 852, 853 and MATH 840 is recommended.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonlinear Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Nonlinear Analysis I.

htmlparse.Course.title: Numerical Analysis I
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics covered may include elementary functional analysis relevant to numerical analysis; numerical solution of differential or integral equations; analysis of stability and convergence; numerical linear algebra including large-scale systems; approximation theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Numerical Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 861.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Ordinary Differential Equations I
htmlparse.Course.description: The modern theory of ordinary differential equations including general theory and the theory of linear differential equations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Ordinary Differential Equations II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 864 to include nonlinear equations and differential equations in Banach spaces.

htmlparse.Course.title: General Topology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Topological spaces and topological invariants; continuous mappings and their invariants; perfect mappings; topological constructions (product, quotient, direct and inverse limit spaces).

htmlparse.Course.title: General Topology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Compact spaces and compactification, uniform and proximity spaces, metric spaces and metrization, topology of Rn, function spaces, complete spaces, introduction to homotopy theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Algebraic Topology
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental groups; Seifert-Van Kampen theorem; covering spaces; homology and cohomology; simplicial, singular, cellular, and axiomatic theories; cup products; Betti numbers, Euler characteristic; universal coefficient and Kunneth theorems; Hurewicz theorem in dimension one; orientation of manifolds; degree of maps.

htmlparse.Course.title: Differential Topology
htmlparse.Course.description: Smooth manifolds; smooth maps; smooth partitions of unity; tangent spaces and tangent bundles; derivatives; inverse function theorem and applications; Morse functions; embedding theorems; orientations and orientability via tangent bundles; cotangent and exterior bundles; differential forms; integration on manifolds; vector fields and Lie derivatives; DeRham cohomology and DeRham’s theorem.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical and Quantum General Relativity
htmlparse.Course.description: A self contained introduction to general Relativity, followed by a mathematical introduction to quantum mechanics and quantum field theory. Course culminates in review of current approaches to quantizing general Relativity.

htmlparse.Course.title: Differentiable Manifolds I
htmlparse.Course.description: Differentiable structures, tangent bundles, tensor bundles, vector fields and differential equations, integral manifolds, differential forms, Stokes’ Theorem, DeRham cohomology, Riemannian metrics, introduction to Lie groups, topics in algebraic topology from a differentiable viewpoint.

htmlparse.Course.title: Differentiable Manifolds II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 881.

htmlparse.Course.title: Riemann Surfaces
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to Riemann Surfaces. Topics will include complex charts, complex structures, holomorphic and meromorphic maps (and functions), order of poles and zeros, covering spaces, monodromy of holomorphic maps, differential forms, DeRham cohomology groups, integration on Riemann surfaces, Cech cohomology of sheaves, compact Riemann surfaces, finite theorems, divisors and sheaves of meromorphic forms, and the Riemann Roch Theorem.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Background of courses needed for topic undertaken and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Mathematics Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar in Mathematics Education

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Thesis Topics
htmlparse.Course.description: Thesis Topics

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Groups
htmlparse.Course.description: Group representations and group characters, transfer, signalizer functors, theory of pushing-up, groups of Lie type, (B, N)-pairs, chamber systems and buildings, sporadic simple groups, amalgam methods, Bass-Serre theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Several Complex Variables
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the theory and analytic functions of several variables, domains of homomorphy and pseudoconvexity, the Levi problem, delta bar equations, Cousin problems, zeros of analytic functions, integral formulas, holomorphic mappings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Group Representations and Character Theory I
htmlparse.Course.description: The basic topics in representation theory are covered: Schur’s Lemma, irreducibility, class functions, characters, orthogonality relations, Frobenius-Schur theorem, induced characters and Frobenius reciprocity, Mackey’s theorem, Clifford’s theorem, exceptional characters and applications to group orders, generalized characters and Brauer’s characterizations of characters.

htmlparse.Course.title: Group Representations and Character Theory II
htmlparse.Course.description: Depending on the interests of the students, topics may be chosen from the following: modular representations, Brauer’s theory of blocks, characters of the linear groups, homologically induced representations, representations of complex Lie algebras.

htmlparse.Course.title: Algebraic Topology I
htmlparse.Course.description: Homotopy groups, covering spaces, fibrations, homology, general cohomology theory and duality, homotopy theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Algebraic Topology II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of MATH 971.

htmlparse.Course.title: Low-Dimensional Topology I-Geometric Topology
htmlparse.Course.description: Manifolds, triangulations, differentiable structures, wild vs. tame embeddings, the Jordan Curve theorem, Schonflies Theorems, the classification of compact surfaces, Dehn’s Lemma, the Triangulation Theorem and Huaptvermutung in dimensions 2 and 3, introduction to knot theory: knot groups, the Alexander polynomial, and related topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Low-Dimensional Topology II-Quantum Topology
htmlparse.Course.description: Artin’s braid groups, Markov’s Theorem, the Jones Polynomial and its generalizations, state-sum invariants of knots and manifolds, skein-relations, quantum groups and categories of tangles, topological quantum field theories.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MATH 973 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Algebra
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in modern algebra.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in modern analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Harmonic Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in harmonic analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Applied Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in applied mathematics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Geometry
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in geometry.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Topology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in topology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Number Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in number theory.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Mathematics
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training to carry on the line or research undertaken and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Research in Mass Media
htmlparse.Course.description: Study and application of mass media research, its literature, and methodology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Mass Communications
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sufficient training to carry on the line of research undertaken.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Thesis/report credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: MNE Graduate Seminar/Research Paper
htmlparse.Course.description: Presentation(oral and written) and discussion of progress in research. Credit hours can be earned by preparing and/or presenting publication quality papers. Topics may be drawn from any current research area in mechanical and nuclear engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing in Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with change in subject matter.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Mechanics of Materials and Applied Elasticity
htmlparse.Course.description: Two- and three-dimensional deformation analysis, equilibrium, and elastic constitutive laws. Stress-strain transformations between coordinate systems. Governing equations of elasticity. Advanced topics in bending, shearing, torsion and combined loads, with applications to engineering problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hous rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermodynamic Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic considerations of the three laws of equilibrium thermodynamics. Availability analysis with applications including multicomponent systems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Topics in Thermal and Fluid Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include combustion, direct energy conversion, modeling and design of internal combustion engines, nonequilibrium multiphase and multicomponent systems, refrigeration, cryogenics, stability and turbulence.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Topics in Automatic Controls
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include analysis and design of nonlinear, adaptive, optimal, digitals or stochastic control systems and the applications of intermediate control and stability theory.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ME 730 or ECE 730 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Boundary Layer Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: The development and solution of various laminar boundary layer problems involving momentum, heat, and mass transfer for a compressible viscous fluid.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Fracture Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: This course provides an introduction to fracture mechanics concepts and applications. Topics include the asymptotic solution for stress at a crack tip, energy balance and crack propagation, computing stress intensity factors, fatigue crack growth, fracture of concrete, applications and current topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Topics in Solid Mechanics and Machine Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include intermediate elasticity, plasticity, tribology, probabilistic machine design, robotics, computational dynamics and nonlinear mechanics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ME 716 or ME 802 or CE 802.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vibrations of Continuous Media
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic mathematical and physical descriptions for wave phenomena in continuous media, with emphasis on propagations of mechanical disturbance in linearly elastic solids. Other selected topics in wave dynamics, including acoustics, water waves, nonlinear phenomena, will be discussed depending on students’ interest.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours of rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Engineering Analysis II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continuation of Engineering Analysis I. Emphasis placed on continuous systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ME 760 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Finite Elements
htmlparse.Course.description: The foundations of the finite element method using weighted residuals and variational methods. Element formulation, assembly and solution are covered in detail. Formulation for dynamic and nonlinear problems. Discussion of advanced topics. The student will develop a complete finite element program.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ME 760. Pr. or conc.: ME 802 or CE 802.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mechanics of Composite Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics include classification of composite materials, elasticity theory for anisotropic and in homogeneous materials, basic model for characterization of composite properties, laminated plate theory, textile composites, strength and criteria for composite failure, and fracture modes in composites.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Plasticity
htmlparse.Course.description: Foundations of plasticity. Vectorial and sensorial analysis. Coverage of pressure-dependent and pressure-independent materials. Hyper elasticity-Green elasticity. Deformation theory of plasticity. Flow theory of plasticity. Plastic work rate-equivalent strain. Classical yield criteria. Closed form solution of simple cases. Numerical solutions of more complex cases.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computational Methods in Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics from optimal design, geometric modeling, and multi-physics finite element methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Thermal and Fluid Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include combustion, direct energy conversion, modeling and design of internal combustion engines, non-equilibrium multiphase and multicomponent systems, refrigeration, cryogenics, stability and turbulence.

htmlparse.Course.title: Thermal System Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced study of steady-state and dynamic simulation of thermal systems; thermal systems optimization. Thermodynamic availability and probabilistics in thermal system design.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Automatic Controls
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include analysis and design of nonlinear, adaptive, optimal, digital, or stochastic control systems and the application of advanced control and stability theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Heat Conduction in Solids
htmlparse.Course.description: General differential equation of heat conduction and methods of solution for steady-state and transient heat conduction, periodic heat flow, and internal heat sources.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Solid Mechanics and Machine Design
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include advanced elasticity, plasticity, tribology, probabilistic machine design, robotics, advanced and computational dynamics and nonlinear mechanics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ME 802 or CE 802 or ME 716 or ME 846.

htmlparse.Course.title: Convection Heat Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: Energy and momentum equations in convective heat transfer, laminar and turbulent thermal boundary layers, steady and nonsteady convection problems.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Radiation Heat Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: Basic theories of thermal radiation, shape factors; exact and approximate solutions of integral equations of radiation heat transfer between solid surfaces with absorbing or nonabsorbing medium.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Boiling Heat Transfer
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of boiling heat transfer and thermal hydraulics of two-phase flow; computational methods; design and analysis applications.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research in Mechanical Engineering PhD Level
htmlparse.Course.description: Dissertation Research in Mechanical Engineering PhD Level
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Approval of department head and major professor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Marketing Concepts and Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Presents marketing concepts and marketing research concepts at the graduate level. Emphasis is directed toward managerial strategy development using marketing theories and applied marketing research techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Three hours of economics, three hours of statistics, and MATH 205 or 220.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Marketing Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Application of advanced research methods to help solve marketing problems. Intensive examination of experimental and survey designs, data collection methods, and selected multivariate analysis techniques are covered.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, odd years on sufficient demand

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced International Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to develop the students’ managerial decision making ability in international marketing. The course will focus on the internationalization process of firms, the unique issues in international marketing, and international marketing strategy. The course will integrate short lectures, class discussions, and case analysis to achieve its objectives.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced International Business
htmlparse.Course.description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the nature and scope of fundamental business skills requisite for a career in international business. A unified survey of the international aspects of accounting, finance, management, marketing and related subjects will be made that is useful to a manager in a global business enterprise. Emphasis will be placed on the identification, articulation and implementation of successful global strategies.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ACCTG 810, ECON 815, FINAN 815, MANGT 820, MANGT 810, MANGT 830, MKTG 810, and STAT 702 or enrollment in the MAcc program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Business Intelligence for Strategic Decision Making
htmlparse.Course.description: Business Intelligence is a systematic approach to harnessing customer data and competitive information to drive strategic business decision making. This course deals with how to collect and analyze business data to enhance quality of decision making in modern enterprises. Unlike courses based on data mining (inductive approach), this course will be largely based on regression techniques (deductive approach). The course will be based on lectures, case analysis, and hands on exercises to make students comfortable with powerful computing tools used for data analysis. The cases and exercises will be bundled with data which will be used to apply concepts learned in class to real business situations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Marketing
htmlparse.Course.description: Investigation and discussion of a selected topic in marketing. One of the following five topics will be chosen for intensive study: (1) industrial marketing management, (2) advanced consumer behavior, (3) product policy, (4) financial aspects of marketing management, (5) marketing in the service sector.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MKTG 810 or 6 hours of marketing.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring, even years on sufficient demand

htmlparse.Course.title: Colloquium in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: A graduate colloquium for M. A. candidates in French, German, and Spanish. Variable topics in literary and cultural fields appropriate to study in common by students in these languages.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Modern Languages

htmlparse.Course.title: Environmental Toxicology
