htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced toxicology course concerned with the occurrence, biological effect, detection, and control of foreign chemicals in the environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social and Behavioral Bases of Public Health
htmlparse.Course.description: The role of behavioral, social, psychological, economic, environmental, and social structural factors in both the occurrence of health problems in groups and populations, and in the development of the risk factors that contribute to these problems. Principles of health behavior change and the application of these principles to a variety of health issues as well as an emphasis on how social structural factors impact health are examined to better understand health behavior and health inequities in contemporary society.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate status in public health or kinesiology program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Public Health Field Experience
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised field experience in an international, state, local, or district health agency or other appropriate health agency.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of instructor. FDSCI 840, DMP 840, HN 840, and KIN 840.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be taken more than once, but only 6 hours may be applied toward the MPH degree/program of study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Epidemiology
htmlparse.Course.description: Epidemiologic principles of disease with a focus on measures of disease occurrence, association and impact, determinants of disease diagnostic test evaluation, study design and critical literature evaluation.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: DMP 708 or DMP 754 or equivalent AND STAT 701 or STAT 703 or DMP 830 or equivalent.

htmlparse.Course.title: Techniques of Music Technology
htmlparse.Course.description: Students develop skills of notation, scanning, manipulating, sequencing, and recording necessary to integrate digital technologies into the practice of music making and teaching.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Graduate Study in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Library procedures, bibliography, research methods, and practice in preparing scholarly papers.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: At least 30 hours of music theory and music history.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Required of all graduate students in music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Music Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparison of major theoretical treatises and historical compositional practices; practical application for the modern musician.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Twenty hours of music theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Music History
htmlparse.Course.description: The history of music with emphasis on the correlation of stylistic factors and man’s cultural environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An in-depth study of works by later Romantic and modern composers: techniques and styles in relation to form.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theories of Music Education
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of the history of music teaching in the United States, with emphasis on the relationship of various theories of music, musical perception, and musical cognition to current practices in teaching music at all levels.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Nine hours graduate credit in music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Acquaints students with musical acoustics, perception and cognition of music, music learning, nature and testing of musical aptitude and achievement, affective response to music, musical preference, and the functionality of music.

htmlparse.Course.title: History and Philosophy of Music Education
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of history and philosophy of music education in the U.S.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Music Education
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to historical, descriptive, and experimental research in music education, including a study of techniques for the evaluation of music teaching and learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Music Education
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies of various topics related to the instrumental, choral, and general music programs in elementary and secondary schools.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 805 or graduate standing in music education and consent of the instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated when topics vary.

htmlparse.Course.title: Curriculum Development and Learning Assessment
htmlparse.Course.description: Music 810 focuses on development and implementation of comprehensive music education in K-12 public schools. Attention is given to sequential scaffolding of content within and across developmental levels, measuring student outcomes, and options for dissemination. Among factors studied will be evaluation materials, techniques, and design of reliable and valid measures.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Fall, Spring, Summer, every other year/every 3rd summer.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symposium in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive short-term studies of various topics in music, featuring presentations by nationally known scholars in the field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Improvisation and Composition in Elementary Curriculum
htmlparse.Course.description: Development of pedagogical practices in the areas of improvisation and composition as appropriate for the elementary music classroom.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Summer, Every two years in Spring

htmlparse.Course.title: Workshop in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced studies in specialized interest areas. Students may enroll in different areas simultaneously.

htmlparse.Course.title: Piano Pedagogy I
htmlparse.Course.description: Piano Pedagogy I focuses on how to teach and perform a broad spectrum of intermediate piano repertoire.

htmlparse.Course.title: Piano Pedagogy II
htmlparse.Course.description: Piano Pedagogy II teaches students how to teach and perform selected advances-level piano repertoire by notable composers for the instrument.

htmlparse.Course.title: Supervised Teaching in Piano
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will be observed by the instructor and classmates teaching lessons and provide feedback and commentary in a masterclass format.

htmlparse.Course.title: Half Recital in Piano
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will present a 30 minute recital demonstrating proficiencies as defined by the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Lecture Recital in Piano
htmlparse.Course.description: Students will present a lecture-recital that will be a musically-illustrated presentation on some aspect if piano pedagogy.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods and Materials for the Studio
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of teaching fundamental techniques; selection of teaching materials outlining courses of study. For graduate students in performance curricula. Taught in divisions according to the major. Practical application through supervised studio teaching.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 391 or MUSIC 492. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Medieval and Renaissance Music
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth investigation of a selected area or problem in medieval or Renaissance music. Emphasis on individual research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 601 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Baroque Music
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth investigation of a selected area or problem in Baroque music. Emphasis on individual research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 601 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Classical Music
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth investigation of a selected area or problem in classical music. Emphasis on individual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Romantic Music
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth investigation of a selected area or problem in Romantic music. Emphasis on individual research.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 601 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in 20th-Century Music
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth investigation of a selected area or problem in twentieth-century music. Emphasis on individual research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Opera Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Opera workshop for graduates.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Baccalaureate degree and previous experience at the undergraduate level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Vocal Ensemble
htmlparse.Course.description: Performance and study with established University vocal organization or small ensemble.

htmlparse.Course.title: Instrumental Ensemble
htmlparse.Course.description: Performance and study with an established University instrumental organization or a small ensemble.

htmlparse.Course.title: Collegium Musicum
htmlparse.Course.description: An ensemble devoted primarily to the performance of music written before 1700. Authentic instruments used when possible.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert Choir
htmlparse.Course.description: Concert Choir
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Baccalaureate degree and previous experience at the undergraduate level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symphony Orchestra
htmlparse.Course.description: Symphony Orchestra
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Baccalaureate degree and previous experience at the undergraduate level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Concert Jazz Ensemble
htmlparse.Course.description: Concert Jazz Ensemble
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Baccalaureate degree and previous experience at the undergraduate level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Symphony Band
htmlparse.Course.description: Symphony Band
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Baccalaureate degree and previous experience at the undergraduate level.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate-Level Performance
htmlparse.Course.description: Instruction is offered every semester in voice and each of the following instruments: baritone, bassoon, clarinet, double bass, early winds, flute, french horn, guitar, harpsichord, oboe, organ, percussion, piano, saxophone, trombone, trumpet, tuba, viola, viola da gamba, violin, and violoncello.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Students may enroll in more than one instrument simultaneously and may earn 1 to 4 hours per semester in each instrument.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Composition
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced Composition

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Choral Conducting
htmlparse.Course.description: Exercises and techniques to refine the conducting gesture; techniques of noted choral conductors; and score study.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Instrumental Conducting
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced Instrumental Conducting
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 417 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Diction
htmlparse.Course.description: Concentrated study of Italian, German, and French diction for singing. Materials are related to work in the voice studio, and concurrent registration in MUSIC 855 is required.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: MUSIC 466. May be repeated once.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent directed research leading to master’s report.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: sixteen hours graduate credit in music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Music
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent research that may lead to master’s thesis.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: sixteen hours graduate credit in music.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: An overview course to acquaint non-nuclear engineers with introductory aspects of nuclear engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Junior standing in engineering or physical sciences.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Engineering Materials
htmlparse.Course.description: An investigation of the nuclear properties, metallurgy, the processing of nuclear materials, and the behavior of fuels and components in a radiation environment.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Neutron and Particle Interactions I
htmlparse.Course.description: Neutron interactions and associated cross sections of importance to nuclear reactor theory; fission and its application to reactor design; energetics of multiple neutron scattering and neutron thermalization.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Neutronics
htmlparse.Course.description: Particle transport, theories of diffusion, numerical analysis of diffusion, transient core analysis.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours rec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Problems in Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Specific studies in advanced problems in various phases of nuclear engineering.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and consent of program director.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nuclear Engineering Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: Design of experiments for the TRIGA nuclear reactor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Six hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: A presentation of various specialtopics covering advanced nuclear engineering specialties.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and consent of program director.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and department head.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and program director.

htmlparse.Course.title: Selected Advanced Topics in Nuclear Engineering
htmlparse.Course.description: Current topics of interest in nuclear engineering at an advanced level, such as controlled thermonuclear reactions, numerical analysis, Monte Carlo methods in radiation transport, etc.

htmlparse.Course.title: Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics selected with approval of major professor and program director.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Philosophy and Methodology of Science
htmlparse.Course.description: This course explores philosophical problems concerning sciences and its methods. Topics selected from: conceptual foundations of modern science, qualitative and quantitative confirmation theories, and the nature of theories, laws, and explanation in the sciences.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Physics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of the solution of advanced problems in physics at a level appropriate to the M.S. Degree.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Mathematical Methods of Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Mathematical techniques for the solution of physical problems. Mathematical topics employed include vector and tensor analysis, matrices, group theory, complex variable theory, differential equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, orthogonal functions, special functions, Fourier series, integral transforms, and the calculus of variations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Computational Methods in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Methods of solving physical problems using digital computers including numerical differentiation and integration, error analysis and curve fitting, interpolation, ordinary and partial differential equations, matrix operations, eigenvalues, special functions of mathematical physics. Monte Carlo simulations, and stability of solutions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: CIS 580 or MATH 655, PHYS 801, and a working knowledge of FORTRAN, C or C++.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. each week and a self-paced practicum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Journal Club
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar in current topics in physics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing in physics. May be repeated

htmlparse.Course.title: Graduate Physics Seminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Lecture by faculty and graduate students on topics of current research interest.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing in physics. May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study in a special problem in physics at the graduate level chosen with the advice of a faculty mentor.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantum Mechanics I
htmlparse.Course.description: Fundamental concepts and general formalisms of quantum theory and its applications to bound states, scattering or few state systems. Introduction to quantum applications of operators and state vectors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Dynamics
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. Includes canonical transformations, the Hamilton-Jacobi equation, and elements of classical chaos theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electrodynamics I
htmlparse.Course.description: The interaction of electrical charges with each other and radiation as described by the theory of Maxwell and Lorentz. Topics include Coulomb’s law and vector fields, Ampere’s law and magnetic fields. Faraday’s law and inductive fields, continuity relations and conservation laws.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Atomic Structure and Atomic Interactions
htmlparse.Course.description: The quantum mechanics of atomic structure and spectra: one and two electron atoms, many electron atoms, molecular structure and spectra, atomic collision theory for electron-atom and ion-atom collisions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electron and Ion Impact Phenomena
htmlparse.Course.description: Atomic collision phenomena; experimental techniques in accelerator-based atomic physics; charged particle and photon spectroscopy; elastic, inelastic, and rearrangement collisions; and applications.

htmlparse.Course.title: Nonlinear and Quantum Optics
htmlparse.Course.description: Theory and applications of nonlinear optics: difference and sum frequency generation; ultrashort pulse characterizations; third order effects; Raman scattering; and higher harmonic generation. Fundamentals of quantum optics including field quantization; coherent state; nonclassical light; and optical tests of quantum mechanics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Solid State Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the physics of condensed matter: crystal lattices; lattice dynamics; electron energy bands; fermi surfaces; optical, magnetic, and transport properties of insulators, semiconductors, and metals.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s level research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical studies of selected advanced topics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Comparison of graduate introductory courses in the field of study or permission of the instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Physics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent study of the solution of advanced problems in physics at a level appropriate to the Ph.D. Degree.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: PHYS 800 and consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantum Mechanics II
htmlparse.Course.description: Formalisms and applications of quantum theory, including symmetry in quantum systems, space-time symmetries, the rotation group, many body systems, and an introduction to relativistic quantum mechanics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: Relativistic quantum mechanics; scattering theory; second quantization and the many-body problem. Introduction to quantum electrodymatics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Mathematical Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical studies of selected advanced topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantum Field Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include second quantization, quantization of the free scalar and Dirac fields, quantum electodynamics, quantization of the electromagnetic fild, propagators and Feynman rules, or other contemporary topics in quantum field theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Electrodynamics II
htmlparse.Course.description: The interaction of electrical charges with each other and radiation as described by the theory Maxwell and Lorentz. Topics include the propagation and production of radiation, Lorentz transformations and relativistic dynamics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Atomic Interactions
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical studies of advanced topics in atomic interactions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Mechanics
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of equilibrium states of physical systems involving many particles. Introduces basic concepts of statistical ensembles and presents applications to non-interacting systems for both classical and quantum-mechanical particles. Discusses aspects of interacting classical systems, including a brief introduction to phase transitions and critical phenomena.

htmlparse.Course.title: Solid State Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Quantized lattice vibrations, methods of band structure calculations, effective mass formulations, applications to optical absorption, excitons, magnetism, and superconductivity.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Continuation of PHYS 881.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Topics in Solid State Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Critical studies of selected advanced topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated once for credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Physics
htmlparse.Course.description: Doctoral level research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Population Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical basis for and applications of population genetic principles to populations of humans, domesticated plants and animals, and natural ecosystems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ASI 500, BIOCH 521, MATH 220, and STAT 510 or STAT 703.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hrs. lec./discussion per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Virology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the composition, symptomatology, diagnosis, isolation, replications, molecular biology, genetics, and evolution of plant-infecting viruses.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: ASI 500, BIOCH 521, BIOCH 522, and PLPTH 500.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant-Virus-Vector Interactions
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of modes of virus transmission, important arthropod vectors, plant responses to viruses and insects, and current literature and techniques.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Rec. Pr.: one of the following: BIOCH 521, BIOCH 522, ENTOM 830, ENTOM 875, or PLPTH 500
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Pathogenic Bacteria
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasizes the diversity, mechanisms of pathogenicity, host-parasite relations, control measures, and the principles and methods of identifying plant pathogenic bacteria. The course will meet for half of the semester.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Four hours lec/ week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Pathogenic Fungi
htmlparse.Course.description: The isolation, handling, storage, inoculation, terminology and taxonomy of fungal pathogens of plants. Particular attention will be given to techniques used to study fungi and to the genus and species concepts for important plant pathogenic fungal genera.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hr lec., and one 3-hr lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to R Programming for Biologists
htmlparse.Course.description: An introduction to the R programming environment for biological applications, including an overview of data management, graphics, introductory statistics, phylogenetic analyses, biomathematical modeling, and bioinformatics.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr. One course in introductory statistics or quantitative biology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Lec/Rec. Four half days.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Reports in the field of plant pathology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Plant Molecular Biology
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of plant genes and genome organization, plant gene expression and regulation, and functional analysis of plant genes.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lecture a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Genomic Bioinformatics
htmlparse.Course.description: Tools and methods for computational analysis of genomic and related data.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lec. and two hours lab per week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Plant Pathology for the MS Degree
htmlparse.Course.description: Work is offered in each of the major pathogen groups, genetics of plant-microbe interactions, disease physiology, ecology, and epidemiology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ecology and Epidemiology of Plant Pathogens
htmlparse.Course.description: Experimental and theoretical approaches to the study of plant disease ecology in agricultural and natural systems.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: A course in Statistics, a course in Calculus, and one of the following: PLPTH 500, PLPTH 730, PLPTH 835, PLPTH 840, PLPTH 845, or a course in Ecology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Molecular Plant-Microbe Interactions
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions of molecular and genetic perspectives of resistant and susceptible interactions between plants and bacterial, viral and fungal pathogens. Evaluation of current hypotheses on the nature of disease resistance.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: PLPTH 500, BIOCH 521, and BIOL 500; BIOL 450 or ASI 500; and one of BIOL 800, PLPTH 835, PLPTH 840, or PLPTH 845.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chromosome and Genome Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced course in eukaryotic chromosome biology and genome analysis, especially of higher organisms (crop plants, insects, and mammals) emphasizing basic features of chromosome structure, behavior in mitosis and meiosis, structural aberrations, numerical changes (aneuploidy, polyploidy) evolution, and manipulation for crop improvement and human health.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hrs. lec. a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Chromosome and Genome Laboratory
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced laboratory course in classical and molecular cytogenetic techniques, C-banding, and flourescence in situ hybridization techniques.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and lectures on important areas and contributions in the field of plant pathology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Special Topics in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions and lectures on important areas and contributions in the field of plant pathology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No Credit.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Practicum in Plant Pathology
htmlparse.Course.description: Practical training in teaching courses offered in the Department of Plant Pathology. Most students will serve as Teaching Assistants.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Credit/No-credit

htmlparse.Course.title: Fungal Genetics
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the classical, molecular, and population aspects of fungal genetics in both model and commercially important systems. Topics to be discussed include genetic analysis via mitosis and meiosis, models of recombination, genetic control of fungal development, basic molecular genetics of fungi, and genetic factors affecting fungal population structure and stability.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: BIOCH 521, ASI 500; recommended: BIOL 604 and a 600-level or higher course in genetics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Three hrs. lecture discussion a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Plant Pathology for the PhD Degree
htmlparse.Course.description: Work is offered in each of the major pathogen groups, genetics of plant-microbe interactions, disease physiology, ecology, and epidemiology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar: Scope and Methodology of Political Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of theoretical foundations of political science, and critique of various analytical models in the study of political phenomena; construction and application of research designs and techniques.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in American Government
htmlparse.Course.description: This seminar introduces students to the methods and the theories used to study American politics. Topics to be addressed include the constitution and the American founding, political and electoral processes, institutional structure and function, and public policy. Exams and a seminar paper are required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Security Studies Methodology
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of commonly used research methods in history and political science. Students will investigate quantitative and qualitative humanities and social sciences methodology through selected readings and limited research exercises.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in International Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: The seminar introduces students to the different school of thought in international relations as well as the different methods used to study the subject. It also analyzes middle range theories on subjects such as the causes of interstate conflict, the democratic peace, and foreign policy decision-making. Exams and a seminar paper are required.

htmlparse.Course.title: Foundations of Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the major historical developments and scholarly approaches in the fields of military history, international relations, and security studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: International Security
htmlparse.Course.description: Surveys traditional issues in the study of international security such as the causes of war, the utility of deterrence, coercion, and engagement, international intervention, and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Attention will also be placed on security and conflict in important regional settings, such as East Asia and the Middle East.

htmlparse.Course.title: Terrorism and Transnational Security Issues
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to the general aspects of terrorism and counter-terrorism in order to build transnational security. The course examines these issues in terms of forms, causal factors, goals, and consequences. The main objective is to understand terrorism as part of new international security issues such as failed states, environmental degradation, demographic explosion and poverty, conflict in developing world, post-conflict reconstruction, income distribution, humanitarian emergencies, and globalization.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Design in Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: An exploration of research methods in history and political science culminating in a piece of original research in Security Studies.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar: Political Thought
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of the history of political philosophy as well as contemporary scholarship. Political philosophy as a subdiscipline of political science and its relevance for other subdisciplines as well as for leadership and administration. Class discussion and research training will focus on textual analysis, or exegesis. Course requirements include a major research paper.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar: Public Administration
htmlparse.Course.description: Seminar: Public Administration

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar: Comparative Politics
htmlparse.Course.description: The seminar introduces students to the methods and theories of comparative politics as well as critical analysis of various topics in political science such as institution and institutional change, social movements and state building, regime and development, political parties and electoral processes, policy making and political performance.  Course requirements include two exams, book reviews, research design, and a major research paper.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Comparative Ideologies
htmlparse.Course.description: This seminar provides a graduate level exploration of ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, communism, and fascism. The tension between ideology and philosophy is also examined.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed off-campus employment experience.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Must be taken for a total of 3 hours.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Thesis

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Research Methods I
htmlparse.Course.description: The first of a two course methods sequence in security studies. Surveys the role of theory, hypotheses testing, operationalization and measurement, and research design in social science. Case study and historical methods will be given particular attention. Students will also be provided with a brief introduction to quantitative social science analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Research Methods II
htmlparse.Course.description: The course is the second in the sequence of two method courses in security studies. It emphasized quantitative analysis in political science and covers regression analysis, violation of regression assumptions, and logit models. The course also introduces students to time series, decision theory, and game theory.

htmlparse.Course.title: Readings in Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Directed reading and discussion of a selected topic in international security.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics in Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of a specific issue in one of the fields or areas of international security.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Specific topics will be listed in the class schedule for the semester in which they are offered.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Security Studies
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD research culminating in completed PhD dissertation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Methods in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the nature of statistical inference in psychological research: hypothesis testing and statistical estimation, including a survey of nonparametric methods; consideration of correlational techniques useful with different kinds of psychological data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Physiological Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: An advanced survey of basic technique, theory, and research in the field of behavioral neuroscience, including memory and learning, sensory and motor processes, motivation, and sexual behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial/Organizational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced survey of theory and research pertaining to human behavior in work organizations. Topics include selection, training, and evaluation of employees, job analysis and evaluation, work motivation and satisfaction, organizational structure and development, and working conditions.

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Design in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to techniques of research planning and experimental design, including critical evaluation of selected experiments.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychological Measurement
htmlparse.Course.description: The logic and methodology underlying the construction of psychological measuring instruments from the psychophysical estimate of threshold to the scaling of complex psychological variables.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Methods in Occupational Health Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Reviews research methods used in social science with emphasis on occupational health psychology issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Research Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines research methods and analyses that are used in the applied psychology literature. Focuses on planning and conducting program evaluation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Applied Research Methods II
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides students with a detailed knowledge of human resource management research methods and analyses. Focuses on how to plan and conduct research in industrial/organizational psychology.  Preparation for the M.S. practicum.

htmlparse.Course.title: Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: In-depth study of empirical and theoretical research on basic learning principles and their effects on behavior.

htmlparse.Course.title: Perception
htmlparse.Course.description: Various systematic approaches to perception, with emphasis on experimental and quantitative data. The role of perception in affectivity, motivation, and personality theory is stressed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Cognitive Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Study of contemporary trends and research in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, decision making, and human learning.

htmlparse.Course.title: Psychology of Health
htmlparse.Course.description: Presents psychological research investigating illness and related dysfunction, as well as the promotion and maintenance of health. Provides students with the theoretical, empirical and clinical aspects of health psychology from a number of perspectives, discusses leading research and explores personal and practical implications of this information.

htmlparse.Course.title: Personality Theory and Research
htmlparse.Course.description: A comparative examination of contemporary theories of personality as well as research findings relevant to such theories.

htmlparse.Course.title: Developmental Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Human psychological development throughout the lifespan. Examination of major theoretical systems relevant to Developmental Psychology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Judgmental Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of empirical findings and theoretical approaches to decision making and judgment with emphasis on higher cognitive processes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Pro-Seminar in Social Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion of empirical findings and theoretical approaches to selected problem areas, such as attitude change, personality and social structure, person perception, small group processes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Proseminar in Occupational Health Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of occupational health issues for first or second year graduate students in health and related fields.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Occupational Health Behaviors
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on organizational and individual prevention and coping behaviors relevant to work-related health problems.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Occupational Health Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides supervised practical experience with occupational health problems in various business, manufacturing and government settings. Students will prepare evaluative analyses of their assigned sites.

htmlparse.Course.title: Current Issues in Health Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Introduction to current issues in health psychology research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Health Psych
htmlparse.Course.description: Independent health research designed in conjunction with major faculty advisor plus another faculty member to produce a journal submission and departmental presentation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Psychopharmacology
htmlparse.Course.description: Surveys basic principles of neural communication and pharmacology, the etiology and bio-behavioral bases of substance abuse, and chemical treatment of psychiatric disorders.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Applied Cognitive Science
htmlparse.Course.description: Multidisciplinary survey and discussion of empirical research and theoretical approaches to cognitive science topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised practical experience in applied psychology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Teaching Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Supervised experience regularly teaching a college psychology course.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing in Department of Psychology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Psychology: Personnel Training
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the training of personnel in an organization. Topics include: determination of an organization’s training needs, selection and motivation of trainees, design and evaluation of training programs, and examination of several specific strategies for accomplishing the training function.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Psychology: Work Motivation
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of empirical findings and theoretical approaches to understanding the relationship between worker motivation and job outcomes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Psychology: Leadership
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current leadership theories, research, and practice in the work setting, focusing on situational approaches to leadership, leadership styles, and interactions between personal characteristics and organizational factors.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Psychology: Personnel Selection
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of theoretical and practical issues in staffing industrial organizations, including recruitment, test validation, and other equal employment opportunity issues (test fairness, adverse impact, etc.).

htmlparse.Course.title: Organizational Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: An examination of the individual’s role in industrial organizations and the effects of organizational variables on the individual worker. Topics include organizational communication, employee socialization, psychological climates of organizations, psychological stress in organizations, group processes and employee performance, and organizational change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Industrial Psychology: Performance Appraisal
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of data sources, rating procedures, psychometric criteria for evaluating performance appraisal systems, and models/theories of the performance evaluation process.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Research in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Research in Psychology

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Physiological Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in physiological psychology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Sensory Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in sensory psychology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Personality
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of current problems of theoretical and empirical interest in the field of personality.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Experimental Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of a problem of current interest based on the class’s study of the pertinent original literature.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: PSYCH 810 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Psychological Measurement
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive discussion of a problem of current interest, based on the class’s study of the pertinent original literature.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Cognitive Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in the study of human thinking and cognition.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Mathematical Models of Behavior
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in mathematical psychology, and applications of mathematical models to behavior.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Social Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Emphasis on discussion of advanced topics of current interest in social psychology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Industrial Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive examination of current empirical and theoretical issues in industrial and organizational psychology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Professional Problems
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive study and discussion of current professional problems in psychology.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Internship in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: Internship in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Consent of the supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Research in Psychology
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Research in Psychology

htmlparse.Course.title: Park and Facilities Maintenance
htmlparse.Course.description: Planning, execution, budgeting and supervision of maintenance operations for public and private recreation agencies.
htmlparse.Course.notes: Two hours lab a week.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introductory Proseminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussions designed to introduce entering graduate students to the discipline of sociology as a profession and to the members of the sociology graduate faculty. Required during the first fall semester on campus.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Admission to the graduate program in sociology.

htmlparse.Course.title: Teaching Proseminar
htmlparse.Course.description: Designed to aid new graduate teaching assistants. Includes such topics as planning a sociology course, handling sensitive issues, leading discussions in large and small classes, use of audiovisuals, special projects, classroom deportment, designing and grading examinations. Required of first-semester GTAs.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Interest in teaching sociology and enrollment in the sociology graduate program.

htmlparse.Course.title: Classical Social Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive seminar in classical sociological theory. Examines the theoretical frameworks and methodologies of Karl Marx, Max Weber, and Emile Durkheim, along with selections from the works of other major classical theorists. Analysis of primary texts will be emphasized.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Comparative analysis of contemporary schools of sociological thought showing their development, current status, and possible future trends. Emphasis on structural functionalism, Marxism and neo-Marxism, symbolic interactionism, phenomenology and ethnomethodology, and exchange theory. A working knowledge of classical sociological theory is assumed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Introduction to Methods of Social Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides an introduction to the methods and techniques utilized in sociological research. Includes such topics as basic collecting and analyzing sociological data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Intermediate Methods of Social Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Current sociological research techniques, strategies of research design, construction of research instruments, logic of sociological inquiry, conceptualization, problem formation, and preparation of research proposals.

htmlparse.Course.title: Qualitative Methodology
htmlparse.Course.description: Collection, analysis, and presentation of sociological data using such methods as participant observation, ethnomethodology, community analysis, documentary research and historiography, case study, and life history. Emphasis upon formulation of problems and the execution of research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Quantitative Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides instruction for advanced techniques in the quantitative analysis of sociological data. Includes regression analysis and estimation of models with categorical data. A working knowledge of basic statistical concepts is assumed.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Demography
htmlparse.Course.description: The study of human population, including the social, economic, political, ecological, and cultural determinants and consequences of changes in fertility, mortality, and migration.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Agriculture
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides a survey of the subfield of sociology of agriculture, including an examination of its roots, growth and current theoretical and substantive directions. Explores the linkages between agriculture, commodity systems, food and the environment.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Community
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey of theoretical perspectives and current research on the sociology of community in the U.S. and other countries. Examples of issues covered include community growth and decline, social inequality, community power and politics, social implications of community economic change, urbanization, and the global context of local change.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender Differentiation and Inequality
htmlparse.Course.description: Offers an analysis of the social construction and reproduction of gender identities. Focuses on current feminist theory and research on the links between gender identities and gender inequality.

htmlparse.Course.title: Environment and Society
htmlparse.Course.description: The interrelationships among population, technology, environment, and social organization. An examination of the origins and development of human ecology in sociology, and recent attempts to redefine the area. Special emphasis on current theoretical and research efforts focusing on the history and uses of ecological ideas.

htmlparse.Course.title: Comparative Social Systems
htmlparse.Course.description: Compares social systems in different regions of the world. Examines models of comparative and historical sociology. Provides students with a background for conducting and evaluating comparative research. Treats such issues as socioeconomic development, group relations, and age and sex roles from a cross-cultural perspective.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Stratification
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of major sociological theories and research on inequality in modern societies. Examines the distribution of wealth, status, political power, and other valued resources; the effects of class, race, gender, and other modes of social differentiation; social mobility and the reproduction of inequality.

htmlparse.Course.title: Technology and Social Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides a survey of theoretical perspectives and current research on the role of technology in social development.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Control
htmlparse.Course.description: Analysis of social and institution processes and mechanisms of social control: socialization, role allocation, systems of social sanctioning, growth and dynamics of institutional systems of social control emphasizing its character at the institutional and societal level of analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of the processes and mechanisms of societal change. Attention centers on current theoretical, methodological, and research issues.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Sociology of Developing Societies
htmlparse.Course.description: A comparative introduction to the state, power and political processes in developing nations. Topics include theories of the state and state reformation, the relationship between the state and civil society, state violence, authoritarian regimes, processes of formal democratization, effects of globalization, impact of socio-economic inequality on governance.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Deviance
htmlparse.Course.description: A critical examination of the nature, types, and societal reactions to deviant behavior. Special emphasis will be given to the process of stigmatization, the social construction of deviance as a social problem, and the effect of inequalities such as race, gender, class, and sexuality on the process of creating and applying deviant labels to individuals and groups.

htmlparse.Course.title: Criminological Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Focuses on traditional and contemporary criminological theories with secondary emphasis on presentation of empirical studies employing the theories under study. Theoretical integration will be stressed.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Twelve hours of social science.

htmlparse.Course.title: Social Movements
htmlparse.Course.description: Examines sociological theories about social movements and their organizational structures and strategies, with an analysis of historical and contemporary nationalist, socialist, labor, womenÆs, civil rights, and environmental movements in the United States and around the world.

htmlparse.Course.title: Practicum in Social Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Provides professional field experience for students enrolled in the Master’s in Social Analysis program in an approved public agency, organization, or private firm, under direction of a faculty member. Requires participation in a quarterly seminar.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: One semester in the MSA program and SOCIO 822.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Thesis Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Research Problems in Sociology
htmlparse.Course.description: Individual study and research for students admitted to doctoral standing in the Graduate School.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Sociological Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in sociological theory. May be repeated with consent of supervisory committee.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods of Social Policy Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of principles, techniques, and design of retrospective and prospective social policy research.

htmlparse.Course.title: Specialized Approaches to Sociological Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Intensive examination of methodological approaches developed for analysis of sociological problems. The approaches to be examined will depend on faculty and student interests. Likely foci include estimation procedures for structural equation models, advanced techniques for quantitative analysis of categorical data, techniques for social network analysis and methods for comparative and historical analysis.
htmlparse.Course.semesters: Spring, odd years on sufficient demand

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Demographic Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Demographic processes such as fertility, mortality, and migration, with emphasis on measurements, methods, and analytical techniques. Includes the construction of life tables and population estimates and projections.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Comparative Community Organization
htmlparse.Course.description: Recent developments in theory and research on processes affecting community organization. Topics will vary. Possible emphases include world urbanization, community linkages to regional and global systems, technology and local economic development, rural community development, and community-based collective action.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender & Society
htmlparse.Course.description: Exploration of feminist theorizing of gender relations in constructing and maintaining social institutions. Objective is to acquaint students with the strengths and weaknesses of current theories of gender, and to analyze social structures as both constituting and constitutive of gender relations at the macro/meso level of society.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Rural Development
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of selected topics and issues in the social organization of rural areas, both international and in the U.S.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: SOCIO 851 or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Demography
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of selected topical areas in demography such as fertility and family planning, migration, population and development, and regional demography.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Work and Organizations
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics and issues in the social structure of industries, firms, and labor processes.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in the Sociology of Aging
htmlparse.Course.description: Consideration of selected topics and issues in the sociology of aging such as retirement and institutional change, societal reactions to aging, population structure and socioeconomic consequences of aging populations, the social organization of leisure, the impact on social organization of services for older people, the structural and organizational consequences of widowhood, age-grading and stratification in aging populations, analysis of the impact on community structure, and organization of special institutions for older people.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Social Interaction
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of current theoretical, methodological, and research issues and topics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Sociology of Global Social Change
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of contemporary global social change around the world. Uses historical and comparative sociological methods to study social causes and consequences of global processes, structures, and movements.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: SOCIO 851, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Political Sociology of Advanced Societies
htmlparse.Course.description: Survey of major theories and research in the political sociology of industrial societies. Examines prominent theories of power and the state; inequality of political representation; social movements and political change; ideology and legitimation; and policy formation under pressures of globalization.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: SOCIO 850, or consent of instructor.

htmlparse.Course.title: Methods Seminar in Criminology/Deviance
htmlparse.Course.description: Examination of principles, techniques, and design of research in criminology, deviance, and corrections.

htmlparse.Course.title: Topics Seminar in Criminology/Deviance
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topical areas in criminology/deviance such as gender, race and/or class and crime; social control; domestic violence; lethal violence; victimology; issues in corrections; and issues in law.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: SOCIO 850 or consent of instructor.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May repeat as topic varies.

htmlparse.Course.title: PhD Dissertation Research
htmlparse.Course.description: PhD Dissertation Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Women’s Perspectives on Peace and War
htmlparse.Course.description: This course will consider the issue of the participation of women in opposition to ware and weapons of war and advocacy for peaceful resolution of conflict. Readings and discussions will focus on four areas: (1) historical and contemporary women’s peace movements; (2) the influence of a male-dominated societal structure on the use of violence and militarism as a means of resolving conlict; (3) the question of whether or not women are naturally more included to be peaceful; and (4) the activities, thoughts, and works of individual women in their quest for peace, within themselves, and in the world.
htmlparse.Course.notes: UGE Course

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: A written report of either research or problem work on a topic in the major field.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Modern Languages
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Modern Languages

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Probability and Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Discussion and lectures on topics in probability and statistics; one seminar talk by each student registered for credit.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Graduate standing and at least two graduate courses in statistics.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Life-Data Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: A study of models and inferential procedures important to life-data analysis. Comparison of estimators (MLE, BLUE, etc.). Pivotal quantities. Design and regression models for non-normal distributions. Analysis of censored data.

htmlparse.Course.title: Numerical Methods of Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Topics may include efficient programming echniques, generating data from non-standard distributions, simulation techniques, resampling methods, optimization techniques, smoothing, and imputation.

htmlparse.Course.title: Probability for Statistical Inference
htmlparse.Course.description: Probability spaces and random elements, distributions, generating and characteristic functions, conditional expectation, convergence modes and stochastic orders, continuous mapping theorems, central limit theory and accuracy, laws of large numbers, asymptotic expansions for approximating functions of random variables and distributions.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 770 &771, or equivalent; MATH 633 or equivalent, or concurrent enrollment in MATH 633.

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Inference
htmlparse.Course.description: Distributions (commonly used univariate and multivariate distributions, including exponential families of distributions and properties), order statistics and distributional properties, (asymptotic) unbiased estimation and the information inequality, likelihood inference for parametric statistical models (including the multi-parameter case, regular and non-regular cases), confidence sets, functional parameters and statistical functional, density estimation and nonparametric function estimation, permutation methods.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 842; MATH 634 or equivalent, or concurrent enrollment in MATH 634.

htmlparse.Course.title: Stochastic Processes
htmlparse.Course.description: Normal processes and covariance stationary processes; Poisson processes; renewal counting processes; Markov chains; Brownian motion; applications to science and engineering.

htmlparse.Course.title: Linear Models I
htmlparse.Course.description: Subspaces, projections, and generalized inverses; multivariate normal distribution, distribution of quadratic forms; optimal estimation and hypothesis testing procedures for the general linear model; application to regression models, correlation model.

htmlparse.Course.title: Linear Models II
htmlparse.Course.description: Continued application of optimal inference procedures for the general linear model to multifactor analysis of variance, experimental design models, analysis of covariance, split-plot models, repeated measures models, mixed models, and variance component models; multiple comparison procedures.

htmlparse.Course.title: Analysis of Messy Data
htmlparse.Course.description: Design structures; treatment structures; equal and unequal variances; multiple comparisons; unequal subclass numbers; missing cells; interpretation of interaction; variance components; mixed models; split-plot and repeated measures; analysis of covariance; cross-over designs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Time Series Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: Autocorrelation function; spectral density; autoregressive integrated moving average processes; seasonal time series; transfer function model; intervention analysis; regression model with time series error.

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Report
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Report

htmlparse.Course.title: Master’s Thesis Research
htmlparse.Course.description: Master’s Thesis Research

htmlparse.Course.title: Statistical Methods for Spatial Data
htmlparse.Course.description: Statistical models and methods for analyzing data that are collected at different spatial locations, and perhaps at different times. Spatial prediction and Kriging for continuous spatial data, along with variogram models and estimation for spatial correlation. Spectral analysis for spatial data. Spatial models for lattice data and inference for lattice models. Models and model fitting for spatial point patterns. Classical approaches as well as newly developed methodological and computational research in spatial statistics will be covered with computer-aided applications.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 771, plus one introductory course in statistical computing (e.g. STAT 726 or equivalent background).

htmlparse.Course.title: Resampling Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Application, theory, and computational aspects of resampling methods. Topics include parametric and nonparametric bootstrap methods, the jackknife, and randomization/permutation methods; techniques for estimation, bias correction, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing; applications to linear and nonlinear models; different test statistatics for randomization inferences such as mean differences, rank based statistics, t-statistics, and moderated t-statistics for high-dimensional settings; implementation of methods using statistical software; simulation designs for comparing methods.

htmlparse.Course.title: High-Dimensional Data and Statistical Learning
htmlparse.Course.description: Statistical methods for the analysis of large scale data. Data mining, supervised and unsupervised statistical learning techniques for prediction and pattern recognition. Methods for model selection, multiple testing control, and estimation in high-dimensions. Applications in various fields, including the sciences and engineering using computer software.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 713 and 771, plus one introductory course in statistical computing (e.g. STAT 726 or equivalent background).

htmlparse.Course.title: Bayesian Statistical Inference
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles of Bayesian inference. Methods of Bayesian data analysis with applications in the sciences. Hierarchical and non-hierarchical models, including linear and generalized linear models. Model checking, Model selection, Model comparison. Bayesian computation including Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms. Applications in the sciences utilizing computer software.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 720 and 771, plus one introductory course in statistical computing (e.g. STAT 725 or 726 or equivalent background).

htmlparse.Course.title: Experimental Design Theory
htmlparse.Course.description: Incomplete block designs; theory of the construction and analysis of experimental designs.

htmlparse.Course.title: Theory of Multivariate Analysis
htmlparse.Course.description: The multivariate normal distribution, the Wishart distribution, Jacobians of vector and matrix transformations, Hotelling’s T2statistic, the union-intersection principle, tests on mean vectors and covariance matrices, Box’s approximations to critical points, the multivariate general linear model, discriminant analysis, and principal component analysis.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Statistical Methods
htmlparse.Course.description: Generalized linear models and generalized mixed models. Statistical models based on the exponential family of distributions. Applications to non-normal and discrete data, including binary, Poisson and gamma regression, and log-linear models. Topics include likelihood-based estimation and testing, model-fitting, residual analyses, over-dispersed models, quasi-likelihood, large sample properties, and the use of computer packages. Also, methods for longitudinal repeated measures data that will include inference for continuous and discrete data. Inferential objectives include prediction of response and estimation of correlation/covariance structures. Nonparametric and semiparametric methods covered as time permits.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: STAT 861, plus one introductory course in statistical computing (e.g. STAT 725 or 726 or equivalent background).

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Statistical Inference
htmlparse.Course.description:
Foundations and methods of modern statistical inference including asymptotic theory in parametric models (including local asymptotic normality and contiguity), efficiency of estimators and tests, Bayes procedures, rank, sign and permutation statistics, U-,
M-, L-, R-estimates, chi-square tests, empirical processes and the functional delta method, quantiles and order statistics, inference for nonparametric and semi-parametric models.

htmlparse.Course.title: Problems in Statistical Consulting
htmlparse.Course.description: Principles and practices of statistical consulting. Supervised experience in consultation and consequent research concerning applied statistics and probability associated with on-campus investigations.

htmlparse.Course.title: Advanced Studies in Probability and Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Theoretical studies of advanced topics in probability, decision theory, Markov processes, experimental design, stochastic processes, or advanced topics.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated.

htmlparse.Course.title: Research in Statistics
htmlparse.Course.description: Research in Statistics

htmlparse.Course.title: Workshop in Playwriting
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced writing of drama.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: THTRE 762 (or ENGL 762) or proof of equiv. Proficiency.

htmlparse.Course.title: Ethics and Professionalism in Drama Therapy
htmlparse.Course.description: The application of ethical principles involved in the practice of drama therapy in a variety of educational and therapeutic settings.

htmlparse.Course.title: Greek and Roman Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in the drama and stagecraft of the Greek and Roman period.

htmlparse.Course.title: Medieval and Baroque Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in the drama and stagecraft of the Medieval and Baroque periods.

htmlparse.Course.title: Contemporary Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in drama and stagecraft since 1968.

htmlparse.Course.title: Seminar in Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Selected topics in theatre research.
htmlparse.Course.notes: May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

htmlparse.Course.title: History of the Physical Stage
htmlparse.Course.description: A survey course in the emergence and development of the theatre building as a distinct architectural form, with particular emphasis on the effect of the physical environment on the play.

htmlparse.Course.title: Modern Theatre
htmlparse.Course.description: Studies in the drama and stagecraft of Europe and America in the period from 1870 to the present.

htmlparse.Course.title: Creative Project
htmlparse.Course.description: Major creative project undertaken to demonstrate competence in a specific area of theatre or drama therapy as required for the Master’s Degree.
htmlparse.Course.requisites: Pr.: Sixteen hours of graduate credit in theatre.

htmlparse.Course.title: Gender: An Interdisciplinary Overview
htmlparse.Course.description: Advanced overview of feminist scholarship, including theories and methods. Examines the social construction of gender inequality and feminist movements for equity. The historical development of feminist theory, contemporary debates, and multicultural and global feminism will be studied. Required for Graduate Certificate in Women’s Studies.
